list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

hom.sense: The eighth letter of the alphabet: called daAlN. It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed niTaEiy-ap [pronounced by pressing the tip of the tongue against the upper gums and suddenly withdrawing it], like T and t. (TA.) It is substituted, agreeably with general usage, for the t of the form AifotaEala and its variations, when the first radical letter is z, as in AizodaAda [for AizotaAda]; or c, as in Aid-akara [for Aicodakara, originally Aicotakara]; or d, as in Aid-araOa [for AidodaraOa, originally AidotaraOa]: and sometimes after j, as in AijodamaEuwA, a dial. var. of AijotamaEuwA: also, sometimes, for the pronominal affix t after d, as in jalad-u for jaladotu; and after z, as in juzodu for juzotu: it is also substituted for the t of tawolajN, contr. to analogy: and it occurs substituted for T, contr. to general usage, as in maradaI for maraTaI. (MF.)
[As a numeral, it denotes Four.]

R. Q. 1. daOodaOa, inf. n. daOodaOapN and diYodaMCN, He (a camel, Ṣ) ran (EadaA) most vehemently, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) going a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN [q. v.]: (TA:) or hastened, or sped, and ran, or rose in his running; syn. OasoraEa waOaHoDara: (Ḳ:) accord. to AA, daOodaMCN↓ is [a subst., or quasi-inf. n., signifying] a quick pace or manner of going: and [the inf. n.] daOodaOapN is syn. with UiHoDaArN: and in the Nawádir [app. of Aboo-ʼAmr EshSheybánee] it is said that dawodaOa (inf. n. dawodaOapN) and tawodaOa (inf. n. tawodaOapN) and kawodaOa (inf. n. kawodaOapN) are syn. with EadaA; and that daOodaOapN and diYodaMCN signify a camel's proceeding with short steps, at a rate quicker than that of the pace termed HafadN [q. v.]: accord. to the Kf, these two words signify the going a pace quicker than that termed xababN [q. v.], not so quick as that termed rabaEapN [q. v.]. (TA.) You say, daOodaOati Ald-aAb-apu The beast ran a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN. (M.) And daOodaOa fiI Uivorihi He followed him, having him near before him. (M,* Ḳ,* TA.) And hence, daOodaOa minohu He ran (OaHoDara) to escape from him, being followed by him, and being near before him; as also tadaOodaOa↓. (M.)
He put a thing in motion. (M, Ḳ.)
And, contr., He rendered a thing, still, or motionless. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tadaOodaOa: see above.
Also It (a stone, TA) rolled; or rolled along or down: (Ḳ, TA:) it (anything) rolled, or rolled along or down, before one, (M, TA,) and went away: IAth says that it may be from tadahodaha. (TA.)
It became, or was put, in motion. (TA.)
And, contr., It became, or was rendered, still, or motionless. (TA.)
daOodaON: see daOodaMCN, in three places.

hom.sense: daOodaOapN inf. n. of R. Q. 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Also The hasty replying of a foolish, or stupid, person. (T, TA.)
The sound of the falling (T, M, Ḳ) of stones in a torrent, (T,) or of a stone upon the bed of a torrent: (M, Ḳ:) or the falling of stones in the bed of a torrent. (Lth, IḲṭṭ, O.)
And The sound of one's moving, or putting in motion, [or rocking,] a child in the cradle (Ḳ, TA) in order that it may sleep. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

daOodaMCN (AA, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and diYodaMCN↓ (AA, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and duWoduwoCN↓, (M, Ḳ,) all with medd, (TA,) The last (of the days, T) of the [lunar] month; (AA, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also daOodaOu↓: (M:) or the day of doubt; yawomu AlX-ak-i [generally meaning the day of which one doubts whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán; but here app. relating to any month]: (TA:) or daOodaON↓ signifies the day, (M,) or night, (TA,) of which one doubts whether it be the last of one month or the first of the next month: (M, TA:) so says Kr: (M:) or the first word and the second (M, Ḳ) and the third (Ḳ) signify the twenty-fifth, and the twenty-sixth, and the twentyseventh, night: (M, Ḳ:) or the twenty-eighth night, and the twenty-ninth: or each of these two is called daOodOapN↓; and the two together, Ald-aMdiYu: (Th, M:) or [each of] three nights of the end of the month; (Ḳ, TA;) which are [also] called layaAliI AlmuHaAqi: (TA:) pl. daMdiYu, (M, Ḳ,) and, by poetic license, daMdK: (M:) or the daMdiY are three nights of the latter part of the month, before those called lyAlI AlmHAq: (T, Ṣ:) thus says AʼObeyd; and IAạr says the like: or they are the three nights that are after the mHAq; and are so called because the moon hastens therein to become invisible; from the phrase daOodaOapu AlbaEiyri: Aṣ says that three of the nights of the month are called the mHAq; and three, the dMdY; and these latter are the last; and AHeyth says the like. (T.) Ald-iYodaMCu↓ signifies also The last part of the night. (Kr, M.) And layolapN daOodaON↓ and daOodaOapN↓ and daOodaMCN and daOodaMCapN↓, (M, Ḳ, TA,) of which the first two are the most common, mean A dark night: (TA:) or a very dark night: (M, Ḳ:) because of the concealment of the moon therein. (TA.)
See also R. Q. 1.

entry.sense: layolapN daOodaMCapN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.
duWoduwoCN: see daOodaMCN.
diYodaMCN: see daOodaMCN, in two places.

1. daOaba, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _a {yadoOabu}, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. daOobN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and daOabN (T, M, A, Ḳ) and duWuwbN, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself; (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and wearied himself, or became wearied; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) in his work, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or in a thing, (T,) and in a journey or journeying; (T, A;) in which last case, daOabato is said of a she-camel, (T,) or of a daAb-ap [or horse or the like]: (A:) or he held on, or continued, (M, and Bḍ in viii. 54,) in his work, and his way. (Bḍ ibid.) See also 4. Hence, All-ayolu waAln-ahaAru yadoOabaAni fiI QEotiqaAbihimaA ‡ [The night and the day hold on their course in their alternating]. (A.)
daOobN (Ḳ) and duWuwbN (TA) also signify The act of driving vehemently; and i. q. TarodN [the act of driving away, hunting,, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)

4. AdOb, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. UidoMbN, (T,) He made another, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) his hired man, and his beast, (A,) to strive, labour, toil, or exert himself; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) he fatigued, or wearied, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) another, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) his hired man, (A,) and his beast: (T, A:) or he made another, and anything, to hold on, of continue: and AdObhu also signifies OaHowajapu UilaI Ald-uWuwbi [he made him to be in need of striving,, &c.; or of holding on, or continuing]: (M:) and OadabuwA is used by a rájiz, but not necessarily by poetic license, for OadoOabuwA. (IAạr, M.)

[Hence,] AdOb Als-ayora [He pursued the journey laboriously, or with energy; or he held on, or continued, the journey]: (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ, in art. msd; and M and L in art. sOd:) and [in like manner] you say, daOabonaA↓ sayoranaA [for fiI sayorinaA, or perhaps fI is omitted by inadvertence]. (TA in art. nHb.)

daOobN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and daOabN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) [both originally inf. ns. of 1: and hence,] ‡ A custom, manner, habit, or wont: (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) an affair, a business, or a concern: (Zj, T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and a case, state, or condition: (Zj,* T,* Ṣ,* M, A,* Ḳ:*) and a deed, or work. (A.) You say, hecaA daOobuka ‡ This is [thy custom,, &c.:] thy affair, business, or concern: or thy case, state, or condition: and thy deed, or work. (A.) Zj says that kadaOobi Mli firoEawona [in the Ḳur iii. 9, &c.] means, accord. to the lexicologists, † Like the case of the people of Pharaoh: but in his opinion, like the striving, labouring, or toiling, of the people of Pharaoh in their unbelief, and their leaguing together and aiding one another against Moses. (T.)
daOaba: see the next preceding paragraph
daYibN: see daAYibN.
rajulN daWuwbN EalaI XaIoCK [A man who strives, labours, toils, or exerts himself, and wearies himself, or who holds on, or continues, with energy, to do a thing]. (M.)

daAYibN (TA, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) and daYibN↓ (TA, and so in two copies of the Ṣ,) Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, and wearying himself, in his work [&c.: or holding on, or continuing, therein: see the verb]. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence,] layolapN daAYibapN [A hard, fatiguing, or continuous, night-journey]. (M and Ḳ in art. mrs.)
And Ald-aAYibaAni ‡ The night and the day; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) which [are so called because they] hold on their course (yadoOabaAni) in their alternating. (TA.)

1. daOala, aor. _a {yadoOalu}, inf. n. daOolN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and daOalN (Ḳ [perhaps a mistake for the next, which is well known but not mentioned in the Ḳ, but see caOala,]) and daOalaAnN (Ṣ, M) and daOalaI, (M, Ḳ,) He walked, or went, in a weak manner, (M, Ḳ,) and with haste: (M:) or he ran with short steps: (M, Ḳ:) or he walked, or went, in a brisk, or sprightly, manner: (Ḳ:) or he walked, or went, as though labouring in his gait, by reason of briskness, or sprightliness: (M:) [or he went along by little and little, stealthily, lest he should make a sound to be heard: for] daOolN is syn. with xatolN: or, accord. to AZ, it signifies the walking, or going, in a manner resembling that which is termed xatolN; and in the manner of him who is heavily burdened, or overburdened: and Aṣ, in describing the manner in which horses go, explains daOalaAnN as signifying the walking, or going, with short steps, and in an unusual manner, as though heavily burdened, or overburdened. (Ṣ.) [See also caOala.]

[Hence, app.,] daOala lahu, aor. as above, inf. n. daOolN and daOalaAnN, He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; syn. xatalahu: (M, Ḳ:) [and daAOalahu↓ signifies the same: or he practised with him mutual deceit, delusion,, &c.: for] mudaAOalapN is syn. with muxaAtalapN; and sometimes it is with a quick pace: (AA, T, Ḳ:) you say, daOalotu lahu and daAOalotuhu: (AA, T, TA:) and Alc-iYobu badoOalu lilogazaAli liyaOokulahu i. e. yaxotuluhu [The wolf deceives,, &c., the gazelle, or young gazelle, that he may eat him]. (AZ, T, TA.)
3: see the last sentence of the paragraph above {1}.
daOolN: see the next paragraph, in four places.
duWulN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

duYilN, and sometimes it is pronounced duWulN↓, The jackal; as also daOalaAnN↓ and daOolN↓: and the wolf: and a certain small animal resembling what is called Aibonu EirosK [the weasel]: (Ḳ accord. to the TA: [accord. to the CK, and app. most MṢ. copies of the Ḳ, daOolN↓ has the last two significations, and not the first signification: but this is inconsistent with what follows the last signification in the Ḳ, as it would require us to read that Ald-aOolu, instead of Ald-uYilu, which is well known as the correct form, is the name of the father of a certain tribe:]) duYilN has the last of these significations: (T, Ṣ:) or it signifies a certain small animal resembling the fox; and this is well known: and accord. to Kr. duWulN↓ signifies a certain small animal; but this is not known: and accord. to him also, daOalaAnN↓, with fet-ḥ to the C, signifies the wolf; (M;) as also caOalaAnN; (TA;) or so daOolaAnN↓ and caOolaAnN; and also the jackal. (Lth in art. cOl.) duYilN is the only instance of the measure fuEilN (Ṣ, Ḳ) known to Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà, (Ṣ,) i. e. Th: (TA:) but there are several other instances: (MF, TA:) [one of these is ruYimN, or Alr-uYimu.]
daOolaAnN and daOalaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

duWoluwlN A calamity, or misfortune: (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) pl. daMliylu. (Ṣ.) And Confusion. (Ḳ.) You say, waqaEa Alqawomu fiI duWoluwlK The people, or party, fell into confusion in respect of their case or affairs. (Ṣ.)

daWuwlN [That runs in the manner termed daOalaAnN, inf. n. of 1,] is [an epithet] from AldAlAn [i. e. Ald-aOalaAnu], which signifies a kind of running, as also daOAlyn↓ and dAAlyl↓ [i. e. daMliynu and daMlylu, pls. of daOalaAnN; the latter irreg., like caMliylu pl. of daOalaAnN, q. v.]. (Ḥam p. 458.) [See also caWuwlN.]
daMliylu and daMliynu: see what next precedes.
1. daOaA, first pers. daOawotu, aor. yadoOaI, inf. n. daOowN: see 1 in the next art.

1. daOaI, and daOaA, aor. yadoOaI, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. daOoIN, (T, M,) of the former verb, (M,) and daOowN, (T, Ḳ,) of the latter verb, (Ḳ,) said of a wolf, (M, Ḳ,) [and of a man, as shown below,] He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him. (T, M, Ḳ.) You say, daOayotu lahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. OadoOaIo lahu, inf. n. daOoIN, I deceived, deluded,, &c., it, namely, a thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or him, namely, a man; (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ;) and so daOawotu lahu. (Ṣ, M.) And Alc-iYobu yadoOaI lilogazaAli The wolf deceives, deludes,, &c., the gazelle, or the young gazelle: (Ṣ, M:) or walks, or goes, in the manner of him who deceives, deludes,, &c., to the gazelle, or the young gazelle. (T.)

daOoIN and diYiI-N↓ and duYiI-N↓, (M, Ḳ,) the last said by IB, on the authority of Aṣ, to be pl. of [the n. un.] daOoyapN↓, of the measure fuEuwlN, [originally duWuwIN,] (TA,) The vertebræ of the kaAhil [or withers (app. of a camel)] and of the back: or the cartilages of the breast: or the ribs thereof, where it meets the side: (M, Ḳ:) or Ald-aOayaAtu↓ signifies the ribs of [i. e. within] the shoulderblade, three on either side; (IAạr, M, Ḳ;) sing. daOoyapN↓: (M:) or daOoyapN↓, (T,) or daOoIN, (Ṣ,) signifies the part of the camel against which lies the [piece of wood called] Zalifap of the saddle, and which is [often] galled thereby: (T, Ṣ:) or daOoIN is the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of daOoyapN↓, and signifies the vertebræ of the withers, in the part between the two shoulder-blades, of the camel, peculiarly; (Lth, T;) and the pl. [of daOoyapN] is daOayaAtN↓: (Lth, T, Ṣ:) or the dOyAt are the vertebræ of the neck: or the vertebræ of the spine: (AO, T:) or the two ribs next to the waAhinataAni are called the daOoyataAni: AZ says that the Arabs knew not the term dOyAt in relation to the neck, but they knew it in relation to the ribs, as signifying six [ribs] next to the stabbing-place of the camel, three on either side; and this is correct: (T:) [and it is said in the L, in art. jnH, that daOoIN signifies the ribs of the back, of a man, which are called the jawaAniH, pl. of jaAniHapN, six in number, three on the right and three on the left:] the pl. of daOoIN [or rather the quasi-pl. n.] is daYiI-N, like as DaYiynN is of DaOonN, and maEiyzN of maEozN: (Ṣ:) and, accord. to IB, duYiI-N is a pl. of daOoyapN↓, as mentioned above, meaning the vertebræ of the neck. (TA.)

hom.sense: daOoyapN; and its pls. daOayaAtN and duYiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph, in seven places.
Hence, (Ṣ,) Aibonu daOoyapa The guraAb [or crow]: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so called because it alights upon, and pecks, the dOyp of the camel that has galls, or sores. (M.)
Also The part, of a bow, upon which the arrow lies: there are two parts of which each is thus called, next to the part of the stave that is held by the hand, above and below. (M.)

daAyapN [without C, from the Pers. daAyaho,] A child's nurse; a woman who has the charge of a child, who takes care of him, and rears, or nourishes, him; (TA in art. HDn;) i. q. ZiYorN; both of which words are said by IJ to be chaste Arabic: pl. daAyaAtN. (M and TA in art. dwI.)

entry.sense: daYiI-N and daYiy-apN: see daMCN (in the latter part of the paragraph), in art. dwO.
duYiI-N and diYiI-N: see daOoIN.
dayoOFI, of the measure fayoEalN; and its fem. with p {dayoOayapN}: see daMCN (in the latter part of the paragraph), in art. dwO.

hom.sense: 1. dab-a aor. _i {yadobibu}, inf. n. dabiybN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and dab-N (M, Ḳ,) and madab-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [and perhaps dababN also, q. v.,] It, or he, (the ant, T, M, and any animal, M, and in like manner a party moving towards the enemy, T, or an army, and a child, Mṣb,) [crept; crawled; or] went, or walked, leisurely, or gently, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) without haste, (T,) EalaI AlOaroDi [upon the ground]: (Ṣ:) and [simply] he walked: (IAạr, T:) he (an old man) [crept along; or] walked leisurely, softly, or gently: (Ṣ:) and db-b↓, also, he walked leisurely, by slow degrees. (TA.) Hence, Oakocabu mano dab-a wadaraja The most lying of those who have walked and died, or passed away, or perished: (T:) i. e., of the living and the dead. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And yadib-u maEa AlquraAdi [He creeps about with ticks]; said of a man who brings a small worn-out skin containing ticks, and ties it to the tail of a camel; in consequence of which, when one of the ticks bites it, the camel runs away, and the other camels run away with it; and thereupon he steals one of them: whence it is said of a thief, or stealer of cattle, &c. (TA.) And huwa yadib-u bayonanaA biAln-amaAYimi ‡ [He creeps among us with calumnies, or slanders]. (A, TA.) And dab-ato EaqaArabuhu [lit. His scorpions crept along]; meaning ‡ his calumnies, or slanders, and mischief, (M, A, Ḳ,) crept along; syn. sarato. (M, Ḳ [See also art. Eqrb.]) And the same phrase is also used to signify ‡ His downy hair crept [along his cheeks]. (MF in art. Eqrb.) And dab-a qamoluhu [lit. His lice crept]; meaning ‡ he became fat: said of a man. (Ḥam. p. 633.) And dab-a Aljadowalu ‡ [The rivulet, or streamlet for irrigation, crept along]. (A.) And dab-a fiyhi ‡ It crept in, or into, it, or him; syn. saraI; (M, A, Ḳ;) namely, wine, or beverage, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) in, or into, the body, (M, Ḳ,) or in, or into, a man, (T,) and into a vessel; (M;) and a disease, or malady, (M, A, Ḳ,) in, or into, the body, (M, Ḳ,) or fiI Euruwqihi [in his veins]; (A;) and wear in a garment, or piece of cloth; (M, Ḳ;) and the dawn in the darkness of the latter part of the night. (M.)
dib-iI Hajalo (in the CK Hajalu) is the name of A certain game of the Arabs: (Ḳ, TA:) the l is quiescent. (TA.)
dub-a used as a noun: see below.

dab-a [second pers. dabibota,] aor. yadab-u, inf. n. dababN, He (a camel) was, or became, such as is termed Oadab-u; (IAạr, T, TA;) i. e., had much hair, or much fur (wabar), or much fur upon the face. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

4. Oadobabotuhu [third pers. Oadab-a] I made him (namely, a child, Ṣ) [to creep, or crawl, or] to go, or walk, leisurely, or gently. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [For the correct explanation, Hamalotuhu EalaI Ald-abiybi, Golius seems to have found Hmlth ElI Ald-aAb-api.])

Adb- AlbilaAda † He filled the country, or provinces, with justice, so that the inhabitants thereof walked at leisure (dab-a OaholuhaA [whence Golius has supposed dab-a to signify “juste se habuit populus”] M, Ḳ, TA) by reason of the security and abundance and prosperity that they enjoyed. (M, TA.)
R. Q. 1. dabodaba, [inf. n. dabodabapN,] He (a man) raised cries, shouts, noises, or a clamour. (AA, T.)
And He beat a drum. (AA, T.)
dab-N: see dababN.

hom.sense: dub-a and Xub-a are used as nouns, by the introduction of mino before them, though originally verbs. (Ṣ and Ḳ * and TA in art. Xb.) One says, OaEoyayotaniI mino Xub-a UilaI dub-a, (M, Ḳ,*) by way of imitation [of a verbal phrase], (M,) and mn Xub-K AlI dub-K, Thou hast wearied me from the time of thy becoming a youth until thy walking gently, [or creeping along, resting] upon a staff: (M, Ḳ,* TA:) a prov.: (M, TA:) said alike to a man and to a woman. (TA in art. Xb.) And faEalota kacaA mino Xub-a UilaI dub-a and mn Xub-K AlI dub-K Thou hast done thus from youth until thy walking gently, [or creeping along, resting] upon the staff. (Ṣ.)
dub-N: see dub-apN, in two places.

Also [The bear;] a certain beast of prey, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) well known; (Ḳ;) a certain foul, or noxious, animal: (Mṣb:) a genuine Arabic word: (M:) fem. with p {dub-apN}: pl. [of mult.] dibabapN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OadobaAbN. (M, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] Ald-ub-u † The constellation of the Greater Bear: and, accord. to some, that of the Lesser Bear: the former, for distinction, being called Ald-ub-u AlOakobaru; and the latter, Ald-ub-u AlOaSogaru. (M, Ḳ.)
dab-apN A single act [of creeping, or crawling, or] of going, or walking, leisurely, or gently: pl. dibaAbN. (Ḳ.)

A hill, or heap, or gibbous hill, syn. kaviyb, (IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of sand: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and (in some copies of the Ḳ “or”) a tract of red sand: or an even tract of sand: (Ḳ:) or, as in some copies of the Ḳ, an even tract of land: (TA:) and a place abounding in sand: (T, L:) pl. as above. (TA.) Hence the prov., waqaEa fulaAnN fiI dab-apF mina Alr-amoli [lit. Such a one fell into, or upon, a place abounding in sand]; meaning, ‡ into difficulty, or misfortune; for the camel in such a place suffers fatigue. (T.)

A certain thing for oil, or ointment; (Ṣ;) a receptacle for seeds (bizor) and olive-oil: (M, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Sb, M.) A kind of bottle, or pot, (baT-apN,) peculiarly of glass. (Ḳ.) [Form the Pers. dab-aho.]
See also dub-aMCN.
And see dababN, in three places.

entry.sense: dub-apN A way, or road. (Ṣ.)

† A state, or condition: (M, Ḳ:) and ‡ a way, mode, or manner, of acting, &c.; (IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) whether good or evil: (IAạr, T:) as also dub-N↓, (M, A, Ḳ,) in both these senses: (M:) and † a natural disposition, temper, quality, or property. (Ṣ:) You say, rakibotu dub-atahu, and dub-ahu↓ (M, A) ‡ I kept to his state, or condition, and his way, mode, or manner, of acting, &c.; and did as he did. (M.) And daEoniI wadub-atiI † Leave thou me and my way, mode, or manner, of acting, &c.; and my natural disposition,, &c. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: dib-apN A mode, or manner, [of creeping, or crawling, or] of going, or walking, leisurely, or gently. (M, Ḳ.*) You say, huwa xafiI-u Ald-ib-api [He has a soft, or stealthy, mode, or manner, of creeping along,, &c.]. (M, Ḳ:) And dababotu dib-apF xafiy-apF [I crept along in a soft, or stealthy, mode, or manner, of creeping]. (T, Ṣ.)

Also i. q. dabiybN↓ [as meaning Anything that creeps, or crawls, upon the earth; and used as a coll. gen. n.]. (Ḳ.) One says, maA Oakovara dib-apF hecaA Albaladi [How many are the creeping, or crawling, things of this country, or town!]. (TA.)

dababN A certain pace, between that termed Aln-aSobu and that termed AlEanaqu: (TA voce naSaba, as on the authority of En-Naḍr:) or this is termed dabiybN↓. (TA voce wasaja, as on the authority of En-Naḍr and Aṣ.)

Also Down; syn. zagabN; (M, Ḳ;) and so dababaAnN↓, (Ḳ,) and dab-apN↓: (Kr. M:) or down (T, Ṣ) of the face, (Ṣ,) or upon the face; (T;) and so dab-apN↓, (Ḳ,) of which the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is dab-N↓; (M, Ḳ;) accord. to Kr, who assigns to it the former meaning, and says that dab-apN↓ is syn. with zagabN, not that it is syn. with zagabapN: (M:) or dababN signifies hair upon the face of a woman: (TA:) or, as also dababaAnN↓, much hair (M, Ḳ) and wabar [or camel's fur]: (M:) or both these words signify hair upon the jabiyn [or part above the temple] of a woman. (ʼEyn, TT.)

Also The young one, when just born, of the [wild] cow: (Ḳ:) or when a [wild] bull is a year old, and weaned, he is thus called; and the female, dababapN, and dbAn. (TA in art. Xb. [But for “and dbAn,” I think it evident that we should read “and the pl. is dub-aAnN,” or “dib-aAnN,” like as jucoEaAnN and jicoEaAnN are pls. of jacaEN. See also XababN.])

entry.sense: dabibapN: see Oadab-u.
dababAnN: see dababN, in two places.
dabaAbi [an imperative verbal n.,] a call to a female hyena, signifying dib-iI [i. e. Creep along; or crawl; or go leisurely]: (Sb, T, Ḳ:) like nazaAli and HacaAri. (Sb, T.)
dabaAbN The pace, or motion, of a she-camel that can scarcely walk, by reason of the abundance of her flesh, and only creeps along, or walks slowly. (T,* TA.)

hom.sense: dabuwbN A she-camel that can scarcely walk, by reason of the abundance of her flesh, and that only creeps along, or walks slowly: (Ṣ:) pl. dububN. (TA.)
† Fat; (T, M, Ḳ;) as an epithet applied to a she-camel, (T,) or to any thing [or animal]. (M, Ḳ.)
jiraAHapN dabuwbN † A wound that flows with blood. (Ḳ.) And TaEonapN dabuwbN † A thrust, or stab, that makes the blood to flow. (Ḳ.)
† A deep cave, or cavern. (Ḳ.)
dabiybN inf. n. of dab-a [q. v.]. (T, Ṣ, M, &c.) See also dababN.
And see also daAb-apN, and dib-apN.

entry.sense: dub-aMCN and dab-apN↓ The gourd: (M, Ḳ:) or round gourd: or dry gourd: but this is said by Ibn-Hajar to be a mistake of En-Nawawee; and he asserts it to be i. q. yaqoTiynN [q. v.]: or it is the fruit of the yqTyn: (TA:) n. un. of the former with p. (M, Ḳ.) Accord. to F [and ISd] and several others, this is the proper art. of the former word, the C being considered by them augmentative: accord. to Z and others, its proper art. is dbI: and some also allow its being written and pronounced dub-FI: this is mentioned by Ḳz and ʼIyáḍ as a dial. var. of dub-aMC. (TA.) [See an ex. voce riXaMCN, in art. rXw.]

maA biAld-aAri dub-iI-N and dib-iI-N There is not in the house any one: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:) dub-iI-N being from dababotu; i. e. mano yadib-u; and it is not used in any but a negative phrase. (Ks, Ṣ.) [See also dib-iyjN and dib-iyHN.]
dub-aMCapN A locust while smooth and bare, before its wings have grown. (Mentioned in the TA in this art., but not there said to belong to it. [See art. dbI.])
[See also dub-aMCN, of which it is the n. un.]
dab-aAbN An animal that is weak, and creeps along, or walks slowly: fem. with p {dab-aAbapN}. (TA from a trad.)
dab-aAbapN fem. of dab-aAbN. (TA.)

[Also, as a subst., The musculus, or testudo;] a machine (M,* Mgh,* Ḳ, TA) made of skins and wood, (TA,) used in war; (M, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) men entering into [or beneath] it, (Mgh, TA,) it is propelled to the lower part of a fortress, and they make a breach therein (M, Mgh, Ḳ, TA) while within the machine, (M, Ḳ, TA,) which defends them from what is thrown upon them from above: (TA:) it is also called DaborN. (Mgh.)
dabodabN The walk of the long-legged ant. (M, Ḳ.) In the T it is said that dabodabapN↓ signifies The long-legged ant [itself: but this is perhaps a mistranscription]. (TA.)

hom.sense: dabodabapN [inf. n. of R. Q. 1, q. v.]

Any quick motion, or pace, performed with short steps: (M:) and any sound like that of solid hoofs falling upon hard ground: (M, Ḳ:) a certain kind of sound [like the tramp of horses, as is indicated by an ex.]: (Ṣ:) or cries, shouts, noises, or clamour: (A:) and dabaAdibu [is its pl., and] signifies a sound like dubo dubo; an onomatopœia. (T.)
[A kind of drum;] a thing resembling a Tabol: pl. dabaAdibu. (Mgh, Mṣb. [See also dabodaAbN.])
Milk such as is termed raAYib, upon which fresh is milked: or the thickest of milk; as also dabodabaI↓. (Ḳ.)
See also dabodabN.

entry.sense: dabodabaI: see the next preceding paragraph.
dabodaAbN A drum; syn. TabolN. (M, Ḳ. [See also dabodabapN.])
dubaAdibN Very clamorous; (IAạr, T, Ḳ;) as also jubaAjibN: (IAạr, T:) or both signify very evil, or mischievous, and clamorous. (Az, in TA, art. jb.)
And A bulky, or corpulent, man. (Ḳ.)

daAb-apN [originally a fem. part. n.], for nafosN daAb-apN, (M,) [or the p is added liln-aqoli, i. e. for the purpose of transferring the word from the category of epithets to that of substs.,] Anything that walks [or creeps or crawls] upon the earth; as also dabiybN↓: (Ṣ: see dib-apN:) an animal that walks or creeps or crawls (yadib-u); (M, A, Ḳ;) discriminating and not discriminating: (M:) any animal upon the earth: (Mṣb:) it is said in the Ḳur [xxiv. 44], waQll-ehu xalaqa kul-a daAb-apK mino maMCK faminohumo mano yamoXiI EalaI baTonihi waminohumo mano yamoXiI EalaI rijolayoni waminohumo mano yamoXiI EalaI OarobaEK [And God hath created every dAb-p of water (meaning of the seminal fluid); and of them is he that goeth upon his belly, and of them is he that goeth upon two legs, and of them is he that goeth upon four]: here, as dAb-p applies to a rational and an irrational creature, the expression fmnhm is used; for which, if it applied only to an irrational creature, faminohaA or faminohun-a would be used: moreover, the expression mn ymXI is used, though dAb-p applies originally to an irrational creature, [or rather a beast, and a reptile,] because the different classes of beings are spoken of collectively: (M:) and this passage of the Ḳur refutes the assertion of him who excludes the bird from the significations of this word: (Mṣb:) in the last verse but one of ch. xxxv. of the Ḳur, it is said to relate to mankind and the jinn (or genii) and every rational being; or to have a general signification: (M:) its predominant signification is a beast that is ridden: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) especially a beast of the equine kind; i. e. a horse, a mule, and an ass: (Kull:) or particularly a birocawon [meaning hackney, or horse for ordinary use and for journeying:] (M:) but as particularly applied, when used absolutely, to a horse and a mule, it is an adventitious conventional term: (Mṣb:) it is applied to a male and a female: (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and is properly an epithet: (M:) pl. dawaAb-u. (Mṣb, TA.) The dim. [signifying Any small animal that walks or creeps or crawls upon the earth, a small beast, a small reptile or creeping thing, a creeping insect, and any insect, and also a mollusk, a shell-fish (as in an instance cited voce maHaArapN in art. Hwr) and the like,] is duwayob-apN↓, (Zj, T, Mṣb,) in which the I is quiescent, but pronounced with UiXomaAm [i. e. a slight approximation to the sound of kesr], as it is in every similar case, in a dim. n., when followed by a doubled letter: (Zj, T:) and duwaAb-apN↓ also has been heard, with the I changed into A anomalously. (Mṣb; and L in art. hd, on the authority of ISd.)

daAb-apu AlOaroDi [The Beast of the Earth] is an appellation of one of the signs of the time of the resurrection: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or the first of those signs. (Ḳ.) It is said to be a beast sixty cubits in length, or height, with legs, and with fur (wabar), and to be diverse in form, resembling a number of different animals. (TA.) It will come forth in Tihámeh, or between Es-Safà and El-Marweh, (M,) or at Mekkeh, from Jebel Es-Safà, which will rend open for its egress, during one of the nights when people are going to Minè; or from the district of Et-Táïf; (Ḳ) or from three places, three several times. (M, Ḳ.) It will make, upon the face of the unbeliever, a black mark; and upon the face of the believer, a white mark: the unbeliever's mark will spread until his whole face becomes black; and the believer's, until his whole face becomes white: then they will assemble at the table, and the believer will be known from the unbeliever. (M.) It is also said that it will have with it the rod of Moses and the seal of Solomon: with the former it will strike the believer; and with the latter it will stamp the face of the unbeliever, impressing upon it “This is an unbeliever.” (Ḳ.)
See also OaraDapN.
dayobuwbN: see dabuwbN.
duwaAb-apN: dim. of daAb-apN, q. v.
duwayob-apN: dim. of daAb-apN, q. v.

Oadab-N Having down (Ḳ, TA) upon the face: (TA:) or having much hair: (M, Ḳ:) and having much wabar [or fur]: (M:) it is applied to a man: (M:) and to a camel, (M, Ḳ,) in the second of these senses, (Ḳ, TA,) or in the third sense, or as meaning having much fur upon the face; (TA;) or i. q. Oazab-u: (M:) and occurs in a trad. written Oadobab, (M, Ḳ,) to assimilate it in measure to a preceding word, namely, HawoCab: (M:) the fem. is dab-aMCu; with which dabibapN↓ is syn.; (M, Ḳ;) signifying a woman having hair upon her face: (TA:) or having much hair upon the jabiyn [or part above the temple]. (M, TA.)

madib-N and madab-N The track, or course, of a torrent, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,*) and of ants: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. madaAb-u. (TA.) One says, of a sword, lahu OavorN kaOan-ahu madab-u Aln-amoli and madaAb-u Alc-ar-i [It has diversified wavy marks like the track of ants and the tracks of little ants]. (TA.) The subst. is with kesr; and the inf. n., with fet-ḥ; accord. to a rule constantly obtaining, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) except in some anomalous instances, (TA,) when the verb is of the measure faEala (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) or faEila, (TA,) and its aor. is of the measure yafoEilu. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [Here it should be observed that majorFI, given as the explanation of madib-N and madab-N in the Ḳ, is both an inf. n. and a n. of place and of time: but J clearly explains both these words as above; and F seems, in the Ḳ, to assign to them both the same signification.]
OaroDN madab-apN A land abounding with dibabap [or bears]. (T, Ṣ, M.*)

mudab-abN, like muEaZ-amN, (TA,) or midobabN, (so in a copy of the T, according to the TT,)
an epithet applied to a camel, (T, TA,) signifying AlcI ymXI dbAdb (TA) [app. dabaAdiba, and if so it seems to mean That walks quickly, with short steps: or that makes a sound with his feet, like dubo dubo: see dabodabapN: but in the TT it is written dabOo dabOo; perhaps correctly dab-FA dab-FA, creeping and creeping].

1. dabaja, aor. _u {yadobuju} [or _i, as will be shown below], (L,) inf. n. dabojN, (L, Ḳ,) [not dabajN and dabajapN as in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag,] He variegated, decorated, embellished, adorned, or ornamented: (L, Ḳ:*) [and so db-j↓, inf. n. tadobiyjN, occurring in the TA in art. nmX; but app. in an intensive sense.] And [hence,] dabaja AlOaroDa, (A, L, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yadobuju} (L, A) or _i, (Mṣb,) inf. n. as above; (A, L, Mṣb;) and dab-ajahaA↓ [but app. in an intensive sense]; (A;) ‡ It adorned the land with meadows, or gardens: (A, L:) or it watered the land, and produced various flowers. (Mṣb.) It is a Pers. word, arabicized: (L:) or derived from diybaAjN. (Mṣb.)

2: see above {1}, in two places. [Accord. to Golius, (for III. is inadvertently put in his Lex. for II.,) as on the authority of the Ṣ and Ḳ, in neither of which is the verb mentioned, “Veste dybAj alium ornavit.”]

maA biAld-aAri dib-iyjN, (ISk, Ṣ, A,) or fiI Ald-aAri, (Ḳ,) ‡ There is not in the house any one: (ISk, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) dib-iyjN is not used otherwise than in a negative phrase: IJ derives it from diybaAjN; because men adorn the earth: (TA:) [Z says,] it is from dabaja, like sik-iytN from sakata; because men adorn houses: (A:) Abu-l-ʼAbbás says that dib-iyHN is more chaste than dib-iyjN: (TA:) [ISk says, or J, for the passage is ambiguous,] A'Obeyd doubted respecting the j and the H; and I asked respecting this word, in the desert, a company of the Arabs thereof, and they said, maA fiI Ald-aAri dib-iI-N, and nothing more; but I have found in the handwriting of Aboo-Moosà El-Hámid, mA fI AldAr dib-iyjN, with j, on the authority of Th: (Ṣ:) AM says that the j in dib-iyNj is substituted for the [latter] I in dib-iI-N, in like manner as they say mur-iI-N and mur-ij-N, &c. (TA.)
dubayobiyjN: see the next paragraph, near the end.

hom.sense: diybaAjN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) or dayobaAjN, (Th,) or both, (IAạr, AʼObeyd,) the latter having been sometimes heard, (IAạr,) or the latter is post-classical, (AʼObeyd,) or wrong, (AZ,) a word of well-known meaning, (Ḳ,) [Silk brocade;] a certain kind of cloth, or garment, made of Uiboriysam [i. e. silk, or raw silk]: (TA:) a kind of cloth, or garment, of which the warp and woof are both of Abrysm: and particularly a name for that which is variegated, decorated, or embellished: (Mgh, Mṣb:) a kind of woven stuff, variegated, or diversified, with colours: (Lb, TA:) [accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the Ṣ and Ḳ, in neither of which is the word explained at all, “vestis serica: imprimis picta, pec. Attalica, auro intexta:] derived from dabaja: (Ks:) or it is a Pers. word, (Kr, Ṣ, A,) arabicized; (Kr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) so some say, and from it dabaja is derived; (Mṣb;) originally diybaAIo, or diybaA; (Kr;) [or rather diybaAho, for the change of the final h into j in arabicized words from the Pers. is very common;] or diywo baAfo, i. e. “the weaving of the deevs, or jinn, or genii:” (Shifá el-Ghaleel:) pl. dayaAbiyju and dabaAbiyju; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the latter being from the supposed original form of the sing., i. e. dib-aAjN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) like danaAniyru [pl. of diynaArN, which is supposed to be originally din-aArN]: and in like manner is formed the dim. [duyayobiyjN↓ and dubayobiyjN↓]. (Ṣ.)
diybaAju AlquroMni is a title given by Ibn-Mesʼood to The chapters of the Ḳur-án called AlHawaAmiymu [the fortieth and six following chapters; each of which begins with the letters HemL]. (TA.)
See also the paragraph next following, in two places.
Also A young she-camel; one in the prime of life. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: diybaAjapN ‡ [A proem, an introduction, or a preface, to a poem or a book; and especially one that is embellished, or composed in an ornate style]. lihecihi AlqaSiydapi diybaAjapN HasanapN ‡ [To this ode is a beautiful proem] is said of a qSydp when it is embellished (muHab-arap) [in its commencement]. (A.) And one says, maA OaHosana diybaAjaAti AlbuHoturiI-i ‡ [How beautiful are the proems of l-Boh- turee!]. (A.)
diybaAjapu Alwajohi, and diybaAju↓ Alwjh, † Beauty of the skin of the face. (IAạr, L.)

And Ald-iybaAjapu ‡ The face [itself]; as also Ald-iybaAju↓, and Ald-iybaAjataAni: (Ḥar pp. 15 and 476:) or the last signifies the two cheeks: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) or the two sides of the neck, beneath the ears; syn. All-iytaAni. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN yaSuwnu diybaAjatayohi, i. e. ‡ [Such a one preserves from disgrace] his cheeks; (A;) or diybaAjatahu his face: and yaboculu diyabaAjatahu [uses his face for mean service, by begging]. (Ḥar p. 15. [See also 4 in art. xlq; and 1 (near the end) in the same art.; where similar exs. are given.])
[Golius, after mentioning the signification of “the two cheeks,” adds, as on the authority of the Ḳ, in which even the word itself is not mentioned, “et quibusdam quoque Nates.”]
diybaAjapu Als-ayofi I. q. Oavoruhu, q. v. (AZ, T in art. Avr.)
duyayobiyjN: see diybaAjN, near the end of the paragraph.
mudab-ajN Ornamented with diybaAj. (Ḳ.) You say TayolasaAnN mudab-ajN A TylsAn [q. v.] of which the ends, edges, or borders, are so ornamented. (Mgh, TA.)
OaroDN mudabajapN ‡ Land adorned with meadows, or gardens. (A.)
mudab-ajN also signifies † A species of the haAm [or owl]. (T, Ḳ.)
And † A species of aquatic bird, (T, Ḳ,) of ugly appearance, called Oagoyaru mudab-ajN, with puffedout feathers, and ugly head, found in water with the [bird called] nuHaAm. (T.)
And, applied to a man, (TA,) † Having an ugly head and make (Ḳ, TA) and face. (TA.)

2. db-H, inf. n. tadobiyHN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,). said of a man, (Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.,) He stretched out his back, and lowered his head, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) so that his head was lower than his posteriors; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb;*) as also AndbH↓; (Ḳ;) and so db-x, [q. v.,] with x: (Mṣb:) the doing thus in inclining the body in prayer, like as the ass does [when he is mounted], is forbidden in a trad.: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) i. e. he lowered his head in inclining his body in prayer so that it was lower than his back: (AʼObeyd, Mṣb:) or he lowered his head, and raised his posteriors, in prayer: (TA:) or [simply] he lowered his head; (IAạr, T, TA;) as also db-x [q. v.]: (T, TA:) or he did so in walking: (TA:) or he bent his back; (Lḥ, T, Mṣb, TA;) as also db-x; with which Aṣ says that dn-x, with n and x, is syn.: (Mṣb:) and db-H Zahorahu signifies he (a man) bent his back, raising the middle of it as though it were a camel's hump: erroneously related by Lth with c. (T, TA.)

Also He (a boy, in play,) lowered his back in order that another might come running from a distance and mount upon him. (Aboo-ʼAdnán, TA.) And one says, dab-iHo liI Hat-aI Oarokabaka, meaning Stoop for me in order that I may mount upon thee. (TA.)
Also, said of an ass having a sore back, He relaxed his legs, and lowered his back and rump, by reason of pain, on being mounted. (L.)
And He was, or became, low, base, abject, or ignominious. (IAạr, Ḳ.) [And so dan-aHa and dan-aHa.]
db-Ht AlkamoOapu [The truffles pushed up the ground above them, or] the ground swelled up from the truffles, without their appearing (Ḳ) as yet. (TA.)
db-H fiI bayotihi He kept in his house, or tent; not going forth. (Ḳ.)
7: see 1, first sentence.
maA biAld-aAri dib-iyHNThere is not in the house any one, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ;) as also dib-iyjN [q. v.]; but the former is the more chaste. (TA.)
ramolapN mudab-iHapN A gibbous tract of sand: pl. madaAbiHu: (ISh, Ḳ:) you say rimaAlN madaAbiHu. (TA.)
2. db-x, inf. n. tadobiyxN, He (a man, Ṣ) made his back round like a dome (qab-abahu) and lowered his head; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also db-H [q. v.]; with H and x, on the authority of AA and IAạr. (Ṣ.)
dub-aAxN A certain game [app. that which is described in the first paragraph of art. dbH.] (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. dabarahu, aor. _u {yadoburu} and _i {yadobiru}, inf. n. dubuwrN, He followed behind his back; he followed his back; (M, TA;) he followed him, with respect to place, and also with respect to time, and also † with respect to rank or station. (TA.) You say, jaMCa yadoburuhumo He came following them. (M, TA.) And dabaraniI fulaAnN Such a one came after me, behind me, (T, A,) or following me nearly. (A.) And dabarahu, inf. n. daborN, He succeeded him, and remained after him. (TA.) And qabaHa Qll-ehu maA qabala minohu wamaA dabara [May God curse the beginning of it and the end]. (Ṣ, A.)
See also 4, in four places.

dabara said of an arrow, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or dabara Alhadafa, (M, A,) aor. _u {yadoburu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. dubuwrN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and daborN, (M, Ḳ,) It passed forth from the butt: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or passed beyond the butt, (M, A, Ḳ,) and fell behind it. (M, A.)
dabara bihi He, or it, went away with it; took it away; carried it off; or caused it to go away, pass away, or cease. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

dabara Alqawomu, aor. _u {yadoburu}, (M, TA,) inf. n. dabaArN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) like damaArN, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) [and dabaArapN, like damaArapN (q. v.), and app. dabaraI↓, (see AlxayobaraI,) or dabraI may be a simple subst.,] The people, or company of men, perished; (Aṣ,* Ṣ,* M, Ḳ * TA;) went away, turning the back, and did not return. (TA. [And Adbr (q. v.) has a similar, or the same, meaning.]) Hence, Ealayohi Ald-abaAru Perdition befall him; may he go away, turning the back, and not return. (M, TA.)
And dabara ‡ He became an old man. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) Hence, as some say, the expression in the Ḳur [lxxiv. 36], waQll-ayolu UicaA dabara ‡ [And the night when it groweth old]. (TA. [See also 4.])

dabarati Alr-iyHu, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoburu}, inf. n. dubuwrN, (M,) The wind blew in the direction of that wind which is termed dabuwr [i. e. west,, &c., which is regarded as the hinder quarter]: (M, A:) or changed, and came in that direction. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence,] dabarato lahu Alr-iyHu baEoda maA Oaqobalato [lit. The wind became west to him after it had been east: meaning ‡ his fortune became evil after it had been good]: and dabara baEoda UiqobaAlK [‡ which means the same: see dabuwrN; and see also 4 in this art., and 4 in art. qbl]. (A.)
And dubira, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a verb of which the agent is not named, (Ṣ,) He, (Ḳ,) a man, (TA,) or it, a people, (Ṣ, M,) was smitten, or affected, by the wind called Ald-abuwr. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
dabara AlHadiyva Eanohu: see 2.
qabalotu AlHabola wadabarotuhu: see dabiyrN.

dabara, aor. _u {yadoburu}, inf. n. daborN, signifies, accord. to Kr, He wrote a writing or letter or book: but none other says so; and the known word is cabara. (M.) [The inf. n. is explained in the Ḳ as syn. with AikotitaAbN.]

dabira, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadobaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dabarN, (M, Mgh,) He (a horse or the like, M, Ḳ, and a camel, Ṣ, M, Mgh) had galls, or sores, on his back, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,* TA,) produced by the saddle and the like; (Mgh;) as also Adbr↓. (Ḳ. [But the corresponding passage in the M shows that this is probably a mistake for Oadobaru a syn. of dabirN.])

entry.sense: 2. db-r AlOamora, (T, M, A,) or fiI AlOamori (Ṣ,) inf. n. tadobiyrN, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He considered, or forecast, the issues, or results, of the affair, or event, or case; (TA;) and so tdb-rhu↓: (Mgh:) or its end, issue, or result; (T, M, Ḳ;) as also tdb-rhu↓: (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he looked to what would, or might, be its result: and tdb-r↓ fiyhi he thought, or meditated, upon it; (Ṣ;) [as also tdb-rhu↓:] Aktham Ibn-Seyfee said to his sons, yaAbaniI-a laA tatadab-aruwA↓ OaEojaAza OumuwrK qado wal-ato SuduwruhaA [O my sons, think not upon the ends of things whereof the beginnings have passed]: (T: [see EajuzN:]) and in the Ḳur [iv. 84] it is said, OafalaA yatadab-aruwna↓ AlquroMna Will they, then, not consider the meanings of the Ḳur-án, and endeavour to obtain a clear knowledge of what is in it? (Bḍ:) and again, in the Ḳur [xxiii. 70], Oafalamo yad-ab-aruwA↓ Alqawola Have they, then, not thought upon, (TA,) and endeavoured to understand, (yatafah-amuwA, Ḳ,) what has been said to them in the Ḳur-án? for tadab-urN↓ signifies the thinking, or meditating, upon [a thing], and endeavouring to understand [it]; syn. tafak-urN and tafah-umN: (TA:) and tdb-rhu↓ he looked into it, considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, in order to know it, or until he knew it. (Mṣb in art. Aml.) db-r OamorFA, inf. n. as above, signifies [also] He did, performed, or executed, a thing, or an affair, with thought, or consideration. (Mṣb.) [And He devised, planned, or plotted, a thing, EalaI gayorihi against another. And hence, He managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, an affair; because the doing so requires consideration of the issues, or results, of the affair. You say, db-r Oumuwra AlbilaAdi, and, elliptically, db-r AlbilaAda, He managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, the affairs of the provinces, or country: and in like manner, the affairs of a house. tadobiyrN is also attributed to irrational animals; as, for ex., to horses; meaning their conducting the affair of victory: and to inanimate things; as, for ex., to stars; meaning their regulating the alternations of seasons, &c.: see Bḍ in lxxix. 5. And db-r alone signifies He acted with consideration of the issues, or results, of affairs, or events, or cases; acted with, or exercised, forecast, or forethought; or acted with policy.]

db-r Eabodahu, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He made his slave to be free after his own death, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) saying to him, Thou art free after my death: (T, TA:) he made the emancipation of his slave to depend upon his own death. (TA.)

db-r AlHadiyva, (inf. n. as above, Ḳ,) He related the tradition, narrative, or story, having received it, or heard it, from another person: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ:*) and huwa yudab-iru Hadiyva fulaAnK He relates the tradition,, &c., of, or received from, or heard from, such a one: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) and db-r AlHadiyva Eanohu; (M;) or dabarahu↓ Eanohu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoburu}; (TA;) He related the tradition,, &c., having received it, or heard it, from him, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) after his death: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) Sh says that db-r AlHadiyva is unknown; but so the phrase is related on the authority of AʼObeyd: Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà [i. e. Th] disallows yudab-iruhu as meaning he relates it; and says that it is yacoburuhu, with c, meaning “he knows it, or learns it, well, soundly, or thoroughly;” syn. yutoqinuhu. (T.)

hom.sense: 3. dAbrhu, (Ṣ, A,*) inf. n. mudaAbarapN and dibaArN, (Ḳ,) [He turned his back upon him: see 6.]

[And hence,] † He severed himself from him, and avoided him, or shunned him; (TA;) became at variance with him; (A;) regarded him, or treated him, with enmity, or hostility. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And dAbr raHimahu † He cut, or severed, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; disunited himself from his relations. (A.)
daAbarotuhaA I made a slit such as is termed UidobaArap in her (a ewe's or goat's or camel's) ear. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 4.

4. Adbr, (M, Ḳ, and Bḍ in ix. 25,) inf. n. UidobaArN (Ṣ, M) and duborN↓, accord. to Kr, but correctly the latter is a simple subst. [or quasi-inf. n.]; (M;) and dabara↓, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. daborN (TA) and dubuwrN; (TḲ;) He went, turning his back; turned back; went back; took a backward course; retreated; retired; retrograded; declined; syn. wal-aIi (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and taOax-ara (IAạr) and cahaba UilaI xalofK; (Bḍ ubi suprà, and Ṣ and Ḳ in art. qbl;) contr. of Oaqobala. (Ṣ, Bḍ.) And Adbr bihi [He went back, or backward, with it, or him; removed, or turned, it, or him, backward]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, yudobiru biAld-alowi UilaI AlHawoDi [He goes back with the bucket to the watering-trough]: opposed to the phrase yuqobilu bihaA UilaI biYori. (A.) See also dabiyrN, first sentence. And Adbr Eanohu [He went back,, &c., from it, or him]. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] † He feigned himself negligent of, or inattentive to, the want of his friend; (Ḳ;) as though he turned back from him. (TA.)

[Hence also,] Adbr signifies † It went backward, to a bad state; said of the affair, or case, of a people. (M, TA.) You say also, OamorN fulaAnK UilaI UiqobaAlK and [in the contr. sense] AlI UidobaArN † [The affair, or case, of such a one is inclining to advance, and to go backward, to a bad state]. (A.) [UidobaArN often signifies The retiring, or declining, of good fortune; opposed to UiqobaAlN: see also 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.] And Adbr Alqawomu † The case of the people took a backward course, and there remained none of them. (TA.) And Adbr Aln-ahaAri and dabara↓ (inf. n. of the latter dubuwrN, A) signify the same; (Fr, T, Ṣ, M;) i. e. The day went, or departed; (M, A;) and so AlS-ayofu [the summer, or the spring]: and in like manner one says [in the contr. sense] Oaqobala and qabala: so says Fr, and he adds, but you say of a man, Aqbl Alr-aAkibu and Adbr only, with A, though [Az says] it seems to me that the two forms are applicable in the same manner to men as they are to times. (T.) Some read, in the Ḳur [lxxiv. 36], waQll-ayoli UicaA dabara↓, (T, Ṣ,) which, accord. to some, means And the night when it cometh after the day; (T;) or when it followeth the day: (Ṣ: [for another rendering, see 1:]) others, (T, Ṣ,) the greater number, (T,) read AcA Oadobara, (T, Ṣ,) meaning when it retreateth to depart. (T.) [Hence,] Adbrt AlS-alaApu † The prayer ended. (Bḍ in l. 39.) And waUidobaAra Als-ujuwdi: and waUidobaAra Aln-ujuwmi: see duburN. And Adbr † He died; (Ḳ;) as also dAbr↓. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ. [See also dabara Alqawomu, in the first paragraph.])
maA Oaqobala mina Aljabali wamaA Oadobara and maA qabala minohu wamaA dabara↓ signify the same [i. e. What is in front, of the mountain; and what is behind]. (JK.)
Adbr also signifies He made a man to be behind him. (M.)
And It, (the saddle, Ṣ, Ḳ, or a burden, M, TA,) and he, (a man, Ṣ, Mgh,) caused a camel, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,) or a horse or the like, (Ḳ,) to have galls, or sores, on the back; galled the back. (M, Mgh, Ḳ.*)
And His camel became galled in the back. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 1, last signification.

It is also said [app., of a man, as meaning He slit the ear of a she-camel in a particular manner, i. e.,] when (T) the fatolap [or twisted slip formed by slitting (see UidobaArapN)] of the ear of a she-camel, (T, Ḳ,) it being slit, (T, [but for AcA nHrt in the TT and TA, from which this is taken, I read UicaA buHirato, an emendation evidently required,]) turns towards the back of the neck: (IAạr, T, TT, Ḳ,* TA:) and Oaqobala is said in like manner when this ftlp is turned towards the face. (IAạr, T, TT, TA. [See also 3.])
It signifies also Earafa dabiyrahu mino qabiylihi, (IAạr,) or Earafa qabiylahu mino dabiyrihi; (Ḳ;) said of a man. (IAạr. [See dabiyrN.])
Also He, (Ḳ,) a man, (TA,) or it, a company of men, (Ṣ, M,) entered upon [a time in which blew] the wind called Ald-abuwr. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
And He journeyed on the day called dubaAr, i. e. Wednesday. (Ḳ, TA.)
And He became possessed of much property or wealth, or of many camels or the like. (Mṣb,* Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 2, in nine places.

Earafa AlOamora tadab-urFA means He knew the thing at the last, (M, Mgh,) after it had past. (Mgh.) Jereer says, (M,)
walaA tat-aquwna AlX-ar-a Hat-aIyuSiybakumo
walaA taEorifuwna AlOamora Uil-aA tadab-uraA
[And ye fear not evil until it befalleth you, and ye know not the thing save at the last, when it has past]. (M, Mgh.*) [See also 10.] And in like manner, tadab-ara AlkalaAma [meaning He postponed the saying] is said of one who has sworn after doing a thing. (Mgh.)
6. tdAbrwA They turned their backs, one upon another. (AʼObeyd, T.)

And hence, (AʼObeyd, T,) † They severed themselves, one from another, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and avoided, or shunned, one another; (AʼObeyd, T;) became at variance, one with another; (A;) regarded, or treated, one another with enmity, or hostility: (M, A:) or it is only said of the sons of one father, or ancestor. (M.)
† They spoke [evil], one of another, behind the other's back. (TA.)
† They abstained from, or neglected, aiding, or assisting, one another. (TA in art. xcl.)
10. Astdbrhu contr. of Astqblhu. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*) [As such it signifies He turned his back towards him, or it.] You say, Astdbr Alqibolapa He turned his back towards the kibleh. (MA.)
[As such also,] He came behind him. (TA.) You say, Astdbrhu faramaAhu (A, TA) He came behind him and cast, or shot, at him. (TA.)

[As such also, He saw it behind him: he looked back to it: he saw it, or knew it, afterwards:] he saw, (M, Ḳ,) or knew, (TA,) at the end of it, namely, an affair, or a case, what he did not see, (M, Ḳ,) or know, (TA,) at the beginning of it: (M, Ḳ:) [or rather] he knew it at the end of an affair, or a case; namely, a thing that he did not know at the beginning of it. (T, A.) You say, Aisotadobara mino Oamorihi maAlamo yasotaqobilo He knew at the end of his affair, or case, what he did not know at the beginning of it. (A.) And Uin-a fulaAnFA lawi Qsotaqobala mino Oamorihi maA Qsotadobarahu lahudiIa liwijohapi Oamorihi Verily such a one, had he known at the beginning of his affair, or case, what he knew at the end thereof, had been directed to the right way of executing his affair. (T.) [See also 5.]

Astdbrhu EalaI gayorihi He appropriated it to himself exclusively, in preference to others: (AO, Ḳ:) because he who does so turns his back upon others, and retires from them. (TA.) El-Aạshà says, describing wine,
tamaz-arotuhaAgayora musotadobirK
EalaI AlX-arobi Oawo munokirK maA Eulimo
i. e. [I sipped it] not appropriating [it] to myself exclusively [in preference to the other drinkers, nor denying what was known]. (AO, TA.)

hom.sense: daborN The location, or quarter, that is behind a thing. (Ḳ. [In the CK, for xalof is put xalaf.]) Hence the saying, (TA,) jaEalotu kalaAmahu dabora OucuniI † I turned away from his speech, and feigned myself deaf to it: (T, Ṣ:) I did not listen to his speech, nor care for it, or regard it. (M, Ḳ,* TA.) You say also, jaEalahu daAbira↓ Oucunihi ‡ He turned away from him, avoided him, or shunned him. (T,* A.)
See also dabariI-N.
Also, [like UidobaArN, inf. n. of 4,] † Death. (Ḳ.)
And † Constant sleep: (M, Ḳ:) it is like tasobiyxN. (M.)

I. q. dibaArN↓; these two words being pls. [or rather coll. gen. ns.] whereof the sings. [or ns. un.] are daborapN↓ and dibaArapN↓; which signify A maXaArap [explained in the TA as meaning a channel of water; but it seems to be here used as meaning a portion of ground separated from the adjacent parts, for sowing or planting, being surrounded by dams, or by ridges of earth, which retain the water for irrigation, as explained in art. Xwr and as is indicated by its Persian equivalent here following,] in, (Ṣ,) or of, (Ḳ,) land that is sown or for sowing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) called in Persian kurod: (Ṣ:) and dibaArN signifies small channels for irrigation between tracts of seedproduce; (Ḳ;) and its sing. is daborapN: (TA:) [Mṭr says,] daborapN is syn. with maXaArapN; in Persian karodah [app. a mistranscription for kurod as above]; and the pl. is daborN and dibaArN: (Mgh:) [ISd says,] daborapN signifies a small channel for irrigation between tracts of land sown or for sowing: or, as some say, i. q. maXaArapN: and the pl. is dibaArN: it is also said that dibaArN signifies i. q. kurodapN; and its n. un. is dibaArapN: and dibaAraAtN signifies rivulets that flow through land of seed-produce; and its sing. is daborapN: but I know not how this is, unless daborapN have dibaArN for its pl., and this have p added to it, as in fiHaAlapN, and so dbArAt be a pl. pl., i. e. perfect pl. of dibaArapN: AḤn says that daborapN signifies a patch of ground that is sown; [as is also said in the Ḳ;] and the pl. is dibaArN. (M.)
Also A piece of rugged ground in a baHorN [i. e. sea or large river], like an island, which the water overflows [at times] and from which [at times] it recedes. (M, Ḳ.)

And A mountain; (T, Ḳ;) in the Abyssinian language: (TA: [Az says, “I know not whether it be Arabic or not:”]) whence the saying of the King of Abyssinia, (T,* Ḳ,* TA,) maA OuHib-u Oan-a liI daborFA cahabFA waOan-iI Mcayotu rajulFA mina Almusolimiyna [I would not that I had a mountain of gold and that I had harmed a man of the Muslims]: (T, Ḳ:) but [SM says that] this is a confounding of two readings; which are, daborFA mino cahabK and Oano yakuwna daborN liI cahabFA: (TA:) another reading is caborFA mino cahabK. (TA in art. cbr.)
See also diborN.

Also, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) and diborN↓, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) A swarm of bees: and hornets, or large wasps; syn. zanaAbiyru: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and the like thereof, having stings in their hinder parts: (B:) it has no sing., or n. un.: (Aṣ, M:) or the n. un. is daborapN↓ or diborapN↓; of which the dim. dubayorapN↓ occurs in a trad.: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OadoburN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] dubuwrN: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and dabuwrN↓, with fet-ḥ to the first letter, signifies bees; and has no proper sing. (M.) 'Ásim Ibn-Thábit El-Anṣáree was called HamiI-u Ald-abori [The protected of hornets, or bees], because his corpse was protected from his enemies by large hornets, (Ṣ,) or by a swarm of bees. (M, Mgh * in art. HmI.)
daborN also signifies The young ones of locusts; (AḤn, Ḳ;) and so diborN↓. (AḤn, M, Ḳ.)
duborN: see duburN: and dabariI-N; the latter in two places.
See also 4, first sentence.

entry.sense: diborN: see daborN, last sentence but two, and last sentence.

Also, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and daborN↓, (M, Ḳ,) Much property or wealth; or many camels or the like; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) such as cannot be computed, or calculated: (M:) the sing. [and dual] and pl. are alike: you say [using it as an epithet] maAlN diborN and maAlaAni diborN and OamowaAlN diborN: (Ṣ, M:) this mode of usage is best known; but sometimes dubuwrN is used as its pl.: (M:) in like manner you say maAlN davorN: and you say also rajulN cuw diborK, (Ṣ, TA,) and rjl dbr, [unless this be a mistake for the phrase immediately preceding,] (Fr, TA,) meaning a man having large possessions in land or houses or other property. (Fr, Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: dabarN [app. signifies A tract of the western sky at sunset: for] the Arabs said, UicaA raOayota Alv-uray-aA bidabaro faXahorN nitaAjo waXahorN maTaro waUicaA raOayota AlX-iEoraI biqabalo famajodu fatFI waHimolu jamalo, meaning When thou seest the Pleiades near to setting with sunset, then [is a month which] is a time of breeding of camels, and [a month which is] a time of rain: and when thou seest Sirius [near to rising] with sunset, [then is the glory of the generous man, and the time for the burden of the full-grown he-camel; for] then is the most intense degree of cold, when none but the generous and noble and ingenuous man will patiently persevere in the exercise of hospitality and beneficence, and when the heavy burden is not laid save upon the strong full-grown he-camel, because then the camels become lean and the pasturage is scanty. (M.)

Also, and so is OadobaArN, a pl. [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n.] of dabarapN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which signifies A gall, or sore, on the back (M,* Mgh, Ḳ,* TA) of a horse or the like (M, Ḳ, TA) and of a camel, (M, Mgh,) produced by the saddle and the like; (Mgh;) and also on the kirokirap [or callous projection on the breast] of a camel. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. sr.) They used to say, in the Time of Ignorance, UicaA baraOa Ald-abaru waEafaA AlOavaru, explained as meaning [When] the galls on the back of the beast or upon the foot of the camel [shall heal, and the footstep, or mark, become obliterated]. (TA from a trad.)
Also inf. n. of dabira. (M, Mgh.)

entry.sense: dabirN (M, Ḳ) and Oadobaru↓ (M) A horse or the like, (M, Ḳ,) and a camel, (M,) having galls, or sores, (M, Ḳ,) on his back (TA) [produced by the saddle and the like; having his back galled: see dabarN]: fem. [of the former] dabirapN and [of the latter] daboraMCu↓: and pl. [of either] daboraI. (M, TA.) [Hence the prov.,] haAna EalaI AlOamolasi maA laAqaI Ald-abiru [What he that had galls on his back experienced was a light matter to him that had a sound back]: applied to one who has an ill concern for his companion. (Ḳ.)

In the phrase rajulN xasirN wadabirN [app. meaning A man erring and perishing], Lh says that dabirN is an imitative sequent to xasirN: but [ISd says,] I think that xasirN is a verbal epithet, and that dabirN is a possessive epithet. (M in art. dmr.) You say also OaHomaqN xaAsirN daAbirN↓ daAmirN: (T in art. bt: [see art. xsr:]) and daAbirN is said to be an imitative sequent to xaAsirN. (TA.)

duburN and duborN↓, (the latter a contraction of the former, Mṣb, [and not so commonly used, like as UibolN is not so commonly used as UibilN,]) The back; syn. ZahorN: (Ṣ, A, B, Ḳ;) the first signification given in the [Ṣ and] A and B: pl. OadobaArN. (TA.) You say, wal-aI duburahu [lit., He turned his back; and tropically,] ‡ he was put to flight. (A.) And wal-aAhu duburahu [lit., He turned his back to him; and tropically,] the same as the phrase immediately preceding. (Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [liv. 45], wayuwal-uwna Ald-ubura [And they shall turn the back, in flight]: where Aldbr is used in a collective sense, agreeably with another passage in the Ḳur [xiv. 44], laA yarotad-u Uilayohimo Tarofuhumo. (Ṣ, B.) You also say, wal-awoA daborapF↓ ‡ They turned back in flight, or being routed. (A, TA.)

The back, or hinder part, contr. of qubulN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of anything: (Mṣb:) as, for instance, of a shirt. (Ḳur xii. 25, 27, and 28.) You say, waqaEa Als-ahomu bidubori Alhadafi The arrow fell behind the butt. (TA in art. qbl.)

The backside; posteriors; buttocks; rump; or podex: and the anus: syn. AisotN. (Ḳ.) [It has the former of these two significations in many instances; and the latter of them in many other instances: in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. jEr, it is given as a syn. of majoEarN, which has the latter signification in the present day. This latter signification may also be intended in the Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, and Ḳ, by the explanation “contr. of qubulN,” as well as the “back, or hinder part,” of anything: for qubulN very often signifies the “anterior pudendum” of a man or woman, and is so explained. The anus is also called Haloqapu Ald-uburi and HitaAru Ald-uburi and Xaraju Ald-uburi.] Its pl. OadobaArN is also applied to the part which comprises the Aisot [or anus] and the HayaMC [or vulva, i. e., external portion of the female organs of generation,] of a solid-hoofed animal, and of a cloven-hoofed animal, and of that which has claws, or talons: or, as some say, of a camel, or an animal having feet like those of the camel: and the sing., to the HayaMC [or vulva] alone, of any such animal. (M, TT.)

† The latter, or last, part, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing, an affair, or an event, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) or of anything: (M, Ḳ:) pl. OadobaArN (M) [and dibaArN: see dabariI-N]. [See also daAbirN.] One says, jiYotuka duburi AlX-ahori, and fiI duburihi, and EalaI duburihi, and OadobaAra AlX-ahori, and fiI OadobaArihi, ‡ I came to thee in the latter, or last, part or parts, of the month. (M, Ḳ.) And OadoEuw laka fiI OadobaAri AlS-alawaAti † [I will petition for thee in the latter, or last, parts, or the conclusions, of the prayers]. (A.) See also dabariI-N. In the Ḳur [I. xxxix.], waOadobaAra Als-ujuwdi signifies † And in the latter parts, or the ends, of the prayers: and waUidobaAra↓ Als-ujuwdi [virtually] signifies the same [i. e. and in the ending of prostration], and is another reading of the text: Ks and Th adopt the former reading, because every single prostration has its latter part: or, accord. to the T, the meaning is, and in the two rek'ahs (Alr-akoEataAni) after sunset; as is related on the authority of ʼAlee the son of Aboo-Tálib. (TA.) The similar expression in the Ḳur [lii. last verse] waOadobaAra Aln-ujuwmi is explained by the lexicologists as signifying † And during the consecution of the stars, and their taking towards the west, to set: but [ISd says,] I know not how this is, since OaxocN, by which they explain it, is an inf. n., and OadobaAr is a pl. of a subst.: waUidobaAra↓ Aln-ujuwmi, which is another reading of the text, signifies and during the setting of the stars: and Ks and Th adopt this latter reading: (M:) or, accord. to the T, both mean and in the two rek'ahs before daybreak. (TA.)
Also The hinder part, (M,) and angle, (zaAwiyap,) of a house or chamber or tent. (M, Ḳ.)
Eitoqa AlEabodi Eano duburK (Ṣ, Ḳ) means The emancipation of the slave after the death of his owner. (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb.* [See 2.])
[See also dabiyrN, of which, and of dibaArN, duburN is said in the TA in art. qbl to be a pl.].

hom.sense: daborapN: see duburN.

Also † A turn of evil fortune; an unfavourable turn of fortune: or a turn to be vanquished; contr. of dawolapN: (Aṣ, M, Ḳ:) dawolapN relates to good; and daborapN, to evil: one says, jaEala Qll-ehu Ealayohi Ald-aborapa † [May God make the turn of evil fortune to be against him]: (Aṣ, T, M:) this [says ISd] is the best explanation that I have seen of daborapN: (M:) or (so accord. to the M, but in the Ḳ “and”) it signifies † the issue, or result, of a thing or an affair or a case; (M, Ḳ;) as in the saying of Aboo-Jahl to Ibn-Mesʼood, when he [the former] lay prostrate, wounded, limani Ald-aborapu † In whose favour is the issue, or result? and was answered, “In favour of God and his apostle, O enemy of God:” (T, TA:) also ‡ defeat in fight; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) a subst. from AlUidobaAru, as also dabarapN↓, (Ṣ,) and daAbirapN↓: (IAạr, A, Ḳ:) you say, kaAnati Ald-aborapu lahu, meaning ‡ His adversary was defeated; and Ealayohi meaning ‡ He was himself defeated: (A:) and limani Ald-aborapu, meaning † Who is the defeater? and EalaImani Ald-aborapu † Who is the defeated? the pl. of daborapN in the last sense is dibaArN: (TA:) which also signifies conflicts and defeats; (Ḳ;) as in the saying, OawoqaEa Qll-ehu bihimu Ald-ibaAra God caused, or may God cause, to befall them conflicts and defeats. (TA.)
See also daborN, in two places.

diborapN The direction, or point, towards which one turns his back; contr. of qibolapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, maA lahu qibolapN walaA diborapN, meaning ‡ He has no way of applying himself rightly to his affair. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And layosa lihecaA AlOamori qibolapN walaA diborapN ‡ The right way of executing this affair is not known. (Ṣ, A.)
See also UidobaArapN.
And see daborN, near the end.
dabarapN: see daborapN:
and see also dabarN.

entry.sense: dabaraI: see 1.
daboriI-N: see the next paragraph, in two places.

dabariI-N [Backward: and hence, ‡ late]. You say, AlEilomu qabaliI-N walayosa biAld-abariI-i † [True learning is prompt, and is not backward]: i. e., the man of sound learning answers thee quickly; but the backward says, I must consider it. (Th, T.) And tabiEotu SaAHibiI dabariy-FA † I followed my companion, fearing that he would escape me, after having been with him, and having fallen back from him. (M.) And Xar-u Alr-aOoIi Ald-abariI-u (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ *) ‡ The worst opinion, or counsel, is that which occurs [to one] late, when the want [of it] is past; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) i. e., when the affair is past: or raOoIN dabariI-N signifies an opinion, or a counsel, not deeply looked into; and in like manner, jawaAbN, an answer, or a reply. (M.) And fulaAnN laA yuSal-iI AlS-alaApa Uil-aA dabariy-FA (AZ, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and daboriy-FA↓, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) and the relaters of traditions say duburiy-FA↓, (Ṣ,) which is said in the Ḳ to be a corruption, but it may have been heard from a good authority, and with respect to the rules of the language is chaste, for, accord. to IAth, dabariI-N is a rel. n. irregularly formed from duburN, (TA,) ‡ Such a one performs not prayer save in the last part of its time. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ *)
It is said in a trad., laA yaOotiI AlS-alaApi Uil-aA dabariy-FA; and in another, Al-A duborFA↓ or daborFA↓, accord. to different relations; ‡ He will not come to prayer save at the last, or late: and in another, OataI AlS-alaApa dibaArFA↓ ‡ He came to prayer at the latest of the times thereof; (IAạr, TA;) or after the time had gone: (Ṣ:) dibaArN↓ being a pl. of duburN↓ and duborN↓ meaning the last of the times of prayer, &c. (IAạr, TA.) One says also, jaMCa fulaAnN daboriy-FA↓ ‡ Such a one came last, or latest. (A,* TA.) dbry-FA is in the accus. case as an adv. n. of time [like duborFA and daborFA and dibaArFA], or as a denotative of state with respect to the agent of the verb. (TA.) In the passage in the Ḳ [where it is said that dabariI-N signifies Prayer in the last of its time,, &c.], there is a looseness. (TA.)
duburiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.

Ald-abaraAnu [The Hyades: or the five chief stars of the Hyades: or the brightest star among them, a of Taurus:] five stars of Taurus, said to be his hump; (Ṣ;) one of the Mansions of the Moon; [namely, the Fourth;] a certain star, or asterism, between Alv-uray-aA [or the Pleiades] and AljawozaMCu [or Orion], also called Alt-aAbiEu and Alt-uwayobiEu; (T;) it follows Alvry-A, (T, M,) and therefore is thus named. (T.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl: and see AlmijodaHu, in art. jdH.]

dubaArN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, [in the M, accord. to the TT, written dubaAru, and it occurs in poetry imperfectly decl., but there is no reason for its being so in prose,]) and dibaArN↓, (Ḳ,) Wednesday; the fourth day of the week; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) an ancient name thereof: (Ṣ, M,* TA:) or, accord. to the ʼEyn, (Ḳ,) the night of [i. e. preceding the day of] Wednesday: (M, Ḳ:) which latter explanation is preferred by some authorities. (TA.) Wednesday is a day of ill luck: Mujáhid, being asked respecting the day of ill luck, answered, “The Wednesday that does not come round [again, i. e. the last Wednesday,] in the month.” (TA.)

hom.sense: dibaArN: see dabariI-N, in two places.

You say also, fulaAnN maA yadoriI qibaAla AlOamori mino dibaArihi Such a one does not know the first part of the affair from the last thereof. (TA.) And maA yaEorifu qibaAlFA mino dibaArK: see dabiyrN. And maA Oanota lahumo fiI qibaAlK walaA dibaArK † Thou art not one for whom they care. (TA in art. qbl.)
See also daborN:
and dubaArN.

dabuwrN, used as a subst. and as an epithet, [of the fem. gender,] so that one says either riyHu Ald-abuwri or riyHN dabuwrN and simply dabuwrN, but more commonly used as an epithet, (M,) [The west wind: or a westerly wind: the west being regarded as the hinder quarter:] the wind that is opposite to that called AlS-abaA (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Alqabuwlu, (L,) blowing from the direction of the place of sunset: (L, Mṣb:) or the wind that comes from [the direction of] the back, or hinder part, of the Kaabeh, going towards the place of sunrise: (M:) but IAth rejects this explanation: (TA:) or the wind that comes from the quarter behind a person when he is standing at the kibleh: [but this is a most strange explanation:] or, accord. to IAạr, the wind that blows from the tract extending from the place where En-Nesr et-Táïr [or Aquila] sets [i. e. about W. 10° N. in Central Arabia] to the place where Suheyl [or Canopus] rises [about Ṣ. 29° E. in Central Arabia]: (M:) or that comes from the direction of the south (Aljanuwb), going towards the place of sunrise: (Mṣb:) it is the worst of winds: it is said that it does not fecundate trees, nor raise clouds: (Meyd, TA:) and in a trad. it is said that the tribe of 'Ád was destroyed by it: (T, TA:) it blows only in the hot season, and is very thirsty: (TA voce nakobaMCu:) pl. duburN and dabaAYiru. (M.) [Hence the saying,] EaSafato dabuwruhu wasaqaTato Eabuwruhu [lit. His west wind, or westerly wind, blew violently, and his Sirius set: meaning ‡ his evil fortune prevailed, and his good fortune departed: for the dbwr is the worst of winds, as observed above, and Sirius sets aurorally in the beginning of winter, when provisions become scarce]. (A.)
See also daborN, last sentence but two.

entry.sense: dabiyrN A twist which a woman turns backward (maA Oadobarato↓ bihi), in twisting it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or what one turns backward from his chest [in rolling it against the front of his body]: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and qabiylN signifies “what one turns forward (maA Oaqobala bihi) towards his chest:” (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, A:) or the former, what the twister turns backward towards his knee [in rolling it against his thigh; against which, or against the front of the body, the spindle is commonly rolled, except when it is twirled only with the hand while hanging loosely]: and the latter, “what he turns forward towards his flank or waist:” (Aṣ, T:) [whence the saying,] qabalotu AlHabolu mar-apF wadabarotuhu↓ OuxoraI [I turned the rope, or cord, forward, or toward me, in twisting it, one time, and turned it backward, or from me, another time]: (TA in art. qbl:) or dabiyrN signifies the twisting of flax and wool: and qabiylN, the “twisting of cotton.” (Lth, T.) One says, Earafa qabiylahu mino dabiyrihi, meaning ‡ He knew, or distinguished, his obedience from his disobedience; (Ḳ, TA;) or dabiyrahu mino qabiylihi his disobedience from his obedience. (Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, IAạr, T.) And fulaAnN maA yaEorifu qabiylFA mino dabiyrK (Ṣ, A) or qabiylahu mn dabiyrihi (TA) ‡ [Such a one knows not, &c.]: or maA yaEorifu qabiylFA mino dabiyrK and qibaAlFA mino dibaArK↓ he knows not the ewe, or she-goat, that is termed muqaAbalap from that which is termed mudaAbarap: or him who advances towards him from him who goes back from him: or the parentage of his mother from that of his father: (Ḳ in art. qbl:) or that of his father from that of his mother: so says IDrd in explaining the former phrase: or a qubul from a dubur: or a thing when advancing from a thing when going back: and the pls. of each are qubulN and duburN. (TA in that art.) Accord. to El-Mufaddal, dabiyrN signifies An arrow's losing in a game of chance [such as Almayosir]; and qabiylN, its “winning therein.” (T, TA.) [See qabiylN, in art. qbl.]
Also The upper [because it is the hinder] part of the ear of a camel: the lower part is called the qabiyl. (TA in art. qbl.)
dibaArapN: see daborN.
dubayorapN: see daborN.

daAbirN act. part. n. of dabara, Following (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) behind the back; following the back; following, with respect to place, and also with respect to time, and also † with respect to rank or station. (TA.) [Hence,] daAbiru qawomK The last that remains of a people or party; he who comes at the end of a people or party; as also daAbiratuhumo↓; which likewise signifies those who remain after them: and daAbirapN↓ [so in the TA, but accord. to the T daAbirN, which I think the right reading,] signifies one who comes after; or follows, another. (TA.) And Ald-alowu bayona qaAbilK wadaAbirK The bucket is between one who advances with it to the well and one who goes back, or returns, with it to the wateringtrough. (A.) And jaEalahu daAbira Oucunihi: see daborN. And Oamosi Ald-aAbiru and Almudobiru↓ Yesterday that is past: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) the epithet being here a corroborative. (Ṣ,* M.) You say, SaAruwA kaOamosi Ald-aAbiri [They became like yesterday that is past]. (A.) And hayohaAta cahaba kamaA cahaba Oamosi Ald-aAbiru [Far distant is he, or it! He, or it, hath gone like as hath gone yesterday that is past]. (Ṣ.)
Also An arrow that passes forth from the butt, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or passes beyond it, (see 1,)] and falls behind it: (TA:) you say sahomN daAbirN, and sihaAmN daAbirapN and dawaAbiru. (Mṣb.)
An arrow that does not win [in the game called Almayosir]; (Ḳ, TA;) contr. of qaAbilN. (Ṣ, TA.)
The last arrow remaining in the quiver. (A.)

The last of anything; (Ibn-Buzurj, T, M, Ḳ;) and so daAbirapN↓: (M:) [see also duburN:] and (accord. to Aṣ and others, TA) the root, stock, race, or the like; syn. OaSolN. (Ḳ.) One says, qaTaEa Qll-ehu daAbirahumo May God cut off the last that remain of them. (Ṣ.) And qaTaEa Qll-ehu daAbirahu May God cut off the last of him, or it: (A:) or may God extirpate him. (Aṣ, T.) And in the Ḳur [vi. 45] it is said, faquTiEa daAbiru Alqawomi And the last of the people were extirpated. (M, TA.) And in a trad., yuqoTaEu bihi daAbiruhumo All of them shall be cut off thereby, not one remaining. (TA.)
See also dabirN, last sentence.
As an epithet applied to a camel: see gud-apN.
daAbirapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
Also ‡ The end of a tract of sand: (Esh-Sheybánee, Ṣ, A,* Ḳ:) pl. dawaAbiru. (A.)

Of a solid hoof, The hinder part: (T, TA:) or the part that corresponds to the hinder part of the pastern: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the part that is next after the hinder part of the pastern: (M, TA:) pl. as above. (T, TA.)

Of a bird, The back toe: it is with this that the hawk strikes: (M, TA:) or a thing like a toe, in the inner side of the foot, with which the bird strikes: (Ṣ:) that of a cook is beneath his SiySiyap [or spur]; and with it he treads: (M, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.)
See also daborapN.
Also A mode of Xagozabiy-ap [or throwing down by a trick] (Ṣ, Ḳ) in wrestling. (Ṣ.)
UidobaArN [originally inf. n. of 4]: see the next paragraph, in two places.

UidobaArapN A slit in the ear [of a ewe or she-goat or she-camel], which being made, that thing [thus made, meaning the pendulous strip,] is twisted, and turned backward: if turned forward, it is termed UiqobaAlapN: and the hanging piece of skin of the ear is termed UidobaArapN [in the former case] and UiqobaAlapN [in the latter case]; as though it were a zanamap [q. v.]; (Aṣ, Ṣ, M,* Ḳ;) and, respectively, UidobaArN↓ and UiqobaAlN, and diborapo↓ and qibolapN. (TA in art. qbl.) The ewe or she-goat [to which this has been done] is termed mudaAbarapN↓ [in the former case] and muqaAbalapN [in the latter]: and you say of yourself [when you have performed the operation, in these two cases respectively], daAbarotuhaA and qaAbalotuhaA: and the she-camel is termed caAtu UidobaArap and caAtu UiqobaAlapN; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so is the ewe or she-goat; (Aṣ, T;) and the she-camel, caAtu UidobaArK↓ and caAtN UiqobaAlK. (TA in art. qbl.)

OudaAbirN A man who cuts, or severs, the ties, or bonds, of his relationship; who disunites himself from his relations; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like OubaAtirN: (Ṣ:) one who does not accept what any one says, (AO, [who mentions OubaAtirN therewith as having the former signification,] T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) nor regard anything: (AO, T, Ṣ, M:) one who will not receive admonition. (IḲṭṭ.) [See OuxaAyilN.]

mudobirN [Going, turning his back; turning back;, &c.: see its verb, 4]. You say, maA lahumo mino muqobilK walaA mudobirK They have not one that goes forward nor one that goes back. (A.) In the phrase in the Ḳur [ix. 25], vum-a wal-ayotumo mudobiriyna [Then ye turned back retreating], the last word is a corroborative denotative of state; for with every tawoliyap is UidobaAr. (M.) See also daAbirN.
naAbN mudobirN is said to signify † An aged she-camel whose goodness has gone. (TA.)

OaroDN mdbrpN [app. mudobirapN] † A land upon which rain has fallen partially, not generally, or not universally. (TA in art. qbl. [This explanation is there given as though applying also to ArD mqblp, app. muqobilapN; but I think that there is an omission, and that the latter phrase has the contr. meaning.])
madobarapN i. q. UidobaArN [inf. n. of 4, q. v.]. (M.)
mudab-arN A slave made to be free after his owner's death; (Ṣ;) to whom his owner has said, “Thou art free after my death;” whose emancipation has been made to depend upon his owner's death. (TA.)

mudab-irN [is extensively and variously applied as meaning One who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, affairs of any kind, but generally affairs of importance]. faQlomadab-iraAti OamorFA, in the Ḳur [lxxix. 5], signifies [accord. to most of the Expositors] And those angels who are charged with the managing, conducting, ordering, or regulating, of affairs. (TA. [See also Bḍ.])

hom.sense: madobuwrN, (TA,) and madobuwruwna, (Ṣ,) A man, (TA,) and people, (Ṣ,) smitten, or affected, by the [westerly] wind called Ald-abuwr. (Ṣ, TA.)
