Also, the former, Wounded: (Ḳ:) or galled in the back. (TA.)
And Possessing much property or wealth, or many camels or the like. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mudaAbarN applied to a place of abode, Contr. of muqaAbalN. (M.) You say, hecaA jaAriI muqaAbaliI and mudaAbariI [This is my neighbour in front of me and in rear of me]. (TA in art. qbl.)

mudaAbarapN applied to a ewe or she-goat: see UidobaArapN: so applied, Having a portion of the hinder part of her ear cut, and left hanging down, not separated: and also when it is separated: and muqaAbalapN is applied in like manner to one having a portion of the extremity [or fore part] of the ear so cut: (Aṣ, T:) and the former, applied to a she-camel, having her ear slit in the part next the back of the neck: or having a piece cut off from that part of her ear: and in like manner applied to a ewe or she-goat: also an ear cut, or slit, in the hinder part. (M.) [It seems that a she-camel had her ear thus cut if of generous race. And hence,] naAqapN muqaAbalapN mudaAbarapN ‡ A she-camel of generous race by sire and dam. (T, TA.) And fulaAnN muqaAbalN wamudaAbarN ‡ Such a one is of pure race, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of generous, or noble, race, (A,) by both parents: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) accord. to Aṣ, (Ṣ,) from AlUiqobaAlapu and AlUidobaArapu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mudaAbirN [act. part. n. of 3, q. v.:] † One who turns back, or away, from his companion; who avoids, or shuns, him. (Aṣ.)

Also A man whose arrow does not win [in the game called Almayosir]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or one who is overcome in the game called Almysr: or one who has been overcome [therein] time after time, and returns in order that he may overcome: or, accord. to AʼObeyd, he who turns about, or shuffles, the arrows in the ribaAbap in that game. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. xD.]

fulaAnN musotadobirN Almajodi musotaqobiluhu ‡ Such a one is [as though he had behind him and before him honour or dignity or nobility; meaning that he is] generous, or noble, in respect of his first and his last acquisition of honour or dignity. (TA. [But it is there without any syll. signs; and with mstqbl in the place of musotaqobiluhu.])
4. Adbst AlOaroDu The land showed its plants or herbage: (Ḳ:) or began to show the blackness of its plants or herbage. (AḤn, M, Ṣ.)

9. Adbs-, inf. n. AidobisaAsN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or AdbAs-↓; (M;) He (a horse, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, and a sheep, or goat, M, and a bird, Ṣ) became black: (Ḳ:) or [brown; i. e.] of a colour between black and red; (Ṣ;) or black tinged, or intermixed, with redness. (M, TA.) [See dubosapN and Oadobasu.]
11: see 9. AdbAs-t AlOaroDu The blackness of the land became mixed with redness. (M, TA.)
dabosN Anything black. (Lth, A, Ḳ.)
[Hence, app.,] Much people; as also dibosN↓: (IAạr, Ḳ:) the former is also common to other things; (M,* TA;) so that you say maAlN dabosN, meaning much property. (TA.)
dubosN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: dibosN (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dubosN↓ (M) and dibisN↓ (Ḳ) The expressed juice of fresh ripe dates; (A, Mgh, Mṣb;) what flows from fresh ripe dates; (Ṣ;) the honey of dates; [i. e. the sweet, thick, or inspissated, juice thereof;] (M, Ḳ;) the expressed juice of dates, (M,) or of fresh ripe dates not cooked: (AḤn, M:) what is called SaqorN in the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh: said by some to be the honey of fresh ripe dates: by some, what flows, or exudes, from raisins and from fresh grapes: and by some, what flows from the baskets of dates: (TA:) [see also rub-N, in an explanation of which the inspissated juice of any fruit is termed its dibos:] also the honey of bees, Easalu Aln-aHolu: so in the copies of the Ḳ and in [some of the copies of] the A; a signification not known; but [AḤn] Ed-Deenawaree mentions the word dabaAsaAtN, and explains it as signifying “domestic bee-hives;” and by this it is seen that the application of dbs to what bees eject may be correct: or the true reading may be Easalu Aln-axoli, with x, as in some copies of the A; and it may be meant as explaining what precedes, meaning the expressed juice of the fruit of the palm-tree, by a kind of trope; though, as such, a useless repetition: but it is said in the O, on the authority of IDrd, that bees' honey is called dibisN↓: (TA:) the vulgar apply the word to [the inspissated juice of fresh ripe grapes, which resembles thick honey: and sometimes to] the honey of raisins. (MF.)
See also dabosN.

entry.sense: dibisN: see dibosN, in two places.

dubosapN A colour in animals that have hair; (Mṣb;) [brownness;] or redness tinged, or intermixed, with blackness: (M, Mṣb:) it is in sheep, or goats, and in horses; (M;) [and in birds: see 9:] accord. to Hoseyn Ibn-ʼAbd-Allah El-Iṣbahánee, in his book on strange pigeons, greenness, or a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, in which are redness and blackness. (TA.) [See also Oadobasu.]

dubosiI-N A certain bird, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of small size, (TA,) of a colour inclining to black, that cooes (yuqaroqiru): (Ḳ, TA:) hence said by some to be the male of the yamaAm [or dove]: (TA:) or a species of pigeons: (M:) or a pigeon of a colour between black and red: (Mgh:) or a species of the fawaAxit [or collared turtle-doves]: (Mṣb:) fem. with p {dubosiy-apN}: (Mgh, Ḳ:) [pl. dabaAsiI-N:] a rel. n. from TayorN dubosN: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) [see Oadobsu:] or from dibos of fresh ripe dates, but made to deviate from the form of the original, like duhoriI-N and suholiI-N: (Ṣ:) or it has the form of a rel. n. without being such. (M, TA.)
dabAsaAtN Domestic bee-hives; xalaAyaA Oaholiy-apN. (AḤn, M.)
dab-aAsN [A seller of dibos]. (Ḳ in art. Sqr.)

dab-uwsN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by some written dub-uwsN, which is said to be the correct form, (TA,) A mace (Ḳ, TA) of iron or other material: (TA:) app. an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) from [the Persian] dbwz (TA) [or dabuwso]: pl. dabaAbiysu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Oadobasu A bird, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) and a horse, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh,) and a sheep, or goat, (M,) or a goat, (A,) [brown; or] of a colour between black and red; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or of a red colour tinged, or intermixed, with blackness: (M:) or, accord. to Hoseyn Ibn-ʼAbd-Allah El-Iṣbahánee, in his book on strange pigeons, of a green colour, or a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, in which are redness and blackness: (TA:) fem. dabosaMCu: (A:) pl. dubosN. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
OaroDN mudobisapN Land beginning to show the blackness of its plants or herbage. (AḤn, Ṣ.)

1. dabaga AlUihaAba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Aljiloda, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yadobugu} and _a {yadobagu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dabogN, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dabogN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dibaAgN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and dibaAgapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the last is a subst. sometimes used as an inf. n., (Mṣb,) He tanned the hide, or skin; i. e., prepared it, or made it fit for use, and softened it, or made it pliable, with qaraZ [q. v.] and the like. (TA.) It is said in a trad., dibaAguhaA TahuwruhaA [The tanning thereof is the means of purification thereof]. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also dabuwgN.

7. Andbg It (a hide, or skin,) was, or became, tanned; i. e., prepared,, &c., with qaraZ and the like; (TA;) quasi-pass. of 1. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) jilodu Alxinoziyri laA yanodabigu [The skin of the pig will not become tanned] is a prov., said of him whom good advice will not profit. (TA.)
dibogN: see dibaAgN.
dabogapN [in one of my copies of the Ṣ written dabog] A single act of tanning. (Ṣ,* TA.)
dibogapN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: dibaAgN Tan; [tanning-liquor, or ooze;] that with which one tans, (Ṣ,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA,) i. e., prepares, or makes fit for use, and softens, or makes pliable, a hide, or skin, consisting of qaraZ [q. v.] and the like; (TA;) as also dibogN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dibogapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and dibaAgapN↓. (AḤn, TA.) One says, Aljilodu fiI Ald-ibaAgi [The skin is in the tan, or tanning-liquor]. (Ṣ.) And naqaEahu fiI Ald-ibaAgi [He soaked it in the tanning-liquor]. (Ḳ in art. mnO.)
[Hence,] dibaAgN lilomaEidapi [app. A stomachic]. (Lth and M and Mṣb voce TurovuwvN, q. v.)
Also an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dabuwgN ‡ Rain that puts the earth into a good state, and softens it, (yadobugu↓ AlOaroDa,) by its water. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA.)
dabiygN, applied to a hide, i. q. madobuwgN↓ [i. e. Tanned]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: dibaAgapN The craft of the dab-aAg [or tanner]. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)
Also an inf. n. of 1, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a subst, sometimes used as an inf. n. of 1. (Mṣb.)
See also dibaAgN.

entry.sense: dab-aAgN A tanner. (Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA.)
daAbuwgN Anguria, or water-melon; in Pers. hinoduwaAnaho (KL.)

madobagapN and madobugapN A place where hides, or skins, are tanned. (T,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA.) [Hence,] one says, hecaA Albaladu madobagapu Alr-ijaAli ‡ [This country is the place where men are tanned by the sun]. (TA.)

Also, the former, Skins put into the dibaAg [or tanning-liquor]: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or of which the tanning has been commenced: (Az, TA:) as though made a pl., (Ṣgh, TA,) like maXoyaxapN as syn. with maXaAYixu. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
OudumN mud-abagapN [app. Hides, or skins, much tanned]. (TA.)
madobuwgN: see dabiygN.
[Hence,] hecaA kalaAmN gayoru madobuwgK ‡ This is speech in which nothing is meant. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. dabiqa bihi, (JK, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadobaqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dabaqN, (TA,) [lit. He, or it, stuck to it: and hence,] † he was, or became, attached, addicted, given, or devoted, to it, (namely, a thing, JK,) so that he did not quit it. (JK, Ḳ.)

dabiqa fiI maEiyXatihi is explained by Lḥ only as signifying laziqa [app. meaning † He stuck fast, or perhaps he clave to one course, in respect of his means of subsistence: see also mudab-aqN]. (TA.)
dabaqahu He stuck it, or made it to adhere. (TA. [See 4.])
See also what next follows {2}.

entry.sense: 2. db-qhu, inf. n. tadobiyqN, (Lth, JK, Ḳ,) He caught it with diboq [or bird-lime]; (Lth, Ḳ;) namely, a bird: (JK:) and so dabaqahu↓, aor. _u {yadobuqu}, inf. n. daboqN. (TA.)
4. Adbqhu He made it to stick, or adhere. (Ḳ. [See also 1.]) You say, Adbqhu Qll-ehu bihi † God made him, or may God make him, to stick to it; or, it to him. (JK, TA.)
maA Oadobaqahu † How great is his attachment, addictedness, or devotedness! (JK, TA.)
5. tdb-q It (a thing) was, or became, sticky, glutinous, viscous, or ropy. (TA.)
It (a bird) was, or became, caught by means of diboq [or birdlime]; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. it stuck, or adhered. (TA. [See also dabiqa.])

diboqN (Lth, IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and daAbuwqN↓ (Fr, Ḳ) and dabuwqaMCu↓ (Ḳ) [Bird-lime: and the viscum, or mistletoe; and its berries, of which bird-lime is mostly prepared: the first of these words has these applications in the present day:] a kind of glue, (IDrd, Ḳ,) well known, (IDrd,) or a sticky, glutinous, or viscous, thing, like glue, (Fr, Ṣ, TA,) with which birds are caught; (Fr, IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) in one dial. called TiboqN: (IDrd:) Lth says, it is the fruit, or produce, of a tree, having in its interior a substance like glue, that sticks to the wing of the bird: the hakeem Dáwood says, [in a passage which is imperfect in the TA,] it is found upon the tree in like manner as lichen (AlX-ayobap), but is a berry, like the chick-pea (Him-aS) in roundness; … the best thereof is the smooth, soft, with much moisture, inclining, in its exterior, to greenness, and it is mostly found upon the oak; when it is cooked with honey and dibos [or the expressed juice of fresh ripe dates,, &c.], … and drawn out into longish strings, and put upon trees, the birds become caught by it. (TA.)
[dabiqN part. n. of dabiqa, Sticky, glutinous, or viscous: so in modern Arabic.]
dabuwqaMCu: see diboqN.
Also Anything sticky, glutinous, viscous, or ropy; that draws out with a sticky, glutinous, viscous, or ropy, continuity of parts. (IDrd, Ḳ,* TA.)
And Human ordure; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) because of its sticky, or ropy, quality. (JK.)
daAbuwqN: see diboqN.
EayoXN mudab-aqN † [Means of subsistence] not complete. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. dabalahu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadobulu} and _i {yadobilu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. dabolN, (M,) He collected it together, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) like as one collects together a morsel, or gobbet, or mouthful, of food with his fingers: (Ṣ:) and db-lhu↓, inf. n. tadobiylN, [in like manner] signifies he collected it together. (TA.) And dabala All-uqomapa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadobulu}, inf. n. as above; (M;) and db-lhA↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadobiylN; (TA;) He made the morsel, or gobbet, or mouthful, large, (M, Ḳ,) collecting it together with his fingers: (M:) or the latter signifies he made the morsel, or gobbet, or mouthful, large, and swallowed it. (IAạr, TA.) And dabalotu AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. as above; (TA;) and dab-alotuhu↓; (Ṣ;) I made the thing into lumps, or compact pieces or portions: (Ṣ,* TA:) and db-l↓ AlHayosa, inf. n. tadobiylN, He made the Hys [generally explained as meaning dates mixed with clarified butter and the preparation of dried curd called OaqiT, kneaded, or rubbed and pressed with the hand until they mingle together and their stones come forth,] into dubal [pl. of dubolapN, q. v.]. (T, TA.)

dabala AlOaroDa, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. dabolN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and dubuwlN, (M, Ḳ,) He put the land into a right, or proper, state, prepared it, or improved it, [or manured it,] with dung such as is termed sirojiyn, [in the Ḳ siroqiyn,] and the like, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in order that it might become good: (T, M:) and so damalahaA. (T.)

And dabalotuhu means I put it into a right, or proper, state; prepared it; or improved it; namely, anything; as also damalotuhu: for instance, a rivulet; i. e. he cleansed it, and put it into a right, or proper, state. (Ṣ.)
dabalahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dabolN, (TA,) also signifies He struck him consecutive strokes with a staff, or stick, (Ḳ,) and with a whip. (TA.)

dabalatohu Ald-ubuwlu↓ Calamities, or misfortunes, befell him: or may calamities, or misfortunes, befall him. (Ḳ.) And dabalatohumu Ald-ubayolapu↓ Calamity, or misfortune; befell them: or may calamity,, &c.: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M:) or they perished: or may they perish. (T.) And dabalatohu Ald-abuwlu↓, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Ald-ubuwlu,]) and cabalatohu Alc-abuwlu, (TA,) Calamity, or misfortune, befell him: or may calamity,, &c.: (TA:) or the bereft woman, i. e. his mother, became bereft of him by death: or may the bereft woman,, &c. (Ḳ, TA.)
maA lahu dabala daboluhu↓, or cabala caboluhu, is a form of imprecation: see the latter in art. cbl. (TA.)
dabila, aor. _a {yadobalu}, inf. n. dabalN, He (a camel, or other animal,) became full of fat and flesh. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in four places.

hom.sense: dabolN A rivulet, or streamlet: (T, M, Mgh, Ḳ:) pl. dubuwlN: (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ:) so called because cleansed, and put into a right, or proper, state [when needing]. (T, Ṣ, M.*)
Plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwnN. (Th, M, Ḳ.)
maA lahu dabala daboluhu: see 1, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: dibolN A calamity, or misfortune; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also dubayolapN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in which the dim. form denotes enhancement; (Ṣ, TA;) and dabuwlN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the first dubuwlN: (TA:) whence the saying, dabalatohu Ald-ubuwlu: see 1, latter part. Also The state of being bereft of a child, or of a person beloved, by death. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.) See dabiylN, in four places.
dabolapN: see dubayolapN.

hom.sense: dubolapN A lump, or compact piece or portion, (Lth, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) such as gum, &c., (Ṣ,) or of [the kind of sweetmeat called] naATif, or of Hayos, [described in the first paragraph of this art.,] or of something kneaded, or the like: (Lth, T:) and a large morsel or gobbet or mouthful: (Ḳ:) or a morsel, or gobbet, or mouthful, of butter: pl. dubalN. (En-Naḍr, T.)
See also dubayolapN.
Also The hole of the faOos [i. e. hoe, or adz, or axe]: pl. dubalN and dubulN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dabaAlN, (M,) like saHaAbN, so in the M, (TA,) or dubaAlN↓, like guraAbN, (Ḳ,) [Dung, such as is called] sirjiyon (M) or sirqiyon, (Ḳ,) and the like; (M, Ḳ;) [used for manuring land;] as also damaAlN. (TA.)
dubaAlN Ulcers that come forth in the side and penetrate into the inside; syn. naq-aAbaAtN; as also cubaAlN. (IAạr, T. [See also dubayolapN.])
See also dabaAlN.

hom.sense: dabuwlN: see dibolN. Hence the saying, dabalatohu Ald-abuwlu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph: (TA:) or this saying is from what here follows. (Ḳ, TA.)
A woman bereft of her child by death. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dibolN↓ dabiylN (M, Ḳ) and dibolN↓ daAbilN↓ (T, M, Ḳ) are intensive expressions (Ḳ) meaning A severe, or heavy, calamity or misfortune: (Ḳ,* TA: [in the CK, dabolN, which is said in the TA to be incorrect:]) or a severe, or heavy, bereavement. (T, M, TA.) And one says, sometimes, (M,) dibolFA↓ dabiylFA (Ṣ, M) and dibolFA↓ daAbilFA↓ (M) in the accus. case as an imprecation [meaning May God send upon such a one a severe, or heavy, calamity or bereavement]. (M.) Aṣ used to say cbl cAbl, meaning “[deep] abasement or ignominy:” (T, TA:) and Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybanee, cblFA cbylFA: (TA:) others pronounced with d. (T.)

dubayolapN A certain malady (M, Mgh, Ḳ) in the jawof, (M, Ḳ,) [i. e.,] in the belly, (Mgh,) being a collection of corrupt matter therein; (Mgh, TA;) wherefore it is thus called; (TA;) as also adbolapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and dubolapN↓: (Ḳ:) accord. to ISh, an ulcer that penetrates into the belly: [see also dubaAlN:] or an ulcer that comes forth within the side, and discharges internally; the sufferer from which seldom recovers: also called caAtu Aljanobi: (TA in art. jnb:) a large tumour (in Pers. waram buzurG). (KL.) [Abu-l-Kásim Ez-Zahráwee describes the modes of cauterizing the dbylp in order to hasten its coming to maturity. (See “Albucasis de Chirurgia,” p. 98, where the word is twice written cbylp; once, cbEylp; and once, correctly, dbylp.) Golius explains dabolapN and dubolapN by “vomica, apostema,” as on the authority of the Ṣ and KL; in neither of which do I find anything of the kind: nor do I find dabolapN even mentioned in either of those works.]
See also dibolN. Hence the saying, dabalatohumu Ald-ubayolapu: see 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.
dibolN daAbilN, and dibolFA daAbilFA: see dabiylN.
OaroDN madobuwlapN Land put into a right, or proper, state; prepared; or improved; [or manured;] with dung such as is termed sirojiyn. (Ṣ.)
1. dabaI, aor. yadobiI, inf. n. daboIN [and app. also dabFI, q. v. infrà], He walked, or went, gently, or in a leisurely manner. (TA.)
2. tadobiyapN i. q. SanoEapN. (Ḳ.) You say, db-Ahu, meaning SanaEahu [He made it, or wrought it;, &c.]. (TḲ.)

4. AdbI, said of the [tree, or shrub, called] rimov, (Ṣ,) or of the Earofaj, (M, Ḳ,) or of each of these, (TA,) It put forth what resembled [the young locusts termed] dabFI; (M, Ḳ;) [i. e.] what came forth, of its leaves, resembled dabFI; (Ṣ;) and thus became fit to be eaten. (Ṣ, M.) [See Oaboqala and vaq-aba and HanaTa; and see also rimovN, and EarofajN.]

hom.sense: dabFI or dabFA [sometimes written with I and sometimes with A] Locusts before they fly: (Ṣ:) or locusts when they [first] put themselves in motion, and become black, before their wings grow: in their first state, when they are white, they are termed saroCN: (AO, T:) or the smallest of locusts, and of ants: (M, Ḳ:) or [locusts] after the state of that which is termed sirowapN: (M:) [see jaraAdN:] n. un. dabApN. (Ṣ, M.)

[Hence,] jaMCa bidabaI dubaI-K↓, (M,) or bidabaA dubaI-K, and bidabaA dubay-ayoni, (IAạr, T, Mj, Ḳ,) and bidabaI dubay-aAna↓ and bidabaI dubay-aAnK, (Th, M,) † He came with, or brought, much; and what was good: (M:) he came with, or brought, much property or wealth, or many cattle: (M, Ḳ:) dubaI-N↓ is a soft tract in Ed-Dahnà, frequented by locusts, which lay their eggs therein; (M;) it is a spacious place; so that the phrase [jaMCa bidabaI dubaI-K] is as though it meant he came with, or brought, property, or wealth, or cattle, like the [locusts termed] dbA of the spacious place called dbI-. (T.) J is in error as to this phrase: (Ḳ, TA:) for it is stated in the Ṣ, as on the authority of IAạr, that one says, jaMCa fulaAnN bidabaA dabaA, meaning Such a one came with, or brought, property, or wealth, or cattle, like the dbA in abundance: and thus it is found in his handwriting: and in the Tekmileh it is written, as on the same authority, bidabaI dabFI. (TA.) Accord. to Abu-l-ʼAbbás [Th], the [right] phrase is bidabaI dubiI-K↓: and in one place he says that dabI-N↓ [thus (for dabiI-N) in the TT as from the T, but probably a mistranscription for dubaI-N↓,] signifies Much property or wealth, or many cattle: and accord. to AA, one says, jaMCa fulaAnN bidubaI-N↓, meaning Such a one came with, or brought, property, or wealth, or cattle, like the dbA. (T.)
Also A gentle, or leisurely, manner of walking or going. (Ḳ. [See 1.])

entry.sense: dabiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph, last sentence but one.
dubaI-N: see dabFI, in five places.
dubay-aAn: see dabFI.
dub-FI: see the next paragraph.

dub-aMCN The gourd: n. un. with p {dub-aMCapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) it is mentioned in this art. by J and Z [and Fei]: but accord. to Hr and the Ḳ, its proper art. is db [q. v.]: accord. to Az, dbO, for he says that its measure is fuE-aAlN: (TA:) some allow its being written and pronounced dub-FI↓. (TA in art. db.)
OaroDN madobaApN: see what next follows.
OaroDN mudobiyapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and madobaApN↓ (Ṣ) A land abounding with [the locusts termed] dabFI or dabFA. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
OaroDN madobuw-apN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: OaroDN madobiy-apN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and madobuw-apN↓, (M, Ḳ,) the w being substituted for the I as interchangeable therewith, (M,) A land of which the herbage has been eaten by [the locusts termed] dabFI or dabFA. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Accord. to Z, both signify [also] A land that produces dub-aMC, i. e. gourds. (TA in art. db.)

1. dav-a Als-amaMCu, (L,) or dav-at, (TA,) aor. _i {yadovivu}, inf. n. dav-N, The sky sent down rain such as is termed dav-;
i. e. weak rain; or the weakest and lightest of rain. (L, TA.)
dav-ahumu Als-amaMCu, (L,) or dav-atohumu, (TA,)) aor. _u {yadovuvu}, inf. n. as above, The sky rained upon them rain such as is termed dav-. (L, TA.)
duv-ati AlOaroDu, inf. n. as above, The land was watered by rain such as is termed dav-. (L.)

entry.sense: dav-N Weak rain; as also divaAvN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the latter [in the CK davAv, but it is] with kesr: or the weakest and lightest of rain; and the pl. is divaAvN: or, accord. to IAạr, i. q. rak-N: (TA:) or rak-N signifies rain exceeding what is termed dav-N. (Ḳ in art. rk.)
samaMCN dav-apN A sky sending down rain such as is termed dav-. (L, TA.)
divaAvN: see dav-N; of which it is said to be a syn. and a pl.
OaroDN madovuwvapN Land watered by rain such as is termed dav-. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. davara, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yadovuru}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. duvuwrN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) said of a trace, or mark, of a house; or of what remains, cleaving to the ground, marking the place of a house; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) or of a place of abode, (T, A,), &c.; (T;) or of a thing; (M;) It became covered with sand and dust blown over it by the wind: this is the primary signification: (TA:) or it became effaced, or obliterated, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, TA,) by the blowing of the winds over it; (TA;) as also tdAvr↓, (Ṣ,) or Andvr↓: (M, Ḳ:) and it became old; (M, Ḳ;) as also Andvr↓, (M,) or tdAvr↓. (Ḳ.) By one of the poets it is metaphorically said of a man's reputation, meaning ‡ It became worn out of regard or notice; became effaced, or obliterated. (M, TA.)
And, said of a man, † He became overcome by old age and emaciation. (T, TA.)
Also, said of a garment, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (T,) It became dirty. (T, Ḳ.)

And, said of a sword, (T, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (A,) ‡ It became sullied from remaining long unfurbished; (A;) it became rusty. (T, Ḳ.) Hence the trad. of El-Ḥasan, HaAdivuwA hecihi Alquluwba bicikori Qll-ehu faUin-ahaA sariyEapu Ald-uvuwri [explained in art. Hdv]. (Sh, T, A, TA.) duvuwrN attributed to the heart is † The having the remembrance of God effaced from it: and attributed to the mind, † The being quick to forget. (Sh, T, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. dv-rhu, (A, TA,) inf. n. tadoviyrN, (TA,) He covered him (A, TA) with a divaAr, (A,) or with something by which he should be rendered warm. (TA.) It is said that Moḥammad, when a revelation came down to him, used to say, dav-iruwniI dav-iruwniI Cover ye me with something whereby I may become warm. Cover ye me, &c. (TA from a trad.)
duv-ira EalaI Alqatiyli Large masses of stone were compactly put together, one upon another, over the slain person. (Ḳ.)
And dav-ara, (Ṣ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It (a bird) put to rights, or adjusted, its nest; put it into a right, or proper, state. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence.
4. Advr, (Ḳ, TA,) like Oakorama, (TA,) or Ad-vr↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) He acquired much wealth. (Ḳ, TA.) [See davorN.]

hom.sense: 5. tdv-r, (T, Ṣ,) and tdv-r bidivaArK, (Mṣb, TA,) and Aidav-ar-a, inf. n. Aidav-ur-N, (T,) He wrapped himself with a dvAr: (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) and tdv-r biAlv-awobi he enveloped himself entirely with the garment. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] huwa yatadav-aru biAlmaAli ‡ He is abundant in wealth. (A, TA.)
tdv-r Aln-aAqapa ‡ He (a stallion) mounted, or leaped, the she-camel. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

And tdv-r farasahu ‡ He (a man) leaped upon, and rode, his horse: (T, Ṣ, M, A, L, B: in the Ḳ, for farasahu, in some copies, is erroneously put qariynahu; and in others, qironahu, which is also wrong: TA:) or rode, and wheeled about upon the back of, his horse: (M:) or mounted his horse from behind. (TA.)

Ibn-Mukbil uses the verb metaphorically in describing rain; saying,
OaSaAxato lahu fudoru AlyamaAmapi baEodamaA
tadav-ara haA mino wabolihi maA tadav-araA
‡ [The large mountain-goats of El-Yemámeh listened to it, after there had fallen upon it, of its shower of big drops, what fell]. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: 6: see 1; each in two places.
7: see 1; each in two places.
8: see 4.

davorN ‡ Much property or wealth; or many camels or the like: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or much, or many, of any thing or things: (M:) [the sing. and dual and pl. are alike; as in the case of its syn. diborN or daborN:] you say, [using it as an epithet,] maAlN daborN, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and maAlaAni davorN, and OamowaAli davorN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [but sometimes duvuwrN is used as its pl.; for] you say Oaholu davorK and Oaholu duvuwrK: (AʼObeyd, T:) you also say maAlN divorN↓: (T:) and the expression EasokarN davarN↓, meaning a numerous army, occurs thus written: (Ṣ:) an instance is found in a verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys, where it is thus for the sake of the metre. (TA.)
Also Abundance of herbage, and the like; or abundant herbage, and the like. (TA.)
See also daAvirN.

hom.sense: divorN: see davorN.
divorN maAlK A good manager of property, or of camels or the like. (Ḳ.)
davarN Dirt, or filth. (Ḳ.)
See also davorN.

entry.sense: divaArN Any garment, (Ṣ, M,* A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) such as a kisaMC &c., which a man throws upon himself (Mgh, Mṣb) over the XiEaAr [or garment that is next the body]: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or one with which a person envelopes himself entirely: (M:) or a garment which one wears for warmth above the XEAr: (T, TA:) pl. duvurN. (Mgh.)

It is said in a trad. respecting the Assistants (AlAnSAr) [of Moḥammad], Oanotumu QlX-iEaAru waQln-aAsu Qld-ivaAru, meaning † Ye are the persons of distinction, and the [other] people are the vulgar. (TA.) [See also XiEaArN.]

Oabuw divaArK and bayotu OabiI divaArK The thin curtain (kil-ap) by which one protects himself from gnats, or musquitoes; the musquito-curtain: [see an ex. in the first paragraph {1} of art. bED:], or Abw dvAr is an appellation of the gnat, or musquito; because it is concealed in the daytime; or because a dvAr is wanted to protect one from its annoyance. (TA.)
davuwrN: see mutadav-irN.

Applied to a man, ‡ Obscure; of no reputation: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) a great sleeper: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) slow: (Ḳ:) heavy; that scarcely moves from his place: (TA:) lazy: (Kr, M:) and in like manner davaAriI-N↓, lazy; quiet; that does not occupy himself with his affairs. (A.)
divaAriI-N: see what next precedes.

daAvirN, applied to a trace, or mark, of a house; or to what remains, cleaving to the ground, marking the place of a house; Being covered with sand and dust blown over it by the wind; or being effaced, or obliterated, by the blowing of the winds over it. (A,* Mṣb,* TA.) You say fulaAnN jad-uhu EaAvirN warasomuhu daAvirN † Such a one's good fortune is at an end, and his vestige is being effaced. (A.)

In a state of perdition. (M, Ḳ.) Hence the saying fulaAnN xaAsirN daAsirN [Such a one is erring, in a state of perdition]: or it is here an imitative sequent [merely corroborative; for xAsr has also the same signification]: (M, TA:) and some say daAbirN. (M.)
A sword ‡ sullied by remaining long unpolished; rusty. (AZ, T, M,* A, Ḳ.)
‡ Negligent; inconsiderate; (L, Ḳ;) as also Oadovaru↓ (Ḳ) and dvr↓ [written without the syll. signs]: (L:) ‡ one who does not care for, or esteem, finery. (A.)
Oadovaru: see the last sentence above.

mtdv-r, (AA, T, Ḳ, [evidently, mutadav-arN, though written in the CK mutadav-ir, see 5, third and fourth sentences,]) applied to a man, (AA, T,) † I. q. maOobuwnu (AA, T, Ḳ) and mivofarN, &c. (AA, T.)

mutadav-irN and mud-av-irN Wrapped in a divaAr; wearing a dvAr; (T, M,* A,* Mṣb, TA;) as also davuwrN↓: (IAạr, M:) you say fulaAnN davuwru AlD-uHaI Such a one wraps himself with a dvAr and sleeps in the morning after sunrise. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. daj-a, aor. _i {yadojiju}, inf. n. dajiyjN (Ṣ A,* Ḳ) and dajajaAnN (Ṣ) and daj-N, (TA,) He, (a man, TA,) or it, (a company of people, accord. to ISk not said of a single person, Ṣ, TA,) crept along; i. e. went, or walked, leisurely, softly, or gently: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or did so with short steps: or came and went. (TA.) You say, mar-a Alqawomu yadij-uwna EalI AlOaroDi The company of men passed, going leisurely,, &c., upon, or over, the ground. (Ṣ.)
Hence, (TA,) He trafficked, or exercised the business of a merchant: (Ḳ) because the merchant travels about at a slow pace. (TA.)
And He hastened, or went quickly. (TA.)
Also,, [aor. _i {yadojiju}] inf. n. daj-N, said of a bayot [or tent, or house, or chamber], It dripped. (Ḳ.)
See also 2.
daj-a, [aor., accord. to rule, _u,] (Aṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. daj-N, (TA,) He let down a veil, or curtain. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. dj-jt Als-amaMCu, [in the CK, erroneously, tadaj-ajat,] inf. n. tadojiyjN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and daj-at↓, [aor. _i {yadojiju}] (A, TA;) The sky became clouded. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

5. tdj-j fiI Xik-atihi, (Ṣ, and so in copies of the Ḳ,) or tadajodaja↓, (A, and so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA,) He covered himself with his arms, or weapons: (A:) or he attired himself with (lit. entered into) his arms; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as though he covered himself with them. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. dajodajN It (the night, Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ) was, or became, dark; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tadajodaja↓ (Ḳ.)
dajodajati Ald-ajaAjapu fiI maXoyihaA The domestic fowl ran. (TA.)
dajodaja biAld-ajaAjapi He called the cock, or hen, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by the cry dajo dajo, (Ḳ,) or, as in some copies of the Ḳ [and in the L] dijo dijo. (TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tadajodaja: see 5:
and see also R. Q. 1.
dajo dajo, (so in copies of the Ḳ,) or dijo dijo (so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the L,) A cry by which domestic fowls are called. (L, Ḳ.) [See R. Q. 1.]
duj-N A chicken: [or probably chickens, as a coll. gen. n. of which duj-apN↓, mentioned in the TA voce dajaAjN, q. v., is the n. un.:] said by some to be a post-classical word. (TA.)

hom.sense: duj-apN Intense darkness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and dujujN↓ signifies the same; (Ḳ) or condensation of darkness. (TA.)
See also duj-N.
dujujN: see duj-apN.
Also Black mountains. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
Also pl. of dajaAjN. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: dajajaAnN [originally an inf. n.; see 1: afterwards (like xaSomN and EadolN, &c.) used as an epithet;] A sucking infant, that creeps along after its mother: fem. with p {dajajaAnapN}. (Ḳ.)

dajaAjN and dijaAjN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and dujaAjN, (TA,) the first of which is more chaste than the second, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,* TA,) and the second than the third; (TA;) a coll. gen. n.; (Ṣ, TA;) n. un. dajaAjapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and dijaAjapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and dujaAjapN; (Ḳ;) applied to the male and the female; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) A certain bird, (TA,) well known; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [the common domestic fowl, both cock and hen;] so called because of its [frequent] coming and going: (Towsheeh:) pl. dujujN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and sometimes dajaAYiju; (Mṣb;) and pl. of the n. un. djAjAtN; and dijaAjN may be regarded as a broken pl. of dijaAjapN, its kesreh and A being considered as the kesreh and A which make the pl. form, and as being not the kesreh and A which are in the sing.; or it may be a pl. of dujaAjapN with the augmentative letter A rejected, as though pl. of duj-apN. (TA.)

[Hence,] Ald-ajaAjapu [† The constellation Cygnus; so called in the present day;] a certain northern constellation, consisting of nineteen stars in the figure and two without the figure, of which the four stars in a row are called AlfawaArisu, and lie across the Milky Way. (Ḳzw.)
dajaAju Albar-i: see HajalN.

dajaAjapN, (accord. to the Ḳ,) or dajaAjN, (accord. to the TA, [the latter app. the correct term,]) also signifies † A family, or household; the persons who dwell with a man, and whose maintenance is incumbent on him. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also the former, † A ball (kub-ap) of spun thread: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the [receptacle called] HifoX thereof: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n., of which it is the n. un.,] dajaAjN. (TA.)
Ald-ajaAjataAni † The two projections, (TA,) or projecting bones, (MF,) of the breast of a horse, on the right and left of the zawor [q. v.]. (TA, MF.)
dajuwjN: see dajuwjiI-N
dajiyjN: see dajuwjiI-N
dajaAjapN and dijaAjapN and dujaAjapN are explained above, voce dajaAjN.
dujaAjiI-N: see dajuwjiI-N, in two places.
naAqapN dajawojaApN: [A long-bodied she-camel; lit.] a she-camel spreading upon, or over, the ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

dajuwjiI-N Of a clear black colour: (AʼObeyd, TA voce gayohabN:) or intensely black; (Ṣ) as also Oasowadu dujodujN↓ and dujaAjiI-N↓. (Ḳ.) It has the latter signification applied to a he-camel; and dajuwjiy-apN to a she-camel. (Ṣ, TA.) Also simply Black; applied to hair; and so dajiyjN↓: or the latter has this signification applied to anything; as also dajodaAjN↓: (TA:) which last likewise signifies dark, applied to a sea or great river, (Ḳ, TA,) because of the blackness of its water. (TA.) You say also layolN dajuwjiI-N Dark night: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or intensely dark night; and so dajuwjN↓ and dujaAjiI-N↓ (TA:) and layolapN dayojuwjN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and dajodaAjapN↓ (Ḳ) a dark night: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the pl. of dayojuwjN↓ is dayaAjiyjN and dayaAj-N the latter a contraction of the former. (TA.)

daAj-N [part. n. of 1]. You say jamaAEapN daAj-apN A party, or company, creeping along; i. e., going, or walking, leisurely, softly, or gently: (ISk, Ṣ:) or doing so with short steps: or coming and going. (TA.) And Oaqobala AlHaAj-u waAld-aAj-u (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA) The [company of pilgrims to Mekkeh, and of the] letters-out of camels, &c., and the servants, or assistants, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the like attendants of the pilgrims, came: (TA:) the two words HAj- and dAj-, though sings., are used in the pl. sense: (TA:) or AldAj- signifies also the merchants; (Ḳ;) or the merchants and others who go leisurely, or creep along, after the pilgrims. (TA.) AldAj- has the same meaning in the words of a trad., heWulaMCi Ald-aAj-u walayosuwA biAljaAj-i [These are the lettersout of camels, &c., and they are not the pilgrims]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said by Ibn-ʼOmar, of a people whom he saw among the pilgrims, whose appearance he disliked: or it means, accord. to AʼObeyd, those who are with the pilgrims, such as the hired men, and the camel-drivers, and the servants, and the like; and Ibn-ʼOmar meant that these were not pilgrims in the proper sense, but merely persons journeying and creeping along. (TA.) In the words of another trad., maA tarakotu mino HaAjapK walaA daAjapK Uil-aA Oatayotu, the word dAjp is without teshdeed, and is an imitative sequent to HAjp: (Ṣ:) [see art. dwj:] but accord. to one relation, it is mA trkt HaAj-apN walaA daAj-apN, meaning, accord. to El-Khaṭṭábee, [I left not a company of] pilgrims to Mekkeh, nor those returning. (TA.) One says also, OamaA waHawaAj-i bayoti Qll-ehi wadawaAj-ihi laOafoEalan-a kacaA wakacaA [Nay, by the pilgrims to the House of God, and those who journey thither for mercantile purposes, I will assuredly do such and such things]. (TA.)
dayojuwjN Darkness. (TA.)
And also used as an epithet: see dajuwjiI-N, in two places.
dujodujN: see dajuwjiI-N.

mudaj-ijN and mudaj-ajN A man completely armed: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) and so AʼObeyd explains mudajodajN↓: he is so called because he walks slowly by reason of the weight of his arms; or because he covers himself therewith, from daj-ajati Als-amaMCu. (TA.)
Also † The hedgehog; syn. qunofucN: (ISd, Ḳ:) or a large qunofucN: (TA:) app. so called because of its spines. (ISd.)
madojuwjN A veil, or curtain, let down. (Aṣ, TA.)
mudajodajN: see mudaj-ijN.

1. dajira, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadojaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dajarN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly, and at the same time exulted, or exulted greatly, and behaved insolently and ungratefully: (Ṣ:) or he became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he became in a state like that of one who is confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (T:) he became in a state of confusion and disturbance: (T, Ḳ:) or [so accord. to the TA, but in the Ḳ “and,”] he became intoxicated. (Ḳ, TA.)

dajirN (TA) and dajoraAnN↓ (Ṣ, TA) Brisk, lively, or sprightly, and at the same time exulting, or exulting greatly, and behaving insolently and ungratefully: (Ṣ, TA:) or, both words, (Ḳ,) in a state of confusion, or perplexity, and unable to see his right course: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in a state of confusion and disturbance: in a state of intoxication: (Ḳ:)
and the former, stupid; foolish; possessing little sense; who pursues a wrong course: (AZ:) pl. (of the former, Ṣ) dajaAraI (Ṣ, Ḳ) and dajoraI. (Ḳ.)
dajoraAnu: see the next preceding paragraph.

dayojuwrN Darkness: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) pl. dayaAjiyru (TA) and dayaAjiru. (A, TA.) You say, xuDotu Uilayoka dayojuwrFA kaOan-iI xuDotu baHorFA masojuwrFA [I waded to thee through darkness as though I waded through a full sea]. (A.) And, in a saying of ʼAlee, tagoriyada cawaAti AlmanoTiqi fiI dayaAjiyri AlawokaAri [Like the warbling of singing birds in the dark recesses of the nests]. (TA.)
It is also used as an epithet: you say layolN dayojuwrN Dark night: (TA:) and layolapN dayojuwrN a dark night: (Ṣ, A, TA:) and diymapN dayojuwrN a dark lasting and still rain. (AḤn.)
Also, applied to dry herbage, Dark and abundant; (Sh, Ḳ;) because of its blackness: (Sh:) or abundant and piled up: (IAth:) or, applied to herbage, abundant. (ISh.)
Also, applied to dust, or earth, (TA,) Of a dusty colour, inclining to black, (Ḳ,) like the colour of ashes. (TA.)
Also Dust, or earth, (Sh, Ḳ,) itself: (Sh:) pl. dayaAjiyru. (TA.)
Oasowadu dayojuwriI-N [Of a deep black colour]. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. dajala, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadojulu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. dajolN, (T, TA,) He smeared a camel with tar; (Ḳ) as also dj-l↓: (TA:) or he smeared him over his whole body with tar: (Ḳ:) or dajolN signifies the smearing in the part that is mangy, or scabby, with tar: (T, TA:) and tadojiylN↓, [inf. n. of daj-ala,] the smearing a camel over his whole body with tar: (T, Ṣ:) and the putting the tar upon the masaAEir [or armpits, and inner parts of the roots of the thighs or other similar parts, only,] is termed das-N. (Ṣ.)

He lied: [as though meaning he concealed the truth with falsehood: for, accord. to the KL, dajolN signifies the concealing the truth: (not, as Golius understood the explanation, its being concealed:)] and confounded or perplexed [such as heard him]. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, AaHoraqa is erroneously put for Oaxoraqa.])
[And app. He enchanted, or fascinated: for] dajolN is also syn. with siHorN. (TA.)
He compressed; coivit, or inivit. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)
He tra versed the regions, or tracts, of the earth, or land. (Ḳ.)
The primary signification of dajolN is [app. The act of covering; like tadojiylN: but it is said to be] the act of mixing, or confusing. (JM.)

Accord. to Fr, one says, huwa yadojulu biAld-alowi and yadoluju bihaA [He transfers the bucket from the mouth of the well to the watering-trough,, &c.]: the former verb being formed by transposition. (TA.)
dajolN also signifies The having one eye and one eyebrow. (KL.) [See daj-aAlN, last sentence.]

entry.sense: 2. dj-l, (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadojiylN, (Ḳ,) He covered (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ,) anything. (IDrd, Mṣb.)
See also 1, in two places.
He gilded [a thing]; (Ḳ;) he washed over anything with gold. (TA.)
It (a river overflowing) covered the land with water. (Mgh.)
dj-l OaroDahu, inf. n. as above, He put his land into a right, or proper, state, prepared it, or improved it, with [dung such as is called dajaAl, i. e.] sirojiyn (TA.)
dajaAlN [Dung for manuring land, such as is called] sirojiyn (Ḳ.)
dujaAlN: see daj-aAlN
dujaAlapN: see what next precedes.
duj-alN The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people. (Ḳ.)
daj-aAlN [in its primary application app. signifies A person, or thing, that covers anything in any manner; or that does so much, or often.]
[And hence,] A gilder or silverer. (Th, Mṣb.)

And [hence,] A liar: (Mṣb, TA:) [one who conceals the truth with falsehood: a falsifier: and] one who deceives, deludes, beguiles, circumvents, or outwits, much, or often; very deceitful,, &c.; or a great deceiver,, &c.: (JM:) pl. daj-aAluwna (Mṣb, TA) and dajaAjilapN. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. relating to Aboo-Bekr's demanding Fátimeh in marriage, qado waEadotuhaA liEaliI-i walasotu bidaj-aAlK, meaning [I have promised her to ʼAlee, and I am not] a liar. (TA.)

And i. q. daj-aAlapN↓, (Ṣ,) which signifies A great company of men journeying together, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) covering the ground by their multitude: or a company of men journeying together, carrying goods for traffic. (TA)
Also, (thus correctly written, but in [some copies of] the Ḳ, and by Ṣgh, written dujaAlN↓, like guraAbN, TA,) Gold: or gold-wash for gilding. (Ḳ, TA.)
And The diversified wavy marks, or streaks, or grain, (firinod) of a sword. (Ḳ.)

Ald-aj-aAlu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. AlmasiyHu Alkac-aAbu [The False Christ, or Antichrist], (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) said to be a certain man of the Jews, who is to come forth in the last days of our people, (TA,) is so called from dajala, because he will cover the earth [with his adherents] (Ḳ, TA,) like as the tar covers the body [of the mangy camel]: (TA:) or because of his lying, (Ḳ,* TA,) in arrogating to himself godship: (TA:) or because he will traverse most of the regions of the earth: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, Ḳ,* TA:) or from daj-ala, “he covered,” (Ḳ,) because he will cover mankind with his infidelity; (TA;) or because he will cover the earth with the multitude of his forces; (Mṣb, TA;) or because he will cover the truth with falsehood: (TA:) or from the same verb signifying “he gilded;” because he will involve men in confusion, or doubt, by falsehood, (Ḳ,* TA,) or will deceive them, or will manifest the contrary of what he conceives or conceals: (TA:) or from daj-aAlN signifying “gold,” or “gold-wash for gilding;” because treasures will follow him wherever he goes: (Ḳ,* TA:) or from the same word as signifying the “firinod of a sword:” or from daj-aAlapN explained above: or from dajaAlN; because he will defile the ground: or from daj-ula Aln-aAsu. (Ḳ.) [Accord. to one trad., he will have but one eye and one eyebrow: and hence, app., it is said that]
daj-aAlN also signifies Having one eye and one eyebrow. (KL.)
daj-aAlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
bayonahumo dawojalapN Among them are narrations from one to another and differing people. (TA.)
mudaj-alN A camel smeared [or smeared all over (see 1)] with tar. (Ṣ.)
And A sword [&c.] gilt. (Mṣb.)

1. dajana, aor. _u {yadojunu}, inf. n. dajonN and dujuwnN, It (a day) was, or became, one in which the clouds covered the sky: (Ṣ:) and dagana, inf. n. duguwnN, signifies the same, accord. to IAạr. (TA. [See also 4.])

dajanati Als-aHaAbu i. q. Adjnt↓ [meaning The clouds rained continually]: (TA:) [for] Adjnt↓ Als-amaMCu signifies the sky rained continually: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or dajanati Als-aHaAbu and Adjnt↓ may mean the clouds covered the sky, or the regions of the sky, or the earth: for] Ald-ajonu↓ [is app. the inf. n. of the former verb, and] signifies the clouds' covering (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) the sky, (Ṣ,) or the regions of the sky, (M, Ḳ,) or the earth. (Ḳ.)

dajana biAlmakaAni, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadojunu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. dujuwnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dajonN, (Mṣb,) ‡ He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) kept to it, or became accustomed to it: (TA:) and so Adjn↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
And hence, (TA,) dajana said of the pigeon, and the sheep or goat, &c., (Ḳ, TA,) as, for instance, the camel, (TA,) ‡ It kept to the house or tent. (Ḳ, TA.)
And dajanato lils-inaAwapi † She (a camel) was, or became, accustomed to irrigating the land. (TA.)

And dajana fiI fisoqihi ‡ He continued in his transgression, or wickedness, or unrighteousness. (TA.) And dajanuwA fiI luWomihimo ‡ They kept to their baseness, or ungenerousness; not abandoning it. (TA.) And Adjn↓ AlmaTaru, and Adjnt↓ AlHum-aI, ‡ The rain, and the fever, continued (IAạr, Ḳ) incessantly for some days. (IAạr, TA.)

3. dAjnhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mudaAjanapN, (Ṣ, M, TA,) He endeavoured to conciliate him; treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, beguiled, or deluded, him; syn. daAhanahu: (Ḳ:) in the Ṣ it is said that mudaAjanapN is like mudaAhanapN: in the M, that it signifies the mixing in familiar, or social, intercourse, or conversing, in a good manner. (TA.) [Golius assigns to dAjn another signification of dAhn; namely “He held in contempt;” as on the authority of the KL; in my copy of which it is not mentioned; nor can I find it elsewhere.]
4: see 1, in six places.

Adjn also signifies It (a day) became one of much rain; and so Aidojawojana↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter has a more intensive meaning,
i. e. it became cloudy with mist or vapour, and dark [with rain]; and [simply] it became dark, or obscure. (TA. [See also 1, first sentence.])
And Adjnw They entered into [or upon a time of] much rain. (AAF, Ḳ.)
12. Aidojawojana: see the next preceding paragraph {4}.
dajonN: see 1, second sentence: and see also dujun-apN [which has the same, or a similar, signification]. Accord. to Az, it signifies The shade of the clouds in a day of rain. (TA.)

Also Much, or abundant, rain: (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OadojaAnN and [of mult.] dujuwnN and dujunN and dijaAnN. (Ḳ.) You say yawomu dajonK and yawomN dajonN and yawomu dujun-apK↓ and yawomN dujun-apN [app. meaning, accord. to the Ḳ, A day of much, or abundant, rain; but it seems to be indicated in the Ṣ that the meaning is a day of clouds covering the whole sky, full of moisture, and dark, but containing no rain]: and in like manner one says of the night [app. laylapu dajonK and layolapN dajonN as well as layolapN dujun-apK↓ and layolapN dujun-apN]: using the latter word both as the complement of a prefixed noun and as an epithet. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
dujonN: see dujun-apN.
dujonapN or [dujun-apN↓] Rain: so in the phrase yawomN cuw dujonapK [or dujun-apK] a day of rain; as also cuw dugonapK [or dugun-apK]. (TA.)
See also dujun-apK.
Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the colours of camels, (Ṣ,) The ugliest kind of blackness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
dujun-N: see the next paragraph, in three places.

dujun-apN (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ) and dijin-apN↓ and dujun-N↓ (Ḳ) Clouds covering the whole sky, full of moisture, and dark, but containing no rain; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) pl. dujun-N↓ [or this is a coll. gen. n. of which dujun-apN is the n. un., though said to be syn. with this last, as well as a pl.]: (Ḳ:) and darkness; syn. ZulomapN: or the first of these words (dujun-apN) has this last signification; i. e. ZulomapN, or ZalomaMCu; [thus in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA; but in other copies of the Ḳ ZalomaMCu only;] and is also without teshdeed; (Ḳ;) i. e., it is also written dujonapN↓, as in the “Book” of Sb: this is explained by Seer [and in the Ṣ] as syn. with ZulomapN; and, accord. to Sb, its pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is dujonN↓; but in the Ṣ it is said that its pl. is dujanN, i. e. like SuradN, and dujunaAtN and dujanaAtN: (TA: [but in one copy of the Ṣ, I find dujonN and dujonaAtN; and in another, dujanN and dujunaAtN:]) and dujun-N↓ is syn. with dajonN↓ [q. v.]: (Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, Ald-ujunu is erroneously put for Ald-ujun-u; and Ald-ajonu, which should immediately follow it, is omitted:]) the pl. of dujun-apN is dujun-aAtN. (TA.)
dujun-apN also signifies The clouds' covering the earth, and being heaped; one upon another, and thick. (Ḳ,* TA.)
See also dajonN, in two places: and see dujonapN.
dijin-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
dajuwnN: see daAjinN, in two places.
Also † A ewe or she-goat that does not withhold her udder from the lambs or kids of another. (TA.)

[daAjinN act. part. n. of 1. Hence,] daAjinapN A rain (maTorapN, in two copies of the Ṣ maATirapN,) overspreading, or covering, [the earth,] like that which is termed diymapN [i. e. lasting, or continuous, and still,, &c.]. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ. [Freytag has written the word, as on the authority of the Ḳ, dajonap.]) And saHaAbapN daAjinapN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and mudojinapN↓ (Ṣ) A cloud raining (Ṣ, Mṣb) much, or continually. (Ṣ. [Which of these two meanings is intended in the Ṣ is not clearly shown.])

jamalN daAjinN and dajuwnN↓ † A he-camel that irrigates land; or that is used for drawing water upon him for the irrigation of land; syn. saAnK [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) or that is accustomed to the irrigation of land, or to be used for drawing water upon him for that purpose: (TA:) and madojuwnapN↓ applied to a she-camel has this latter signification. (Ḳ, TA.)
Oadojanu A camel (Ṣ) of the colour termed dujonapN: fem. dajonaMCu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mudojinapN: see daAjinN.
layolapN midojaAnN A dark night. (Ḳ.)
XaApN midojaAnN [A sheep or goat, or a ewe or she-goat,] that keeps to the lambs or kids, or is familiar with them, and affects them. (IB, TA.)
madojuwnapN: see daAjinN.
Also It (the hair of a she-goat) was, or became, such that one part thereof overlay another, and it was not loose and sparse. (Ḳ.)
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dujuw-N, (TA,) It (a garment) was complete, full, or ample; [such as covered the wearer completely;] or long, reaching to the ground. (Ḳ.)
And, said of a man, i. q. jaAmaEa; (Ḳ;) as also daHaA. (Ḳ in art. dHw.) You say, dajaAhaA He compressed her. (IAạr, TA.)

dajaA Oamoruhumo EalaI celika means † [Their affair, or case,] became in a good, right, or proper, state [upon that ground, or condition: probably from dajaA said of the night, as meaning “it was, or became, still, or calm”]. (Aṣ, TA.)

dajo laA daja kun-a Qll-ehu [app. Come hither, may God not protect you; if, as is probably the case, from dajaA said of the night, as meaning “it covered everything;”] is said in chiding the domestic fowl. (TA. [See dajo in art. dj.])

3. dAjI, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mudaAjaApN, (TA,) He treated another with concealment of enmity; (Ḳ and TA in art. djI;) as though he came to him fI dujoyapK, i. e. in darkness; (TA;) or from Oadojayotu Albayota [q. v. infrà]. (Ḥar p. 393.)

[Hence,] mudaAjaApN signifies [also] The treating with gentleness, or blandishment; soothing, coaxing, wheedling, or cajoling; or deceiving, deluding, beguiling, circumventing, or outwitting; or striving, endeavouring, or desiring, to do so: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the treating hypocritically: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) the coaxing, or wheedling, with comely behaviour or speech, not rendering sincere brotherly affection; or simply the treating with comely behaviour: and the putting [one] off [in the matter of a right, or due], as one does by repeated promises. (TA.) You say, daAjayotuhu, meaning I treated him with gentleness, or blandishment;, &c.; as though with concealment of enmity. (Ṣ.)
Also The preventing, or forbidding, or refusing, in a manner between that of severity and that of laxness. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4: see 1, first sentence.
[Hence,] Oadojayotu Albayota I let down the curtain [of the door] of the chamber. (Ḥar p. 393.)
5: see 1, first sentence, in two places.
[Hence,] tdj-I Als-aHaAbu The clouds closed together and spread so as to cover the sky. (AḤn.)
12. AidojawojaI: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: dujapN The three fingers [meaning the thumb and first and second fingers] with a mouthful upon [or between] them. (Ḳ.) And The mouthful [that is taken with the thumb and first and second fingers]. (TA.) valaAvu dujapK yaHomilona dujapF UilaI AlgayohabaAni waAlminovajapi is an enigma of the Arabs of the desert, meaning Three fingers conveying a mouthful to the belly and the anus. (TA.)
A button (T, M, Ḳ) of a shirt: (T, Ḳ:) pl. dujaAtN and dujFI. (Ḳ.)
See also art. djI.

entry.sense:
dujFA (as written by some) or dujFI (as written by others) Darkness; (Ṣ;) and so dujoyapN↓, of which, in this sense, [as well as in others, mentioned in art. djI,]
dujFI is also the pl., (Ṣ, and Ḳ in art. djI,) accord. to Ks, as mentioned by IJ, who holds it to be [only] sing.; (Ḥar p. 611;) and so, too, daAjiyapN↓, of which the pl. is dawaAjK: (TA:) or dujFI signifies the blackness of night, with clouds, so that one sees not star nor moon: or, as some say, [the state of the night] when it covers everything; not from the being dark: [see 1, first sentence:] (TA:) and dayaAjiI↓ All-ayolu signifies the darknesses, or intense darknesses, of night. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

You say also layolapN dujFI [A dark night, or a night that covers everything]: and layaAlK dujFI [dark nights,, &c.]; not pluralizing the latter word, because it is an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA.) [See also daAjK.]
dijowN A like, or an equal: and a [friend, or companion, such as is termed] xidon. (TA.)
dujoyapN: see dujFA, above: and see also art. djI.
dajowaMCu, applied to a she-goat, (Ḳ,) and to a she-camel, (TA,) Having full, ample, or long, hair or fur. (Ḳ, TA.)
dajiI-N: see what next follows, in two places.
layolN daAjK and dajiI-N↓ Dark night. (TA, and Ḳ in art. djI.) And layolapN daAjiyapN A dark night. (Ṣ.)

niEomapN daAjiyapN (Ḳ) and naEomaMCu daAjiyapN (IAạr, TA) An ample benefit, boon, or blessing. (IAạr, Ḳ. [Or, if the right reading in the former phrase be naEomapN, both phrases may mean Ample enjoyment or good fortune.]) Uin-ahu lafiI EayoXK daAjK, (Ṣ,) or EayoXK daAjK dajiI-K↓, (TA,) app. means Verily he is in an easy or a tranquil, or a plentiful and pleasant, or a soft or delicate, state of life. (Ṣ, TA.)
[daAjiyapN fem. of daAjK, q. v.:]
as a subst.: see dujFA.
dayaAjiI All-ayoli: see dujFA.
3. dAjI, mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ: see art. djw.

hom.sense: dujapN: see art. djw:
and see also the paragraph here following.
dujoyapN: see dujFA, in art. djw.
Also The lurking-place, or covert, (qutorap,) of a hunter: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. dujFI. (Ṣ.)
And A bee-hive. (KL.)

Of a bow, (Ḳ, TA,) A piece of skin (TA) of the measure of two fingers, put at the extremity of the thong, or strap, by which the bow is suspended, (Ḳ, TA,) having a ring in which is the extremity of the thong, or strap: but the word mentioned by IAạr as having this meaning is dujapN↓, when he says that the dujap is at [the distance of] four fingers from the notch of the bow into which enters the ring that is at the end of the string. (TA.)

And A sinew with which a bow is covered in the part of the stave that is held by the hand, lest it should break. (Ṣgh, TA.) [Golius says, as on the authority of the Ṣ, in which I find nothing of the kind, that it signifies A black patch, with which the extremity of a bow is covered for the sake of ornament.]
Red wool: pl. as above. (TA.)
The young one of the bee: pl. as above. (TA.) And [hence,] Oum-u dujoyapK The bee. (T in art. Am.)

entry.sense: dajiI-N: see art. djw.
daAjK: see art. djw.

1. daHarahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoHaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. duHuwrN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and daHorN, (T, Ḳ,) He (God, Ṣ) drove him away; expelled, or banished, him: he removed him; put, or placed, him at a distance, or away, or far away: (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) he pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, (Ḳ,) with roughness, or violence, and ignominy. (TA.) It is said, in a form of prayer, Aal-ehum-a QdoHaro Ean-aA AlX-ayoTaAna O God, drive away from us the devil. (TA.)
daHuwrN: see what next follows.

daAHirN and daHuwrN↓ Driving away; expelling, or banishing: removing; putting or placing at a distance, or away, or far away: pushing, thrusting, or repelling, (Ḳ,) [with roughness, or violence, and ignominy: see the verb.] In the Ḳur [xxxvii. 8-9], some read wayuqocafuwna mino kul-i jaAnibK daHuwrFA, meaning [And they shall be darted at from every side] with that which driveth away, or expelleth, &c.; as though it were said bidaAHirK, or bimaA yadoHaru: so says Fr; but he does not approve of this reading. (TA.)
OadoHaru More [or most] violently and ignominiously repelled. (TA from a trad., cited voce OadoHaqu.)
madoHarapN [said in Ḥar p. 210 to be syn. with the inf. n. duHwrN signifies A cause, or means, of driving away,, &c.].

madoHuwrN Driven, or removed, far away: so in the Ḳur vii. 17 and xvii. 19. (Ṣ.) And hence, AlX-ayoTaAnu madoHuwrN mino raHomapi Qll-ehi The devil is driven away, or banished, from the mercy of God. (A.)
Q. 1. daHoraja, inf. n. daHorajapN and diHoraAjN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) [He rolled a thing along: and] he rolled a thing down. (L, Ḳ.)
[And He rounded a thing; made it round: see the pass. part. n., below.]
Q. 2. tadaHoraja quasi-pass. of Q. 1; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) [It (a thing) rolled along: and] it rolled down. (L, Ḳ.)
[And It became round.]
duHoruwjapN The little ball [of dung] that is rolled along by the juEal [or species of black beetle called cantharus, and in which it deposits its eggs]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. daHaAriyju. (Ṣ.)

It also signifies mA tdHrj mn Alqdr: [so in the L and TA: but the following verse, cited as an ex. of this signification, suggests that Alqdr is probably a mistranscription for Alqurodi or Alqurudi, i. e. “ticks;” to which, in several different stages of growth, the Arabs apply different appellations: (see HamonaAnN:) and this is rendered more probable by the fact that, in the L, d and r are often written almost exactly alike: if so, the meaning is † A round tick; or a tick that has become round: likened, I suppose, to the little ball of dung above mentioned:] pl. as above: En-Nábighah says,
OaDoHatu yunaf-iruhaA AlwilodaAnu mino sabaOK
kaOan-ahumo taHota daf-ayohaA daHaAriyju [app. describing a she-camel, and meaning, She became so that the children of Seba scared her away, as though they were round ticks biting her beneath her two sides]. (L, TA. [This verse is also cited in the M and TA in art. sbO; but not there explained.])
mudaHorajN pass. part. n. of Q. 1 [as meaning Rolled along: and rolled down]. (TA.)
[And] Rounded; or round; syn. mudaw-arN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AlmudaHoriju [The roller; meaning] the juEal [or species of black beetle mentioned above, voce duHoruwjapN]. (IAạr, TA.)
haAlibu AlX-aEori and mudaHoriju AlbaEori are [Two] days of winter. (Ḳ in art. hlb.)

hom.sense: 1. daHaDato rijoluhu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoHaDu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. daHoDN (Ṣ, A) and duHuwDN, (A, TA,) His foot slipped. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And daHaDa said of a man, He slipped. (Mṣb.)

daHaDati AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. ns. as above, (TA,) ‡ The sun declined (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) towards the place of setting, (TA,) Eano kabidi Als-amaMCu (Ṣ) or En baToni AlsmMC (A) [from the meridian]; as though it slipped. (TA.)

daHaDato Huj-atuhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoHaDu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. duHuwDN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or daHoDN, (Mṣb,) ‡ His argument, plea, allegation, or evidence, was, or became, null, or void. (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also 4, in two places.

entry.sense: 4. AdHD, (A, TA,) inf. n. UidoHaADN, (Ṣ,) He made (Ṣ, A, TA) a man's foot, (A, TA,) and a man, (TA,) to slip; (Ṣ, A, TA;) as also daHaDa↓. (TA.)
It (rain) made a place slippery. (TA.)

‡ He (God, Ṣ, Mṣb, or a man, Ḳ) annulled, or rendered null or void, an argument, a plea, an allegation, or an evidence: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he rebutted it; as also daHaDa↓, inf. n. daHoDN. (TA; but in this instance, only the inf. n. of the latter verb is mentioned.) Thus in the Ḳur [xviii. 54, and xl. 5], liyudoHiDuwA bihi AlHaq-a ‡ That they may, or might, rebut thereby the truth. (TA.)

daHoDN A slippery place; as also daHaDN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and daHuwDN↓ (O, Ḳ) and midoHaDN↓ (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees,) [or madoHaDN?]: pl. diHaADN, (Ḳ,) [a pl. of the second,] like as jibaAlN is pl. of jabalN. (TA.)
Also Water that causes slipping: pl. OadoHaADN. (TA.)
daHaDN: see the next preceding paragraph.
daHuwDN: see the next preceding paragraph.

daAHiDN [Slipping] has for a pl. duHoDN:
occurring in a trad., in the phrase duHoDu AlOaqodaAmi, meaning † those having no firmness, or stability, nor determination, or resolution, in affairs. (TA.)
Huj-atuhumo daAHiDapN, in the Ḳur [xlii. 15], means ‡ Their argument, or plea, or allegation, is null, or void: or, as IDrd says, on the authority of AO; it means madoHuwDapN [rebutted]. (TA.)
midoHaDN [or madoHaDN?]: see daHoDN.

madoHaDapN A cause of slipping; syn. mazal-apN. (Ḳ.) You say, hecihi madoHaDapN liloqadami [This is a cause of slipping to the foot]. (A.) And makaAnN madoHaDapN, in a trad. respecting the Sirát, means A place on which the feet will not remain firm. (TA.)
midoHaADN A place in which one slips much, or often: pl. madaAHiDu. (TA.)

1. daHaqahu, aor. _a {yadoHaqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. daHoqN, (TA,) He drove him away; removed him; put him away, or far away; as also AdHqhu↓. (Ḳ.) One says, OadoHaqahu↓ Qll-ehu waOasoHaqahu, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. May God remove him; or put him away, or far away. (TA.)
And [hence, app.,] daHaqahu Aln-aAsu, (Ṣ,) or Qll-ehu, (TA,) † Men, (Ṣ,) or God, (TA,) disregarded him, or cared not for him. (Ṣ, TA.)
daHaqati Alr-aHimu (Ṣ, Ḳ) biAlmaMCi (Ḳ) The womb rejected the semen; did not admit it. (Sudot;, Ḳ.)

And daHaqato biraHimihaA, aor. _a {yadoHaqu}, inf. n. daHqN and duHuwqN, She (a camel, or other animal,) ejected her womb after bringing forth, and died in consequence: (TA:) or daHoqN and diHaAqN [each app. as an inf. n., or the latter may be a simple subst.,] signify the coming forth of the womb of a she-camel after her giving birth. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA.)

And daHaqato bihi She brought him forth. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the saying, qabaHa Qll-ehu Oum-FA daHaqato bihi [May God remove far from good, or prosperity, or success, a mother who brought him forth]. (Ṣ.)
daHaqato yaduhu Eanohu His arm, or hand, fell short of reaching it, or attaining it. (Lth, Ibn-ʼAbbád, ISd, Ḳ.*)
4: see above {1}, in two places.
7. AndHqt raHimu Aln-aAqapu The she-camel's womb came forth from its place. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
daHuwqN A she-camel whose womb comes forth after her giving birth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also daAHiqN↓. (Ḳ.)
daHiyqN Driven away; (Ḳ;) removed; remote; put away, or far away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A man removed from good, or prosperity; and from others; as also mudoHaqN↓. (TA.)

EayonN daHiyqN is like maToruwfapN [i. e. An eye hit, or hurt, with a thing, so that it sheds tears]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, AlmaToruwqap is erroneously put for AlmaToruwfap.]) mano EaAnaka Eyonuhu daHiyqo fiyhaA turobN saHiyqo wadamuhu tadofiyqo walaHomuhu tamoXiyqo [Whoso smites thee with an evil eye, may his eye be hit, or hurt, so as to shed tears; may there be in it bruised earth; and may his blood be copiously shed; and may his flesh be much lacerated;] is one of their formulas of incantation. (TA.)
daAHiqN: see daHuwqN. Also A woman ejecting her womb, fat and flesh. (TA.)

OadoHaqN Further [or furthest] driven away or removed or put away: occurring in the following trad.: maA mino yawomK Uiboliysu fiyhi OadoHaru walaA OadoHaqu minohu fiIyawomi Earafapa [There is not any day in which Iblees is more violently and ignominiously repelled, nor in which he is further driven away, than he is in the day of ʼArafeh]. (TA.)
mudoHaqN: see daHiyqN.

hom.sense: 1. daHala, (T, Ḳ,) or daHala fiI Ald-aHoli, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yadoHalu}, He (a man, T, Ṣ) entered into the daHol [q. v.]; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AdHl↓. (Ḳ.)

And daHala, aor. _a {yadoHalu}, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. daHolN, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, in the side of the xibaMC [or tent]: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [from daHala in the former sense; or] from [the subst.] Ald-aHolu: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) the sides [or side] of the xbMC being likened to the hollow [called daHol] in the lower part of a valley. (TA.)
Or daHala signifies [or rather signifies also] He dug, or excavated, in the sides of the well: (Ḳ:) [or] daHala AlbiYora has this meaning. (Ṣ.)

And daHala Ean-iI, aor. _a {yadoHalu}, (in a copy of the Ḳ erroneously said to be like fariHa, TA,) He went, or removed, to a distance, or far, from me: (T, O, Ḳ:) fled from me: concealed himself from me [as though in a daHol]: feared me: (Ḳ:) the inf. n., or an inf. n., is daHalaAnN. (TA.)
daHila, aor. _a {yadoHalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. daHalN, (Ṣ,* TḲ,) He was, or became, such as is termed daHilN, in all the senses of this word. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. dAHlhu, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. mudaAHalapN, (TA,) He strove, or endeavoured, or desired, to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit, him. (T, Ḳ.)
He acted with him in a niggardly, a tenacious, or an avaricious, manner; syn. maAkasahu. (Ḳ.) [See daHilN.]
He concealed from him what he knew, and told him some other thing. (Sh, Ḳ.)

diHaAlN [an inf. n. of the same verb] signifies The act of refraining, abstaining, or holding back; syn. AimotinaAEN; (Aṣ, Ḳ;) as though striving to deceive, delude, beguile, circumvent, or outwit; and disobeying: not from daHolN signifying “a subterranean cavity.” (Aṣ, TA.) And The act of declining on one side. (TA.)
4: see 1, first sentence.

daHolN A hollow, or cavity, or a deep hollow or cavity, in the ground, and in the lower parts of valleys, narrow, and then widening: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, O:) or a [hollow such as is termed] qaEor, in the ground, curving, or winding, or uneven, resembling a well, narrow at the mouth, and then widening; or it may be not widening: (Ḥam p. 477:) or, as also duHolN↓, a hole (naqobN) narrow in the mouth and wide in the lower part, so that one may walk therein, (Ḳ, TA,) having a bending or the like, (TA,) and sometimes producing sidor [or lote-trees]: or a place into which one may enter beneath a jurof [or water-worn bank]; or in the width of the side of a well, in its lower part; (Ḳ;) and the like in a watering-place: all these explanations in the Ḳ are found in the M: (TA:) or each, (accord. to the Ḳ,) or daHolN, (accord. to the TA,) signifies [or rather signifies also] † a hole in [any of] the tents of the Arabs of the desert, made for the purpose of a woman's entering into it when a man enters [the tent]; (M, Ḳ;) so called as being likened to the daHol [commonly thus termed]: (TA:) and a kind of reservoir (maSonaEN) that collects water: (Ḳ:) Az describes, as seen by him, at El-Khalsà, in the district of Ed-Dahnà, many a daHol, being a natural subterranean cavity extending in an even manner, and then becoming hollowed out on the right and left, sometimes narrow and sometimes wide, in smooth rock, and leading to an abyss (jaw-) of water, of extent and abundance unknown because of the darkness of the dHl beneath the earth, sweet and clear and cold and pleasant to drink because of rain-water that had flowed thither from above, and collected therein: (TA:) and daHolN also signifies a lateral hollow (laHodN) of a grave: (TA in art. tw: [in this sense, perhaps formed by transposition:]) daHiylapN↓, also, signifies a hollow, or cavity, in the ground; like daHolN; or like the daHol: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] of dHl is OadoHaAlN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OadoHulN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] duHuwlN and diHaAlN and duHolaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
duHolN: see the next preceding paragraph.

daHilN Wicked, deceitful, guileful, artful, crafty, or cunning; (AA, Ṣ;) as also daHinN: (AA, Ṣ in art. dHn:) or very crafty and deceitful or guileful: (AZ, Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or cunning, ingenious, or clever, and skilful; as also daHinN. (TA.) See also daHuwlN, last sentence.

One who diminishes the price, or demands a diminution of the price, or vies in niggardliness, or in acuteness, in a case of selling or buying, [app. the latter,] in order that he may attain, or so that he attains, the object of his want. (T, Ḳ, TA.)
Having much wealth. (O, Ḳ.)
Flabby and large and wide in the belly. (Ḳ,* TA.) Fat, short, and flabby and prominent, or large and flabby, in the belly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
daHolapN A well. (ISd, Ḳ.)
biYorN daHolaMCu A well narrow in the head [or upper part]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

biYorN daHuwlN A well hollowed in the sides, the water having eaten its interior: (Ṣ:) or a well of which the water, when it has been dug [and cased], is found to be beneath the rock on which its casing rests, wherefore it is dug [further] until its water is fetched out (Ḳ, TA) from beneath that rock: (TA:) and a well wide in the sides. (Ḳ.) And HuforapN daHuwlN A hollow, or cavity, made deep, not in a straight direction, or not evenly. (Ḥam p. 477.)
daHuwlN also signifies A she-camel that keeps aside from the other camels, over against them; (Ḳ,* TA;) like EanuwdN. (TA.)
Also A flatterer: and an impostor, or a cheat: and so daHilN↓. (KL.)
daHiylapN: see daHolN, near the end of the paragraph.
daH-aAlN One who hunts, or catches game, by making use of the daAHuwl: so in the verse cited voce daAHuwlN. (TA.)
daAHilN Very rancorous, malevolent, malicious, or spiteful; wont to hide enmity, and violent hatred, in his heart, and to watch for opportunities to indulge it, or exercise it. (Az, TA.)

daAHuwlN [an arabicized word from the Pers. daAxuwlo] A thing which the hunter of gazelles sets up [for the purpose of scaring them into his toil or into the neighbourhood of his place of concealment], consisting of pieces of wood: (Ṣ:) or a thing which the hunter sets up for [the purpose of scaring] the [wild] asses, (Ḳ, TA,) and Az adds, and the gazelles, (TA,) consisting of pieces of wood like short spears (Ḳ,* TA) stuck in the ground, with some pieces of ragged cloth upon their heads; and sometimes set up at night, for [the purpose of scaring] the gazelles, with the addition of a lighted lamp; (TA;) [whence] Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
wayaXorabona OajonFAw Aln-ujuwmu kaOan-ahaA
maSaAbiyHu daH-aAlK↓ yucak-iI cubaAlahaA
[And they drink water that is altered for the worse in taste and colour, while the stars are like the lamps of the hunter by means of the dAHwl when he makes their wicks to blaze brightly]: (TA:) the pl. is dawaAHiylu. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. daHaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers. daHawotu, (Ṣ,) aor. yadoHuw, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. daHowN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He spread; spread out, or forth; expanded; or extended; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a thing; (Ṣ;) and, when said of God, the earth; (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also daHaI, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers. daHayotu, (Ḳ in art. dHI,) aor. yadoHaI, inf. n. daHoIN: (Mṣb, and Ḳ in art. dHI:) or He (God) made the earth wide, or ample; as explained by an Arab woman of the desert to Sh: (TA:) also, said of an ostrich, (Ṣ, TA,) he expanded, and made wide, (TA,) with his foot, or leg, the place where he was about to deposit his eggs: (Ṣ,* TA:) and, said of a man, he spread,, &c., and made plain, even, or smooth. (TA in art. dHI.)
Also, said of a man, (Ḳ,) aor. yadoHuw, inf. n. daHowN, (TA,) i. q. jaAmaEa; (Ḳ;) as also dajaA; on the authority of IAạr. (TA.) [You say, daHaAhaA He compressed her; like as you say, dajaAhaA.]

Also He threw, or cast, and impelled, propelled, or removed from its place, a stone, with his hand. (TA.) One says also, to him who is playing with walnuts, OaboEidi AlmadaIwaQdoHuhu, meaning [Make thou the distance far, and] throw it. (Ṣ, TA.) See also midoHaApN, in two places. And of a torrent, one says, daHaA biQlobaToHaACi It cast along [the soft earth and pebbles in its course; or drove them along]. (TA.) And of rain, one says, daHaA AlHaSaI Eano wajohi AlOaroDi (Ṣ, Mṣb) It drove the pebbles from the surface of the earth; (Mṣb;) or removed them. (TA.) [See also daHaI, in the next art.] And Ald-aHowu biAlHijaArapi also signifies The vying, one with another, in throwing stones, and striving to surpass [in doing so]; as also AlmudaAHaApu↓ [inf. n. of daAHaI]. (TA.)
mar-a yadoHuw, inf. n. daHowN, said of a horse, He went along throwing out his fore legs without raising his hoofs much from the ground. (Ṣ, TA.)

daHaA AlbaTonu The belly was, or became, large, and hanging down; (Kr, Ḳ;) and AndHI↓ it (the belly) was, or became, wide, or distended: (MF:) or both signify it (the belly) became swollen, or inflated, or big, and hung down, by reason of fatness or disease; as also daAHa and AinodaAHa. (TA in art. dwH.)

entry.sense: 3. dAHI, inf. n. mudaAHaApN: see 1.

5. tdH-I He spread out, or extended, himself; syn. tabas-aTa. (Ḳ in art. dHI.) You say, naAma fulaAnN fatadaH-aI Such a one slept, and [extended himself so that he] lay upon a wide space of ground. (TA in that art.)

And tadaH-atu AlUibilu fiI AlOaroDi The camels made hollows in the ground where they lay down, it being soft; leaving therein cavities like those of bellies: thus they do only when they are fat. (El-'Itreefee, TA in art. dHI.)
7: see 1, last sentence.
9. AidoHawaI [of the measure AifoEalala for AifoEal-a, like AiroEawaI,] It (a thing, TA) was, or became, spread, spread out or forth, expanded, or extended. (Ḳ.)

daAHK [act. part. n. of 1]. Aall-ehum-a daAHiIa AlmadoHuw-aAti↓, in a prayer of ʼAlee, means O God, the Spreader and Expander of the [seven] earths: (TA:) AlmadoHuw-aAtN [properly] signifies the things that are spread,, &c.; as also AlmadoHiy-aAtN↓. (TA in art. dHI.)
AlmaTara Ald-aAHiI The rain that removes [or drives] the pebbles from the surface of the earth. (TA.)

OudoHiI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [originally OudoHuwIN, of the measure OufoEuwlN from daHayotu, but said in the Ṣ to be of that measure from daHawotu, the dial. var. daHayotu not being there mentioned,] and UidoHiI-N and OudoHiy-apN↓ and OudoHuw-apN↓, (Ḳ,) The place of the laying of eggs, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of the hatching thereof, (Ṣ,) of the ostrich, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the sand; (Ḳ;) because that bird expands it, and makes it wide, with its foot, or leg; for the ostrich has no [nest such as is termed] EuX-: (Ṣ:) pl. OadaAHK (TA in the present art.) and AdAHI [i. e., if not a mistranscription, OadaAHiI-N, agreeably with the sing.]: (TA in art. dHI:) and madoHFI↓ [likewise] signifies the place of the eggs of the ostrich. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] binotu OudoHiy-apK↓ A female ostrich. (TA.)

[Hence also,] AlOudoHiI-N and AlUidoHiI-N † A certain Mansion of the Moon, (Ḳ, TA,) [namely, the Twenty-first Mansion,] between the naEaAYim and saEod Alc-aAbiH; [more commonly] called Albalodapu: likened to the AdH-I of the ostrich. (TA.)
OudoHuw-apN and OudoHiy-apN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places:
and for the latter {OudoHiy-apN}, see also midoHaApN, below.
madoHFI: see OudoHiI-N.
midoHaApN A wooden thing with which a child is driven along (yudoHaI), and which, passing over the ground, sweeps away everything against which it comes. (Ḳ, TA.)

Accord. to Sh, A certain thing with which the people of Mekkeh play: he says, I heard El-Asadee describe it thus: AlmadaAHiI and AlmasaAdiI- signify stones like the [small round cake of bread called] quroSap, according to the size of which a hole is dug, and widened a little: then they throw those stones (yadoHuwna↓ bihaA) to that hole; and if the stone fall therein, the person wins; but if not, he is overcome: you say of him, yadoHuw↓ and yasoduw when he throws the stones (UicaA daHaAhaA) over the ground to the hole: and the hole is called OudoHiy-apN↓. (TA.) [Accord. to Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán El-Hudhaleeyeen, A round thing made of lead, by the throwing of which persons contend together.]
AlmadoHuw-aAtu and AlmadoHiy-aAtu: see daAHK.
1. daHaI, first pers. daHayotu, aor. yadoHaI, inf. n. daHoIN: see 1 in art. dHw.
daHayotu AlUibila, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) I drove the camels; (Ḳ;) as also caHayotuhaA. (TA.)
[4. mentioned by Freytag as on the authority of the Ḳ is a mistake for 5.]
5. (mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ and TA): see art. dHw.
7. (mentioned in this art. by MF): see art. dHw.

hom.sense: daHayotuhu A single act of daHoIN, i. e. spreading,, &c. (Mṣb.)
A she-ape, or she-monkey. (Ḳ.)
diHoyapN A mode, or manner, of daHoIN, i. e. spreading,, &c. (Mṣb.)

A headman, or chief, (R, Ḳ, TA,) in an absolute sense, in the dial. of El-Yemen, (R, TA,) and particularly, of an army, or a military force. (Ḳ, TA.) AA says that it originally signifies “a lord,” or “chief,” in Pers.; but seems to be from daHaAhu, aor. yadoHuwhu, meaning “he spread it, and made it plain or even;” because it is for the headman or chief to do this; the w being changed into I as it is in SiboyapN and fitoyapN; and if so, it belongs to art. dHw. (TA.) [Accord. to Golius, the pl. is diHaMCN; but I think that it is more probably diHFI.] It is said in a trad. that what is called Albayotu AlmaEomuwru [q. v. in art. Emr] is entered every day by seventy thousand companies of angels, every one of these companies having with it a diHoyap and consisting of seventy thousand angels. (TA.)

entry.sense: OudoHiI-N and UidoHiI-N: see art. dHw.
OudoHiy-apN: see OudoHiI-N, in art. dHw, in two places.
midoHaApN (mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ): see art. dHw.
AlmadoHiy-aAtN: see daAHK, in art. dHw.
Q. 1. daxodara He gilded an earring: (Ḳ:) from the noun following. (TA.)

daxodaArN A white, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or black, (Ḳ,) garment, or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is laid up, or preserved [in a chest, or wardrobe, whence its name]: (Ṣ:) an arabicized word, originally taxoto daAro, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is Persian, and means yumosikuhu Alt-axotu, i. e. cuw taxotK. (Ṣ.) [Golius, app. misled by the words ASl txt dAr Ast, in the KL of Ibn-Maạroof, probably corrupted in the copy of that work used by him, adds to the explanation “pannus albus”, &c., as from the work above mentioned, “qui throno Regis Persici quondam insterni solebat: inprimis Darii.”]
Also Gold; (Ḳ;) because preserved in chests. (TA.)

1. daxara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoxaru}; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and daxira, aor. _a {yadoxaru}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. of the former, duxuwrN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and (of the latter, TA) daxarN; (Ḳ, TA; in the CK duxorN;) He was, or became, object, mean, contemptible, or despicable. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
4. Adxrhu He (God, A, or a man, Mṣb) rendered him abject, mean, contemptible, or despicable. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
8. Ad-xr: see art. cxr.
daAxirN, applied to a man, Abject, mean, contemptible, or despicable. (Ṣ, TA.)
mud-axirN: see art. cxr.
dixoriSN, and with p {dixoriSapN}: see what follows.

dixoriySN (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dixoriySapN, (TA voce tixoriySN,) or dixoriSN↓ and dixoriSapN↓, (AA, TA,) or the last two are sometimes used, (Mgh,) and are dial. vars. of the first. (Mṣb,) [A gore] of a shirt, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) and of a coat of mail, (TA,) or [any] garment; (Mṣb;) a piece with which it is widened; (Mgh;) that with which the body thereof is joined together to widen it; (TA;) i. q. tixoriySN, (Ḳ,) which is a dial. var.; (TA;) arabicized, (Lth, T, Mṣb,) from tiyriyzN, (Lth, Ḳ voce txryS,) which is Persian; (Lth;) called by the Arabs [in their proper language] baniyqapN [q. v.]: (AʼObeyd, IAạr, Mṣb, TA:) or, as some say, Arabic: (Mṣb:) pl. daxaAriySu. (AA, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. daxala, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yadoxulu}, (TA,) inf. n. duxuwlN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and madoxalN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He, or it, entered; or went, came, passed, or got, in; contr. of xaraja; (Ḳ;) as also Aid-axala↓, of the measure AifotaEala, and Andxl↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) this last occuring in poetry, but not chaste, (Ṣ,) and tdx-l↓, (Ḳ,) or this signifies it (a thing) entered by little and little. (Ṣ, O.) You say, daxalotu madoxalFA HasanFA [like duxuwlFA HasanFA I entered with a good entering]. (Ṣ.) And daxalotu Albayota (Ṣ) or Ald-aAra, i. e. [I entered the house, or] I became within the house, and the like, (Mṣb,) correctly meaning UilaI Albayoti [&c., or fiI Albayoti, &c., i. e.
