I entered into the house,, &c.], the prep. being suppressed, and the noun put in the accus. case after the manner of an objective complement: for nouns of place are of two kinds, vague and definite; the vague being such as the six relative locations, xalofN, and qud-aAmN, and yamiynN, and XimaAlN, and fawoqN, and taHotN, and the like, such as OamaAmN, and waraMCN, and OaEolaI, and Oasofalu, and Einoda, and laduno, and wasoTN in the sense of bayonN, and qubaAlapN, all which, and similar nouns of place, may become adverbs, because indefinite; for dost thou not see that what is xalof to thee may be qud-aAm to another? but that which is definite, having make, and corporeal substance, and tracts that comprehend it, as a mountain and a valley and a market and a house and a mosque, the noun signifying such a thing cannot become an adverb; for you may not say, qaEadotu Ald-aAra, nor Sal-ayotu Almasojida, nor nimotu Aljabala, nor qumotu AlwaAdiIa; the phrases of this kind that occur being instances of the suppression of a prep.; as daxalotu Albayota, and nazalotu AlwaAdiIa, and SaEidotu Aljabala. (Ṣ, O, TA.) You say also, daxalotu EalaI zayodK Ald-aAra, meaning I entered the house after Zeyd, he being in it. (Mṣb.) [And simply daxala Ealayohi He came in upon him: and also he came upon him; i. e. invaded him.] And daxala biQmoraOatihi, (Mṣb, TA,) and EalayohaA, (MA,) inf. n. duxuwlN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) [like daxala biOaholihi, and EalayohaA, (see OaholN,) i. e. ‡ He went in to his wife or woman,] is a metonymical phrase, denoting AljimaAE, (Mṣb, TA,) i. e. AlwaToC, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) whether it be such as is allowed by the law or such as is forbidden, (Mgh,) generally such as is lawful. (Mṣb, TA. [See what is said in explanation of the term xalowapN in the first paragraph of art. xlw.]) And daxala baEoDuhu fiI baEoDK i. q. tadaAxala [q. v.]. (TA in art. qSr, &c.) [For ex.,] you say, daxala baEoDu Aln-ujuwmi fiI baEoDK [The stars became confused together]. (Mgh and TA in art. Xbk: in the former coupled with AixotalaTato.) And daxala fiyhimo [He entered among them, so as to become a member of their community, confraternity, party, sect, or the like;] said of a stranger. (Ḳ.) [And daxala fiI TaAEatihi: see TaAYiEN, in art. TwE.] When daxala is said of income, or revenue, [meaning It came in, accrued, or was received,] the aor. is as above, and the inf. n. daxolN: (Mṣb:) and you say, yadoxulu EalaI AlUinosaAni [It comes in, or accrues, to the man]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.*) daxala bihi [lit. He entered with him, or it]: see 4.

[Hence, daxala fiyhi meaning † It became included, comprehended, or comprised, in it. And hence,] daxala fiI diyni AlUisolaAmi † [He entered within the pale of the religion of El-Islám; he entered the communion of that religion; he entered into, embraced, or became a proselyte to, that religion]. (Mṣb in art. slm, &c. [See Ḳur cx. 2.]) And daxala fiI AlOamori, inf. n. duxuwlN, † He entered upon, began, or commenced, the affair. (Mṣb.) [And daxala fiI Oamori gayorihi, and Oumuwri gayorihi, and tdx-l↓, and tdAxl↓ † He entered into, or mixed himself in, another's affair, and another's affairs.]
[Hence also, daxala Ealayohi said of night, &c., It came upon him, or invaded him. And said of a word, such as a prep., &c., It was, or became, prefixed to it, preposed to it, or put before it.]

[daxalaniI minohu seems (from an instance in art. bDE in the Ḳ) to mean † An evil opinion of him entered my mind; from daxolN as signifying “a thing that induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion.”]

duxila, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like EuniIa; (Ḳ;) and daxila, aor. _a {yadoxalu}; inf. n. [of the former] daxolN and [of the latter] daxalN; (Ḳ;) † He had an unsoundness (daxalN, Ṣ, Ḳ, i. e. fasaAdN, Ḳ) in his intel-lect, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in his body, (Ḳ,) or in his grounds of pretension to respect. (TA in explanation of the former verb.) And daxila Oamoruhu, aor. _a {yadoxalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. daxalN, (TA,) † His affair, or case, or state, was, or became, intrinsically bad or corrupt or unsound. (Ḳ.)
duxila AlT-aEaAmu The corn, or food, became eaten by worms or the like. (JK.)
duxila Ealayohi † He was led into a mistake, or an error, respecting a thing, without knowing it, by his having preconceived it. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2. dx-l, inf. n. tadoxiylN, He put dates into a dawoxal-ap [q. v.]. (TA.) [In the present day, dx-lhu is used in the first of the senses assigned below to Oadoxalahu; but for this I have not found any classical authority.]

3. mudaAxalapN [inf. n. of dAxl] signifies The entering [with another] into a place: or † into an affair. (KL.) You say, dAxlhu fiI Oumuwrihi † [He entered with him into, or mixed with him in, his affairs]. (JK, Ṣ.) And daAxalahumo [alone † He entered with them into, or mixed with them in, their affairs: he mixed with them in familiar, or social, intercourse: he conversed with them; or was, or became, intimate with them]. (Lḥ, TA in the present art. and in art. xlT. [See 3 in art. xlT.]) And daAxalahu fasaAdN fiI EaqolK Oawo jisomK † [Unsoundness in intellect, or body, infected him, as though commingling with him; like xaAlaTahu]. (Ḳ.) dixaAlN [also is an inf. n. of dAxl]: see 6, in two places.
[See also dixaAlN below.]

4. Adxlhu, inf. n. UidoxaAlN and mudoxalN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made, or caused, him, or it, to enter; or to go, come, pass, or get, in; he put in, inserted, brought in, or introduced, him, or it; as also daxala↓ bihi [lit. he entered with him, or it], (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. duxuwlN. (TA.)
You say, Oadoxalotu zayodFA Ald-aAra, [for fiI Ald-aAri, I made, or caused, Zeyd to enter the house, or I brought, or introduced, Zeyd into the house,] inf. n. mudoxalN. (Mṣb.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xvii. 82], rab-i OadoxaloniI mudoxala SidoqK (Ṣ,* TA) O my Lord, cause me to enter El-Medeeneh in a good, or an agreeable, manner: (Jel: [see also various similar explanations in Bḍ:]) [or mudoxal↓ may be here a n. of place, or of time: see, in art. xrj, what is said of the words of the Ḳur that follow, OaxorijoniI maxoraja SidoqK.] One says also, Oadoxalotu Alxuf-a fiI rijoliI and Alqalanosuwapa fiI raOosiI [for Oadoxalotu rijoliI fiI Alxuf-i and raOosiI fiI Alqalanosuwapi I put, or inserted, my leg, or foot, into the boot and my head into the cap]. (Ḥam p. 43.)
Hence the saying, yudoxilu EalaI qawomihi makoruwhFA yaloTaxuhumo bihi [He brings against his people an abominable, or evil, charge, aspersing them with it]. (Ṣ in art. Er.)
5: see 1, first sentence: and again in the latter half of the paragraph.

hom.sense: 6. tdAxl signifies daxala baEoDuhu fiI baEoDK [One part of it entered into another, or parts of it into others; meaning it became intermixed, intermingled, commixed, or commingled; it intermixed; it became confused: and hence it often means it became compact, or contracted]. (TA in art. qSr.) [Hence,] tadaAxalN signifies The entering of joints one into another; (M;) as also dixaAlN↓ (JK, M, Ḳ) and daxiylN↓; (Ḳ;) but this last is not in the M [nor in the JK], and requires consideration: (TA:) [perhaps the joints (mafaASil) here mentioned are those of a coat of mail; for it is said immediately before in the JK that dixaAlN in coats of mail signifies firmness, or compactness, of make. Hence also,] tadaAxulu All-ugaAti [The intermixture, or commixture, of dialects]. (Mz 17th nwE.) And tadaAxulu AlOumuwri † The dubiousness and confusedness of affairs; as also dixaAlu↓ AlOumuwri. (TA.)
See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

[It is also trans.] You say, tadaAxalani minohu XaIoCN [Something thereof, or therefrom, crept into me, i. e., into my mind]. (Ṣ, TA. [In the former, this meaning seems to be indicated by what there immediately precedes.]) And tadaAxalaniI mino hecaA AlOamori ramaDN † [Distress and disquietude, or grief, crept into me from, or in consequence of, this thing]. (A and TA in art. rmD.)

entry.sense: 7: see 1, first sentence.
8. Uid-axala: see 1, first sentence. Ad-xl EalaI-a [app. He encroached upon me]. (TA in art. hyD: see 1 in that art.)
10. Astdxl He wished, desired, asked, or begged, to enter. (KL.)
And He entered a xamar [or covert of trees, &c., or some other place of concealment]: said of one lurking to shoot, or cast, at objects of the chase. (TA.)

hom.sense: daxolN Income, or revenue, or profit, that comes in, or accrues, to a man from his immovable property, such as land and houses and palm-trees, &c., (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and from his merchandise; (Mṣb;) contr. of xarojN; (Ṣ;) as also madoxuwlN↓ [for madoxuwlN bihi]: (TA:) the former is originally an inf. n., of which the verb is daxala, aor. _u {yadoxulu}. (Mṣb.) You say, daxoluhu Oakovaru mino xarojihi [His income is more than his outgoings, or expenditure]. (Mṣb.)
See also duxolapN.

A disease; (Ḳ;) as also daxalN↓: (Ḳ, TA; but not decisively shown to have this meaning in the CK:) a vice, fault, defect, or blemish; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and particularly in one's grounds of pretension to respect, (Az, TA,) as also, thus restricted, daxalN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) and a thing that induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; as also daxalN↓ [app. in all the senses explained in this sentence: each originally an inf. n.: see duxila and daxila]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, (Ṣ, TA,) of _u Athmeh Bint-Matrood, (TA,)
taraI AlfitoyaAna kaAln-axoli
wamaA yudoriyka biAld-axoli
[Thou seest the youths, or young men, like palmtrees; but what will acquaint thee with the vice,, &c., that is, or may be, in them]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) applied in relation to him who is of pleasing aspect, but devoid of good. (O, TA. [See also another reading of this verse voce raqolapN.])
See also dixaAlN:
and daxilN.

entry.sense: duxolN [A species of millet;] i. q. jaAwarosN; as also duxonN. (TA.)
dixolN: see duxolapN.

hom.sense: daxalN primarily signifies A thing that enters into another thing and is not of it. (Bḍ in xvi. 94.) See daxolN, in three places. Also Badness, corruptness, or unsoundness; or a bad, a corrupt, or an unsound, state or quality; (Ṣ in art. dgl, and Ḳ;) in intellect or in body [&c.]. (Ḳ.) You say, fiI Eaqolihi daxalN [In his intellect is an unsoundness]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And hecaAAlOamoru fiyhi daxalN and dagalN [This affair, or case, in it is an unsoundness]: both signify the same. (Ṣ.)
Rottenness in a palm-tree. (TA.)
Leanness, or emaciation. (TA.)

Perfidiousness, faithlessness, or treachery: (Ḳ and TA; but not in the CK:) deceit, guile, or circumvention. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xvi. 96], walaA tat-axicuwA OayomaAnakumo daxalFA bayonakumo [And make ye not your oaths to be a means of] deceit, or guile, or circumvention, between you. (Ṣ, TA. [And in the same sense it is used in verse 94 of the same ch.])

Also People, or persons, who assert their relationship to those of whom they are not: (Ḳ:) in this sense thought by ISd to be a quasi-pl. n. [app. of daxiylN (q. v.), like as XarafN is of XariyfN]. (TA.) You say, humo daxalN fiI baniI fulaAnK They are, among the sons of such a one, persons who assert their relationship to them not being of them. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [But Freytag asserts, though without naming any authority, evidently taking it from the TḲ, in which I find it, that one says, hm dxl lhm, and also hw; thus applying it to a single person (which is questionable) as well as to a plurality.]
And Tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees; (Ḳ;) as also dagalN. (TA.)

entry.sense: daxilN Intrinsically bad or corrupt or unsound: and daxolN↓ occurs in the same sense at the end of a verse: this may be a contraction of the former, or it may be for cuw daxolK. (TA.)

hom.sense: daxolapN A place in which bees, (Ḳ,) or wild bees, (AA, TA,) deposit their honey. (AA, Ḳ, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
duxolapN The night of the ceremony of conducting a bride to her husband. (TA.) [In the present day, this night is commonly called layolapuAld-uxolapi; vulgarly layolap Aald-uxolaho.]

† The inward, or intrinsic, state, or circumstances, of a man; as also daAxilapN↓: (Ṣ:) or, as also dixolapN↓ and daxolapN↓ and daxiylapN↓ and daxiylN↓ and duxolulN↓ and duxolalN↓ and duxayolaMCu↓ and daAxilapN↓ and dux-alN↓ and dixaAlN↓, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to Lth, duxaAlN↓, (TA,) and dux-ayolaI↓ and dixolN↓ and daxolN↓ † a man's intention: his way of acting, or his opinion: his whole case or circumstances: his mind, or heart: and his secret. (Ḳ.) You say, huwa EaAlimN biduxolatihi † He is acquainted with his inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances. (Ṣ.) And every one of the foregoing fourteen syn. words is prefixed to the word Oamor, so that you say, Earafotu duxolapa Oamorihi, &c., meaning † I knew the whole [of the inward, or intrinsic, circumstances] of his case. (TA.) faraXotuhu dixolapa↓ OamoriI, or faraXotu lahu dixolapa OamoriI, is a post-classical prov., meaning † I laid open to him the inward, or intrinsic, and true, or real, state of my case. (Ḥar p. 306.) One says also, huwa Hasan-u Ald-ixolapi↓ and Almadoxali↓ ‡ He is good in his way of acting in his affairs: (Ḳ, TA:) and fulaAnN Hasanu Almadoxali↓ waAlmaxoraji † Such a one is good, and laudable, in his way of acting, or conduct. (TA.)

entry.sense: dixolapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places:
and see duxolulN.
Also A mixture of colours in a colour. (T, M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: duxolalN: see dux-alN.
and see also duxolapN:
and the paragraph here next following.

duxolulN † A companion, [such as is] a confidant, and special friend; as also daxiylN↓ (KL) and daxiylapN↓ [app. for SaAHibu daxiylapK] (Ḳ * and TA voce waliyjapN) and dixolapN↓ [app. for SaAHibu dixolap]: (L voce waliyjapN:) [the pl.] duxoluluwna signifies special, or particular, and choice, or select, friends: (Az, TA:) or duxolulN signifies, as also dixolalN↓ and daxiylN↓ and mudaAxilN↓, one who enters with another into the affairs of the latter: (Ḳ, TA:) [i. e.] daxiylu↓ Alr-ajuli and duxoluluhu signify the man's particular, or special, intimate, who enters with him into his affairs. (Ṣ.) You say, bayonahumaA duxolulN and dixolalN↓, meaning † Between them two is a particular, or special, intimate, who enters with them into their affairs: so says Lḥ: but ISd says, I know not what it is: accord. to the T, on the authority of AO, the meaning is, between them is brotherhood, or fraternization, and love, or affection:
and accord. to ISd and the Ḳ, duxolalN↓ AlHub-i and duxoluluhu [the latter not in the CK nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ] and daAxiluhu↓ signify † purity of inward love. (TA.)
duxoluluwna signifies also Persons of the lower, or lowest, sort, who enter among a people, or party, of whom they are not: thus having two contr. meanings. (Az, TA.)

Aldxll [app. Ald-uxolulu] and Ald-ux-aAlu↓ [thus in the TA] and Ald-aAxilu↓, accord. to IAạr, all signify The same as dax-aAli↓ AlOucuni [an appellation now applied to the ear-wig; in the Ḳ, art. Eqrb, said to be the EuqorubaAn, but not as meaning the Eaqorab or the male Eaqorab]: accord. to AZ, it is the hrnSAn [i. e. hironiSaAn or hirinoSaAn, a kind of worm, the species of which is doubtful]. (TA.)
See also dix-alN.
And see duxolapN.

entry.sense: dixolalN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
dixolilN A portion of flesh (in some copies of the Ḳ of fat, TA) in the midst of flesh. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: duxaAlN: see dixaAlN:
and see also duxolapN.
dixaAlN [an inf. n. of 3, q. v.].

In watering, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) it is The putting in a camel, that has drunk, between two camels that have not drunk, (Ḳ,) or the bringing back a camel, that has drunk, from the resting-place by the water, to the watering-trough, and putting him in between two thirsty camels, (Ṣ,) in order that he may drink what, may-be, he has not drunk: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in like manner it is explained in the T, on the authority of Aṣ, who adds that this is done only when the water is scanty: (TA:) or the putting in a weak or sick camel [that has already drunk] with those that are drinking, and then, after that, with those that are returning to the water, so that he drinks three times: (Skr:) or the driving of camels to the watering-trough a second time, in order that they may complete their drinking, after they have already been watered drove by drove: (JK, TA:) so says Lth; but the approved explanation is that of Aṣ: (TA:) or the driving of camels to the watering-trough at once, all together; as also daxolN↓. (JK.)
The forelocks of a horse; (Ḳ;) because of their entering, one into another; (TA;) as also duxaAlN↓: (Ḳ:) so in the M. (TA.)
See also duxolapN.
daxiylN A guest. (M, TA.) Hence the saying of the vulgar, OanaA daxiylu fulaAnK [I am the guest of such a one; generally meaning I am under his protection]. (TA.)
See also duxolulN, in three places.

[An adventive abider among a people.] You say, fulaAnN daxiylN bayona Alqawomi Such a one is a person abiding among the people, not related to them. (Mṣb.) And huwa daxiylN fiyhimo He is a stranger to them (M, Ḳ) who has entered, (M,) or who enters, (Ḳ,) among them: (M, Ḳ:) applied also to a female. (TA.) [See daxalN, which is app. a quasi-pl. n. of daxiylN in this sense.]
Hence, A subject of discourse introduced by way of digression, or as having some relation to the class, or category, of the proper subjects treated of, but not included therein. (Mṣb.)

And A word that is adventitious, not indigenous, to the language of the Arabs; that is introduced into that language, and does not belong to it. (Ḳ.) There are many such words in the Jemharah of Ibn-Dureyd. (TA.)
And A horse that is introduced between two other horses in a race for a wager. (JK, O, TA.) [See muHal-ilN.] See also daxiyliI-u.
And see duxolapN:
and daAxilN.
It is also said in the Ḳ to be syn. with dixaAlN in a sense explained above: see 6.

entry.sense: daxiylapN: see duxolapN:
and duxolulN.
duxayolaMCu: see duxolapN.

daxiyliI-N A gazelle [and any animal] brought up in, or near, the house or tent, and there fed, syn. rabiybN, (IAạr, Ḳ, TA,) like OaholiI-N, (TA,) upon the neck of which are hung cowries. (IAạr, TA.) And A horse that is fed only with fodder: so accord. to Aboo-Naṣr and others: a meaning erroneously assigned in the Ḳ to daxiylN↓. (TA.) Accord. to Skr, A horse of a race called banaAtu daxiylK. (TA.)
duxayoliyaMCu [in the CK with p in the place of the C] A certain game of the Arabs. (JK, O, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: dux-alN Herbage that enters among the stems of trees, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or among the lower parts of the branches of trees, (M, TA,) or among the branches of trees, and cannot be depastured by reason of its tangled state; also termed Euw-acN. (T, TA.)

The feathers, or portions of feathers, that enter between the ZuhoraAn and buTonaAn [here app. meaning the outermost and innermost portions]: (Ḳ:) they are the best thereof, because the sun does not strike upon them. (TA.)

A portion, or portions, of flesh, or of muscle, lying within sinews: (M, Ḳ:) or flesh whereof one portion is intermixed with another: (TA:) or dux-alu All-aHomi means flesh that cleaves to the bone; and such is the best of flesh. (T, TA.)
Applied to a man, (TA,) Thick, and compact, or contracted, in body; (Ḳ,* TA;) lit, having one portion thereof inserted into another. (TA.)

A certain bird, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of small size, (Ṣ, TA,) dust-coloured, (Ḳ, TA,) that alights upon palm-trees and other trees, and enters among them; (TA;) also called duxolalN↓ and duxolulN↓: (Ḳ:) n. un. dux-alapN: ISd says that it is an intrusive bird, smaller than the sparrow, found in El-Ḥijáz: accord. to the T, it is a kind of small bird, like the sparrow, that has its abode in caves and in dense trees: AḤát says, in “the Book of Birds,” that the dux-alap is a certain bird that is found in caves, and enters houses or tents, and is caught by children: when winter comes, the birds of this kind disperse; and some of them become of a dusky colour, and of a dark and somewhat reddish colour, and gray (zaroqaMC); and some, variegated with blackness and redness, and with whiteness: they are of the size of the lark, but the latter is larger than they are in the head; neither short nor long in the tail; but short in the legs, which are like the legs of the lark: (TA:) the pl. is daxaAxiylu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is anomalous in respect of the insertion of the I: (M:) in the T, dxAlyl [which is app. a mistranscription]. (TA.)
See also duxolapN.

entry.sense: dux-alapN Any compact portion of flesh. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
Also n. un. of dux-alN [q. v.]. (TA.)
dax-aAlN That enters [into anything] much, or often; wont to enter. (TA.) [See das-aAsN.]
[Hence,] dax-aAlu AlOucuni: see duxolulN.
Ald-ux-aAlu: see duxolulN.
dux-ayolaI: see duxolapN.
daAxilN [act. part. n. of 1, Entering,, &c. Hence,] Ald-aAxilu as meaning dax-aAlu AlOucuni: see duxolulN.
It is [also] applied as an epithet to a disease, and to love; [as meaning Internal, or inward;] and so daxiylN↓, in the same sense. (Ḳ.)

[Also, as a subst.,] The interior of anything; (M, Mṣb,* TA;) contr. of xaArijN. (Mṣb.) Sb says that it is not used adverbially unless with a particle; [so that you may not say daAxilFA as meaning Within; but you say fiI daAxilK; and in like manner you say UilaI daAxilK meaning In, or inwards; and mino daAxilK meaning From within;] i. e. it is only a subst.; because it has a special signification, like yadN and rijolN. (TA.)
daAxilu AlHub-i: see duxolulN.

daAxilapu AlUizaAri The part of the AzAr [or waist-wrapper] that is next the body; (Mgh;) the extremity of the AzAr that is next the body, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) next the right side (Ḳ, TA) of a man when he puts it on; being the inner extremity in that case: and the part of the body which is the place thereof; not of the AzAr: IAmb says that, accord. to some, it is a metonymical term for the macaAkiyr [meaning the penis with what is around it]: or, accord. to some, the hip, or haunch. (TA.)

daAxilapu AlOaroDi The part of the ground that may serve as a place for concealment, and that is low, or depressed: pl. dawaAxilu. (T, Ḳ.) One says, maA fiI OaroDihimo daAxilapN mino xamarK [There is not in their land a place for concealment such as a hollow or a covert of trees]. (TA.)
[In the Ḳ and TA in art. jwz, the term daAxilap is applied to Bad pieces of money intermixed and concealed among good pieces; as is there indicated in the Ḳ, and plainly shown in the TA.]
Ald-awaAxilu in the phrase Ald-awaAxilu waAlxawaAriju has been explained in art xrj. (Mṣb. See xaArijapN.)
See also duxolapN, in two places.

dawoxal-apN and dawoxalapN, with and without teshdeed, A thing [or receptacle] made of palm-leaves woven together, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which fresh ripe dates are put, (ISk, Ṣ,) or in which dates are put: (Ḳ:) pl. dawaAxiylu, occurring in poetry, [the I being app. inserted by poetic license,] (TA,) and dawaAxilu. (Ḳ in art. lhv.)
madoxalN An entrance, i. e. a place of entrance, or ingress, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) of a house [or the like; and any inlet]. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] ‡ A way of acting. (Ḳ, TA: see duxolapN, last sentence, in two places.) [And madoxalu xayorK † A means of attaining, or doing, good.]
[Also A time of entrance.]
mudoxalN is syn. with UidoxaAlN: and is also the pass. part. n. of Oadoxalahu: (Ṣ:) [and a n. of place: and of time:] see 4.

Also † Base, base-born, or ignoble; of suspected origin or lineage, or adopted, or who claims for his father one who is not: (Ḳ,* TA:) because he is introduced among a people [to whom he is not related]. (TA.)
[midoxalN An instrument by means of which one enters: mentioned by Golius as meaning a key; on the authority of Ibn-Seenà (Avicenna).]
mud-axalFA, in the Ḳur [ix. 57, accord. to the most usual reading, there meaning A place into which to enter], is originally mudotaxalFA. (TA.)

hom.sense: madoxuwlN [for madoxuwlN bihi]: see daxolN.
madoxuwlN bihaA [and EalayohaA] ‡ A wife, or woman, to whom a man has gone in; meaning compressed; whether with the sanction of the law or not; (Mgh, TA;) but generally the former. (TA.)
† Having an unsoundness in his intellect, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in his body, or in his grounds of pretension to respect. (TA.)
† Emaciated. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Corn, or food, eaten by worms or the like. (TA.)
naxolapN madoxuwlapN A palm-tree rotten (Ṣ, Ḳ) within. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: mudaAxilN: see duxolulN.

naAqapN mudaAxilapN Alxaloqi A she-camel compact, and firm, or strong, in make. (TA.) And rajulN mutadAxilu↓ Aljisomi (Ḳ,* TA) A man compact, or contracted, in body; lit., having one portion thereof inserted into another. (TA.)
mutadax-alN fiI OumuwrK One who puts himself to trouble, or inconvenience, to enter into affairs. (Ḳ.) [One who intrudes in affairs.]
mutadAxilu Aljisomi: see mudaAxilN.

1. daxanati Aln-aAru, aor. _a {yadoxanu} and _u {yadoxunu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. daxonN and duxuwnN, (Ḳ,) The duxaAn of the fire rose; [i. e. the fire smoked, or sent up smoke;] as also Aid-axanat↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure AifotaEalat; (Ṣ;) and Oadoxanat↓, and dax-anat↓; (Ḳ;) the last with teshdeed, mentioned by Z. (TA.)
And daxana Ald-uxaAnu, (JK,) and AlgubaAru (Ḳ) and Aln-aqoEu, (TA,) inf. n. duxuwnN, (Ḳ) The smoke, (JK,) and ‡ the dust, (Ḳ, TA,) rose; or spread, or diffused itself. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)

And daxinati Aln-aAru, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with kesr to the x, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoxanu}, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. daxanN, (Mṣb,) The smoke (duxaAn) of the fire (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) became vehement, (JK,) or became excited, or raised, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in consequence of its having firewood, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in a fresh, or green, state, (JK,) thrown upon it, (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and being thus marred. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

daxina, aor. _a {yadoxanu}, said of food, (JK, Ḳ,) and of flesh-meat, (TA,) inf. n. daxanN, (JK,) means It was, or became, infected with smoke (duxaAn), (Ḳ, TA,) while being roasted or cooked, (TA,) and acquired its odour, (Ḳ, TA,) so that this predominated over its flavour: (TA:) [in this sense] it is said of cooked food when the cooking-pot is infected with smoke (UicaA tadax-anati↓ Alqidoru). (Ṣ, TA.)
[Hence, as is indicated in the TA, it is said of wine, or beverage, as meaning † It became altered for the worse in odour. (See daxinN.)]

[Hence also,] † It was, or became, of a dusky, or dingy, colour, inclining to black, (Ḳ, TA,) like the colour of iron: (TA:) you say daxina Aln-abotu, and daxinati Ald-aAb-apu, ‡ The plant, and the beast, became of that colour; (Ḳ, TA;) as though overspread with smoke (duxaAn); (TA;) as also daxuna, aor. _u {yadoxunu}, inf. n. duxonapN. (Ḳ.)
[Hence also,] daxina xuluquhu ‡ His nature, or disposition, was, or became, bad, corrupt, or wicked. (Ḳ, TA. [See also daxanN, below.])

hom.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

dx-nhu [He smoked it, or made it smoky]; namely, flesh-meat. (Ṣ in art. XyT.) And dx-nhu biAld-uxonapi [He fumigated it, or him, with what is termed duxonap, q. v.]; namely, a house, or tent, or chamber, (JK, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a garment, (M,) and another man. (TA.) And dax-anuwA EalaI qawomK fiI gaArK faqataluwhumo [They smoked a party of men in a cave and so killed them]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, first sentence.

Oadoxana Alz-aroEu; (JK, CK, and so in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ;) or Aid-axana↓, (so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA,) of the measure AifotaEala; (TA;) † The seed-produce became hard in the grain, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) and full therein; (JK;) being overspread with a slight duskiness, or dinginess. (TA.)

5. tdx-n i. q. tabax-ara [He fumigated himself]: (TA in art. bxr:) from Ald-uxonapu. (Mgh.) You say, of a man, tdx-n biAld-uxonapi [He fumigated himself with what is termed duxonap q. v.]; as also Aid-axana↓, of the measure AifotaEala. (TA.)
See also 1.
8: see 1:
and 5:
and 4.

duxonN A well-known kind of grain; (Mṣb;) i. q. jaAwarosN; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] the grain of the jAwrs: (JK, M, Ḳ:) or a certain grain smaller than that, very smooth, cold, dry, and constipating: (M, Ḳ:) [a species of millet; the holcus saccharatus of Linn.; holcus dochna of Forskål; sorghum saccharatum of Delile: and the holcus spicatus of Linn.: and the panicum miliaceum of Linn.: (Delile's “Flor. Aegypt. Illustr.,” no. 164: no. 57: and no. 79:)] n. un. with p {duxonapN}; signifying a single grain thereof. (Mṣb.)
daxanN inf. n. of daxina [q. v.]. (JK, Mṣb.)
[Hence,] † The appearance, or appearing, of conflict and faction, sedition, discord, or the like. (TA.)
Hence also, i. e. from daxanu Aln-aAri and AlT-abiyxi, (TA,) ‡ A state of alteration for the worse, of intellect, and of religion, and of the grounds of pretension to respect or honour. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also i. q. duxaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See this word in two places.

[Hence,] † A duskiness, or dinginess, inclining to blackness; (Ṣ TA;) as also duxonapN↓; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) [like the colour of smoke, (see 1, last signification but one,) or] like the colour of iron: (TA:) it is in a sheep, (Ṣ,) or a horse and similar beasts, or in a garment, (TA,) and in a sword: (Ṣ, A, TA:) in this last it means ‡ a blackness that appears in the broad side, by reason of its great brightness: (A, TA:) or the diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, (syn. firinod,) of a sword. (Ḳ.)
Also ‡ Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (JK, Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ Badness, corruptness, or wickedness, of nature or disposition. (Ḳ, TA.)
daxinN [applied to food, and to flesh-meat, Infected with smoke: see daxina.]
[And hence,] applied to wine, or beverage, † Altered for the worse in odour. (TA.)
And rajulN daxinu Alxuluqi (Sh, JK, Ṣ) ‡ A man bad, corrupt, or wicked, in respect of nature, or disposition. (Sh, JK, TA.) [See also daAxinN.]

hom.sense: duxonapN i. q. cariyarpN [which generally means Particles of calamus aromaticus], (Ḳ,) or the like thereof, (Ṣ,) [i. e.] incense, or a substance for fumigation, (baxuwrN, JK, Mgh, Mṣb,) [of any kind, and particularly] like cryzp, (Mgh, Mṣb,) with which houses, or tents, or chambers, (Ṣ Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or a house, or tent, or chamber, (JK, M,) and clothes, (M,) are fumigated. (JK, Ṣ M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also daxanN.

[Hence, app.,] Oabuw duxonapi or Abw duxonapa A certain bird, (IB, Ḳ, TA,) the colour of which is like that of the qub-arapN [or lark]: so says IB: or, as in some MSS., like the colour termed Alguborap [i. e. dust-colour]. (TA.)

entry.sense: yawomN daxonaAnN ‡ A hot, or an intensely hot, day: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) and layolapN daxonaAnapN ‡ a night intensely hot, (JK, TA,) in which the heat is such as takes away the breath; (TA;) as though it were overspread by smoke: (JK, TA:) or a dusky, or dingy, night, inclining to blackness. (Ṣ.)
duxonaAnN: see duxonaMCN.

duxaAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dux-aAnN↓, (Ḳ,) which latter is the form [now] commonly used, (TA,) and daxanN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. q. EuvaAnN [a less usual term, meaning Smoke]: (Ḳ: [in the Ṣ it is said merely that the duxaAn of fire is well known:]) pl. (of the first, Ṣ, Mṣb) dawaAxinu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as EawaAvinu is pl. of EuvaAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) the only other instance of the kind, (Mṣb,) deviating from rule, (Ṣ,) and dawaAxiynu, [also irreg., and both pls. of mult.,] and OadoxinapN [a pl. of pauc.]. (Ḳ.) [Hence, the tribes of] Ghanee and Báhileh (ganiI- and baAhilap) were called AibonaA duxaAnK [The two sons of smoke] (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) because they smoked a party of men (dax-anuwA EalaI qawomK) in a cave and so killed them. (TA.) Hence also, (Ṣ,) hudonapN EalaI daxanK↓ ‡ A calm [or truce] for a cause other than reconciliation: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, lagalabapK is erroneously put for liEil-apK:])
or † [as a cloak] upon [i. e. concealing] inward corruptness; from daxinati Aln-aAru explained above; [see 1;] (Mṣb;) [for] IAth says that it likens inward corruptness beneath outward rectitude to the smoke [or smoking] of fresh, or moist, firewood: (TA:) or † upon latent rancour or malevolence: (Ṣ and TA in art. hdn:) but AʼObeyd, in explaining a trad. in which it occurs, takes it from daxanN as signifying “a duskiness, or dinginess, inclining to blackness,” in the colour of a beast or of a garment; for he says that it means [a case in which] the mutual love of two parties will not become pure, like the duskiness, or dinginess, that is in the colour of a beast. (TA.)

duxaAnN is also used by the Arabs for † Evil, or mischief, when it arises; as in the saying, kaAna bayonanaA OamorN QrotafaEa lahu duxaAnN [There was between us an affair that had evil, or mischief, arising in consequence of it]. (TA.)

It also means † Dearth, drought, sterility, or unfruitfulness; and hunger: and so it has been said to mean in the Ḳur xliv. 9: for it is said that the hungry [once] saw smoke (duxaAn) between him and the sky: or hunger is thus called because of the dryness of the earth in drought, and the rising of the dust, which is likened to duxaAn [properly so termed]. (TA.)
[In the present day, it is also applied, but generally pronounced dux-aAn↓, to Tobacco; nicotiana tabacum of Linn.]
dux-aAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, first and last sentences.
daAxinN Firewood producing duxaAn [or smoke]. (TA.)
[Hence,] xuluqN daAxinN † A bad, corrupt, or wicked, nature or disposition. (TA.) [See also daxinN.]

daAxinapN [A chimney;] a hole, or perforation, [or hollow channel,] in which are pipes of baked clay (Uirodab-aAt) [for the passage of smoke]: (JK:) its pl. is dawaAxinu, (TA,) signifying holes, or apertures, [or hollow channels, for the passage of smoke,] made over frying-pans and the fire-places of baths, &c.; (Ḳ, TA;) called by the vulgar madaAxinu [pl. of madoxanapN↓]. (TA.)
Oadoxanu, applied to a ram [&c.], (JK, Ṣ,) Of a dusky, or dingy, colour, inclining to blackness: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. daxonaMCu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[A place of smoke.]
madoxanapN: see daAxinapN.

midoxanapN A vessel for fumigation; i. q. mijomarapN: (Ḳ:) or differing from the mijomarap, [app. in being made only of baked clay,] and not disapproved; whereas the mjmrp is disapproved, because generally of silver: (Mgh in art jmr:) pl. madaAxinu. (TA.)

hom.sense: dadN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, [but in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ written dad-, and said in the TA, in art ddn, to be so written by some, though it is there implied that this is of doubtful authority,]) without teshdeed, (A, TA,) like yadN, (MF,) Diversion, sport, play, or such as is vain, or frivolous; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also dadFA, like qafFA; and dadnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and dadadN↓: (Ed-Demámeenee, CK:) but accord. to IB, it should be mentioned in art. ddn [in which dadanN is mentioned again in the Ṣ and Ḳ], or art. ddw [in which dadFA is mentioned again together with dadN and dadanN]. (L.) [The proper place of dadN seems to be art. ddw (like as art. Axw is the proper place in which OaxN should be mentioned), as well as of dadFA; and the proper place of dadanN, art. ddn.] Hence, (A,) maA OanaA mino dadK walaA Ald-adu min-iI [I have no concern with diversion,, &c., nor has diversion,, &c., any concern with me]: a saying [of Moḥammad] occurring in a trad. (Ṣ, A.)
Also A space (HiynN) of time. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dadadN: see above.

dadidN [meaning Diverting himself, sporting, playing, or doing so in a vain, or frivolous, manner,] occurs [accord. to one reading] in a verse of Et-Tirimmáh [cited in this art. in the Ḳ, and in the present work in art. Trb, as an ex. of AisotaToraba]: the poet has annexed to it a third d because an epithet is not susceptible of variation unless comprising three letters: (Ḳ:) or such is the opinion of F; but this requires consideration. (MF.)

dadanN (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and dadFA and dadN; (T, Ḳ;) all mentioned by El-Aḥmar; (T;) and compared by Aboo-ʼAlee, in respect of having the last radical letter sometimes n and sometimes an infirm letter and sometimes elided, to laduno and ladaA and lado; the second like qafFA and EaSFA, and the third like yadN, (T, TA,) and by some written dad-N, with teshdeed; (TA; [but it is there implied that this is of doubtful authority;]) and the second and third said by some to be formed from the first, by the change of n into A and by the elision of n; (TA;) Diversion, sport, play, or such as is vain, or frivolous; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also dayodN, [which should be mentioned in art. dyd,] and dayadaAnN↓, (IAạr, T, Ḳ, [not dayodaAnN as in Freytag's Lex., being followed in the Ḳ by the epithet maHar-akapN,]) and dydwn↓, (TA, [app. dayoduwnN, of the measure fayoEuwlN, like tayoquwrN,]) and dayodabuwnN↓, (IAạr, T, Ṣ,) [mentioned also in the Ṣ in art. dbn,] by Ṣgh and in the Ḳ mentioned in art. ddb, and said in the Ḳ to be wrongly included by J in the present art. (TA.) dadanN and dadaAnN are the only words in which the first and second radical letters are the same, without an intervening letter, and both movent. (Ṣ.)

dadaAnN, applied to a sword, Blunt; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) that will not penetrate into the thing struck with it: (Ṣ:) and also sharp: thus bearing two contr. significations: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Th, a sword with which trees are cut; called by others miEoDadN; and this is not necessarily the contr. of a blunt sword. (TA.)

Also, applied to a man, [perhaps from the first of the significations mentioned above,] meaning laAganaMCa Einodahu [Not having, or not possessing, what suffices; or not profitable to any one]. (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

dayodanN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and diydanN↓ (TA on the authority of El-Khuwárezmee and El-Wáḥidee) and dayodaAnN↓ (IJ, Ṣ, Ḳ) and dydwn↓ [app. dayoduwnN] (TA) and dayodadaAnN↓ (Ḳ) A custom, manner, habit, or wont. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
diydanN: see what next precedes.
dayodaAnN: see what next precedes.
dayadaAnN: see dadanN.
dydwn [app. dayoduwnN]: see dadanN:
and dayodanN.
dayodabuwnN: see dadanN.
dayodadaAnN: see dayodanN.
dadN: see what follows.

dadFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like EaSFA (Ṣ) or qafFA, (TA,) and dadN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like damN (Ṣ) or yadN, (TA,) and dadanN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which last is mentioned in art. ddn, (Ṣ,) Diversion, sport, play, or such as is vain, or frivolous. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also arts. dd and ddn.]

hom.sense: 1. dar-a, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _i {yadoriru} and _u {yadoruru}, [the latter anomalous,] inf. n. dar-N (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and duruwrN, (TA,) It (milk) was, or became, copious, or abundant, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and flowed, or streamed; it flowed, or streamed, copiously, or abundantly; and so † the water of the eye, or tears, and the like, (TA,), &c.; (Mṣb;) as also Astdr-↓: (Ḳ, TA:) and, said of milk, it ran, or flowed: and it collected [or became excerned] in the udder from the ducts and other parts of the body. (TA.)
[Hence,] said of sweat, † It flowed (Ḳ) like as milk flows. (TA.)
And of the tax called xaraAj, † Its produce became abundant. (Ḳ.)
And [in like manner] one says, laAadar-a dar-uhu: see dar-N, below.
And [hence,] dar-a also signifies † It was, or became, consecutive. (Ḳ in art. dhdr.) And † It continued; as in the phrase, dar-a lahu AlX-aIoCN † [The thing continued to him]. (Sh, TA in art. jrI.)
And, said of a horse,, aor. _i {yadoriru}, inf. n. dariyrN (Ḳ) and dar-apN, (TA,) † He ran vehemently: or ran easily (Ḳ, TA) and without interruption. (TA.)
And of herbage, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dar-N, (TA,) † It became tangled, or luxuriant, (Ḳ,* TA,) by reason of its abundance. (TA.)

One says also, of a she-camel, dar-ato, (TA,) and dar-ato bilabanihaA, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoruru} and _i, [the former anomalous,] inf. n. duruwrN and dar-N; (TA;) and Adr-t↓, alone, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Adr-t↓ bilabanihaA; (Ḳ;) She yielded her milk, or made it to flow, copiously, or abundantly. (Ḳ, TA.) And dar-aAlD-aroEu biAll-abani, aor. _u {yadoruru}, (Ṣ,) or _i, (TA,)
inf. n. duruwrN, (Ṣ,) or dar-N, (TA,) [The udder abounded with milk: or yielded milk copiously, or abundantly: and Adr-↓ All-abana signifies the same; or it yielded, or emitted, the milk.]

And [hence,] dar-ato Haluwbapu Almusolimiyna, (Ṣ, A,) and liqoHatuhumo, (TA,) [lit. The milch-camel of the Muslims yielded milk copiously,] meaning ‡ the tribute, or taxes, pertaining to the Muslims poured in abundantly. (Ṣ,* A, TA.)
And dar-ati Als-amaMCu biAlmaTari, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoruru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. dar-N and duruwrN, (Ḳ,) † The sky poured down rain (Ḳ, TA) abundantly. (TA.)
And dar-abimaA Einodahu ‡ He produced, or gave forth, what he had. (A.)
And dar-ati Ald-unoyaA EalaI OaholihaA ‡ The world was bountiful to its inhabitants. (A.)
And dar-ati Als-uwqu, (Ṣ in art. gr, and Ḳ,) inf. n. dir-apN, (Ṣ ubi suprà,) ‡ The market became brisk, its goods selling much; (Ṣ ubi suprà, Ḳ, TA;) contr. of gaAr-at. (Ṣ ubi suprà.)
And dar-ati AlEuruwqu The ducts, or veins, became filled with milk, (TA,) or ‡ with blood. (A, TA.)
And dar-a AlEiroqu, inf. n. duruwrN, † The vein pulsated uninterruptedly. (TA.)

And dar-F Als-ahomu, (AḤn, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yadoriru}, (TA,) inf. n. duruwrN, † The arrow turned round well upon the nail (AḤn, Ḳ *) of the left thumb, [app. so as to produce a sound, (see Han-aAnN,)] being turned with the thumb and fore finger of the right hand [for the purpose of testing its sonorific quality]: the arrow does not thus turn, nor does it produce the kind of sound termed Haniyn, unless in consequence of the hardness of its wood, and its goodly straightness, and its compact make. (AḤn.)
dar-a also signifies It (a thing) was, or became, soft, tender, or supple. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
And It (a lamp) gave light, shone, or shone brightly. (Ḳ.)

And, aor. yadar-u. which is extr., (Ḳ,) or, as some say, the pret. is originally darira, [the sec. pers. being darirota,] and, if so, the aor. is not extr., (MF,) It (a man's face) became goodly after disease. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. Adr- [He made milk to flow, or to flow copiously, or abundantly:] he drew forth milk. (Mṣb.) See also 1, in three places.
[Hence,] Oadar-uwA AlxaraAja † They (the collectors) made the produce of the tax called xrAj to come in abundantly. (TA.)
[And Adr- Albawola † It (a medicine, &c.,) caused the urine to flow plentifully; acted as a diuretic; (see the act. part. n. below;) as also Astdrhu↓.]

Adr- Oum-ahu He (a young camel) sucked, or drew the milk of, his mother. (TA.) And Adr-hA He stroked her (a camel's) dugs, to draw her milk: he milked her; (TA;) as also AstdrhA↓, referring to a ewe or she-goat: (Mṣb:) and the latter, he stroked her dugs with his hand, causing the milk to flow, or to flow copiously: and the same verb, he sought, or desired, her milk, or the flowing of her milk. (TA.)

[Hence,] OadiruwA liqoHapa Qlmusolimiyna ‡ [Make ye. the tribute, or taxes, pertaining to the Muslims to pour in abundantly: lit., make ye the milchcamel of the Muslims to yield milk abundantly]: said by ʼOmar to the collector of the taxes. (TA.)

[Hence, also,] one says to a man, when he seeks a thing, and begs for it importunately, Oadir-ahaA waUino Oabato, meaning, [lit.,] Ply her, though she refuse, until she yield her milk abundantly. (TA.)

And Oadar-a Qll-ehu lahu OaxolaAfa Alr-izoqi ‡ [God milked for him the dugs of sustenance; i. e. provided for him the means of subsistence]: and Astd-r↓ niEomapa Qll-ehi biAlX-ukori ‡ [He drew the favour, or blessing, of God, by thankfulness]. (A.)

Alr-iyHu tudir-u Als-aHaAba, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and tasotadir-uhu↓, (Ṣ, L,) † The wind draws forth a shower of fine rain from the clouds: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ: in some copies of the last, we find, as the explanation of Oadar-ati Alr-iyHu Als-aHaAba, instead of Halabatohu, [agreeably with the above explanation,] jalabatohu, with j: the explanation in the [Ṣ and] L is tasotaHolibuhu: TA:) and nasotadir-u↓ Als-aHaAba † [We desire, or look for, a shower of rain from the clouds]. (TA in art. Hlb.)

And bayona Eayonayohi EiroqN yudir-uhu AlgaDabu (said in a trad., TA) ‡ Between his eyes was a vein which anger caused to flow; (Ṣ;*) or to fill with blood; (A;) or to become thick and full: (TA:) or which anger put in motion: (Ṣ:) for (TA) Oadar-a AlX-aIoCa signifies he put the thing in motion. (Ḳ, TA.)
Adr-t Almigozala ‡ She twisted the spindle vehemently, (A, Ḳ,) so that it seemed to be still in consequence of its vehement twirling. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And Adr- Als-ahoma † He made the arrow to turn round well upon the nail (AḤn, Ḳ *) of his left thumb, turning it with the thumb and fore finger of his right hand. (AḤn. [See 1, latter part.])
And Oadorarotu Ealayohi AlD-arobu ‡ I inflicted upon him an uninterrupted beating. (A.)

hom.sense: 10: see 1, first sentence:
and see dir-apN.
See also 4, in five places.
Astdr-t † She (a goat) desired the ram: (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and one says also Aisotacorato. (El-Umawee, Ṣ. [See art. crw.])
And Astdr- † He spoke, or talked, much. (TA in art. glt.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. darodara, (inf. n. darodarapN, TḲ,) He (a child, Ṣ) chewed, or mumbled, an unripe date (Ṣ, Ḳ) with his toothless gums. (TA.) Hence the saying of a certain Arab, to whom El-Aṣmaʼee had come, OatayotaniI waOanaA Oudarodiru [Thou camest to me when I was a child mumbling with toothless gums: or it may mean thou hast come to me when I am old, mumbling, &c.: see durodurN]. (TA.)
Also He (a man) lost his teeth, and their sockets became apparent. (TA.)

R. Q. 2. tadarodara It (a thing) was, or became, in a state of motion or commotion, or it moved about. (T in art. dl.) And tadarodarati All-aHomapu The piece of flesh quivered. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] one says of a woman, tadarodaru, [for tatadarodaru,] meaning She quivers in her buttocks, by reason of their largeness, when she walks. (TA.)

hom.sense: dar-N an inf. n. used as a subst., (Mṣb,) Milk; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also dir-apN↓. (Ḳ.) Hence, cawaAtu Ald-ar-i, and Ald-ar-u alone, Milch-animals. (TA.) And Oum-ahaAtu Ald-ar-i The teats of a camel or clovenfooted animal. (TA.)

Hence also the saying, lil-ehi dar-uka ‡ To God be attributed the good that hath proceeded from thee! or thy good deed! (TA:) or thy deed: (A:) or thy gift! and what is received from thee! [and thy flow of eloquence! and the like: when said to an eloquent speaker or poet, it may be rendered divinely art thou gifted!] a man's gift [or the like] was originally thus likened to the milk of a camel; and then this phrase became so common as to be used as expressive of admiration of anything: (Aboo-Bekr, TA:) it was first said by a man who saw another milking camels, and wondered at the abundance of their milk: (ISd, TA:) the thing alluded to therein is attributed to God to indicate that none other could be its author. (TA.) You say also, lil-ehi dar-uhu ‡ To God be attributed his deed! (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or his knowledge! or his good! or bounty! or beneficence! (Ḥar p. 418:) [&c.:] meaning praise. (Ṣ.) Accord. to IAạr, dar-N signifies ‡ A deed, whether good or evil. (TA.) Ibn-Aḥmar says, lil-ehi dar-iI [To God be attributed what hath brought me to this state!] wondering at himself. (TA.) One also says, lil-ehi dar-uka mino rajulK, which is likewise an expression of praise, (Ṣ,) meaning ‡ To God be attributed the goodness, or good action, of thee, as a man! [i. e., of such a man as thou!] (TA.) And lil-ehi dar-uhu faArisFA ‡ [To God be attributed his excellence as a horseman!]. (Mṣb.) And, in dispraise, (Ṣ,) laA dar-a↓ dar-uhu May his good, or wealth, not be, or become, much, or abundant! (Ṣ, A, TA:) or may his work not thrive! (Ḳ.) El-Mutanakhkhil says,
laA dar-a dar-iIa Uino OaToEamotu naAzilahumo
qirofa AlHat-iIi waEinodiI Albur-u makonuwzu
[May my wealth not become abundant, or may my work not thrive, if I feed him among them who is a guest with the rind of HatiI- (q. v.) when I have wheat stored up]: this verse is cited by Fr, who also mentions the phrase, dar-a dar-u fulaAnK [May the wealth of such a one become abundant! or may his work thrive!]. (TA.)
Also The soul; syn. nafosN. (Ḳ.) One says rajulN sariI-N Ald-ar-i A man of generous and manly soul. (TḲ.) And dafaEa Qll-ehu Eano dar-ihi May God defend his soul. (Lḥ.)

entry.sense: dur-N and durarN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dur-aAtN (Ḳ) pls., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or rather the first is a coll. gen. n., and the second and third are pls., (MF,) of dur-ahN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which last signifies A pearl: (Ṣ:) or a large pearl. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
dar-apN: see dir-apN.
dur-apN: see dur-N.

hom.sense: dir-apN: see dar-N, first sentence.

Also Copious, or abundant, flowing milk; milk flowing copiously, or abundantly: (TA:) and a flow, or stream, or a flowing or streaming, of milk; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and its abundance or abounding: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also dar-apN↓: (L:) or this latter signifies a single flow, or stream, of milk. (Mṣb.) Hence the prov., laA Mtiyka maA Qxotalafati Ald-ir-apu waAljir-apu I will not come to thee as long as the flow of milk and the cud go [the former] downwards and [the latter] upwards. (TA. [See also jir-apu.])

[Hence also the phrase,] lils-aHaAbi dir-apN † The clouds have a pouring forth: pl. dirarN. (Ṣ.)
En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab says,
salaAmu AlUilaAhi warayoHaAnuhu
waraHomatuhu wasamaMCN diraro
meaning caAtu dirarK [i. e. The peace, or security,, &c., of God, and his bounty, and his mercy, and a sky pouring forth showers]. (Ṣ.) Some say that dirarN signifies daAr-N↓ [flowing, or streaming; or flowing, or streaming, copiously, or abundantly]; like as qiyamFA in the Ḳur vi. 162 signifies qaAYimFA. (TA.) In like manner one says also diyamN dirarN [Lasting and still rains pouring down]. (TA.)
And lils-uwqi dir-apN † The market has a brisk traffic going on in it, its goods selling much. (AZ, Ṣ.)

And lils-aAqi dir-apN † The thigh, or shank, [of the horse or the like] has a continuous movement for running; syn. AisotidoraArN↓ lilojaroIi. (AZ, Ṣ.) You say also, mar-a Alfarasu EalaI dir-atihi, meaning † The horse passed along without being turned aside by anything. (TA. [See also musotadir-N.])
dir-apN also signifies ‡ Blood [as being likened to milk]. (Ḳ.) A poet cited by Th likens war and the blood thereof to a [raging] she-camel and her dir-ap. (TA.)
And † The means of subsistence [as being likened to milk]. (TA in art. gr. [See an ex. voce gir-apN.])
And A mode, or manner, of flowing, or streaming, of milk. (Mṣb.)

Also A certain thing with which one beats, or flogs; (Kr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. the dir-ap of the Sultán: (TA:) a whip: (Mṣb:) [app. a whip for flogging criminals; as seems to be implied in the TA: I have not found any Arab who can describe it in the present day: it seems to have been a kind of whip, or scourge, of twisted cords or thongs, used for punishment and in sport, such as is now called firoqil-ap: or a whip made of a strip, or broad strip, (see 1 in art. xfq,) of thick and tough hide, or the like: it is described by Golius and Freytag (by the latter as from the Ṣ and Ḳ, in neither of which is any such explanation found,) as “strophium ex fune aliave re contortum, aut nervus taurinus, similisve res, quibus percuti solet:”] an Arabic word, well known: (TA:) [or an arabicized word, from the Pers. dur-aho:] pl. dirarN. (A, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: dararN The right course or direction of a road: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) its beaten track: its hard and elevated part. (TA.) You say, naHonu EalaI darari AlT-ariyqi We are upon the right course [&c.] of the road. (Ṣ.) And humaA EalaI dararK waAHidK They two are following one direct course. (Ṣ.)
dararu bayotK The direction, point, place, or tract, which is in front of, or opposite to, a house. (Ḳ.) You say, daAriI bidarari daArika My house is in front of, or opposite to, thy house. (TA.)
dararu Alr-iyHi The direction, or point, from which the wind blows. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
daruwrN: see daAr-N, in two places.

hom.sense: dariyrN A horse (Ṣ, Ḳ) or similar beast (Ḳ, TA) that is swift: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or swift in running, and compact in make: (TA:) or compact and firm in make. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also dar-iI-N and musotadir-N.]
See also daAr-N.

entry.sense: dar-aMCu: see daAr-N.

hom.sense: farasN dar-iI-N (TA) or dar-iy-apN (A) A horse, or mare, that runs much. (A, TA.) [See also dariyrN and musotadir-N.]
kawokabN dar-iI-N: see the next paragraph.

AlfaArisiy-apN Ald-ar-iy-apu The chaste dialect of Persian: (Mgh:) or the most chaste dialect thereof: (TA:) so called in relation to daro, (Mgh, TA,) as the name of a district of Sheeráz, (TA,) or as meaning “a door” or “gate.” (Mgh, TA.)

entry.sense: kawokabN dur-iI-N and dir-iI-N↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and dar-iI-N↓ (Ḳ, TA) A shining, or brightly-shining, star: (Ḳ:) or a star that shines, glistens, or gleams, very brightly: (Ṣ, A:) called dur-iI-N in relation to dur- [i. e. pearls, or large pearls], (Fr, Zj, Ṣ, A,) because of its whiteness (Zj, Ṣ, A) and clearness, and beauty: (Zj:) pl. daraAriI-u. (A.) It is also termed dur-iIoCN and dir-iIoCN and dar-iIoCN. (TA. [See art. drO.])

dur-iI-N also signifies The glistening, or shining, of a sword: (Ḳ:) a rel. n. from dur-N; because of its clearness: or likened to the star so termed: it occurs in poetry; but some read car-iI-N, with c [and fet-ḥ]. (TA.)
dir-iI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
duho dur-ayoni, (Ṣ,) or duhodur-ayoni: (Ḳ:) see art. dhdr.

durodurN The part of the gums where the teeth grow: (TA:) or the part where the teeth grow of a child: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or the part where the teeth grow both before they grow and after they have fallen out: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. daraAdiru. (Ṣ.) Hence the prov., OaEoyayotiniI biOuXurK fakayofa bidurodurK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or fakayofa Oarojuwka bidurodurK, (TA,) i. e. Thou [weariedst me, and] didst not accept good advice when thou wast a young woman and when thy teeth were serrated and sharp in their extremities; then how should I hope for any good in thee now when thou hast grown old, and the places of the growth of thy teeth have become apparent by reason of age? (Ḳ,* TA.) In the Ḳ we read lamo taqobila Aln-uSoHa XaAb-FA: but it should be lamo taqobaliI Aln-uSoHa XaAb-apF. (TA.) durodurN is also said to signify The extremity, or tip, of the tongue: or, as some say, its root: but the signification commonly known is that first given above. (TA.)
darodarapN inf. n. of R. Q. 1. (TḲ.)
Also an onomatopœia meaning The sound of water rushing along in the beds of valleys. (TA.)

hom.sense: darodaArN A certain kind of tree, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known; (T;) also called Xajarapu Albaq-i: [both of these names are now applied to the elm-tree; and so both are applied by Golius:] there come forth from it various OaqomaAE [app. excrescences of the nature of gall-nuts], like pomegranates, in which is a humour that becomes baq- [i. e. bugs or gnats, for both are signified by this word]; and when they burst open, the bq- come forth: its leaves are eaten, in their fresh state, like herbs, or leguminous plants: so in the “Minháj ed-Dukkán.” (TA.)
Also The sound of the drum. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: duroduwrN A whirlpool, in which shipwreck is feared; (Ṣ;) a place in the midst of the sea, where the water is in a state of violent commotion, (T, Ḳ,) and from which a ship scarcely ever escapes. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: daAr-N: see dir-apN.

Also, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and daruwrN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dar-aMCu↓ (A) and mudir-N↓, (Ṣ,) A she-camel, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or ewe, or she-goat, (Mṣb,) abounding with milk; having much milk: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. (of the first, Ṣ, Mṣb) dur-aMrN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and one says also UibilN dururN ( a pl. of daruwrN [in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ Abl daruwrN]) and UibilN dur-arN (also a pl. of daruwrN [in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ Abl dararN]): (Ḳ, accord. to the TA:) and darwrN↓ applied to an udder signifies the same: (TA:) [and midoraArN↓ also app. signifies the same; for you say]
samaMCN midoraArN↓ ‡ A sky pouring down abundance of rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and saHaAbapN midoraArN↓ a cloud pouring down much rain. (A, TA.)
rizoqN daAr-N ‡ Continual, uninterrupted, sustenance, or means of subsistence. (TA.)
daAr-N and dariyrN↓ A lamp giving light, shining, or shining brightly. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: tadir-apN A copious flowing, or streaming, of milk. (Ḳ.)
mudir-N: see daAr-N.
mudir-N lilobawoli [and musotadir-N↓ lahu, and simply mudir-N and musotadir-N↓, A diuretic medicine, &c.]. (TA in art. jzr, &c.) And mud-irN lilT-imovi [Emmenagogue]. (Ḳ in art. AXn, &c.)
mudir-apN and mudir-N A woman twirling her spindle vehemently, so that it seems to be still in consequence of its vehement twirling. (Ḳ,* TA.)
midar-apN: see dar-aArapN.
midoraArN: see daAr-N, in three places.
musotadir-N: see mudir-N, in two places.
Also ‡ A number of arrows in their flight resembling the streaming of milk, by reason of the vehemence with which they are impelled; occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (TA.)
farasN musotadir-N fiI Eadowihi ‡ [A horse that runs far without being turned aside by anything]. (A.) [See dir-apN, and see also dar-iI-N and dariyrN.]

hom.sense:
1. daraOahu, aor. _a {yadoraOu}, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. daroCN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and daroOapN; (Ḳ;) and dr-Ohu↓; (M, TA; [or this latter has probably an intensive signification;]) He pushed it, or thrust it; or pushed it, or thrust it, away, or back; repelled it; or averted it;
syn. dafaEahu; (Ṣ,* M, Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a thing. (Mṣb.) Hence, kaAna bayona Eumara wamuEaAci boni EaforaMCa daroCN There was, between ʼOmar and Mo'ádh Ibn-'Afrà, a contending, and a mutual pushing or thrusting,, &c. (Mgh.) And daraOa Eanohumo He repelled from them, or defended them; as also daraha, which is formed by substitution from the former, like haraAqa from OaraAqa. (Ṣ in art. drh.) And daraOa Eanohu AlHad-a He averted (dafaEa) from him the prescribed castigation: (M, Mgh:) or he deferred his prescribed castigation: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to other things. (AZ, T.) It is said in a trad., AidoraWuwA AlHuduwda biAlX-ubuhaAti [Avert ye, or defer ye, the prescribed castigations on account of dubious circumstances]. (ISk, M, TA.) And AidoraWuwA AlHuduwda maA QsotaTaEotumo [Avert ye, or defer ye, the prescribed castigations as long as ye are able]. (Ṣ, form a trad.)
See also 5.

daraOa Eani AlbaEiyri AlHaqaba is explained by Sh as meaning He pushed back the kind girth of the camel: but AM says that the correct meaning is, he spread the kind girth upon the ground, and made the camel to lie down upon it [in order that he might gird him]. (TA.) [For] daraOa signifies also He spread, or laid flat, (Ḳ, TA,) a thing upon the ground. (TA.)

daraOa AlX-aIoCa biAlX-aIoCa He supported the thing by the thing; made the. thing to be a support to the thing. (TA.) [Hence,] daraOa AlHaAYiTa bibinaMCK He conjoined the wall with a structure [so as to support the former by the latter]. (TA.)
daraOa biHajarK He cast a stone; like radaOa. (TA.) You say, daraOahu biHajar and radaOahu bihi He cast a stone at him. (M in art. rdO.)

daraOa said of a torrent, (Ḳ,) inf. n. daroCN, (TA,) ‡ It rushed, or poured forth with vehemence; as also AndrO↓. (Ḳ.) And daraOa AlwaAdiI biAls-ayoli † The valley poured along the torrent. (TA.) [See also daroCN, below.]

daraOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. duruwoCN, (TA,) is syn. with TaraOa [He came from a place, or from a distant place, unexpectedly;, &c.]. (Ḳ.) And you say, daraOa EalayonaA fulaAnN, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. duruwoCN (Ṣ, TA) and daroCN; (TA;) and AndrO↓ (Ṣ, TA) and tdr-O↓; (TA;) Such a one came, or came forth, upon us unexpectedly, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) or whence we knew not; as also TaraOa, (T,) and daraha. (IAạr, TA in art. drh.) And AndrO↓ Ealayohi biXar-K, vulg. AndrI, He came upon him suddenly with evil, or mischief. (TA.)

Hence, i. e. from daraOa signifying “he came, or came forth, unexpectedly,” (T, Ṣ, TA,) daraOa, inf. n. duruwoCN, said of a star, meaning ‡ It shone, or glistened, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) intensely, (Ṣ, TA,) and its light spread: (TA:) or, as some say, it rose. (T.) [Hence also,] daraOati Aln-aAru † The fire gave light, shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (Sh, Ḳ.)

daraOa, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoraOu}, (T,) inf. n. duruwoCN, (T, Ṣ,) He (a camel) had what is termed the gud-ap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. the plague, or pestilence, (TaAEuwn,) of camels, (T,) and had therewith a tumour in his back, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in his naHor [or stabbing-place, in the uppermost part of the breast]: but in a female, it is in the udder: (TA:) or had a tumour in his naHor. (IAạr, T.) The epithet applied to the male is daAriYN↓: and so, accord. to ISk, to the female, (T, Ṣ,) meaning Attacked by the gud-ap in her maraAq, (T, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) thus, without teshdeed to the q, signifying the part, of her throat, which is the place of passage of the water, (T, TA,) or in her maraAq- [or thin and soft parts of the belly], (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) so that the protuberance of the gud-ap [or pestilential tumour] is apparent: which protuberance is termed daroCN↓. (T, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

3. mudaAraOapN, primarily, (TA,) signifies The act of opposing; and repelling, or striving to repel: (Ṣ, TA:) or treating in an evil, or adverse, manner; and opposing: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or the putting one off in the matter of a right or due, by promising to render it time after time; and treating in an evil, or adverse, and a contrary, manner. (Mgh in arts. drI and XrI.) One says, daraOotuhu I repelled him, or strove to repel him. (T, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And fulaAnN laA yudaAriYu walaA yumaAriI, (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. Such a one does not act in an evil, or adverse, manner, nor oppose, [nor does he wrangle, or dispute obstinately:] and lA yudaAriI, meaning, accord. to Ṣgh, if for lA yudaAriYu, does not repel, or strive to repel, him who has a right from his right. (TA.)

Accord. to El-Aḥmar, in [the exercise of] good disposition, (T, Ṣ,) and in social intercourse, (Ṣ,) it is with and without C; (T, Ṣ;) contr. to the assertion of AʼObeyd, who says that in this case it is without C. (T.) [F says,] daAraOotuhu is syn. with daArayotuhu and daAfaEotuhu and laAyanotuhu [the second of which has a meaning explained above; the first and last meaning I treated him with gentleness or blandishment, soothed him, coaxed him, or wheedled him;, &c.]; thus bearing two contr. significations: (Ḳ:) [or] daraOotuhu and daArayotuhu both signify I was fearful, or cautious, of him; and treated him with gentleness or blandishment, or soothed him, coaxed him, wheedled him, or cajoled him: (Ṣ:) [but Az says,] I say that the verb with C means I was fearful, or cautious, of him, as says AZ; or of his evil, or mischief: and daArayotu signifies “I deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted;” as also darayotu. (T.)

4. OadoraOato biDaroEihaA, (AZ, T, Ṣ,) inf. n. UidoraMCN, (AZ, T,) [as also AcrOt, with c,] She (a camel) excerned (Oanozalato) the milk, (AZ, T, Ṣ,) and relaxed her udder, on the occasion of bringing forth. (AZ, Ṣ.) The epithet applied to the she-camel so doing is mudoriYN↓. (AZ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
tdr-O EalayonaA He domineered over us. (Ṣ.) And tdr-WwA Ealayohimo They domineered over them, (Ḳ, TA,) and aided one another against them. (TA.)

tdr-WwA, (M, Ḳ, TA,) and Aid-araWuwA↓ dariyoYapF, (TA,) They concealed themselves from a thing in order to beguile it, or circumvent it: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or they made use of a cariyEap [or dariyoYap] for hunting and spearing or thrusting [or shooting objects of the chase]: (TA:) and Ad-rOtu↓ lilS-ayodi, (Ṣ,) or AlS-ayodi, (Ḳ,) I prepared for myself a dariyYap for the chase: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and daraOa↓ Ald-ariyoYapa lilS-ayodi, aor. _a {yadoraOu}, inf. n. daroCN, He drove the dryYp to the chase, and concealed himself by it. (M.)

6. tdArWwA They repelled, or strove to repel, one another (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) in contention, or altercation, (M, Ḳ,) and the like; and disagreed. (M.) Aid-aAraOotumo is originally tadaAraOotumo, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the t being incorporated into the d, (Ṣ, TA,) because they have the same place of utterance, (TA,) and the A being added to commence the word: (Ṣ, TA:) the meaning is, Ye disagreed; and repelled, or strove to repel, one another. (Ṣ.) faQd-aAraOotumo fiyhaA, in the Ḳur ii. 67, means And ye contended together respecting it; because those who contend repel one another: or ye repelled, or strove to repel, one another, by each of you casting the slaughter upon his fellow. (Bḍ.)
7: see 1, in three places.

The phrase AlHuduwdu tanodariYu biAlX-ubuhaAti [The prescribed castigations shall be, or are to be, averted, or deferred, on account of dubious circumstances,] is agreeable with analogy, but has not been heard [from the Arabs of classical times]. (Mgh.)
AndrO AlHariyqu The fire [of a burning house, &c.] spread, (Ḳ, TA,) and gave light, shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (TA.)
8: see 5, in two places.

hom.sense: daroCN and inf. n. of 1 in senses pointed out above. (Ṣ, M, &c.) So of that verb said of a torrent. (TA.) [Hence,] jaMYa Als-ayolu daroCFA and duroCFA↓ The torrent rushed, or poured forth with vehemence, [or came rushing,, &c.,] from a place, (M, Ḳ,) or from a distant place, (TA,) unknown: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or the latter signifies the torrent came from a distant land or tract. (Ṣ.) And jaMCa AlwaAdiI duroCFA↓ The valley flowed with the rain of another valley: if with its own rain, you say, saAla ZahorFA: (IAạr, M; and the like is said in the TA in the present art. and in art. Zhr:) or sAl duroCFA means it flowed with other than its own rain; and ZahorFA, “with its own rain.” (TA in art. Zhr.) Hence Ald-uroCu↓ has been metaphorically used by a rájiz to signify ‡ The flowing of water from the mouths of camels into their insides. (M.)

A bending; (TA;) a crookedness, or curvity; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) in a cane, or spearshaft, and the like; (M, Ḳ;) or in a staff, and anything that is hard to straighten: (T, TA:) pl. duruwoCN. (M.) One says, Oaqamotu daroCN fulaAnK † I rectified the crookedness and opposition, or resistance, of such a one. (Ṣ.) And hence, biYorN caAtu daroCK A well having a part [of its shaft] projecting, or protuberant. (Ṣ, O.) And TariyqN cuw duruwoCK A road having furrows, (M,* Ḳ,*) or abrupt, water-worn, ridges, (T, Ṣ, M,) and protuberances, and the like. (T.)
The extremity, or edge, of a thing; because it repels therewith. (Ḥam p. 213.)
A portion of a mountain that projects, or juts out, from the rest, (M, Ḳ, TA, and Ham p. 213 in explanation of the pl.,) unexpectedly: (TA:) pl. as above. (M.)
See also 1, last sentence.
Also † Disobedience, and resistance, and hatred, or dislike, (T, TA,) and crookedness, (T,) and disagreement, on the part of a wife. (T, TA.)

entry.sense: duroCN: see daroCN, in three places.

dariyoYapN A ring by aiming at which one learns to pierce or thrust [with the spear] (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and to shoot: (T,* M, Ḳ:) said by Aṣ to be with C: (Ṣ:) and also called watiyrapN. (Ṣ in art. wtr.) ʼAmr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib says,
Zalilotu kaOan-iI lilr-imaAHi dariyoYapN
OuqaAtilu Eano OabonaMCa jaromK wafar-ati
[I passed the day as though I were a ring for the spears to be aimed at, fighting in defence of the sons of Jarm, when they had fled]. (T, Ṣ, M. [See also Ḥam p. 75, where it is written dariy-apN.])

Also A camel, (T, Ṣ,) or other thing, (Ṣ,) or anything, (M, Ḳ,) by which one conceals himself (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) from the wild animals, (T,) or from the objects of the chase, (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ,) in order that they may be circumvented, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) so that when the man is able to shoot, or cast, he does so: (T, Ṣ:) like cariyEapN: (Ṣ in art. crE:) accord. to AZ, it is with C, (Ṣ,) because the dryYp is driven (tudoraOu, i. e. tudofaEu,) towards the objects of the chase: (T,* Ṣ:) but IAth says that it is dariy-apN, without C; and that it signifies an animal by means of which the sportsman conceals himself, leaving it to pasture with the wild animals until they have become familiar with it and so rendered accessible to him, when he shoots, or casts, at them: (TA:) the pl. of dariyoYapN is daraAyaA and daraAYYu with two hemzehs, each of them extr. [with respect to analogy]. (M, TA.)
dar-iIoCN: see what next follows.
dur-iIoCN: see what next follows.

kawokabN dir-iIoCN, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) like xim-iyrN and sik-iyrN (Ṣ) or sik-iynN, (Ḳ,) from daraOa EalayonaA fulaAnN; (Ṣ;) and dur-iIoCN↓, (M, Ḳ,) the only instance of the measure fuE-iylN except mur-iyqN; (Ḳ;) [which latter word has been mistaken by Golius and Freytag for a noun qualified by the epithet dr-IC;] but AʼObeyd says that when it is pronounced with the first letter madmoomeh it is dur-iI-N, without C, a rel. n. from dur-N, of the measure fuEoliI-N, [and the like is said in the Ḳ, though dur-iIoCN is also there mentioned as correct,] because there is not [to his knowledge] in the language of the Arabs any word of the measure fuE-iylN; and that he who pronounces it [dur-iIoCN] with C means that it is [originally of the measure] fuE-uwlN, like sub-uwHN, and that one of its vowels is changed to kesr because it is deemed difficult of pronunciation; and Akh mentions also dar-iIoCN↓, with C, of the measure faE-iylN, with fet-ḥ to the first letter, (Ṣ, TA,) on the authority of Ḳatádeh and AA; (TA;) ‡ A star that shines, or glistens, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) intensely: (Ṣ:) or a star that is impelled in its course from the east to the west: (M:) accord. to IAạr, [a shooting star;] a star that is impelled (yudoraOu) against the devil [or a devil; for the Arabs believed, and still believe, that a shooting star is one that is darted against a devil when he attempts to hear by stealth the discourse of the angels in the lowest heaven]: (T, TA:) and said by some to signify one of the five planets: (TA in art. dr:) pl. daraAriIoCu; (T, Ṣ, M;) said by Fr to be applied by the Arabs to the great stars of which the names are not known. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: daAriYN Coming from a place, or from a distant place, unexpectedly: (M, TA: but only the pls. of the word in this sense are there mentioned:) an enemy showing open hostility, or coming forth into the field to encounter another in battle: and a stranger: (T:) pl. duraOLCu (T, M, TA) and dur-aMCN. (M, TA.) People say, naHonu fuqaraMCu duraOLCu [We are poor men, come from a distant place, or strangers]. (T, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.
[Hence,] metaphorically used by Ru-beh as meaning ‡ Swollen with anger. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: Als-uloTaAnu cuw tudoraOK, (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ,) and tudoraOapK↓, (Ḳ,) accord. to different relations of a trad. in which it occurs, (TA,) The Sultán is possessed of apparatus [of war], (Eud-ap, Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or might, (Eiz-, so in other copies of the Ḳ,) and power, to repel his enemies: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:*) accord. to IAth, cw tdrO signifies impetuous, not fearing or dreading; and so, having power to repel his enemies: (TA:) it is used in relation to war and contention. (M.) You say also, huwa cuw tudoraOK and tudorahK: and huwa cuw tudoraYihimo and tudorahahimo (TA in art. drh, q. v.)
tudoraOapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
mudoriYN: see 4.
midoraON A thing with which one pushes, or thrusts; or pushes, or thrusts, away, or back. (TA.) [Applied in the present day, pronounced midoraA, without C, to A boat-pole.]
caAtu AlmidoraOapi The she-camel of violent spirit. (TA.)

duraAqinN and dur-aAqinN, (Ḳ, and the latter is mentioned in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) the latter is that which is in common use, (TA,) The peach; syn. xawoxN: (AḤn, IDrd, Ḳ; and so in a copy of the Ṣ:) and the apricot; syn. miXomiXN; (Ḳ;) but this application of the words is not known: (TA:) of the Syrian dial.: (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ:) IDrd says that the people of Syria call the former fruit drAqn, which is an arabicized Syrian word, or [rather] Greek, [originally δωράκιον,] and El-Jawáleeḳee also mentions it among arabicized words. (TA.)

1. dariba bihi, (T,* Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadorabu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. darabN (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and durobapN, (Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and tdr-b↓, (M, A, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) and darodaba [which is generally regarded as a quadriliteral-radical word (see art. drdb)]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He was, or became, accustomed, or habituated, to it; attached, addicted, given, or devoted, to it; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and bold to do it, or undertake it: (Mṣb:) or he knew it, had knowledge of it, or was knowing in it. (A, TA.) And dariba EalaI AlS-ayodi He (a hawk) was, or became, accustomed, or habituated, or trained, to the chase; and bold to practise it. (A.)

hom.sense: 2. dr-bhu bihi (M, Mṣb,* Ḳ) and Ealayohi and fiyhi, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoriybN, (Ḳ,) He accustomed, or habituated, him to it; made him to become attached, addicted, given, or devoted, to it. (M, Mṣb,* Ḳ.) And dr-b, (M,) or dr-b EalaI AlS-ayodi, (T, Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,*) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He accustomed, or habituated, or trained, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,*) a hawk, (T, Ṣ, A,) or an eagle, (Ḳ,) or a bird or beast of prey, (M,) to the chase; (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;*) and made it bold to practise it. (A.) And dar-abatohu AlX-adaAYidu Difficulties, or hardships, exercised him so as to render him strong to endure them, and habituated, or inured, to them. (Lḥ, T, Ṣ.)
And dar-aba, (IAạr, T,) inf. n. as above, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) He was, or became, patient in war in the time of flight. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

4. Adrb Alqawomu The people, or party, entered a land of the enemy pertaining to the territory of the ruwm [or people of the Greek Empire]. (Ṣ.) OadorabonaA occurs in a trad. as meaning We entered the darob [q. v.]. (TA.)
Adrb He beat a drum; (IAạr, T, TA;) as also darodaba and dabodaba. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tdr-b quasi-pass. of 2: (Mṣb:) see 1.

darobN is not a word of Arabic origin: (Mṣb:) Ald-arobN is [the Arabic name of the ancient Derbe, near the Cilician Gates, which were the chief mountain-pass, from the direction of the countries occupied by the Arabs, into the territory of the Greek Empire: these “Gates” are mentioned by El-Idreesee as fortified, and guarded by troops who watched the persons going and coming:] a well-known place in Alr-uwm [or the territory of the Greek Empire], mentioned by Imra-el-Ḳeys, [as El-Idreesee also says,] in the words,
bakaI SaAHibiI lam-aA raOaI Ald-aroba Hawolahu
[My companion wept when he saw the drb around him; knowing himself to be in the power of the Greeks]. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] Any place of entrance, (Kh, T, M, A, Mgh [in my copy of which it is written darab in all its senses], K,) or a narrow pass, (Mgh,) to [the territory of] Alr-uwm: (Kh, T, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ:) or such as is not open at both ends: such as is open at both ends being called darabN↓: (Ḳ:) or a place of entrance between two mountains: (Mṣb:) or a narrow pass in mountains: and hence it has another meaning well known: (Ṣ:) [i. e.] the gate of a sik-ap [here meaning street: misunderstood by Golius, who has consequently explained darobN as having, for one of its meaning, “porta ingressusve palmeti”];
used in this sense by the Arabs because it [i. e. the drb properly so called] is like a gate, or entrance, to that whereto it leads: (Mṣb:) or the gate of a wide sik-ap: (T:) or a wide gate of a sik-ap; and the largest gate; (M, Ḳ;) both of which explanations mean the same: (M:) and also a wide sik-ap itself: so in the phrase, zuqaAqN Oawo darobN gayoru naAficK [a narrow street or a wide street not being a thoroughfare]: (Mgh: [in my copy of which, darabN is put for darobN:]) [but in the present day, and as used by El-Makreezee and others, a by-street, whether wide or narrow, branching off from a great street, or passing through a HaArap (or quarter), open, or having a gate, at each end:] pl. duruwbN (Kh, T, M, Mgh, TA) and diraAbN. (Sb, Ḳ. [The former pl., the only one commonly known, is not mentioned in the Ḳ.])
Also A place in which dates are put to dry. (M, Ḳ.)
darabN: see the next preceding paragraph.

daribN [part. n. of dariba]. You say, huwa daribN bihi [He is accustomed, or habituated, to it; attached, addicted, given, or devoted, to it; and bold to do it, or undertake it: and] he knows it, has knowledge of it, or is knowing in it. (A, TA.) And some use daAribN↓ as part. n. of dariba: (Mṣb:) it signifies Skilful in his handicraft: (IAạr, T, Mṣb:) and with p {daribapN}, intelligent: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) and skilful in her handicraft: (Ḳ:) and [hence] a female drummer. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.) And EuqaAbN daAribN↓ (M) or EuqaAbN daAribN EalaI AlS-ayodi (Ḳ) means daribapN (Ḳ) or daribapN biAlS-ayodi (M) [An eagle accustomed, or habituated, or trained, to the chase; and bold to practise it].

durobapN Custom, or habit; (IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) or habituation; (T, Mṣb;) and boldness to engage in, or undertake, war, and any affair: (IAạr, T, Ṣ, A,* Mṣb,* Ḳ:) and dur-aAbapN↓, (M, TA,) with teshdeed, (TA,) on the authority of IAạr, (M, TA,) but written in the Ḳ duraAbap↓, (TA,) signifies the same. (M, Ḳ, TA.) One says, maA zilotu OaEofuw Eano fulaAnK Hat-aI Qt-axacahaA durobapF [I ceased not to forgive such a one until he took it as a habit]. (T,* Ṣ.)

darabuwtN (Lḥ, M, Ḳ [in the CK darabuwbN]) and daruwbN↓, (Ḳ,) the former like tarabuwtN, in which the [initial] t is [said to be] a substitute for d, (Lḥ, M,) A he-camel, (M, Ḳ,) or such as is termed bakorN, (Lḥ, M,) and a she-camel, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) submissive, or tractable, (M, Ḳ,) or rendered submissive or tractable: and a she-camel that will follow a person if he takes hold of her lip or her eyelash. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ. [But I read bihudobi EayonihaA, as in the explanation of tarabuwtN in the TA, instead of nahazota EayonahaA in the M and CK in this art., and nahazato EayonuhaA in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ. See also tarabuwtN.])
daruwbN: see the next preceding paragraph.
duraAbapN and dur-aAbapN: see durobapN.
daAribN: see daribN, in two places.

mudar-abN A man, (Ṣ, M,) or an old man, (T,) tried, or proved, in affairs, and whose qualities have become known; or tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs; experienced, or expert: or whose qualities have been tried, or proved: syn. mujar-abN (T, Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ) and munaj-acN: (M, Ḳ:) and mudar-ibN↓ is syn. with mujar-bN: (Ṣ:) or in every word of the measure mufaE-alN syn. with mujar-abN, the medial radical letter may be pronounced with fet-ḥ or with kesr, except mudar-abN. (M, Ḳ.)
And hence, (M,) One afflicted with trials or troubles. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ.)
And A camel well trained, and accustomed to be ridden, and to go through the [narrow passes in mountains called] duruwbN: fem. with p {mudar-abapN}. (Ḳ.)
Almudar-abN The lion. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
mudar-ibN: see the next preceding paragraph.
darobaAnN (Ḳ) and dirobaAnN and durobaAnN (Kr, TA) sings. of daraAbinapN, (Ḳ, TA,) which signifies Door-keepers, or gate-keepers: [the sing. is] Persian, [originally darobaAno,] arabicized. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. daraja, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoruju}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. duruwjN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and darajaAnN, (Ḳ,) said of a man, and of a [lizard of the kind called] Dab-, (Ṣ,) He went on foot; [went step by step; stepped along;] or walked: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and said of a child, he walked a little, at his first beginning to walk: (Mṣb, TA:*) or, said of an old man, and of a child, and of a bird of the kind called qaTFA, aor. as above, inf. n. [duruwjN and] darojN and darajaAnN and dariyjN, he walked with a weak gait; crept along; or went, or walked, leisurely, slowly, softly, or gently. (TA.)

[Hence,] daraja qaronN baEoda qaronK Generation after generation passed away. (A.) And daraja Alqawomu The people passed away, or perished, none of them remaining; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also AndrjwA↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And daraja He left no progeny, or offspring: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) he died, and left no progeny, or offspring: [opposed to OaEoqaba:] but you do not say so of every one who has died: (TA:) or it signifies also [simply] he died: (Aboo-Tálib, Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) so in the prov., Oakocabu mano dab-a wadaraja (Ṣ, Mṣb) The most lying of the living and the dead. (Ṣ.) Or daraja signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (Ṣ,) He went his way; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so darija, [aor. _a {yadoraju},] like samiEa. (Ḳ.) layosa hecaA biEuX-iki faQdorujiI, i. e. [This is not thy nest, therefore] go thou away, is a saying occurring in a xuTobap of El-Hajjáj, addressed to him who applies himself to a thing not of his business to do; or to him who is at ease in an improper time; wherefore he is thus ordered to be diligent and in motion. (TA. [See also art. EX.])
darajato and Oadorajato↓ She (a camel) went beyond the year [from the day when she was covered] without bringing forth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
darajati Alr-iyHu The wind left marks, or lines, [or ripples,] upon the sand. (TA.)
darajati Alr-iyHu biAlHaSaA The wind passed violently over the pebbles [app. so as to make them move along: see also 10]. (Ḳ.)
darija, aor. _a {yadoraju}, He rose in grade, degree, rank, condition, or station. (Ḳ, TA.)
He kept to the plain and manifest way in religion or in speech. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also (i. e. darija) He continued to eat the kind of bird called dur-aAj. (Ḳ.)
daraja as a trans. v.: see 4, in two places.
