2. dr-jhu, [inf. n. tadoriyjN, He made him to go on foot; to go step by step; to step along; or to walk: he made him (a child) to walk a little, at his first beginning to walk: or he made him (an old man and a child) to walk with a weak gait; to creep along; or to go, or walk, leisurely, slowly, softly, or gently: see 1, first sentence: and see also 10, first sentence.] You say, of a child, yudar-aju EalaI AlHaAli [He is made to walk,, &c., leaning upon the go-cart]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] dr-jhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoriyjN, (Mṣb,) He brought him near, or caused him to draw near, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) by degrees (EalaI Alt-adoriyji, Ṣ), or by little and little, (Mṣb,) UilaI kacaA to such a thing, (Ṣ,) or UilaI AlOamori to the thing or affair; (Mṣb;) as also Astdrjhu↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And He exalted him, or elevated him, from one grade, or station, to another, by degrees (EalaI Alt-adoriyji); as also Astdrjhu↓. (A.)
And hence, ‡ He accustomed him, or habituated him, UilaI kacaA to such a thing. (A.)

[Hence] also, inf. n. as above, † He fed him, namely, a sick person, when in a state of convalescence, by little and little, until he attained by degrees to the full amount of food that he ate before his illness. (TA.)
dar-ajaniI, inf. n. as above, said of corn, or food, and of an affair, It was beyond, or it baffled, my ability, or power, to attain it, or accomplish it. (Ḳ.)
See also 4.
dr-j as an intrans. v. signifies He went on foot, or walked, [&c.,] much. (Ḥar p. 380.)
[It is also said to signify He imitated the cry of the bird called dur-aAj: see De Sacy's “Chrest. Ar.” 2nd ed. ii. 39.]
4. Adrj He (God) caused people to pass away, or perish. (TA. [See also 10.]) [Hence,] Adrjhu biAls-ayofi [He destroyed him with the sword]. (Ḳ in art. Xmr.)

tudoziju garoDahaA watuloHiquhu biHaqabihaA said of a she-camel when she makes her saddle with its appertenances to shift backwards [She makes her fore girth to slip back and to become close to her kind girth]. (TA.) Accord. to Aboo-Tálib, UidoraAjN signifies A camel's becoming lank in the belly, so that his belly-girth shifts back to the kind girth; the load also shifting back. (TA.)
Adrj Ald-alowa He drew up the bucket gently: (Ḳ:) drew it up, or out, by little and little. (Er-Riyáshee, TA.)

Adrj AlUiqaAmapa; and darajahaA↓ aor. _u {yadoruju}, inf. n. darojN; i. q. OarosalahaA [i. e. He chanted the UiqaAmap (q. v.); meaning he chanted it in a quick, or an uninterrupted, manner; for such is the usual and prescribed manner of doing so: see 1 in art. Hcm: in the present day, daraja, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he chanted, or sang, in a trilling, or quavering, manner; and uninterruptedly, or quickly]. (Mṣb.)
[UidoraAjN in speaking signifies, in like manner, The conjoining of words, without pausing; i. q. waSolN, as opposed to waqofN: it occurs in this sense in the Ṣ in art. hl, &c.]

Adrj (inf. n. UidoraAjN, TA) also signifies He folded, folded up, or rolled up, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing, (TA,) a writing, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and a garment, or piece of cloth; (Mṣb;) as also dr-j↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoriyjN; (TA;) and daraja↓, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoruju}, inf. n. darojN: (TA:) the first of these verbs is the most chaste: (L:) [it signifies also he rolled a thing like a scroll; made it into a roll, or scroll: and hence, he made it round like a scroll; he rounded it: (see Oadomaja and mudomajN and mudamolajN and Har-ada, &c.:) and he wound a thing upon another thing:] also he infolded a thing; put it in, or inserted it: and he wrapped, wrapped up, or inwrapped, a thing in another thing. (L.) You say, Oadoraja AlkitaAba fiI AlkitaAbi He infolded, enclosed, or inserted, the writing in the [other] writing; or put it within it. (A, L.) And Adrj Almay-ita fiI Alkafani waAlqabori He put the dead man into the grave-clothing and the grave. (TA.) And OadorajaniI fiI TaI- Aln-isoyaAni † [He, or it, infolded me in the folding of oblivion]. (TA in art. TwI.)
[And hence, † He foisted, or inserted spuriously, a verse or verses into a poem.]
rajaEa UidoraAjahu or EalaI UidoraAjihi: see darajN.
Oadorajato said of a she-camel: see 1.
Adrj biAln-aAqapi He bound (Sar-a) the she-camel's teats (Ḳ, TA) with a durojap↓ [app. meaning a piece of rag wrapped about them]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tdr-j He progressed, or advanced, by degrees, UilaI XaIoCK to a thing. (TA.) He was, or became, drawn near, or he drew near, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) by degrees (EalaI Alt-adoriyji, Ṣ), or by little and little, (Mṣb,) UilaI kacaA to such a thing, (Ṣ,) or UilaI AlOamori to the thing or affair. (Mṣb.)
And ‡ He became accustomed, or habituated, UilaI kacaA to such a thing. (A.)
7. AndrjwA: see 1.
Andrj also signifies It was, or became, folded, folded up, or rolled up. (KL.) [And It was, or became, infolded, or inwrapped.]
[And hence, Andrj fiyhi † It was, or became, involved, implied, or included, in it.]
[And Andrj taHota kacaA † It was, or became, classed as a subordinate to such a thing.]

10. Astdrjhu [is syn. with dar-ajahu in the first of the senses assigned to this latter above. Hence,] Dhu-Rummeh says,
Sariyfu AlmaHaAli QsotadorajatohaA AlmaHaAwiru
meaning [The creaking of the large sheaves of pulleys] which the pivots made to go [round] slowly (Say-aratohaA UilaI Oano tadoruja). (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.
[Also] He caused him to ascend, and to descend, by degrees. (Bḍ in vii. 181.)

And hence, He (God) drew him near to destruction by little and little: (Bḍ ibid:) He brought him near to punishment by degrees, by means of respite, and the continuance of health, and the increase of favour: (Idem in lxviii. 44:) He (God) took him (a man) so that he did not reckon upon it; [as though by degrees;] bestowing upon him enjoyments in which he delighted, and on which he placed his reliance, and with which he became familiar so as not to be mindful of death, and then taking him in his most heedless state: such is said to be the meaning in the Ḳur vii. 181 and lxviii. 44: (TA:) or He bestowed upon him new favours as often as he committed new wrong actions, and caused him to forget to ask for forgiveness [thus leading him by degrees to perdition]: and [or as some say, TA] He took him by little and little; [or by degrees;] not suddenly: (Ḳ:) or Aisotadorajahumo signifies He took them by little and little; [one, or a few, at a time;] not [all of them together,] suddenly. (L.) And He, or it, called for, demanded, or required, his destruction: from daraja “he died.” (A, TA.)
It (another's speech, Aboo-Saʼeed, TA) disquieted him so as to make him creep along, or go slowly or softly, upon the ground. (Aboo-Saʼeed, Ḳ.)
He deceived him, or beguiled him, (AHeyth, Ḳ, TA,) so as to induce him to proceed in an affair from which he had refrained. (AHeyth, TA.)

Astdrj Aln-aAqapa He invited the she-camel's young one to follow after she had cast it forth from her belly: so accord. to the Ḳ: [in the CK, for Aln-aAqapa and waladahaA, we find Aln-Aqpu and waladuhA:] but accord, to the L and other lexicons, Astdrjt Aln-aAqapu waladahaA, i. e. the she-camel invited her young one to follow [her] after she had cast it forth from her belly. (TA.)

Astdrjt Alr-iyHu AlHaSaA The wind [blew so violently that it] made the pebbles to be as though they were going along of themselves (Ḳ, TA) upon the surface of the ground, without its raising them in the air. (TA. [See also 1.])
AisotidoraAjN also signifies The drawing forth (in Pers. byrwn Awrdn) speech, or words, from the mouth. (KL.)
And The rejecting a letter, such as the w in yaEidu for yawoEidu. (Mṣb in art. wEd.)

hom.sense: darojN: see darajN, in two places.

Also, and darajN↓, A thing in, or upon, which one writes; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [a scroll, or long paper, or the like, generally composed of several pieces joined together, which is folded or rolled up:] and mudorajN↓, [used as a subst.,] a writing folded or rolled up; pl. madaAriju: (Ḥar p. 254:) and mdrjp [app. mudorajapN↓, from Oadoraja “he folded” or “rolled up,” with p added to transfer it from the predicament of part. ns. to that of substs.,] signifies [in like manner] a paper upon which one writes a risaAlap [or message,, &c.], and which one folds, or rolls up; pl. madaAriju. (Ḥar p. 246.)

fiI daroji AlkitaAbi signifies fiI Tay-ihi [lit. Within the folding of the writing; meaning infolded, or included, in the writing]; (Ṣ, A, TA;) and fiI vinoyihi [which means the same]; (A;) and fiI daAxilihi [an explicative adjunct, meaning in the inside of the writing]. (TA.) You say, Oanofacotuhu fiI daroji AlkitaAbi [I transmitted it in the inside of the writing]. (Ṣ, TA.) And jaEalahu fiI daroji AlkitaAbi [He put it in the inside of the writing]. (A, L, TA.) And fiI daroji AlkitaAbi kacaA wakacaA [In the inside of the writing are such and such things; or in the writing are enclosed, or included, or written, or mentioned, such and such things; this being commonly meant by the phrase fiI TaI-i AlkitaAbi kcA wkcA]. (TA.)

entry.sense: durojN A woman's HifX; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. a small receptacle of the kind called safaT, in which a woman keeps her perfumes and apparatus, or implements: (TA:) [accord. to the Ḳ, it is a coll. gen. n.; for it is there added, (I think in consequence of a false reading in a trad.,)] the n. un. is with p {durojapN}: and the pl. [of mult.] is dirajapN and [of pauc.] OadoraAjN. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
darajN A way, road, or path; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also darojN↓: (L:) and madorajapN↓ (Ṣ, A) and madorajN↓ (A, Ḳ) signify [the same; or] a way by, or through, which one goes or passes; a way which one pursues; a course, or route; syn. macohabN (Ṣ) and masolakN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mamar-N; (A;) and particularly the way along which a boy and the wind, &c. go; as also darajN; respecting which last, in relation to the wind, see daruwjN: (L:) or madorajN↓ signifies a road; or a cross-road; or a bending road; and its pl. is madaArijN: (Mṣb:) and madorajapN↓ is explained by Er-Rághib as signifying a beaten way or road: and it signifies also the course by which things pass, on a road, &c.: and the main part of a road: and a rugged [road such as is termed] vaniy-ap, between mountains: (TA:) the pl. of darajN (Ṣ, L) and of darojN↓ (L) is OadoraAjN (Ṣ, L) and diraAjN, which occurs in a prov. cited below: (Meyd:) and the pl. of madorajapN is madaArijN↓: (Ṣ, TA:) madaAriju↓ OakamapK signifies the roads that lie across a hill such as is termed Akmp. (TA.) You say OadoraAjaka meaning Go thy way, as thou camest. (TA from a trad.) And rajaEa darajahu (TA) and rajaEa OadoraAjahu (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ) and UidoraAjahu↓ (Ḳ) or EalaI UidoraAjihi (IAạr) He returned by the way by which he had come. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And rajaEa darajahu He returned to the thing, or affair, that he had left. (TA.) And rajaEa EalaI OadoraAjihi and rajaEa darajahu AlOaw-ala He returned without having been able to accomplish what he desired. (IAạr.) And Aisotamar-a darajahu and OadoraAjahu [He kept on his way; persevered in his course]. (TA.) And huwa EalaI daraji kacaA He is on the way of, or to, such a thing. (TA.) And Ait-axacuwA daArahu madorajapF↓ and madorajFA↓ They made his house a way through which to pass. (A.) And hecaA AlOamoru madorajapN↓ lihecaA † This thing, or affair, is a way that leads to this. (TA.)
And AimoXa fiI madaAriji↓ AlHaq-i ‡ Walk thou in the ways of truth. (TA.) And cahaba damuhu OadoraAja Alr-iyaAHi ‡ His blood went for nothing; [lit., in the ways of the winds; meaning] so that no account was taken of it, and it was not avenged. (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ.) And xal- daraja AlD-ab-i Leave thou the way of the Db- [a species of lizard], (Ṣ, Meyd,) and oppose not thyself to him, (TA,) lest he pass between thy feet, and thou become angry (fatanotafixa): (Ṣ, Meyd:) a prov., applied in the case of demanding security from evil. (Meyd. [See another reading, and explanations thereof, in Ḥar p. 220, or in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 437.]) And mano yarud-u AlfuraAta Eano diraAjihi or OadoraAjihi, accord. to different readings, with two different pls. of darajN; i. e. Who will turn back Euphrates from its course? a prov. applied to an impossible affair. (Meyd.) And mano yarud-u Als-ayola EalaI OadoraAjihi Who will turn back the torrent to its channels? another prov. so applied. (Meyd.) daraju sayolK and madoraju↓ sayolK signify The way by which a torrent descends in the bendings of valleys. (TA.)
[Hence, perhaps, as denoting a way, or means,] † A mediator between two persons for the purpose of effecting a reconciliation. (Ḳ.)

OanaAa daraju yadayoka means ‡ [I am submissive, or obedient, to thee;] I will not disobey thee: (A, TA:*) and drj used in this sense does not assume a dual nor a pl. form: [therefore] you say also, humo daraju yadika ‡ They are submissive, or obedient, to thee. (TA.)
daraju Alr-amoli and AlmaMCi signify [The ripples of sand and of water;] what are seen upon sand, and upon water, when moved by the wind. (Az and TA in art. Hbk.) See daruwjN.
See also darajapN, in two places.
And see darojN.

durojapN A thing which is rolled up, and inserted into a she-camel's vulva, and then [taken forth, whereupon] she smells it, and, thinking it to be her young one, inclines to it [and yields her milk]: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilá- bee, (Ṣ,) a thing (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) consisting of rags, (T,) or of tow and rags (Ṣ, M) and other things, (M,) which is rolled up, (T, Ḳ,) and stuffed into a she-camel's vulva, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and into her tuel, (Ḳ,) and bound, (TA,) when they desire her to incline to the young one of another, (T, Ṣ,) having first bound her nose and her eyes: (Ṣ:) they leave her thus, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with her eyes and nose bound, (Ḳ,) for some days, (Ṣ,) and she in consequence suffers distress like that occasioned by labour: then they loose the bandage [of her vulva] from her, and this thing comes forth from her, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and she thinks it to be a young one; and when she has dropped it, they unbind her eyes, having prepared for her a young camel, which they bring near to her, and she thinks it to be her own young one, and inclines to it: (Ṣ:) or with the thing that comes forth from her they besmear the young one of another she-camel, and she thinks it to be her own young one, and inclines to it: (Ḳ:) the thing thus rolled up is called durojapN (T, Ṣ) and jazomN and waviyqapN; (T;) and the thing with which her eyes are bound, gimaAmapN; and that with which her nose is bound, SiqaAEN: (Ṣ:) the pl. [of mult.] is durajN (Ṣ, TA) and [of pauc.] OadoraAjN: (TA:) or it signifies [or signifies also] a piece of rag containing medicine, which is put into a she-camel's vulva when she has a complaint thereof: pl. durajN. (L, Ḳ.)

Also ‡ A piece of rag stuffed with cotton, which a woman in the time of the menses puts into her vulva, (Ḳ, TA,) to see if there be any remains of the blood: (MF:) likened to the drjp of a she-camel. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, kun-a yaboEavona biAAld-arajapi fiyhaA Alkurosufu [They (women) used to send the drjp, with cotton therein]: (IAth, Ḳ,* TA:) but accord. to one reading it is dirajap, (IAth, Ḳ,) pl. of durojN [explained above], meaning “a thing like a small safaT, in which a woman puts her light articles and her perfumes:” (IAth:) El-Bájee read darajap, which seems to be a mistake. (Ḳ.)
See also 4, last sentence.
And see what here next follows.

entry.sense: darajapN A single stair, or step, of a series of stairs or of a ladder; one of the daraj of a sul-am: (Mgh:) and hence, by a synecdoche, (Mgh,) a series of stairs, or a ladder, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) constructed of wood or of clay [&c.] against a wall or the like, (Mgh,) by which one ascends to the roof of a house; (TA;) as also durajapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and durojapN↓ and duraj-apN↓ and Oadoruj-apN↓: (Ḳ:) the pl. of the first is darajN↓, (Ṣ,) or [rather] darajapN [has for its proper pl. darajaAtN, and] is n. un. of darajN like as qaSabapN is of qaSabN. (Mṣb.) darajN↓ and darajaAtN also signify Stages upwards: opposed to darakN and darakaAtN: and hence darajaAtN is used in relation to Paradise; and darakaAtN, in relation to Hell. (B voce darakN, q. v.)
A degree in progress and the like: you say darajapF darajapF By degrees; gradually. (TA.)
‡ A degree, grade, or order, of rank or dignity: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:*) degree, grade, rank, condition, or station: and exalted, or high, grade, &c.: (TA:) pl. darajaAtN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
[A degree of a circle:] a thirtieth part of a sign of the Zodiac: (TA:) [pl. darajaAtN.]
[A degree, i. e. four minutes, of time: pl. darajaAtN.]

hom.sense: durajapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Also, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and dur-ajapN↓, (Sb, TA,) A certain bird, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) of which the inside of the wings is black, and the outside thereof dustcoloured; in form like the qaTaA, but smaller, or more slender: (ISk, Ṣ:) thought by IDrd to be the same as the dur-aAj. (TA.) [See also dar-aAjapN, last sentence.]

entry.sense: duraj-apN: see darajapN.

riyHN daruwjN A wind swift in its course: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or not swift nor violent in its course: (TA:) and in like manner qidoHN an arrow: (Ṣ, TA:) or ryH drwj signifies a wind of which the latter part leaves marks (yadoruju) so as to produce what resembles [the track made by the trailing of] the tail of a halter upon the sand: and the place is called darajN↓. (L.)
dur-ajN Great and difficult affairs or circumstances. (Ḳ.) You say, waqaEa fulaAnN fiI dur-ajK Such a one fell into great and difficult affairs or circumstances. (TA.)
dur-ajapN: see durajapN.
dar-aAjN One who creeps along (yadoruju) with calumny, or slander, among people: (A:) one who calumniates, or slanders, much or frequently. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
Ald-ar-aAju The hedge-hog; syn. Alqunofucu: (Ḳ:) because he creeps along all the night: an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.)
Oabuw dar-aAjK A certain small bird. (TA.)

dur-aAjN A certain bird, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [the attagen, francolin, heath-cock, or rail,] resembling the HayoquTaAn, and of the birds of El-'Irák, marked with black and white spots, or, accord. to the T, spotted: IDrd says, I think it is a post-classical word; and it is the same as the durajap and dur-ajap: in the Ṣ it is said that the names dur-aAjN and dur-aAjapN↓ are applied to the male and the female [respectively] until one says HayoquTaAn, which is applied peculiarly to the male. (TA.) [See also De Sacy's “Chrest. Ar.” 2nd ed. ii. 39.]

dir-iyjN, like sik-iynN, (Ḳ,) or dur-ayojN, (so in the L,) A thing, (Ḳ,) i. e. a stringed instrument, (TA,) resembling the Tunobuwr, with which one plays: (Ḳ, TA:) the like of this is said by ISd. (TA.)

dar-aAjapN A HaAl [or kind of go-cart]; i. e. the thing upon which a child is made [to lean so as] to step along, or walk slowly, when he [first] walks: (Aboo-Naṣr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the machine on wheels on which an old man and a child [lean so as to] step along, or walk slowly. (TA.)

Also A dab-aAbap [or musculus, or testudo], which is made for the purpose of besieging, beneath which men enter. (Ḳ.) [The first and last of these significations are also assigned by Golius and Freytag to durajapN: but for this I find no authority; although, after the latter of them, Golius indicates the authority of the Ṣ and Ḳ; and Freytag, that of the Ḳ.]
dur-aAjapN: see dur-aAjN.
daArijN [part. n. of 1, q. v.:] A boy that has begun to walk slowly, and has grown; (Mgh;) a boy in the stage next after the period when he has been weaned. (IAạr, TA voce muTab-ixN, q. v.)
Dust (turaAb) caused by the wind to cover the traces, or vestiges, of dwellings, and raised, and passed over violently, thereby. (Ḳ.)
[Also, in the present day, The trilling, or quavering, or the quick, part of a piece of music or of a song or chant: see 4.]
[And Current, or in general use. And hence Ald-aAriju, or AlkalaAmu Ald-aAriju, or All-isaAnu Ald-aAriju, The modern speech; i. e. the modern Arabic.]
daArijapN sing. of dawaAriju, (T, TA,) which signifies The legs of a beast (T, Ḳ) and of a man: ISd knew not the sing. (TA.)
Oudoruj-apN: see darajapN.
mudorajN: see darojN.
[Also † A verse foisted, or inserted spuriously, into a poem.]
mudorijN A she-camel that has gone beyond the year [from the day when she was covered] without bringing forth. (TA.)
And A she-camel that makes her fore girth to slip back and to become close to her hind girth; contr. of misonaAfN; as also midoraAjN↓; of which the pl. is madaAriyju. (TA.)

hom.sense: madorajapN, and its pl. madaAriju, which is also pl. of madorajN: see darajN, in seven places.
OaroDN madorajapN A land in which are birds of the kind called dur-aAjN. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: mudorajapN: see darojN.

midoraAjN A she-camel that is accustomed to go beyond the year [from the day when she was covered] without bringing forth: (Ṣ:) or that exceeds the year by some days, three or four or ten; not more. (TA.)
See also mudorijN.

1. darida, (M, Mgh, L,) aor. _a {yadoradu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. daradN, (Ṣ,* M, Mgh, L, Ḳ,*) He was, or became, toothless; (Ṣ, L;) he lost his teeth. (M, Mgh, L, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Oumirotu biAls-iwaAki Hat-aI xifotu laOadoradan-a (Ṣ, Mgh *) I was commanded to make use of the tooth-stick until I feared, meaning I thought, or opined, that I should assuredly become toothless: for the Arabs use Zan-a in the same manner as a verb signifying an oath, and give it the same kind of complement, saying, Zananotu laEabodu Qll-ehu xayorN minoka: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to one relation, the words of this trad. are lazimotu Als-iwaAka Hat-aI xaXiytu Oano yadoradaniI [a mistranscription for yudoridaniI↓, from Oadorada, i. e. I kept to the use of the toothstick until I feared that it would deprive me of my teeth, or render me toothless]: (L:) or, accord. to another relation, xaXiytu Oano Oudorida↓ OasonaAniI [I feared that I should make my teeth to fall out]; but this [verb, Mṭr says,] I have not heard. (Mgh.)
4: see above {1}, in two places.
daradN inf. n. of darida. (Ṣ,* M, &c.)
And i. q. HaradN [but in what sense is not said: see what next follows]. (M, TA.)
daridN, as an epithet applied to a man, I. q. HaridN [but in what sense is not said]. (M, TA.)
dirodimN: see Oadoradu, in two places.

durodiI-N The dregs, feces, lees, or sediment, or what remains at the bottom, of olive-oil, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of other things, (Ṣ,) or of [the beverage called] nabiyc, (A,) and of any fluid, such as beverages, or wines, and oils. (L.)
Also A ferment that is put into, and left in, expressed juice and [the beverage called] nabiyc, in order that it may ferment. (L.) [See xamiyrN.]
durayodN an abbreviated dim. of Oadoradu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: Oadoradu A toothless man; (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh;) as also dirodimN↓, with an augmentative m: (M:) fem. of the former darodaMCN: (Ṣ, M:) and pl. durodN. (A.)

naAqapN darodaMCu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and dirodimN↓, with an augmentative m, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as in the instance of diloqimN syn. with daloqaMCu, and of diqoEimN syn. with daqoEaMCN, (Ṣ,) A she-camel advanced in years: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or having her teeth [worn, or consumed,] down to the sockets, (M, Ḳ,) by reason of old age. (M, TA.)
Ald-arodaMCu the name of A certain corps, or troop of horse, (katiybap, [in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ kaviybap,]) that belonged to the Arabs. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: darozN [A seam, or a raised seam, of a garment or piece of cloth;] the elevation that is occasioned in a garment or piece of cloth when its two edges are put together in the sewing; (Mgh;) one of the duruwz of a garment or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, TA,) and the like; (TA;) which are well known: (Ḳ:) a Persian word, [originally darozo,] (Ṣ, TA,) arabicized: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, the nap, or villous substance, (ziYobir,) and lustre, (maMC,) of a garment, or piece of cloth. (TA.)
[Hence,] banaAtu Ald-uruwzi ‡ Lice: and nits; syn. SiYobaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. darasa, aor. _u {yadorusu}, inf. n. duruwsN, It (a trace, or mark, or what is termed rasomN, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and a house, A, or a thing, M) became effaced, erased, rased, or obliterated; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also Andrs↓, (Ḳ, TA,) said of what is termed rsm: (TA:) or it (the trace, or mark, of a house; or what remained, cleaving to the ground, marking the place of a house;) became covered with sand and dust blown over it by the wind: (TA in art. dvr:) or it (an abode, or a place of sojourning,) became effaced, erased, rased, or obliterated, and its traces, or remains, became concealed, or unseen: (Mṣb:) and darusa signifies the same as darasa in the first of the senses explained above, but in an intensive manner. (M.)
[Hence daArasati↓ AlMyaAtu as explained near the end of this paragraph.]
Hence, also, (AHeyth,) darasa Alv-awobi, (AHeyth, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. darosN, (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ The garment, or piece of cloth, became old and worn out. (AHeyth, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
And darasa AlkitaAbu † The writing, or book, became old. (Mṣb.)
[Hence, also,] darasato, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadorusu}, (M,) inf. n. duruwsN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and darosN, (M, Ḳ,) ‡ She (a woman, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, or, accord. to Lḥ, a girl, M) menstruated. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)

darasatohu Alr-iyHu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or Alr-iyaAHu, (A,) [aor. _u {yadorusu},] inf. n. darosN, (A, TA,) The wind, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or winds, (A,) effaced, erased, rased, or obliterated, it, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) by repeatedly passing over it; (A;) namely, a trace, or mark, [of a house, &c.,] or what is termed rasomN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and [erased, or rased,] a house; (A;) or a thing: (M:) and darasahu Alqawomu The people effaced, erased, rased, or obliterated, it. (M.)
Hence, (AHeyth,) darasa Alv-awoba, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadorusu}, inf. n. darosN, (TA,) ‡ He rendered the garment, or piece of cloth, old and worn-out. (AHeyth, Ḳ.)

darasa AlT-aEaAma, (M,) or AlHinoTapa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) wanaHowahaA, (Mṣb,) aor. _u {yadorusu}, (TA,) inf. n. darosN (M, Ḳ) and diraAsN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ He trod, or thrashed, the wheat, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the like: (Mṣb:) [because he who does so passes repeatedly over it:] of the dial. of El-Yemen: (M, TA:) or diraAsN in the sense here indicated is of the dial. of Syria. (TA.)
darasa AlmaroOapa, (A,) or AljaAriyapa, (Ḳ,) ‡ He compressed the woman, (A,) or the girl. (Ḳ.)

darasa Aln-aAqapa, (M, A,) aor. _u {yadorusu}, inf. n. darosN, (M,) ‡ He broke, or trained, the she-camel: (M, A:) [and so, app., daArasahaA↓; for it is said that] the primary signification of mudaArasapN is the breaking, or training, or disciplining, [a beast;] and returning time after time (taEah-udN) to a thing. (TA.) You say also, baEiyrN lamo yudorasu, meaning ‡ A camel that has not been ridden. (Ṣ, TA.)

Hence, (M,) [or from darasatohu Alr-iyHu, or from darasa Alv-awoba,] darasa AlkitaAba, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yadorisu} (M, Ḳ) and _i {yadorisu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. darosN and diraAsapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and daraAsapN and diraAsN, (TA,) ‡ He read the book; (M, Ḳ;) as though he opposed it until it became easy for him to remember it: (M:) or he read it repeatedly, [or studied it,] in order to remember it: (A:) or he made it easy to remember, by much reading: (TA:) or he read and learned it: (Bḍ in vi. 105:) and daArasahu↓, inf. n. mudaArasapN and diraAsN, signifies the same: (M:) and so daras-ahu↓, and Oadorasahu↓: (Ḳ:) or the former of the last two has an intensive signification: the latter of them is mentioned by IJ: (TA:) [but accord. to the M, it is said by IJ that both of these are doubly trans., and have a different signification, which is also indicated in the A as that of the former of them: see 2:] daArasato↓ Alkutuba, and tadaArasotuhaA↓, and Aid-aArasotuhaA↓, signify the same as darasotuhaA [I read the books, or read them repeatedly,, &c.]: (Ṣ, TA:) and tadaArasa↓ AlquroMna signifies He read the Ḳur-án, and returned to it time after time, in order that he might not forget it. (TA.) You say also, darasotu AlEiloma, aor. _u {yadorusu}, inf. n. darosN and diraAsapN, ‡ I read science. (Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [vi. 105], accord. to different reading, waliyaquwluwA darasota, and daArasota↓, ‡ [And to the end that they may say, Thou hast read,, &c.:] but some say that the former means Thou hast read the books of the people of the Scriptures: and the latter, Thou hast consulted, or conferred, with them; expl. by caAkarotuhumo: (M:) or the former means Thou hast learned: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás:) and the latter, Thou hast read, or studied, under the Jews as thy teachers, and they have read, or studied, under thee as their teacher: (I’Ab, Mujáhid, Ḳ:) and another reading is daArasa↓;
i. e. daArasa Aln-abiI-u Alyahuwda [he prophet hath read, or studied, with the Jews]: and another, daArasato↓, which may be rendered in two ways: The Jews have read, or studied, or consulted, or conferred, with (daArasato) Moḥammad: and The signs (MyaAt) have vied in length of time [or antiquity] with those of other scriptures so that every one of them has for the most part become obliterated: (TA:) and another reading is darasato; and another, darusato; both meaning, They (these stories, or histories,) have become obliterated: (M:) or they are things which have long since passed: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás:) but the latter of these two verbs has a more intensive signification: and it is also said to signify They have been dissipated. (M.) [You also say, darasa Ealayohi ‡ He read, or studied, under him as his teacher; like qaraOa Ealayohi.]

entry.sense: 2. dar-asa gayorahu ‡ [He made another to read, or to read repeatedly, or to study, in order to remember; or to read and learn: he taught him to read,, &c.: he lectured him]. (A.) And dar-asotuhu AlkitaAba and Oadorasotuhu↓ Uiy-aAhu ‡ [I made him, or taught him, to read the book, or to read it repeatedly, or to study it, or to read and learn it]. (IJ, M.)
See also darasa AlkitaAba.

hom.sense: 3. daArasati AlMyaAtu: see 1.
dArs Aln-aAqapa: see 1.

dArs gayorahu ‡ [He read, or studied, with another, each of them teaching the other]. (A.) And daArasotuhu AlkitaAba, inf. n. mudaArasapN, ‡ [I read, or read repeatedly, or studied, or read and learned, with him the book, each of us teaching the other]. (A.) And daArasahumo † He called to mind with them a subject of discourse, &c.; or he conferred with them; syn. caAkarahumo. (M.) See also 1, latter half, in five places.

entry.sense: 4: see 2:
and see darasa AlkitaAba.
5. tadar-asotu OadoraAsFA wataXam-alotu XimaAlFA ‡ [app., I clad myself in old and worn-out garments, and wrapped myself in shemlehs]. (A, TA.)
6. tadaArasuwA AlkitaAba Hat-aI HafiZuwhu ‡ [They read the book, or read it repeatedly, or studied it, or read and learned it, together, teaching one another, until they retained it in memory]. (A.)
tadaArasotu Alkutuba, and Aid-aArasotuhaA, and tadaArasa AlquroMna: see darasa AlkitaAba.
7: see 1, first signification.

hom.sense: darosN A road, or way, that is unapparent; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as though the traces thereof had become effaced. (TA.)
See also dirosN.
[A lecture: pl duruwsN.]

entry.sense: dirosN The relic, trace, or mark, of a thing that becomes effaced, erased, rased, or obliterated. (M.)

‡ An old and worn-out garment, or piece of cloth; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) [app. an epithet used as a subst.;] as also darosN↓ (M) and dariysN↓; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) ↓which last also signifies an old and worn-out carpet; (A;) ↓and as an epithet, signifying old and worn-out, is applied to a coat of mail, (M, TA,) and to a sword, and to a migofar [&c.]: (TA:) pl. [of the first] OadoraAsN, (M, Ḳ,) [a pl. of pauc.,] and [of the same or of either of the others] dirosaAnN. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
[Hence, or, as IF says, from AlHayoD,] Oabuw OadoraAsK [in some copies of the Ḳ Oum-u OadoraAsK] ‡ The pudendum muliebre. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
durosapN † Training, or discipline. (Ḳ.)
dariysN: see dirosN, in three places.
[Also Dry birosiym, or Alexandrian trefoil.]
raboEN daArisN [A house of which the remains are becoming effaced, erased, rased, or obliterated: or i. q. raboEN madoruwsN]. (A.)
AimoraOapN daArisN, (M, Ḳ,) or, accord. to Lḥ, jaAriyapN daArisN, (M,) ‡ A woman, (M, Ḳ,) or girl, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) menstruating: (Lḥ, M, Ḳ:) pl. dur-asN and dawaArisu. (M.)
Uidoriysa ‡ The penis. (A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: tadoriysN [inf. n. of 2, q. v.]
[Also † A conventional term or signification used by the mudar-isuwn, or lecturers, tutors, or professors, of colleges]. (Mgh, in arts. Hnf and dyn, &c.)

entry.sense: midorasN † A book, or writing: (Ḳ, TA: but omitted in some copies of the former:) [also, accord. to Golius, a commentary by which any one is taught; Heber. מִדְרָש.]
See also the next paragraph.

madorasapN ‡ A place of reading, or study; (Mṣb;) in which persons read, or study; (TA;) [a college, a collegiate mosque; an academy;] as also midorasN↓ (TA) and midoraAsN↓; (M, Ḳ;) the measure of which last, [as well as that of the next preceding word,] as that of a n. of place, is strange: (ISd, TA:) whence the midoraAs↓ of the Jews; (Ḳ;) their house in which is repeatedly read the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: (A:) or their house in which the Book of God is read, or read repeatedly: (TA:) or their synagogue: (Mṣb:) the pl. of mdrsp is madaArisu; (TA;) and that of mdArs is madaAriysu. (Mṣb.)
madorasapu Aln-aEami ‡ The road or track (Tariyq) [of camels, or of camels and sheep or goats]. (A, TA.)
mudar-asN ‡ A bed made plain, even, smooth, or easy to lie upon. (TA.)
‡ A man tried and proved, or tried and strengthened, by use, practice, or experience; expert, or experienced. (A, TṢ, Ḳ.)
mudar-isN ‡ A man who reads much and repeatedly. (Ḳ, TA.)

Hence, the mudar-is of madorasap ‡ [i. e. The lecturer, tutor, or professor, of a college, a collegiate mosque, or an academy: from which it is not to be understood that there is but one such person to every college; for generally one college has several mudar-isuwn]. (TA.)
midoraAsN: see madorasapN, in two places.
Also ‡ One who reads, or reads repeatedly, or studies, the books of the Jews: the measure of the word implies intensiveness. (TA.)
raboEN madoruwsN [A house of which the remains are effaced, erased, rased, or obliterated: see also daArisN]. (A.)
TariyqN madoruwsN ‡ A road much beaten by passengers, so as to be made easy by them. (A, TA.)
mudaArisN ‡ One who reads, or studies, with another; syn. muqaAriYN: (Ḳ:) or one who has read books. (Ḳ.)

1. dariEa, aor. _a {yadoraEu}, inf. n. daraEN, He (a horse, and a sheep or goat,) was black in the head, and white [in the other parts]: or, as some say, was black in the head and neck. (Mṣb: [in my copy of which is an evident omission, which I have supplied: see OadoraEu.]) [See also daraEN, below.]
2. dr-E, inf. n. tadoriyEN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He clad a man with a diroE, (Ḳ,) i. e. a drE of iron [or coat of mail]: (TA:) and a woman with a qamiyS [or shift]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4. AdrE AlX-ahoru, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UidoraAEN, (TA,) The month passed its half. (ISh, Ḳ.) UidoraAEuhu also signifies The blackness of its first part. (ISh.)
5: see 8, in three places.

8. Aid-araEa He (a man) clad himself with a diroEN (Ṣ Ḳ) of iron [i. e. a coat of mail]; (Ḳ;) as also tdr-E↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Aid-araEato She (a woman) clad herself with a diroE, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. a qamiyS [or shift]. (Ṣ, TA.)
Ad-rE midoraEapF, and tdr-EhA↓, and tamadoraEahaA↓, (Kh,) and tdr-E↓ alone, (Ṣ,) and tamadoraEa↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but this last is of weak authority, (Ṣ,) He clad himself with a midoraEap [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ,)

Ad-rE fulaAnN All-ayoli ‡ Such a one entered into the darkness of the night, journeying therein; (Ḳ, TA;) like Aigotamada All-ayola. (Ṣ and L in art. gmd.) Hence the saying, (TA,) Xam-iro cayolFA waQd-ariEo layolFA ‡ Use thou prudence, or precaution, or good judgment, and journey all the night. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also art. Xmr.]
Ad-rE Alxawofa ‡ He made fear as it were his innermost garment; by closely cleaving to it. (TA.)
Q. Q. 2. tamadoraEa: see 8, in two places.

diroEN A coat of mail; syn. zarad-iyapN: (IAth, Mṣb, TA:) [or a coat of defence of any kind; being a term applied in the Ṣ and Ḳ, &c. to a yalabap, i. e. a coat of defence of skins, or of camel's hide:] and also, of plate-armour: (AO, in his book on the diroE and bayoDap, cited in the TA voce migofarN:) [but the first is the most general, and proper, meaning:] as meaning a diroE of iron, it is fem.; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ *) or mostly so; (Mṣb;) but sometimes masc.: (Ḳ:) AO says that it is masc. and fem.; (Ṣ, TA;) and so Lḥ: (TA:) pl. OadoruEN and OadoraAEN and duruwEN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the first and second, pls. of pauc.; the third, a pl. of mult. (Ṣ.) The dim. is durayoEN↓, which is anomalous, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for by rule it should be with p; (Ṣ;) or this may be [a regular form] of the dial. of those who make the word masc.; and some say durayoEapN↓. (Mṣb.)

Also A woman's qamiyS [or shift]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a garment, or piece of cloth, in the middle of which a woman cuts an opening for the head to be put through, and to which she puts arms [or sleeves], and the two openings of which [at the two sides] she sews up: (T, TA:) or a woman's garment which is worn above the qamiyS: or, accord. to El-Hulwánee, one of which the opening for the head to pass through extends towards, or to, the bosom; whereas the qmyS is one of which the slit is towards, or to, the shoulder-joint; but this [says Mṭr] I find not in the lexicons: (Mgh:) a small garment which a young girl wears in her house, or chamber, or tent: (TA:) as meaning a woman's diroE, it is masc., (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) only; (Lḥ;) or sometimes fem.: (TA:) pl. OadoraAEN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See a verse cited voce mijowalN.]

daraEN Whiteness in the breast of a sheep, or goat, and in its naHor [or part where it is slaughtered, but wanaHorihaA, in the Ḳ, is probably a mistranscription, for wanaHowihaA, meaning and the like thereof, i. e., of the sheep, or goat], and blackness in the thigh. (Lth, Ḳ.) [See also 1; and see duroEapN.]
layaAlK duraEN: see OadoraEu.
duroEapN, in a horse, and in a sheep or goat, Blackness of the head, and whiteness [of the other parts]: or, accord. to some, blackness of the head and neck: a subst. from dariEa [q. v.]. (Mṣb.)
See also OadoraEu, in the middle of the paragraph.
diroEiy-apN, applied to an arrow-head or the like, Penetrating into, or piercing through, the coats of mail: pl. daraAEiI-u. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
durayoEN and durayoEapN: see diroEN.
dur-aAEapN: see midoraEapN, in four places.

OadoraEu, applied to a horse, and to a sheep or goat, Having a black head, the rest being white: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or, as some say, having a black head and neck, (Mṣb, TA,) the rest being white: (TA:) or having a white head and neck, the rest being black: (TA:) fem. daroEaMCu: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. duroEN: (Ṣ:) or daroEaMCu signifies having what is termed daraEN [q. v.]; applied to a sheep or goat, (Ḳ,) and to a mare: (TA:) or a sheep or goat black in the body, and white in the head: or black in the neck and head, the rest of her being white: or, accord. to AZ, a ewe having a black neck: or, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, sheep or goats differing in colour: or, accord. to ISh, black except in having the neck white: and red [or brown], but having the neck white: and also, having the head with the neck white: accord. to Az, the right explanation is that given by AZ, meaning having the fore part black; being likened to the nights termed duraEN; or the latter are likened to the former: and hence, (TA,)

layolapN daroEaMCu ‡ A night of which the moon rises at the dawn, (Ḳ,) or at the commencement of the dawn; the rest thereof being black, and dark. (TA.) And layaAlK duraEN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said by AḤát to have been heard by him only on the authority of AO, but so accord. to Aṣ and AʼObeyd and AHeyth, (TA,) and duroEN; (Ḳ;) the former contr. to rule, for by rule it should be duroEN, its sing. being daroEaMCu; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ;) or, accord. to AHeyth, you say valaAvN duraEN wavalaAvN ZulamN, and duraEN and ZulamN are pls. of duroEapN↓ and ZulomapN, not of daroEaMCu and ZalomaMCu; and Az says that this is correct and regular; but IB says that daroEaMCu has duraEN for its pl. for the purpose of assimilation to ZulamN in the saying valaAvN ZulamN wavalaAvN duraEN, and that no other instance had been heard by him of a word of the measure faEolaMCu having a pl. of the measure fuEalN; (TA;) ‡ Three nights of the month which follow those called AlbiyDu; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;*) namely, the sixteenth and seventeenth and eighteenth nights; (TA;) because of the blackness of their first parts, and the whiteness of the rest thereof: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) there is no difference in what Aṣ and AZ and ISh say respecting them: but some say that they are the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth; because part of them is black and part of them white: [this, however, seems to have originated from a misunderstanding of an explanation running thus; three nights of the month which follow those called AlbiyD, which, meaning the latter, are the thirteenth, &c.; for the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth are all white:] or, accord. to AO, All-ayaAliI Ald-uraEu signifies the nights of which the fore parts are black and the latter parts white, of the end of the month; and those of which the fore parts are white and the latter parts black, of the commencement of the month. (TA.)

OadoraEu also signifies † One whose father is free, or an Arab, and whose mother is a slave; syn. hajiynN; (Ḳ;) as also muEalohajN. (TA.) And qawomN duroEN ‡ A people, or company of men, of whom half are white and half black. (TA.)
midoraEN: see the following paragraph.

hom.sense: midoraEapN A certain garment, [a tunic,] like that called dur-aAEapN↓, never of anything but wool, (Lth, Ḳ,) [and having sleeves; for] mention is made, in a trad., of a mdrEp narrow in the sleeve; wherefore the wearer, in performing the ablution termed wuDuwoC, put forth his arm from beneath the mdrEp, and so performed that ablution: (TA:) accord. to some, the dr-AEp↓ is a [garment of the kind called] jub-ap, slit in the fore part; (TA;) [thus resembling a kind of jub-ap worn by persons in Northern Africa, reaching to, or below, the knees, and having the two front edges sewed together from the bottom, or nearly so, to about the middle of the breast: it is said in the MA to be a wide vest or shirt; a large jub-ap: and the midoraEap is there said to be a woollen dur-aAEap; a woollen tunic: El-Makreezee (cited by De Sacy in his “Chrest. Arabe,” 2nd ed., vol. i., p. 125,) describes the drA-Ep↓ as a garment worn in Egypt particularly by Wezeers, slit in the fore part to near the head of the heart, with buttons and loops: Golius describes it as “tunica gossipina, fere grossior;” adding, “estque exterior tum virilis tum muliebris;” as on the authority of J, who says nothing of the kind, and of the Loghat Neamet-Allah: and as epomis, seu amiculum quod humeris injicitur; on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof: J only says,] the midoraE↓ and midoraEap are one; and dur-aAEapN↓ is sing. of, or signifies one of what are called, daraAriyEu: (Ṣ:) the pl. of mdrEp is madaAriEu. (MA.)

Also The [appendage called] Suf-ap [q. v.] of a raHol [or camel's saddle], when the heads of the waAsiTap [or fore part (Az says the wasaT, accord. to the TA,)] and the Mxirap [or hinder part] appear from [above] it. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: daraqN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: daraqapN i. q. HajafapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or turosN, (Mgh,) [i. e. A shield,] made without wood and without sinews: (Mgh, TA:) or made of skins sewed one over another: (ISd and TA voce HajafapN, q. v.:) pl. daraqN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. is] OadoraAqN [a pl. of pauc.] and diraAqN; (Ḳ;) this last mentioned by IDrd, who says, they are made of the skins of beasts found in the country of the Abyssinians, (TA,) [as are shields thus called in the present day: they are made of the skin of the hippopotamus, and of other pachydermatous animals; and sometimes of the skin of the crocodile; generally oval, with a large protuberance in the middle, behind which is the handle, and between a foot and a half and two feet in length.]

Also A xawoxap [here meaning sluice] in a rivulet: an arabicized word, from [the Persian] dariyJaho. (Ḳ, TA.) This is what is meant by the saying of the lawyers, that the repairing of the drqp is incumbent on the owner of the rivulet. (TA.)

entry.sense: dir-aAqN: see what next follows.

diroyaAqN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and daroyaAqN (El-Hejeree, Ḳ) and diroyaAqapN↓ and daroyaAqapN↓ (Ḳ) and dir-aAqN↓, (Fr, TA,) with kesr, like din-aArN, &c., not dar-aAqN, as it would seem to be from the manner in which it is mentioned in the Ḳ, (TA,) [and as it is written in the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,] i. q. tiroyaAqN [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, (Ḳ,) or diroyaAqapN↓, (TA,) ‡ Wine; (Ḳ, TA;) as being likened to tryAq [properly so called: a meaning also borne by tiroyaAqN and tiroyaAqapN]. (TA.)
diroyaAqapN and daroyaAqapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

daworaqN A certain measure for wine, or beverage, (Ṣ, A, O, L,) containing the quantity to be drunk [at once]: a Persian word, [originally daworaho or duwraho,] arabicized: (L, TA:)
[J says,] I think it to be Persian, arabicized: (Ṣ:) it is thus correctly written; not, as the context of the Ḳ requires it to be in this sense, darodaqN. (TA.)

Also A jar having a loop-shaped handle, (Ḳ, TA,) that is lifted, or carried, by the hand: of the dial. of the people of Mekkeh: pl. dawaAriqu. (TA.) [In Egypt, it is applied to A narrownecked drinking-bottle, made of a dust-coloured, or grayish, porous earth, for the purpose of cooling the water by evaporation: several varieties of this kind of bottle are figured in ch. v. of my “Modern Egyptians.”]

1. daraka, from which should be derived daraAki and dar-aAkN, is unused, though its noun drk [i. e. darokN or darakN, which latter (the more common of the two) see below,] is used. (IB.) [daraka in Golius's Lex. is evidently a mistranscription for daAraka.]

2. tadoriykN The dropping of rain with close consecutiveness, (IAạr, Ḳ, TA,) as though one portion thereof overtook another. (IAạr, TA.) You say, dr-k AlmaTaru The rain dropped with close consecutiveness. (TḲ.)
Also The hanging a rope upon the neck of a person in coupling him with another. (AA.)

3. diraAkN The making one part, or portion, of a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) whatever it be, (TA,) to follow another uninterruptedly; (Ḳ, TA;) as also mudaArakapN: (TA:) both [are inf. ns. of dArk, and] signify the same [i. e. the continuing, or carrying on, a thing uninterruptedly]: (Ṣ:) mudaArakapN is when there are no intervals between things following one another; like muwaASalapN: otherwise it is muwaAtarapN. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wtr.) You say, of a man, dArk Sawotahu He continued his voice uninterruptedly. (Ṣ, TA.)

Also A horse's overtaking, or coming up with, wild animals (Ḳ, TA), &c. (TA.) You say, of a horse, dArk AlwaHoXa, inf. n. diraAkN, He overtook, or come up with, the wild animals. (TḲ.) [Thus it is syn. with Adrk.]
In the saying, laA baAraka Qll-ehu fiyhi walaA daAraka, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) it is an imitative sequent: (Ḳ, TA:) all these verbs have one and the same meaning. (Ṣ, TA. [See taAraka.])

4. Adrkhu, (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UidoraAkN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and mudorakN, (Mṣb,) He, or it, attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, him, or it: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or sought, or pursued, and attained, reached,, &c., him, or it: (Mṣb:) [dArkhu, also, signifies the same, as shown above:] and tdArkhu↓, likewise, [of which Aid-arAakahu is a variation,] is syn. with Adrkhu; (Jel in lxviii. 49, and KL,* and TA;*) and so is Aid-arakahu↓. (TA.) You say, Oadorakotu Alr-ajula and Aid-arakotuhu↓ [I attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, the man]. (IJ, TA.) And maXayotu Hat-aI Oadorakotuhu I walked, or went on foot, until I overtook him, or came up with him. (Ṣ, TA.) And EiXotu Hat-aI Oadorakotu zamaAnahu I lived until I attained, or reached, his time. (Ṣ, TA.) And Oadorakotu AlfaAYita [I attained,, &c., that which was passing away]. (Mgh.) And Adrkhu bimakoruwhK [He overtook him, or visited him, with some displeasing, or abominable, or evil, action]. (M and Ḳ in art. wtr. See also 6, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places: and see 10, first sentence.) And OadorakaniI Aljahodu [Difficulty, or distress,, &c., overtook me, ensued to me, or came upon me]; a phrase similar to balaganiI Alkibaru in the Ḳur [iii. 35]: and so Oadorakotu Aljahoda [I came to experience difficulty,, &c.]; like balagotu mina Alkibari EutiyFA in the Ḳur [xix. 9]. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. blg.)

[Hence, He attained, obtained, or acquired, it; and so tdArkhu↓, as is shown in the KL; so too Adrk bihi, for one says,] Adrk bidamihi [He obtained revenge, or retaliation, for his blood]. (Ṣ in art. wtr.)

[Hence also, He perceived it; attained a knowledge of it by any of the senses.] You say, Oadorakotuhu bibaSariI [I perceived it by my sight;] I saw it. (Ṣ, TA.) laA tudorikuhu AlOaboSaAru, in the Ḳur [vi. 103], means, accord. to some, The eyes [perceive him not]: accord. to others, the mental perception comprehendeth not [or attaineth not the knowledge of] the real nature of his hallowed essence. (TA.) You say also, Adrk EilomiI, meaning My knowledge comprehended that such a thing was a fact. (TA.)

[Hence likewise, as an intrans. v., or a trans. v. of which the objective complement is understood,] Adrk also signifies [He attained a knowledge of the uttermost of a thing; or] his knowledge attained the uttermost of a thing. (TA.) See also 6, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places.

Also It (a thing) attained its proper time: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) it attained its final time or state, or its utmost point or degree. (Ḳ.) [He (a boy, and a beast,) attained his perfect, ripe, or mature, state; and in like manner Adrkt is said of a girl: or it is like Adrk as meaning] he (a boy) attained to puberty, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or to the utmost term of youth. (TA.) It (fruit) attained to ripeness, or maturity; became ripe, or mature; (Ṣ Mṣb;) attained its time, and its utmost degree of ripeness or maturity. (T, TA.) And Adrkt Alqidoru The cooking-pot attained its proper time [for the cooking of its contents]. (TA.) And Adrkt Alxamoru [The wine became mature]. (Mṣb and Ḳ in art. xmr.) And Adrk maMCu Alr-akiy-api The water of the well reached its darak, i. e. its bottom (Aboo-ʼAdnán, TA.)

Also It passed away and came to an end; came to nought; became exhausted; or failed entirely: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said in this sense of flour, or meal: (Ṣ:) and thus it has been explained as used in the Ḳur [xxvii. 68], where it is said, [accord. to one reading,] balo Oadoraka Eilomuhumo fiI AlMxirapi [Nay, their knowledge hath entirely failed respecting the world to come]. (TA. [See also 6.]) Sh mentions this signification as heard by him on no other authority than that of Lth; and Az asserts it to be incorrect: but it has been authorized by more than one of the leading lexicologists, and the language of the Arabs does not forbid it; for it is said of flour, or meal, and in this case can only mean it came to its end, and entirely failed, or became exhausted; and fruits, when they are ripe (UicaA Oadorakato) are exposed to coming to nought, and so is everything that has attained to its extreme term; so that the signification of “coming to nought” is one of the necessary adjuncts of the meaning of UidoraAkN. (TA.) [In like manner,] Aid-araka↓ signifies It (a thing) continued uninterruptedly and then come to nought: (IJ, TA:) and agreeably with this signification is explained the saying in the Ḳur [xxvi. 61], Uin-aA lamud-arikuwna [Verily we are coming to nought, by those who read thus instead of lamudorakuwna being overtaken]. (TA.)
You say also, Adrk Alv-amanu AlmuXotariIa, meaning [The payment of] the price was, or became, obligatory on the purchaser: this is an ideal reaching, or overtaking. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 6. td-ArkwA i. q. tlAHqwA (Ṣ) [i. e.] They attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, one another; as also Aid-aArakuwA, and Aid-arakuwA↓; (Sh, TA;) [or] the last of them attained, reached, overtook, or came up with, the first of them. (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [vii. 36], (Ṣ,) Hat-aI UicaA Qd-aArakuwA fiyhaA jamiyEFA [Until, when they have overtaken one another, or have successively arrived, therein, all together]: originally tadaArakuwA. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) And tdArk Alv-ariyaAna [The two moistures reached each other; (like AilotaqaI Alv-arayaAni;) meaning] the moisture of the rain reached the moisture of the earth. (Ṣ.)

And [hence] tdArk signifies [It continued, or was carried on, uninterruptedly; it was closely consecutive in its parts, or portions;] one part, or portion, of it, followed, or was made to follow, another uninterruptedly; said of anything. (TA.) You say, tdArk Als-ayoru [The course, or pace, or journeying, continued uninterruptedly]. (Ṣ and TA in art. Hfd, &c.) And tdArkt AlOaxobaAru The tidings followed one another closely. (TA.)

[Hence, when said of knowledge, meaning, accord. to Fr, It continued unbroken in its sequence or concatenation.] bali Qd-araAka Eilomuhumo fiI AlMxirapi (Ḳ, TA,) in the Ḳur [xxvii. 68], (TA,) [virtually] means Nay, they have no knowledge respecting the world to come: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as IJ says, their knowledge is hasty, and slight, and not on a sure footing,, &c.: Az says that AA read balo Oadoraka [of which an explanation has been given above (see 4)]: that I’Ab is related to have read balaI MOadoraka↓ [&c., i. e. Yea, hath their knowledge reached its end, &c.?], as interrogatory, and without teshdeed: and that, accord. to the reading bl Ad-rAk Fr says that the proper meaning is, [Nay,] hath their knowledge continued unbroken so as to extend to the knowledge of the world to come, whether it will be or not be? wherefore is added, balo humo fiI Xak-K minohaA balo humo minohaA Eamuwna: he says also that Ubeí read, Oamo tadaAraka; and that the Arabs substitute balo for Oamo, and Oamo for balo, when a passage begins with an interrogation: but this explanation of Fr is not clear; the meaning is [said to be] their knowledge shall be unbroken and concurrent [respecting the world to come] when the resurrection shall have become a manifest event, and they shall have found themselves to be losers;
and the truth of that wherewith they have been threatened shall appear to them when their knowledge thereof will not profit them: accord. to Aboo-Mo'ádh the Grammarian, the readings balo Oadoraka↓, &c. and bali Qd-aAraka, &c. mean the same; i. e. they shall know in the world to come; like the saying in the Ḳur [xix. 39], OasomiEo bihimo waOaboSiro, &c.: and Es-Suddee says of both these readings that the meaning is, their knowledge shall agree, or be in unison, in the world to come; i. e. they shall know in the world to come that that wherewith they have been threatened is true: or, accord. to Mujáhid, the meaning of bali Qd-aAraka Eilomuhumo, &c. is said to be, is their knowledge concurrent respecting the world to come? bl being here used in the sense of Oam: (TA:) or it may mean their knowledge hath gone on uninterruptedly until it hath become cut short; from the phrase tdArk banuw fulaAnK meaning The sons of such a one went on uninterruptedly into destruction. (Bḍ.)

tdArkhu: see 4, in two places. It is used in the [primary] sense of Oadorakahu in the saying in the Ḳur [lxviii. 49], lawo laA Oano tadArakahu niEomapN mino rab-ihi lanubica biQloEaraMCi [Had not favour (meaning mercy, Jel) from his Lord reached him, or overtaken him, he had certainly been cast upon the bare land]. (Jel.)

[Hence, elliptically, He overtook him, or visited him, with good, or with evil.] El-Mutanebbee says,
Oana fiI Oum-apK tadaArakahaA Qll-e
hu gariybN kaSaAliHK fiI vamuwdi
[I am among a people (may God visit them with favour and save them from their meanness, or visit them with destruction so that I may be safe from them,) a stranger, like Sálih among Thamood]: tdArkhA Qll-eh is a prayer for the people, meaning AdrkhA↓ Qll-eh wnj-Ahm mn lwmhm [i. e. luWomihimo]: or it may be an imprecation against them, i. e. Adrkhm↓ Qll-eh bAlAhlAk liOanojuwa mnhm: [each meaning as explained above:] and IJ says that because of this verse the poet was named Almtnb-I. (W p. 35. [The verse there commences with OanaA; but Oana is required by the metre, and is more approved in every case except the case of a pause.]) It is mostly used in relation to aid, or relief, and benefaction: [so that it signifies He aided, or relieved, him; he benefited him; he repaired his, or its, condition; he repaired, amended, corrected, or rectified, it:] whence the saying of a poet,
tadaArakaniI mino Eavorapi Ald-ahori qaAsimN
bimaA XaMCa mino maEoruwfihi AlmutadAriki
[Kásim relieved me, or has relieved me, from the slip of fortune with what he pleased of his relieving, or continuous, beneficence]. (TA.) [See also, in the first paragraph {1} of art. dq, another example, in a verse of Zuheyr, which is cited in that art. and the present in the TA: and see the syn. talaAfaAhu. Hence,] tadaArakotu maA faAta i. q. Astdrkthu, q. v. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

entry.sense: 8. Aid-araka: see 4, first and second sentences:
and {4} near the end of the paragraph:
and see also 6, first sentence.

10. Astdrk AlX-aIoCa biAlX-aIoCi [properly] signifies HaAwala UidoraAkahu↓ bihi [i. e. He sought, or endeavoured, to follow up the thing with the thing]: (Ḳ:) as, for instance, AlxaTaOa biAlS-awaAbi [the mistake with what was right]. (TḲ.) [Hence,] you say, Aisotadorakotu maAfaAta [I repaired, amended, corrected, or rectified, what had passed neglected by me, or by another; and I supplied what had so passed, or what had escaped me, or another, through inadvertence]; and tadaArakotuhu↓ signifies the same [in relation to language and to other things; whereas the former verb is generally restricted to relation to language or to a writer or speaker]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say also, Astdrk Ealayohi qawolahu He corrected, or rectified, what was wrong, or erroneous, in his saying: [but more commonly, he supplied what he had omitted in his saying; generally meaning, what he had omitted through inadvertence: and Aisotadorakotuhu Ealayoh I subjoined it, or appended it, to what he had written, or said, by way of emendation; or, more commonly, as a supplement, i. e., to supply what had escaped him, or what he had neglected:] and hence, Almusotadoraku↓ EalaI AlbuxaAriI-i [The Supplement to El-Bukháree; a work supplying omissions of El-Bukháree;] by El-Hákim. (TA.) [Thus] AisotidoraAkN signifies The annulling a presumption, or surmise, originating from what has been before said, [by correcting an error, or errors, or by supplying a defect, or defects,] in a manner resembling the making an exception. (Kull.) [Hence Harofu QsotidoraAkK, meaning A particle of emendation, applied to balo, and to lekin-a or lekino.]
darokN: see the next paragraph, in eight places.

hom.sense: Also The attainment, or acquisition, of an object of want: and the seeking the attainment or acquisition thereof: as in the saying, bak-iro fafiyhi darakN [Be thou early; for therein is attainment,, &c.]: and darokN↓ signifies the same. (Lth, TA.) [Hence, perhaps,] yawomu Ald-arika: this was [a day of contest] between El-Ows and El-Khazraj: (Ḳ:) thought to be so by IDrd. (TA.)

And i. q. tabiEapN [i. e. A consequence; generally meaning an evil consequence: and perhaps it also means here a claim which one seeks to obtain for an injury]: as also darokN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, maA laHiqaka mino darakK faEalaI-i xalaASuhu (Ṣ, TA) and mn darokK↓ [i. e. Whatever evil consequence ensue to thee, on me be the compensation thereof]: in the A, mA Oadorakahu mn darakK fElI- xlASh i. e. maA yaloHaquhu mino tabiEapK [Whatever evil consequence ensue to it,, &c.; relating to a thing sold]. (TA.) And hence DamaAnu Ald-araki in the case of a claim for indemnification for a fault of a defect or an imperfection in a thing sold [meaning either Responsibility, or indemnification, (see DamaAnN,) for evil consequence]: (TA in the present art:) or this means [indemnification for evil consequence in a sale; i. e., virtually,] the returning of the price to the purchaser on the occasion of requirement by the thing sold: the vulgar say incorrectly [DamaAn darak, and still more incorrectly] DumaAn darak [generally meaning thereby I sell this, or I purchase this, on the condition of responsibility, or indemnification, for any fault or defect or imperfection that may be found in it]: (TA in art. Dmn:) [and in this manner DamaAnu Ald-araki may be correctly rendered; for] darakN also signifies a fault or a defect or an imperfection [in a thing sold]; for instance, in a slave that is sold. (TA in art. Ehd.) [In the KT, Ald-araku is also explained as signifying The purchaser's taking from the seller a pledge for the price that he has given him, in fear that the thing sold may require it: but this seems to be an explanation of the case in which the word is used; not of the word itself.]

Also A rope, (M, Ḳ,) or a piece of rope, (Ṣ,) that is tied upon the [lower] extremity of the main rope (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of a well, to the cross pieces of wood of the bucket, (Ṣ,) so as to be that which is next the water, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in order that the main rope may not rot (Ṣ, M) in the drawing of water: (M:) or a doubled rope that is tied to the cross pieces of wood of the bucket, and then to the main wellrope: (Az, TA:) and darokN↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ. [But only darakN is authorized by the TA in this sense.]) [See also karabN.]

Also, and darokN↓, The bottom, or lowest depth, (Sh, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of a thing, (T, M, Ḳ,) as of the sea and the like, (T,) or of anything deep, as a well and the like: (Sh:) pl. OadoraAkN, (Ḳ,) a pl. of both, of a form frequent and analogous with respect to the former, but extr. with respect to the latter; and darakaAtN also. (TA.) And A stage of Hell: (IAạr:) a stage downwards: (MA:) or stages downwards; like darakaAtN: (B:) opposed to darajN (MA, B) and darajaAtN, (B,) which are upwards: wherefore, (MA, B,) the abodes of Hell, or the stages thereof, are termed darakaAtN; (AO, Ṣ, MA, Ḳ, B;) [Golius and Freytag give darakapN as its sing.; the former as from the Ṣ, and the latter as from the Ḳ, in neither of which it is found;] and those of Paradise, darajaAtN. (Ṣ, MA, B.) It is said in the Ḳur [iv. 144], Uin-a QlomunaAfiqiyna fiI Qld-araki QloOasofali mina Qln-aAri [Verily the hypocrites shall be in the lowest stage of the fire of Hell]: here the Koofees, except two, read fI Ald-aroki↓. (TA.)
[Golius gives another signification, “Pars terræ,” as on the authority of the Ṣ and Ḳ, in neither of which it is found.]

entry.sense: dirokapN The ring of the bow-string, (Ḳ, TA,) that falls into the notch of the bow. (TA.)
And A thong that is joined to the string of the bow, (Ḳ,) of the Arabian bow. (TA.)
And A piece that is joined to the girdle when it is too short, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) and in like manner, to a rope, or cord, when it is too short. (Lḥ, TA.)
daraAki an imperative verbal noun, (Ṣ,) meaning Oadoriko [Attain thou, reach thou, overtake thou,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) form the unused verb daraka: (IB:) like taraAki [from taraka], meaning Outoruko. (TA.)

diraAkN [an inf. n. of 3, used in the sense of the part. n. mutadaArikN↓]. You say, TaEanahu TaEonFA diraAkFA He thrust him, or pierced him, with an uninterrupted thrusting or piercing: and Xariba XurobFA diraAkFA He drank with an uninterrupted drinking: and DarobN diraAkN An uninterrupted beating or striking. (TA.)
diraAkapN: see madorakN.
dariykapN i. q. TariydapN [as meaning An animal that is hunted]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

dar-aAkN an epithet from Oadoraka, (Ṣ, Kudot;,) applied to a man, (Ḳ,) and signifying kaviyru AlUidoraAki [i. e. One who attains, reaches, or overtakes,, &c., much, or often: and also having much, or great, or strong, perception: as will be seen from what follows]: (Ṣ, TA:) and so mudorikN↓ [expressly said in the TA to signify kvyr AlAdrAk, though why it should have this signification as well as that (which it certainly has) of simply attaining, &c., I cannot see,] and mudorikapN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) the last explained by Lḥ as signifying sariyEu AlUidoraAki [i. e. quick in attaining,, &c.]. (TA.) Keys Ibn-Rifá'ah says,
waSaAHibu Alwitori layosa Ald-ahora mudorikahu↓
EinodiI waUin-iI ladar-aAkN biOawotaAri
[And he who has a claim for blood-revenge is not ever an attainer of it with (meaning from) me; but verily I am one who often attains bloodrevenges]. (IB.) Seldom does faE-aAlN come from OafoEala; but they sometimes said Has-aAsN dar-aAkN [i. e. Having much, or great, or strong, perception]; it being [in this instance] a dialectal syn. [of Hs-As], or thus for conformity: (Ṣ:) it is said to be the only instance of faE-aAlN from OafoEala except jab-aArN and saO-LrN; [and some other instances might be added; but all of them require consideration:] accord. to IB, dr-Ak is from the unused verb daraka. (TA.)
madorakN: see mudorakN
lahu madorakN [if not a mistranscription for mudorikN or mudorakN] means He has a sense in excess; [app. a preternatural perception, or a second sight;] and so diraAkapN↓. (TA.)

mudorakN A place, and a time, of UidoraAkN [i. e. attaining, reaching, overtaking,, &c.]. (Mṣb.) Hence madaAriku AlX-aroEi; (Mgh, Mṣb;) among which is included investigation of the law by means of reason and comparison; (Mgh;) i. e. The sources from which are sought the ordinances of the law; where one seeks for guidance by means of texts [of the Ḳur-án or the Sunneh] and by means of investigation by reason and comparison: (Mṣb:) the lawyers make the sing. to be madorakN↓; (Mgh,* Mṣb;) but there is no way of resolving this: (Mṣb:) correctly, by rule, it is mudorakN; because the meaning intended is a place of UidoraAk. (Mgh.)
[Also pass. part. n. of 4.]
[And hence, Perceived by means of any of the senses; like maHosuwsN: and perceived by the intellect; thus opposed to maHosuwsN.]
mudorikN: see dar-aAkN, in two places.
[Alquw-apu Almudorikapu, and simply Almudorikapu, as a subst., The perceptive faculty of the mind. See also what next follows.]

hom.sense: mudorikapN: see dar-aAkN.
[See also mudorikN.]
AlmudorikaAtu Alxamosu and AlmadaAriku Alxamosu signify The five senses. (TA.) [See also madorakN.]

Also The Hajomap [a word I do not find in any other instance, app. a mistranscription for maHojamap (which when written with the article differs very little from the former word) i. e. the place to which the cupping-vessel is applied, for this is often] between the two shoulder-blades: (Ḳ:) so says Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)

entry.sense: mudaArikapN A woman (TA) that will not be satiated with coitus; (Ḳ, TA;) as though her fits of appetency were consecutive. (TA.)

mutadaArikN Uninterrupted; or closely consecutive in its parts, or portions: differing from mutawaAtirN, which is applied to a thing in the case of which there are small intervals. (Lḥ.) See also diraAkN.

Applied to a rhyme, (Lth, M, Ḳ,) and to a word, (Lth, TA,) Having two movent letters followed by a quiescent letter; as faEuwo and the like: (Lth, TA:) or having two movent letters between two quiescent letters; as mutafaAEiluno, (M, Ḳ,) and musotafoEiluno, and mafaAEiluno, (M, TA,) and faEuwluno faEalo, (M, Ḳ,) i. e. as faEalo when immemediately following a quiescent letter, (M, TA,) and faEuwlu fulo, (M, Ḳ,) i. e. as fulo with a movent letter immediately followed by it: (M, TA:) as though the vowel-sounds overtook one another without an obstacle between the two movent letters. (M, Ḳ.)
[AlmutadaAriku is also the name of The sixteenth metre of verse; the measure of which consists of faAEiluno eight times.]
musotadorakN [A supplement]: see 10.
[In the TA and some other similar works, it is often used as signifying Superfluous, or redundant.]

1. darina, aor. _a {yadoranu}, inf. n. daranN; (T,* Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) and Adrn↓; (T, M, Ḳ;) It (a garment, Ṣ, M, &c.) was, or became, dirty, or filthy: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or was, or became, defiled, polluted, or smeared, with dirt, or filth. (T, Ḳ.) And darinato yaduhu biAlX-aIoCi His hand was, or became, defiled, polluted, or smeared, with the thing. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. Adrn: see 1.
Also He rendered a garment dirty, or filthy: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he defiled, polluted, or smeared, a garment with dirt, or filth. (Ḳ.)
Oadoranati AlUibilu The camels fed upon what is termed dariyn: (M, Ḳ:) thus they do in the case of drought, or sterility. (M.)

entry.sense: daranN Dirtiness, or filthiness; or dirt, or filth: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or defilement, or pollution, with dirt or filth: (T, Ḳ:) and accord. to the Ḳ, AlUidorawonN↓ also is syn. with Ald-aranu; but ISd says that this is not known. (So in the TA. [In the text of the M, however, as given in the TT, in the place of Ald-aranu in this case I find AlradiIL (for Alr-adiIoCu, i. e. the bad,, &c.); and another passage in the M, respecting a signification of UidorawonN, (which see below,) suggests that the explanation of AlUidorawonu as meaning Ald-aranu may have been taken from this passage in consequence of an oversight.]) maAkaAna Uil-aA kadaranK bikaf-iI, meaning It was no otherwise than like dirt in my hand, which I therefore wiped with the other hand, is a prov. applied in the case of a thing done in haste. (M.)
[Hence,] Oum-u daranK means † The present world, or the present state of existence. (Z, Ḳ.)
daranN is also used as meaning † Vileness, ignominy, or abjectness. (Ḥar p. 509.)
darinN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Oadoranu↓, (M, TA,) applied to a garment, Dirty, or filthy: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or defiled, polluted, or smeared, with dirt, or filth. (Ḳ.)
And, so applied, Old and worn out; as also dariynN↓. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] yadaAhu daranaAtN biAlxayori ‡ [in the CK mina Alxayori, His hands are worn out by beneficence; meaning, much used therein]: and Oayodiyhimo diraAnN ‡ [Their hands are worn out thereby]: and huwa darinu Alyadayoni ‡ [He is worn out in respect of the hands thereby]. (Ḳ, TA.)
darinapN applied to a she-camel means Mangy, or scabby. (TA.)
daranN, like saHaAbN, (Ḳ,) or dar-aAnN↓, (so accord. to the TT as from the M,) The fox. (M, Ḳ.)
dariynN: see darinN.

Also, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and duraAnapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) Dry herbage: (M:) and whatever is broken in pieces, of [plants of the kind termed] HamoD, or of trees, or of herbs, or leguminous plants, (M, Ḳ,) of such as are eaten without being cooked, or are slender and succulent or soft or sweet, and such as are hard and thick, or thick and inclining to bitterness, or thick and rough, when old (M) and dry: (M, Ḳ:) or dariynN signifies what is broken in pieces, of herbage, when it is old (Ṣ, TA) and withered, or wasted, and black; (so in a copy of the Ṣ;) i. e. withered, or wasted, herbage; such as is seldom made use of by the camels: (Ṣ, TA:) or herbage that has become a year old, and then dried up: (Th, M:) dry herbage a year old: (Lth, T:) or dry and old herbage. (Ḥam p. 527.)

[Hence,] Oum-u dariynK † Sterile, or unfruitful, land. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) A poet says,
taEaAla nusam-iTo Hub-a daEodK wanagotadiI
sawaMCayoni waAlmaroEaI biOum-i dariyni
[Come thou, let us keep to our love of Daad (a woman's name), and we will go forth early in the morning, both alike, though the pasturing be in sterile land]: he means, we will keep to our love, though the means of subsistence be strait. (Ṣ.)
duraAnapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

durayonapN [used in the manner of a proper name] The foolish; stupid; unsound, or dull, or deficient, in intellect: (M, A, Ḳ:) thus applied by the people of El-Koofeh: (M, A:) the people of El-Basrah say dugayonapu. (A, TA.)
dar-aAnN: see daraAnN.
Oadoranu: see darinN.

UidorawonN, quasi-coordinate to jirodaHolN, (IJ, M,) i. q. MriI-N (M, Ḳ) or Mxiy-apN (TA in art. Axw) [A rope, or loop of a rope, to which a beast is tied: for further explanations, see Mxiy-apN]: and a manger: (M, Ḳ:) pl. OadaAriynu. (TA in art. Axw.) You say, rajaEa Alfarasu UilaI Uidorawonihi The horse returned to his MriI-: (M, TA:) or to his manger. (TA.)

A place of abode; settled place of abode; place of constant residence; dwelling; or home. (M, Ḳ.) So in the saying, rajaEa Uila Uidorawonihi [He returned to his place of abode,, &c. See also what next follows.] (M.)

I. q. OaSolN [app. as meaning Origin; or original state or condition: and this may sometimes be meant by the phrase immediately preceding]: (M, Ḳ:) particularly such as is bad, accord. to some, who derive it from Ald-aranu: but this is nought, or of no account. (M.)
See also daranN.
Accord. to IAạr, one says, fulaAnN Uidorawonu Xar-K, meaning Such a one is evil in the utmost degree. (T.)
mudorinN Dry firewood. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: midoraAnN, applied to a man and to a woman, Very dirty or filthy: (IAạr, M, Ḳ:*) pl. madaAriynu. (M.)
And A gazelle that eats dariyn. (Ḳ.)

1. daraha Eanohumo, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and lahumo, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadorahu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. darohN, (TA,) He repelled from them, or defended them; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like daraOa, from which it is [said to be] formed by substitution, as haraAqa from OaraAqa; (Ṣ;) and so darahahumo: (Ḥar p. 551: [but for this I find no other authority:]) or he spoke for them, and repelled from them or defended them. (Mṣb.)

daraha Ealayohimo, aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) or the inf. n. is duruwhN, (JK,) He came upon them suddenly, or unawares, (IAạr, Ḳ,) whence they did not expect him; like daraOa: (IAạr, TA:) and [simply] he came upon them. (JK, Ḳ.)
darohN also signifies The being bold, or daring. (TA.)

darahahu; (JK;) so in the handwriting of Ṣgh, but accord. to the Ḳ dr-hhu↓, inf. n. tadoriyhN; (TA;) i. q. tanak-ara lahu [He became changed in countenance to him by anger so that he did not know him; or he met him in a morose manner]. (JK, Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.)
daraha EalaI AlmiAYapi It was on the point of amounting to a hundred. (JK.) [See also 2.]
darahotu biAlmiEozaI I called the goats to water. (JK.)
2: see 1.
dr-h EalaI kacaA, inf. n. tadoriyahN, It exceeded such a thing. (Ḳ.) [See also 1, last signification but one.]

entry.sense: 5. tdr-h i. q. tahad-ada [He threatened, or frightened]. (IAạr, TA.)
dir-iyhN The chief of a people or party. (JK, Ṣgh, TA.)
darahorahapN † A shining, or brightly-shining, star, (AA, Ḳ, TA,) that rises from the horizon glistening intensely. (AA, TA.)
A woman who overcomes, or subdues, her husband. (AA, TA.)
sik-iynN darahorahapN A knife with a curved end; called by the vulgar minojalN. (TA.)
daArihN [act. part. n. of 1]. [Hence,] daArihaAtu Ald-ahori The assaults of time or fortune. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
[Hence also,] One who intrudes uninvited at feasts; a smell-feast; a spunger. (JK, Ṣgh.)
And A messenger. (JK, Ṣgh.)
Also † Shining, gleaming, or glistening, much, or intensely. (MF, TA.)

huwa cuw tudorahK, and tudoraOK, He is one who is wont to come suddenly, or unawares, upon his enemies, whence they know not. (TA.) And huwa cuwtudorahihimo, (IAạr, JK, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, tudorihihimo,]) and tudoraYihimo, (TA,) He is the repeller from them, or the defender of them, (IAạr, Ḳ,) fiI AlHarobi [in war or fight]: (JK:) you may not say huwa tudorahuhumo, without cuw. (TA.) Some say that the h is a substitute for the C. but ISd affirms that the two words, with h and with C, are dial. vars. (TA.)

midorahN A noble chief or lord; (ISd, Ḳ;) so called because he is strong to execute affairs, and ventures upon them suddenly: (ISd, TA:) and a headman, or chief, (muqad-am, [so in the copies of the Ḳ, but the right reading is probably muqodim, i. e. bold,]) in respect of tongue, on the occasion of contention, or disputation; and in arm, or hand, on the occasion of fight: (Ḳ,* TA:) or the headman and spokesman of a people, or party: (Ṣ:) or the spokesman and defender of a people, or party: (Mṣb:) or midorahu qawomK means the defender of a people, or party; (JK, TA;) the chief, or headman, among them: (JK:) or the headman and orator and spokesman and defender of a people, or party: (TA:) and midorahu HarobK means the same; (JK, TA;) or the chief by whom evil is repelled, and who orders, or arranges, the affairs of war: (Ḥam p. 232:) pl. madaArihu. (Ṣ.)
darahorahapN: see the next preceding article.
Q. 1. darohamato, said of the xubaAzaI [or mallow], (Ḳ, TA,) It became round [in its leaves]; (TA;) its leaves became like [the silver coins called] daraAhim. (Ḳ.)
Q. 4. Aidoraham-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. AidorihomaAmN, (Ṣ,) He (a man, TA) became aged: (Ḳ, TA:) or he (an old man) tottered (saqaTa) by reason of age. (Ṣ, TA.)
Adrhm- baSarahu His sight became dim, or obscure. (Ḳ.)

dirohamN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure fiEolalN, (Mṣb, MF,) of which it has been said that there are only three other instances, but there are many more; (MF;) an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) from the Pers. [diramo]; (Ṣ;) also pronounced dirohimN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but this is of rare occurrence; (TA;) and dirohaAmN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is more rare; (TA;) A certain silver coin; (Mgh, Mṣb;) like as diynaArN signifies a certain gold coin: (Mgh:) [and the weight thereof; i. e. a drachm, or dram:] its weight is six dawaAniyq [or dániks]; (Mṣb, and Ḳ in art. mk;) i. e., the weight of the diroham UisolaAmiI-: but in the Time of Ignorance, some dirhems were light, being four dwAnyq; and these were called Tabariy-apN: and some were heavy, being eight dwAnyq; and these were called Eabodiy-apN, or bagoliy-apN: and of these two they made two that were equal; so that each drhm was six dwAnyq: this is said to have been done by ʼOmar: or, accord. to another account, some dirhems were of the weight of twenty carats, and were called the weight of ten [i. e. of ten dániks]; and some were of the weight of ten [carats], and were called the weight of five; and some were of the weight of twelve [carats], and were called the weight of six; and they put the three weights together, and called the third part thereof the weight of seven: and one of the weights of the drhm before El-Islám was twelve carats, which is six dwAnyq: but the drhm AslAmI- is sixteen carats; the dAnq of this being a carat and two thirds: (Mṣb:) or dirhems should be fourteen carats [i. e. seven dániks]; ten being of the weight of seven mavaAqiyl [or mithkáls]: in the Time of Ignorance, some were heavy, [equal to] mvAqyl; and some were light, [called] Tabariy-apN; and when they were coined in the age of El-Islám, they made of the heavy and the light two dirhems, so that ten became equal to seven mvAqyl: AʼObeyd says that this was done in the time [of the dynasty] of the sons of Umeiyeh: (El-Karkhee, cited in the Mgh:) [see also De Sacy's “Chrest. Arabe,” sec. ed., vol. ii. p. 110 of the Arabic text, and p. 282 of the transl.; where it is further stated, on the authority of Ibn-Khaldoon, that the diroham magoribiI- was three dwAnyq; and the yamaniI-, one dAnq; and, as is said in the Mṣb, that ʼOmar adopted the mean between the bglI- and the TbrI-, making the drhm to be six:] the pl. (of drhm, Ṣ) is daraAhimu and (of drhAm, Ṣ) daraAhiymu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [The former of these pls. is often used as signifying Money, cash, or coin, in an absolute sense.] The dim. is durayohimN↓ and durayohiymN↓: the latter held by Sb to be anomalous; for he says that it is as though it were formed from dirohaAmN, though this was not used by them. (TA.)

Hence, as being likened thereto, [i. e., to the coin thus called,] (TA,) dirohamN signifies also † A Hadiyqap [app. as meaning a round piece of land surrounded by a fence or the like, or by elevated land; for this is one of the significations of HadiyqapN]. (Ḳ.)
[It is said that] this is taken from the saying of 'Antarah, [describing shower of copious rain,]
fatarakona kul-a HadiyqapK kaAld-irohami
[So that they left every ridged-round spot of ground like the drhm]. (TA.) [But accord. to one reading, he said, kul-a qaraArapK; meaning, as is said in the EM, p. 227, “every round hollow;” and likening such a hollow to the drhm because of its roundness, and the clearness and whiteness of its water.]
dirohimN: see the next preceding paragraph.
dirohaAmN: see the next preceding paragraph.
durayohimN: see the next preceding paragraph.
durayohiymN: see the next preceding paragraph.
mudarohamN A man possessing many daraAhim: (AZ, Ḳ:) it has no verb: (TA:) you should not say durohima. (AZ, Ḳ.)
mudorahim-N An old man tottering (saAqiTN) by reason of age. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
1. daraI AlX-aIoCa He knew the thing; syn. Ealimahu; (M;) [and so daraI biAlX-aIoCi; for] you say, darayotuhu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and darayotu bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor.
