OadoriI, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. daroIN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and diroIN (Lḥ, M, Ḳ) and diroyapN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and daroyapN, (M,* Ḳ,) which last is said by Sb to be not used as an inf. n. of un., but as denoting a state, or condition, (M,) and, accord. to some copies of the Ṣ, duroyapN, (TA, [so in one of my copies of the Ṣ,]) and diraAyapN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and darayaAnN and diroyaAnN (M, Ḳ) and duriI-N, (TṢ, Ḳ,) I knew it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) syn. Ealimotuhu (Mṣb, Ḳ) or Ealimotu bihi: (Ṣ:) or it has a more special meaning than Ealimotuhu: it is said to signify I knew it after doubting: so says Aboo-ʼAlee: (TA:) or I knew it by a sort of artifice, or cunning, or skill; (Ḳ, TA;) or with painstaking, and artifice or cunning or skill; (Ḥar p. 24;) and therefore daraI is not said of God: (TA:) a rájiz says, (Ṣ,* TA,) but this is an instance of the rude speech of the Arabs of the desert, (TA,)
laA hum-a laA OadoriI waOanota Ald-aAriI↓
[O God, I know not, but Thou art the knowing]: (Ṣ, TA: [in Ḥar, p. 24, it is cited as commencing with Aal-ehum-a, and therefore as a prose-saying, ascribed to Moḥammad, and as adduced by some to show that Ald-aAriI is allowable as an epithet applied to God:]) or, as some relate it, laA Oadori, (Ṣ,) in which the I is elided in consequence of the frequent usage of the phrase; (Ṣ, M;) like the phrases lamo Oubalo and lamo yaku; (Ṣ;) and like laA yaOolu in the saying Oaqobala biDarobahK laA yaOolu [q. v. in art. Alw]. (M.) [The saying laA darayotu walaA QYotalyota or Oalayota, &c. is explained in the latter part of the first paragraph {1} of art. Alw.] One says, maA OadoriI OaI-u Aln-aAsi huwa [I know not who of mankind he is]. (The Lexicons passim.) And IAạr mentions the saying maA tadoriI maA diroyatuhaA, (M,) or durayotuhaA, (TA,) as meaning Thou knowest not (maA taEolamu [which may also be rendered she knows not]) what is her knowledge. (M, TA.)

daraI, (T, M, Ḳ,) aor. yadoriI, (T, Ṣ,) inf. n. daroIN, (T, M, Ḳ,) He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) a man, (ISk, T,) and an object of the chase; as also Aid-araI↓ and tdr-I↓: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ: [AdorAhu in the CK is a mistake for Ad-rAhu:]) he hid, or concealed, himself, and deceived, deluded,, &c. (Ṣ.) A rájiz says,
kayofa taraAniI Oac-ariI waOad-ariI↓
gir-aAti jumolK watadar-aI↓ girariI , (T, Ṣ, M) i. e. How seest thou me winnowing the dust of the mine and deceiving Juml by looking at her while she is inadvertent, (T, Ṣ,) she also deceiving me [by looking at me while I am inadvertent]: tadar-aI being for tatadar-aI. (Ṣ.) See also 3.

daraI raOosahu, (Ḳ,) aor. yadoriI, inf. n. daroIN, (TA,) He scratched his head with the midoraI: (Ḳ:) or dr-I↓ raOosahu he combed his head with the midoraI: (M: [see Ḥam p. 159, line 11: and see also car-aIa:]) and tadar-ato↓ she (a woman, Ṣ) loosed and let down, or loosed and separated, or combed, her hair (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) with the midoraAp. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see above {1}, last sentence.
dar-ayotu turaAba AlmaEodini, inf. n. tadoriyapN, [I winnowed the dust of the mine to separate its gold: a dial. var. of car-ayotu: or perhaps a mistake for the latter.] (Mṣb.)

3. dArAhu, (T, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. mudaAraApN, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him: (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb:) or deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; or strove, endeavoured, or desired, to do so: (T, Mgh:) mudaAraApu Aln-aAsi and mudaAraOapu Aln-aAsi both signify AlmudaAjaApu and AlmulaAyanapu: (Ṣ in the present art.:) and daAraOotuhu and daArayotuhu both signify I was fearful, or cautious, of him; and treated him with gentleness or blandishment, or soothed him, coaxed him, wheedled him, or cajoled him: (Ṣ in art. drO:) or daAraOotuhu means “I was fearful, or cautious, of him,” as says AZ; or “of his evil, or mischief:” and daArayotu signifies I deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted; as also darayotu↓: (T in art. drO:) and mudaAraApN also signifies [the acting with] good nature or disposition; and the holding familiar intercourse with others. (T in the present art.) You say also, dArAhu Eani AlOamori, and Ealayohi, He endeavoured to turn him, or entice him, by blandishment, or by deceitful arts, from the thing, and to it; syn. raAwadahu. (L in art. rwd.)
And dArI Eanohu He defended him; or spoke, or pleaded, or contended, in defence of him; like raAjama Eanohu. (TA in art. rjm.)

hom.sense: 4. AdArhu bihi He made him to know, or have knowledge of, it; acquainted him with it. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) The reading walaA OadoraOakumo bihi, with C, [in the Ḳur x. 17,] is incorrect: the proper reading is without C. (Ṣ, M.)
AdrI dariy-apF, and tdr-I↓, (M, TA,) He took for himself, or prepared, a dry-p. (TA.) [See also tadar-aOa.]
5: see 1, latter part, in two places,
and also {1} in the last sentence:
and see also 4.
jayoXN yatadar-aI [as though for yatadar-aOu] An army of which one part presses upon another; like yatajaEobaI. (TA in art. jEb.)

entry.sense: 7. AinodaraI for AinodaraOa is vulgar. (TA in art. drO.)
8: see 1, latter part, in two places.
Aid-arawo makaAnFA means They directed their course to, or towards, a place, making an inroad, or incursion, upon an enemy, and going to fight and plunder: (M, TA:) or as though they did so. (Ṣ.)
duroyapN, accord. to some copies of the Ṣ, is an inf. n. of darayotuhu meaning Ealimotuhu, like diroyapN, &c. (TA.)
OataI hecaA AlOamoru mino gayori duroyapK means This thing, or event, came without any act, or deed. (T, TA.)

dariy-apN, without C, A beast, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ,) or a camel, (ISk, T,) or a she-camel, or a cow, (M,) by means of which one conceals himself from the objects of the chase, or wild animals, (Aṣ, ISk, T, Ṣ, M,) so deceiving them, (ISk, T, M,) shooting, or casting, when he is able to do so: (Aṣ, ISk, T, Ṣ:) or, accord. to AZ, it is with C, [dariyoYapN,] because the dryYp is driven (tudoraOu, i. e. tudofaEu,) towards the objects of the chase. (Ṣ, M.)
Also A wild animal, or wild animals, (waHoX,) specially of such as are objects of the chase. (M, TA.)
And A thing, (Ḳ,) or ring, (Ḥam p. 75,) by aiming at which one learns to pierce or thrust [with the spear]. (Ḥam, Ḳ.) So in a verse cited voce dariyoYapN, in art. drO. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)
Ald-aAriI, as an epithet applied to God: see 1.

hom.sense:
midorFI and midoraApN↓ (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and madoriyapN↓, (T, M, Ḳ,) the last with fet-ḥ to the m and with kesr to the r, (TA, [in the CK, erroneously, midoriyap,]) An iron instrument with which the head is scratched, called [in Pers.] saro xaAraho; (T;) a thing like a large needle, with which the female hair-dresser adjusts, or puts in order, the locks of a woman's hair; (Ṣ;) a thing with which the head is scratched: (W p. 125, in explanation of the first:) or a wooden instrument which a woman puts into her hair: (TA voce miXoqaOapN, in explanation of the second:) and, (T, Ṣ,) as being likened to the iron instrument thus called, (T,) a horn (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of a [wild] bull [and of a gazelle], (T, Ṣ,) with which the female hairdresser sometimes adjusts, or puts in order, the locks of a woman's hair, (Ṣ,) or with which one scratches his head: (Ḳ:) and, accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, a comb: (TA:) the pl. is madaArK and madaAraI, (M, Ḳ, TA,) in the latter of which, the alif [written I] is a substitute for I [properly so called]. (M, TA.)
[Hence,] jaOobN AlmidoraI, or jaAbu AlmdrI (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ, [or jaOobapu AlmidoraI, or jaOobapu AlmdrI, see arts. jOb and jwb,]) A gazelle whose horn is thick; which shows it to be young. (Ṣ.)
[See also mirodFI (in art. rdI), last sentence.]

entry.sense: midoraApN: see the next preceding paragraph.
madoriyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. das-ahu, (Ṣ, M, A, &c.,) aor. _u {yadosusu}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. das-N (M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and das-iysaI, (Ḳ,) like xiS-iySaI, (TA,) He hid it, or concealed it, (Lth, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, anything, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) in the earth or dust, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or beneath a thing: (A, Mgh:) he buried it (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) in the earth or dust, (Mṣb,) or beneath a thing: (Ḳ:) or he put it in, or inserted it, beneath: (M:) or, accord. to some, he put it in, or inserted it, with force; he thrust it in: (TA:) and das-asahu↓ and das-aAhu↓, (M, Ḳ,*) in the latter of which one of the s is changed into I because the reduplication is disliked, (M,* TA,) signify the same as das-ahu, (M, Ḳ,*) [or, probably, have an intensive signification.] It is said in the Ḳur [xvi. 61], Oamo yadus-uhu Alt-uraAbi Or whether he shall bury it in the dust: meaning, his female child, which he buried alive: the pronoun agreeing with the word mA [which precedes in the same verse]. (T, TA.) It is also said in the Ḳur [xci. 9 and 10], qado OafolaHa mano zak-aAhaA waqado xaAba mano das-aAhaA↓, (M, Ḳ,*) in which ds-AhA is for das-asahaA↓, like taZan-ayotu for taZan-anotu, (Ḳ,) because the niggardly conceals his place of sojourning and his property, but the liberal makes his place of sojourning upon an open and elevated spot that he may not be concealed from guests and those who desire to come to him: (Fr, Zj, Ḳ:*) or the meaning is, He is successful who maketh it (namely his soul) pure and believing, and he is unsuccessful who introduceth it among the good when he is not of them: (IAạr, Th, M, Ḳ:*) or [he is successful who maketh it to increase in grace by good works,] and he is unsuccessful who maketh it vile and little by evil works: (M:) or the latter clause means, and he is unsuccessful who hideth it, and maketh it obscure and of no reputation, by the neglect of almsgiving and of obedience [to God in other matters]: (TA:) or the soul is unsuccessful that God rendereth obscure [so I render, here, ds-AhA]. (Fr, Ḳ.)

das-a AlbaEiyra,, aor. _u {yadosusu}, inf. n. das-N, He anointed the camel with tar, not thoroughly, [but only in the arm-pits, and the inner parts of the roots of the thighs or other similar parts:] (M:) [for it is said that] dus-a AlbaEiyru signifies the camel was anointed with tar in the parts called the masaAEir: (Ṣ: [see dajala:]) or the latter signifies the camel became swollen in the parts so called. (M.) Hence the prov., layosa AlhanoCu biAld-as-i [which see explained in art. hnO]. (TA in art. hnO. [In the Ṣ and M and TA, in the present art., instead of AlhanoCu, we find AlhinaMCu: but the former is the preferable reading.])

entry.sense: 2. das-asahu and das-aAhu: see das-ahu; each in two places.

7. Ands- [He, or it, became hidden, or concealed, in the earth or dust, or beneath a thing: he, or it, hid, or concealed, himself, or itself, in the earth, &c.:] he, or it, became buried: he, or it, buried himself, or itself: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it became put in, or inserted, or it put in, or inserted, itself, beneath. (M.)

[Hence,] Ands- fulaAnN UilaI fulaAnK yaOotiyhi biAln-amaAYimi ‡ [Such a one came secretly to such a one, bringing him calumnies]: (TA:) or Ands- AlI flAn means † he came to such a one with calumnies. (Ḥam p. 219.)
das-N Tar with which the arm-pits, and the inner parts of the roots of the thighs or other similar parts, of camels, are anointed. (TA.)

hom.sense: dasiysN The concealment of guile or artifice. (Ṣ.)

One whom thou hidest, or concealest, (mano tadus-uhu,) in order that he may bring thee news, or information: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to some, similar to mutaHas-isN; (M;) or mutajas-isN; and called by the vulgar daAsuwsN↓: (TA:) or dasiysu qawomK signifies one whom a people send secretly to bring them news, or information; (A;) the spy of a people, who searches for, and then brings, news, or information; syn. jaAsuws. (Mṣb.)
And dususN [pl. of dasiysN] Persons hypocritical in their actions, who enter among the reciters of the Ḳur-án when they are not of them. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dasiysapN [app. The coming secretly to a person, bringing him calumnies: in modern Arabic, a secret machination or the like]. (TA, where, after the phrase Ands- flAn AlI flAn yOtyh bAlnmAYm, (see 7,) it is added, wahiI-a Ald-asiysapN.)

das-aAsN That enters much, or often; wont to enter; syn. dax-aAlN: so in the saying, AlEiroqu das-aAsN [The natural disposition is wont to enter and actuate him in whom it is engendered: generally applied to him who has some fault derived from his mother, or the like; as is said in a marginal note in my copy of the TA: see EiroqN]. (TA.)
daAsuwsN: see dasiysN.
madosuwsN, applied to a camel: part. n. of dus-a [q. v.]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: dasotN i. q. daXotN, (Ḳ,) A [desert, or such as is termed] SaHoraMC: an arabicized word [from the Pers. daXoto]: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it is either a dial. var. of dXt or an arabicized word from this latter. (TA.)
The upper end of a chamber, which is the most honourable place therein: (A, Ḳ, TA:) in this sense an arabicized word [from the Pers. dasoto]. (Ḳ.)

Hence, [A place, or seat, of honour: a seat of office: used in these senses in the present day:] used by the later writers to signify a court, or council; syn. diywaAnN: and the court, or council, (majolis,) of a wezeer or governor. (TA.)
A thing against, or upon, which one leans, or stays himself: (Ḥar p. 261:) a pillow, or cushion. (Id. p. 276.)
Headship, rule, dominion, government, or superiority. (MF.)

A game; a single act of a game or play: pl. dusuwtN. (TA.) You say, Ald-asotu liI The game is mine: and Ald-asotu EalaI-a The game is against me. (Ḥar p. 130.) And tam-a Ealayohi Ald-asotu [The game ended, or has ended, against him]: this is said of one who is overcome: the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance used to say so when a man's arrow [in the game called Almayosir] was unsuccessful, and he did not attain his desire. (TA.) [In the contrary case, one says, tam-a lahu Ald-asotu The game ended, or has ended, in his favour.] fulaAnN Hasanu Ald-asoti [Such a one is a good player] is said of a skilful chess-player. (A.) And a poet says,
tafarozanu fiI OuxoraI Ald-usuwti AlbayaAciqu
[The pawns become queens in the ends of the games: tafarozana being for tatafarozana]. (TA.)
[It is also used in the present day to signify A trick of cards.]
And An evasion, a shift, a wile, or an artifice; or art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill: (MF, and Ḥar p. 130:) and deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention. (Ḥar ibid.)

Also, (TA,) or dasotN mina Alv-iyaAbi, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) as also daXotN mn AlvyAb, (TA in art. dXt,) [A suit, or complete set, of clothes;] the clothes which a man wears and which suffice him for his going to and fro in the transaction of his affairs: pl. as above: (Mṣb:) in this sense, also, an arabicized word [from the Pers. dasoto]. (Ḳ.) El-Ḥareeree has mentioned together instances of this word in three different senses, in the 23rd Maḳámeh, where he says, naAXadt-uka Qll-eha Oalasota Al-aciI OaEaArahu Ald-asoto faqulotu laA waAl-aciI Oajolasaka fiI hecaA Ald-asoto maA OanaA biSaAHibi celika Ald-asoto balo Oanota Al-aciI tam-a Ealayohi Ald-asoto I conjure thee by God [to tell me], art thou not he who lent him the suit of clothes? And I said, No, by Him who seated thee in this place of honour, I am not the owner of that suit of clothes: but thou art he against whom the game hath ended. (TA.)

And dasotN mina Alwaraqi, (Ḳ,) as also daXotN mn Alwrq, (TA in art. dXt,) [A quire, or twenty-five sheets folded together, of paper: still used in this sense: pl. as above:] in this sense, also, an arabicized word [from the Pers. dasoto]. (Ḳ.)
[dasotN is also used in the present day in a similar, but more extensive, sense; as signifying A lot, or parcel, of things: of some things, ten; of others, twelve;, &c.]

Also an appellation applied, as mentioned by El-Khafájee in the “Shifá el-Ghaleel,” by the common people of Egypt and of other countries of the East, to A copper cooking-pot: (MF:) [it is still used in this sense; applied in Egypt to a copper cookingpot wide at the bottom, contracted at the mouth, and more contracted a little below the mouth. And dasotu xaXabK is applied to A shallow wooden tub.]

entry.sense:
Ald-asotabanodu [from the Pers. dasobanodo] A certain game of the Magians, which they thus call; i. q. Ald-aEokasapu: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. dEks:)
they turn round [in a circle, as though imitating the revolutions of the “host of heaven”], having taken one another by the hand, [in a manner] like dancing. (Ḳ in that art.) [Hence probably originated the similar performances of certain Muslim darweeshes in celebrating what they term a cikor, described in the works of several travellers, and in my own work on the Modern Egyptians.]

dusotuwrN, an arabicized word, (Ḳ,) [from the Persian dasotuwro,] by some of the Arabs, [and in the present day generally,] pronounced dasotuwrN, which is not absolutely erroneous, as it is the original form of the word before its being arabicized, (MF,) The copy, or original, [of the register, as will be seen from what follows,] which is made for the several classes [of the officers and servants of the government], from which their transcription is made, (expl. by Aln-usoxapu AlmaEomuwlapu lilojamaAEaAti Qlt-aIi minohaA taHoriyruhaA, Ḳ,) and in which are collected the rules and ordinances of the King; (TA;) the register (dafotar) in which are collected the rules of the realm: (Kull p. 186:) pl. dasaAtiyru. (Ḳ.)

Hence, ‡ The great wezeer (waziyr) to whom recourse is had [by the King] with respect to what he may prescribe concerning the circumstances of the people, because he is the possessor of the register so called: (Mefáteeh el-'Uloom by Ibn-Kemál-Páshà, in TA; and Kull ubi suprà:) the officer who manages, conducts, orders, or regulates, the affairs of the King. (TA.)
[Hence also, in the conventional language of astronomy, ‡ An almanac.]

Also, vulgarly, Permission; leave. (TA.) [For instance, it is used in this sense by a man entering a house, or approaching an apartment, in which he supposes that there may be some woman whom he should not see unveiled, in order that she may veil herself or retire: on such an occasion, he repeats the word dstwr several times as he advances.]

1. dasarahu, (Ṣ, M, A,) aor. _u {yadosuru}, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. dasorN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He, or it, pushed, thrust, drove, impelled, propelled, or repelled, him, or it. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.) Ambergris is said (by I’Ab, Ṣ) to be XaIoCN yadosuruhu AlbaHoru A thing which the sea drives (Ṣ, A) and casts upon the shore. (TA.) And dasarati Als-afiynapu AlmaMCa biSadorihaA means The ship repelled, (TA,) or opposed, (M,) the water with its prow. (M, TA.)
He thrust, pierced, or stabbed, him, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) vehemently, (A,) with a spear. (Ṣ, A.)

dasara, (M,) aor. _u {yadosuru} and _i {yadosiru}, (TA,) inf. n. dasorN, (M, Ḳ, TA,) He drove in a nail, with force: (Ḳ,* TA:) he nailed anything: (M:) he fastened, (M,) or repaired, (Ḳ,) a ship with a nail, (M, Ḳ,) or with cord of fibres of the palm-tree: (M:) or he fastened a ship by uniting its planks in the manner of sewing. (TA.)
dasara, (A,) inf. n. as above, (M, Ḳ,) ‡ Inivit feminam: (M,* A, Ḳ:*) you say dasarahaA biOayorihi. (TA.)
dasoraMCu, [fem. of Oadosaru↓, and] sing. of dusorN, which (as some say, TA) means Ships that repel [or oppose] the water with their prows. (Ḳ.)

disaArN Cord of the fibres of the palm-tree (liyf) with which the planks of a ship are bound together: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) or (so accord. to the Ṣ and M and A, but accord. to Fr and the Ḳ “and”) a nail, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) of a ship: (M:) pl. dusurN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and dusorN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) used in one or the other of these two significations in the Ḳur liv. 13. (Ṣ, TA.)

dawosarN A bulky camel: fem. with p {dawosarapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a camel (M) strong and bulky; (M, Ḳ;) as also dawosariI-N↓ (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ) and dawosaraAniI-N↓ (Ṣ,* Ḳ) and duwaAsirN↓ (M, Ḳ) and duwasiriI-N↓: (L:) fem. dawosarN [like the masc.] and dawosarapN: or dawosarN, applied to a she-camel, signifies large: (M:) and dawosariI-N↓ a strong camel: (Fr, TA:) and duwaAsirN↓ sharp, spirited, or vigorous, and strong. (TA.)
A tough, or hardy, lion, (Ḳ, B,) firm in make. (B, TA.)
A penis bulky (M, Ḳ) and strong. (M.)

katiybapN dawosarN, and dawosarapN, An army, or a troop of horse, or a portion of an army, collected together. (M.) And dawosaru An army, or a troop of horse, or a portion of an army, belonging to En-Noamán (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) Ibn-El-Mundhir. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
dawosariI-N: see dawosarN, in two places.
dawosaraAniI-N: see dawosarN.
duwaAsirN: see dawosarN, in two places.
duwaAsiriI-N: see dawosarN.
Oadosaru: see dasoraMCu.
midosarN [A man who thrusts much with the spear. A signification implied in the Ṣ.]
‡ Qui multum coit. (Ḳ.)

1. dasaEahu, aor. _a {yadosaEu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. dasoEN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and dasiyEapN, (Ṣ, TA,) He impelled it, pushed it, thrust it, or drove it; and particularly so as to remove it from its place; propelled it, repelled it; pushed it, thrust it, or drove it, away, or back. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA.)

Hence, (TA,) dasaEa AlbaEiyru bijir-atihi, (Ṣ, Z, L,) aor. _a {yadosaEu}, (TA,) inf. n. dasoEN (Z, TA) and dusuwEN, (TA,) The camel propelled his cud so as to make it pass forth from his inside to his mouth; (Ṣ, TA;) drew it forth from his stomach and cast it into his mouth. (Z, L, TA.) And dasaEa fulaAnN baqiyoYihi Such a one cast forth his vomit. (TA.) And dasaEa alone, (Mgh, TA,) aor. _a {yadosaEu}, (TA,) inf. n. dasoEN, (Ḳ,) He vomited: (Ḳ, TA:) or he vomited as much as filled his mouth. (Mgh.) And dasaEa AlbaHoru biAlEanobari The sea collected together the ambergris like foam, or scum, and then cast it aside. (TA.)

[Hence, also, (as appears from an explanation of dasiyEapN, q. v. infrà,)] dasaEa, aor. _a {yadosaEu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. dasoEN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He gave a large gift. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) It is said in a trad., (Ṣ, TA,) that God will ask the son of Adam on the day of resurrection, (TA,) Oalamo OajoEaloka tarobaEu watadosaEu Did I not make thee to take the fourth part of the spoil, and to give largely? (Ṣ:) and on his answering “Yes,” that God will ask, “Then where is [thy] gratitude for that?” for the doing thus is the act of the chief. (TA.)
And dasaEotu AlqaSoEapa, (Ibn-ʼAbbád,) inf. n. dasoEN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) I filled the bowl. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, 'K.*)
and dasaEa AljuHora, (TA,) inf. n. dasoEN, (Ḳ,) He stopped up the burrow at once (Ḳ, TA) with a stopper of rag, or some other thing of the size of the burrow. (TA.)
dasoEapN [inf. n. of un. of 1].
A single act of vomiting. (Mgh, TA.)
dasiyEapN an inf. n. (Ṣ, TA.) dasiyEapu ZulomK A wrongful, or tyrannical, pushing, or thrusting, or the like; for dasiyEapN mino ZulomK; occurring in a trad. (TA.)

A gift: (Ṣ:) a large gift: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because given at once, like as a camel's cud is propelled by him with a single impulse. (TA.) You say of a munificent man, (Az, TA,) huwa Daxomu Ald-asiyEapi (Az, Ṣ, TA) He is a large giver; one who gives much. (Az, TA.)
Natural disposition: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, generosity of action: or, as some say, make; or natural constitution. (TA.)
The pl. is dasaAYiEu. (TA.)

dasokarapN A building like a qaSor [q. v.], surrounded by houses, or chambers, (Lth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and places of abode for the servants and household, (TA,) and pertaining to kings: (Lth, Mgh, Mṣb:) Heraclius is related, in trads., to have received the great men of the Greeks in a dskrp belonging to him: (TA:) or a building like a qaSor, which is surrounded by houses, or chambers, and in which the vitious, or immoral, (XuT-aAr,) assemble: (Ḥar p. 140:) or houses of the foreigners (OaEaAjim), in which are wine and instruments of music or the like: (Ḳ:) thought by Az to be an arabicized word; (Mṣb;) not genuine Arabic: (TA:) [from the Persian dasokaraho, or dasotokaraho:] pl. dasaAkiru. (Ḳ.)
Also A Christian's cloister, or cell; syn. SawomaEapN. (AA, Ḳ.)
And A town, or village; syn. qaroyapN. (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And A plain, or level, land. (Ḳz, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. dasima, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadosamu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dasamN, (Mṣb, TA,) or dusuwmapN, (Mgh, in which the verb is not mentioned,) It (a thing, Ṣ, M, Mgh, or food, Mṣb) was, or became, greasy; or had in it, or upon it, grease, or gravy, or dripping of flesh-meat or of fat; (M, Ḳ,* Mgh;) as also tds-m↓: (M:) and it (a garment, or some other thing,) was, or became, dirty, or filthy. (Ḳ.)
And dasima, (inf. n. dasamN, TḲ,) He, or it, was, or became, of the colour termed dusomap, i. e., dust-colour inclining to blackness. (M, Ḳ.)

dasama, (Z, Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ,) [aor., app., _i,] inf. n. dasomN; (TA;) or ds-m↓; (so in some copies of the Ṣ;) said of rain, It moistened the earth (Ṣ, Z, Ḳ) a little, (Ḳ,) not much, (Ṣ,) or so as not to reach the moist soil. (Z, TA.)
And dasama, aor. _i {yadosimu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dasomN, (TA,) He smeared a camel with tar. (Ḳ.)

And hence, i. e. from dasama AljuroHa or from dasama AlqaAruwrapa, (TA,) ‡ Inivit feminam. (Kr, M, Ḳ, TA.) [And hence also,] one says to the musotaHAaDap, [see this word,] AudosumiI waSal-iI † [Stuff thy vagina with cotton, to arrest the blood, and say thy prayers]. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dasomN, (TA,) He closed, or locked, a door; syn. Oagolaqa. (Ḳ.)

Also, (i. e. dasama,) i. q. Tasama, [in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA, Tamasa, which signifies the same, i. e. It became effaced, or obliterated,] said of a relic, trace, mark, or the like. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. tadosiymN, (Ṣ,) inf. n. of ds-m, (Mṣb,) signifies The smearing (Ṣ, Mṣb) a thing, (Ṣ,) or a morsel, or mouthful, (Mṣb,) [or seasoning it, imbuing it, or soaking it,] with dasam [i. e. grease, or gravy, or dripping]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

das-imuwA nuwnatahu, (Mgh, Ḳ,) said by ʼOthmán respecting a beautiful boy, (Mgh,) means Blacken ye his dimple in the chin, in order that the evil eye may not have effect upon it. (Mgh, Ḳ.*) [Accord. to another explanation, mentioned in the TA, the blackness denoted by this phrase is behind the ear: but this is evidently a mistake.]
See also 1.
4: see 1.
5: see 1.
tds-mwA also signifies They ate [food] with dasam [i. e. grease, or gravy, or dripping] dasam (TA.)

hom.sense: dasomN: see dasamN.
OanaA EalaI dasomi AlOamori means ElI TarafK minohu [app. I am beside, or out of, the case, or affair]. (Ḳ.)

dasamN a word of well-known meaning; (Ṣ;) i. q. wadakN; (M, Ḳ;) both signifying Grease, or gravy; i. e. the dripping that exudes from flesh-meat and from fat; (Mṣb in art. wdk;) the wadak of flesh-meat and of fat: (Mgh: [in the CK, Alwaraku is erroneously put for Alwadaku:]) or, accord. to the T, anything that has wadak, of flesh-meat and of fat: (TA:) and dirt, or filth: (M, Ḳ:) and dasomN↓ signifies the same as dasamN, accord. to El-Kurtubee; but El-Welee El-'Irákee says, I have not seen this on the authority of any other lexicologist. (TA.) You say, yaduhu mina Ald-asami saliTapN [app. meaning, if correctly transcribed, His hand is hard by reason of dirt adhering to it: in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, the last word is written saTilapN; a word which I do not find in any sense: in the TḲ, sTlp: this Freytag thinks to be the right reading, though I know of no such word; and he renders the phrase, “manus ejus propter sordes inhaerentes catinus est;” evidently assuming that sTlp is a dial. var. of saTolN]. (Ḳ.) [It seems that you say also, maA fiyhi dasamN meaning † There is not in him, or it, any profit, or good: a sense assigned in the TA to the phrase mA fyh dysm dsm; in which I think it evident that the transcriber has written dysm by mistake, and forgotten to erase it after adding dsm.]
Also The bowels, or intestines. (TA.)

Accord. to IAạr, it means also kaviyru Alc-ikori [Praising, or glorifying, God, much]; a sense in which it is incorrectly said in the Ḳ to be dasiymN↓, like OamiyrN: (TA:) and hence the trad., of weak authority, laA yacokuruwna Qll-eha Uil-aA dasamFA: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Z, this is from dasama said of rain: and, as related by Abu-d-Dardà, the words are OaraDiytumo Uino XabiEotumo EaAmFA Oal-aA tacokuruwna Qll-eha Uil-aA dasamFA, meaning [Do ye approve, if ye be satisfied in your stomachs throughout a year,] that ye should not praise, or glorify, God, save a little? (TA:) or it may denote commendation; so that the meaning of lA yckrwn Qll-eh Al-A dsmFA is, that praise, or glorification, is the stuffing of their hearts and of their mouths: and it may denote discommendation; as meaning that they praise, or glorify, little; from tadosiymu nuwnapi AlS-abiI-i; (Ḳ, TA;) the blackness denoted by this phrase being small in quantity: or, as some say, the meaning is, that they do not praise, or glorify, God for anything but eating, and the grease, or gravy, in their insides. (TA.)

entry.sense:
dasimN A thing greasy; or having in it, or upon it, grease or gravy, (M, Mgh,) of flesh-meat or of fat: (Mgh:) [and dirty, or filthy: pl. dusomN; like as curobN is pl. of caribN.] You say maraqapN dasimapN [Greasy broth]. (TA.) And viyaAbN dusomN, Dirty, or filthy, garments. (Ṣ, TA.) And dasima Alv-awobi, applied to a man, [Dirty in the garment: and hence, going on foot;] not riding; as also Oadosamu↓ Alv-awobi. (TA.) [Hence also,] † Defiled by culpable dispositions. (TA.) A rájiz says,
laAhum-a Uin-a EaAmira bona jahomi
Oawocama Haj-FA fiI viyaAbK dusomi
meaning † [O God, verily 'Ámir Ibn-Jahm] hath imposed upon himself, (Ṣ in art. wcm,) or hath performed, (M,) pilgrimage being defiled by sins. (Ṣ in art. wcm, and M.)

EimaAmapN dasimapN signifies A black turban; (TA;) as also dasomaMCu↓ EmAmp. (Az, Mgh, TA.) And dasimN occurs in a trad. as meaning † Strict, or pious, [though] black, (Oasowadu, [or this may here mean a genuine Arab, as opposed to OaHomaru meaning a foreigner,]) and religious. (TA.)

hom.sense: Oum-u dasomap [probably a mistranscription for Oum-u dusomapK↓, lit. “the mother of blackness;”] † The cooking-pot. (T in art. Am.)
Mxiru dasomapK i. q. Mxiru EahodK [The last time]; like Mxiru maxoTarK. (TA in art. xTr. [See xaTorapN, last sentence.])
dusomapN A thing with which a hole in a skin for water or milk is stopped up. (M, Ḳ.)
Blackness; (IAạr, TA;) [and] so dayosamN↓: (Ḳ:) or dust-colour inclining to blackness. (M, Ḳ.) Hence the Abyssinian is called Oabuw dusomapK. (IAạr, TA.) See also Oum-u dasomap, above.

Applied to a man, † Low, or ignoble; base; vile; mean, or sordid: (Ṣ, TA:) or bad, corrupt, base, or vile. (M, Ḳ. [Freytag erroneously assigns the meaning “vilis” to Oadosamu.]) One says, maA Oanota Uil-aA dusomapN ‡ Thou art none other than one in whom is no good. (TA.)

entry.sense: disaAmN A stopper; (M, Ḳ;) a thing with which one stops up the ear, and a wound, and the like, and the head of a flask or bottle, and the like. (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad. that the Devil has a disaAm; meaning that he has a stopper by which he prevents one from seeing the truth (M, TA) and from keeping in mind admonition. (TA.)
dasiymN: see dasamN.
daAsimN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: dayosamN Darkness. (M, Ḳ.)
See also dusomapN.

The fox: (Ḳ:) [or] the young one of the fox: (M:) or, as some say, (M,) the young one of the fox from the bitch: (M, Ḳ:) and (so in the M, but in the Ḳ “or”) of the wolf from the bitch: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and the bear: (Ḳ:) or the young one of the bear; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) which is the only meaning allowed by Abu-l-Ghowth. (Ṣ.) Also, (Ḳ,) or as some say, (M,) The young one of the bee. (M, Ḳ.) And, accord. to Abu-lFet-h, (TA,) whose name was dayosamN, (Ḳ,* TA,) the companion of Ḳuṭrub, A [young ant, such as is termed] car-apN: (TA:) or dayosamapN↓ [in the CK erroneously written dasamap] has this last signification. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
Also A certain plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL,) called in Pers. bstAn Afrwz [which is said to be a name applied to the amaranth, anemone, and the like]. (KL.)
And [A man] gentle, nice, or skilful, in work; careful, or solicitous [therein]; as also daAsimN↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dayosamapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: OadosamN, and its fem. dasomaMCu: see dasimN.
dasomaMCu also signifies A kind of milking-vessel; i. q. EulobapN and janobapN and samoraMCu. (T and TA in art. Elb.)
Also [Black: see dusomapN: or] of a dust-colour inclining to blackness: (M, Ḳ:) fem. as above. (Ḳ.)

[Freytag assigns to it also the significations “Multum pinguis” and “Oleo conspurcatus;” both as on the authority of the Ḳ, in which I do not find either of them: also that of “Vilis,” as applied to a man; a signification belonging to dusomapN.]

daXotN A [desert, or such as is termed] SaHoraMC; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also dasotN: (Mṣb and Ḳ in art. dst:)
a Persian word [arabicized]; or an instance of agreement between the two languages [of Arabia and Persia]. (Ṣ.)
daXotN mina Alv-iyaAbi, and mina Alwaraqi, i. q. dasotN. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. daE-ahu, aor. _u {yadoEuEu}, (Ṣ, Z,) inf. n. daE-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He pushed him, thrust him, or drove him, away; he repelled him: (Ṣ:) or he did so harshly, roughly, or violently. (AʼObeyd, Ḳ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [cvii. 2], facelika Al-aciI yaduE-u Alyatiyma That is he who pusheth, thrusteth, or driveth, away the orphan: (Ṣ:) or, who doth so harshly, roughly, or violently: (Bḍ, Jel:) or, who treateth the orphan with harshness, roughness, or violence; pushing, thrusting, or driving, away; and chiding with rudeness, or coarseness. (Z, TA.) And in like manner, in the same [lii. 13], yawoma yudaE-uwna UilaI naAri jahan-ama daE-FA On the day when they shall be pushed, or thrust, or driven, with harshness, roughness, or violence, to the fire of Hell. (AʼObeyd, Bḍ, Jel, TA.) And in a trad. of Esh-Shaabee, kaAnuwA laA yudaE-uwna Eanohu They used not to be driven, nor pushed, or repelled, from it. (TA.)

1. daEaba, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoEabu}, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. duEaAbapN (Ṣ,* Mgh, MF) and duEobubN, (MF,) [see the former of these two ns. below,] He jested, or joked; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also daEiba, aor. _a {yadoEabu}: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or he jested, or joked, with playing, or sporting. (TA.)
And i. q. dafaEa [He impelled, pushed, thrust,, &c.]. (Ḳ.)
And Inivit [feminam]. (A, Ḳ.)
[The last, perhaps, from the same verb signifying He trod a road; mentioned by Freytag as used in this sense in the Deewán of the Hudhalees.]
3. dAEbhu, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. mudaAEabapN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) He jested, or joked, with him: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or he did so, playing, or sporting, with him: see 1.]
5. tdE-b Ealayohi He acted, or behaved, presumptuously, or boldly, towards him; syn. tadal-ala, (Ḳ, TA,) from Ald-alaAlu. (TA.)
6. tdAEbwA They jested, or joked, [or they did so, playing, or sporting,] one with another. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
daEibN: see daAEibN.

hom.sense: duEobubN: see duEaAbapN.
See also daAEibN:
and duEobuwbN.
Also A good, or an excellent, singer. (Ḳ.)
A youth soft or tender, thin-skinned, or fine-shinned, and plump. (Ḳ.)
The fruit of a certain plant: (Ḳ:) or (Ḳ, TA) the plant itself, namely, (TA,) Eanibu Alv-aEolabi; [see art. vElb;] (Ḳ, TA;) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
duEobuwbN, (Ḳ, TA,) applied to a man, (TA,) Brisk, lively, or sprightly. (Ḳ.)
Weak, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and an object of ridicule. (Ḳ.)
Short and ugly and contemptible. (Ḳ,* TA.)
I. q. muxan-avN, (CK, and so in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) or muxan-ivN, of the form of the act. part. n., (TA,) [Effeminate,, &c.]
Applied to a horse, Tall, or long-bodied; syn. TawiylN. (Ḳ.)
A road beaten, or trodden, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) travelled, (TA,) and plain, or conspicuous. (Ḳ, TA.)
A dark night. (Ḳ.)
Black ants; as also duEaAbapN↓. (Ḳ.)
A certain black esculent grain: or the stem, or root, (OaSol,) of a certain herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolap,) which is peeled and eaten. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: riyHN duEobiy-apN: see daAEibN.

hom.sense: duEaAbapN A jesting, or joking; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) such as is deemed pleasing, or facetious: (Mṣb:) or play, or sport; (A, Ḳ;) as also duEobubN↓: (Ḳ:) both of which words are also used as inf. ns.: and the latter is also used as an epithet; [as explained below, voce daAEibN;] app. in an intensive sense [because originally an inf. n.]. (MF.) And Speech that causes laughter. (Ḥar p. 18.)
Also Stupidity, or foolishness. (Ḳ.)
See also duEobuwbN.

entry.sense: daE-aAbN: see the next paragraph.
daE-aAbapN: see the next paragraph.

daAEibN and daEibN↓ (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [in a sense thought by MF to be intensive (see duEaAbapN)] duEobubN↓ (Ḳ) and [in an intensive sense] daE-aAbN↓ (Ṣ [there coupled with laE-aAbN, perhaps as an explicative adjunct,]) and [in a sense doubly intensive] daE-aAbapN↓ (Ḳ) Jesting, or joking, (A, Mṣb,) and saying what is deemed pleasing, or facetious: (A:) or playing, or sporting: (Ḳ:) [in the case of the third, app., and of the fourth, much, or often: and in the case of the last, very much, or very often.]

[Hence,] maMCN daAEibN ‡ Water playing in its course, or running hither and thither: (A, Ḳ:) pl. miyaAhN dawaAEibu. (A.) And riyHN daAEibapN A wind, (A,) or violent wind, (TA,) that carries away everything; as it were, making sport with it: pl. riyaAHN dawaAEibN: (A, TA:) and riyHN duEobiy-apN↓ signifies the same; (TA;) or [simply] a violent wind. (Ḳ.)
OadoEabu: see duEobuwbN.

daEija, [aor. _a {yadoEaju},] inf. n. daEajN, He (a man, &c.) was, or became, characterized by what is termed daEajN as explained below. (TA.) And daEijati AlEayonu The eye was, or became, [so characterized; or] wide and black; or intensely black and intensely white. (Mṣb.)

daEajN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and duEojapN↓ (Ḳ) Blackness: or intense blackness: (TA:) or width, with blackness, of the eye: (Mṣb:) or intense blackness, with width, of the eye: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or intense blackness in the eye, with intense whiteness thereof and width thereof: (A:) or intense blackness of the black of the eye, with intense whiteness of the white thereof; (Mṣb,* TA;) but accord. to Az, this is said only by Lth, and is a mistake. (TA.)
Also, the former, Blueness inclining to whiteness. (MF.)
duEojapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: daEojaMCu Insanity, or diabolical possession: (Ḳ:) accord. to MF, it is an inf. n. [of which the verb is not mentioned]. (TA.)
Also fem. of the epithet next following. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: OadoEaju A man characterized by what is termed daEajN in the eyes: fem. daEojaMCu: and pl. duEojN. (Mṣb.) And EayonN daEojaMCu An eye so characterized. (Ṣ.)
Also Black; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as an epithet applied to a man. (Ṣ.)

And ‡ A bull, (A,) [i. e.] a wild bull, and a he-goat, (TA,) characterized by intense blackness (A) of the horns, (A, TA,) and of the head, and of the legs, (A,) and of the eyes, in the case of the he-goat. (TA.)
XafapN daEojaMCu and livapN daEojaMCu ‡ [A lip and a gum app. of a blue colour inclining to white]. (TA.)
layolN OadoEaju ‡ [A black, or an intensely black, night;] a dark, black night. (A,* TA.)
Ald-aEojaMCu ‡ The first of [the three nights called] the muHaAq; i. e. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) the twenty-eighth night: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) the second is called Als-araAru; and the third, Alfalotapu. (Ṣ.)
madoEuwjN Affected with insanity, or diabolical possession. (Ḳ.)
1. daEira, aor. _a {yadoEaru}, inf. n. daEarN, It (wood) was bad; (Ṣ;) it smoked much: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or smoked, and did not burn brightly, or blaze. (Ḳ.)
It (a zanod [or piece of wood for producing fire]) failed to produce fire: (Ḳ:) or became burned at its extremity from frequent use in producing fire, and failed to produce fire. (TA.)

daEira, aor. _a {yadoEaru}; and daEara, aor. _a {yadoEaru}; inf. n. daEaArapN; He acted vitiously, or immorally; transgressed the command of God; or committed adultery or fornication: syn. fajara wamajara [the latter of which appears to be an imitative sequent to the former]: (TA:) and daEira, inf. n. daEarN, he stole, committed adultery or fornication, and did harm to others: (ISh, TA:) and daEira he acted badly, corruptly, or wickedly: from the same verb in the first of the senses explained above. (Mṣb.) [See also daEarN, below.]

daEarN Bad, corrupt, or wicked, conduct; syn. fasaAdN, [in the sense of UifosaAdN,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and xubovN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and daEaArapN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and diEaArapN↓ and daEorapN↓, or daEarapN↓, (as in different copies of the Ḳ,) signify the same; syn. xubovN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and UifosaAdN; (Mṣb;) and vice, or immorality; vitious, or immoral, conduct; transgression of the command of God;
or the commission of adultery or fornication: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and treachery; and hypocrisy: (TA:) and daEaArapN↓ also signifies illnature; or excessive perverseness or crossness: (Mṣb:) and daEaAr-apN↓, with a sheddeh to the r, evilness, or badness, in the disposition; (Ḳ;) as also daEarapN↓. (TA.)

daEirN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and duEarN↓ (El-Ghanawee, Ṣ, Ḳ) Bad wood; (Ṣ;) which smokes much: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) or which smokes, and does not burn brightly, or blaze: (Ḳ:) and the former, wood, &c., that burns, and becomes extinguished before it burns intensely; (Ḳ;) n. un. with p {daEirapN}: (TA:) old, wasted, crumbling, and bad, wood, (Sh, Ḳ,) which, when put upon the fire, does not burn brightly, or blaze; (Sh;) as also daAEirN↓: (Ḳ:) but [SM says,] I do not find any one beside the author of the Ḳ to have mentioned this last word as applied to wood. (TA.)

Also daEirN, or duEarN↓, A zanod [or piece of wood for producing fire] having its extremity burnt from frequent use in producing fire, and failing to produce fire; (TA;) as also OadoEaru↓: (Ṣ:) or this signifies a znd that does not produce fire. (Ḳ.)
duEarN: see daEirN, in two places:
and see daAEirN.
daEorapN and daEarapN: see daEarN; the second, in two places.
duEarapN: see daAEirN.
daEaArapN and diEaArapN and daEaAr-apN: see daEarN; the first, in two places.
daAEirN: see daEirN.

Also A man who acts badly, corruptly, or wickedly; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb;) who acts vitiously, or immorally; transgresses the command of God; or commits adultery or fornication; (ISh, Ṣ, A;) and does harm to others: (ISh:) pl. duE-aArN; which is also explained as signifying men who intercept, and rob, or slay, travellers on the way: (TA:) fem. with p {daAEirapN}: (AA, Ṣ:) also duEarN↓ one in whom is no good: or treacherous, and one who attributes to his companions vices or faults; as also duEarapN↓ [in an intensive sense]. (TA.)
UibilN daAEiriy-apN Certain camels, so called in relation to a stallion named daAEirN, that begot an excellent breed: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or in relation to a tribe named thus. (Ḳ.)
OadoEarN: see daEirN.

1. daEakahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoEaku}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. daEokN, (Ṣ,) He rubbed it, or rubbed and pressed it, (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA,) or did so well, (KL,) and softened it; (TA;) namely, a skin, or hide. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
He softened its (i. e. a garment's) roughness by wearing it. (Ḳ.)
He softened him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and subdued him, or rendered him submissive; (TA;) namely, an adversary, or antagonist; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so maEakahu, inf. n. maEokN. (TA.)
daEakahu fiI Alt-uraAbi He rolled him, or turned him over, in the dust. (Ḳ.)
daEakotu Alr-ajula biAlqawoli I pained the man by speech. (IDrd.)

3. mudaAEakapN [app. The act of contending, disputing, or litigating, vehemently: (see mudaAEikN, below; and see also 6:) accord. to Golius, (who names no authority,) the act of conflicting, or contending; as though rubbing against another.]

[Also] The delaying with another, deferring with him, or putting him off, by repeated promises. (Z, TA.) You say, dAEk Algariyma He delayed, or deferred, with the creditor, or put him off, promising him payment time after time; like daAlakahu. (TA in art. dlk.)
6. tdAEkwA They contended, disputed, or litigated, one with another, vehemently. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or tdAEkA, said of two men, (Ṣ,) They contended together, smiting one another; syn. tamar-asuwA, (Ḳ,) or tamar-asaA; (Ṣ;) contended, or conflicted; (IF, TA;) fiI AlHarobi [in war, battle, or fight]. (IF, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
daEikN Very pertinacious in contention or the like; very contentious; or a great wrangler. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)

midoEakN: see the following paragraph. [For Oalad-u in the Ḳ, Golius seems to have found in his copy of that Lexicon Mlapu; for he has explained midoEakN, as on the authority of the Ḳ, by “Instrumentum quo quid defricatur aut levigatur;” a meaning which it may possibly have, as agreeable with analogy, but for which I find no authority.]
xaSomN mudaAEikN (Ḳ) and midoEakN↓ (IDrd, Ḳ) An adversary, or antagonist, vehement in contention, dispute, or litigation. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA.)

1. daEamahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoEamu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. daEomN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He supported it, propped it, or stayed it; (Mgh, Mṣb,) or he set it up; (Ḳ;) namely, a thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or a wall, (Mgh, Mṣb,) that was leaning; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and the trellis of a grape-vine, and the like. (TA.)
And [hence], inf. n. as above, ‡ He strengthened him, and aided him. (TA.)

And [hence also,] daEamahaA ‡ He compressed her (jaAmaEahaA); namely, a woman: (Ḳ, TA:) or this, (Ḳ,) or dEmhA biOayorihi, (TA,) signifies he thrust [his Ayr] into her (Ḳ, TA) with an agitating action: (TA:) or he inserted it entirely: (Ḳ, TA:) and daHamahaA signifies the same: so says ISh. (TA.)

8. Aid-aEama EalayohaA, (Ṣ,* Mgh, Ḳ,* TA,) originally AidotaEama, He supported, propped, or stayed, himself upon it; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) i. e., EalaI EaSFA [upon a staff, or stick]. (TA.) Hence, Aid-aEama EalaI raAHatayohi fiI Als-ujuwdi [He supported himself by resting upon the palms of his hands in prostration]. (Mgh.)
[Hence also,] OanaA Oad-aEimu Ealayohi fiI OumuwriI ‡ [I stay myself upon him in my affairs]. (TA.)

daEomN Strength: (TA:) strength and fatness: (Ṣ, TA:) fat and flesh. (TA.) You say, laA daEoma bifulaAnK There is no strength nor fatness in such a one. (Ṣ, TA.) And jaAirayapN caAtu daEomK A girl, or young woman, having fat and flesh. (TA.)
Also Much wealth or property. (TA.)
diEomapN: see diEaAmapN, in two places.

hom.sense: duEomiI-N A strong thing: (TA:) a thing having a strong support or prop or stay. (Ḳ, TA.)
A carpenter; syn. naj-aArN. (Ḳ.)

A horse having a whiteness in his breast: or, in his lab-ap [app. as meaning the pit above the breast]: and so OadoEamu↓: (Ḳ:) accord. to AA, this latter term is applied when there is a whiteness in a horse's breast; (TA;) and its pl. is duEomN. (TA in art. dgm.)
The main part of a road: or the middle thereof. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: diEaAmN: see diEaAmapN, in two places.
daEaAmapN A condition, term, or stipulation. (Ḳ.)

diEaAmapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and diEaAmN↓ and diEomapN↓ (Ḳ) A support, prop, or stay, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a house or the like, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a leaning wall; (Mgh, Mṣb;) i. e. a piece of wood used as a support, prop, or stay, of a house [&c.]: (TA:) and the wood that is set up for the constructing [or supporting] of the EariyX [or trellis of a grapevine], or for the raising of the shoots of a grapevine: (AḤn, Ḳ:) pl. (of the first and second, TA) daEaAYimu and (of the last, TA) diEamN. (Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence,] OaqaAmN fulaAnN daEaAYima AlUisolaAmi † [Such a one set up the supports of El-Islám]. (TA.) And hecaA mino daEaAYimi AlOumuwri † This is of the things whereby affairs are held together. (TA.)

And [hence,] diEaAmapN signifies also ‡ A lord, or chief. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) One says, huwa diEaAmapu Alqawomi ‡ He is the lord, or chief, of the people, (Mṣb, TA,) and their support, or stay; (TA;) like as one says, huwa diEaAmuhumo↓. (Mṣb.) And humo daEaAYimu qawomihimo ‡ [They are the lords, or chiefs, and the supports, or stays, of their people]. (TA.) ʼOmar Ibn-El-Khattáb was called by ʼOmar Ibn-'AbdEl-'Azeez diEaAmapu AlD-aEiyfi ‡ [The support, or stay, of the weak]. (TA.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or [correctly] diEaAmataAni (Ṣ, TA) and diEomataAni↓, (TA,) The two [upright] pieces of wood of the pulley [that support the cross piece to which the pulley is suspended]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) such as are made of clay are termed zuronuwqaAni. (Ṣ.)
OadoEamu: see duEomiI-N.

madoEuwmN, applied to a leaning house or the like, that is about to crack, or fall down, Supported, or propped: differing from maEomuwdN, which is applied to that which presses heavily, such as a roof; meaning “held [up, or supported,] by columns.” (TA.)
[midoEamN, app., A means of supporting, propping, or staying. See an ex. voce mirojamN.]
mud-aEamN, originally mudotaEamN, A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging; a place of refuge; an asylum. (IAạr, TA.)
Q. 1. daEomaSa It (water) abounded with daEaAmiyS [pl. of duEomuwSN]. (Ḳ.)

duEomuwSN A certain animalcule (duwayob-apN), (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that dives in water: (Ṣ:) or a certain black animalcule that swims upon water: (Mgh:) or a certain worm (duwdapN), that is in pools left by torrents when their water sinks into the earth: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or a certain worm (dwdp) having two heads, seen in water when it becomes little in quantity: (IB:) pl. daEaAmiySu and daEaAmiSu. (Ṣ.)

[Hence, app.,] † One who enters much into affairs; who is a frequent visitor of kings. (Ḳ.) And hence, AlOaTofaAlu daEaAmiySu Aljan-api, meaning † [Infants will be] roamers in Paradise: they will not be debarred from any dwelling: (Ḳ:) a trad.: but the words occurring in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh are SigaArukumo daEaAmiySu Aljan-api [Your little children, &c.]. (TA.)
Also The embryo in the belly of a mare until the fortieth day: then its make becomes apparent, and it is called duwdapN, until three months old: when it is called saliylN. (Kr, TA.)
duEayomiySN [dim. of duEomuwSN].

One says, huwa duEayomiySu hecaA AlOamori, meaning He is acquainted with, or knowing in, this affair. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) duEayomiySu Alr-amoli was the name of a certain cunning, or knowing, or skilful, man; and hence the saying above mentioned: (Ṣ:) he was a black slave, very cunning or knowing or skilful, and an expert guide of the way. (Ḳ.) And [hence] one says, OahodaI mino duEayomiySu Alr-amoli [More expert in showing the way than Do'eymees-er-Raml]. (O, TA.)

1. daEawotu and daEayotu signify the same: (Fr, Ḳ and TA in art. dEI:) the aor. of the former is OadoEuw, (TA in that art.,) sec. pers. fem. sing. tadoEiyna and tadoEuwiyna and tadNEuyona, the last with an inclination to the sound of a ḍammeh in the vowel of the E [so that it is between a kesreh and a ḍammeh], and sec. pers. masc. and fem. pl. tadoEuwna: (Ṣ, TA:) aor. of the latter verb OadoEiI: inf. n. duEaMCN. (TA in art. dEI.) duEaMCN [generally] signifies [or implies] The act of seeking, desiring, asking, or demanding. (KT.)

You say, daEaA Qll-eha, (Ḳ,) first pers. daEawotu, aor. OadoEuw, (Mṣb,) inf. n. duEaMCN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and daEowaI, (Ḳ,) in which latter the alif [written I] is to denote the fem. gender, [and therefore the word is without tenween,] (TA,) He prayed to God, supplicated Him, or petitioned Him humbly, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) desiring to obtain some good that He had to bestow. (Mṣb, TA.) And daEawotu Qll-eha lahu [I prayed to God for him]; and Ealayohi [against him]; inf. n. duEaMCN: (Ṣ:) [and daEawotu lahu I prayed for him, or blessed him; and daEawotu Ealayohi I prayed against him, or cursed him:] and daEawotu lahu bixayorK [I supplicated for him good]; and daEawotu Ealayohi biXar-K [I imprecated upon him evil]. (TA.)
daEaA biAlkitaAbi He desired, or required, or requested, that the writing, or book, should be brought. (TA.) And daEaA Oanofuhu AlT-iyba His nose, perceiving its odour, desired the perfume. (TA.)

[Hence,] daEaA bihi, said of anything in the earth, means It needed it; or required it: [and so daEaA Uilayohi: one says of a wall, daEaA UilaI UiSolaAHihi It needed, or required, its being repaired: (see 10 in art. rm:) and] one says to him whose clothes have become old and worn out, qado daEato viyaAbuka [Thy clothes have become such as to need thy putting on others; or] thou hast become in need of putting on other clothes. (Aboo-ʼAdnán, TA.) [See also 10.]

daEawotuhu, (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Mṣb,) and daEawotu bihi, (MA, [and of frequent occurrence,]) inf. n. [duEaMCN and] daEowN, (TA, [but the former is more common,]) also signify I called him, called out to him, or summoned him, (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Mṣb,) syn. naAdayotuhu, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or Ald-uEaMCu is to the near and Aln-idaMCu is to the distant, (Kull p. 184,) and desired him to come, to come forward, or to advance; (Mṣb;) and AisotadoEayotuhu↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ, MA,) [i. e.] I called him to myself. (MA.) One says, daEaA AlmuWac-inu Aln-aAsa UilaI AlS-alaApi [The mWc-n called the people to prayer]. (Mṣb.) And the saying of En-Nahdee kun-aA nadoEuw wanadaEu means We used to call, or invite, them to El-Islám at one time, and to leave doing so at another time. (Mgh.) And daEawotu Aln-aAsa, (Mṣb,) inf. n. duEaMCN and daEowapN, (Ṣ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and madoEaApN, (Ṣ, [app. there mentioned as an inf. n., agreeably with many other instances,]) means also I invited people to eat with me, or at my abode. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] maA daEaAka UilaI hecaA AlOamori What drew, led, induced, or caused, and constrained, or drove, thee to do this thing? (TA.) And daEaAnaA gayovN waqaEa bibaladK qado OamoraEa, i. e. [Rain that fell in a region which had become abundant in herbage invited us thither, or] was the cause of our seeking its herbage. (TA.) And yadoEuwmaA baEodahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,*) or yadoEuwmaA waraMCahu mina All-abani, (Nh, TA,) [It draws, or attracts, what is to come after it, of the milk,] said of some milk left in the udder. (Ṣ, Nh, Mgh, Ḳ, TA.) And daEaAhu UilaI AlOamiyri He drove him, or urged him to go, [but more commonly meaning he summoned him,] to the prince, or commander. (Ḳ,* TA. [In the TḲ, AlI AlOamori to the thing, or affair.])
[Hence likewise,] Ald-uEaMCu signifies also The calling to one's aid: thus, [in the Ḳur ii. 21,] waQdoEuwA XuhadaMCakumo means And call ye to your aid [your helpers]. (TA.)

And daEaA Almay-ita He called upon the dead, praising him, and saying, Alas for such a one! or he wailed for, wept for, or deplored the loss of, the dead, and enumerated his good qualities and actions; as though he called him. (TA. [See also 5.])
And daEawotuhu zayodFA and bizayodK ‡ I called him, i. e. named him, Zeyd. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) And daEawotuhu biQboni zayodK † I called him, i. e. asserted him to be, the son of Zeyd. (Mṣb.)

daEaAhu Qll-ehu † God destroyed him: [as though He called him away:] whence tadoEuw mano Oadobara watawal-aI, in the Ḳur lxx. 17, [describing the fire of Hell,] † It shall destroy him who shall have gone back from the truth and turned away from obedience: or this means ‡ it shall draw, and bring,, &c.: or it refers to the zabaAniyap of Hell [i. e. the tormentors of the damned]: (Bḍ:) or it means † it will do to them hateful deeds. (TA.) [Also] God punished him, or tormented him. (TA.) And daEaAhu Qll-ehu bimakoruwhK ‡ God caused an evil, or abominable, event to befall him. (ISd, Z, Ḳ.)
daEaA fiI AlD-aroEi ‡ He left some milk, such as is termed daAEiyap, in the udder. (M, Ḳ, TA.) Accord. to IAth, daAEiyapN is an inf. n., like EaAqibapN and EaAfiyapN. (TA.)

3. mudaAEaApN signifies ‡ The proposing an enigma or enigmas to a person; or the contending with another in doing so; syn. muHaAjaApN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say, daAEayotuhu ‡ I proposed to him an enigma or enigmas;, &c. (TA.) A poet says,
OudaAEiyka maA musotaSoHabaAtN maEa Als-uraI
HisaAnN wamaA MvaAruhaA biHisaAni
[† I propose to thee an enigma: What are things that are taken as companions in night-journeying, good, and the effects whereof are not good?]: meaning swords. (Ṣ.)
And The asking a thing of one much, so as to weary; as also muHaAjaApN. (Ḳ.)
daAEayonaA AlHaAYiTa Ealayohimo ‡ We pulled down, or demolished, the wall upon them, from the sides [or foundations] thereof. (Ḳ,* TA.)

[Golius assigns other significations to daAEaI, for which I find no authority: namely, “Convocavit ad Deum propheta, præco sacer,” followed by an accus.: and “Contendit contra alium: Provocavit: pecul. rem vindicans sibi vel arrogans.”]

4. OadoEaAhu [so in some copies of the Ḳ; in other copies Aid-aEaAhu↓; the former of which I regard as the right reading;] He made him to assert his relationship as a son [for yudoEaI, in my copies of the Ḳ, I read yad-aEiI↓, syn. with yaEotaziI,] to one who was not his father. (Ḳ.) [SM, who appears to have read Aid-aEaAhu↓, says that it is like AisotaloHaqahu and AisotalaATahu.]

5. Alt-adaE-iI [inf. n. of tadaE-ato] signifies The taToriyb [or singing, or quavering or trilling and prolonging of the voice, or prolonging and modulating of the voice,] of a woman wailing for the dead. (TA. [See daEaA Almay-ita, above.])

hom.sense:
6. Alt-adaAEiI signifies The calling, summoning, or convoking, one another. (Mgh.) You say, tadaAEawo liloHarobi [They called, summoned, or convoked, one another for war: and hence,] † they prepared themselves for war. (TA.) And tadaAEawoA Ealayohi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or EalaI baniI fulaAnK, (T, M,) They collected themselves together, (Ḳ,) or called one another so that they assembled together, (M,) or leagued together, and called one another to mutual aid, (T, Mṣb,*) against him, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or against the sons of such a one. (T, M.)
And tadaAEaI Ealayohi AlEaduw-u mino kul-i jaAnibK † The enemy advanced against him from every side. (Ḳ,* TA.)

[Hence,] tadaAEati Als-aHaAbapu biAlbaroqi waAlr-aEodi mino kul-i jaAnibK † The cloud lightened and thundered from every quarter. (TA.) And tadaAEaI AlbunoyaAnu, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or AlbinaMCu, (TA,) ‡ The building cracked in its sides, (Mṣb,) or became much broken, (TA,) and gave notice of falling to ruin: (Mṣb, TA:) or cracked in several places, without falling; and in like manner, tadaAEati AlHiyTaAnu, (Mgh,) the walls cracked in several places, without falling: (Mgh, Ḳ:*) and tadaAEati AlHiyTaAnu liloxaraAbi the walls fell to ruin by degrees; syn. tahaAdamat: (Ṣ:) [but Mṭr says,] tadaAEato UilaI AlxaraAbi is a vulgar phrase; not [genuine] Arabic. (Mgh.) And tdAEI said of a sand-hill, † It, being put in notion, or shaken in its lower part, poured down. (Mṣb.) And [hence,] tadaAEato Uibilu baniI fulaAnK ‡ ‡ The camels of such a one became broken by emaciation. (TA.)
tadaAEawo biAlOaloqaAbi They called one another by surnames, or nicknames. (Mṣb.)

Alt-adaAEiI also signifies † The trying one another with an enigma or enigmas; or contending, one with another, in proposing an enigma or enigmas; syn. Alt-aHaAjiI. (TA in art. Hjw.) You say, bayonahumo OudoEiy-apN yatadaAEuwona bihaA † [Between them is an enigma with which they try one another; or by proposing which they contend, one with another]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
yatadaAEawona faSola AlxiTaAbi † They compete, one with another, [as though each one challenged the others,] in discoursing of the science of chasteness of speech, and eloquence. (Ḥar p. 446.)
See also 8, in two places.
[It is also used transitively:] you say, tadaAEawuA Alqawoma They [together] called the people. (Mgh in art. nqD. [See 6 in that art.])

entry.sense: 7. AndEI i. q. OajaAba. (Ḳ.) Akh heard one or more of the Arabs say, lawodaEawonaA laQnodaEayonaA, meaning laOajubonaA [i. e. Had they called us,, &c., we had certainly answered, or replied, or assented, or consented]. (Ṣ.)

8. Aid-aEaI He asserted a thing to be his, or to belong to him, or to be due to him, either truly or falsely: (Ḳ,* TA:) he claimed a thing; laid claim to it; or demanded it for himself: and he desired a thing; or wished for it. (Mṣb.) And Aid-aEawuA AlX-aIoCa and tadaAEawuA↓ AlXIC signify the same [i. e. They claimed the thing, every one of them for himself]. (Mgh.) You say, Aid-aEayotu EalaI fulaAnK kacaA [I asserted myself to have a claim upon such a one for such a thing; preferred a claim against such a one for such a thing; or claimed of such a one such a thing]. (Ṣ.) And Aid-aEaI zayodN EalaI Eamorw maAlFA [Zeyd asserted himself to have a claim upon ʼAmr for property; or preferred a claim against ʼAmr, &c.]. (Mgh.) And Aid-aEayota EalaI-a maA lamo OafoEalo [Thou hast asserted against me, or charged against me, or accused me of, that which I have not done]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. Xrb, and Ṣ in art. Akl.) hecaA Ql-aciI kunotumo bihi tad-aEuwna, in the Ḳur [lxvii. 27], means This is that on account of which ye used to assert vain and false things: or which ye used to deny, or disbelieve: or, accord. to Fr, the latter verb may here be used in the sense of tadoEuwna; and the meaning may be, this is that which ye desired to hasten, and for which ye prayed to God in the words of the Ḳur [viii. 32], “O God, if this be the truth from Thee, then rain Thou upon us stones from Heaven, or bring upon us some [other] painful punishment:” it may be from Ald-uEaMCu: and it may be from Ald-aEowaI: (TA:) [i. e.] it means this is that which ye used to demand, and desire to hasten; from Ald-uEaMCu: or that which ye used to assert, [namely,] that there will be no raising to life; from Ald-aEowaI. (Bḍ.) And walahumo maA yad-aEuwna, in the Ḳur [xxxvi. 57], is explained as meaning And they shall have what they desire, or wish for; which is referrible to the meaning of Ald-uEaMCu. (TA.)

You say also, Aid-aEaI gayora Oabiyhi [He asserted the relationship of father to him of one who was not his father; or claimed as his father one who was not his father]. (T, Mgh, Mṣb.) And yad-aEiI UilaI gayori Oabiyhi [He asserts his relationship as a son, or claims the relationship of a son, to one who is not his father]. (T, Mṣb. See 4, in three places.) And yad-aEiyhi gayoru Oabiyhi [One who is not his father asserts him to be his son; or claims him as his son]. (T, Mṣb.) AlAid-iEaMCu in war signifies The asserting one's relationship; syn. AlAiEotizaMCu; (Ṣ, TA;) as also Alt-adaAEiI↓; (TA;) i. e. the saying “I am such a one the son of such a one.” (Ṣ.) And [hence] sometimes it includes the meaning of Informing, or telling; and therefore bi may be prefixed to its objective complement; so that one says, fulaAnN yad-aEiI bikarami fiEaAlihi, i. e. Such a one informs of the generosity of his deeds. (Mṣb.)
10: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph.
[Hence, AstdEI signifies also It called for, demanded, required, or invited, a thing. See also daEaA bihi.]
daEowapN [as an inf. n. of un.] signifies A single time or act (Ṣ, Mṣb) [of prayer and of imprecation, as is indicated in the Ṣ, and also, though less plainly, in the TA]. See duEaMCN.

[Also, as such, A call.] You say, huwamin-iI daEowapu Alr-ajula (Ḳ, TA) and Alkalobi, and daEowapa Alr-ajuli and Alkalobi, in the former case dEwp being used as a simple subst., and in the latter case as an adv. n., (TA,) meaning qadoru maA bayoniI wabayonahu caAka [i. e. He, or it, is distant from me the space of the call of the man and of the dog]. (Ḳ, TA.) And lahumu Ald-aEowapu EalaI gayorihimo The call is to them before the others of them: (Ḳ, TA: [yabodaOu in the CK is a mistake for yubodaOu:]) accord. to the T and the Nh, in the case of gifts, or pay, or salary. (TA.)

The call to prayer: whence, in a trad., Ald-aEuwapu fiI AlHabaXapi [meaning The office of calling to prayer rests among the Abyssinians]; (JM, TA;) said by the Prophet in preference of his muWac-in Bilál. (JM.)

A call, or an invitation, to El-Islám. (Mgh.) You say, OadoEuwka bidaEowapi AlUisolaAmi and diEaAyapi↓ AlslAm and daAEiyapi↓ AlAslAm, meaning I call thee, or invite thee, by the declaration of the faith whereby the people of false religions are called: daAEiyapN being an inf. n. syn. with daEowapN, like EaAfiyapN and EaAqibapN: (JM:) daEowapu AlUisolaAmi and daEAyatuhu↓ and daAEiyatuhu↓ signify the same: and daEowapu AlHaq-i [in like manner] means the declaration that there is no deity but God. (TA.)

An invitation to food, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and to beverage; or, accord. to Lḥ, specially a repast, feast, or banquet, on the occasion of a wedding or the like: (TA:) thus pronounced by most of the Arabs, except 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, who pronounce it, in this sense, diEowapN↓: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) it is an inf. n. in this sense, (Ṣ,) or a simple subst.: (Mṣb:) and duEowapN↓ signifies the same; (Ḳ;) or, as some say, this, which is given as on the authority of Ḳṭr, is a mistake: (TA:) and so does madoEaApN↓ [app. an inf. n.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, kun-aAfiI daEowapi fulaAnK and madoEaAtihi↓, meaning [We were included in] the invitation (duEaMC [see 1]) of such a one to food: (Ṣ, Mṣb: [but in the latter, naHonu, in the place of kun-aA:]) [or we were at the repast, or feast, or banquet, of such a one; for] you say [also] daEaAhu UilaI Ald-aEowapi and AlI AlmadoEaApi↓ [He invited him to the repast, or feast, or banquet: and in this sense daEowap is commonly used in the present day]. (MA.)
See also diEowapN:
and daEowaI.

Also i. q. HalifN or HalofN (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ) [both in the sense of Confederation to aid or assist]: (Ḳ, TA:) [whence] one says, daEowapN fulaAnK fiI baniI fulaAnK [meaning The confederation of such a one is with the sons of such a one]. (TA.)
duEowapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

diEowapN respects relationship, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) like daEowaI↓ or daEowaI fiI Aln-asabi; (Ṣ;) meaning A claim in respect of relationship; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] one's claiming as his father a person who is not his father; (Az, Mgh, Mṣb;) [in other words,] one's claiming the relationship of a son to a person who is not his father: or one's being claimed as a son by a person who is not his father: (Az, Mṣb:) thus pronounced by most of the Arabs, except 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, who pronounce it, in this sense, daEowapN↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) See also daEowaI.
Also Kindred, or relationship, and brotherhood: so in the saying, liI fiI Alqawomi diEowapN [I have in, or among, the people, or company of men, kindred, or relationship, and brotherhood]. (Ks, Mṣb.)
See also daEowapN.
daEowaI: see duEaMCN, in five places.

Also a subst. from 8; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) omitted in the Ḳ, though better known than the sun; (TA;) and so daEaAwapN↓ (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and diEaAwapN↓ and diEowapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to the general pronunciation, (M, TA,) and daEowapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to the pronunciation of 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, (M, TA,) and daAEiyapN↓; (TA, there said to be syn. with daEowaI;) [meaning An assertion that a thing belongs to one, or is due to one; a claim; as is indicated in the Ṣ and Mgh and Ḳ, &c.;] a demand; a suit; (Yz, Az, Mṣb;) whether true or false: (Mgh, Ḳ, TA:)
the pl. of daEowaI is daEaAwK and daEaAwaI; the former of which is preferable accord. to some, being, as IJ says, the original form; but some say that the latter is preferable: (Mṣb:) [the latter only is mentioned in the Mgh:] the alif in the sing. [written I] is a sign of the fem. gender; and therefore the word is without tenween. (Mgh.) Yz mentions the sayings, liI fiI hecaA AlOamori daEowaI I have, in respect of this thing, [a claim or] a demand, and daEaAwaI or daEaAwK [claims or] demands, as written in different copies. (Az, Mṣb.) And lawo OuEoTiIa Aln-aAsu bidaEaAwiyhimo [If men were given according to their claims, or demands,] occurs in a trad. (Mṣb.)
See also diEowapN.

duEowiI-N is a word used only in negative sentences: (Ṣ:) you say, maA biAld-aAri duEowiI-N There is not in the house any one: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) Ks says that it is from daEawotu, and [properly] means layosa fiyhaA mano yadoEuw [there is not in it one who calls,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

duEaMCN is an inf. n. of 1; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also daEowaI↓: (Ḳ:) the former is originally duEaAwN: (Ṣ:) [both, used as simple substs., signify A prayer, or supplication, to God:] and the pl. of the former is OadoEiyapN. (Ṣ.) IF says that some of the Arabs, for daEowapN↓, say daEowaI↓, with the fem. alif [written I]. (Mṣb, TA.) One says, Aall-ehum-a OaXorikonaA fiI daEowaI↓ Almusolimiyna, meaning [O God, make us to share] in the prayer (duEaMC) of the Muslims. (TA.) And hence, in the Ḳur [x. 10], daEowaAhumo↓ fiyhaA suboHaAnak Qll-ehum-a [Their prayer in it shall be sbHAnk Qll-ehm-]. (TA.) [duEaMCN followed by li signifies An invocation of good, a blessing, or a benediction: followed by EalaI, an imprecation of evil, a curse, or a malediction.] suwrahu Ald-uEaMCi is a title of The first chapter of the Ḳur-án. (Bḍ.)
[Hence,] duEaMCN signifies also Adoration, worship, or religious service. (TA.)
And i. q. UiymaAnN [i. e. Belief; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles, &c.: faith:, &c.]: a meaning mentioned by the Expositors of El-Bukháree. (TA.)
[Also A call, or cry; and so daEowaI↓, as in the Ḳur vii. 4 (where the latter is explained by Bḍ as syn. with the former) and xxi. 15.]
And [particularly] A calling, or crying, for aid or succour. (TA.)
daEiI-N One invited to a repast: pl. duEawaMCu; as in the saying Einodahu duEawaMCu [With him, or at his abode, are guests invited to a repast]. (TA.)

One who makes a claim in respect of relationship; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] one who claims as his father a person who is not his father; (Az, Mgh, Mṣb;) [in other words,] one who claims the relationship of a son to a person who is not his father: or one who is claimed as a son by a person who is not his father; (Az, Mṣb;) an adopted son: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OadoYiyaMCu, (Ṣ,) which is anomalous; (Bḍ in xxxiii. 4;) occurring in the Ḳur [in the verse just referred to], where it is said, wamaAjaEala OadoYiyaACakumo OabonaMCakumo (Ṣ) Nor hath He made your adopted sons to be your sons in reality. (Jel.)
And One whose origin, or lineage, or parentage, is suspected; (Ḳ, TA;) as also madoEiI-N↓: pl. of the former as in the next preceding sentence. (TA.)
daEaAwapN and diEaAwapN: see daEowaI.
diEaAyapN: see daEowapN, in two places.
daE-aMCN One who prays, or supplicates God, or who calls,, &c., much, or often. (TA.)
Ald-aE-aMCapu [an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates;] The sab-aAbap [or fore finger]; (Ḳ;) i. e. the finger with which one calls [or beckons]. (TA.)

daAEK [Praying, or supplicating God:] calling, or summoning: (Mgh:) [inviting:] and particularly, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] one who calls, or summons, or invites, to obey a right or a wrong religion: (TA:) pl. duEaApN (Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and daAEuwna. (Mṣb, TA.) [Hence,] daAEiI Qll-ehi [God's summoner, or inviter; i. e.] the prophet: (Ḳ:) and also, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or simply Ald-aAEiI, (TA,) The muWac-in [or summoner to prayer]. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) [Hence also, daAEiI AlmanaAyaA The summoner of death, lit. of deaths; like TaAriqu AlmanaAyaA]
See also the next paragraph, in two places.
Also A punisher. (TA.)
daAEiyapN: see daEowapN, in two places:
and see also daEowaI.

daAEiy-apN All-abani The remainder of the milk, (Ḳ,) or what is left, of the milk, in the udder, (Ṣ, Mgh,) that draws, or attracts, (Ḳ,) or in order that it may draw, or attract, (Ṣ, Mgh,) what is to come after it; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;*) as also daAEiI↓ All-abani, occurring in a trad., where it is said, daEo daAEiIa All-abani [Leave thou the remainder of the milk, in the udder, that is to draw, or attract, what is to come after it]; (Ṣ, Mgh;) i. e. do not exhaust it entirely. (Mgh.)

Hence, daAEiyapN is metaphorically applied to signify ‡ A mean, or means; a cause; or a motive; (Ḥar p. 306;) [as also daAEK↓, often used in these senses in the present day;] and so, in an intensive sense, madoEaApN↓ [properly signifying a cause of drawing, attracting, or inducing,, &c., originally madoEawapN, being a noun of the same class as maboxalapN and majobanapN]: (Idem p. 86:) [the pl. of the first is dawaAEK.]
Also † The cry of horsemen in battle; (Ḳ;) as being a call to him who will aid, or succour. (TA.)
dawaAEiI AlS-adori † The anxiety [or rather anxieties] of the bosom. (Ḥam p. 509.)
dawaAEiI Ald-ahori ‡ The vicissitudes of fortune: (Ḳ, TA:) sing. daAEiyapN. (TA.)
OudoEuw-apN: see what next follows.

OudoEiy-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OudoEuw-apN↓ (Ḳ) An enigma; a riddle; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) like OuHojiy-apN [and OuHojuw-apN]; and including such as is in verse, like that quoted above, in the second paragraph of this article. (Ṣ.)
madoEaApN: see daEowapN, latter part, in three places:
and see also daAEiyapN: [pl. madaAEK.]
[Hence the saying,] lahu masaAEK wamadaAEK, i. e. ‡ [He possesses means of attaining honour and elevation, and] causes of glorying, or memorable and generous qualities, especially in war. (TA.)
[madoEuw-N pass. part. n. of 1; as also madoEiI-N↓.]
madoEiI-N: see what next precedes:
and see also daEiI-N, last sentence.
mud-aEFI Claimed property [&c.]: mud-aEFI bihi is nought. (Mgh.)
mud-aEFI Ealayohi One upon whom a claim is made for property [&c.]. (Mgh.) [A defendant in a law-suit.]
mud-aEK Claiming property [&c.]; a claimant. (Mgh.) [A plaintiff in a law-suit.]
1. daEayotu, aor. OadoEiI, inf. n. duEaMCN: see 1 in art. dEw.
daEiI-N:, &c.: see art. dEw.

hom.sense: 1. dagara, aor. _a {yadogaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dagorN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He pushed, thrust, drove, impelled, or repelled. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) This is the primary signification. (Ṣ, A.)
dagarahu, aor. as above, He pressed him, or squeezed him, until he died. (Ḳ.)

dagarato Haloqa AlS-abiI-, (TḲ,) aor. _a {yadogaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dagorN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) She pressed the throat, or fauces, of the child, (Ḳ,* TA,) on account of the pain termed AlEucorapu, (Ṣ,* TA,) and (or that is to say, TA) raised his uvula with her finger, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) compressing that part on the occasion of the pain's being excited by the blood. (AʼObeyd, TA.) So in the trad., EalaAma tuEac-ibona OawolaAdakun-a biAld-agori Wherefore do ye torment your children by raising the uvula, &c.: (Ṣ:) and laA tuEac-ibona OawolaAdakun-a biAld-agori Torment ye not your children by pressing the throat, or fauces, &c. (AʼObeyd, TA.)

And dagarato waladahaA, (TḲ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) She fed her child ill: and she suckled him without satisfying him, (Ḳ,) so that he remained hungry, and applied himself to every one he met, and ate and sucked, and would suck the dug of a ewe or goat: and the like is said of a she-camel with respect to her young one, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed Es-Sukkaree, who thus explains the latter of the two traditions quoted above; but Az says that the right explanation is that given by AʼObeyd, as is shown in the traditions [elsewhere]. (TA.)
dagara AlX-aIoCa biAlX-aIoCi, (TḲ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He mixed the thing with the thing. (Ḳ,* TḲ.)

dagara Ealayohi, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadogaru}, (TA,) inf. n. dagorN, (Ḳ,) and dagoraI↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (TA,) He rushed upon him without consideration; (Ḳ, TA;) he charged upon him. (TA.) Hence the saying, dagoraI↓ laA Saf-aI, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,*) and dagaraI↓, and dagoraMCa↓, (Ḳ,) and dagorFA laA Saf-FA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like EaqoraI waHaloqaI, and EaqorFA waHaloqFA, (Ṣ,)
i. e., Rush ye upon them without consideration, and oppose them not in regular ranks: (Ṣ,* A,* Ḳ,* TA:) or mix ye among them, &c. (Kr.) A woman is related to have said to her son, UicaA raOati AlEayonu AlEayona fadagoraI↓ walaA Saf-aI When the eye sees the eye, [or when eye meets eye in war,] then rush thou, &c. (TA.)
dagara fiI Albayoti He entered the house: (Ḳ:) as though he thrust himself in. (TA.)

entry.sense: Aid-agara: see 8 in art. vgr.

dagorN (TA) and dagorapN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) The act of snatching a thing unawares; seizing it hastily when its owner is unawares: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or the springing, or rushing, upon a commodity, to snatch it unawares: or the filling one's hand with a thing and carrying it off. (TA.) Hence the trad. (Ṣ, A) of ʼAlee, (TA,) laAqaToEa fiI Ald-agorapi↓ [There shall be no amputation of the hand for snatching a thing unawares:, &c.]. (Ṣ, A, TA.)
dagorapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
dagoraI and dagaraI and dagoraMC: see 1; the first, in three places.
madogarapN A fierce war, in which the word is dagoraI, (Ḳ,) or dagorFA. (TA.)

hom.sense: daAgiSapN [The patella, or knee-pan;] the round bone which moves about in the head of the knee; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or which turns aside and moves about above the raDof of the knee [which are said to be certain bones in the knee, like fingers put together, holding together one another]: (TA:) or the bone in the inside of the knee, on the right and left of which are the ligaments (AlEaSab [app. meaning the internal and external lateral ligaments of the knee-joint, between which is the patella]): (IDrd, TA:) or a bone having at its extremity (fiI Tarafihi [perhaps a mistake for fiI Tarafayohi at its two extremities]) two ligaments (EaSabataAni [app. the tendon of the extensor muscles of the leg and the ligamentum patellæ]), at the head of the waAbilap [a bone in the knee-joint]: (TA:) it is a subst., like kaAhilN and gaAribN: (TA:) also [explained as signifying] the piece, or portion, of fat beneath the skin that is above the knee: or, as some say, the ligament (EaSabap) [in that part]. (TA.)
Also Compact flesh: pl. dawaAgiSu. (TA.) You say of a man whose flesh is compact, kaOan-ahu daAgiSapN [As though he were a dAgSp]. (TA.)
Also Clear, shallow, water: (IDrd, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
dagofalN The young one of an elephant: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of a wolf. (Ḳ.)

EayoXN dagofalN An ample, or easy, and a plentiful, life; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) [as also dagofaliI-N↓.] A poet says,
wafaAraqa minohaAEiyXapN dagofaliy-apN↓
walamo taxoXa yawomFA yazuwla sariyruhAa
[And an ample, or a plentiful, state of life, that was hers, passed away: and she feared not one day that her ease, or affluence, would depart]. (Ṣ in art. sr.)

You say also EaAmN dagofalN A plentiful, or fruitful, year: so says IAạr: and he cites the saying of El-ʼAjjáj,
waUico zamaAnu Aln-aAsi dagofaliI-N↓
[And when the time of men, or of the people, is, or was, plentiful, or fruitful]. (Ṣ.)
And riyXN dagofalN Abundant feathers or plumage. (Ḳ.)

1. dagala fiyhi, aor. _a {yadogalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dagolN, (TA,) He entered it like as enters he who is doing a thing that induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; (Ḳ, TA;) like as the hunter enters the lurkingplace to circumvent the game: so in the T and M. (TA.)
dagala lahumu AlX-ar-a He sought, or desired, to do to them evil, or mischief, when they thought that he desired to do them good. (T, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Adgl He (a man, TA) disappeared in a dagal [or place in which one fears being taken unawares]. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Adgl bihi He acted treacherously towards him, and took him unawares. (Ḳ.)
He slandered him, or calumniated him. (Ḳ.)
Adgl fiI AlOamori He introduced into the affair what rendered it unsound, or corrupt, (Ḳ,) or what contravened it, (JK, Ṣ, M, O,) and rendered it unsound, or corrupt. (Ṣ, M, O.)
Adglt AlOaroDu The land became abundant [and dense (as is implied in the Ṣ)] in trees. (Ṣ, TA.)
dagolN: see dagilN.

dagalN Badness, corruptness, or unsoundness; or a bad, a corrupt, or an unsound, state or quality; (Ṣ, and Mgh in art. ngl;) [in an affair, &c.;] like daxalN; (Ṣ;) and a thing that induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; [in an affair; or] in a man: (Mgh ubi suprà:) or a cause of badness, corruption, or unsoundness, in an affair. (JK, T, Ḳ, TA.) Hence the saying of El-Ḥasan, Ait-axuwA kitaAba Qll-ehi dagalFA [They made the Book of God to be a cause of corruption: or perhaps they made the Book of God corrupt; i. e. they corrupted it]. (TA.)

Confusedness, or entanglement, and abundance, of plants or herbage; (M, Ḳ;) most commonly known in plants of the kind termed HamoD, when amid gryl [i. e. giroyal, app. here meaning silt, or alluvial deposit, left upon the ground by a torrent]. (M, TA.)
Tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also daxalN. (TA.)

Any place in which a wile, machination, or plot, is practised; (JK;) a place in which one fears being taken unawares: (Ḳ:) and dagiylapN↓ signifies the same as dagalN [app. meaning such a place as is here described]: (JK, Ḳ:) the pl. of the former is OadogaAlN [a pl. of pauc.] and digaAlN. (Ḳ.)

Accord. to En-Naḍr, An elevated [tract of ground such as is termed] quf-: and i. q. OakamapN [a hill, or mound,, &c.]: and a valley: and a level, or smooth, wide, depressed tract of land: and OadogaAlN signifies mountains: and OadogaAlu AlOaroDi, [tracts of] land from which water has sunk into the earth, or receded: and low, or depressed, tracts of land: and level, or smooth, tracts thereof. (TA.)
dagilN, applied to a man, In whom is a bad, a corrupt, or an unsound, quality, and what induces doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; as also dagolN↓, a contraction of the former. (Mgh in art. ngl.)
Applied to a place, as also mudogilN↓, i. q. cuw dagalK [app. as meaning Having tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees]: or obscure, or concealed; (Ḳ;) as also daAgilN↓. (TA.)
dagiylapN: see dagalN.
