dagaAwilu Calamities, or misfortunes: (AʼObeyd, JK, T, Ḳ:) erroneously written by J dawaAgil, (Ḳ,) and so by IF in the Mj, (TA,) as on the authority of AʼObeyd, who said only dagaAwil, (Ḳ,) and thus it is in a verse of Sakhr El-Hudhalee: (TA:) [but in one of my copies of the Ṣ it is written dagaAwil:] it has no sing.: (Ḳ:) or, as El-Bekree says, its sing. is not known: but some say that it is dgwlp [thus without any syll. signs]. (TA.)
daAgilN One who seeks, or desires, to do evil, or mischief, to his companions, when they think that he desires to do them good. (T, TA. [See the next paragraph.])
See also dagilN.

hom.sense: daAgilapN Concealed rancour, malevolence; malice, or spite. (M, Ḳ.)
Persons who seek to blame one, or to find fault with one, and to act treacherously towards one. (M, Ḳ. [See daAgilN.])

entry.sense: mudogilN: see dagilN.
madaAgilu The bottoms, or interior parts, of valleys; (M, Ḳ;) and the level, or smooth, tracts thereof, when their trees are numerous. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. dagama, aor. _a {yadogamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dagomN, (JK, Ṣ,) He, or it, broke the nose, making the breach to extend into the interior. (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ. [So too accord. to the explanation of the inf. n. in the KL; though Golius renders it, and app. dag-ama also, as on the authority of the KL, “depressit nasum;” while Freytag follows him in thus rendering only the latter verb; which I do not find in any Lexicon.])
Also, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (M, TA,) He covered a vessel. (M, Ḳ.)
And, said of rain, It covered, or overwhelmed, and prevailed over, or subdued, the earth, or land; as also Adgm↓. (TA.)

[The inf. n.] dagomFA is also used, (Ḳ, TA,) in a form of imprecation, (TA,) as an imitative sequent to ragomFA [q. v.], and is in like manner followed by sin-agomFA, (Ḳ, TA,) or Xin-agomFA. (TA.) And one says, faEalotu celika EalaI ragomihi wadagomihi waXin-agomihi [meaning I did that in spite of him; or against his will]. (TA.)
4: see above {1}, in two places.
Adgm Alfarasa All-ijaAma He put the bit into the mouth of the horse; (JK, Az, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Adgm All-ijaAma fiI fami Alfarasi. (TA.)

And hence, (Az, Ṣ, TA,) though some say that the reverse is the case, (TA,) Adgm AlHarofa (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ) fiI AlHarofi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UidogaAmN, (JK, Ṣ,) He inserted [or incorporated] the letter into the letter; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) as also Aid-agamahu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [which is itself an example of the incorporation of one letter into another, being] originally Aidotagamahu. (Ṣ, TA.)

Adgmhu, said of God, He blackened his face: (Ḳ:) and i. q. Oarogamahu; (Ḳ,* TA;) both signify ‡ He did evil to him, and angered him: or the former verb has the former of these significations, explained in the Ḳ; and the latter verb signifies, with its pronoun, “he angered him.” (TA.)
Adgmhu UilaI kacaA He, or it, caused him to want such a thing; (AA, TA in art. dmg;) [and] so Adgmhu likacaA; (L in art. jld;) as also Admghu. (AA, L in art. jld voce Oajolada, and TA in art. dmg.)

Adgm fulaAnN Such a one vied, or strove, with the people, or party, in hastening [to eat], fearing lest they should be before him, and therefore ate the food without chewing. (Ḳ,* TA.) [And Oadomaga TaEaAmahu, as explained in the TA in art. dmg, has a similar meaning.]

entry.sense: 8: see the next preceding paragraph {4}.

11. AdgAm-, inf. n. AidogiymaAmN, said of a horse, He was of a colour inclining to blackness in his face and lips, [or in his face and the part next the lips,] blacker therein than in the other parts of his body. (Ḳ.)

dagamN and dugomapN↓, in a horse, [and in some other animals, (see Oadogamu,)] A colour inclining to blackness, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the face and the part next the lips, (Ṣ,) or in the face and the lips, (Ḳ,) differing from, (Ṣ,) or blacker than, (Ḳ,) the colour of the other parts of the body. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
dugomapN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: dugomaAnN, with damm, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to a man, (Ṣ,) Black: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or black and big. (Ḳ.)
Also a pl. of Oadogamu [q. v.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: dugaAmN A pain in the fauces. (Ḳ.)
daAgimN an imitative sequent to raAgimN. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Oadogamu A horse of a colour inclining to blackness, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a black colour, (Mgh,) in the face and the part next the lips, (Ṣ,) or in the face and the lips, (Ḳ,) or in the face and the muzzle, (Mgh,) differing from, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or blacker than, (Ḳ,) the colour of the other parts of the body; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) called in Pers. dayozaj [or rather diyzaho, from which dayozajN is arabicized]; (AO,* Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) in some instances, without any admixture of xuDorap [here meaning dark, or ashy, dust-colour]: (AO, TA:) it is also applied as an epithet to a wolf: and the fem. is dagomaMCu: and the pl. is dugomN: (Ṣ:) the masc. is also applied to a ram, meaning having any, the least, blackness; especially in the end of the nose and beneath the chin: and the fem. to a ewe, meaning black in the end of the nose and in the chin; (TA;) or, thus applied, black in the face: (JK:) and the masc. also signifies black in the nose: (JK, Ḳ:) in which sense it has for its pl. dugomaAnN: (TA:) accord. to the Ḳ [and the JK], dugomN, a pl. of Oadogamu, signifies white; as though it had two contr. meanings; but this is a mistranscription for duEomN, with the unpointed E. (TA.) It is said in a prov., Alc-Yobu Oadogamu [The wolf is blackish in the face and in the part next the lips, not being so in the other parts; or rather, is black in the nose]: for, whether he lap from a vessel or not, dugomap is a necessary characteristic of the wolf, [all] wolves being dugom; and therefore he is sometimes, or often, suspected of having lapped from a vessel when he is [really] hungry: the prov. is applied to him who is regarded with a wish for the like of that which he has not obtained. (Ṣ.)
Also One who snuffles; i. e., speaks from [i. e. through] his nose; (JK, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. i. q. Oaxan-u. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. daf-a, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _i {yadofifu}, (T, M, TA,) or _u (Mṣb, [but this is a deviation from a general rule, and is probably a mistake,]) inf. n. dafiyfN (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb) and daf-N; (M, TA;) and Adf-↓; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said of a bird, (Lth, T, Ṣ, &c.,) It beat its sides (daf-ayohi, i. e., Mṣb, janobayohi, M, Mṣb) with its wings: (M, Mṣb:) this is what is meant by the following explanation: (Mṣb:) it moved [or flapped] its wings (Mṣb, Ḳ) for its flight, (Mṣb,) as the pigeon (Ḳ) and the like: (TA:) and it went [or flew] along a little above the ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it moved [or flapped] its wings, with its feet upon the ground, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ,) flying, and then rose; (Lth, T;) and in like manner dafodafa↓ and Astdf-↓: (Ḳ:) [or] df- and Adf-↓ signify also it (a bird) went along quickly, with its feet upon the ground, and then raised itself flying. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., yuWokalu maA daf-a walaA uWokalu maA Saf-a, (Ḳ,* TA,) i. e. What moves [or flaps] its wings [in flying], as the pigeon (Ḳ, TA) and the like, (TA,) may be eaten; but [what skims along without flapping,] such as vultures (Ḳ, TA) and hawks and the like, (TA,) may not be eaten. (Ḳ,* TA.) [But] daf-a,, aor. _i {yadofifu}, said of an eagle, signifies It approached, or was near to, the ground in its flying. (T.)

And, daf-a, aor. _i {yadofifu}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. dafiyfN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and daf-N, (Ḳ,) He, or it, (said of a camel, Ḳ, TA, and of a bird, TA, or of a party of men, Mṣb,) went a gentle pace; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also dafodafa↓. (IAạr, TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh uses it metaphorically in relation to Ald-abaraAni [the asterism of the Hyades, or α of Taurus], describing Alv-uray-aA [the Pleiades]; saying,
yadif-u EalaI MvaArihaA dabaraAnuhaA
falaA huwa masobuwqN walaA huwa yaloHaqu
[Their Debarán goes along gently near after them, so that it is not outstripped, nor does it overtake]. (M.) [And tadaAf-a↓, accord. to ISd, seems to signify nearly the same: for it is immediately added in the M,] in the saying,
Uilayoka OaXokuw maXoyahaA tadaAfiyaA
maXoIa AlEajuwzi tanoqulu AlOavaAfiyaA [app. complaining, to God, of the slowness of his she-camel, as though meaning To Thee I complain of her pressing on slowly and laboriously, like the gait of the old woman removing the three stones for the support of the cooking-pot], the poet means tadaAfufFA. (M. [But I rather think that the meaning here intended is, going along with an inclining from side to side; perhaps from daf-N signifying the “side.” See also 6 in art. dfw.]) One says also, AljayoXu yadif-uwna naHowa AlEaduw-i The troops go gently, or leisurely, towards the enemy. (Ṣ.) And daf-ato EalayonaA mino baniI fulaAnKdaAf-apN↓ [A company coming gently, or leisurely, of the sons of such a one, so came to us]. (Ṣ.) And daf-ato Ealayohimo daAf-apN↓ mina AlOaEoraAbi A company of Arabs of the desert journeying leisurely in search of herbage and sustenance [so] came to them. (Z, TA.) And humo qawomN yadif-uwna, inf. n. dafiyfN, They are a party journeying together not a hard pace. (AA, T.) And daf-a EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi (IAạr, T, TA,) inf. n. daf-N, (Ḳ, TA,) He went lightly upon the ground; (Ḳ,* TA;) and caf-a signifies the same. (IAạr, T.) And dafiyfN also signifies The act of running. (T.)
Also daf-uwA, aor. _i {yadofifu}, [app. They journeyed to a region of green herbage and waters in consequence of drought: (see daAf-apN:) and hence,] they had rain after experiencing drought. (M.)
See also 10, in two places.
See also 3.
daf-a AlX-aIoCa, aor. _u {yadofufu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. daf-N, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) He uprooted the thing; extirpated it. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
2. df-f, inf. n. tadofiyfN, He hastened, sped, or went quickly; (Ḳ;) as also dafodafa↓. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
See also 3, in two places.

entry.sense:
3. dAf-hu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and dAf- Ealayohi, (TA,) inf. n. mudaAf-apN and difaAfN; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) as also daAfaAhu, which is of the dial. of Juheyneh, (T, M,) altered from the former, (M,) and cAf-hu; (Mṣb, TA;) and df-fhu↓, (Ḳ,) or df-f↓ Ealayohi, (M, Mṣb, TA,)
inf. n. tadofiyfN; (Mṣb;) as also cf-f Elyh; (T, M;) and daf-↓ Ealayohi, aor. _u {yadofufu}, [or, accord. to rule, _i]; (Mṣb;) [as also caf-a Elyh;] namely, a man, (Ṣ,) a captive, (T, Ṣ,) or a wounded man, (M,) He despatched him; i. e. hastened and completed his slaughter; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or wounded him so as to hasten his death. (Mṣb.)
4. Adf-: see 1, first sentence, in two places.
Oadaf-to Eayohi AlOumuwru The events came upon him consecutively, or uninterruptedly. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
6. tdAf- Alqawomu The party, or company of men, bore, or pressed, or crowded, one upon another. (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.*)
See also 1.
10. Astdf-: see 1, first sentence.

Also It (a thing, M) was, or became, prepared, (AZ, T, M,) within one's power or reach, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and easy; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like AstTf-, the d being substituted for T; (Ṣ;) [as also Astcf-;] and so daf-a↓, (T, M,) aor. _i {yadofifu}; (M;) [as also caf-a.] You say, xuco aA Qsotadaf-a laka, (AZ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mA daf-a↓ lk, (AZ, T,) Take thou what is prepared for thee; (AZ, T;) what is within thy power or reach, and easy to thee. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And It (an affair, or a thing,) was, or became, rightly disposed or arranged; in a right state; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or complete, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and in a right state: (Ṣ:) and Astcf- signifies the same. (IḲṭṭ, IB, TA.)
Astdf- biAlmuwsaI ‡ He shaved his pubes with the razor, (Ḳ,* TA,) and did so utterly; occurring in this sense in a trad. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. dafodafa: see 1, in two places:
and see also 2.
[The inf. n.] dafodafapN signifies [also] The beating a duf- [or tambourine] hastily [or quickly]. (M, TA.)

daf-N The side, syn. janobN, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of anything, (Lth, T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) for instance, of a bird, (Mṣb,) and of a camel; (Ṣ;) as also daf-apN↓: (Lth, T, Mgh, Mṣb:) or the surface (SafoHap) of the side; (M, Ḳ;) as also daf-apN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. dufuwfN. (T, M, Mṣb.) Hence,
OaSobaru mino EawodK bidaf-ayohi julabo
[More enduring than an old camel in whose sides are scabs formed over wounds: a prov.]. (TA. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 737.]) And baAta yaq-alabu EalaI daf-atayohi↓ [and daf-yohi, i. e. He passed the night turning over and over upon his sides]. (TA.) The saying of' Antarah, describing his she-camel,
wakaOan-amaA tanoOaI bijaAnibi daf-ihaA
QlowaHoXiI-i mino haziji AlEaXiI-i muWaw-ami
means And as though she were shrinking from the quarter of her off side, bi being here used in the sense of Eano, from a creature that cries for food at supper-time; meaning a cat, of ugly form and big head, fearing to be scratched by it: as J says, [in art. wHX,] she shrinks with her off side because the rider's whip is in his right hand: (EM p. 233:) [or the meaning is, as though she were shrinking with the outside of her off side; lit, with the side of her off side; for, accord. to ISd,] this is an instance of the prefixing of a noun to another identical therewith [in signification]. (M.) [Hence also,] ramaAhu Qll-ehu bicaAti Ald-af-i i. e. cAt Aljanobi [May God smite him with the pleurisy] (TA.)

Also A bank; an acclivity; or a part that faces one, above the foot or base; of sand; and of land or ground: (Ḳ:) accord. to En-Naḍr, [the pl.] dufuwfN signifies banks; acclivities; or parts that face one, above the foot or base; of land or ground; (T, TA;) as also dafaAdifu, of which the sing. is dafodafapN↓: (T, Ḳ:) accord. to Z, the dufuwf of valleys are the elevated parts of the sides. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
And daf-apN.

duf-N and daf-N↓, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former the more approved, (Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by AʼObeyd, (Ṣ,) [and now the more common, A tambourine;] a certain thing with which one beats, (M, Ḳ,) or with which women beat, (Ṣ,) or with which one plays; (Mgh, Mṣb;) of two kinds; round; [such as is figured, under the name of “tár” (TAr), in chap. xviii. of my work on the Modern Egyptians, with several pairs of tinkling plates of brass in apertures in the hoop, and sometimes, as in the kind used by hired wailing-women, without those tinkling plates;] and four-sided: [the latter seems to be only for amusement; for] it is said that the foursided is unlawful; but there is no harm in selling the round: (Mgh:) pl. dufuwfN. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
daf-apN: see daf-N, in three places.

[Hence,] daf-ataA Als-aroji † [The two side-boards of the horse's saddle;] the two boards that lie against the two sides of the beast; (Mgh;) or the two sides [or boards] of the horse's saddle, that embrace it between them: [see qarabuwsN:] and so daf-ataA Alr-aHoli † the two sides, &c. of the camel's saddle. (M.) And in like manner, (M,) dafUataA AlmuSoHafi ‡ The two sides [or boards] of the book; (M, TA;) the two things that embrace the book between them; (T, M, Mgh, Ḳ,* TA;) the two faces, that are on the two sides, of the book. (Mṣb.) One says, HafiZa maA bayona Ald-af-atayoni ‡ [He retained in his memory, or got by heart, what is between the two boards, meaning the whole contents, of the book]. (TA.) [daf-apN signifies also † A board in a general sense; and so daf-N↓. And hence, † A rudder.] And daf-apu AlT-aboli † The thing [or piece of skin] that is upon the head of the drum: (so in a copy of the M:) or daf-ataA AlT-aboli ‡ the two things, (T, Ḳ,) i. e. the two pieces of skin, (TA,) that are upon the head [or rather upon the two extremities] of the [common cylindrical] drum. (T, Ḳ, TA.) One says, Daraba daf-atiI AlT-aboli ‡ [He beat the two skins of the drum]. (TA.)
dafuwfN An eagle approaching the ground (Ṣ, Ḳ) in its flight (Ṣ) when making a stoop: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or flying swiftly. (Skr, TA.)
dufuwfiI-N [rel. n. from dufuwfN pl. of duf-N and daf-N; app. meaning A seller, or, like mudaf-ifN, a maker, of tambourines]. (Ḳ: there mentioned as an appellation of a certain man.)

hom.sense: daf-aAfN An owner of tambourines (dufuwf). (M, TA.) [And] A beater of the tambourine (duf-); (MA;) [and] so mudafodifN↓. (M.)
daf-aAfapN: see daAf-N.
dafodafapN: see daf-N, near the end of the paragraph.
[It is also the inf. n. of R. Q. 1, q. v.]

entry.sense: daAf-N [originally daAfifN, act. part. n. of daf-a, q. v.,] is opposed to SaAf-N, which signifies “spreading its wings and not moving [or flapping] them” [in its flight]. (M, TA.) A rájiz, (M,) Ru-beh, (T,) [for the sake of rhyme], uses daAfiI for daAfifu. (T, M.)

jamaAEapN daAf-apN A company of men going a gentle pace: (Mṣb:) and daAf-apN [alone] a party journeying together not a hard pace: (AA, T:) an army going gently, or leisurely, towards the enemy: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) a company of men coming from one country or town to another: (IDrd, M:) a party going to a great town or city: (TA:) a company of men journeying leisurely (yadif-uwna) in search of herbage and sustenance: (Z, TA:) a party of the people of the desert journeying to a region of green herbage and waters in consequence of drought: and [hence] a party having rain after experiencing drought; as also daf-aAfapN↓. (M.) See 1, in two places.

hom.sense: mudaf-ifN A maker of dufuwf [or tambourines]. (M. [See also dufuwfiI-N.])
sanaAmN mudaf-ifN A camel's hump that falls [or hangs] down upon his sides. (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mudafodifN: see daf-aAfN.

hom.sense:
1. dafiYa, aor. _a {yadofaOu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dafaON, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA,) like ZamaON inf. n. of ZamiYa, and dafaMCapN, like karaAhapN inf. n. of kariha, (Ṣ,) said of a man, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He was, or became, warm, or hot: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:*) [generally meaning the former: see difoCN, below:] or he experienced [warmth, or] heat: (Ḥar p. 295:) or he wore what rendered him warm, or hot: (Mṣb:) and dafiYa mina Albarodi [he wore warm clothing to protect himself from the cold]: (Mgh:) and tdf-O↓ (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ) biAlv-awobi, (Ṣ, Mgh,) and AstdfO↓ (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ) bAlvwb, (Ṣ, Mgh,) and Aid-afaOa↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) bAlvwb, the last of these verbs [originally AidotafaOa,] of the measure AifotaEala, (Ṣ,) [He warmed himself with the garment,] are said of him who has clad himself with that which renders him warm, or hot: (Ṣ:) or the meaning [of AstdfO bAlvwb] is he desired warmth, or heat, by means of the garment: (Mgh:) and Aid-afayotu and Aisotadofayotu occur, for Ad-fOt and AstdfOt, as meaning I wore what rendered me warm, or hot. (Lth, T, TA.*) You say also, dafiYa Albayotu [The tent, or house, or chamber, was, or became, warm, or hot]. (Mṣb.) And dafuWa, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadofuOu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dafaMCapN, (TA,) It (a tent, or house, or chamber, ISk, T, and a day, Mṣb, TA) was, or became, warm, or hot. (ISk, T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) [And in like manner, a garment; as is implied in the Ṣ.]
And dafuWato layolatunaA Our night was, or became, warm, or hot. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
dafaOa, for dafaA: see 1 in art. dfw.

entry.sense: 3: see 4.

hom.sense: 4. AdfOhu It (a garment, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, of wool or the like, Mgh) rendered him warm, or hot. (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb.*) And He clad him with a garment (M, Ḳ, TA) of wool, &c. (TA) that rendered him warm, or hot. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence,] ‡ He gave him a large gift; (TA;) or he gave him much. (Ḳ.)
AdfO Alqawomu The people, or company of men, collected themselves together [app. so that they made one another warm, or hot]. (Ḳ.)
AdfOt AlUibilu EalaImiAYapK The camels exceeded a hundred. (M.)
AdfOhu, in the dial. of El-Yemen, as also daAfaOahu↓, i. q. [OadofaAhu and] daAfaAhu and dafaAhu, [see art. dfw,] He despatched him, namely, a wounded man; i. e. put him to death quickly. (L.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.
8: see 1.
dafoCN: see what next follows.

difoCN Warmth, or heat; syn. suxuwnapN (T, Ṣ, Mgh) and HaraArapN; (Mgh;) contr. of barodN; (Mṣb;) or contr. of Hid-apu barodK; (M, Ḳ;) as also dafoCN↓ (IḲṭṭ TA) and dafaON↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. of dafiYa, (Ṣ, TA,) and dafaMCapN↓, (Ḳ,) also inf. n. of dafiYa accord. to the Ṣ and Ṣgh, and of dafuWa accord. to Yz: (TA:) pl. OadofaMCN. (M, Ḳ.)

A thing [or garment or covering] that renders one warm, or hot, (Th, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) of wool, (Th, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) or the like, (Mgh,) or of camels' fur; (Th, M, Ḳ;) as also difaMCN↓: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. of the former as above. (Ṣ.) You say, maA Ealayohi difoCN [There is not upon him any warm garment or covering, or anything to render him warm]: but you should not say, mA Elyh dafaMCapN, (T, Ṣ,) because this is an inf. n. (Ṣ.)

The shelter (kin-) of a wall [by which one is protected from cold wind]. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, AuqoEudo fiI difoCi hecaA AlHaAYiTi [Sit thou in the shelter of this wall]. (T, Ṣ.) And dafoOapN↓ [also] signifies A shelter, for warmth, from the wind. (M.)

The young ones, or offspring, (nitaAj, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and hair, or fur, (M, Ḳ,) and milk, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,) of camels, and whatever else, of a profitable, or useful, nature, is obtained from them: (Ṣ, M,* Mgh, Ḳ:*) so called because clothing, with which to warm oneself, is made of camel's hair and wool: (TA:) it occurs in the Ḳur xvi. 5: (Ṣ, TA:) accord. to I “Ab, there meaning the offspring of any beast (daAb-ap). (TA.)
Also † A gift. (Ḳ.)
dafaON: see difoCN.

Also i. q. janaON [The having a bending forward of the upper part of the back over the breast:, &c.: see janiYa, of which janaON is the inf. n.]. (M: in some copies of the Ḳ janaOC; in others, and in the TA HanaOC. [See OadofaOu, below: and see dafFA and OadofaI in art. dfw.])

dafiYN Warmly clad; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man; (Ṣ, TA;) fem. with p {dafiYapN}: (TA:) and so dafoMnu↓; fem. dafoOaI; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and pl., of the masc. and fem., difaMCN: (M, TA:) and so dafiIoCN↓, accord. to IAạr, who cites, as an ex., the following verse:
yabiytu Oabuw layolaI dafiyoYFA waDayofuhu
mina Alqur-i yuDoHiI musotaHiq-FA xaSaAYilaho
[Aboo-Leylà passes the night warmly clad, while his guest, by reason of the cold, becomes deserving of his properties]: (M, TA:) though it has been asserted that dafoMnu↓ and its fem. are applied peculiarly to human beings; and dafiIoCN↓, peculiarly to time and place; and dafiYoCN, to a human being and to time and place: (TA:) [for] this last signifies [also] warm, or hot: (M:) [and so does each of the two other epithets:] you say bayotN dafiYN(Mṣb) or dafiIoCN↓, of the measure faEiylN, (T, Ṣ, O, TA, [though this is said in the Mṣb to be not allowable,]) [a warm, or hot, tent or house or chamber,] and in like manner vawobN dafiIoCN↓ [a warm garment], (Ṣ, M, O, TA,) and yawomN dafiIoCN↓ (T, Ṣ, O, TA) and dafoMnN↓ (TA from Expositions of the Fṣ) [a warm, or hot, day], and layolapN dafiyoYapN↓ (T, Ṣ, O, TA) and dafoOaI↓ (TA from the Expositions of the Fṣ) [a warm, or hot, night], and OaroDN dafiYapN and dafiyoYapN↓ (Ḳ) and madofaOapN↓ (M, Ḳ) a warm, or hot, land; pl. of the last madaAfiYu. (M, TA.)
dafoOapN: see difoCN.
dafoMnu, and its fem. dafoOaI: see dafiYN, in four places.

dafaYiI-N, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) also termed davaYiI-N, (Aṣ, IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) but this latter is not of established authority, and is not mentioned in the M nor in the O., (TA in art. dvO,) The rain that falls after the heat has acquired strength; (M, Ḳ in art. dvO, TA;) when the earth has put (lit. vomited) forth the kamoOap [or truffles, which, accord. to Ḳzw, are found in Nejd (Central Arabia) at the period of the auroral setting of the Tenth Mansion of the Moon, (which happened, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, in that part, on the 11th of February O. Ṣ.,) when the sharpness of winter is broken, and the trees put forth their leaves: see also 1 in art. ntj]: (Lth, IAạr, Th, M:) or the rain that is after [that called] the rabiyE [q.v.], before, (qabol, as in one copy of the Ṣ, in another qbl without any syll. signs,) or in the first part of, (qubul, as in the TA,) [that called] the Sayof [q. v., see also nawoCN], when the kamoOap disappear entirely from the earth: (Ṣ, O, TA:) AZ says that the beginning of the dafaYiI- is wuquwEu Aljabohapi and the end is AlS-rofapu [i. e. the period extends from the auroral setting of the Tenth Mansion of the Moon (about the 11th of February O. Ṣ. as explained above, when the sun in Arabia has begun to have much power,) to about the 9th of March O. Ṣ.: see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl; and see also another statement voce nawoCN]. (Ṣ, TA.)

And the term dafaYiy-apN↓ [used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, for miyrapN dafaYiy-apN,] is applied to The miyrap [or provision of corn, &c.], (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) whatever it be, that is brought (AZ, T, Ṣ) before, (qbl, written without any syll. signs in a copy of the Ṣ, and qbla in the CK,) or in the first part of, (qubul, as in the M and TA and in a copy of the Ṣ and in one of the Ḳ, [and this appears to be the right reading,] in a copy of the T qibl,) the Sayof [here meaning spring]: (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) this is the third myrp; [see this word for an explanation of the statement here given;] the first being that called the riboEiy-ap [q. v.]; and the second, that called the Sayofiy-ap [q. v.]: then comes the dfYy-p; and then, the ramaDiy-ap, which comes when the earth becomes burnt [by the sun]. (M.)

And in like manner also, (AZ, Ṣ,) i. e., by the term dafaYiI-N is also meant, (M,) The nitaAj [or offspring] (AZ, Ṣ, M) of sheep or goats [brought forth at that period, as is implied in the Ṣ, or] in the end of winter: or, as some say, at any time. (M.)
dafaYiy-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
difaMCN: see difoCN.
dafiIoCN, and its fem. (dafiyoYapN): see dafiYN, in seven places.
dafaMCapN: see difoCN.
OadofaOu; (so in some copies of the Ḳ; but accord. to the TA without a final C, i. e. OadofaA, as in other copies of the Ḳ;) fem. dafoOaI; Curved in body. (Ḳ. [See also OadOfaI in art. dfw.])
madofaOapN: see dafiYN.

UibilN madofaOapN (Aṣ, Th, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and mudaf-aOapN↓ (M, Ḳ) Camels having abundance of fur (Aṣ, Th, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and fat; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) rendered warm by their fur; (M;) as also mudofiYapN↓ and mudaf-iYapN↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter two signify many camels; (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, O;) because (Aṣ, Ṣ, O) rendering one another warm by their breath; (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, O;) and so, accord. to the L, mudofaApN, without C. (TA.)
mudofiYapN: see what next precedes.
mudaf-aOapN: see what next precedes.
mudaf-YapN: see what next precedes.

dafotarN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and difotarN, (Lḥ, Fr, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like dirohamN, (TA,) [A register;] a number of leaves put, or joined, together: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or an account-book; syn. jariydapN HisaAbK: (Mṣb:) or a written book: and it may be met. applied to a blank book, like dafotarN OaboyaDu: (Mgh:) [it is a Persian word, arabicized; though asserted to be] an Arabic word, but, as IDrd says, of unknown derivation; and by some of the Arabs, [namely, the Benoo-Asad, (Fr, TA in art. tftr,)] pronounced tafotarN: (Mṣb:) pl. dafaAtiru: (Ṣ, Mgh:) of which the dim. is dufayotiraAtN. (Mgh.)
dufayotiraAtN: see above.

1. dafira, aor. _a {yadofaru}, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dafarN (A, Mgh, Mṣb) and daforN, (A,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and Adfr↓; (Mṣb;) It, (a thing, A, Mṣb,) and he, (a man, TA,) stank: (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [see also daforN, below:] but some say, of dafirN, that it is a possessive epithet, having no verb pertaining to it: and accord. to IAạr, Adfr↓ signifies he (a man) smell of his art. (TA.)
dafira, aor. _a {yadofaru}, (TḲ,) inf. n. dafarN, (Ḳ,) or daforN, (M,) It (food, or wheat, M, Ḳ, and flesh-meat, M, TA) became maggotty. (M, Ḳ, TḲ.)
Also He (a man, TḲ) was, or became, base, abject, vile, or despicable. (IAạr,* Ḳ,* TḲ.)
4: see 1, in two places.

daforN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dafarN↓, (IAạr, M, A, Ḳ,) the former a simple subst., and the latter an inf. n., (Mṣb,) or both inf. ns., (A,) and daforapN↓, (Mṣb,) Stink; stench: (IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) never used to signify a sweet smell: (M:) accord. to Aboo-” Alee El-Ḳálee, dafarN↓ has the above-mentioned signification; but daforN signifies pungency of odour, whether stinking or sweet: other authorities, however, assert, accord. to what is transmitted from them, that the word signifying intense pungency of odour, whether sweet or bad, is cafarN, with c, and with two fet-ḥahs, whence misokN Oacofaru: IAạr says that cafarN↓ signifies stink, or stench; and caforN, baseness, or vileness; but this is not known on any other authority. (M, L, TA.)

Hence the saying of ʼOmar, wadaforaAho, meaning [Alas, what stench! i. e., † Alas, what an abominable thing! i. e.] waAnatonaAho: (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M:) or it means Alas, what baseness, or vileness! (IAạr, T, M.)

Hence also the phrase, daforFA lahu, meaning [May God make stench to cleave to him, or it! i. e., † Fy, or shame, upon him, or it! i. e.] natonFA lahu: (Ṣ, Mgh:) and daforFA dafirFA↓ limaA yajiIoCu bihi fulaAnN, (T,* Ṣ, M,) meaning [May foul stench cleave to that which such a one doth! i. e., † Foul shame upon it! i. e.] natonFA; (Ṣ, M;) but in an intensive sense; (M;) said in declaring a man's case, or affair, to be bad, or abominable. (T, Ṣ.)
Hence, too, Ald-aforu, (TA,) and Oum-u daforK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) † Calamity, or misfortune. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

And Oum-u daforK, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) written by Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee Oum-u dafarK↓, but this is wrong, (R,) and Oum-u daforapa↓, (IAạr,) and dafaAri↓, and Oum-u dafaAri, (M, Ḳ,) † The present world; (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) because of its calamities, or misfortunes. (TA.)
dafarN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
dafirN (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Oadofaru↓ (M, A, Ḳ) Stinking: (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) fem. [of the former] dafirapN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and [of the latter] daforaMCu↓. (M, A, Ḳ.)
laHomN dafirN Stinking and maggotty flesh-meat. (A.)
katiybapN daforaMCu↓ An army, or a collected portion thereof, or a troop of horse, having rusty armour or arms: (Ḳ:) or smelling of the rust of their armour or arms. (A.)
daforapN: see daforN, in two places.

dafaAri (indecl., with kesr for its termination, TA) The female slave. (T, M, Ḳ.) Mostly used in vocative expressions. (TA.) One says to a female slave, (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) reviling her, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) dafaAri, yaA meaning O thou stinking one! (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) alluding to her intrinsic foulness. (Mṣb.)
See also daforN, last sentence.
daforFA daAfirFA: see daforN.
Oadofaru, and its fem. daforaMCu: see dafirN, in three places.

1. dafaEahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadofaEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dafoEN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and dafaAEN (TA) and madofaEN, (Ḳ,) [He impelled it, pushed it, thrust it, or drove it; and particularly, so as to remove it from its place; he propelled it; he repelled, or repulsed, it; he pushed it, thrust it, or drove it, away, or back;] he put it away, or removed it from its place, (Mṣb, TA,) by, or with, force, or strength: (TA:) or dafoEN signifies the putting away or removing or turning back a thing before the coming or arriving [of that thing]; like as rafoEN signifies the “putting away or removing or turning back” a thing “after the coming or arriving” thereof. (Kull p. 185.) Hence the saying in the Ḳur [ii. 252, and xxii. 41], walawo laA dafoEu Qll-ehi Aln-aAsa [And were it not for God's repelling men]; where some read difaAEu↓ [which means the same, as will be seen in the course of what follows, though bearing also another interpretation, likewise to be seen in what follows]. (TA.) You say, dafaEotu Alr-ajula [I impelled, pushed,, &c., the man]. (Ṣ.) And dAfEhu↓, inf. n. difaAEN [and mudaAfaEapN]; and df-Ehu↓; (TA;) [both, app., accord. to the TA, signifying the same; but the latter more properly relates to several objects together, or signifies he impelled it, pushed it,, &c., much, or vehemently, or often; whereas] mudaAfaEapN (Ḳ, TA) and difaAEN (TA) are [often exactly] syn. with dafoEN. (Ḳ, TA.) Thus, (TA,) you say, as meaning the same, dAfE↓ Eanohu and dafaEa [He repelled from him; whence another explanation of these two phrases, which see in what follows]. (Ṣ, TA.) And hence, dafaEa Qll-ehu Eanoka Almakoruwha, inf. n. dafoEN, ‡ [May God repel, or avert, from thee what is disliked, or hated, or evil]: (TA:) and daAfaEa↓ Qll-ehu Eanoka Als-uwoCa, inf. n. difaAEN, ‡ [May God repel, or avert, from thee evil]. (Ṣ, TA.) And dafaEotu Eanohu AlOacaI ‡ [I repelled, or averted, from him what was hurtful, or annoying; as also daAfaEotu↓]. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) Sb mentions, as a saying of the Arabs, AidofaEi AlX-ar-a walawo UiSobaEFA ‡ [Repel thou, or avert thou, evil, or mischief, though but with a finger: the last word being in the accus. case by reason of the subaudition of the prep. b; the meaning being biUiSobaEK]. (TA.) [See also an ex. voce dafuwEN.] When dafoEN is made trans. by means of Eano, [and has a single objective complement, a second objective complement is understood, and in general] it has the meaning or the act of † Defending; as in the Ḳur [xxii. 39], Uin-a Qll-eha yadofaEu Eano Ql-aciyna MmanuwA † [Verily God defendeth those who have believed; i. e. repelleth from them aggression and the like]; (B;) and yudaAfiEu↓, in the same, (Ḳ, TA,) accord. to another reading, signifies the same; (Ḳ, TA;) or this latter signifies † defendeth energetically, with the energy of him who contendeth for superiority in so doing. (Bḍ.) And daAfaEotu↓ Eanohu signifies [also] † I pleaded, or contended in arguments, in defence of him. (Mṣb.) [Exceptions to the statement cited above form the B will be found in what follows in this paragraph; and another exception, voce mudaf-aEN.]
[In the exs. which follow, the verb is used in senses little differing, essentially, from those assigned to it in the first sentence of this art.]
dafaEotu mina AlUinaMCi dafoEapF [I poured forth from the vessel a single pouring]: the last word, which is with fet-ḥ, is an inf. n. [of un.]. (Mṣb.)

dafaEati All-ibaOafiI DaroEihaA qubayola Aln-itaAji ‡ [She (a ewe, or goat, Ṣ, or a camel, Ṣ, Ḳ) infused the first milk into her udder, i. e. secreted it therein, a little before bringing forth]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And dafaEati All-abani EalaI raOosi waladihaA likavoratihi ‡ [She (a ewe or goat, or a camel, TA) secreted the milk in her udder when about to produce her young, by reason of its abundance]; for the milk becomes abundant in her udder only when she is about to bring forth: the inf. n. [app. the inf. n. of un.] is dafoEapN. (TA.) And dafaEato alone, said of a ewe or goat, signifies † She secreted milk in her udder when about to produce the young; expl. by OaDoraEato EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [which see in art. DrE]. (Ṣ, TA.) Accord. to En-Naḍr, one says dafaEato bilabinihaA, and biAll-abani, when her young is in her belly; but when she has brought forth, one does not say dafaEato. (TA.)

In the saying, gaXiyitonaA saHaAbapN fadafaEonaAhaA UilaI gayorinaA [lit. A cloud overspread us, and we drove it away to other persons], meaning ‡ it departed from us to other persons, dfEnAhA is for dafaEatonaA, which means dufiEato Ean-aA [lit. it was driven away from us]. (TA.)
dafaEahu biHuj-apK † [He refelled him, or refuted him, by an argument or the like]. (MF in art. kfH.)
dafaEotu Alqawola † I rebutted the saying; repelled it by an argument, an allegation, or a proof. (Mṣb.)
AidofaEo hecaA ‡ Leave thou this, sparing him. (Aṣ, TA.) [See mudaf-aEN.]
[In several exs. here following, the verb resembles AndfE; nafosahu, or the like, being understood after it.]

dafaEa AlmaMCu [The water poured out, or forth, as though it impelled, or propelled, itself]: (TA: [where it is followed by waQnoSab-a, as an explicative adjunct:]) and so Als-ayolu [the torrent]. (ISh.) [See also 6.]
And dafaEa AlwaAdiI biAlmaMCi [The valley poured with water]. (TA in art. HXk.)
dafaEa fiI Eadowihi † [He pushed, or pressed, on, or forward, as though he impelled himself, in his running]. (Ṣ in art. gwr;, &c.) [See also 7.]
dafaEa Alqawomu † The people, or company of men, came at once. (Mṣb.)

dafaEa UilaI AlmakaAni, (TA,) and dufiEa Uilayohi, (Mṣb, TA,) in the pass. form, (Mṣb,) ‡ He reached, or came to, the place. (Mṣb, TA.) You say also, hecaA TariyqN yadofaEu UilaI makaAni kacaA ‡ This is a road which reaches to such a place. (TA.)

dafaEa mino EarafaAtK † He commenced the journey from 'Arafát, and impelled and removed himself thence, or impelled his she-camel, and urged her to go. (TA, from a trad.) And dafaEotu Eani AlmawoDiEi † I removed, went, went away, or journeyed, from the place. (Mṣb.) [See again 7.]
dafaEa also signifies † He returned. (MF.)

When dafoEN is made trans. by means of UilaI, it [generally, but not always, as has been shown above,] has the meaning of the act of Giving, or delivering; as in the Ḳur [iv. 5], faQdofaEuwA Uilayohimo OamowaAlahumo [Then give ye, or deliver ye, to them their property]. (B.) You say, dafaEotu UilaII fulaAnK XayoYFA [I gave, or delivered, to such a one a thing]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) And dafaEotu AlwadiyEapa UilaI SaAHibihaA I restored the deposit to its owner. (Mṣb.) And dafaEotu lahu qiToEapF mina AlmaAli [I gave him a part, or portion, of the property]. (Ṣ in art. zEb; and the like is said in that art. in the Ḳ.) And dafaEahu [alone] He gave it; syn. OaEoTaAhu. (Er-Rághib, MF.)
2: see 1; fourth sentence.
df-Ehu UilaI kacaA ‡ He drove him, compelled him, or necessitated him, to do, or to have recourse to, such a thing. (TA.)
df-Ehu also signifies He rendered him abject and contemptible, or poor; as though deserving to be repelled. (Ibn-Maạroof, as cited by Golius.) [See the pass. part. n., below.]
df-E qawosahu † He made his bow even. (AḤn, TA.)

3. mudaAfaEapN [in its primary acceptation] signifies The contending, or striving, with another, to push him, or repel him; or the pushing, or repelling, another, being pushed, or repelled, by him; or the pushing against another; syn. muzaAHamapN. (TA.) [Hence, yudaAfiEu AlOaxobavayoni He is striving to suppress the urine and ordure: see Oaxobavu. And mudaAfaEapu AlEayoXi The striving to retain life: see 2 in art. zlj.]
[But it is often used in the same sense as dafoEN:] see the verb and its two inf. ns. in seven places in the former half of the first paragraph of this article.

Also † i. q. mumaATalapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) in some of the copies of the Ṣ, muTaAwalapN. (TA.) You say, daAfaEotuhu biHaq-ihi, (Jm, TA,) or Eano Haq-ihi, (Mṣb,) † I deferred with him, delayed with him, or put him off, in the matter of his right, or due, by promising time after time to render it to him; [and so repelled him, or strove to repel him, from it;] syn. maATalotuhu. (Jm, Mṣb, TA.) And dAfE biHaAjatihi † He deferred, delayed, postponed, or put off, his (another's) needful affair. (L in art. rvd.)
dAfE Alr-ajulu Oamora kacaA † The man attached, or devoted, himself to such an affair, and exerted himself, and persisted, or persevered, in it. (TA.)
5: see 6, and 7.

hom.sense: 6. tdAfEwA [They contended, or strove, together, to push, or repel, one another; or] they pushed, or repelled, one another; or pushed against one another. (Mṣb.) You say, tdAfEwA fiI AlHarobi They pushed, thrust, or repelled, one another in war, or battle. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] tdAfE AlkalaAmaAni † The two sayings, or sentences, opposed, or contradicted, each other; conflicted; were mutually repugnant. (Mṣb in art. nqD.)

tdAfE Als-ayolu ‡ The torrent was impelled, driven, or propelled, in its several parts, or portions, by the impetus of one part, or portion, acting upon another; and in like manner, [or as signifying it became impelled, driven, or propelled,] AndfE↓, and [in an intensive sense] tdf-E↓. (TA.) [See also dafaEa. Als-ayolu.]
tdAfE jaroIu Alfarasi [in like manner signifies † The running of the horse continued by successive impulses, his force of motion in each part of his course impelling him through the next]. (TA.)
See also 7.

[It is also trans.] You say, tdAfEwA AlX-aIoCa They repelled the thing, every one of them from himself. (TA.) And DayofN yatadAfaEuhu AlHaI-u [A guest whom the tribe repel, or repulse, every one of them from himself]. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 7. AndfE is quasi-pass. of dafaEahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and tdf-E↓ is quasi-pass. of df-Ehu; and tdAfE↓ is quasi-pass. of dAfEhu: but all three are used in the same sense: see 6: (TA:) [the first, however, primarily signifies He, or it, became impelled, pushed, thrust, or driven; and particularly, so as to be removed from his, or its, place; became propelled; became repelled; became impelled, pushed, thrust, or driven, away, or back, or onwards; became put away, or removed from its place; as is implied in the Ṣ and Ḳ and TA: whereas the second, properly, has an intensive signification: and the third properly denotes the acting of two or more persons or things, or of several parts or portions of a thing, against, or upon, one another; as is shown by exs. and explanations above: though the second and third are often used in the primary sense of the first.]

[Hence,] AndfE also signifies † He went away into the country, or land, in any manner: (Lth:) or, said of a horse [&c.], ‡ he [or it] went quickly or swiftly (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) [as though impelled or propelled; pressed, or pushed, on, or forward; rushed; launched, or broke, forth; it poured forth with vehemence, as though impelled: see 1, which has a similar meaning, particularly in the phrases dafaEa AlmaMCu, and Als-ayolu, and dafaEa fiI Eadowihi, &c.].

AndfE fiI AlHadiyvi, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and fiI AlUinoXaAdi, (TA,) ‡ He pushed on, or pressed on, in discourse, and in reciting poetry; or entered thereinto; or launched forth, or out, thereinto; or was large, or copious, or profuse, therein; or dilated therein; or began it, commenced it, or entered upon it; syn. OafaADa fiyhi. (Ḳ, TA.) And AndfE fiI AlD-aHiki [He broke forth into laughing]. (JK in art. bwq.)
[AndfE fiI AlT-aEaAmi † He fell to eating of the food; or applied himself eagerly to it.]
AndfE fiI AlOamori ‡ He acted with penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in the affair; syn. maDaI fiyhi. (A, TA.)
10. AisotadofaEotu Qll-eha AlOasowaMCa ‡ I asked, or begged, God to repel from me evils. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
dafoEN [see 1. Used as a simple subst., it signifies Impulsion; or the act of pushing, thrusting, or driving; and particularly, so as to remove a thing from its place; propulsion; repulsion;, &c.].

dafoEapN A single impulsion; a push, a thrust, or single act of driving; and particularly, so as to remove a thing from its place; a single propulsion; a single repulsion: (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA:) [it is an inf. n. of un. of 1 in all its senses; and thus,] it signifies also a single act of pouring: [&c.:] pl. dafaEaAtN. (Mṣb.) You say, dafaEahu dafoEapF, i. e. [He impelled,, &c., him, or it,] once [or with a single impulsion,, &c.]. (TḲ.) And dafaEotu mina AlUinaMCi dafoEapF, i. e. [I poured forth from the vessel] a single pouring. (Mṣb.)
[As an inf. n. of un. of 1,] it also signifies † A coming of the collective body of a people, or party of men, to a place at once. (TA.)
[Also † A heat, a single course, or one unintermitted act, of running, or the like.]

dufoEapN A quantity that pours forth, or out, at once, from a skin, or vessel: (Lth, Ḳ:) a quantity poured forth, or out, at once, (Mṣb,) [or with vehemence, being] syn. with dufoqapN. (IF, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the CK with E in the place of the q,]) of rain, [i. e. a shower, fall, or storm, as meaning the quantity that falls without intermission,] (IF, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and [a gush] of blood, (IF, Mṣb,), &c.: (IF, Ṣ, Mṣb:) it is also [used as signifying the tide] of a valley, (Ḳ in art. THm,) and [the tide, or rush,] of a torrent, (Ṣ and Ḳ in that art.,) and [the rush, or irruption,] of a troop of horses or horsemen, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. dlq, &c.,) and [the irruption, or invasion,] of night: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. THm:) pl. dufaEN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and dufaEaAtN and dufuEaAtN and dufoEaAtN. (Mṣb.) You say, baqiIafiI AlUinaMCi dufoEapN There remained in the vessel as much as one pours out at once. (Mṣb.)
Also A part, or portion, that is given, of property. (Ṣ in art. zEb.)
difaAEu, determinate, as a proper name, The ewe: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) so called because she pushes her thigh this way and that by reason of bulkiness. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

dafuwEN and midofaEN↓ [That impels, pushes, thrusts, drives, propels, or repels, much, or vehemently:] both signify the same. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying of a woman, (Ṣ,) an immodest woman, (O,) namely, Sejáhi [the false prophetess, to her husband the false prophet Museylimeh, describing the kind of cakar which she most approved], (L,) laA balo qaSiyrN midofaEN↓. (Ṣ, O, L.) You say also, rajulN daf-aAEN↓ A man who impels, propels, repels, or defends, vehemently. (TA.) And naAqapN dafuwEN A she-camel that hicks (tadofaEu) with her hind leg on being milked. (TA.)
daf-aAEN: see dafuwEN.
Also One who, when a bone happens to be in the part that is next to him, of a bowl, puts it away, or aside, in order that a piece of flesh-meat may become in its place. (El-Jáhidh, Ḳ.)

duf-aAEN The main portion, that pours down at once, or vehemently, of waves, and of a torrent, (Ḳ, TA,) and of a sea: (TA:) or a great torrent: (Ṣ:) or abundance and vehemence of water: (L:) or a great quantity of water of a torrent: and a great number of people. (AA.) You say, jaMCa duf-aAEN mina Alr-ijaAli waAln-isaMCi There came a great number of men and women crowding one upon another. (TA.)
Also ‡ A great thing by which a similar great thing is impelled, propelled, or repelled. (Ḳ,* TA.)

daAfiEN [act. part. n. of 1]. It is said in the Ḳur [lii. 8], maA lahu mino daAfiEK There shall not be any repeller thereof. (Bḍ.) And in the same [lxx. 2], layosa lahu daAfiEN There shall not be for it any repeller: (Bḍ:) or any defender. (B.)

Applied to a ewe or she-goat, (Ṣ,) or to a she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also daAfiEapN and midofaAEN↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ That infuses (tadofaEu) the first milk into her udder [i. e. secretes it therein] a little before bringing forth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) that infuses the milk into her udder when about to produce her young, by reason of its abundance: AO says that some make mufokihN and daAfiEN to signify the same, [i. e., to signify as explained above, or nearly so,] saying, hiIa daAfiEN biwaladK; and if you will, you say, hiIa daAfiEN, alone. (TA.)

daAfiEapN [fem. of daAfiEN, q. v.: and, used as a subst.,] The lower, or lowest, part of any [water-course such as is called] mayovaMC: pl. dawaAfiEu: this latter signifying the lower, or lowest, parts of the miyv, [pl. of myvAC,] (ISh, Ḳ,) where they pour into the valleys, (ISh,) or where the valleys pour thereinto: (Ḳ:) or the pl. signifies the parts in which the water pours to the myv; while the myv pour into the main valley: (Aṣ:) or the dAfEp is a [water-course such as is called] taloEap which pours into another tlEp, when it runs down a descending ground, or declivity, from elevated, or rugged and elevated, ground, and you see it going to and fro in places, having spread somewhat, and become round; then it pours into another, lower than it: every one such is thus called; and the pl. is as above. (Lth.)

madofaEN [A channel of water;] one of the madaAfiE of waters, in which the waters run: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [madaAfiEu being its pl.:] the lower, or lowest, part of a valley, where the torrent pours forth, and its water disperses: (ISh:) and the [water-course, or channel, such as is called] miconab of a daAfiEap [q. v.]; because this latter pours forth therein to another dAfEp; (Ḳ, TA;) the mcnb being the channel between the daAfiEataAni. (TA.)
midofaEN: see dafuwEN, in two places.

[Its primary signification is An instrument for impelling, propelling, or repelling: and hence it is applied in modern Arabic to a cannon: and to an instrument used by midwives for protruding the fœtus.]
[Hence, also, it is used as an intensive epithet: and hence,] rukonN midofaEN A strong corner. (TA.)

mudaf-aEN, applied to a camel, ‡ Held in high estimation by his owner; (A, Ḳ,* TA;) so that when he comes near to the load, he is sent back: (A, TA:) one that is reserved for covering, and not ridden nor laden; of which, when he is brought to be laden, one says, AidofaEo hecaA, i. e. Leave thou this, sparing him. (Aṣ.)
Also, (applied to a camel, TA,) † Held in mean estimation by his owner; (Ḳ,* TA;) so that when he comes near to the load, he is sent back as despised. (TA.) Thus it bears two contr. meanings. (Ḳ.)

Applied to a man, (A, TA,) ‡ Poor, (Ṣ, A, TA,) and abject, (Ṣ,) whom every one repels from himself, (A, TA,) or because every one repels him from himself; (Ṣ;) used conjointly with mudaq-aEN; i. e., you say, fulaAnN mudaf-aEN mudaq-aEN: (A, TA:) a man † despised, or held in contempt, (Lth, Ḳ,) as also mutadaAfaEN↓; (Lth;) who does not show hospitality if he make one his guest, nor give if he be asked to give: (Lth:) and one † who is repelled, or repulsed, from his relations (Al-aciI dufiEa Eano nasabihi: [nasabihi being used for cawiI nasabihi, like as nasabFA is used in the Ḳur xxv. 56, for cawiI nasabK, as explained by Bḍ:]) (IDrd, Ḳ:) and a guest † whom the tribe repel, or repulse, every one of them from himself, every one turning him away to another. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
OanaA mudaf-aEN UilaI Oamori kacaA ‡ I am driven, compelled, or necessitated, to do, or to have recourse to, such a thing. (TA.)
midofaAEN: see daAfiEN.
huwa say-idu qawomihi gayoru mudaAfaEK † He is the lord, or chief, of his people, or party, not straitened in his authority, nor thrust from it; (TA;) i. q. gayoru muzaAHamK. (Ḳ.)
AlmudaAfiEu † The lion. (Ṣgh.)
mutadAfiEu: see mudaf-aEN.
qawolN mutadaAfiEN ‡ [A saying of which one part opposes, or contradicts, another; a self-contradictory saying]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. dafaqahu, aor. _u {yadofuqu}. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and _i, (Jm, Ḳ,) inf. n. dafoqN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and by poetic license dafaqN, (TA,) He poured it forth, or out: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he poured it forth, or out, with vehemence: (Mgh, Mṣb:) namely, water [&c.]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) And dufiqa AlmaMCu The water poured out, or forth: one should not say dafaqa AlmaMCu: (Ṣ:) or this last, aor. _u {yadofuqu}, inf. n. dafoqN, signifies the water poured forth, or out, with vehemence: but Aṣ disallowed its being used in an intrans. sense: (Mṣb:) [the forms of the verb commonly used intransitively are 7 and 5:] accord. to Lth, alone, (Ḳ,) i. e. in the ʼEyn, (TA,) dafaqa AlmMCu, (Ḳ, TA,) and Ald-amoEu, aor. _u {yadofuqu}, (TA,) inf. n. dafoqN and dufuwqN, signify the water, (Ḳ, TA,) and the tears, (TA,) poured forth, or out, at once: (Ḳ. TA:) but Az disallows this. (TA.)

[Hence,] dafaqa Qll-ehu ruwHahu † [God poured forth his spirit; i. e.] God caused him to die: (Ḳ:) or it means may he die. (Ṣ.) Aṣ says, I alighted at the abode of an Arab woman of the desert, and she said to a daughter of hers, Bring to him the drinking-bowl (AlEus-): and she brought me a drinking-bowl in which was milk, and spilled it; whereupon she said to her dafaqato muhojatuki [May thy blood, or heart's blood, be poured forth: or, as appears from a statement above, the right reading is probably dufiqato]. (TA. [See also muhojapN.])

One says also, of a river, or rivulet, and of a valley, dafaqa, [app. for dafaqa AlmaMCa,] meaning, It became full so that the water poured forth, or overflowed, or so that it poured forth the water, from its sides. (TA.)
And dafaqa Alkuwza He poured forth, (JK,) or scattered, (Ḳ,) the contents of the mug at once; (JK, Ḳ;) as also Adfqhu↓. (Ḳ.)
The verb is also used transitively and intransitively in relation to a beast: you say, dafaqotu Ald-aAb-apa † I made the beast to hasten, or go quickly:

and dafaqati Ald-aAb-apu † The beast hastened, or went quickly: (Mṣb:) and [in like manner] one says of a quick camel, yatadaf-aqu↓ fiI miXoyihi † [He hastens, speeds, or presses forward, in his pace, or going]: and tadaf-aqati↓ AlOutunu The wild she-asses hastened, or went quickly. (TA.)
dafiqa, [aor. _a {yadofaqu},] (TA,) inf. n. dafaqN, (JK, Ṣ, TA,) He (a camel) had his teeth standing outwards: (Ṣ, TA:) or had his elbows far apart from his sides. (JK. [See also rafiqa.])

entry.sense: 2. [df-qhu He poured it forth, or out, copiously, or abundantly; namely, water, &c. See an ex. of the inf. n. used as a pass. part. n. voce daHiyqN.]
[Hence,] daf-aqato kaf-aAhu Aln-adaI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadofiyqN, (Ḳ,) His two hands poured forth largess (Ṣ, Ḳ) [copiously, or abundantly, for] it is with teshdeed to denote muchness. (Ṣ.)
4: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

5. tdf-q i. q. taSab-aba (Ṣ, Ḳ) [meaning (as the former is explained in the KL) It poured forth or out, or became poured forth or out, copiously, or abundantly; for it is quasi-pass. of daf-aqahu; though taSab-aba is said to be quasi-pass. of Sab-ahu like AinoSab-a, and though it is said in the TA that tdf-q is quasi-pass. of dafaqahu like Andfq].
See also 1, latter part, in two places.
[Hence,] huwa yatadaf-aqu fiI AlbaATili ‡ He hastens to do that which is false, vain, or unprofitable. (TA.)
And tdf-q Hilomuhu ‡ His forbearance, or clemency, departed. (TA.)
7. Andfq i. q. AnSb- [It poured forth or out, or became poured forth or out: see also dafaqa, which, if allowable, is less usual]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
10. Astdfq Alkuwzu The mug had its contents poured forth or out (AinoSab-a) at once. (TA.)
dafoqapN A single act of pouring forth or out [in any manner, or at once, (see 1,) or] with vehemence: pl. dafaqaAtN. (Mṣb.)

dufoqapN A quantity poured forth or out (Mṣb) at once, like dufoEapN, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. dfE, q. v.,) [or] with vehemence; (Mṣb;) of rain, [i. e. a shower, fall, or storm, as meaning the quantity that falls without intermission,] (Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ in art. dfE,) and [a gush] of blood, (Mṣb in that art.,), &c.: (Ṣ and Mṣb in that art.:) pl. dufaqN and dufaqaAtN and dufuqaAtN and dufoqaAtN. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] jaMCa Alqawomu dufoqapF waAHidapF ‡ The party came at once, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,*) or together. (Mṣb.)

difaq-N † Quick, swift, or fleet; applied to a he-camel; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Oadofaqu↓: (JK:) and so, applied to a she-camel, difaq-apN (JK) and difaAqN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is likewise applied to a he-camel, (JK, TA,) and dufaAqN↓ (Ḳ) and dafuwqN↓ and dafoqaMCu↓ (JK, TA) and dayofaqN↓ (JK, Ḳ) and difiq-aI↓. (TA.) † A camel going in the manner termed difiq-aI; as also difaAqN↓. (Ḳ.) † And, applied to a horse, Fleet, or swift; as also difq-N↓: and so, applied to a mare, difaq-apN and dafwuqN↓ and difaAqN↓ and difaq-aI↓ and difiq-aI↓. (Ḳ.)
difiq-N: see what next precedes.
difaq-aI: see difaq-N: and see also what next follows, in two places.
difiq-aI and difaq-aI↓ ‡ A she-camel quick, swift, or fleet, and of generous race: or that has never brought forth. (Ḳ, TA.) See also, for the former, difaq-N, in two places.

maXaI Ald-ifiq-aI, (Ḳ,) and Ald-ifaq-aI↓, (TA, and so in copies of the Ṣ,) the latter on the authority of IAmb, (TA,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) † He walked, or went quickly, or swiftly: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he went with slow steps (tamaX-aI), inclining at one time to one side and at another time to another side: or he went with wide steps, (Ḳ, TA,) and quickly. (TA.) And yaEoduw Ald-ifiq-aI † [He runs quickly:, &c.]. (TA.)
dufaAqN, applied to a torrent, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) That fills the valley: (Ṣ, O:) or that fills the two sides of the valley: (L:) or swift. (Ḳ.)
See also difaq-N.
difaAqN: see difaq-N, in three places.
dafuwqN: see difaq-N, in two places.

daf-aAqN [Pouring forth, or out, copiously, or abundantly: or] extensive, and copious, or abundant, rain: applied also [in the former sense] to the mouth of a leathern water-bag: and to a river, or rivulet; and so mudofiqN↓. (TA.)

daAfiqN [act. part. n. of dafaqahu; Pouring forth or out,, &c.]. daAfiqu xayorK [May it be pouring forth good] is said in prognostication on the occasion of the pouring forth of the contents of such a thing as a mug. (Lth, TA.)

maMCN daAfiqN means madofuwqN [i. e. Water poured forth or out,, &c.]; (IḲooṭ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because dafaqa is trans. [only] accord. to the generality (Ḳ, TA) of the leading lexicologists; (TA;) like sir-N kaAtimo meaning makotuwmN, (IḲooṭ, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and EaArifN meaning maEoruwfN, and EaASimN meaning maEoSuwmN, (IḲooṭ, Mṣb,) after a manner obtaining among the people of El-Ḥijáz, who change the mafoEuwlN into faAEil when it is used as an epithet: (Fr, Mṣb, TA:) or it means cuw dafoqK [having a pouring forth or out,, &c.]; (Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) accord. to Kh and Sb (TA) and Zj; (Mṣb, TA;) and in like manner they say that sir-N kaAtimN means cuw kitomaAnK: or, accord. to Lth, [i. e.] in the ʼEyn, it means water pouring forth, or out, at once: (TA:) it occurs in the Ḳur lxxxvi. 6; where daAfiq is said by Kh and Sb to signify munodafiq [i. e. pouring forth or out]: (Az, TA:) and it [there] means the sperma genitale. (JK.)
dayofaqN: see difaq-N.

hom.sense: Oadofaqu, and its fem. dafoqaMCu: see difaq-N.

The former is also applied to a pace, or rate of going, as meaning Quick, or swift: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to AO, it means OaqoSaI AlEanaqi [the utmost of the pace called AlEanaq]. (Ṣ, TA. [In my copies of the Ṣ, erroneously, AlEunuqi: in the TA without any vowel signs, app. because needless to any but the tyro in Arabic.])
Also, i. e. the former, A man bowed, or bent, (IAạr, Ḳ,) in his back, (IAạr,) by age or grief. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

And i. q. OaEowaju [here meaning Oblique]: (Aboo-Málik, Ḳ:) applied to a hilaAl [or new moon]: (Aboo-Málik:) Aboo-Málik says that the hlAl thus termed is better, or more auspicious, than that termed HaAqinN, which means “having its two extremities elevated, and its back decumbent:” and AZ says the like: (TA:) [or] Adfq applied to a hlAl signifies erect (musotawK [which must here mean nearly, not exactly, erect,]) and white, not turning sideways upon one of its two extremities: (Ḳ:) [and this also is esteemed more auspicious than that termed HAqn, q. v.:] so in the “Nawádir.” (TA.)

Also, applied to a camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to a mouth, (JK, TA,) Having the teeth standing out, or forwards: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, applied to a camel, having the elbows far apart from the sides. (Ḳ. [See also Oarofaqu.])

entry.sense: mudofiqN: see daf-aAqN.

hom.sense: difolN: see the following paragraph.
Also i. q. qaTiraAnN and zifotN [both app. here meaning Tar, or liquid pitch]: (Ḳ:) or such as is thick: mentioned in this art. by IF, and also as written with c. (TA.)

entry.sense: difolaI, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) accord. to those who make the alif to be a sign of the fem. gender; and difolFI, accord. to those who make that letter to be one of quasi-coordination; used alike as a sing. and a pl.; (Ṣ;) and difolN↓; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) [the first of these appellations applied in the present day to The rose-bay, or laurel-bay; oleander, nerium oleander, rhododendron, or rhododaphne: and also to the common laurel:] a certain tree, (T, M,) or plant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) bitter, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) very bitter, (TA,) and poisonous, (T,) green, and beautiful in appearance, the blossom of which is beautifully tinged, (M,) called in Persian xarozahoraho: (Ḳ:) there is a river-kind, and a land-kind: the leaves are like those of the HamoqaMC [or gardenpurslane], but more slender; and the branches, or twigs, are long, spreading over the ground; at the leaves are thorns; and it grows in waste places: the river-kind grows upon the banks of rivers; its thorns are unconspicuous, or unapparent; its leaves are like those of the xilaAf [or salix Aegyptia] and of the almond, broad; and the upper part of its stem is thicker than the lower part thereof: (TA:) it is very deadly: its blossom is like the red rose, (Ḳ,) very rough (xXn jd-A [but this I think is a mistranscription for HasanN jid-FA very beautiful]), and upon it is a kind of tuft like hair: (TA:) its fruit is like the xuronuwb [q. v.]; (Ḳ;) having an aperient, or a deobstruent, property; and stuffed with a substance like wool: (TA:) it is good for the mange, or scab, and the itch (Hik-ap), used in the manner of a liniment, (Ḳ,) and especially the expressed juice of its leaves; (TA;) and for pain of the knee and the back, (Ḳ,) of long duration, (TA,) applied in the manner of a poultice, or plaster; and for expelling fleas and the [insect called] OaraD, by the sprinkling of a decoction thereof; and the rubbing over with the heart thereof twelve times, after cleansing, is good for removing the [malignant leprosy termed] baraS; (Ḳ;) and its leaves put upon hard tumours are very beneficial: but it is a poison: [yet] sometimes it is mixed with wine and rue, and given to be drunk, and saves from the poisons of venomous reptiles: the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna,] says that it is perilous by itself, and its blossom, to men, and to horses and the like, and to dogs, but is beneficial when made into a decoction with rue, and drunk: (TA:) IAạr says that the [trees termed] MC and OalaMC and Hbr [app. a mistranscription for xabor, a species of lote-tree,] are all called difolaI. (T.) AḤn says that the zanod made from the difolaI is excellent for producing fire: and hence the prov., AiqodaHo bidifolaI fiI maroxi vum-a Xud-a baEodu Oawo Oaroxi [Endeavour thou to produce fire with wood of the dflI upon wood of the mrx: then tighten afterwards or loosen]: (M:) said when one incites a bad man against another bad man: (M, Meyd:) or, accord. to IAạr, said in relation to a man whom one needs not to press, or importune. (Meyd.)

hom.sense:
1. dafanahu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yadofinu}, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dafonN, (M, Mṣb, TA,) He buried it; interred it; i. e. hid it, concealed it, or covered it, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) in the earth, or dust, (TA,) or beneath layers, or strata, of earth, or dust; (Mṣb;) namely, a thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) primarily having for its object a dead body: (M:)
and df-nhu↓ signifies the same; [but app. in an intensive sense or applying to a number of objects;] (M, TT;) or Aid-afanahu↓, of the measure AifotaEalahu. (Ḳ. [So too, accord. to the TA, in the M; but in the text of the M as given in the TT, df-nhu.]) One says to a man who is obscure, unnoted, or of no reputation, dafanota nafosaka fiIHayaAtika ‡ [Thou hast buried thyself in thy lifetime]. (TA.)
Hence, (M,) dafana sir-ahu ‡ He hid, or concealed, his secret. (M, TA.) And dafanotu AlHadiyva † I hid or concealed, the information, or news,, &c. (Mṣb.)

[Hence also, dafana Alr-akiy-apa He filled up, stopped up, or choked up, with earth or dust, the well.] And dafanotu Euyuwna AlmiyaAhi I stopped up the sources of the waters; syn. Eaw-arotuhaA, and sadadotuhaA. (Sh, TA in in art. Ewr.)

dafanato, aor. _i {yadofinu}, inf. n. dafonN, said of a she-camel, She went her own way, or at random, or heedlessly, (M, Ḳ,) without need: (M:) or it signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (Ḳ,) she was, or became, (M, Ḳ,) usually, (Ḳ,) in the midst of the other camels when they came to water: (M, Ḳ:) and Aid-afanato↓, (En-Naḍr, T, TA,) of the measure AifotaEalato, (TA,) said of a she-camel, she was, or became, such as is termed dafuwnN↓; (En-Naḍr, T, TA;) i. e. she absented, or hid, herself from the other camels: or went her own way, at random, or heedlessly, alone. (En-Naḍr, T.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.
3. mudaAfanapu AlmawotaI: see 6.
5: see 7.

6. Alt-adaAfunu signifies mudaAfanapu↓ AlmawotaI [i. e. The cooperating in the burying of the dead]. (TA.) laA yakaAdu Aln-aAsu yatadaAfanuwna [The people can hardly, or cannot nearly, bury one another] is said in the case of a quick and spreading death. (TA voce cariygN.)

[Hence,] tadaAfanuwA ‡ They practised concealment, one with another; syn. takaAtamuwA. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) It is said in a trad., lawo takaAXafotumo lamaA tadaAfanotumo ‡ [If ye revealed, one to another his faults, or his secrets, ye would not practise concealment, one with another, in any case]; meaning, if the fault, (Eayob, as in my copies of the Ṣ and in the TA in the present art.,) or secret or secrets, (gayob, as in one of my copies of the Ṣ in art. kXf,) of each one of you were open, or revealed, to each other of you: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to IAth, [if ye revealed, one to another his secrets, ye would not bury one another; for he says that] the meaning is, if each one of you knew what is concealed in the mind of each other of you, the conducting of his funeral, and his burial, would be deemed onerous. (TA in art. kXf.)

7. Andfn It was, or became, buried, or interred; i. e., hidden, concealed, or covered, (Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) in the earth, or dust, (TA,) or beneath layers, or strata of earth, or dust: (Mṣb:) and Aid-afana↓, of the measure AifotaEala, signifies the same; (Ṣ;) or tdf-n↓. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, said of a portion of a well, (Ṣ,) or of a well [absolutely], and of a watering-trough or tank, and of a water-ing-place, or spring to which camels came to water, (M, Ḳ, TA,) [and] so Ad-fn↓, (T,) [It was, or became, filled up, stopped up, or choked up, with earth or dust; (see 1, of which each of these verbs is a quasi-pass.;) or] it had the dust swept into it by the wind [so that it became filled up, stopped up, or choked up]. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: 8. Aid-afana, of the measure AifotaEala: see 7, in two places.

Also, said of a slave, He ran away [given without any addition as one of the explanations in the Ṣ] before arriving at the city [or place] in which he was to be sold: (T, M, Ḳ:) this is not a running away (UibaAq) for which he is to be returned [to the seller]: so says Yezeed Ibn-Hároon: but he adds that if he arrive there and run away, he is to be returned for it, though he do not absent himself from that city [or place]: (T:) or he absented himself, (T,) or stole away, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,) from his owners [or owner] for a day or two days, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh,) as AZ says, (T, Ṣ,) or, (T, M,) as AO says, (T, Ṣ,) without absenting himself from the city [or place in which he was sold]; (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh;) as though he buried himself in the houses of that city [or place] in fear of punishment for an offence that he had committed: (Mgh:) thus, agreeably with the explanations of AZ and AO, the verb is used by the Arabs: (AʼObeyd, T:) and the epithet dafuwnN↓, applied to a slave, means one who does as is described above; (Ḳ;) or who is wont to do so: (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh:) or the verb signifies he fled from his owner, or from hard, or severe, work, but did not go forth from the town, or the like; and the doing so is not a fault [for which he may be returned to the seller], for it is not termed UibaAq. (Mṣb.)
See also 1, last sentence.
Aid-afanahu: see 1, first sentence.

entry.sense: dafonN [originally an inf. n.]: see dafiynN, in four places.
Also, applied to a man, ‡ Obscure, unnoted, or of no reputation; (Ḳ, TA;) [and] so dafuwnN↓. (AZ, T.)
difonN: see dafiynN, in four places.
dafinN: see dafiynN, in two places.
dafaniI-N A kind of striped cloths or garments. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
difaAnN: see dafiynN, in two places.
dafuwnN applied to a slave: see 8.
Applied to a she-camel, That is in the midst of the other camels: (Ṣ:) or that is usually in the midst of the other camels when they come to water. (M, Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence.
See also dafonN. In like manner one says HasabN dafuwnN † Obscure grounds of pretension to respect or honour. (AZ, T.)

dafiynN i. q. madofuwnN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Buried, or interred; i. e. hidden, concealed, or covered, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) in the earth, or dust, (TA,) or beneath layers, or strata, of earth, or dust; (Mṣb;) as also difonN↓ (M, Ḳ) and dafonN↓: (TA:) pl. [of the first] dufanaMCu (M, Ḳ) and of the same also dufunN; (TA;) and [of the second] OadofaAnN, (M, Ḳ,) which is also pl. of the third: (TA:) dafiynN is also applied to a woman, and so is dafiynapN; (Lḥ, M, Ḳ;) and the pl. is dafonaI, (Lḥ, M,) or dufanaMCu, (Ḳ,) and dafaAYinu: (Lḥ, M, Ḳ:) and the pl. dufunN is also used as a sing., applied to land (OaroDN). (TA. [But in the M it is said that dafonN↓ is thus applied as an epithet to land (ArD), and that its pl. is dufunN.])
See also dafiynapN.

Also, applied to a well (rakiy-apN), Partly filled up with earth or dust (Ainodafana baEoDuhaA); as also difaAnN↓; pl. dufunN: (Ṣ:) or i. q. munodafinapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) i. e. [filled up with earth or dust; or] having the dust swept into it by the wind [so that it is filled up, stopped up, or choked up]; (T, TA;) as also midofaAnN↓ (M, Ḳ) and difaAnN↓: (Ḳ:) and so dafonN↓, (M, TA,) or difonN↓, (Ḳ,) thus applied, (Ḳ, TA,) and applied likewise to a watering-place, or spring to which camels have come to water, (M, Ḳ, TA,) and to a watering-trough or tank; (M, Ḳ;) as also dafiynN. (TA.)
Also Flesh-meat buried in rice: but this is a vulgar application. (TA.)

daMCN dafiynN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and dafinN↓, (IAạr, M, TA,) which is anomalous, app. a possessive epithet, like nahorN as applied to a man, (M,) in the Ḳ, erroneously, difonN↓, (TA,) ‡ A latent disease, which the constitution has overpowered [so as to prevent its becoming apparent]; it is said in a trad. that the sun causes it to appear: (IAth, TA:) or a disease that is unknown (T, Ṣ) until evil and mischief appear from it: (T:) or a disease that appears after being latent, and from which evil and mischief (Xar-N waEar-a [in the CK, erroneously, waEur-N]) then appear and spread: (M, Ḳ:) [it is said that] it is seldom, or never, cured. (M.)
rajulN dafiynu Almuruw-api, and difonN↓ Almrw-p, (TA,) or dafinu↓ Almrw-p and dafonu↓ Almrw-p, (T,) † A man without manliness, or manly virtue: so says Aṣ. (T, TA.)
dafiynapN A thing buried: (Th, Ḳ:) and hence, (TA,) a treasure, or a buried treasure: pl. dafaAYinu: (M, Ḳ, TA:) and dafiynN↓ also signifies buried treasure. (TA in art. rkz.)
duf-aAnN [irregularly] sing. of dafaAYinu signifying The xaXab [or pieces of wood, by which may be meant planks, or spars, or ribs, &c.,] of a ship. (AA, TA.)
daAfinu OamorK, in the Ḳ, erroneously, daAfinaMC, (TA,) ‡ The inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of a case or an affair. (Ḳ, TA.)
baqarapN daAfinapu Aljacomi A cow, or an animal of the ox-kind, whose OaDoraAs [i. e. teeth, or molar teeth,] are ground, or worn, by reason of extreme age. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mdfn [by rule madofinN, but commonly pronounced madofanN,] A place of burial: [a tomb:] pl. madaAfinu. (TA.)

hom.sense: midofaAnN: see dafiynN:
and dafuwnN.
Also An old, worn-out, skin for water or milk. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: madofuwnN: see dafiynN.
munodafinapN, applied to a well (rakiy-apN): see dafiynN.

hom.sense: 1. dafiIa, [aor. yadofaI,] inf. n. dafFA, He, or it, was, or became, such as is termed OadofaI, in any of the senses of this epithet. (M.) [See also 4.]

dafawotu AljariyHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, dafayotu,]) aor. Oadofuwhu, inf. n. dafowN; (Ṣ, TA;) and daAfayotuhu↓ and Oadofayotuhu↓; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) I despatched the wounded man; i. e. hastened and completed his slaughter; or made his slaughter sure, or certain: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so daAfaOotuhu and OadofaOotuhu (TA) [and daAfaqotuhu, &c.: see 3 in art. df]. Accord. to Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, dafaI, [or rather dafaA,] sometimes pronounced with C, [dafaOa,] signifies He slew, in the dial. of Kináneh. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1.

hom.sense: 4: see 1.

It is related in a trad. that a captive was brought to the Prophet, (Ṣ, TA,) shivering by reason of cold, (TA,) and he said to some persons, AicohabuwA bihi faOadofuwhu, meaning [Take ye him away and] clothe him so as to protect him from the cold; (Ṣ, TA;) for OadofiYuwhu; because the pronunciation of C was not of the dial. of Kureysh; but they thought that he meant slaughter; (TA;) and they took him away and slew him: therefore he paid the fine for his blood. (Ṣ, TA.) As is said in the Ḳ, Oadofayotu is a dial. var. of OadofaOotu. (TA.)
AdfI said of a gazelle, His horns were, or became, so long as almost to reach his hinder part. (T, Ḳ.) [See also dafiIa.]

entry.sense: 6. Alt-adaAfiI i. q. Alt-adaAruku [app. in relation to a camel's pace, or manner of going, as meaning The continuing uninterruptedly]: (Ḳ:) and Alt-adaAwulu [denoting alternation of any kind]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [accord. to the TA, this means, here, what next follows; and the same seems to be indicated in the Ṣ:] and a camel's going along with an inclining from side to side (Oano yasiyra sayorFA mutajaAfiyFA): (Ḳ:) you say, tadaAfaI AlbaEiyru, meaning saAra sayorFA mutajaAfiyFA [The camel went along with an inclining from side to side]. (Ṣ.) [See also the second of the verses cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. df: from the explanation of which by ISd, it appears that tadaAfaI is perhaps originally tadaAf-a.]
8. Aid-afayotu a dial. var. of Aid-afaOotu. (Lth, T in art. dfO.)
10. Aisotadofayotu a dial. var. of AisotadofaOotu. (Lth, T in art. dafO, and Ḳ in the present art.)
dafFA inf. n. of dafiIa [q. v.]. (M.) A bending, or curving. (T, Ṣ.) You say, of a man, fiyhi dafFA In him is a bending, or curving: and this is said of Ed-Dejjál. (T.) [See also dafaON.]
Also, in a mountain-goat, The having very long horns, extending towards his ears. (Ṣ.)
daAfiI, used [for the sake of rhyme] by Ru-beh for daAfifu: see daAf-N, in art. df.

OadofaI, applied to a man, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) Humpbacked: (T, Ṣ:) or who walks with an inclining on one side: or, as some say, i. q. OajonaOu [q. v.]: or having contracted shoulders: (M:) or bending, or curving. (Ḳ.) [See also OadofaOu.] Its fem., in all its senses, is dafowaMCu. (M.)

Applied to a camel, Long in the neck, and protuberant in the back, whose head nearly touches his hump: (M:) and the fem., applied to a she-camel, (Ḳ,) or to an excellent she-camel, (Lth, T, Ṣ,) long in the neck; (Lth, T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) that, when she goes along, almost puts her head upon the back of her hump, and is long in the back. (Lth, T.)

Applied to a ram, Whose horn extends towards his ear: (T:) or, applied to a mountain-goat, (Ṣ, M,) and to a domestic goat, (M,) whose horns are very long, extending towards his ears; (Ṣ;) or whose horns are so long that they turn down backwards upon his ears: (M:) and [in like manner] the fem. is applied to a she-goat; (Ṣ;) meaning, accord. to AZ, whose horns turn down to the extremity of each of her EilobaAwaAni [dual of EilobaMCN, q. v.]. (T.)

Applied to a bird, Long in the wing: (Ṣ:) or long in the wings and tail: (M:) or long in the wings, having the ends of the primary feathers even with the end of the tail. (ʼEyn.) And the fem., applied to an eagle (EuqaAb), Crook-billed: (Ḳ:) or so applied because that bird is crook-billed. (Ṣ.)

And the fem., applied to an ear [of a beast], Approaching the other ear so that the extremities of the two almost touch each other, bending down towards the forehead, not standing erect, but strong: as some say, applied to the ear of a horse only: or, as Th says, only meaning inclining. (M.)
Also, the fem., accord. to AʼObeyd, Having wide bones. (M.)

XajarapN dafowaMCu A great tree: (Ṣ:) or a great, shady tree; and it may be, inclining: (T:) or a shady tree, having many branches: (IAth, TA:) or, as some say, an inclining tree: (TA:) occurring in a trad., describing a certain tree that was worshipped. (T, Ṣ.)
UibilN mudofaApN: see mudofaOapN, in art. dfO.

hom.sense: 1. daq-a, aor. yadiq-u, inf. n. dif-apN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It (a thing, Ṣ) was, or became, daqiyq, which means the contr. of galiyZ; as also Astdq-↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [i. e. it was, or became, thin as meaning slender, or small in diameter or circumference as compared with length: also small in all dimensions; small in size; minute, or fine, either as a whole, or in its component particles: and sometimes, as said of a garment or the like, thin, or fine, as opposed to thick or coarse; like raq-a:] contr. of galuZa: (Mṣb:) Astdq-↓ is said of the hilaAl [or moon a little after or before the change], and of other things. (TA.) [See also riq-apN.]

And [hence], aor. and inf. n. as above, ‡ He, or it, was, or became, little in estimation, paltry, inconsiderable, mean, vile, or contemptible. (TA.) One says to him who refuses to confer a benefit, daq-a bika xuluquka † [Thy nature, or natural disposition, hath rendered thee mean,, &c.; the verb being made trans. by bi, agreeably with a common usage mentioned in p. 141]. (TA.)

Also, [aor. and] inf. n. as above, said of a thing, an affair, or a case, [and of speech, or language,] † It was, or became, subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure. (Mṣb.) And you say, daq-a fiI kalaAmihi ‡ [He was, or became, subtile, nice, abstruse,, &c., in his speech, or language]. (TA.)

daq-ahu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoququ}, inf. n. daq-N, (M, Mṣb,) He broke it, (M, Ḳ, TA,) or crushed it, (M,) in any manner: (M, TA:) or he bruised, brayed, or pounded, it; i. e., he beat it with a thing so that he broke it, or crushed it: (M, Ḳ:*) namely, a thing, (Ṣ, M, TA,) such as medicine, &c. (TA.)
[And hence, He beat it; namely, a garment or the like; in washing and whitening it. And daq-a AlbaAba He knocked at the door for admission.]

And [hence also, (in the CK, erroneously, “or,”) as appears from what follows,] † He made it apparent; showed, exhibited, manifested, or revealed, it: (Ḳ:) so says IAạr, citing the following verse of Zuheyr:
tadaArakotumaA EabosFA wacuboyaAna baEodamaA
tafaAnawoA wadaq-uwA bayonahumo EiTora manoXimi : (TA:) i. e. Ye two repaired the condition of the tribes of 'Abs and Dhubyán by peace, (talaAfayotumaA OamorahumaA biAlS-uloHi,) after they had shared, one with another, in destruction, and had brayed [among themselves] the perfume of Menshim as a sign of their having leagued together against their enemy; i. e., after slaughter had come upon the last of their men, as upon the last of those who perfumed themselves with the perfume of Menshim: for [it is said that] mnXm is the name of a woman who sold perfume in Mekkeh, and a party bought of her some perfume, and leagued together to fight their enemy, making the dipping of their hands in that perfume to be a sign of their league; and they fought until they were slain to the last of them: whence the prov., OaXoOamu mino EiTori manoXima: (EM p. 117:) [so that, accord. to this explanation, which is one of many, mnXm is made perfectly decl. for the sake of the rhyme:] or the meaning is, † after they had manifested enmities and faults. (TA.) One says also, in cases of enmity, laOaduq-an-a XuEuwraka, meaning † I will assuredly manifest thy circumstances. (TA.)
duq-a, inf. n. daq-N and diq-N, He was seized with the malady termed diq- [i. e. hectic fever]. (MA.)

entry.sense: 2. dq-q, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoqiyqN, (Ṣ,) He bruised, brayed, or pounded, finely; he comminuted, or pulverized; syn. OanoEama Ald-aq-a. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) This is the primary signification. (TA.)
And hence, † [He made a minute examination.]
[And He spoke, or expressed himself, and] he proved a question, or a problem, in a subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure, manner. (El-Munáwee, TA.)
See also 4.

3. dAq- SaAHibahu AlHisaAba, inf. n. mudaAq-apN, ‡ [He was minute, observant of small things, nice, or scrupulous, with his companion in the reckoning; and so dAq-hu fiI AlHisaAbi;] (JK, Ḳ, TA;) he reckoned with his companion with minuteness: (TḲ:) it signifies an act between two. (TA.)
[And dAq-hu fiI AlOamori † He was minute,, &c., with him in the affair, or case.] AlmudaAq-apu fiI AlOamori signifies Alt-adaAq-u↓; (Ṣ;) which is an instance of tafaAEulN from Ald-iq-apu: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) you say, tadaAq-aA↓, meaning † They were minute,, &c., each with the other. (TḲ.) You say also, dAq- Aln-aZara fiI muEaAmalaAtihi wanafaqaAtihi [He examined minutely into his dealings and his expenses]. (TA in art. dnq.)
And [hence] mudaAq-apN, metonymically, signifies ‡ The being niggardly, stingy, or avaricious. (Az, TA in art. dnq.)

hom.sense: 4. Adq-hu He made, or rendered, it (a thing, Ṣ, M) daqiyq [i. e. thin, or slender,, &c.]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also dq-qhu↓. (Ṣ, M.)

And He gave him a small thing: (Ṣ, TA:) or he gave him little: (Ṣ in art. jl:) or ‡ he gave him a sheep, or goat; (M;) or sheep, or goats. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, Oatayotuhu famaA Oadaq-aniI walaA Oajal-aniI (Ṣ, M) I came to him, and he gave me not a small thing, nor gave he me a great thing: (Ṣ in the present art.:) or he gave me not little, nor gave he me much: (Ṣ in art. jl:) or he gave me not a sheep, or goat, nor gave he me a camel. (M.)
And Adq-t, said of the eye, It shed few tears; opposed to Ajl-t; as in the saying of El-Fak'asee cited in art. jl. (Ṣ * and TA voce Oajal-a, q. y.)
And Adq- † He pursued little, paltry, or mean, things. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6: see 3, in two places.

7. Andq- It (a thing, Ṣ, M, TA, such as medicine, &c., TA) was, or became, broken, (M, Ḳ, TA,) or crushed, (M,) in any manner: (M, TA:) or bruised, brayed, or pounded; i. e. beaten with a thing so that it was broken, or crushed: (M, Ḳ:*) quasi-pass. of daq-ahu. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
