10: see 1, first sentence, in two places. Astdq- nuHuwluhaA means Her thinness increased in thinness. (Ḥam p. 33.)

hom.sense: diq-N: see daqiyqN, in nine places.
Hence, Hum-aI Ald-iq-i [Hectic fever; so termed in the present day]; that is, from diq-N as signifying the contr. of galiyZN. (Ṣ.)
diq-N in measuring, relating to the thing measured, is The being broken, crushed, or bruised, in the measure, so as to become close, or compact. (TA.)
Also ‡ Niggardliness, stinginess, or avarice; the condition of him in whom is little, or no good. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: duq-apN Soft dust swept by the wind (Ṣ, Ḳ) from the ground: pl. duqaqN: (Ṣ:) or dust swept from the ground; as also duqaAqapN↓: (TA:) or duqaqu Alt-uraAbi signifies fine dust; and duq-apN is its sing.: (M:) or, accord. to IB, the sing. of duqaqN is duq-aI↓, like as the sing. of julalN is jul-aI. (TA.)

Also Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food, (IDrd, M, Ḳ,) bruised, or brayed, (M,) and what are mixed therewith; (IDrd;) such as are termed qazoH, and the like: all such seeds of the cooking-pot are called duq-ap by the people of Mekkeh: (IDrd, Ṣgh:) and salt with such seeds mixed therewith: (M, Ḳ:) this is the application now commonly obtaining: (TA:) or salt alone: (M:) or salt bruised, or brayed: (Lth, Ḳ:) whence the saying, maA lahu duq-apN He has not salt. (Lth, M, Ḳ.*)

And [hence,] ‡ Beauty, or prettiness: (M, Ḳ, TA:) whence the phrase AimoraOapN laA duq-apa lahaA, (M,) or qaliylapu Ald-uq-api, (Ḳ,) or maA lahaA duq-apN, (TA,) ‡ A woman who is not beautiful, or pretty; (M, Ḳ;*) who has not beauty, or prettiness. (TA.)
Also A certain ornament (HaloIN) of the people of Mekkeh. (Ḳ.)
And The small, or young, (HaXow,) of camels. (TA.)

diq-apN inf. n. of the intrans. verb daq-a [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [As a simple subst.,] The state, or condition, or quality, of that which is termed diq-N [and daqiyqN; properly and tropically: i. e., it signifies slenderness,, &c.]: and smallness, littleness, or the like; [properly and tropically;] contr. of EiZamN. (Ḳ.)
[Hence,] ‡ Littleness in estimation, paltriness, inconsiderableness, meanness, vileness, or contemptibleness. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And † Subtileness, niceness, abstruseness, reconditeness, or obscureness.]
daqaqapN [pl. of daAq-N↓, agreeably with analogy,] Persons who manifest, or reveal, the faults, or vices, of the Muslims. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
See also madoquwqN [with which it is sometimes syn.]:
and see daqiyqN.
diqaAqN: see the next preceding paragraph.
daquwqN A certain medicine (JK, M, Ḳ) for the eye, (JK, Ḳ,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, (JK, M, Ḳ,) and then sprinkled (JK, M) therein. (JK.)

hom.sense: daqiyqN contr. of galiyZN (JK,* Ṣ, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ) and jaliylN; (Mṣb;) as also duqaAqN↓ and diq-N↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the last contr. of jil-N: (JK, Ṣ, M:) [i. e. Slender, or small in diameter or circumference as compared with length: also small in all dimensions; small in size; minute, or fine, either as a whole, or in its component particles: and sometimes, as applied to a garment or the like, thin, or fine, as opposed to thick or coarse; like raqiyqN: but properly,] daqiyqN differs from raqiyqN; the former signifying the contr. of galiyZN [as stated above], and the latter, the contr. of vaxiynN: therefore one says HasFA raqiyqN and HasFA vaxiynN [“thin soup” and “thick soup”], but not HasFA daqiyqN; and one says sayofN daqiyqu AlmaDoribi [a sword thin in the edge, or in the part next the point]; and rumoHN daqiyqN [a slender spear]; and guSonN daqiyqN [a slender branch]; and HabolN daqiyqN [a slender rope]: (IB, TA:) pl. [of mult. diqaAqN and of pauc.] Oadiq-apN. (Mṣb.) One says, maA lahu diq-N↓ walaA jil-N [He has neither slender, or small, or fine, nor thick, or great, or coarse]; i. e. daqiyqN walaA jaliylN. (Ṣ in art. jl.) And Oaxacotu diq-ahu↓ wajil-ahu [I took the slender,, &c., thereof, and the thick,, &c., thereof]; like as one says, Axct qaliylahu wakaviyrahu. (Ṣ in the present art.) And it is said in a trad., Aall-ehum-a QgofiroliI canobiI kul-ahu diq-ahu↓ wajil-ahu [O God, forgive me all my sin, the small thereof and the great thereof]. (TA.) XajarN diq-N↓ means Shrubs, bushes, or small trees: (M:) opposed to XajarN jil-N. (Lth in art. jl, and Mgh in art. bql.) Accord. to AḤn, diq-N↓ signifies Plants that are slender and soft to the camels, so that the weak of the camels, and the young, and such as has its teeth worn down to the sockets, and the sick, eat them: or, as some say, their small leaves: (M:) or slender and long leaves of the OaraAk: and grain trodden out but not winnowed: pl. OadoqaAqN. (JK.) And Hulalu diq-K↓ means Thin, or fine, [garments, or dresses, of the kind called] Hulal; opposed to Hulalu jil-K: (Mgh:) or diq-N↓ signifies the contr. of jil-N as applied to carpets, and to the garments called Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMC] and the like, and to the [cloth called] Hilos, and to the mat and the like. (TA in art. jal.)

[Hence,] daqiyqN is also applied to a thing, an affair, or a case, as meaning † Little in estimation, paltry, inconsiderable, mean, vile, or contemptible; in this case, contr. of jaliylN: (IB, TA:) and means also ‡ niggardly, stingy, or avaricious; (M, TA;) in whom is little, or no, good; (M, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] Oadiq-apN and [of mult.] diqaAqN and Oadiq-aMCu. (TA.)

Also, applied to a thing, an affair, or a case, † Subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure: (M, Ḳ, TA:) [applied likewise to speech; and so diq-N↓:] you say, jaMCa bikalaAmK diq-K and daqiyqK ‡ [He uttered subtile, nice, abstruse, recondite, or obscure, speech]. (TA.)

[The fem.] dqyqp↓ [used as a subst.] signifies ‡ Small cattle; i. e. sheep or goats; opposed to jaliylapN (JK, Ḳ, TA) which signifies camels: (JK, TA:) pl. daqaAYiqu. (TA.) You say, maA lahu daqiyqapN walaA jaliylapN ‡ He has neither sheep, or goats, nor camels: (TA:) or neither a sheep, or goat, nor a she-camel. (M.) And kamo daqiyqatuka ‡ How many are thy sheep, or goats? (TA.) And huwa raAEiI Ald-aqaAYiqi ‡ He is the pastor of sheep, or goats. (TA.) And OaEoTaAhu mino daqaAYiqi AlmaAli ‡ [He gave him of the small cattle]. (TA.)

Also, [i. e. daqiyqapN↓,] as a conventional term of the astronomer, † [A minute of a circle;] the sixtieth [in the O, and in some copies, app. most, of the Ḳ, erroneously, “thirtieth,” as remarked by MF and SM and others,] part of a darajap [or degree of a circle: pl. daqaAYiqu, as above]. (Ḳ, TA.)
[↓And † A minute of time; the fourth part of a darajap (or degree) of time: pl. as above.]
[daqiyqapN↓ is also sing. of daqaAYiqu as syn. with madaAq-N, q. v.]
daqiyqN signifies also Flour, or meal, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) of wheat, &c.; (Mṣb;) [thus used as a subst.; as though] in the sense of madoquwqN. (Mṣb, TA.)

[Hence, Farina,] You say, jaraI Ald-aqiyqu fiI Als-unobuli [The farina pervaded the ears of wheat]. (L in art. qmH.) And Hamala Ald-aqiyqa [It bore farina] is said of seed-produce [or corn]. (TA in art. Hnq. [See 4 in that art.])

entry.sense: duqaAqapN: see duq-apN: and duqaAqN.
daquwqapN Bulls, or cows, and asses, that tread, or thrash, wheat or grain. (JK, M, Ḳ.)
daqiyqapN: see daqiyqN, in four places, in the latter part of the paragraph.
daqiyqiI-N, (M, L, TA,) or daq-aAqN↓, (O, Ḳ,) but the latter is disallowed by Sb, (M, L,) A seller of daqiyq, i. e. flour, or meal. (M, O, L, Ḳ, TA.)
duq-aI: see duq-apN.
daq-aAqN One who breaks [or crushes] much, in any manner; or who bruises, brays, or pounds, much. (TA.)
See also daqiyqiI-N.
daq-aAqapN [in the CK, erroneously, daqaAqap,] A thing with which one breaks or crushes, or bruises, brays, or pounds, rice (Ibn-ʼAbbád, M, Ḳ) and the like. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

daqodaqapN an onomatopœia, (Ṣ, M,) The sounds of the hoofs of horses or similar beasts, (JK, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) with quick reiteration; like TaqoTaqapN. (Ṣ, TA.) And The cries, shouts, noises, or clamour, or the confusion of cries, &c., of men. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
daqodaAqN Small gibbous tracts of sand heaped up. (El-Mufaddal, Ḳ.)
daAq-N: see daqaqapN.
Oadaq-u [More, and most, daqiyq, i. e. slender,, &c. See an ex. in a prov. cited voce xayoTN].
madaq-u [A place of breaking or crushing, or of bruising, braying, or pounding]. [Hence,] madaq-u AlHawaAfiri The place of falling of the hoofs of horses or the like [upon the ground]. (Ḥam p. 679.)
muduq-N: see what next follows, in two places.

midaq-N and midaq-apN↓ and muduq-N↓, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the last extr. (Mṣb, Ḳ) with respect to rule, (Mṣb,) one of the instances of an instrumental noun of the measure mufoEulN, (Ṣ, TA,) like munoxulN, (Az, TA,) said by Sb to be of this form because it is a subst. like julomuwdN, (M,) A thing with which one breaks (Ṣ,* M, Mgh,* Ḳ) or crushes in any manner, (M,) or with which one bruises, brays, or pounds, i. e. beats so as to break or crush, (Ṣ,* M, Mgh,* Ḳ,) a thing, (M,) in a general sense: (Mgh:) [signifying also] the thing with which qumaAX [or cloth of any kind] &c. are beaten: (Mṣb:) [also, the first, the wooden implement called minodaf, by means of which, and a bow, cotton is separated and loosened: and the second, the implement with which corn is thrashed; as mentioned by Golius on the authority of El-Meydánee:] but the particular terms for the thing used by the qaS-aAr [or whitener of cloth, for beating it, in washing,] are kuciynaqN and bayozarN and miyjanapN: (Mgh:) Az says that muduq-N↓, with damm to the m [and d], signifies a stone with which perfume is bruised: [and in like manner it is said in the Ṣ, in one place, to mean the midowak of the seller of perfumes:] but when it is made an epithet, it is restored to the measure mifoEalN [so that you say midaq-N]: (TA:) the pl. is madaAq-u: and the dim. is mudiyuq-N↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence,] HaAfirN mudaq-N A solid hoof that breaks, crushes, or bruises, things. (M, TA.)
Also, midaq-N, † Strong; (M, TA;) applied to a man. (TA.)
midaq-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
mudaq-aqapN, meaning A kind of food, [a ball of minced meat, &c., so called in the present day,] is post-classical. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: Also Seized with the malady termed diq- [i. e. hectic fever]. (MA.)

entry.sense: madaAq-u [a pl. of which the sing is not mentioned and app. is not used]. You say, yatatab-aEuwna madaAq-a AlOumuwri [and daqaAYiqa↓ AlOumuwri † They pursue, or investigate, or they seek successively, time after time, or repeatedly, or in a leisurely manner, gradually, step by step, or one thing after another, to obtain a knowledge of,] the subtilties, niceties, abstrusities, or obscurities, of things, affairs, or cases. (TA.) [And † They pursue,, &c., the minutiæ of things, affairs, or cases: or small, or little, things, &c.; for in the phrase tatab-aEa madaAq-a AlOumuwri (in the Ṣ in art. sf), mdAq- AlAmwr signifies, accord. to the PṢ, small, or little, things, &c.] And you say, Oasaf-a UilaI madaAq-i Alkasobi † [He pursued small means of gain]. (TA in art. dqE.) And Oasaf-a UilaI madaAq-i AlOumuwri waOalaAYimihaA [lit. † He pursued small, or little, things, and the meanest, or most ignoble, thereof]; meaning he became mean, or ignoble. (M in art. sf.)
mudayoqN: see mdaq-N, near the end of the paragraph.

musotadaq-N The slender, or thin, part of anything. (M, TA.) And [hence,] The fore part of the saAEid [or fore arm], next the wrist. (M, Ḳ.) [And The lower part of the saAq, or shank, next the ankle.]

diqoraArN and diqoraArapN↓ A kind of short drawers, without legs, covering only that portion of the wearer which decency requires to be concealed; (TA;) i. q. tub-aAnu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) also the latter, trowsers of the ordinary kind; syn. saraAwiylu; and so duqoruwrN↓ and duqoruwrapN↓: pl. daqaAriyru.
duqoruwrN and duqoruwrapN: see above; and the latter, in what follows.

hom.sense: diqoraArapN: see diqoraArN.
Also, A short man: (Ḳ:) as though likened to the short drawers above mentioned: (TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
Also A calamity; a misfortune: pl. as above. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And An alominable lie: (TA:) foul language: calumny; slander: (Ḳ:) forgery of tales. (TA.) You say fulaAnN yafotariI Ald-aqaAriyra Such a one forges lies, (Ṣ,) or abominable lies, (TA,) and foul language. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also Contrariety; opposition; and so duqoruwrapN↓: and contention, or altercation, (Ḳ, TA,) that wearies one: (TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)

And An evil, or a bad, habit: pl. as above. (Ḳ.) It is related in a trad. of ʼOmar, that he said to his freedman Aslam, who was a Bejáwee slave, Oaxacatoka diqoraArapN Oaholika The evil habit of thy family, or people, which was deviation from the truth, and acting falsely, hath come upon thee. (TA.)
Also A calumniator; a slanderer: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as though meaning cuw diqoraArapi, i. e., cuw namiymapK: (TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 1. daqiEa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadoqaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. daqaEN, (Mṣb,) He (a man, Ṣ) clave to the dust, or earth, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) by reason of abasement, or abjectness; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or, as some say, by reason of poverty: or he clave to the dust, or earth, and became poor; as also AdqE↓: or he clave to the dust, or earth, or some other thing, by reason of anything whatever: (TA:) and he became lowly, humble, or submissive, and clave to the dust, or earth. (Ṣ, TA.) It is said in a trad. [cited voce xajila], UicaA juEotun-a daqiEotun-a When ye [women] are hungry, ye become lowly, humble, or submissive, and cleave to the dust, or earth; (Ṣ, TA;) or ye bear poverty ill. (TA in art. xjl.)
He was, or became, grieved, unhappy, or disquieted in mind; as also daqaEa, inf. n. daqoEN and duquwEN; and lowly, humble, submissive, or abased. (TA.)
He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, in seeking, or requesting, an object of want, and desired it vehemently. (TA.)
He was, or became, content with mean sustenance. (Ḳ; but only the inf. n., namely daqaEa, of the verb in this sense, is there mentioned.)

[And, as shown above,] He bore poverty ill. (Ṣ, Ḳ; but only the inf. n., as above, is mentioned in them.) [Thus the verb bears two contr. meanings.] El-Kumeyt says,
walamo yadoqaEuwA Einoda maA naAbahumo
liSarofi zamaAnK walamo yaxojaluwA
i. e. They did not bear poverty ill [on the occasion of what befell them by reason of a changing of fortune], nor did they bear richness ill: or, as some say, they did not cleave to the ground in consequence of poverty and hunger,, &c., nor did they become lazy, or indolent, and remiss, in seeking subsistence. (TA.)
He (a young camel) turned away with disgust from the milk; was averse from it; loathed, or nauseated, it; syn. baXima Eani All-abani. (Ḳ.)
daqaEa, inf. n. daqoEN, [mentioned above,] also signifies He pursued small means of gain; as also AdqE↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AdqE: see 1; first and last sentences.
AdqE lahu, and Uilayohi, He acted exorbitantly towards him in reviling, &c., [as though he debased himself to him,] not shunning, or preserving himself from, foul speech. (AZ.)

AdqEhu, inf. n. UidoqaAEN, He caused him to cleave to the dust, or earth; meaning he abased him, or rendered him object. (KL; but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.) And AdqEhu Alfaqoru Poverty caused him to cleave to the dust, or earth. (Ḥar p. 33.) [See the act. part. n., below.]

entry.sense: Q. Q. 1. danoqaEa He (a man) was, or became, poor, or needy: the n being augmentative. (TA.)

daqiEN [part. n. of daqiEa; Cleaving to the dust, or ground,, &c.:] grieved, unhappy, or disquieted in mind; as also daAqiEN↓; and lowly, humble, submissive, or abased: (TA:) and mudoqiEN↓ [is syn. with daqiEN as signifying] cleaving to the dust, or earth, and in a state of poverty: (TA:) [the pl. of daqiEN is daqoEaI; like as wajoEaI is pl. of wajiEN, and haromaI of harimN.] You say, raOayotu Alqawoma SaqoEaI daqoEaI [I saw the people, or company of men, struck by a thunderbolt, or struck by the enemy as with a thunderbolt,] cleaving to the ground. (TA.)
Al-adoqaELACu: see OadoqaEu.
Ald-iqoEimu: see OadoqaEu.
Ald-aqaAEu: see OadoqaEu.
Ald-uqaAEu: see OadoqaEu.
daquwEu Alyadayoni A camel that throws forth his fore legs, and scrapes the dust, or earth, (Ḳ, TA,) when he goes the pace, or at the rate, or in the manner, termed xabab. (TA.)
daAqiEN: see daqiEN.

Content with what is mean, or vile; as also midoqaAEN↓: and both signify one who cares not for whatever has fallen into food or beverage or any other thing: or, as some say, who pursues mean, or vile, things: (TA:) or the former signifies one who seeks, or pursues, small means of gain. (Ṣ, TA.)

dawoqaEapN Poverty: and abasement, or abjectness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and calamity. (TA.) You say, in imprecating, ramaAhu Qll-ehu biAld-awoqaEapi [May God afflict him with poverty:, &c.]: (Ṣ:) or rmAh Qll-eh fiI Ald-awoqaEapi [may God cast him into poverty:, &c.]. (TA.)
dayoquwEN: see OadoqaEu.
OadoqaEu Vehement hunger; (ISh, Ḳ;) as also dayoquwEN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
curapN daqoEaMCu [fem. of OadoqaEu] Bad [millet]: (IDrd, Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd.)
OaroDN daqoEaMCu Land having in it no plants, or herbage. (Ḳ.)

Ald-aqoEaMCu↓, [used as a subst.,] (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Ald-iqoEimu↓, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the m is augmentative, as it is in dirodimN syn. with darodaMCu, (Ṣ,) and AlOadoqaEu, and Ald-aqaAEu↓, and Ald-aqaAEu↓, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) The dust, or earth: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the fine dust or earth upon the face of the ground. (TA.) One says, in imprecating, bifiyhi Ald-aqaEaMCu, and Ald-iqoEimu, and AlOadoqaEu, May the dust, or earth, be in his mouth. (Lḥ.)

hom.sense: mudoqiEN: see daqiEN.
Fleeing: hastening, or going quickly. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Lean, or emaciated, in the utmost degree. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Causing to cleave to the dust, or earth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied in this sense to poverty. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: mudaq-aEN: see mudaf-aEN.
midoqaAEN: see daAqiEN.
Vehemently, or excessively, desirous; eager; or covetous: (Ḳ:) pl. madaAqiyEu. (TA.)
UibilN madaAqiyEu Camels that eat the herbage until they make it to cleave to the ground by reason of its paucity. (Ṣ.)
4. Adql Aln-axolu, (inf. n. UidoqaAlN, TA,) The palmtrees produced dates such as are termed daqal: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the dates of the palm-trees became daqal. (Es-Sarakustee, Mṣb.)
Adqlt AlX-aApu The sheep, or goat, was, or became, lean, or emaciated, and small in body; despised and little in the eyes of beholders. (Ḳ.)
daqolN Weakness of the body (IAạr, Ḳ) of a man. (IAạr, TA.)

daqalN [A certain kind of palm-trees;] i. q. xiSaAbN [not as meaning “palm-trees having much fruit,” but as an appellation applied by the people of El-Bahreyn to the palm-trees which others call daqalN: see art. xSb]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) in the Ḳ, AlxiDaAbu is erroneously put for AlxiSaAbu: (TA:) n. un. with p {daqalapN}: (Ṣ:) Az says that daqalN signifies species (OalowaAnN, of which the sing. is lawonN, [but here meaning varieties,]) of palm-trees; and the dates thereof are bad, though the daqalap may be abundant in fruit; and some have red dates, and some have black; the body of the dates being small, and the stones being large: (TA:) accord. to AḤn, the term daqalN is applied to any palmtrees [of which the varieties are] unknown: the n. un. daqalapN is syn. with xaSobapN, of which the pl. is xiSaAbN: and what are termed OadoqaAlN [pl. of daqalN] are the worst of palm-trees, and their dates are the worst of dates. (O, TA.)

Also [The fruit of the trees thus called; described above;] the worst of dates: (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a bad kind of dates: (Mgh:) or dates of which the kinds are unknown: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to Es-Sarakustee, the fruit of the dawom: n. un. with p {daqalapN}. (Mṣb.) A rájiz says,
lawo kunotumu tamorFA lakunotumu daqalaA
Oawo kunotumu maMCF lakunotumu w XalaA
[If ye were dates, ye would be dates of the worst kind; and if ye were water, ye would be such as distils scantily, in interrupted drops, from a mountain or rock]. (TA.)

Also The mast (sahom) of a ship; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) from the same word in the first of the senses explained above; (Ṣ;) in Pers., tiyri kiXotiI, (MA, PṢ,) and sutuwno; (MA;) i. e., (or so daqalapN [the n. un.], JK,) the tall piece of wood of a ship, (JK, T, M, Mgh,) fixed in the midst thereof, (JK, T, M,) for the sail, (JK,) i. e., upon which the sail is extended, (T,) or [rather] to which the sail is suspended; (Mgh;) as also dawoqalN↓. (Ḳ.)
daqalapN n. un. of daqalN [which see throughout]. (T, Ṣ, &c.)

XaApN daqalapN and daqilapN↓ and daqiylapN↓ and mudoqilN↓ A sheep, or goat, lean, or emaciated, and small in body; despised and little in the eyes of beholders: pl., of any but the last, diqaAlN: (Ḳ:) or, as ISd thinks, the pl., of daqiylapN is daqaAYilu, unless it be formed by the rejection of the augmentative letter [in the sing.]. (TA.)
daqilapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
daqiylapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
dawoqalN: see daqalN, last sentence.
mudoqilN: see daqalapN.

1. dak-a, aor. _u {yadokuku}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. dak-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He broke, or crushed, in any manner; or bruised, brayed, or pounded; i. e., beat with a thing so as to break or crush; i. q. daq-a. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) He threw down, pulled to pieces, or demolished. (Ḳ.) He broke a wall, and a mountain. (Lth, TA.) He beat a thing and broke it so as to lay it even with the ground. (Ṣ.) Hence the saying in the Ḳur [lxix. 14], faduk-ataA dak-apF waAHidapF, (Ṣ,) i. e. And they shall be beaten together with one beating, and the whole shall become fine dust: or they shall both be spread with one spreading, so as to become an even ground. (Bḍ.) [For] dak-a AlOaroDa, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ, TA,) means He made even the elevations and depressions of the earth, or ground. (Ḳ, TA.) OacaA duk-ati AlOaroDu dak-FA, in the Ḳur [lxxxix. 22], means When the earth shall be made level, without hills, (Ibn-ʼArafeh, Bḍ,) and without mountains: or it means, shall become fine dust scattered: (Bḍ:) or shall be shaken so that every building thereon shall be demolished and non-existent. (Jel.) See also dak-N below.

dak-N also signifies The spreading (kabos [for which kanos is erroneously put in the CK]) of earth, and making it even. (Ḳ.) When a roof, or flat house-top, has been spread with earth (kubisa biAlt-uraAbi), one says, duk-a Alt-uraAbu Ealayohi [Earth was spread upon it]: and dak-a Alt-uraAba EalaI Almay-iti, inf. n. dak-N, means He poured earth upon the corpse. (AZ, AḤn.)

Also The filling up a well (Ḳ, TA) with earth; and so dakodakapN↓. (TA.) You say, dakakotu Alr-akiI-a I filled up the wells with earth: (Ṣ:) and dakodaka↓ Alr-akiI-a He filled up the wells with earth. (TA.)
And dak-ahu signifies also He pushed him, or thrust him; like Sak-ahu and lak-ahu. (Aṣ, TA.)

[Hence,] dak-a jaAriyatahu ‡ He (a man) distressed his young woman, or female slave, by throwing his weight upon her when desiring to compress her. (AA, TA. [See also rak-a.])
And dak-a Ald-aAb-apa biAls-ayori ‡ He distressed, or jaded, or fatigued, the beast by journeying. (TA.) And duk-a Alr-ajulu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. dak-atohu AlHum-aI, (AZ, Ṣ,) or dak-ahu AlmaraDu, (Ḳ,) meaning ‡ Fever, or disease, weakened the man: (TA:) or he became sick, or ill. (Ḳ.)
And dak-N also signifies The sending forth camels all together. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
2. dk-khu He mixed it; namely, colocynth with dates or some other thing. (O, L, Ḳ.) You say, dak-ikuwA lanaA Mix ye for us. (L, O.) [See mudak-akN.]

6. tdAk- Ealayohi Alqawomu The people pressed, or crowded, upon him. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of ʼAlee, vum-a tadaAkakotumo EalaI-a tadaAkuka AlUibili Alhiymi EalaI HiyaADihaA, i. e. Then ye pressed [upon me like the pressing of thirsty camels upon their wateringtroughs]. (TA.) And one says, tadaAk-ato Ealayohimu Alxayolu The horses, or horsemen, pressed upon them. (TA.)
7. Andk- It (a place) became levelled, its elevations and depressions being made even. (Ḳ.)
It (a camel's hump) became spread upon the animal's sides, (TA,) or upon his back. (IDrd, TA.)
It (sand) became compact. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. dakodaka, inf. n. dakodakapN: see 1, in two places.
One says of the stallion-camel when he covers, yudakodiku Aln-aAqapa [app. meaning He distresses the she-camel by his weight: see dak-a AljaAriyatahu, above]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
R. Q. 2. tadakodakavi AljibaAlu The mountains became dak-aAwaAt, i. e. hills of mould or clay. (Ṣ.)

dak-N An even, or a level, place; (Ḳ;) [and so Oadak-u↓, as is shown by an explanation of its fem. in this paragraph:] or land, or ground, broken, and made even: (Ṣ:) you say OaroDN dak-N: (Akh, Ṣ:) pl. dukuwkN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [vii. 139 and xviii. 98], jaEalahu dak-FA, (Akh, Ṣ, TA,) i. e. [He made it, in the former instance, and shall make it, in the latter instance,] even, or level, (AZ, Az, Ibn-ʼArafeh,) without any hill: (Ibn-ʼArafeh: [this addition relating to the former instance:]) or crumbled: (Ksh,* Bḍ:) or, accord. to Akh, dak-FA may be here an inf. n.; as though the meaning were dak-ahu dak-FA↓: [see 1:] or it may be elliptical, meaning jaEalahu caA dak-K: another reading is jaEalahu dak-aMCa↓, (Ṣ,) meaning in the former instance a hill rising from the ground like the dak-apa: (Ksh:) or meaning jaEalahu OaroDFA dak-aMCa, (Ṣ,) i. e. He made it even, or level, ground; (Ksh, Bḍ;) because the word jabal [to which dk-MC virtually relates] is masc. (Ṣ.)
And A [mound, or hill, of dust or earth, such as is called] tal-: (Ḳ:) or the like of a tal-: (L:) in some of the copies of the Ḳ, Altk- is erroneously put for Alt-l. (TA.)

hom.sense: duk-N A low mountain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or an elevated, or overlooking, hill of mould, or clay, in which is somewhat of ruggedness: (Aṣ, TA:) pl. dikakapN; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and dikakN [app. another, though irregular, pl. of the same,] is said to signify qiyraAn [i. e. small isolated mountains, or knolls of mountains,, &c., (see qaArapN,)] breaking, or crumbling, down: or disintegrated [hills, or mountains, such as are called] hiDaAb. (TA.)
[See also Oadak-u, of which it is a pl.]
Also Strong and bulky. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dak-apN A certain thing, (Ṣ,) [i. e.] an elevated place, (Mṣb,) a flat-topped structure, (Ḳ,) upon which one sits; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. q. masoTabapN [a kind of wide bench, of stone or brick, &c., generally built against a wall]: (Mṣb:) pronounced by the vulgar dik-apN↓ [and commonly applied by them to a long seat of wood]: (TA:) and duk-aAnN↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but accord. to some, this belongs to art. dkn [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) the pl. of the former is dikakN, like as the pl. of qaSoEapN is qiSaEN: (Mṣb:) and the pl. of duk-aAnN↓ is dakaAkiynu. (TA.) [For another modern application, see maHofilN.]
See also dak-N.
dik-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
[It is also vulgarly used for tik-apN, q. v.]
dakakN The state of having no hump, or no prominence of the hump, in a camel. (Ḳ.) [See Oadak-u.]
dukukN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] She-camels having their humps broken, bruised, or crushed. (TA.)
dukakapN A thing [meaning food] made of habiyd [i. e. colocynths, or colocynth-seeds,] and flour, when flour is scarce. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.) [See also mud-akakN.]
dakiykN, applied to a year, (Ṣ, TA,) and a month, (TA,) and a day, (Ḳ,) Complete. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

dak-aMCu, fem. of Oadak-u [q. v.], used as a subst., (TA,) A hill of mould or clay, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) not rugged, (Aṣ, M, Ḳ,) nor amounting to a mountain: (TA:) or the pl. signifies natural [mounds, or hills, of dust or earth, such as are called] tilaAl: (TA:) the pl. is dak-aAwaAtN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) because it is used as a subst.: (TA:) or it has no sing.: (Ḳ:) ISd says, this is what the lexicologists say; but in my opinion the sing. is dak-aMCu. (TA.)
duk-aAnN: see dak-apN, in two places: and see also art. dkn.
dakodakN and dikodikN: see what next follows.

dakodaAkN (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ) and dakodakN↓ and dikodikN↓ (Ḳ) Sand that is compact, and cleaving to the ground, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) not elevated, (Ṣ,) or not much elevated: (Aṣ, TA:) or sand containing dust or earth, compacted together: (AḤn, TA:) or sand pressed, and even, or level: or land in which is ruggedness: (Ḳ:) or a low, or depressed, and even, or level, tract of land: (TA:) n. un. of the first [and app. of each of the others] with p {dakodaAkapN}: (ISh, T in art. rbw:) pl. dakaAdiyku and dakaAdiku. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Oadak-u, and its fem. dak-aMCu: see dak-N. You say also OakamapN dak-aMCu, meaning A hill wide [and app. flat, or nearly so,] in its top: (TA:) or an expanded hill: (Mṣb:) pl. dak-aAwaAtN, which is extr. in this case, because dk-MC is here an epithet. (TA.) And duk-N, [its regular pl.,] applied to sands, Even and compact. (AḤn, M in art. clf.)

[Hence,] A horse contracted [in make] and broad in the back; (Ṣ;) or a horse broad in the back, (Ks, AʼObeyd, Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) and short (Ks, AʼObeyd, Mgh, TA) therein; (TA;) of the sort called baraAciyn; (AʼObeyd, TA:) pl. duk-N. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.)

And the fem. signifies A she-camel having no hump: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or whose hump is not prominent, (Ḳ, TA,) but spreading upon her sides: (TA:) pl. duk-N and dak-aAwaAtN, (Ṣ,) said in the Ṣ to be like HumorN and HamoraAwaAtN, but one does not say HamoraAwaAtN, like as one does not say OaHomaruwna: (IB:) and in like manner the masc. is applied to a he-camel: (Ḳ:) or dak-aMCu [in the sense here explained] has no masc., and therefore it is allowable to say dak-aAwaAtN. (IB.)

hom.sense: midakN ‡ A strong man, that treads the ground vehemently: (Ṣ, TA:) or strong to work; (Ḳ;) and the fem., with p {midakapN}, is applied in this latter sense to a female slave. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also a dial. var. [now vulgarly used] of mitak-N [q. v.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: HanoZalN madak-akN Colocynth eaten with dates or other things. (Ḳ.) [See also dukakapN.]
madokuwkN [Broken, crushed, or bruised,, &c.: see its verb, 1].
OaroDN madokuwkapN Land having no OasonaAd [or elevations (in the CK, erroneously, AisonaAd)], producing [the shrub called] rimov. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
madokuwkN applied to a horse, Having no prominence of his Hajabap [or crest of the hip or haunch]; (Ḳ;) and so madoluwkN. (Ḳ in art. dlk.)
Applied to a man, Weakened by fever, (Ṣ,* TA,) or by disease: or sick, or ill. (TA.)
See also what follows.

OaroDN mudakodakapN i. q. madoEuwkapN, (Ḳ, TA,) meaning Land in which are many people, and pastors of camels or cattle, so that it is marred thereby, and abounds with the traces and urine of the cattle, and they dislike it, except when it collects them after a cloud [has rained upon it] and they cannot avoid it; as also madokuwkapN↓. (TA.)
dikorN and dukorN: see cikorN.

hom.sense: 1. dakana AlmataAEa, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadokunu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dakonN; (TA;) and dk-nhu↓; (Ḳ;) He put the goods, household-goods, or furniture and utensils, one upon another. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) [In the TA, this is said to be tropical: if so, it seems that the proper signification is, He made the goods,, &c., like a duk-aAn, or bench upon which one sits: see 2.]

, dakina, aor. _a {yadokanu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dakanN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) It (a thing, TA, or a garment, Ṣ, or a horse, Mṣb) was, or became, of a blackish colour; of a colour inclining to blackness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of a colour inclining to that of dust; [or brown; i. e.] of a colour between redness and blackness: (Mṣb, TA:) and Aid-akana↓ [originally Aidotakana] signifies the same as dkn [app. dakina]. (TA.) And dakina said of a garment, It became dirty and dust-coloured. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. dk-n Ald-uk-aAna He made [or constructed] the duk-aAn. (TA.)
See also 1.
8: see 1.
dakonN and dakanN: see what next follows.

dukonapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and dakonnN↓ and dakanN↓ [which last is the inf. n. of dakina] (TA) A blackish colour; a colour inclining to blackness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a colour inclining to that of dust; [or brownness; i. e.] a colour between redness and blackness. (TA.)
dukayonaMCu [dim. of dakonaMCu fem. of Oadokanu] A certain small reptile (duw-ayob-apN), of such as are termed OaHonaAX. (Ḳ.)

duk-aAnN A shop; [generally a small chamber, with an open front, along which extends a wide bench of stone or brick;] syn. HaAnuwtN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and a dik-ap [or kind of wide bench, of stone or brick, &c., generally built against a wall], (Mṣb, TA,) upon which one sits, (Mṣb,) [i. e.] constructed for the purpose of sitting upon it: (TA:) and the like of which is built against a leaning palm-tree, to support it: (Aṣ, AḤát, Mṣb:) if used as syn. with HaAnuwtN, it is masc. and fem.: (Mṣb:) En-Näwawee affirms it to be masc.: (TA:) accord. to some, (Mṣb,) a Persian word, [originally dukaAno,] (Ṣ,) arabicized; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and if so, the n is a radical letter: (MF, TA:) IḲṭṭ and several others say that the n is a radical, and that the word is derived from the verb first mentioned above: but Es-Sarakustee says that the n is augmentative accord. to Sb, and in like manner says Akh; and that the word is from the phrase OakamapN dk-aMCu meaning “an expanded hill:” (Mṣb:) the pl. is dakaAkiynu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Oadokanu A thing, (Ṣ, TA,) [or a garment, (see 1,)] or a horse, (Mṣb,) of a blackish colour; of a colour inclining to blackness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of a colour inclining to that of dust; [or brown; i. e.] of a colour between redness and blackness: (Mṣb, TA:) and a garment dirty and dust-coloured: (TA:) fem. dakonaMCu; (Mṣb, TA;) applied also to a serpent: pl. dukonN, applied also to clouds. (TA.) In the following verse, Lebeed applies it as meaning A wine-skin that has become in good condition in respect of its colour and odour by reason of its oldness; (Ṣ;) or a blackish, or black, wine-skin: (EM p. 169:)
OugoliI Als-ibaMCa bikul-i Oadokana EaAtiqK
Oawo jawonapK qudiHato wafuD-a xitaAmuhaA : (Ṣ, EM:) i. e. I buy wine at a high price, together with every blackish, or black, old, wineskin, or wine-jar smeared with pitch, from which one has ladled out, the sealed clay upon its mouth having been broken. (EM.)

variydapN dakonaMCu [A mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth] having a large quantity of seeds with which it is seasoned: (Ḳ:) [app. because of its colour: but SM says,] as though the said seeds were put one upon another on it. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. dal-a, aor. yadul-u, He, or it, directed; directed aright; guided; or caused to take, or follow, a right way or course or direction. (IAạr, T.) And dul-a He (a man) was directed, directed aright, guided,, &c. (IAạr, T.) You say, dal-ahu Ealayohi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. dal-N, (M,) or duluwlapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and dilaAlapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [but this is afterwards said in the M to be a simple subst., as it is also in the Mṣb, and so is duluwlapN in the M,] and dalaAlapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is of higher authority than dilaAlapN, (Ṣ,) and dulaAlapN, (Ḳ,) and [perhaps] dal-iylaI, [which see below, voce dilaAlapN,] (Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (M,) He directed him, or rightly directed him, or guided him, to it; (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ;) namely, the way, (Ṣ,) or a thing: (M:) or he showed him it; namely, the way. (TA.) And dal-ahu AlT-ariyqa [He directed him to the way; or showed him the way]. (TA.) And dal-a AlX-aIoCa, and Uilayohi [or Ealayohi], aor. as above, inf. n. duluwlapN, [He indicated the thing, by a word, &c.,] said of a man; as also Adl-↓ [i. e. Adl- AlX-aIoCa, &c.]. (Mṣb.) You say also, of a word, yadul-u EalaI kacaA [It denotes, or signifies, such a thing]. (The lexicons passim.)

Accord. to Sh, you say, dalilotu bihecaA AlT-ariyqi, [aor. Oadal-u,] inf. n. dalaAlapN, i. e. I knew this way; and dalalotu bihi, aor. Oadil-u, inf. n. dalaAlapN: accord. to AZ, you say, Aid-alalotu↓ biAlT-ariyqi, inf. n. Aid-ilaAlN, [I was, or became, directed, or rightly directed, or guided, in the way:] and [Az says,] I heard an Arab of the desert say to another, OamaA tanodal-u↓ AlT-ariyqi EalaI [meaning Wilt thou not be directed, or rightly directed, to the way?]: (T:) [for] Andl-↓ signifies he was, or became, directed, or rightly directed, (M, Ḳ, TA,) to the way: (TA:) and IAạr cites as an ex., (T,)
maA laka yaA OaHomaqu laAtanodal-u
wakayofa yanodal-u QmoruWN Eivowal-u
[What aileth thee, O stupid, that thou wilt not be rightly directed? but how shall the dull and slack be rightly directed?]. (T, M, TA: but in the M, yA fulaAnu; and in the TA, yA OaEowaru.) And sometimes Astdl-↓ is quasi-pass. of dal-ahu AlT-ariyqa [explained above: see 10 below]. (TA.)

dal-ato, [sec. pers. dalaloti,] aor. tadil-u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dal-N; (Ṣ,* M,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) and dal-ato of the class of taEiba, [sec. pers. daliloti, aor. tadal-u,] (Mṣb, MF, TA,) inf. n. dalalN; (Mṣb;) and tdl-lt↓; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) She (a woman) behaved in an amorous manner, or used amorous gesture or behaviour, with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition; (Ṣ;) she behaved with boldness (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) towards her husband, (M, Ḳ,) and with amorous gesture or behaviour, and coquettishness, feigning opposition: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [and dal-ato also signifies she talked and jested in a pleasing manner, displaying a pleasant mien or guise: and in like manner dal-a is said of a man with his wife: see dal-N, below. See also 4.]
dal-a also signifies He gloried in, or boasted of, certain properties, or peculiar qualities. (IAạr, T.)
Also, aor. yadil-u, He favoured with, or conferred, a gift. (IAạr, T.)

And dal-a, [aor., accord. to rule, yadul-u,] He emboldened: so in the phrase, maA dal-aka EalaI-a [What emboldened thee, or hath emboldened thee, against me?]: and in the saying of Keys Ibn-Zoheyr,
OaZun-u AlHiloma dal-a EalaI-a qawomiI
waqado yusotajohalu Alr-ajulu AlHaliymu
[I think that forbearance hath emboldened against me my people: for sometimes the forbearing man is reckoned ignorant]: (T:) and dl-l↓ signifies the same. (T and TA in art. dlw.)

entry.sense: 2: see what immediately precedes {1}:
and for a meaning of Alt-adoliylu [inf. n. of dal-ala], see jalada Eumayorapa, in the first paragraph of art. jld.

hom.sense: 4. Adl-: see 1.

Adl- Ealayohi He acted, or behaved, with boldness, or presumptuousness, towards him; syn. AinobasaTa Ealayohi; (M, Ḳ;) as also tdl-l↓: (M, Mgh,* Ḳ:) and hiIa tudil-u Ealayohi [and tatadal-alu↓] She emboldens herself against him. (T.) Imrael-Keys says,
OafaATima maholFA baEoDa hecAa Alt-adal-uli↓
faUino kunoti qado OazomaEoti SaromiI faOajomiliI
[O Fátimeh (fATm being a contraction of faATimapu), act thou gently: relinquish somewhat of this boldness; (or, as is said in the EM, p. 15, of this amorous gesture or behaviour, and coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition; see 1;) and if thou have determined upon cutting me, act with goodness, or moderation]. (TA.)

Also He confided in his love, and therefore acted presumptuously towards him. (IDrd, M, Ḳ.*) In the copies of the Ḳ, Oawovaqa is here put in the place of waviqa. (TA.) [And in the CK, Oawovaqa biHab-atih is put for waviqa bimuHab-itihi.] Hence, (TA,) one says, Oadal-a faOamal-a [He acted presumptuously, confiding in another's love, and disgusted]: (Ṣ, M, TA:) a prov. (M, TA.)
One says also, huwa yudil-u bifulaAnK, meaning [simply] He confides in such a one. (Ṣ.)

And Adl- EalaI OaqoraAnihi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) meaning Oaxacahumo mino fawoqK [i. e. He overcame, or overpowered, his adversaries], (M, Ḳ,) in war, or battle: (Ṣ:) and so AlbaAziI EalaI Sayodihi [the hawk, his prey, or quarry]. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Adl- said of a wolf, He became mangy, or scabby, and lean, or emaciated, and small in body. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, and 4; the latter in three places. tdl-l also signifies He exalted himself; or was, or became, haughty, proud, or disdainful: you say, humo yatadal-aluwna EalaI Als-uloTaAni [They exalt themselves against the Sultán; or behave haughtily to him]. (Ṣ in art. dkl.)
7. Andl-: see 1, in three places.
Also It poured out or forth; or was, or became, poured out or forth. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
8. Aid-al-a, first pers. Aid-alalotu: see 1.

10. Astdl- He desired, or sought, an indication, an evidence, a proof, or an argument: [this is the primary signification: and hence,] he adduced an indication,, &c.: and he drew an inference, or a deduction: (KL:) or he established an indication for the purpose of obtaining a certain knowledge of a thing indicated, or for the purpose of affirming a thing indicated: and sometimes it is quasi-pass. of dal-ahu AlT-ariyqa [explained above, so that it signifies he was, or became, directed, or rightly directed, to the way]. (TA. See 1.) [You say, Astdl- biXaIoCKEalaI XaIoCK Mxara He desired, or sought, to be directed, or guided, by a thing, to another thing: he adduced, or took, or regarded, a thing as an indication, an evidence, or a proof, of another thing, or as an argument in favour of another thing: he inferred, from a thing, another thing: he sought, or found, or perceived, or saw, in a thing, an indication, an evidence, or a proof, of another thing, or an argument in favour of another thing: he was, or became, directed, or guided, or he directed or guided himself, by a thing, to another thing, or to the knowledge of another thing. Ald-aliylu maA yusotadal-a bihi, occurring in the Ṣ, means The dlyl is that whereby one is directed, or guided.]

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. dalodala, (M,) inf. n. dalodalapN and dilodaAlN, (M, Ḳ,) He put in motion or in a state of commotion, or moved about, (M, Ḳ,) a thing suspended, (M,) and his head and limbs in walking, (M, Ḳ) said of a man. (M.)
dalodala fiI AlOaroDi He went away into the country, or in the land. (T.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tadalodala It was, or became, in a state of motion or commotion, or it moved about, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) hanging down; i. e. it dangled: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it hung down loosely. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] tadalodaluwA bayona Oamorayoni falamo yasotaqiymuwA [† They wavered, vacillated, or hung in suspense, between two affairs, and did not pursue a direct course]. (Lḥ, T, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: dal-N Amorous gesture or behaviour, of a woman, with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition; as also dalaAlN↓: (Ṣ, M:) the former is an inf. n., [see 1,] and ↓the latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) both signifying a woman's boldness of behaviour (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) towards the husband, (M, Ḳ,) with amorous gesture, and coquettishness, feigning opposition; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also daAluwlaMCu↓, (Ḳ,) and daAl-apN↓: (Ḥar p. 567:) or dal-N signifies a woman's pleasing talk and jesting and mien or guise; as also dalaAlN↓: (Sh, T:) and pleasing talk and jesting of a man with his wife: (TA in art. smt:) and also, (Kudot;,) accord. to AʼObeyd (T, Ṣ) and Hr, (M,) like hadoIN, (Ḳ,) or nearly the same as this word, (T, Ṣ, M,) both signifying a certain calm or placid or grave manner of deportment, with pleasingness of mien or guise or aspect, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and of the natural dispositions, &c., (T, Ṣ,) of a man: (T, Ṣ, M:) and boldness [or presumptuousness]; (T in art. dlw;) as also dalaAlN↓ and daAl-apN↓: (Mgh, and Ḥar p. 243, and T ubi suprà in explanation of the last:) or this last signifies a kind of boldness (IAạr, T, M,* Ḳ *) towards a person in whose estimation one holds a high place, (IAạr, T,) or towards a person beloved, or a beloved and loving relation; (M, Ḳ;) and is a subst. from Oadal-a; (Ṣ;) syn. with UidolaAlN; (Ḥar p. 243;) as is also dil-apN↓. (Fr, T.) One says, hiIa Hasanapu Ald-al-i and Ald-alaAli↓ [She is pleasing in respect of her amorous gesture, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

It is also an arabicized word, from the Pers. dilo signifying The heart, or mind: (M, Ḳ:) sometimes used in the speech of the Arabs, (M,) and applied by them as a proper name (M, Ḳ,) to a woman: (M:) with fet-ḥ (M, Ḳ) and teshdeed (Ḳ) because there is no such word in their language as dil-N; wherefore they changed it to dal-N, which has the first of the meanings assigned to it above. (M.)

entry.sense: [dal-apN, to which Golius assigns a meaning partly belonging to dalodalapN, an inf. n. of dalodala, and partly to other words of this art, (“Capitis membrorumve motus seu gestus, extrinsecus gravitatem præ se ferens, profectus tamen ab eo qui amat favetque,”) as on the authority of the Ḳ and KL, I do not find in either of those works.]
dul-apN A favour, or benefit, conferred, or bestowed. (Fr, T.)
dil-apN: see dal-N.
dalaAlN: see dal-N, in five places.

daliylN i. q. daAl-N↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) i.e. [A director; or] a right director (Mṣb, Kull, TA) to that which is sought or desired; a guide; (Kull;) one who directs, or rightly directs, another; (M;) [an indicator;] and a discoverer: (Mṣb:) and a thing by which one is directed, or guided, (maA yusotadal-u bihi Ṣ, TA,) or by which one is rightly directed; (TA;) [an indication; an evidence; a proof; and an argument;] a sign set up for the knowledge of a thing indicated; (whence smoke is called daliylN EalaI Aln-aAri [an indication of fire];) anything whereby a thing indicated is known, whether relating to an object of sense or to the law [&c.], decisive or indecisive: and dalaAlapN↓ is used in the sense of daliylN, because a thing is called by the inf. n. of its verb: (Kull:) and so is dil-iylaI↓, (Ṣ, MF, TA,) though this is asserted in the Ḳ to have been said heedlessly by J because this last word is an inf. n.; for the inf. n. is used in the sense of the act. part. n., almost by a general rule, as it is also in the sense of the pass. part. n.: (MF, TA:) the pl. of daliylN is Oadil-aMCu [generally restricted to rational beings, or always so restricted,] and Oadil-apN [generally restricted to things by which one is directed, &c., but properly a pl. of pauc.,] (M, TA) and, accord. to some, dalaAYilu, (Kull,) or this is pl. of daliylapN↓ [fem. of daliylN], or of dalaAlapN↓, as is also dalaAlaAtN. (TA.) yaA daliyla AlmutaHay-iriyna means O guide of those who are perplexed to that by means of which their perplexity will depart. (Kull.) The saying of a poet,
Xad-uwA AlmaTaI EalaI daliylK daAYibi
means, as some say, bidaliylK [i.e. They bound the saddles upon the camels for riding, with, or by means of, a toiling guide]: or, accord. to IJ, it may be elliptical, for EalaIdilaAlapi daliylK, and is like the phrase siro EalaI Qsomi Qll-ehi; as though he said, muEotamidiyna EalaI daliylK daAYibi [relying upon a toiling guide]. (M.)
dalaAlapN: see the next paragraph, in four places; and see its pl. in the same:
see also daliylN, in two places.

As a conventional term, (TA,) it means A word's signification, or indication of meaning: (Mṣb, TA:) this is of three kinds: thus UinosaAnN signifies, or indicates, “an animal endowed with reason” biAlmuTaAbaqapi, i. e. by complete correspondence; and “an animal” or “a being endowed with reason” biAlt-aDam-uni, i. e. [by partial inclusion, or] partially; and “a being capable of knowledge” biQliAlotizaAmi, i. e. [necessarily, or] by a necessary idea attached to it in the mind. (TA.)

dilaAlapN a subst. signifying Direction, right direction, or guidance; (Fr, T, M, Mṣb;) as also dalaAlapN↓, (Fr, T, Mṣb,) or the former only accord. to IDrd, (M,) and duluwlapN↓ and dil-ilaylaI↓; (M;) or this last is an inf. n. like dalaAlapN↓; (Ḳ;) or signifies the skill of a guide in direction or right direction or guidance; his well-grounded skill therein. (Sb, M, Ḳ.) A poet says,
Uin-iI QmoraON biAlT-uroqi cuw dalaAlaAto
[Verily I am a man possessing varied skill in guiding in the roads, or ways]. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.)
The occupation of the dal-aAl [q. v.]; (M, Ḳ;) as also dalaAlapN↓: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to IDrd, the latter [only] has this meaning. (M.)
The hire that one gives to the daliyl, or [so in the M, but in the Ḳ “and”] to the dal-aAl: (M, Ḳ:) and so, sometimes, dalaAlapN↓. (Ḳ.)
duluwlapN an inf. n. of dal-a [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a simple subst.: (M:) see the next preceding paragraph.
daliylapN: see dalyilN:
and see also what next follows.

dul-aI A conspicuous road or beaten track. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
In the T, at the end of art. ld it is said that daliylapN↓ signifies A white road or beaten track; on the authority of AA. (TA.)

dal-aAlN A broker; or one who acts as an intermediary between the seller and the buyer, for effecting the sale; because he directs the purchaser to the merchandise, and the seller to the price; also called simosaArN; (TA in art. smsr;) one who brings together the seller and the buyer. (M, Ḳ.)
dil-iylaI: see daliylN:
and see also dilaAlapN.

hom.sense: qawomN dulodulN (T,* Ḳ) and dalodaAlN↓ (Lḥ, T, Ḳ) A people, or party, wavering, vacillating, or hanging in suspense, between two affairs, and not pursuing a direct course. (Lḥ, T, Ḳ.) You say also, jaAwuwA dulodulFA, meaning They came wavering; not inclining to these nor to those. (ISk, T, Ṣ.)

dulodulN also signifies A case, or an affair, of great magnitude or moment, difficult, or formidable. (Ḳ.) You say, waqaEa Alqawomu fiI Ald-aloduli [The people, or party, fell into that which was a case of great magnitude, &c.]. (TA. [See also a similar phrase in the next paragraph.])

Also, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and duloduwlN↓, (Ḳ,) The qunofuc [or hedge-hog]: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) or a species of qnfc having long prickles: (M:) or a large qnfc: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the male qnfc: (MF:) or an animal like the qnfc; (M, Ḳ;) it is a certain beast that shakes, and shoots forth prickles like arrows: the difference between it and the qnfc is like that between fiYarap and jirocaAno, and the ox-kind and buffaloes, and Arabian camels and those called baxaAtiI-: (M:) or a certain large thing, larger than the qnfc, having long prickles. (Lth, T.)

Also, the former, without the article Al (M, TA,) incorrectly written in the Ḳ with that article, (TA,) the name of A certain mule, (M, Ḳ, TA,) of a colour in which whiteness predominated over blackness, (TA,) belonging to the Prophet. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: dalodaAlN [Motion, or commotion, or a moving about, of a thing suspended, and of the head and limbs in walking;] a subst. from dalodala in the first of the senses assigned to this verb above: (M, Ḳ:) agitation, convulsion, tumult, or disturbance. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence,] one says, waqaEa Alqawomu fiI dalodaAlN The people, or party, fell into an unsound, a corrupt, or a disordered, and an unsteady, or a fluctuating, state of affairs. (Lḥ, T. [See a similar phrase in the next preceding paragraph.])
See also another signification in the next preceding paragraph.
duloduwlN: see dulodulN.
daAl-N: see daliylN.
daAl-apN: see dal-N, in two places.
daAluwlaMCu: see dal-N.
Oadal-N Very bountiful or beneficent. (IAạr, T.)

AisotidolaAliI-N [Inferential, illative, or deductive, knowledge;] a term opposed to DaruwriI-N as meaning [intuitive, immediate, or axiomatic, or] such as originates without thought, or reflection, and intellectual examination of an evidence or a proof. (Kull p. 232.)

mudil-N [Acting, or behaving, with boldness, or presumptuousness:, &c.: see its verb (4).] Trusting in himself, and in his weapons and apparatus. (Ḥam p. 383.) And mudil-N biAlX-ajaAEapi [Presuming by reason of courage: or] bold, daring, or brave. (T.)
fulaAnapu mudal-alapu fulaAnK, meaning Such a female is the foster-child of such a man, is a phrase of the people of Baghdád, not of the [classical] language of the Arabs. (Ṣgh, TA.)
mudal-ilN One who accuses of a crime, an offence, or an injurious action, wrongfully. (IAạr, T.)

hom.sense: madoluwlN [pass. part. n. of dal-a; Directed, directed aright, or guided: and indicated, denoted, or signified. Hence, madoluwlu lafoZK The indicated meaning, or signification, of a word: pl. madoluwlaAtN.]
[Also] Emboldened. (T.)

dulobN A kind of tree; (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ;) the tree called the Eayovam [or EayovaAm], (T,) or the gayovaAn [probably a mistranscription for EayovaAm]: (M:) or the Sin-aAr or SinaAr [i. e. the plane-tree]; (T, M, Ḳ, accord. to different copies; in some copies of the Ḳ explained as the SnAr; in other copies, as a kind of tree, and the SnAr;) which is most like to it [referring to the Eyvm]; (T;) or which is most likely; (M;) a kind of great tree, (Mgh,) having neither blossom nor fruit, the leaves of which are serrated (M, Mgh) and wide, resembling those of the vine, (M,) called in Persian SinaAr [or rather JanaAro]: (Mgh:) in the [Kitáb en-] Nebát, [or Book of Plants, of AḤn,] the [tree called] SnAr, which is a Persian word that has become current in the language of the Arabs: it grows large and wide: and some say that it is called the EayovaAm: (TT:) accord. to Ibn-El-Kutbee, it is a great, well-known, tree, the leaves of which resemble those of the xirowaE [or palma Christi], except in being smaller, and are bitter in taste, and astringent; having small blossoms: (TA:) [see also De Sacy's “Abdallatif,” p. 80: and his “Chrest. Arabs,” sec. ed., p. 394 (173 of the Arabic text) and the notes thereon: the word is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with nawaAqiys. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) The naAquws [pl. of huwa mino Oaholi Ald-urobapi bimuEaAlajapi Ald-ulobapi, answering to the Christians the purpose of churchbells,] are made of the wood of this tree: whence the saying, huwa mino Oaholi Ald-urobapi bimuEaAlajapi Ald-ulobapi [He is of the people who are accustomed to ply the wood of the plane-tree], meaning he is a Christian. (A.)
Ald-ulobu [or, as in a copy of the T, accord. to the TT, Ald-alobu,] A certain race of the blacks, (T, Ḳ,) of Es-Sind: [said to be] formed by transposition from Ald-ayobulu. (T.)
dulobapN n. un. of dulobN [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
And Blackness, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) like luEosapN [q. v.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: daAlibN A coal that will not become extinguished. (Ḳ.)

duwlaAbN, (Ṣ,) or dawolaAbN, (A, Mgh,) or each of these, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of which the latter is the more chaste, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) an arabicized word, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from the Persian [duwlo Mbo dól-áb]; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) but some say it is Arabic; (Mṣb;) [A kind of water-wheel;] a machine that is turned by a horse or the like; (Mgh, Mṣb;) a thing formed like the naAEuwrap, with which water is drawn, (M, A, Ḳ,) for irrigating land [&c.]: (A:) or, more correctly, the same as the nAEwrp; vulgarly called saAqiyap: (TA:) [it mainly consists of a vertical wheel, which raises the water in earthern pots, these being attached to cords, and forming a continuous series; a second vertical wheel, fixed to the same axis as the former, with cogs; and a large, horizontal, cogged wheel, which, being turned by a pair of bulls or cows or by a single beast, puts and keeps in motion the two other wheels and the pots:] pl. dawaAliybu; (Ṣ, M, A;) for which dawaAliI occurs in poetry: (M:) [or rather this (occurring at the end of a verse, and with the article Al,) is pl. of daAliyapN.]
It has also other meanings, not mentioned in the Ḳ. (TA.) [Nor are they mentioned in the TA. Among other meanings used in the present day, are the following.]
[A machine: particularly any machine with a rotatory motion.]
[A cupboard.]
[And A machination; an artifice; a trick; or a fraud.]
OaroDN madolabapN A land containing, (Ṣ,) or abounding with, (Ḳ,) the kind of trees called dulob. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. dalaja, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoluju} (Ṣ, L) and _i {yadoliju}, (L,) inf. n. duluwjN, He transferred the bucket from the mouth of the well to the watering-trough, to empty it therein: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he took the bucket, when it came forth, and went with it whithersoever he pleased. (TA.) One says also, huwa yadoluju biAld-alowi and yadojulu bihaA: the latter verb being formed by transposition. (Fr, TA in art. djl.)
And He transferred the milk, when the camels had been milked, to the [large bowls called] jifaAn. (Ḳ.)
[See a remark of IF at the end of art. dlk.]

4. Adlj, (inf. n. UidolaAjN, Mṣb, TA,) He journeyed from the beginning of the night: and Aid-alaja↓ he journeyed from the latter part of the night: (Th, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the former signifies he journeyed all the night: and ↓the latter, he journeyed in the latter part of the night: (A, Mṣb, TA:) or the former, he journeyed in the night, at any hour from the beginning to the end thereof: (Th, from Aboo-Suleymán El-Aarábee:) or, accord. to El-Fárisee, ↓both these verbs are syn., and each bears the first and second of the significations given above: IDrst contends against the assertions of those who make a difference between them, and affirms them to be syn., and to signify he journeyed in the night, at any time, in the beginning or middle or end thereof:
therefore, he says, their signification is restricted, in several examples, by the context; and hence, he adds, the appellation mudolijN given to a hedgehog: (TA:) [agreeably with this explanation,] ʼAlee says,
AiSobiro EalaI Als-ayori waAlUidolaAji fiI Als-aHari
[Endure thou with patience travelling, and journeying in the night, in the period a little before daybreak]. (MF.) [See another ex. voce OaSobaHa.]
8: see 4, in three places.
dalojN: see the next paragraph.
dalajN: see the next paragraph.
dalojapN: see the next paragraph.

dulojapN and dalojapN↓ and dalajN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) all substs., (Ṣ,) A journeying from the beginning of the night: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the first and second a journeying from the latter part of the night: (Ṣ:) or thus the first: (A:) and the second, (ISd, A,) or the first and second, (TA,) a journeying all the night: (ISd, A, TA:) and the second, also, a journeying a little before daybreak: (ISd, TA:) or the first and second (TA) and third (IDrst, TA) a journeying in the night; and this seems to be the meaning intended in the trad., Ealayokumo biAld-ulojapi faUin-a AlOaroDa tuTowaI biAll-ayoli [Keep ye to journeying in the night, for the earth is to be traversed by night]: (TA:) [and daliyjN↓ occurs in the L in the sense of dulojapN, &c.:] the pl. of the first is dulajN. (Ḥam p. 521.) One says also, Ald-ulojapa qabola Albulojapi [Keep to the journeying in the night,, &c., before the breaking of the dawn]. (A.) [See another ex. voce bulojapN.]

Also, the same three words, and dalojN↓ and dalajapN↓, An hour, or a time, or a short portion, (saAEapN,) of the latter part of the night: (ISd, TA:) or dalajN signifies the whole of the night, from the beginning to the end. (Th, from Aboo-Suleymán El-Aarábee.)
dalajapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
daliyjN: see the next preceding paragraph.
daAlijN One who takes the bucket and goes with it from the mouth of the well to the wateringtrough, to empty it therein. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And One who transfers the milk, when the camels have been milked, to the [large bowls called] jifaAn. (Ḳ.)

dawolajN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and madolajapN↓ (Ḳ) A wild animal's, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or gazelle's, (TA,) covert, or hidingplace, among trees: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) the former word like tawolajN: (Ṣ:) the d in dwlj is held by Sb to be a substitute for t, and the t is a substitute for w. (TA.)
Also, the former, A hole, or den, of a wild animal; or a subterranean excavation or habitation; syn. sarabN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And A closet; a small chamber within a large chamber. (TA.)
madolajN and madolajapN↓ The space between the well and the watering-trough. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

Almudoliju (Ḳ) and Oabuw AlmudoliJ (A, Ḳ) The hedgehog; syn. Alqunofucu: (A, Ḳ:) so called because he goes about all the night: (TA:) or not because he does so in the first part of the night, or in the middle, or in the latter part, or during the whole of it; but because he appears at night at any time when he wants herbage or water, &c. (IDrst, TA.)

hom.sense: madolajapN: see madolajN:
and see also dawolajN.

entry.sense: midolajapN A large milking-vessel in which milk is transferred [to the jifaAn, or large bowls: see 1]. (Ḳ.)
saHaAbapN midolaAjN [A cloud that comes in the latter part of the night]. (A voce bakuwrN, q. v.)
1. dalasa, inf. n. dalosN: see the next paragraph {2}, in three places.
2. dl-s, (M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. tadoliysN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He concealed, or hid, a thing; he did not make it known; as also tdl-s↓. (TA.)

He concealed a fault, or defect, in an article of merchandize, from the purchaser, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in selling; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also dalasa↓, aor. _i {yadolisu}, inf. n. dalosN; but the former is the more common: (Mṣb:) and he did not show a fault, or defect; without restriction to a case of selling. (TA.) You say, dal-asa EalaI Alr-ajuli fiI AlbayoEi, (M, A,) and dl-s lahu fiI AlbayoEi, (A,) He concealed, disguised, or cloaked, from the man the fault, or defect, of the thing sold; (A;) he did not show the fault, or defect, to the man in selling. (M.) And dl-s fiI AlbayoEi wagayorihi He did not show his fault, or defect, in selling, and in other cases. (M.) And dl-s Ealayohi He concealed, disguised, or cloaked, from him his fault, or defect. (A.) And Az heard an Arab of the desert say, layosa fiI AlOamori walosN walaA dalosN↓ There is not in the affair treachery nor deceit: (Mṣb:) or maA liI fiyhi walosN walaA dalosN↓ I have not, with respect to it, treachery nor deceit; (Ḳ,* TA;) referring to a thing, or an affair, in which he was accused, or suspected, of evil. (L, TA.) [In the CK, instead of dalosN, we find dalasN.]

Hence tadoliysN in the ascription of a tradition to its relater or relaters; which is, ‡ One's relating a tradition as from the earliest sheykh when perhaps he has not seen him, but only heard it from one inferior to him, or from one who had heard it from him, and the like; (Ḳ;) or when he has seen him, but has heard what he ascribes to him from another, inferior to him; (Az, TA;) which has been done by several persons in whom confidence is placed: (Ḳ:) or one's not mentioning, in his tradition, him from whom he heard it, but mentioning the highest authority, inducing the opinion that he had heard it from him. (A.)

3. dAls, (M,) inf. n. mudaAlasapN (Ṣ, M) and dilaAsN, (M,) He endeavoured to deceive, beguile, or circumvent; or acted deceitfully with another. (Ṣ, M.) You say, fulaAnN laA yudaAlisuka Such a one will not endeavour to deceive thee, or act deceitfully with thee, and conceal from thee the thing, as though he came to thee in the dark. (Ṣ.) [See dalasN.] And fulaAnN laA yudaAlisu walaA yuwaAlisu Such a one will not endeavour to deceive, beguile, or circumvent; or will not act deceitfully with another; nor will he act perfidiously: (M, L:) or will not act wrongfully, nor treacherously, (Ḳ, TA,) nor practise artifice or fraud. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5: see 2, first signification:
and see also 7, in two places.

entry.sense: 7. Andls It (a thing) was, or became, concealed, or hidden; as also tdl-s↓: (TA:) and ↓the latter, he (a man, TḲ) concealed, or hid, himself; (TḲ;) syn. tkt-m. (Ḳ.)

dalasN The dark; or darkness; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also dulosapN↓: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the confusedness of the darkness, or of the beginning of night; expl. by AixotilaATu AlZ-alaAmi. (A, Ḳ.) You say, OataAnaA dalasa AlZ-alaAmi He came to us in the confusedness of the darkness, or of the beginning of night. (TA.) And xaraja fiI Qld-alasi waQlogalasi [He went forth in the confusedness of the darkness, or of the beginning of night, and in the darkness of the last part of the night]. (A, TA.)
dulosapN: see dalasN.
Hence, Deceit, guile, or circumvention. (IF, Mṣb.)
1. dalaSa, aor. _u {yadoluSu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. daliySN, (M, Ḳ, TḲ,) It (a thing, TḲ) shone, or glistened. (M, Ḳ, TḲ.)

dalaSati Ald-iroEu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ,) or daluSat, (so in a copy of the M,) aor. _u {yadoluSu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. dalaASapN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with which dalaSN is syn., (TA,) [the former a reg. inf. n. of daluSat, and the latter of dalSat, which is the form given in the TḲ, and is perhaps a dial. var.,] The coat of mail was, or became, soft, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and smooth, (M, Ḳ,) and shining, or glistening. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
daliSati Aln-aAbu, aor. _a {yadolaSu}, The aged she-camel lost her teeth (Ḳ, TA) by reason of extreme age; (TA;) as also dariSat and daliqat. (TA.)

2. dl-S, (Ṣ, M, A,) inf. n. tadoliySN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made a thing to shine, or glisten: (M:) he, or it, made soft; (so in some copies of the Ḳ, and so accord. to the TA;) for Alt-alobiysN in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ is a mistake for Alt-aloyiynu: (TA:) he made a coat of mail soft, and shining, or glistening: (Ṣ:) it (a torrent) made stone, or rock, smooth: (Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ:*) and he gilded a thing, so that it shone, or glistened. (A, TA.*) [Hence,] dl-St jabiynahaA She (a woman) plucked out the hair upon the sides of her forehead [and so rendered it smooth or glistening]. (M, TA.) [See also Q. Q. 1.]
Coivit circa vulvam; membro in vulvam non immisso: (A:) vel extra vulvam: (Ḳ:) the action which it denotes is termed tazoliyqN as well as tadoliySN. (A.)

7. AndlS It fell, or dropped: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or went forth quickly; as also AnmlS: (Lth:)
or went forth, and fell, or dropped: (M:) or went forth quickly, or slipped out by reason of its smoothness, (AnmlS) and fell, or dropped: (A:) mino yadiI [from my hand]; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) or mina AlX-aIoCi (Lth) or Eani AlXI [from the thing]: (M:) IF says that the d is app. a substitute for m. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1. dalomaSa mataAEahu, and damolaSahu, He adorned, or decorated, and made to shine, or glisten, his household-goods, or utensils and furniture. (M.) [But some hold the m to be a radical letter. See also 2, above.]
Q. Q. 2. tadalomaSa It (the head) became bald in the fore part. (Ḳ. in art. dlmS.)
daliSN: see dilaASN, in three places.

dilaASN Shining, or glistening; as also daliySN↓, (A,) and dulaAmiSN↓, (Ṣ and M in this art., and Ḳ in art. dlmS,) with an augmentative m, (Ṣ,) of the measure fuEaAmilN accord. to Sb, but fuEaAlilN accord. to others, (M,) [see an ex. in a verse cited voce xamiySapN,] and dulamiSN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is a contraction of that next preceding, (Ṣ, M,) and in like manner dumaAliSN↓, and dumaliSN↓, (Ṣ in this art, and Ḳ in art. dmlS,) which last two are formed by transposition from the two next preceding: (TA in art. dmlS:) or, as also daliySN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA) and daliSN↓ and dal-aASN↓, (M, TA,) shining, or glistening, and smooth; (M;) or soft, and shining, or glistening, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and smooth. (TA.) You say, diroEN dilaASN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and dulaAmiSN↓ (A) A coat of mail smooth, (M, A, Ḳ,) soft, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and shining, or glistening: (Ṣ, M, A:) pl. dilaASN, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) like the sing., (Ṣ,) and duluSN. (Lth, M, A.) And cahabN dulaAmiSN↓ Glittering gold. (Ḳ.) And AimoraOapN dulamiSapN↓ A shining, or glistening woman. (TA.) And raOosN dulamiSN↓ A head bald in the fore part. (Ḳ.) And daliSN↓, (El-Moḥeeṭ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or daliySN↓, (as in other copies of the Ḳ,) and OadolaSN↓, applied to a man, signify i. q. Oazolaqu; (Ḳ;) i. e., Hairless and glistening in body: (TḲ:) fem. of the last, daloSaMCu. (Ḳ.) dal-aASN↓, also, applied to a man, signifies Very smooth: (TA:) and applied to a she-camel, and to land (OaroD), smooth: (Ḳ:) but it is not applied to a he-camel. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.) And daliSN↓ and daliSapN, applied to land, signify Even, or level: pl. dilaASN. (Ḳ.)
daliySN: see dilaASN, in three places.
Also The water, or lustre, (maMC,) of gold: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, glistening, or glittering, gold. (TA.)
dal-aASN: see dilaASN, in two places.
dil-awoSN That wabbles, or moves to and fro; (Ṣ;) or moves about; (Ḳ;) as, for instance, a sinew does when chewed by an old woman. (Ṣ.)
dulamiSN: see dilaASN, in several places.
dulaAmiSN: see dilaASN, in several places.
dumaliSN: see dilaASN, in several places.
dumaAliSN: see dilaASN, in several places.
Applied to an ass, To which new hair has grown; as also OadolaSiI-N↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
And the fem., applied to an aged she-camel, Whose teeth have fallen out (Ḳ TA) by reason of extreme age; (TA;) as also daroSaMCu and daloqaMCu. (TA.)
OadolaSiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
SaxorapN mudul-aSapN A rock made smooth (A, TA) by torrents. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. dalaEa lisaAnahu, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadolaEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. daloEN, (Lth, Ḳ,*) He (a man, Ṣ, [and a dog,] and a tired wolf, TA) lolled, lolled out, put forth, or protruded, his tongue; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AdlEhu↓; (Lth, IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) but the latter is of rare occurrence, though chaste. (Lth.)

And dalaEa lisaAnuhu, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) the verb being intrans. as well as trans., (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yadolaEu} and _u {yadoluEu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. duluwEN, (Lth, Ḳ,) like as rajaEa has rujuwEN for its inf. n. when intrans., but rajoEN when trans., (Lth,) His tongue lolled, or protruded; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AndlE↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Aid-alaEa↓, [originally AidotalaEa,] of the measure AifotaEala: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) [said of a man,] his tongue protruded from the mouth, and hung down upon the hair between the lower lip and the chin, like the tongue of the dog; (TA;) and [in like manner,] AndlE↓, it protruded and hung down, by reason of much grief, or distress of mind, affecting the breath, or respiration, or by reason of thirst, like that of the dog. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
7: see 1, in two places.

[Hence,] AndlE baTonuhu † His belly became prominent, or protuberant: (Ṣ:) or became large and flabby: (Ḳ:) said of a man: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to Naseer, as related by Aboo-Turáb, the verb has the latter signification said of the belly of a woman; as also Andlq. (TA.)
And AndlE Als-ayofu mino gimodihi ‡ The sword became drawn, or it slipped out, from its scabbard; (Ḳ, TA;) as also Andlq. (TA.)
8. Aid-alaEa: see 1.
OaHomaqu daAliEN Stupid in the utmost degree; (El-Hujeymee, Ḳ;) who ceases not to loll out his tongue. (El-Hujeymee, TA.)
OamorN daAliEN † An affair in the way to the attainment of which there is nothing intervening as an obstacle; expl. by layosa duwnahu XaIoCN. (Ḳ.)
farasN OadolaEu A horse that lolls out his tongue in running. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

mudolaEN [pass. part. n. of 4]. It is said in a trad., yuboEavu XaAhidu Alz-uwri yawoma AlqiyaAmapi mudolaEFA lisaAnuhu fiI Aln-aAri [The false witness will be raised to life on the day of resurrection with his tongue lolled out in the fire]. (TA.)

1. dalafa, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yadolifu}, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. daliyfN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and dalafN (T, M, Ḳ) and dalofN (Ḳ) and dalafaAnN (M, Ḳ) and duluwfN, (M, TA,) He walked, or went, gently, or leisurely: (Ṣ, M:) said of an old man, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) he walked, or went, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) with short steps, (Ṣ, M,) or in the manner of him who is shackled, (Ḳ,) as some say, (M,) at a rate above that which is termed dabiybN, (Aṣ, T, M, Ḳ,) like as does the army, or body of troops, to the [other] army, or body of troops. (Aṣ, T.) You say, dalafati Alkatiybapu UilaI Alkatiybapi fiI AlHarobi (T, Ṣ,* M, Ḳ *) meaning The army, or body of troops, went gently, or leisurely, to the [other] army, or body of troops, in war: (M:) or advanced, or went forward; syn. taqad-amat: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [for] dalafN (T, M) accord. to AʼObeyd, or dalofN accord. to AA, (T,) signifies the act of advancing, or going forward; syn. taqad-umN: (T, M:) and one says dalafonaAhumo, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or dalafonaA lahumo, (M, and so in one place in the TA,) meaning [as is implied in the Ṣ and Ḳ] we advanced to them; syn. taqad-amonaA: (M:) and dalafa Uilayohi he drew near to him, or it. (TA.) dalafotu also signifies maXayotu [i.e. I walked; or went on foot, whether quickly or slowly]: (Ḥam p. 678:) and [in like manner,] tdl-f↓ Uilayohi signifies maXaI [he walked,, &c., to him, or it]: (O, TA:) or this latter signifies tamaX-aI [said in the TA, in art. mXI, to be syn. with maXaI; but it rather signifies he walked with slow steps to him, or it]; and approached, or drew near: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but AʼObeyd says that tazal-afa is more common. (M.)

Hence, the saying of a poet,
dalafotu UilaI Samiymika biAlqawaAfiI
meaning † I have wounded thy heart with rhymes. (Ḥam ubi suprá.)
[The verb seems to bear two contr. significations; for it is said that] dalafa liQlotizaAmiI means He hastened to take me by the hand and embrace me. (Ḥar p. 368.)
dalafa biHimolihi, aor. _i {yadolifu}, inf. n. daliyfN, He (one carrying a thing) was heavily burdened, or overburdened, by his load [so that he went slowly]. (M.)
You say of a she-camel, tadolifu biHamolihaA, meaning She rises [app. with difficulty (see daAlifN)] with her load. (T,* Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
And dalafa AlmaAlu, aor. _i {yadolifu}, inf. n. daliyfN, The camels, or cattle, clave to the ground by reason of emaciation. (M, TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Adlfhu It (old age) made him to walk, or go, gently, or leisurely; with short steps; [or in the manner of him who is shackled; (see 1;)] at a rate above that which is termed dabiybN. (IAạr, M.)
Adlf lahu Alqawola i. q. OaDoxama lahu, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,*) He spoke to him in a rough, harsh, coarse, rude, uncivil, or ungentle, manner. (TḲ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.
7. Andlf EalaI-a i. q. AinoSab-a [app. as meaning It poured out, or forth, upon me]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
dilofN Courageous; brave; strong-hearted. (AA, T, Ḳ.)
dulufN A she-camel (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ) that rises [app. with difficulty (see daAlifN)] with her load. (T, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
It is also a pl. of daAlifN: (Ḳ:) and of daluwfN. (TA.)

dulofiynN [The dolphin;] a certain fish, (T,) or beast, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [app. thus termed because it is a mammal,]) of the sea, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) that saves him who is drowning; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) also called duxasN; and abounding in the Sea of Dimyát [or Damietta]. (TA.)

Ald-ulofiynu † [The constellation Delphinus;] one of the northern constellation, which comprises ten stars, and follows Aln-asoru AlT-aAYiru [α and β and γ of Aquila]: the bright star on its tail is called canabu Ald-ulofiyni. (Ḳzw.)
daluwfN ‡ A fat camel, that walks, or goes, gently, or leisurely, or with short steps, or in the manner of him who is shackled, by reason of his fatness: pl. dulufN, with two dammehs. (TA.)
And ‡ A palm-tree (naxolapN) having much fruit. (TA.)
Also † A swift eagle: (IAạr, M, Ḳ:) pl. dulofN [perhaps a contraction of dulufN, an analogous form of pl.]. (Ḳ.) [Thus it bears two contr. significtions]

daAlifN An old man that walks, or goes, gently, or leisurely, or with short steps, or in the manner of him who is shackled: (TA:) walking with a heavy load, with short steps; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like daAliHN: (Ṣ:) pl. dul-afN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and dulufN (Ḳ) and dul-aAfN: (TA:) and dawaAlifu [as pl. of daAlifapN] is applied to old women. (TA.)
† Old, and rendered lowly, humble, or submissive, by age. (M.)
‡ An arrow that hits a thing in the way to the butt, or object of aim, and then glances off from the place thereof. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
mutadal-ifN: see what follows.
munodalifN and mutadal-ifN↓ A lion walking at his ease, (Ḳ, TA,) without haste, and with short steps, because of his presumptuousness, and lack of fear. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. dalaqa as an intrans. verb: see 7, in three places.

dalaqahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoluqu}, (TA,) inf. n. daloqN, (Ṣ,) He made it (a sword) to slip forth from its scabbard: (Ṣ:) or he drew it forth, or made it to come forth; namely, a sword, from its scabbard: (Ḳ:) and [in like manner] Adlqhu↓ he drew it forth, or made it to come forth; (Ḳ;) namely, a sword, &c.; (TA;) as also Astdlqhu↓ (Ḳ) and Astclqhu. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. of ʼAlee, jiYotu waqado OacolaqaniI↓ AlmaTaru I came, the rain having drawn me forth, or having made me to come forth. (TA.) And AlmaTaru yasotadoliqu↓ AlHaXaraAti The rain draws forth the reptiles, or small creeping things, or makes them to come forth, from their holes; as also ystclqhA. (TA.)
You say also, jaMCa waqado dalaqa lijaAmahu, [as to the letter and the meaning like jaMCa waqado lafaZa lijaAmahu,] i. e. † He came harassed, or distressed, by thirst and fatigue. (TA.)
And dalaquwA Ealayohimu AlgaArapa They scattered, or poured forth, upon them the horsemen making a sudden attack and engaging in conflict, or the horsemen urging their horses. (TA.)
And dalaqa baAbahu, inf. n. as above, He opened his door vehemently. (TA.)
daliqati Aln-aAbu The aged she-camel lost her teeth by reason of extreme age; like daliSat. (TA in art. dlS.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.
5: see the next paragraph {7}.

7. Andlq It (a sword) came forth (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) from its scabbard (Mṣb) without being drawn: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or became loose, and so came forth, and came forth quickly: (TA:) and in like manner, its scabbard became slit, (Ṣ,) or it slit its scabbard, (Ḳ,) so that it came forth from it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it fell from its scabbard, and came forth, without being drawn; (Ḥar p. 386;) and so dalaqa↓, inf. n. duluwqN (TA, and Ḥar ubi suprà) and daloqN: (TA:) which also signifies it (a thing) came forth, or issued, from its place of egress quickly: (TA:) and [in like manner] the former verb signifies it (a thing) came forth, or issued, from its place: (AʼObeyd, Ḳ:) it (anything) came forth, or issued, or fell out. (Ṣ.) You say, TaEanahu faQnodalaqato OaqotaAbu baTonihi He pierced him, and the intestines of his belly came forth. (Ṣ.) And Andlqt Alxayolu (Ṣ, TA) The horses, or horsemen, came forth, or issued, and hastened: (TA:) and dalaqati↓ Alxayolu The horses, or horsemen, came forth, or issued, consecutively, or uninterruptedly. (TA.)

It (a torrent) came suddenly, or unawares, EalaI qawomK upon a people, or party: (Ṣ:) or rushed, or became impelled, or poured forth as though impelled, (Ḳ, TA,) EalayohimN upon them; (TA;) as also tdl-q↓: (Ḳ:) or came, or advanced: (Mṣb:) and [in like manner] dalaqa↓ EalayohimN. (JK.)
He preceded: (Ṣ:) or went before and away. (TA.) You say, Ainodalaqa mino bayoni OaSoHaAbihi He went before and away from among his companions. (TA.)

It was, or became, flabby and prominent; said of a belly; (TA in the present art.;) or, accord. to Naseer, said of the belly of a woman, like AndlE, meaning it became large and flabby. (TA in art. dlE.)
It (a door) shut again (AinoSafaqa) when opened; would not remain open. (TA.)
10: see 1, in two places.

dalaqN, a Persian word (Ṣ, Mṣb) arabicized, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally dalahN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) [A species of weasel; accord. to some, app., the common weasel;] a certain small beast (duwayob-apN, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) like the sam-uwr [or sable], (Ḳ,) or like the cat, having a long back, [of the coat] of which are made fur garments: some say that it is the [animal called] Aibon miqoraD [q. v.; and this is agreeable with the description of Ḳzw, who says that it is “a certain wild animal, an enemy to pigeons, likened to the cat, which, when it enters a pigeonhouse, leaves not in it anything, and abundant in Egypt;” a description altogether applicable to the common weasel, now generally called Aibon nimos]: some say that it resembles the Eiros [or ichneumon]: some, that it is the Greek ichneumon (nimos ruwmiI-): (Mṣb in the present art.:) accord. to IF, the [common] nimos. (Mṣb in art. nms.)

[Also, from the same Persian original, in post-classical times, but variously pronounced by moderns, dalaqN and daliqN↓ and daloqN and (now generally by the vulgar) diloqN; the third being perhaps a contraction of the first, like as XaEorN is of XaEarN, or, as also the fourth, of the second, like as katofN and kitofN are contractions of katifN; A certain kind of garment; first probably applied to one made of the fur of the animal so called: then applied to a kind of garment formerly worn by the kádees and other 'ulamà and the khateebs of mosques, (see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., vol. ii. pp. 267-269,) and by other persons of religious orders: and lastly, to a kind of patched garment worn by many devotees, reputed saints, and darweeshes; also called muraq-aEapN (q. v.) and xiroqapN. It occurs in a piece of post-classical poetry, quoted in p. 45 of the Arabic text of the vol. of the Chrest. above referred to, necessarily with the l quiescent; probably by poetic license, or in conformity with the common vulgar pronunciation.]

hom.sense: daliqN: see daluwqN:
and see also dalaqN.

entry.sense: daloqaMCu: see daluwqN, in four places.
diloqamN: see what next follows, in three places.

hom.sense: daluwqN A sword that comes forth easily from its scabbard; as also daAliqN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and daliqN↓ (IDrd, Ḳ) and daloqaMCu↓: (Ḳ:) [which last is strange, and requires consideration; being fem., whereas sayofN (a sword) is masc.:] all, applied to a sword, signify that comes forth from its scabbard without being drawn; and that which does so is the best of swords. (TA.) [For the pl., see what follows.]

gaArapN daluwqN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and duluqN, (TA,) and xayolN duluqN and munodaliqapN↓, (Ṣ,) [Horsemen making a sudden attack and engaging in conflict, or horsemen urging their horses, and simply horsemen, or horses,] rushing vehemently: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) duluqN is pl. of daluwqN and of daAliqN↓ having the same signification. (TA.)

Also, and daloqaMCu↓ and diloqimN↓, with an augmentative m, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like as one says daqoEaMCu and diqoEimN, and darodaMCu and dirodimN, (Ṣ,) and diloqamN↓, (TA,) A she-camel having her teeth broken by old age (Ṣ, Ḳ) so that she spirts out water [after drinking].
