(Ṣ, TA.) A poet, cited by Yaạḳoob, says,
XaArifN daloqaMCu↓ laA sin-a lahaA
taHomilu AlOaEobaMCa mino Eahodi Uiramo
[Old and decrepit, having her teeth broken by old age so that water falls from her mouth when she drinks, having no tooth left, carrying burdens from the time of Irem, i. e. Aram the son of Shem the son of Noah]: and XaArifN daloqaMCu↓ occurs in a trad. as meaning having the teeth broken so that water falls from her mouth when she drinks: (TA:)
[but] AZ says that one applies to the she-camel, after what is termed buzuwlN, the epithet XaArifN; then, Eawozamo; then, liToliTN then, jaHomariXN; then, jaEomaMCu; and then diloqimN↓, when having her teeth (OaDoraAs) fallen out by reason of extreme old age. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also art. dlqm.]

entry.sense: daAliqN: see daluwqN, in two places.
Also Preceding; going before. (TA.)
xayolN munodaliqapN: see daluwqN.

diloqimN A she-camel (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) whose teeth are consumed by old age; (Ṣ;) aged, and having broken teeth; (Ḳ) having her teeth broken by old age, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. dlq,) so that she spirts out water [after drinking]; (Ṣ in that art.;) like daluwqN and daloqaMCu: (Ṣ and Ḳ in that art.:) and also written diloqamN: (TA in that art.:) or whose teeth are broken, and whose saliva flows: (Aṣ, TA in the present art.:) or having her teeth (OaDoraAs) fallen out by reason of extreme old age: (Ṣ in art. dlq:) and by some applied to the male: the m, accord. to J and some others of the learned, is augmentative: or it may be from Ald-aqomu, which means “the breaking of the teeth;” and the l may be augmentative. (TA.) [See also daluwqN.]
Also † An old woman. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. dalakahu, (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadoluku}, inf. n. dalokN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He rubbed it, or rubbed it and pressed it, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with his hand: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or he did so well: or he pressed it, or squeezed it, and rubbed it: for] dalokN signifies the act of rubbing, or rubbing and pressing, well: (KL:) or the act of pressing, or squeezing, and rubbing: (Ḥam p. 798:) [and in like manner, dl-khu↓, inf. n. tadoliykN, signifies in the present day he rubbed it, or rubbed it and pressed it; and particularly, a person's body and limbs, in the bath: its proper meaning, however, is, he rubbed it, or rubbed it and pressed it, much or well: Golius explains it as signifying he rubbed it much or well on the anthority of the KL; but it is not in my copy of that work.] You say, dalaka Alv-awoba He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, the garment, or piece of cloth, to wash it. (TA.) And dalakotu Als-unobula Hat-aI Qnofaraka qiXoruhu Eano Hab-ihi [I rubbed the ears of corn until their husks rubbed off from their grain]; (TA;) and Aid-alakahu↓ [signifies the same]. (Ḳ in art. rhw, &c.) And dalaka Eayonayohi [He rubbed his eyes]; i. e., a man looking at the setting sun. (Z, TA.) And dalakati AlmaroOapu AlEajiyna [The woman kneaded the dough]. (TA.) And dalakotu Aln-aEola biAlOaroDi I wiped the sandal with [meaning upon] the ground. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] dalakahu Ald-ahoru ‡ Time, or fortune, disciplined him well, tried, or proved, him, rendered him expert, or experienced, or firm or sound in judgment, and taught him. (Ḳ,* TA.) And dalakatohu AlOasofaAru ‡ Journeyings inured him to them; namely, a camel. (TA.) And dulika biAlOasofaAri, said of a camel, (A, O, L, Ḳ,) ‡ He was inured by journeyings, and habituated thereto: (A, L:) or he was fatigued, or jaded, by journeyings; like [duk-a and] kud-a. (O, TA.)
[Hence also,] dulikati AlOaroDu † [The produce, or herbage, of] the land was eaten, or consumed. (IAạr, TA.)
See also 3.

dalakati AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yadoluku}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. duluwkN, (Ṣ, Mgh, &c.,) ‡ The sun set; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) accord. to Z, because he who looks at it rubs (yadoluku) his eyes, so that it is as though it were the rubber; (TA;) and in like manner, Aln-ujuwmu the stars: (Mṣb:) or became yellow, (Ḳ, TA,) and inclined to setting: (TA:) or declined (Ḳ,* TA) so that the beholder almost required, when looking at it, to contract the rays from his eyes with the palm of his hand: (TA:) or declined after midday: (Ibn-ʼOmar, TA:) or it signifies (or signifies also, Mṣb) the sun declined from the meridian, or midheaven, (I’Ab, Fr, Zj, Az, Ṣ,* Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) at noon; (I’Ab, Fr, Zj, Az;) and in like manner, Aln-ujuwmu the stars. (Mṣb.) Az says that, in his opinion, the words of the Ḳur [xvii. 80] Oaqima QlS-alaApa liduluwki AlX-amosi (TA) mean Perform thou prayer from the declining of the sun at noon: so that the command expressed by these words with what follows them includes the five prayers: (Mgh,* TA:) for by the dlwk are included the first prayer [of noon] and that of the EaSor; and by the gasaq of night, the two prayers [of sunset and nightfall] of which each is called EiXaMC; and by the quroMn of the fajor, the prayer of daybreak: if you make the dlwk to be the setting, the command is restricted to three prayers: in the language of the Arabs, duluwkN is said to be syn. with zawaAlN; and therefore the sun is said to be daAlikapN when it is declining at noon and when it is setting. (TA.) [Respecting the phrase dalakato baraAHi or biraAHi, accord. to different readings, occurring at the end of a verse, see baraAHi, and see also raAHapN in art. rwH.] It is said in [one of the works entitled] the “Nawádir el-Aaráb,” that dalakati AlX-amosu signifies The sun became high; like damakat and Ealat and AiEotalat. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.
Accord. to AA, dal-akahaA, inf. n. tadoliykN, signifies gac-aAhaA [He fed, nourished, or reared, her (if relating to a woman or female), or them (if relating to irrational creatures)]. (TA.)

3. dAlkhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mudaAlakapN, (TA,) He delayed, or deferred, with him, or put him off, (namely, his creditor, Ṣ, TA,) promising him payment time after time; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also daAEakahu. (TA.) El-Ḥasan (El-Basree, TA) was asked, OayudaAliku Alr-ajulu QmoraOatahu [May the man delay, or defer, with his wife?], meaning, in the matter of the dowry; and he answered, “Yes, if he be in a state of bankruptcy,” or “poor.” (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA.) And you say likewise, dalaka↓ Alr-ajula Haq-ahu He deferred, or put off, by repeated promises, giving the man his right, or due. (TA.)
The inf. n. also signifies The vying in patience: or, as some say, the importuning, pressing hard, or urging, in demanding the giving, or payment, of a due or debt. (TA.)

5. tdl-k He rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, his body in washing himself: (Ṣ:) or he rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, himself well in the hot bath. (MA.) And tdl-k bihi He rubbed himself over (taxal-aqa) with it; i. e., with daluwk [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
8: see 1, third sentence.

hom.sense: dalakN The time of the setting of the sun: or of its declining from the meridian: one says, Oatayotuka EinodaAld-alaki, meaning I came to thee in the evening, or afternoon. (TA.)
Also A looseness, or laxness, in-the knees of a camel. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dulakapN A certain little beast or animal or creeping thing or an insect (duwayob-apN): (Ḳ:) mentioned by IDrd: but he says “I am not certain of it.” (TA.)

daluwkN A thing with which one rubs himself over, (Ḳ, TA,) in washing himself; (TA;) meaning perfume, or some other thing, (Ṣ, TA,) of what are termed gasuwlaAt, such as [meal of] lentils, and kali, or potash, (TA,) with which one is rubbed. (Ṣ, TA.*) Also applied to [The depilatory called] nuwrap [q. v.]; because the body is rubbed with it in the hot bath. (A, TA.) And The foot-stone [or foot-rasp] that is used for rubbing in the hot bath. (MA.)

hom.sense: daliykN Dust which the wind carries away [as though it were rubbed from the ground]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

A certain food, prepared of butter and dates, [app. kneaded, or mashed, together,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like variyd [q. v.]: I think [says J] that it is what is called in Persian JanokaAl xusot [or JanoGaAl xiXot?]: (Ṣ, TA:) accord. to Z, tamorN daliykN signifies mariys [i. e. dates macerated, and mashed with the hand, or moistened, and rubbed and pressed with the fingers till soft, in water or in milk]. (TA.) [See also daliykapN.]

‡ A man (Ḳ, TA) rendered firm, or sound, in judgment, by experience; (TA;) one who has exercised himself diligently in the management of affairs, (Ḳ, TA,) and known them: (TA:) pl. dulukN, (Ḳ,) which is explained by IAạr as signifying intelligent men. (TA.)
A certain plant: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {daliykapN}. (TA.)

And The [hip, or] fruit of the [wild] red rose, that comes after it, [i. e. after the flower,] (Ḳ, TA,) becoming red, like wheat, and ripening, (TA,) and becoming sweet, like the fresh ripe date; called in Syria Suromu Ald-iyoki: (Ḳ, TA:) n. un. with p {daliykapN}: (TA:) or [the fruit of] the mountainrose Alwarod AljabaliI- [a name now given to the wild rose, or sweet brier], like wheat bur- [in the CK busor] in size and redness, and like the fresh ripe date in sweetness: in El-Yemen it is sent from one to another as a present: (Ḳ, TA:) Az says, so I have heard from an Arab of the desert, of the people of El-Yemen; and it grows with us [app. meaning in El-'Irák] so as to form thickets. (TA.)

entry.sense: dulaAkapN What is drawn from the udder before the first fiyqap [or milk that collects in the udder between two milkings], (Ḳ,) and before the second fyqp collects. (TA.)

daliykapN i. q. HayosN [which is generally described as Dates mixed with clarified butter and the preparation of dried curd called OaqiT, kneaded, or rubbed and pressed with the hand until they mingle together, whereupon their stones come forth]. (A, TA.) [See also daliykN.]
dal-aAkN One who rubs, or rubs and presses, the body in the hot bath. (TA.)

hom.sense: duWoluwkN A case, or an affair, of great magnitude, or gravity, or moment: pl. daMliyku. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) You say, tarakotuhumo fiI duWoluwkK [I left them in, or engaged in, a case, or an affair, of great magnitude,, &c.]. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: Ald-awaAliyku The act of urging, or pressing forward, and striving, (taHaf-uzN,) in gait, or pace, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) and parting the legs widely (taHay-ukN) [therein]; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA;) as also Ald-aMliyku↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) A poet uses the phrase yamoXiI Ald-awaAliyka [Walking, or going, with urging,, &c.]. (TA.) [See also dawaAlayoka, in art. dwl.]

mudolikN [so in the TA, but probably it should be midolakN, agreeably with analogy,] Much given to delaying, or deferring, with a creditor, or putting him off, in the matter of a debt, by promising payment time after time. (Fr, TA.)
madoluwkN [Rubbed, or rubbed and pressed, with the hand:, &c.: see its verb, 1:]
[and] polished. (TA.)
[Hence,] applied to a horse, i. q. madokuwkN; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. ‡ Having no prominence of his Hajabap: (TA:) or so madoluwku AlHajabapi: (Ṣ:) and [so] madoluwku AlHaroqafapi. (TA.)

Applied to a camel, it means dulika biAlOasofaAri, (Ḳ,) i. e. ‡ Inured by journeyings, and habituated thereto: (A, L:) or fatigued, or jaded, by journeyings: (O, TA:) or having a looseness, or laxness, in his knees. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
OaroDN madoluwkapN † Land [of which the produce, or herbage, is] eaten, or consumed. (IAạr, TA.)
mudaAlikN Any one who delays, defers, or puts off, by repeated promises. (TA.)

One who does not hold himself above a low, or an ignoble, action. (Fr, TA.) IF says, in the “Makáyees,” [but the remark does not universally hold good,] that every word commencing with d and l denotes motion, coming and going, and removal from place to place. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. dalima, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadolamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dalamN, (M,) He, or it, was, or became, intensely black, and smooth; (M, Ḳ;) said of a man and a lion (M, TA) and an ass (TA) and a mountain and a rock; (M, TA;) as also AdlAm-↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter, inf. n. AidoliymaAmN he, or it, was, or became, black; said of a man and an ass [&c.]. (Ṣ. [Golius erroneously assigns this signification to Adl-m as on the authority of the Ṣ.]) And AidolaOam-a↓ All-ayolu [so in the TA and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, but in the CK AdolAm-a↓,] i. q. Aidolaham-a [i. e. The night was, or became, black; or intensely dark]; (Ḳ;) the h being a substitute for h. (TA.)

dalimato XifaAhuhu, inf. n. dalamN, His lips were, or became, flaccid and pendulous. (Ḳ,* TA. [Golius assigns this signification also to Adlm-↓, but without indicating any authority.]) [See also dFlamN below.]

entry.sense: 9: see 1. [Also mistaken by Golius for AdlAm-.]
11: see 1, in two places.
4. AidolaOam-a: see 1.

dalamN A certain thing resembling the serpent, found in El-Ḥijáz: (Ḳ:) or resembling what is termed the Tab-uwE; not a serpent: (TA:) or it signifies, (TA,) or thus dulamN↓, (so in the T accord. to the TT,) the young one of a serpent: and the pl. is OadolaAmN. (T, TA.) Hence the prov., huwa OaXad-u mina Ald-alami [He is more distressing than the dlm]: (Ḳ:) and one says also, huwa OaXad-u mina Ald-alami fiI AlX-afapi, meaning [He is more distressing] than flaccidity and pendulousness in the lip. (This, as well as the former saying, being mentioned in the TA, as from the Ḳ.)
dulamN The elephant; (Ḳ;) because of his blackness. (TA.)
See also dalamN.
dulomapN Intense blackness, with smoothness; like guboXapN; in the colours of beasts or horses and the like [&c.: see 1]. (TA in art. gbX.)
dalaAmN Blackness. (Seer, M, Ḳ.)
And the same, (Ḳ,) or dulaAmN↓, (M, accord. to the TT, in two places,) Black: (M, Ḳ:) mentioned by Sb. (M.) [See also Oadolamu.]
dulaAmN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: dayolamN The blacks, or negroes. (T, TA. [But Ald-ayolamu is more commonly known as the name of a certain people to be mentioned in what follows.])

The Abyssinian, i. e. black, ant: (M:) or, as some say, (M,) a place where ants and ticks collect, at the places where the camels stand when they come to drink at the watering-troughs, and where they lie down at the watering-places: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) [or] ants [themselves]; (T, TA;) and ticks; both said by Z to be so called because they are enemies to the camels [from a signification of the same word to be mentioned below]: (TA:) or numerous ants. (Ḥar p. 586.)
† An army; likened to ants in respect of its numerousness: (TA:) or a numerous army. (T.)
† An assembly, or assemblage, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or a numerous assembly or assemblage, (TA,) of men, (Ṣ, TA,) and of things of any kind. (M, TA.)
Camels [collectively]. (TA.)

† Enemies: (ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and an enemy: pl. dayaAlimapN: so called because the people named Ald-ayolamu are notorious for evil and enmity: (Z, TA:) because the dayolam are enemies to the Arabs: (M:) they are a certain people, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) well known; (M, Ḳ;) [inhabitants of a mountainous tract, a part of the ancient Media, on the south of the Caspian Sea;] called by Kr the turok [or Turks]; (M;) but accord. to the opinion commonly held by the genealogists, (TA,) they are said to be of the descendants of Dabbeh Ibn-Udd, whom some of the kings of the 'Ajam [or Persians] placed in those mountains [which their posterity inhabit], and who there multiplied: (T, TA:) or Ald-ayolamu is a surname of the Benoo-Dabbeh, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) because of their blackness, (Ḳ,) or because they, or the generality of them, are dulom [pl. of Oadolamu]. (Ṣ.)
[Hence, perhaps,] dayolamN also signifies † A calamity, or misfortune. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also The male of the dur-aAj [i. e. attagen, francolin, heath-cock, or rail]. (Ḳṭr, Kr, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
And A species of [the bird called] the qaTaA: or the male thereof [like dalohamN]. (Ḳ.)
Also The tree called salaAm, (T, Ḳ,) which grows in the mountains. (T.)

entry.sense: Oadolamu, applied to a man (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and an ass (Ṣ) and a lion (M, Ḳ) and a horse (TA) and a mountain (M, Ḳ) and a rock, (M,) Black: (Ṣ: [see also dalaAmN:]) or intensely black, and smooth: (M, Ḳ:) or, as some say, (so in the M, but accord. to the Ḳ “and,”) i. q. Mdamu [q. v.]: (M, Ḳ:) or, applied to a man, tall and black; and in like manner applied to a mountain, but as meaning, with smoothness, and not intensely black, in its rock: or, accord. to IAạr, i. q. Oadogamu [q. v.]: (T:) pl. dulomN, (Ṣ, TA,) which is also applied to mules as meaning black. (TA.)
Also A black serpent. (T.)

And i. q. OaranodajN [Black leather, or a black skin or hide]. (Sh, T, Ḳ.) So, accord. to Sh, in the saying of 'Antarah,
walaqado hamamotu bigaArapK fiI layolapK
sawodaMCa HaAlikapK kalawoni AlOadolami
[And verily I purposed a hostile incursion in a night intensely black, like the colour of black leather]. (T.)
[Hence,] by way of comparison, one says layolN Oadolamu [meaning † Black, or intensely dark, night]. (TA.)
Ald-alomaMCu [fem. of AlOadolamu] † The thirtieth night (Ḳ, TA) of the [lunar] month: because of its blackness. (TA.)
dalomaSa and tadalomaSa and dulamiSN and dulaAmiSN: see art. dlS.

1. daliha, aor. _a {yadolahu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. dalahN (JK, Ḳ, TḲ) and duluwhN, (Ḳ, TḲ,) He (a man, TḲ) became bereft of his heart, or mind, or reason, in consequence of anxiety and the like; (JK, Ḳ,* TḲ;) as when a man's mind is confounded, or perplexed, so that he cannot see his right course, (ydlh, [app. for yudal-ahu↓,]) in consequence of excessive love of a woman, or from some other cause; (TA;) or like as is the woman for her child (kamaA tudal-ahu↓ AlmaroOapu EalaI waladihaA) when she has lost it: (JK:) and dul-iha↓,
also, (JK,) inf. n. tadoliyhN; (JK, Ṣ;) and tdl-h↓; (Ḳ;) signify he became bereft of his heart, or mind, or reason, (JK, Ṣ,* Ḳ,) in consequence of anxiety, (JK,) or love, or desire, (Ṣ,) or excessive love of a woman: (Ḳ:) [or] daliha aor. _a {yadolahu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. dalahN; (TA;) and tdl-h↓; (TA;) he became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in consequence of love, (Ṣ,) or excessive love of a woman, and anxiety: (TA:) or the former of these two verbs signifies he became insane, or bereft of reason, in consequence of excessive love of a woman, or from grief: (Ḳ:) and dul-iha↓, he (a man) was caused to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (TA.)

dalaha, aor. _a {yadolahu}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. duluwhN, (M, TA,) or dalohN, (TḲ,) He became free from care, or thought; or became diverted [Eano XaIoCK from a thing] so as to be free from care [respecting it]. (M, Ḳ.) And dalihato Eano UilofihaA, and Eano waladihaA, (so in three copies of the Ṣ,) or dalahato, (thus in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) aor. _a {yadolahu}, inf. n. duluwhN, She (a camel) scarcely ever, or never, yearned towards her mate, or fellow, and her young one. (AZ, Ṣ.)

2. dl-hhu, inf. n. tadoliyhN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of love, (Ṣ,) or of excessive love of a woman, (Ḳ,) and of anxiety, (TA,) It bereft him of his heart, or mind, or reason: (Ḳ:) or caused him to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (Ṣ, TA.) See also 1, in four places.
5: see 1, in two places.
cahaba damuhu dalohFA His blood went for nothing; as a thing of no account, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
daluwhN A she-camel that scarcely ever, or never, yearns towards her mate, or fellow, or her young one: so says AZ in the “Book of Camels.” (Ṣ.)
daAlihN and daAlihapN, (Ḳ,) each applied to a man, (TA,) [but the latter is of a form denoting intensiveness of signification,] Weak-minded. (Ḳ.)

mudal-ahN Bereft of his heart, or mind, or reason, in consequence of anxiety [&c.]: (JK:) or heedless in heart, bereft of reason, in consequence of excessive love of a woman, and the like: or one who will not keep, or retain, in his mind, or memory, (laA yaHofaZu,) what he does or what is done to him: (Ḳ:) and one going to and fro in confusion, or perplexity, not knowing his right course. (TA.)

Q. 4. Aidolaham-a It (the night) was, or became, black; (TA;) or intensely dark: (Mgh:) and AidolaOam-a signifies the same; (Ḳ and TA in art. dlm;) the C being a substitute for h. (TA in that art.) And It (darkness) was, or became, dense, or thick. (Ḳ.) See the next paragraph.
Also He (a man) was, or became, aged; and so Aidolahan-a. (Ḳ in art. dlhn.)
dalohamN Dark. (Ḳ.) You say layolN dalohamN Dark night: (TA:) and layolapN mudolahim-apN↓ A dark night. (Ṣ, TA.)

And Deprived of his reason by love: (Ḳ:) a signification which shows the m to be augmentative; for it is from Ald-alahu: or, accord. to IḲṭṭ and others, the l in Adlhm-↓ is augmentative; for, they say, it is from Ald-uhomapu: either opinion is allowable. (TA.)
Also The wolf. (Ḳ.)
And The male of [the bird called] the qaTaA [like dayolamN]. (Ḳ.)
dilohaAmN A man who is penetrating, sharp, vigorous, and effective. (Ḳ.)
And A lion. (Ḳ.)
mudolahimN Densely black. (TA.) And Oasowadu mudolahimN Intensely black. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) See also dalohamN.
falaApN mudolahim-apN [A desert, or waterless desert,] in which are no signs of the way. (TA.)

1. dalaA Ald-alowa, (Mgh, Ḳ, [in the CK, dal-AhA is erroneously put for dalaAhaA,]) [and dalaA biAld-alowi,] first pers. dalawotu Ald-alowa, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and dalawotu biAld-alowi, (Mṣb,) aor., first pers., Oadoluw, inf. n. dalowN; (T;) and AdlI↓ Ald-alowa; (Mgh; [the only authority that I find for the latter verb in the sense here explained;]) He pulled the dalow [or bucket] up, or out, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) from the well, (T, Mgh,) full: (T, Mgh:) or he pulled the dlw to make it come forth. (Ḳ.) Hence, i. e. from AdlI Aldlw as explained above, the saying, in a trad., if it be correct, waraduwA maMCK fasaOaluwA Oaholahu Oano yudoluwhumo↓ Eani AlmaMCa [They came to water, and they asked its owners to draw for them from the water]; for yudoluwA lahumo, or yudoluwA dalowahumo. (Mgh.) And Oadoluw HaAjatiI, from dalawotu Ald-alowa explained above, means † I seek, or demand, the accomplishment of my want: (Ḥam p. 500:) or dalaA HaAjatahu means † He sought, or demanded, the object of his want. (TA.) And dalawotu bifulaAnK Uilayoka, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ I begged, or beg, such a one to make intercession for me to thee. (Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence also,] dalaA † He drove, or urged on: (IAạr, T:) or did so gently; for dalowN [the inf. n.] means the driving, or urging on, gently. (M.) You say, dalawotu Aln-aAqapa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. Oadoluw, (TA,) inf. n. dalowN, (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ I made the she-camel to go gently, or leisurely. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

And dalawotuhu and daAlayotuhu↓ ‡ I was gentle with him; namely, a man; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) treated him with gentleness or blandishment, soothed him, coaxed him, or wheedled him; (Ṣ, TA; and Ḳ in art. dlI [in which, as is said in the TḲ, daAwayotuhu is erroneously put, in some copies, for daArayotuhu];) endeavoured to conciliate him. (TA.)
See also 4, in three places.

2. tadoliyapN [inf. n. of dl-I] signifies The lowering a thing; like UidolaMCN↓ [inf. n. of 4]. (Bḍ in vii. 21.) You say, dl-I AlX-aIoCa fiI mahowaApK He let down the thing, made it to hang down, or let it fall, into a pit or the like. (T,* M, TA.) And dal-aAhu mino saToHK biHabolK He let him, or it, down from a house-top by means of a rope. (Mgh.) And dl-I rijolayohi mina Als-ariyri [He hung down his legs from the couch]; and AdlI↓ occurs in the same sense. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., dul-iIa EalaI-a jiraAbN mino XaHomK mino baEoDi HuSuwni xayobara, meaning [A bag, or provision-bag, of fat] was let down, or let fall, upon me [from one of the forts of Kheyber]. (Mgh.) See also 4.
And dl-I AlX-aIoCa He made, or brought, or drew, the thing near to another thing (mino gayorihi); like UidolaMCu↓ Ald-alowi. (Ḥar p. 173.)
3. daAlayotuhu: see 1.

4. Oadolayotu, [in the CK, erroneously, dalayotu,] and dalawotu↓ (Ḳ;) or Oadolayotu Ald-alowa, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UidolaMCN; (T, Mṣb;) and dalawotu↓ Ald-alowa, [and app. biAld-alowi,] aor. Oadoluw, [inf. n. dalowN;] (T,* Mṣb;) I let down the dalow [or bucket] (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) into the well, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) to fill it, (T,) or to draw water with it. (M, Mṣb.) Oadoli dalowaka fiI Ald-ilaMCi [Let down thy bucket with the other buckets] is a prov. used in urging [a person] to strive, or labour, for gain; (TA;) originating from a company's assembling at a well, and letting down their buckets in order that every one of them may take his share of the water, or what is easily procurable by him thereof: meaning, use means to acquire, like as do others. (Ḥar p. 167.) See also 2, in four places.

Hence, (Mgh,) AdlI biHuj-atihi ‡ He adduced his plea, or the like, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) correctly, or validly; (T;) or he defended himself by adducing it or urging it: (Ṣ:) or he established his plea, or the like, and so obtained his claim or demand or suit. (Mṣb.) And in like manner you say, AdlI biHaq-ihi ‡ [He urged, or established, his right or due]. (TA.)

And AdlI bimaAlihi ‡ He gave, (dafaEa, M, Ḳ, TA,) or presented, or offered, (rafaEa, Ṣ, TA,) his property, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) Uilayohi [to him], (M,) or AlI AlHaAkima [to the judge]. (Ṣ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [ii. 184], watudoluwA bihaA UilaI AlHuk-aAmi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. ‡ And [do not] give it, or offer it, as a bribe to the judges: (Ṣ,* TA:) or and do not endeavour to conciliate with it the judges in order that they may cut off for you what is the right of others: (T:) or and do not throw it to the judges to be decided by them, (Mgh, Bḍ, Jel,) or as a bribe. (Jel.) And in a letter of ʼOmar, faQfohamo UicaA OudoliIa Uilayoka And understand thou when an application is made to thee by litigants for the decision of a cause. (Mgh.)

And AdlI biraHimihi ‡ He sought to bring himself near, to approach, or to gain access, [UilaI gayorihi to another,] by means of his relationship: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and he pleaded, or made intercession, thereby. (TA.) waqado dalawonaA↓ bihi Uilayoka, in a prayer for rain, of ʼOmar, referring to El-ʼAbbás, i. e., accord. to the “Ghareebeyn,” † And we have sought to approach, or to gain access, to Thee by him, app. means that they sought to obtain the mercy and aid of God [by means of his intercession], like as one seeks to get at, or obtain, the water by means of the dalow [or bucket]. (M.) One says also, OadolaI UilaI Almay-ati biAlbunuw-api wanaHowihaA, meaning † He was united to the dead by sonship, and the like; from UidolaMCu Ald-alowi. (Mṣb.) And fulaAnN yudoliI UilaI Almay-iti bicakirK † Such a one is united with the dead by a male. (Mgh.)
AdlI fiyhi means ‡ He said of him what was evil, or foul. (M, Ḳ.)
And AdlI said of a horse, &c., He put forth his yard, for the purpose of staling or covering; (M, Ḳ;) as also dl-I↓ said of an ass, as is also the former verb. (M.)
See also 1, first and second sentences.

5. tdl-I It was let down or lowered; it hung down, or dangled; it was let down; (T,* M, Mgh;) into, and over, a pit or the like; (M;) it hung (Ḳ) from (mino) a tree; (Ṣ, Ḳ) it hung down as a fruit [from a tree]. (Bḍ in liii. 8.) [Hence,] tdl-I EalayonaA mino OaroDi kacaA [He, or it, came down, or descended, upon us from such a land]. (TA.) And tdl-I biAlX-ar-i He descended upon one with evil, or mischief. (TA.)

Also He drew near, or approached: (Ḳ in art. dlI:) or he drew near, or approached, [from above, or] after being high. (IAạr, T.) Accord. to Fr, vum-a danaA fatadal-aI [in the Ḳur liii. 8] means vam-a tadal-aI fadanaA, (T,) i. e. Then he (Gabriel) hung down from the highest region of the sky, and so drew near to the Apostle: showing that he took him up without becoming separated from his place: or the meaning of the phrase, as it stands, is, then he drew near to the Prophet, and he clung to him: (Bḍ:) but accord. to Zj, it means then he drew near, and drew nearer; and is like the phrase danaA fulaAnN min-iI waqaruba. (T. [See also another explanation in what follows.])
And He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; or he lowered, humbled, or abased, himself. (IAạr, T; and Ḳ in art. dlI.)

In the saying of a poet,
kaOana raAkibahaA guSonN bimarowaHapK
UicaA tadal-ato bihi Oawo XaAribN vamilN
tdl-t may be quasi-pass. of dalaA, inf. n. dalowN, signifying “he drove, or urged on, gently:” or it may be for tadal-alato: [so that the meaning may be, As though her rider were a branch of a tree in a place over which the wind was blowing, when she became urged on gently with him, or an intoxicated drinker: or, when she emboldened herself with him,, &c.:] (M:) [for] tadal-aI is also syn. with tadal-ala: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and [J says that] this is its meaning in the saying in the Ḳur [otherwise explained above] vum-a danaA fatadal-aI: being like yatamaT-aI in the Ḳur [lxxv. 33], i. e. yatamaT-aTu. (Ṣ.)
12. AidolawolaI, of the measure AifoEawoEala, He hastened, made haste, sped, or went quickly; (Ṣ;) [like AclwlI.]
dalFA: see what next follows.

dalowN [A bucket, generally of leather;] a certain thing with which one draws water; (Ṣ, TA;) a vessel with which one draws water from a well; (KL;) well known; (T, Ḳ;) in Pers. dwl [i. e. duwlo, pronounced “dól”]: (MA:) masc. and fem.; (M;) sometimes masc.; (Ḳ;) mostly fem., (M, Mṣb,) and thus accord. to the more approved usage: (M:) pl. (of pauc., T, Ṣ, Mṣb) OadolK, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure OafoEulN, [originally OadoluwN,] (Ṣ,) and (of mult., T,* Ṣ, Mṣb) dilaMCN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and duliI-N, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is of the measure fuEuwlN (Ṣ, Mṣb) originally, (Mṣb,) and diliI-N (T, M, Ḳ, omitted in the CK) and duliy-apN, omitted here by the author of the Ḳ but mentioned by him in art. nHw, (TA,) and dalaA↓; (Ḳ; [there said to be like EalaI; but correctly dalFA;]) or dalFA is syn. with dilaMCN, and its sing. [or n. un.] is dalaApN↓; (Ṣ, M;) like as that of falFA is falaApN; (M;) [for] dalaApN is syn. with dalowN: (T:) or dalaApN signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (M,) a small dalow. (M, Ḳ. [But in the M, in one place, it seems to be stated that, accord. to some, dalaApN and dalFA signify the same, in a pl. sense: for, after the pls. of dalowN, it is added, wahiIa Ald-alaApu waAld-alaA. I think, however, that he who first said this meant thereby that Ald-alaApu and Ald-alaA signify, respectively, the same as Ald-alowu and Ald-ilaMCu, &c.]) [Hence the saying, OatobiEi Ald-alowa riXaMCahaA: see 4 in art. tbE.] As masc., it has for its dim. dul-aI-N↓: as fem., dulay-apN↓. (Mṣb.) See also daAliyapN.
And hence, (M,) Ald-alowu ‡ [The sign of Aquarius;] one of the signs of the Zodiac. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
And † The hopper of a mill. (Golius on the authority of Meyd.)
And † A certain mark made with a hot iron upon camels; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) app. in the form of a dalow [properly so called]. (TA.)
And † Calamity, misfortune, or mischief. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the saying, jaMCa fulaAnN biAld-alowi † [Such a one brought calamity,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
dalaApN: see the next preceding paragraph.

[Hence,] † A share, or portion: so in the saying of a rájiz,
Mlayotu laA OuEoTiIa gulaAmFA OabadaA
dalaAtahu Uin-iI OuHib-u AlOasowadaA
meaning [I have sworn, or, emphatically, I swear, I will not give a boy, ever,] his share, or portion, of love, or affection: [verily I love El-Aswad:] El-Aswad was the name of his son. (Ṣ, TA.)
dulaI-N: see dalowN, of which they are dims.
dulay-apN: see dalowN, of which they are dims.
daAlK Pulling up, or out, a dalow [or bucket] from a well: (T:) and occurring in poetry in the sense of mudolK [meaning letting down a dalow into a well]: (Ṣ:) pl. dulaApN. (TA.)

daAliyapN A [water-wheel, or machine for irrigating land, such as is called] manojanuwn, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) that is turned by an ox or a cow: (Ṣ:) and [such as is called] a naAEuwrap: (Ḳ:) or the nAEwrp is turned by water: (Ṣ:) and a thing made of palm-leaves (M, Ḳ) and pieces of wood, with which water is drawn [for irrigating land] by means of ropes, or cords, (M,) [app. held and drawn at one end by a man, and at the other end] tied to a tall palm-trunk: (M, Ḳ:) it is a bucket (dalow), and the like, with pieces of wood made in the form of a cross, [i. e. with two pieces of wood placed across and so tied together,] the two arms of which are bound to the top [or rim] of the bucket; them one end of a rope is tied to it, and the other end to a palm-trunk standing at the head of the well; and one irrigates [land] with it [app. by drawing and swinging it up by means of another, or of the same, rope]: the word is of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN [because it is pulled up]: the pl. is dawaAlK: El-Fárábee deviates from others, by explaining it as meaning a manojanuwn; and J follows him: (Mṣb:) [a similar apparatus for irrigating land is used in the northern parts of Egypt, called qaTowap and dalow↓: it consists of a bowl-shaped bucket, with four cords attached to its rim: two men, each holding two of the cords, throw up the water by means of it into a trough or trench: accord. to Mṭr,] the daAliyap is a tall palm-trunk set in the manner of the machine with which rice is beaten [to remove the husks], having at its head a large bowl, with which water is drawn [for irrigating land]. (Mgh.)
Also Land that is irrigated by means of the dalow [or bucket] or the [machine called] manojanuwn [mentioned above]. (M, Ḳ.)
And the pl., dawaAlK, Unripe dates hung, and eaten when they become ripe. (T, Ḳ.) Hung fruit. (Bḍ in liii. 8. [But perhaps Alvmr is there a mistranscription for Alt-moru.])

Also (i. e. the pl.) Black grapes, but not intensely black, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) the bunches of which are the largest of all bunches, appearing like goats hung [upon the vines]: the berries thereof are coarse, breaking in the mouth, and round; and are dried. (AḤn, M.) [See also dawaAliI-u, in art. dwAl.]
[The sing. also signifies A grape-vine itself: and a shoot of a grape-vine: pl. as above.]
1. daliIa, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadolaIu}, inf. n. dalFA, (TḲ,) He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)
3. mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ: see art. dlw.
5. mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ: see art. dlw.

hom.sense:
1. dam-a, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yadomumu}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. dam-N, (T, M, Mṣb,)
He smeared, or did over, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,*) or the face, (Mṣb,) with any kind of dye [or the like]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and a house, or chamber, with [plaster of] gypsum, (T, M, Ḳ,) or with mud or clay, (T,) and with [a wash of] quick lime: (TA:) and a ship with tar: (M, Ḳ:) and an eye, externally, (Lth, T, Ḳ,) or a pained eye, externally, (M,) with a dimaAm, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ,) i. e. any medicinal liniment, (Lth, T,) such as aloes, and saffron; (TA;) as also dm-m↓: (Kr, M, Ḳ:) [or this latter, probably, has an intensive signification: see also R. Q. 1:] and dam-ato, aor. and inf. n. as above, said of a woman, she smeared the parts around her eye with aloes or saffron: (M:) or dam-ati AlEayona she applied a collyrium to the eye; or smeared it with a dimaAm. (Mṣb.) You say also, dam-a Alqidori, aor. and inf. n. as above, He smeared, or did over, the [stone] cooking-pot with blood or spleen, [or with liver, (see damiymN,)] after repairing it: (Lḥ, M:) and dum-at it (the [stone] cooking-pot) was smeared, or done over, with blood or spleen [or liver], after it had been repaired: (T:) or was plastered with mud or clay, and with gypsum. (TA.) And dam-a AlS-adoEi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He smeared over the crack with blood and burnt hair mixed together; as also dam-amahu↓. (M.)

[Hence,] dum-a biAlX-aHomi, said of a camel, &c., † He was, or became, loaded [or overspread] with fat; syn. Oawoqara or Ouwoqira. (So accord. to different copies of the Ṣ.) And dum-a [alone], inf. n. as above, ‡ He (a camel) had much fat and flesh, so that one could not feel in him the prominence of a bone. (T, TA.) And dum-a wajohuhu HusonFA † His face was [flushed,] as though it were overspread, with beauty. (M.)

[Hence also,] bima dam-ato EayonaAhaA, [so I find it written, but I think it should be dum-ato,] meaning ‡ What did she bring forth? or what has she brought forth? a male or a female? and dm-t fulaAnapu bigulaAmK [the verb (here written without any vowel-sign) being app. dum-ato, meaning dum-ato EayonaAhaA, because offspring, and especially boys, are among the things by which the eye is said to be refreshed, as it is by the application of a dimaAm,] ‡ Such a woman brought forth a boy. (TA.)

dam-a AlOaroDa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He made the earth, or ground, even, (M, Ḳ,) as is done after turning it over for sowing. (M.) And dam-a juHorahu, said of the Jerboa, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (T,) It stopped up the mouth of its hole with its nabiyXap [or earth which it had extracted]: (T:) or it filled up its hole with earth: (Ṣ:) or it covered over its hole and made it even. (M, Ḳ.) And dam-a AlkamoOapa He made the earth, or dust, even over the truffles. (Ḳ.) And damamotu EalaI AlX-aIoCi I covered over the thing; (T, TA;) as also damamotu AlX-aIoCa: (Ḥam p. 461: [see also R. Q. 1:]) and in like manner, damamotu Ealayohi Alqabora [I covered up the grave over him]: and damodamotu↓ EalaI AlX-aIoCi I buried the thing, making the ground even over it. (T, TA.*)

dam-ahu, (Ḳ,) or dam-a raOosahu, (T, M,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) † He broke his head: (M, Ḳ:) or he struck, or beat, and broke, his head: (T:) or it signifies, accord. to Lḥ, (M,) or signifies also, (Ḳ,) he struck, or beat, his head, (M, Ḳ,) whether he broke it or not. (M.) And dam-a Zahorahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, ‡ He struck, or beat, his back with a brick, (M, TA,) and with a staff or stick, or with a stone: a tropical meaning, as is said in the A. (TA.)

dam-ahumo, (Lḥ, T, M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Lḥ, T, M,) and so the inf. n., (M,) † He crushed them (TaHanahumo), and destroyed them; (Lḥ, T, M, Ḳ;) as also damodamahumo↓, and damodama↓ EalayohimN: (M, Ḳ:) or this last (dmdm Elyhm) signifies He (God) destroyed them: and damodamotu↓ AlX-aIoCa, I made the thing to cleave to the ground, and scattered it, or broke it, destroying it. (Ṣ.) fadamodama↓ EalayohimN rab-uhumo, (M, TA,) in the Ḳur [xci. 14], (TA,) means And their Lord crushed them (TaHanahumo), and destroyed them: (M, TA:) or made punishment to fall, or come, upon them in common, or universally; expl. by OaTobaqa Ealayohimu AlEacaAba: (Zj, T, Bḍ, Jel, TA:) or made the earth to quake with them: (Fr, T, TA:) or was angry with them: (IAmb, T:) or spoke to them in anger: (TA:) for [the inf. n.] damodamapN signifies the being angry: (M, Ḳ:) and the speaking so as to disquiet, or agitate, a man: (T, TA:) and damodama Ealayohi he spoke to him in anger. (M, Ḳ.) You say also, dam-a fulaAnFA, meaning He (a man, IAạr, T) punished such a one fully, or completely; (IAạr, T, Ḳ;) as also damodamahu↓: (TA:) [or perhaps damodama Ealayohi; for Az says, in another place, at the close of this art.,] IAar says that damodama signifies he punished fully, or completely; or inflicted a full, or complete, punishment. (T.)
dam-a AlHijora, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) said of a stallion horse, He leaped the mare. (Ḳ.)

dam-a, (M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) also signifies He hastened; syn. OasoraEa [app. in a trans. sense; for otherwise, accord. to rule, the aor. should be yadim-u, with kesr]. (M, Ḳ, TA. In the CK, [erroneously,] AaSoraEa.)

dam-a; (T, Mṣb;) sec. pers. damamota, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,)) aor. _i {yadomimu} (Ks, Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yadomumu}; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and damimota, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadomamu}; (AZ, T, Mṣb;) and damumota, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) aor. _u {yadomumu}; (T, Mṣb;) inf. n. (of the last, TA, or of all, M) damaAmapN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) the last of these verbs mentioned by IḲṭṭ on the authority of Kh; (TA;) and [said to be] the only instance of its kind, among reduplicative verbs, (T, Mṣb, TA,) except labubota and Xarurota (Mṣb, TA) and fakukota, mentioned in the Ḳ, and Eazuzati AlX-aApu, mentioned by IKh; (TA;) He (a man, T, Ṣ, Mṣb) was, or became, such as is termed damiym [q. v.]: (Ks, Lḥ, T, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or he did evil; syn. OasaMCa. (M, Ḳ. [See also 4.])

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.

4. Adm- He did what was bad, evil, abominable, or foul; syn. OaqobaHa (Lth, T, Ḳ) and OasaMCa: (Lth, T: [see also 1, last sentence: in the Ḳ, also, and in the M, the sec. pers., Oadomamota, is explained as meaning OaqobaHota AlfiEola, which is a pleonasm for OaqobaHota:]) or he had a child, or offspring, borne to him such as is termed damiymN (Ḳ, TA) or qabiyHN damiymN (so in the CK) in make. (TA.)

R. Q. 1. damodama, [inf. n. damodamapN,] He smeared, or did over, a thing much, or exceedingly, or with energy: and he so covered over a thing. (Ḥam p. 461. [But the context there indicates that the verb in these two senses should be correctly written dm-m.])
See also 1, near the middle of the paragraph, and in five places after that.

hom.sense: dam-N: see dimaAmN:
and dam-aMCu.
Also a dial. var. of damN [i. e. Blood: see art. dmw or dmI]: (Ḳ:) but ignored by Ks. (T, TA.)

entry.sense: dum-N: see damiymN.

hom.sense: dum-apN: see daAm-aMCu.
Also A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And A certain game. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dim-apN The lodging-place, or nightly lodging-place, (marobiD, [for which Golius appears to have read mryD,]) of sheep or goats; (M, Ḳ, TA;) as though [originating] from its being befouled with urine and dung: occurring in a trad., in which it is said that there is no harm in praying in a dm-p of sheep or goats: (M, TA:) but some read, in this instance, dimonap: and some say that dim-ap is originally dimonap. (TA.)
A piece of baEor [i. e. camels', sheep's, goats', or similar, dung]: (Ṣ, Ḳ: [in the CK, Albaqarapu is erroneously put for AlbaEorapu:]) so called because of its despicableness. (TA.)
A louse; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or a small louse: (M, TA:) or (so in the M, but in the Mṣb and Ḳ “and”) an ant; (M, Ḳ;) because of its smallness; (TA;) or a small ant. (Mṣb.)
And hence, app., (M, TA,) † A short and contemptible man. (M, Ḳ. [See also damiymN.])
And A cat. (Ḳ.)
damimN Blood, or biestings, with which the crevices of stone cooking-pots are stopped up (tusad-u: in the TT and CK, tuXad-u). (IAạr, M, Ḳ, TA.)
dumamapN: see daAm-aMCu.
dumamaMCu: see daAm-aMCu.

dimaAmN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dam-N↓ (M, Ḳ) A thing (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) of any kind (Ṣ, TA) with which one smears, or does over, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the face [&c.]: (Mṣb:) said by some to be the red pigment with which women redden their faces: (Mṣb:) and particularly, [i. e. both these words,] (Ḳ,) or the former, (Ṣ,) a medicinal liniment with which one smears the forehead of a child (Ṣ, Ḳ) and the exterior of his eyes: (Ṣ:) or the former word, a medicament with which the forehead of a child is smeared, called HuDaD or HuDuD: and as some say, [the pigment called] naWuwr: (TA:) and a collyrium, or liniment, that is applied to the eye: (Mṣb:) or any medicament with which the exterior of the eye is smeared; (Lth, T;) such as aloes, and saffron: (TA:) and i. q. naWuwrN, which is applied to the gums. (T.) buS-irato bidimaAmK, said of the feathers of an arrow, means They were stuck fast with glue: (M, TA:) or they were besmeared with blood. (Ṣ in art. bSr.)
Also, [i. e. both words,] (Ḳ,) or the former word, (T,) † Clouds in which is no water; (Ḳ, TA;) as being likened to the liniment so called. (TA)

hom.sense: damiymN, applied to a qidor [or cooking-pot], (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or a buromap [meaning one of stone, (see dimamN,)] (T,) Smeared, or done over, with spleen (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) or liver (M, Ḳ) or blood [or biestings], (T, M, Ḳ,) after being repaired; (T, Ḳ;) as also damiymapN (T, Lḥ, M, Ḳ) and madomuwmapN↓: (T, Ṣ:) and dum-N↓, with damm, [app. pl. of damiymN,] signifies cooking-pots (quduwrN) [so] smeared. (IAạr, TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) applied to a man, (M, Mṣb,) Foul, or ugly; syn. qabiyHN: (Ṣ, M:) or contemptible: (M, Ḳ:) or foul, or ugly, (qabiyH,) in aspect, and small in body: (Mṣb:) not pleasing to the eyes: (TA in art. bXE:) damiymN relates to the stature; and camiymN, to the dispositions: (IAạr, T:) app. from dim-apN signifying “a louse” and “a small ant:” (Mṣb:) [see also dim-apN:] fem. with p {damiymapN}: pl. dimaAmN and damaAYimu; the former masc. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and fem., (M, Ḳ,) and the latter fem. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: dum-aA [or dum-aI], and dum-aMCu, or dam-aMCu: see daAm-aMCu.
dam-aAmN One who repairs cooking-pots by cementing them. (Golius from Meyd. See 1.)

daAm-aMCu and dumamapN↓ and dum-apN↓ (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) The hole that is stopped up by the jerboa with the earth that it has extracted; (T, TA;*) and so dum-aA↓ [more properly written dum-aI], or dum-aMCu↓, each with damm, (TA,) or dam-aMCu↓: (T, accord. to the TT:) or one of the holes of the jerboa; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like raAhiTaMCu [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) [and so, app., dam-N↓, accord. to the KL; there explained as signifying swrAx mwX dXtI:] and also, (Ḳ,) or the first and second, (M,) the earth which the jerboa collects and extracts from its hole, and with which it stops up the entrance thereof; (M, Ḳ;) or the earth with which it stops up one of its holes: (M:) and dumamaMCu↓ also signifies the daAm-aMCu of the jerboa: (IAạr, Ḳ:) the pl. (of daAm-aMCu, Ṣ) is dawaAm-u. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

dayomuwmN and dayomuwmapN A wide [desert such as is termed] falaAp; (M, Ḳ, TA;) in which journeying continues long (yaduwmu [for it is regarded by some as derived from daAma, of which dayomuwmapN is also an inf. n.,]) by reason of its far-extending: (TA:) or a [desert such as is termed] mafaAzap in which is no water: (Ṣ:) or a level tract of land in which are no signs of the way, nor any road, nor water, nor any one to cheer by his presence: pl. dayaAmiymu: which is explained as signifying smooth deserts of which the extremities are far apart: and OaroDN dayomuwmapN signifies a land that is disapproved, disliked, or abominable. (T in art. dwm, and TA.)
midam-apN A wooden implement with teeth, with which the earth, or ground, is made even, (M, Ḳ,) after it has been turned over for sowing. (M.)
kur-N mudam-amN (Ṣ, Ḳ *) [A well] cased with stones or burnt bricks; syn. maTowiI-N. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
madomuwmN [Smeared, or done over, with any kind of dye, &c.: fem. with p {madomuwmapN}]: see damiymN.
[Hence,] Red. (Ṣ.)

And † Fat in the utmost degree; (M, Ḳ;) full of fat; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as though smeared therewith: (M:) applied to a camel, &c.; (Ṣ;) or to a human being, and an ass, and a bull, and a sheep or goat, and any beast. (TA.) [Accord. to the KL, it signifies also Heavily laden: but the right explanation is probably laden with fat: see dum-a biAlX-aHomi, in the first paragraph of this art.]

1. damiva, (Ṣ, M, A, &c.,) aor. _a {yadomavu}, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. damavN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb,) sometimes contracted into damavN, (Mṣb,) It (a place, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, or other thing, A, Ḳ) was, or became, soft and even: (M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or it (a place) was, or became, soft and sandy. (Ṣ.)

And dmv, (Mṣb,) [i. e. damuva, or damiva as above,] inf. n. damaAvapN (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dumuwvapN (M, TA) and damavN, (A,) or damovN, (Mgh,) ‡ He (a man) was, or became, easy in nature, or disposition. (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

2. dm-vhu, (T, M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. tadomiyvN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made it even, (T, A,) or soft, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or soft and even; (Mṣb;) namely, a place, (T, A, Mṣb,) or a bed, or place on which to lie: (Ṣ:) and (A) he macerated it, namely, a thing, and mashed it, (M, A,) with his hand, (A,) in order that it might become soft. (M, A.) [Hence,]
dam-ivo lijanobika qabola All-ayoli muDoTajaEaA , (T,) or qabola Aln-awomi, (A,) [lit. Make soft and even for thy side a bed, or place on which to lie, before night, or before sleeping;] a prov., meaning ‡ prepare for an event before its happening. (T,* A.) [Hence also,] mano kacaba EalaI-a faUin-amaA yudam-ivu majolisahu mina Aln-aAri, i. e. [Whoso lieth against me, verily] he will make even, meaning will prepare, his sitting-place in the fire [of Hell]; a saying of Moḥammad. (Mgh.)

[And hence,] dm-v AlHadiyva, (T, A,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ He mentioned (T, A, Ḳ) the beginning of (T, A) the tradition, or story. (T, A, Ḳ.) You say, dam-ivo liI celika AlHadiyva Hat-aI OaToEuna fiI xawoDihi ‡ Mention thou to me the beginning of that tradition, or story, in order that I may know the manner thereof (T, A) and how I should enter upon it [so that I may push on in it]. (A.)
4. maA kaAna Oadomava fulaAnFA waOaloyanahu ‡ How easy in nature, or disposition, was such a one! [and how gentle was he!]. (Ṣ, TA.)
damovN: see dmivN, in two places.
damavN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

damivN Even, or soft; applied to a valley, and to anything: (T:) or a place soft and even; (Mgh, TA;) as also damiyvN↓, (A,) and damovN↓, or damavN↓; the last also explained as a subst., meaning an even, or a soft, tract of land; app. an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Mgh:) or damivN [in one copy of the Ṣ erroneously written dimivN, and in another dimovN,] signifies a soft and sandy place; and its pl. is dimaAvN: (Ṣ:) or a place soft to the tread; as also damavN↓: and so this last applied to a tract of sand (ramolapN); as though it were an inf. n. used as an Aisom [here meaning an epithet; wherefore it is used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and dual and pl.]: and [for this reason] damavN↓ signifies also plain, or soft, tracts of land;pl. [of pauc.] OadomaAvN and [of mult.] dimaAvN: (M:) or dimaAvN has this last meaning; and its sing. is damivapN↓ [with p added to transfer the word from the category of epithets to that of substantives]; and dimaAv consist of sands and of what are not sands: damaAYivu likewise is applied to what is [or are] even and soft; and its sing. is damivapN↓ [like as xaribapN is sing. of xaraAYibu]: (T: [but for damivapN, in this last instance, I find damiyvapN↓: if this be right, the pl. is agreeable with analogy; but if damivapN be the sing., the pl. is anomalous:]) and damivN is applied to sand, as meaning not cohering. (TA.) It is said in a trad., maAla UilaI damivK fabaAla fiyhi, (Mgh,) or damovK↓, (A, Mgh,) accord. to different readings, i. e. [He turned to] a soft and even place [and made water upon it]. (Mgh.) And you say, nazalonaA biOaroDK mayovaMCa damovaMCa↓ [We alighted, or alighted and abode, in a tract of land even, or soft, or soft and even]. (A.)

Hence, (T,) ‡ A man easy in nature, or disposition, (T, M, TA,) and generous; (T;) as also damiyvN↓: (TA:) and in the same sense damiyvapN↓ is applied to a woman; (T;) or damivapN; (TA;) she being likened to land so termed, because such is the best, or most productive, of land. (T, TA.) And damivu AlOaxolaAqi ‡ A man easy in natural dispositions. (A.)
damivapN, as a subst.: see damivN, (of which, also, it is the fem.,) in two places.
OaroDN damovaMCu: see damivN.
damiyvN: see damivN, in two places.
damiyvapN, as a subst, and as fem. of damiyvN: see damivN, in two places.
OudomuwvN The place of the mal-ap [or hot ashes] (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) when bread has been baked there. (Ṣ, L.)

hom.sense:
1. damaja, [aor., accord. to a rule of the Ḳ, _u,] inf. n. dumuwjN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and Andmj↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Aid-amaja↓, as also Aidoram-aja; (Ṣ, Ḳ;)
It (a thing, Ṣ, A) entered, and became firm, fiI XaIoCK in a thing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it became firm and consolidated: (A:) or it entered, and became concealed, in a thing: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb:) and the first and second, he (a wild animal) entered into his covert among trees: (A, TA:) and in like manner, the first, a man into his house or tent; as also dm-j↓. (L.)
[Hence,] damaja baEoDuhu fiI baEoDK ‡ [It became intricate]; said of darkness. (A, TA.)
And damaja Oamoruhumo ‡ Their affair, or case, was, or became, right, just, or sound, and consistent. (A, TA.)
And damajati AlOaronabu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadomuju}, inf. n. as above, (TA,) The hare went quickly, with short steps: (M, Ḳ:*) and in like manner damaja is said of a camel. (M.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
3. dAmjhu, (A, L,) inf. n. dimaAjN, (L,) ‡ He agreed with him, [and he aided him, (see 6,)] Ealayohi [against him, or respecting it, or to do it]. (L, A.)
And † [He soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him, as though concealing enmity: for its inf. n.] mudaAmajapN is like mudaAjaApN. (Ṣ.)
4. Admj He wrapped a thing in a garment, or piece of cloth. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [Said in the TA to be tropical: but for this there is no reason that I can see.])
He rolled up tightly a TuwmaAr [or scroll]; syn. Xad-a UidoraAjahu. (A, TA.)

He twisted: or he twisted well a rope: or he twisted it firmly, making it slender. (TA.) And Admjt, said of a female comber and dresser of hair, (A, L,) She rolled, or made round, (Oadorajat,) and made smooth, the locks of a woman's hair: (A:) or she plaited such locks; as also damajato↓, inf. n. damojN. (L.)

† He, or it, made a horse lean, lank, or light of flesh, or slender, or lank in the belly. (TA.) UidomaAjN [as inf. n. of Oudomija, not of Oadomaja,] signifies † The being slender in the waist, or middle. (KL.) [See also 7.]
Admj kalaAmahu ‡ He disposed his words in a closely-connected order: (A:) or he made his speech vague. (Mṣb.)
5. tdm-j fiI vyaAbihi ‡ He wrapped himself in his clothes, in consequence of his feeling the cold. (A.)

6. tdAmjwA ‡ They agreed together: (A:) [they conspired together:] they leagued together, (A,) and aided one another. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.*) You say, tdAmjwA Ealayohi ‡ They aided one another, (Ṣ,) or leagued together, and aided one another, (A, TA,) against him. (Ṣ, A, TA.)
7. Andmj: see 1.
Also, said of a horse, ‡ He was, or became, lean, lank, or light of flesh, or slender, or lank in the belly. (A, TA.)
8. Aid-amaja: see 1.
damojN A plaited, or braided, lock of hair. (L, Ḳ.*)
dimojN A [friend, or companion, such as is termed] xidon; and an equal. (Ḳ.)

SuloHN dumaAjN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and dimaAjN↓ (A, Ḳ) ‡ A peace, or reconciliation, that is secret, or concealed: (Ḳ, TA:) or as though secret, or concealed; from mudaAmajapN [inf. n. of 3]: (Ṣ:) or firmly established: (A, Ḳ:) or complete, and firmly established: (Az, Ṣ:) or that is not made with any malicious intention. (AA.) And OamorN dumaAjN † A right, or just, affair or case. (TA.) The saying of a poet, cited by IAạr,
yuHaAwilona SaromFA Oawo dumaAjFA EalaI AlxanaI [which may app. be correctly rendered Do they (referring to women) seek to affect a severing of the tie of union, or a confirming thereof notwithstanding the calamities of fortune?] is explained as meaning, they make a show of union outwardly sound but inwardly unsound; from Oadomaja AlHabola signifying “he twisted firmly the rope.” (TA.)
dimaAjN: see the next preceding paragraph.
dumuwjN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
Also Smoothness; or the being smooth: in this sense extr., inasmuch as it [is an inf. n. that] has no unaugmented triliteral-radical verb belonging to it. (L.)
dum-ajN: see mudomajN.
layolN daAmijN ‡ Dark night: (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA:) or night of intricate darkness. (A.)

Also † An arrow that is used in the game called Almayosir. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) El-Hárith Ibn-Hillizeh says,
OalofayotanaA lilD-ayofi xayora EimaArapK
Ul-aA yakuno labanN faEaTofN Almudomaji
[Thou hast found us to be, for the guest, the best tribe: if there is not any milk, then is the shuffling of the gaming arrow]: meaning, if there is not any milk, we shuffle the gaming arrow for [the purpose of deciding who shall supply] the camel to be slaughtered, and we slaughter it for the guest. (Ṣ.)
mudam-ajN: see the next preceding paragraph.
midomaAjapN A turban; syn. EimaAmapN; (AHeyth, Ḳ;) a rare instance of the addition of p to the measure mifoEaAlN: or it seems to be an epithet applied to a turban, meaning firmly wound. (AHeyth.)
munodamijN: see mudomajN.
Also Round, or rounded; as an epithet applied to a naSol [i. e. the head of an arrow or of a spear, &c.] (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. damara, aor. _u {yadomuru}, (T, M, A, Mṣb, &c.,) inf. n. damaArN (T, M, MF, TA) and damaArapN (MF, TA) and dumuwrN, (MF,) or damaArN is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and dumuwrN is an inf. n. of damara in a trans. sense, (TA,) It (a people, T, M, A, or a thing, Mṣb) perished: (T, M, A, Mṣb, TA:) or perished utterly. (TA.)
See also 2.

damara Ealayohimo, (Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadomuru}, (Ṣ, M,) inf. n. dumuwrN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and damorN, (M,) He intruded upon them; went, or came, in to them without permission: (Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ:*) or intruded upon them in an evil manner. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., mano sabaqa Tarofuhu QsotiYocaAnahu faqado damara He whose look precedes his asking permission [does that which is as bad as the act of him who] enters without permission. (Ṣ,* TA.) And it is said, UicaA daxalota Ald-uwra Uiy-aAka waAld-umuwra When thou enterest houses, [meaning, desirest to enter them,] beware of entering without permission. (A.)

2. dm-rhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and dm-rhumo, (T, M, A,) and dm-r Ealayohi, (T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and Ealayohimo, (M, A,) inf. n. tadomiyrN; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and damarahumo↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. dumuwrN, (Ḳ, TA,) and, accord. to the Ḳ damaArN [which is omitted in the CK] and damaArapN, but this is wrong, (MF, TA,) for the second and third of these three inf. ns., (TA,) or all of them, (MF,) are of damara in the intrans. sense explained above; (MF, TA;) He (God, M, TA) destroyed, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) or destroyed utterly, (A, TA,) him, or it, or them. (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) And dm-r Als-ayolu AlmakaAna The torrent destroyed the place. (TA from a trad.)

dm-r, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (a sportsman) fumigated his qutorap [or lurking-place] with fur, or soft hair, [of camels,] in order that the wild animals might not perceive his smell. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also the act. part. n., below.]

entry.sense: 3. dAmr All-ayola ‡ He passed the night sleepless: (A:) or he endured, or braved, the difficulty, or trouble, of the night, and passed it sleepless. (Ḳ.)
damirN: see daAmirN, in two places.

hom.sense: damoraMCu A ewe, or she-goat, having little milk. (Ḳ.)
And One short in make. (TA.)
Applied to a woman, and to others, [i. e. applied also to a company of people, jamaAEapN, (TḲ,)] Wont to intrude upon others; to go, or come, in to them without permission. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense:
damaArN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and damaArapN↓ (MF, TA) and dumuwrN↓, (MF, [but see 1,]) Perdition: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, &c.:) or utter perdition. (TA.) You say, Hal-a bihimu Ald-amaAru Perdition [or utter perdition] befell them. (A.)
And maA raOayota mino xasaAratihi wadamaAratihi↓ wadabaAratihi [What sawest thou of his error and his perdition and his state of destruction?]. (T.)
dumuwrN: see the next preceding paragraph.
damaArapN: see damaArN, in two places.
dumaAriI-N: see tadomuriI-N.

daAmirN A man in a state of perdition, in whom is no good. (M.) And rajulN xaAsirN daAmirN (Yaạḳoob, T, M, A) and xasirN wadamirN↓ (Lḥ, T, M) [A man erring and perishing]: Lh says that damirN↓ in the latter phrase is an imitative sequent to xasirN: but [ISd says,] I think that xasirN is a verbal epithet, and damirN a possessive epithet. (M.) [See also art. xsr.]
daAmiriI-N: see tadomuriI-N.
dayomuriI-N A sharp and pertinacious man. (Ḳ.) [And so cayomuriI-N, q. v.]

hom.sense: tadomuriI-N, applied to a man, Ignoble, or mean. (M.)

yarobuwEN tadomuriI-N (T, Ṣ, M) and tudomuriI-N and dumaAriI-N↓ (M) A jerboa that is small and short: (Ṣ:) or of vile make, (T, M,) with broken nails, (M,) and tough flesh: (T, TA:) or the kind called the maAEiz of jerboas, (T, M,) short and small, without nails to its legs, and not quickly overtaken: it is smaller than the XufaAriI-: (M:) this latter is the DaOon thereof, and is characterized by its having a nail in the middle of its leg, in the place of the spur of the cock. (T.)
Hence, (TA,) OucunN tadomuriy-apN † A small ear. (Ḳ.)

Any one: so in the saying, maA fiI Ald-aAri tadomuriI-N (Fr, T, Ḳ *) and tudomiriI-N (Ḳ) and daAmiriI-N↓ (A, TA) [There is not in the house any one]; like taOomuriI-N, &c. (TA.) One says also of a beautiful woman, maA raOayotu tadomuriy-FA OaHosana minohaA, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. [I have not seen] any one [more beautiful than she]. (TA.)
tadomuray-apN an appellation of Certain dogs, not such as are called saluwqiy-ap nor such as are called kurodiy-ap. (M.)

entry.sense: mudam-arN A sportsman who fumigates his qutorap [or lurking-place] with fur, or soft hair, (M, A,) of camels, (M,) in order that the wild animals may not perceive his smell. (M, A.)
And hence, or because he rushes upon the game unperceived, and [as it were] without permission, ‡ A skilful, or skilled, sportsman. (A.)

hom.sense: damaEati AlEayonu, aor. _a {yadomaEu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. damoEN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and damaEaAnN and dumuwEN; (TA;) and damiEat, (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadomaEu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. damaEN; (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA; [in one copy of the Ṣ, damoEN, which is a mistake;]) or only damaEat, with fet-ḥ to the m; (AZ, Ks;) The eye shed tears. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
damaEa AljuroHu ‡ The wound flowed [with blood]. (TA.) And damaEati AlX-aj-apu † The wound on the head flowed with blood; its blood ran. (Mṣb.)
damaEati Aljafonapu ‡ The bowl flowed [or overflowed] with its grease, or gravy. (TA.) And damoEN also signifies † The flowing from the strainer of the dyer. (TA.)

Aboo-ʼAdnán says, I asked El-'Okeylee respecting this verse:
waAlX-amosu tadomaEu EayonaAhaA wamanoxiruhaA
wahun-a yaxorujona mino biydK UilaI biydi [app. meaning † And the sun was shedding its fierce rays and its gossamer when they were going forth from deserts to deserts]: and he said, I think [that the poet means] it was the Zahiyrap [or midday of summer when the heat was vehement], when what is called luEaAbu AlX-amosi [and muxaATu AlX-amosi, which latter is here the more appropriate term,] was flowing [in the air]: and El-Ghanawee says, when the beasts thirst, their eyes shed tears, and their nostrils flow. (TA.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2. tadomiyEN Vehement flowing of tears from the eye. (KL.)

4. AdmEhu, (IAạr,) inf. n. UidomaAEN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He filled it, [app. so as to make it overflow,] (IAạr, Ḳ,) namely a bowl, (IAạr,) or a vessel; (Ḳ;) as also damaEahu↓ [if this be not a mistranscription for the former]. (TA.)
5. tdm-E [He shed tears; or wept]. (Occurring in a version of the Gospel of St. John, xi. 35: but perhaps post-classical.)
10. huwa yusotadomiEu [app. He draws forth tears]. (TA.)

damoEN Tears; the water, or fluid, of the eye; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) whether from grief or joy: (Ḳ:) originally an inf. n.: (Mṣb:) [but having a pl., both of mult. and of pauc.: for] the pl. [of mult.] is dumuwEN (Ḳ) and [of pauc.] OadomuEN: (TA:) and damoEpN↓ [is the n. un., signifying] a single drop thereof; [i. e. a tear:] (Ṣ, Ḳ:) if from joy, it is cool; or if from grief, hot. (TA.)

damoEu daAwuwda [David's tears;] a certain well known medicine: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) [perhaps the fruits of a species of coix, namely coix lachryma, now called damoEu Oay-uwba, or Job's tears, which are hard and stony, and are said to be strengthening and diuretic.]
bakati Als-amaACu wadamoEu Als-aHaAbi saAli ‡ [The sky wept, and the tears of the clouds flowed]. (TA.)
Xaribi damoEapN↓ Alkaromi ‡ [He drank the tear of the vine]; i. e., wine. (A, TA.)
dumuwEi Aljafonapi ‡ [The tears, meaning] the grease, or gravy, of the bowl. (TA.)

damiEN [masc. of] damiEapN A woman quick to shed tears: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or quick to weep, abounding with tears; (L;) as also damiyEN↓, without p; (Lḥ, L;) of which latter, which is applied also to a man, the pl. is dumaEaMCu, applied to men, and damoEaI, applied to men and to women, and damaAYiEu, applied to women. (L.) [See also damuwEN.]
dumuEN A mark made with a hot iron in the part where the tears run, (El-Aḥmar, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) of a camel; (El-Aḥmar;) said by Aboo-ʼAlee, in the “Tedhkireh,” to be a small line. (TA.)
damoEapN: see damoEN, in two places.
qadaHN damoEaAnN ‡ A bowl that is full so as to overflow (L, Ḳ,* TA) from its sides. (L, TA.)

dumaAEN Water of the eye arising from disease or old age; not tears: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, the traces of tears upon the face: thus in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà, in the margin of a copy of the Ṣ. (TA.)
dumaAEu Alkaromi, (Ṣ, A,) or Ald-um-aAEu↓, like rum-aAn, (Ḳ,) and thus written by Ṣgh, with teshdeed, (TA,) ‡ What flows from the grape-vine in the days of the [season called] rabiyE (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,* TA.)

dimaAEN A mark made with a hot iron upon the manaAZir (fiI AlmanaAZiri [app. a mistake for fiI Aln-aAZiri, meaning upon the place of the vein at the edge of the nose, commencing from the inner angle of the eye,]) running down to the nostril, (Ḳ, TA,) so says ISh, (TA,) or to the nostrils: (CK:) sometimes there are two such marks. (TA.)
EayonN damuwEN An eye that sheds many tears: or quick to shed tears: and EayonN dam-aAEapN↓ [has the former signification]. (TA.) [See also damiEN.]

varFI damuwEN ‡ Earth, or soil, from which water exudes: (TA:) and varFI dam-aAEN↓, and daAmiEN↓, ‡ earth, or soil, that exudes moisture; (Ḳ;) or that seems as though it exuded moisture, or almost did so. (TA.)
damiyEN: see damiEN.
yawomN dam-aAEN ‡ A day in which is [fine rain such as is called] racaAc. (Ḳ, TA.)
dum-aAEN: see dumaAEN.
daAmiEN [act. part. n. of damaEa]. You say, EayonN daAmiEapN An eye shedding tears; an eye of which the tears are flowing: (Mṣb:) pl. dawaAmiEu. (TA.)

Xaj-apN daAmiEapN ‡ A wound on the head from which blood flows (A, IAth, Mgh, TA) in small quantity, (A, TA,) or in drops, (IAth, TA,) like tears; (IAth, Mgh, TA;) ranking after that termed daAmiyapN: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) AʼObeyd says, (Ṣ,) the dAmyp is that which bleeds without a flowing of blood from it; (Ṣ, Mgh;) and when the blood flows from it, it is termed dAmEp, with the unpointed E: (Ṣ:) yet the author of the Ḳ says, in art. dmg, [as on the authority of AʼObeyd,] that the dAmEp is before the dAmyp; and charges J with error in saying the contrary. (TA.) [See also Xaj-apN.]
jafonapN daAmiEapN ‡ A bowl flowing [or overflowing] with its grease, or gravy. (TA.)
varFI daAmiEN: see damuwEN.

madomaEN The channel of the tears; or part where the tears run: (TA:)
or the place where the tears collect in the sides of the eye: pl. madaAmiEu, which comprises the inner and the outer angles of the eyes: (Az, TA:) or the pl. signifies the inner angles, (AlmaMqiI,) which are the extremities of the eye [or eyes]. (Ṣ.)
The pl. also signifies † Waters which drop, or drip, from the side of a mountain. (Aboo-ʼAdnán.) And it may also signify Flowings of tears. (Ḥam p. 551.)
madomuwEN A camel marked with the mark called dumuEN. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. damagapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadomagu} (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yadomugu}, (IDrd, Ḳ,) inf. n. damogN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He broke his head so that the wound reached the dimaAg [or brain]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he broke the bone of his dimaAg: (Mṣb:) or he struck it, namely, a person's head, so that the stroke reached to the dimaAg: (Mgh:) and he struck his dimaAg, (Ḳ, TA,) and broke the interior of the skull, next the dimaAg. (TA.) And damagatohu AlX-amosu The sun pained his dimaAg. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

Also, inf. n. as above, ‡ He overcame, or subdued, and abased, him, or it: like as the truth does falsehood: and hence fayadomagahu in the Ḳur [xxi. 18], meaning ‡ so that it may overcome it, or prevail over it, and abolish it: or, accord. to Az, so that it may do away with it, in such a manner as to render it despicable, or ignominious. (TA.) And dm-ghu↓ signifies ‡ He overcame him, or prevailed over him, much, so as to subdue him, or abase him. (TA.)
[Hence, app.,] dumigati AlOaroDu † [The produce of] the land was eaten. (IAạr, TA.)

And damagahumo bimuTofaYapi Alr-aDofi ‡ He slaughtered for them a lean sheep or goat: (Ḳ:) so says Lḥ, except that he does not explain the verb, which is thus explained by Ibn-ʼAbbád and Z: (TA:) or, as some say, a fat sheep or goat. (Ḳ.)

dmgt Hawiy-atahaA, [the verb written in the L and TA without teshdeed, so that it is app. damagato, but it may be dam-agato↓,] She (a woman) made, or put, a daAmigap [q. v.] to her Hwy-p [or stuffed thing whereon she rode upon her camel]. (ISh, L, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. dm-g, inf. n. tadomiygN, ‡ He made a variydap [or mess of crumbled, or broken, bread,] soft with grease, or gravy. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ḳ.)
See also 1, in two places.

Ald-imaAgu a word of which the signification is well known; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) [The brain;] the marrow of the head; (Ḳ;) or the stuffing of the head: (TA:) or [app. a mistake for “and” (what is termed)] Oum-u AlhaAmi or Oum-u Alr-aOosi or [in one copy of the Ḳ “and”] Oum-u Ald-imaAgi is a thin skin, like a pouch, in which it is contained: (Ḳ:) [these three terms, Am- AlhAm and Am- AlrOs and Am- AldmAg, appear all to signify the meninx; (see Oum-N;) but the first and second of them seem to have been mistaken by the author or transcribers of the Ḳ for different explanations of Ald-amaAgu:] the pl. [of pauc.] is OadomigapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] dumugN. (TA.)

damiygN and madomuwgN↓ Having his head broken so that the wound reaches the dimaAg [or brain]: (IDrd, Ḳ:) the former is likewise applied to a woman: and the pl., applied to men and to women, is damogaI. (IDrd, TA.)

Also, both words, † Stupid; foolish; or unsound, or dull, or deficient, in intellect: mudam-agN↓ is incorrectly used by the vulgar in this sense; (Ḳ, TA;) as though meaning overcome, so as to be subdued, or abased, by the devil: it is said in the “Námoos” that this last word may be correct as having an intensive signification; but it may admit of such a signification, and yet may be incorrect, not heard from persons of chaste speech. (TA.)

daAmigapN A wound in the head, reaching the dimaAg [or brain]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) with which there is no living: (Mṣb:) it is the last [in degree] of [the wounds termed] XijaAj [pl. of Xaj-apN]; these being ten, as follows: [1] qaAXirapN, also called HaAriSapN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and HaroSapN, or, as some think, the HArSp or HrSp is different from the qAXrp: (TA:) [2] baADiEapN: [3] daAmiyapN: [4] mutalaAHimapN: [5] simoHaAqN: [6] muwDiHapN: [7] haAXimapN: [8] munaq-alapN: [9] Mm-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) also termed maOomuwmapN: (TA:) [10] daAmigapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and AʼObeyd adds daAmiEapN, with the unpointed E, after daAmiyapN; (Ṣ;) or, accord. to F, who pronounces J to have erred in saying thus, before dAmyp: but J is right in this case. (TA.) [See Xaj-apN daAmiEapN, voce daAmiEN. Several other terms are mentioned in the TA; but these, which will be found in their proper arts., appear to be all syn. with some that are mentioned above. See also Xaj-apN.]

Also A spadix (TaloEapN) that comes forth from amid the broken portions of the qulob [or heart of the palm-tree], long and hard, and, if left, mars the palm-tree; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) wherefore, when its existence is known, it is detached. (TA.)

And An iron above the muWax-arap [or hinder part] of the [camel's saddle called] raHol; (Aṣ, Ḳ;) also called gaAXiyapN: (TA:) or an iron with which the back of the rHol is fastened: (JK:) the pl. is dawaAmigu: ISh says that the dwAmg are above the middle of the heads, or upper extremities, of the [curved pieces of wood called] OaHonaMC [pl. of HinowN]; and sometimes they are of wood, firmly bound; and i. q. xacaAriyfu, pl. of xucoruwfN [q. v.]: [but] Az says that when the dAmgp is of iron, it is placed across, or athwart, above the two extremities of the HinowaAni, and nailed with two nails, the xcAryf being fastened upon the heads of the cross-pieces, in order that it, or they, may not become disconnected. (TA.) [What it is, I am unable further to explain. It is perhaps thus called because so placed that a person is liable to have his head wounded by it.]
And A piece of wood placed across between two poles, upon which is hung the skin for water or milk. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

daAmuwgN One that wounds so as to reach the dimaAgN [or brain]; and that breaks the head or the like. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And HajarN daAmuwgapN A stone that does so much, or vehemently: the p denoting intensiveness of signification. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
mudam-agN: see damiyagN.
madomuwEN: see damiyagN.

hom.sense: 1. damala AlOaroDa, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadomulu}, (T, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. damolu and damalaAnN, (M, Ḳ,) He put the land into a right, or proper, state: (M, Ḳ:) or he did so with damaAl, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) i. e., [he manured it with] sirojiyn (Ṣ) or siroqiyn, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or samaAd; (Mgh;) or OadomalahaA↓ has this latter signification; (M;) and so dabalahaA. (T in art. dbl.)

And [hence,] damala AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ in art. dbl, and Mṣb,) aor. _u {yadomulu}, inf. n. damolN, (Mṣb,) † He put the thing into a right, or proper, state; prepared it, or improved it; (Ṣ in art. dbl, and Mṣb;) as also dabalahu. (Ṣ in that art.) And damala bayona Alqawomi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yadomulu}, (M,) inf. n. damolN, (TA,) ‡ He made peace, effected a reconciliation, or adjusted a difference, between the people; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) as also dawomala↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

damala AljuroHa, (T, M, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yadomulu}, (M,) † It (a remedy) healed the wound: (T,* M, Ḳ:*) [and Admlhu↓ has a similar meaning; for] UidomaAlN signifies the healing a wound; and causing it to skin over. (KL.)
damila: see 7.

entry.sense:
3. dAmlhu, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. mudaAmalapN, (Ṣ,) ‡ He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; (T, M, Ḳ;) in order to effect a reconciliation between himself and him: (T, M,* TA:) mudaAmalapN is similar to mudaAjaApN. (Ṣ.) Abu-l-Ḥasan says,
XaniYotu mina AlUixowaAni mano lasotu zaAYilFA
OudaAmiluhu damola↓ Als-iqaMCi Almuxar-aqi
[† I hated, of the brethren, him whom I was not ceasing to treat gently, with the gentle treatment of the water-skin, or milk-skin, having in it many holes, or rents]: (T, M:) thus using an inf. n. with a verb to which it does not properly belong. (M.) And one says, daAmili Alqawoma, (so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or Oadomili↓ Alqawoma, (so in two other copies of the Ṣ, [but only the former agrees with the context,]) meaning AiTowihimo EalaI maA fiyhimo [i. e. † Treat thou the people with gentleness, notwithstanding what fault, or the like, there may be in them: see a phrase similar to this explanation voce balalN]. (Ṣ, TA.)
4: see 1, in two places:
and see also 3.
5. tdm-lt AlOaroDu The land was, or became, put into a right, or proper, state, with damaAl, i. e. siroqiyn. (M, Ḳ.)
6. tdAmlw ‡ They made peace, or became reconciled, one with another. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

7. Andml † It (a wound, T, Ṣ, M, Mgh,* Mṣb) healed; or became in a healing state; (M, Ḳ;)
as also damila↓, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadomalu}: (Ḳ:) or became healed, (Mgh,) or nearly healed, (T, Ṣ, Mgh,) as also Aid-amala↓, originally Aidotamala, (AA, TA,) and in a healthy state: (T, Mgh:) from damala AlOaroDa: (Mgh:) or gradually recovered. (Mṣb.) And † He became nearly recovered from (mino) his disease, (T, M,*) and from a wound, (T,) and from his pain. (M.)
8. Aid-omala: see 7.
Q. Q. 1. dawomala bayona Alqawomi: see 1.
damolN Gentle treatment. (M, Ḳ.) See also 3.
dumalN: see dum-alN.

damaAlN [Dung, such as is called] sirojiyn (Ṣ) or siroqiyn, (T, M, Ḳ,) and the like; (T;) [used for manuring land;] as also dabaAlN: (M in art. dbl:) or compost of dung and ashes, or of dust, or earth, and dung: (Mgh:) and camels' or similar dung, and dust, or earth, trodden by the beasts. (M, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] † A means [of kindling] of war; like as dmAl [signifying dung] is a means of kindling of fire. (Ṣ, TA.)
Rotten dates: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ:) or rotten, black, old dates: (M, Ḳ: [in the CK, Alv-amaru is erroneously put for Alt-amoru:]) [and] such are called tamorN damaAlN. (M.)

Refuse that the sea rejects, (Lth, T, M,* Ḳ,) consisting of dead creatures therein, (Lth, T,) and the like, (ʼEyn, TT,) such as [the shells, or shell-fish, called] OaSodaAf and manaAqiyf, (Lth, T, TA,) or Sadaf and manaAqif, (M,) and nab-aAH. (Lth, T, M, TA. [The last word is erroneously written in one place, in the TT, nab-aAj; and in another place, in the same, sub-aAH.])

An unsoundness, or infection, in the spadix of the palm-tree, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) so that it becomes black, (M, Ḳ,) before it attains to maturity, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) or before it is fecundated: (IDrd:) also termed damaAnN, [q. v.,] (Mgh, TA,) from dimonN meaning siroqiyn. (Mgh.)

dum-alN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dumalN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) A kind of purulent pustule, or imposthume; (T, Ṣ;) i. q. xuraAjN; (M, Ḳ;) well known: (Mṣb:) [said to be] an appellation applied as ominating good, (M, O,) like mafaAzapN applied to a place of destruction; (O;) or because it tends to healing: (T:) said by IF to be Arabic: (Mṣb:) by Aṣ said to be used in Arabic: (T:) [app. of Pers. origin:] in Pers. dunobalN, and bunaAwarN: (MA:) [now vulgarly pronounced dim-alN and dim-il: and applied to any pimple or pustule, and to a boil: see HibonN:] the pl. (of dum-alN, T, Ṣ) is damaAmiylu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is anomalous, (M,) or damaAmilu [agreeably with analogy]. (Mṣb.)
dam-aAlN One who manures land with [damaAl, i. e.] siroqiyn. (M.)
dum-ayolaI The dam-aMC [q. v.] of the jerboa. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.) [See also dum-ayonaI.]

Q. 1. damolaja, (JM, TA,) inf. n. damolajapN and dimolaAjN, (Ḳ, TA,) He made, or wrought, a thing, (Ḳ, JM, TA,) as, for instance, a bracelet, (TA,) evenly or equably, or justly or properly, (Ḳ, JM, TA,) and well. (JM, TA.) [And He made a thing round and smooth; like damolaqahu: see the pass. part. n., below.] It is said in a trad., damolaja Qll-ehu luWoluWahu [God has made his pearls round and smooth]. (TA.) Accord. to Lḥ, dumolija jisomuhu signifies His body was, or became, rounded, or compacted, (TuwiIa,) so that his, or its, flesh was firm, or hard. (TA.)
dumolajN and dumolujN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

dumoluwjN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) and dumolujN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and dumolajN↓ (Ḳ) An armlet; a bracelet for the arm; syn. miEoDadN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) i. e. the ornament thus called: (Mgh, TA:) pl. of the first damaAliyju; (Ṣ;) [and of the second and third damaAliju.] You say, OaloqaI EalaI damaAliyjahu [He put (lit. cast) upon me his armlets]. (Ṣ.)
Also the first and ↓second A smooth stone. (TA.)
And [the pl.] damaAliyju Hard lands: (Ḳ:) so in the L and the Tekmileh. (TA.)

mudamolajN i. q. mudorajN Oamolasu [Round, as though rolled like a scroll, and smooth]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and a stone, and a solid hoof, smooth and round; as also mudamolaqu and mudamolakN. (Ṣ in art. dmlq.) A rájiz says, (Ṣ, TA,) namely, El-ʼAjjáj, (so in a copy of the Ṣ,)
kaOan-a minohaA AlqaSaba AlmudamolajaA
suwqN mina AlbarodiI-i maA taEaw-ajaA [app. describing a certain animal, or animals, and meaning As though her, or their, round and smooth leg-bones were stalks of the papyrus, not crooked]. (Ṣ, TA.)
damolaSa and dumaliSN and dumaAliSN: see art. dlS.

Q. 1. damolaqahu He made it smooth and even: [or smooth and round:] like [damolajahu and] damolakahu. (TA) And dumolaqN It was made smooth and round: or smooth like the hand, and, accord. to some, hard. (TA.)
damolaqN and dumaliqN: see mudamolaqN.
dumoluwqN: see madamolaqN, in two places.

Also A sort of truffle, (AḤn, TA,) smaller than the Eurojuwn, (JK, AḤn, Ḳ, TA,) the shortest thereof (AḤn, TA) found in sands and meadows; (JK, AḤn, Ḳ, TA;) it is good, (AḤn, TA,) and seldom becomes black (JK, AḤn, TA) while fresh; (JK;) and it is the sort of which the head is like a miZal-ap [q. v.]: (AḤn, TA:) pl. damaAliyqu. (JK.)
dumaAliqN: see mudamolaqN.
Also An old man bald in the fore part of his head. (TA.) And dumaAliqu Alr-aOosi Having the head shaven. (En-Naḍr, Ḳ.)
Also, applied to a woman's vulva, Wide, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) and, some add, large. (TA.)

mudamolaqN, applied to a stone, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to a solid hoof, like mudamolakN and mudamolajN, (Ṣ,) and dumaAliqu↓ (JK, Ḳ) and dumaliqN↓ (Ḳ) and damolaqN↓ (JK, TA) and dumoluwqN↓, (JK, Ḳ,) Smooth and round: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or very round: (JK:) or, accord. to Aboo-Kheyreh, dumoluwqN↓ signifies a stone smooth like the hand, and, some add, hard: the pl. [of dumaAliqN and dumaliqN and damolaqN] is damaAliqu and [that of dumoluwqN is] damaAliyqu. (TA.)
Q. 1. damolakahu He made it smooth and round: (Ṣ:) or smooth and even: like damolaqahu. (TA in art. dmlq.)

Q. 2. tadamolaka It was, or became, smooth and round: (Ṣ, TA:) [or smooth and even: see above.] Said of a girl's breast, It became round and prominent: (Lth, Ḳ:) one should not say tadamolaqa. (Lth, TA.)
dumoluwkN: see what follows.
