mudamolakN Smooth and round; applied to a solid hoof; like mudamolaqN and mudamolajN; and as applied to an iron head of an arrow or of a spear, &c.: (Ṣ:) and so dumoluwkN↓ applied to a stone: (M, Ḳ:) or the latter, thus applied, signifies [simply] round: (Ṣ:) and the former, smooth and even; or made smooth and even; syn. muxal-aqN [in the CK muHal-aqN]; applied to a stone, and to an arrow: (M, Ḳ:) and i. q. mafotuwlN maEoSuwbN [app. as meaning compact, or firm, in make; as though twisted]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. damana AlOaroDa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yadomunu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. damonN, (TA,) i. q. damalahaA; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. He put the land into a right or proper state, prepared it, or improved it, [or manured it,] with [damaAn, i. e. dung such as is termed] siroqiyn. (TA.)

damina, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadomanu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. damanN, (KL,) ‡ He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) of long continuance, (M, Ḳ, TA,) Ealayohi against him: (Ṣ, M, TA:) and daminato quluwbuhumN ‡ Their hearts bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (Ṣ, TA,) of long continuance. (TA.) [Perhaps from daminati Aln-axolapu said in the TḲ to signify The palm-tree became rotten and black: see damaAnN, below.]

The inf. n. damanN also signifies The being lasting, continual, or permanent. (KL.) [And Andmn↓ app. signifies It was, or became, of long continuance: see a usage of its part. n. munodaminN voce dimonapN.]

2. dam-anati AlmaAXiyapu AlmakaAnu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadomiynN, (Ḳ,) The cattle dunged (M, Ḳ *) and staled (M) in, or upon, the place. (M, Ḳ.) And dm-n AlX-aMCu AlmaMCa The sheep, or goats, dunged in the water. (Ṣ, TA.)
dm-n Alqawomu Ald-aAra, (Ṣ,) or AlmawoDiEa, (M,) The people, or party, blackened [by the dung of their cattle, or by their cooking,] (Ṣ, M,) the house, or abode, (Ṣ,) or the place. (M.)

dm-n fulaAnN finaMCa fulaAnK, (T,) or baAbahu, (Ḳ,) ‡ Such a one came, and kept, or clave, to the court, or yard, of such a one, (T, TA,*) or [simply] kept, or clave, to his door. (Ḳ. [Freytag assigns this signification (which he renders “semper stetit ad alicujus portam”) to Oadomana followed by an accus. case, as on the authority of the Ḳ.])
And dm-nhu, (Kr, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He granted him, or conceded to him, indulgence, or facilitation. (Kr, M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. Admnhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UidomaAnN, (Mṣb,) He did it continually, or perpetually: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he kept, or clave, to it (T, M, Mṣb, TA) without desisting from it, or without quitting it, (M,) constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, (Mṣb,) or inseparably; (TA;) namely, drinking, (T,) and wine, (T, M,), &c. (M.)
[5. tdm-n app. signifies It (water, or a place,) had dung of sheep or goats, or of camels, fallen into it, or upon it: see its part. n. mutadam-anN, below.]
[7. see 1, last sentence.]
damonN: see damaAnN.

dimonN [Dung, such as is called] siroqiyn, (T, M, Ḳ,) or sirojiyn, (Mṣb,) that has become compacted, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and formed a cake upon the ground: (T:) and camels', sheep's, goats', or similar, dung; syn. baEorN: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) also, (T,) or dimonapN↓, of which the former word is the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.], (TA,) [dung of the kind called] baEor, and mud, or clay, that have become mixed together, at a watering-trough or tank, (T, TA,) and compacted, or caked: (T:) and remains of water in a watering-trough or tank. (TA.) See also dimonapN, in three places.
fulaAnN dimonu maAlK is a phrase like UizaMCu maAlK, (Ṣ, TA,) and means † Such a one is a manager, or tender, of cattle, or camels, &c., (Ḳ, TA,) who keeps to them inseparably. (TA.)

dimNnapN: see the next preceding paragraph. Also A trace, (M,) or traces, (Ḳ,) of a house or an abode: (M, Ḳ:*) and the traces of men [in a place where they have sojourned]; and a place which they have blackened; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) where they have left marks of the dung of cattle; a patch of ground which the people who have occupied it have blackened, and where their cattle have staled and dunged: (TA:) [a black, or dark, patch of compacted dung and urine of cattle:] a place near to a house or an abode: (M, Ḳ:) a place in which [dung such as is called] siroqiyn has become compacted, or caked: (M, TA:) and a piece of zibol [i. e. srqyn]: (TA:) pl. dimanN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and dimonN↓, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or [rather] the latter is a [coll.] gen. n.: (M:) [accord. to Az,] dimonN↓ signifies what men have blackened [where they have sojourned, consisting] of the traces of baEor &c.; and is a gen. n., and also pl. of dimonapN. (T.) It is said in a trad., Uiy-aAkumo waxaDoraMCa Ald-imani, meaning † Avoid ye the beautiful woman that is of bad origin: she is thus likened to the herbage that grows in the diman; that appears to be in a flourishing condition, but is unwholesome as food, and of stinking origin. (M. [See also OaxoDaru: and see EuXobapu Ald-aAri, in art. EXb.])

Also ‡ Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) of long continuance (munodaminN↓ M, or qadiymN Ḳ, and vaAbitN TA) in the bosom: it is said that it is not thus termed unless of long continuance: (M, TA:) pl. dimanN (T, Ḳ) and [coll. gen. n.] dimonN↓. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: damaAnN [Dung such as is called] sirojiyn (M) or siroqiyn (Ḳ, TA) with which land is manured; (TA;) [as also damaAlN and dabaAlN.]
And Ashes. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, (Aṣ, Sh, T, Ṣ, M, IAth, Ḳ,) or dumaAnN↓, with damm, like other words significant of diseases and the like, as in the “Ghareeb” of El-Khaṭṭábee, or, accord. to the “Towsheeh,” both of these, and dimaAnN↓, (TA,) and damonN↓, (M, Ḳ,) and OadamaAnN↓, (Ibn-Abi-z-Zinád, T, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,) Rottenness and blackness of a palm-tree: (M, Ḳ:) or the state of a palm-tree UicaA Oanosagato, as Aṣ says, (T, Ṣ, [and the like is said in the M, Oano tunosiga Aln-axolapu,]) but Sh says, correctly, UicaA QnoXaq-ato [when it splits], (T,) in consequence of rottenness and blackness: (T, Ṣ, M:) or, accord. to IAth, corruptness and rottenness of fruits (Alvmr [perhaps a mistranscription for Alt-amor i. e. dates]) before their coming to maturity; as also damaAlN: (TA:) or damaAnN and damaAlN both signify an unsoundness, or infection, in the spadix of the palm-tree, (Mgh and TA in art. dml,) so that it becomes black, (TA ib.,) before it attains to maturity, (Mgh and TA ib.,) or before it is fecundated. (TA ib.)
Also damaAnN, (M, Ḳ,) or in this sense it is correctly dam-aAnN↓, (TA,) One who manures land with [the dung called] siroqiyn. (M, Ḳ,* TA.)

[Golius adds the signification of “Tormentum, supplicium,” as from the KL, in my copy of which the only explanation given is EfwntI kh bh drxt xrmA rsd “a rottenness that infects a palm-tree:” he seems to have found in his copy of that work EqwbtI, either alone, or followed by some words imperfectly written.]

entry.sense: dumaAnN and dimaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.
dam-aAnN: see damaAnN.
dam-uwnN Bad, foul, or unseemly. (Ḳ.)
dum-ayonaI The [hole called] dam-aMC of a jerboa: (Ḳ:) because of its continuance therein. (TA.)

hom.sense: OadomaAnN A certain tree of the [kind called] janobap. (Ḳ. [Golius read mina Aljan-api i. e. “of Paradise,” for mn Aljanobapi.])
Also, accord. to the Ḳ, A certain canker, disease, or bane, of palm-trees: but this is OadamaAnN↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: OadamaAnN: see what next precedes, and damaAnN.
hcA mdmnhm [thus in the TA: app. either madominuhumo, and if so meaning This is their place of continuance, or mudam-anuhumo, meaning the place where their cattle dung and stale].
rajulN mudominu xamorK, (Ṣ,) or mudominu Alxamori, (T,) A man who is a continual drinker of wine; (Ṣ;) an incessant drinker of wine: (T, TA:) likened in a trad. to an idolater. (TA.)
mutadam-anN A place in which, or upon which, cattle have dunged and staled. (Ḳ,* TA.) And water into which the dung of sheep or goats, or of camels, has fallen. (Ṣ.)
munodaminN: see dimonapN, last sentence.

1. damiIa, (T, Ṣ, M, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [held by some to be originally damiwa,] like raDiIa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is from Alr-iDowaAnu, being thus [with I] because of the kesreh, (Ṣ,) [but most hold the last radical to be I,] and damaI, (TA as from the Mṣb, [but not in my copy of the latter work,]) aor. yadomaI, inf. n. damFA or damFI (T, Ṣ, M, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dumiI-N, (Ṣ, MA, [but in the Mṣb it seems to be indicated that it is damaIN,]) said of a thing, (Ṣ,) or of a wound, (Mṣb,) and damiyato said of the arm or hand, (T,) It bled; blood issued from it: (Mṣb:) [and] it was, or became, bloody; i. e., smeared, or defiled, with blood. (MA.)

2. dam-ayotuhu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadomiyapN, (Ṣ,) i. q. Oadomayotuhu↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) i. e. [I made him to bleed;] I struck him, or smote him, so that blood issued from him: (Ṣ:) [and I made him bloody; for] dam-aAhu signifies [also] he smeared him, or defiled him, or made him to be smeared or defiled, with blood. (MA.) Hence the prov., wuloduki mano dam-aI Eaqabayoki, (M, TA,) Thy son is he who made thy two heels to be smeared with blood; (TA in art. wld;) i. e., whom thou thyself broughtest forth; (Ḳ and TA in that art.;) he is thy son really; not he whom thou hast taken from another, and adopted. (TA in that art.)
dm-I AlmaAXiyapa † It (pasture, or herbage,) fattened the cattle so as to make them like what are termed dumFI [pl. of dumoyapN]. (M.)
dam-ayotu lahu, inf. n. as above, ‡ I made a way easy to him. (Ḳ, TA.)
† I made, or brought, [a thing] near to him. (Ḳ.) You say, dam-aI lahu fiI kacaA wakacaA † He made, or brought, near to him [some object of desire in such and such cases]. (Th, M.)
† I appeared to him. (Ḳ.) One says, xuco maA dam-aI laka † Take thou what has oppeared to thee. (Th, M.)
4: see 2.

hom.sense: 10. AstdmI He (a man) stooped his head, blood dropping from it; (M;) as also AisotadaAma, formed by transposition from AstdmI. (Kr, TA in art. dwm.)
AstdmI gariymahu † He acted gently with his debtor; as also AisotadaAmahu: (Fr, M and Ḳ in art. dwm:) judged [by ISd] to be formed by transposition from the latter. (M in that art.)
AstdmI mawad-atahu He looked, or watched, or waited, for his love, or affection: [formed by transposition] from AisotadaAma. (M in art. dwm.)

damN [Blood;] one of the [four] OaxolaAT [or humours], (M,) well known: (T, M, Ḳ:) accord. to some, (Mṣb,) it is originally damawN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or it is originally damFI; (Zj, Mbr, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) thus in the correct copies of the Ḳ; (TA; [in some copies damoIN, and in the CK damaIN;]) though deviating from other words of the same form in respect of its pl. [which see below]; (Mbr, Ṣ;) as is shown by its dual, (Zj, M,) which is damayaAni, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) whereby [also] the letter gone from it is shown to be I; (Mbr, Ṣ;) but it has also for its dual damaAni; (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and some of the Arabs say damawaAni; (Ṣ, M;) in which last, however, [accord. to ISd,] the w is substituted for I, though generally w is changed into I: (M:) and this original form is used by a poet, [namely, Hoseyn Ibn-El-Homám, accord. to one of my copies of the Ṣ,] in his saying,
falasonaA EalaI AlOaEoqaAbi tadomaI kuluwmunaA
walekino EalaI OaqodaAminaA yaqoTuru Ald-amaI↓
[And we have not our wounds bleeding upon the heels; but upon our feet the blood drops]: (Ṣ:) or it is originally damoIN; (Sb, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) as is shown by its pls., (Sb, Ṣ,) which are dimaMCu (Sb, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and dumiI-N, (Sb, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) also pronounced dimiI-N; (TA;) like as ZaboIN and dalowN have for their pls. ZibaMCu and ZubiI-N and dilaMCN and duliI-N; for if it were like qafFA and EaSFA, it would not have such pls. (Sb, Ṣ.) dam-N is ignored by Ks; but is used by poetic license; (M;) or it is a dial. var. of damN. (Ḳ in art. dm.) damapN↓ has a more special signification than damN, the two words being like bayaADapN and bayaADN; (Ṣ;) [i. e.] it signifies A portion of blood: (T, M, Ḳ:) or it is a dial. var. of damN, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to IJ. (M.) The dim. of damN is dumaI-N↓. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] rajulN cuw damK A man seeking to obtain, or prosecuting for, [the revenge of] blood. (TA.) damu fulaAnK fiI vawobi fulaAnK is a saying of the Arabs, meaning † Such a one is the slayer of such a one. (Ḥam p. 632.) Ald-amu Ald-amu waAlhadomu Alhadomu, or waAlhadama Alhadama, is a saying of the Arabs, meaning If thy blood be sought, my blood shall be sought; and if thy blood go for nought, my blood shall go for nought: or, accord. to the latter reading, as is said in the Nh, and where thou shalt be buried, I will be buried: or thine abode shall be mine abode. (JM in art. hdm, q. v.) See also an ex. voce dumoyapN.

damu AlOaxawayoni [The red, resinous, inspissated juice called dragon's blood;] what is called AlEanodamu; (Ṣ;) i. q. damu AlgazaAli; (Ḳ voce maZ-N;) now called AlqaATiru Alamik-I-u; or a species thereof; (TA;) [vulgarly qaTor mak-ap; and also called damu Alv-uEobaAni;] what is called in Pers. xuwn siyaAwuXaAn (Ḳ.)

damu AlgizolaAni A certain herb, or leguminous plant, having a beautiful blossom: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, dumoyapu↓ AlgizolaAni is the name of a certain herb, or leguminous plant, having a blossom. (T.)
banaAtu damK A certain plant, (M, Ḳ,) well known; (Ḳ;) a certain red plant. (T in art. bnI.)
Ald-amu The cat: (M, Ḳ:) mentioned by En-Naḍr in “The Book of Wild Animals.” (M.)

entry.sense: damapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Ald-amaI, said to be the original form of Ald-amu: see damN.
damK Bleeding; having blood issuing from it: (Ṣ,* Mṣb:) [and] bloody; i. e. smeared, or defiled, with blood: and daAmK↓ signifies the same [in both senses]. (MA.)

dumoyapN An image, or effigy, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) of ivory and the like, (Ṣ,) or of marble, (M, Ḳ,) variegated, decorated, embellished, or coloured, (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) in which is redness like blood: (Mgh:) or an image, or effigy, in a general sense: (Kr, M, Ḳ:) accord. to Abu-I-ʼAlà, because originally painted with red, as though from Ald-amu: and any beautiful female is likened thereto, because adorned: (TA:) metonymically applied to ‡ a woman: (IAạr, T:) or anything that is deemed beautiful in respect of whiteness: (TA:) and an idol: (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ:) said in the R to be so called because of the shedding of blood at the place thereof for the purpose of propitiation; but MF says that this derivation requires consideration: more probably because it is decorated: (TA:) pl. dumFI. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.) Accord. to MF, it is also pronounced dimoyapN↓. (TA.) One says, OaHosanu mina Ald-umoyapi, meaning More beautiful than the image of ivory. (Ḥar p. 611.) And laAwa Ald-umaI is an oath of the Pagan Arabs, meaning No, by the idols: or, as some relate, it is laA waAld-imaMCi↓ meaning No, by the blood of what is sacrificed upon the stones set up to be worshipped: so in the Nh. (TA.)
The pl., dumFI, also signifies Garments upon which are pictures or effigies. (Ṣ.)
See also damN, last sentence but two.
dimoyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
damoyaMCu, as in the Tekmileh; in the Ḳ, erroneously, daAmiyaMC↓, (TA,) Good, or good fortune, and prosperity. (Ḳ,* TA.)
[In the phrase xc mA dm-I, in Freytag's Lex., dmI- is a mistake for dam-aI: see 2, last sentence.]
dumaI-N dim. of damN, q. v. (Ṣ.)
damawiI-N: see damiI-N.
Ald-amawiy-apu, meaning Hectic fever (Hum-aI Ald-iq-i) is a vulgar word of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)
daAmK: see damK. [And see the next paragraph.]
daAmiI AlX-afapi, (M, Ḳ,) applied to a man, (M,) [lit. Having a bleeding lip,] means ‡ poor. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
XajarapN daAmiyapN † A beautiful tree. (TA.)

daAmiyapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Xaj-apN daAmiyapN, (T,* M,* Mṣb,) A wound in the head that bleeds but does not flow with blood (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) as yet: (M:) such as flows with blood is termed daAmiEapN. (T, Mṣb.) [See Xaj-apN.]
daAmiyaMC: see damoyaMCa.

mudam-FI Red; applied to a garment, or piece of cloth: (M:) or anything in the colour of which is blackness and redness: (T:) [of a dark red colour, like blood:] or anything intensely red: (Ṣ:) applied in this last sense [particularly] to a horse, &c.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, applied to a horse, of a sorrel colour (OaXoqaru) intensely red, like the colour of blood: (T:) or, so applied, of an intense sorrel colour: (M:) and kumayotN mudam-FI of an intensely red bay colour: (Ṣ, TA:) or of an intense red colour like that of blood: (TA:) or intensely red in the back [and] as far as the thin and soft parts of the belly: and OaXoqaru mudam-FI of which the sorrel colour is overspread, in its upper portion, with a yellowness like the colour of the yellow [or gilded] bay: (AʼObeyd, T:) and lawonN mudam-FI a colour in which is blackness. (M.) sahomN mudam-FI An arrow upon which is the redness of blood (Ṣ, Ḳ) that has adhered to it so that it inclines to blackness: a man, when he shot at the enemy with an arrow, and hit, and the enemy then shot it at him with blood upon it, used to put it in his quiver, auguring good from it: or, as some say, it means an arrow which the archers shoot by turns, one at another; an explanation reducible to that before mentioned: (Ṣ:) or an arrow which one shoots at his enemy and the latter then shoots at the former: (M:) or an arrow shot once. (T.)
musotadomK Having blood dropping from the nose, while stooping the head. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
† One who draws forth his debt from his debtor with gentleness. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. dan-a: see R. Q. 1, in four places.

[danina is mentioned by Golius and Freytag (by the former as from the Ṣ) as though it were the verb of which dananN (q. v.) is the inf. n.; but I find no authority for it: and if dananN have a verb, it should, accord. to rule, be dan-a, aor. yadan-u.]

entry.sense: 2: see R. Q. 1.

4. Adn-, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. UidonaAnN, (T, TA,) He (a man, T, TA) remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (T, Ḳ, TA,) [as though set in the ground like a dan-,] baAlmakaAni in the place; like Oaban-a: (T, TA:) on the authority of Aboo-Turáb, (T,) or Ibn-El-Faraj. (TA.)

R. Q. 1. danodana It buzzed, or made a buzzing sound; syn. Saw-ata, and Tan-a, (Ḳ,) and TanoTana; (Sh, T, TA;) as also dan-a↓, and dn-n↓; said of the fly, (Ḳ,) [and of the bee, and of the hornet, and the like; for] danodanapN [inf. n. of danodana] (Lth, T, M, Ḳ) and daniynN [inf. n. of dan-a↓] (Lth, T, M) and dinodinN↓ [a simple subst.] (M) signify the buzzing (Sawot, Lth, T, M, Ḳ) of the fly, (M, Ḳ,) or the bee, (Lth, T,) and the hornet, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ,) and the like. (M.)

And [hence,] He (a man) spoke in a low, gentle, or soft, tone, so that his speech was not understood; (AʼObeyd, Ḳ, TA;) [as also dan-a↓; for] danodanapN [inf. n. of the former] (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and daniynN [inf. n. of dan-a↓] and dinodinN↓ (M, Ḳ) signify the speaking in a low, gentle, or soft, tone, (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ,) or in the manner termed hayonamapN, (M, Ḳ,) so that the speech is not understood: (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M:) or danodanapN signifies [merely] the speaking in a low, or faint, tone: (M:) accord. to IAth, it is a little above what is termed hayonamapN. (TA.) A poet says,
nudanodinu mavola danodanapi Alc-ubaAbi
[We buzz in our speech like the buzzing of the fly]. (Sh, T.) And it is said in a trad., HawolahaA nudanodinu, (Ṣ,) or HawolahumaA, (M, JM, TA,) which is thus explained: the Prophet asked an Arab of the desert, “What dost thou say in the taXah-ud?” [see this word, which means the repetition of a form of words at the close of the ordinary prayers:] and he answered, “I ask of God Paradise, and seek protection of Him from the fire [of Hell]: but as to thy danodanap and the danodanap of Mo'ádh, I do not approve it:” and the Prophet said, HawolahumaA nudanodinu; (M, JM;*) i. e. [We speak with a low, or faint, voice] about those two things, namely, the seeking Paradise and the praying for protection from the fire [of Hell]; and on account of them: (JM:) accord. to some, it is from danodana Hawola AlmaMCi He went round about the water: [hence it may mean we utter our prayer respecting them with a low, or faint, sound, as though we were buzzing round about them like flies; seeking to enter the one, and to keep outside the other:] Aṣ says that it may be from the signification of the sound [of buzzing], or from that of going round about: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, the Prophet said, EanohumaA nudanodinu [From a consideration of them we utter our prayer with a low, or faint, voice;] i. e. our danodanapu arises from them; and is because of them: and hence, (JM,) danodana means also He (a man, JM) went to and fro in one place. (JM, TA.)

dan-N A wine-jar: (MA:) a [jar of the kind called] Hub-: (Ṣ:) or [a jar] in form like a Hub-: (Mṣb:) or a large raAquwd [or earthen jar, smeared inside with pitch, long in the lower part], (M, Ḳ,) in form like the Hub-, (M,) but taller; (M; in the Ḳ, or taller than the Hub-;) uniform in make, [tapering to the bottom,] having at the lower end what resembles the qawonas [or tapering top] of a helmet: (M:) or smaller than the Hub-, having a pointed lower extremity, [so I render EusoEusN, (agreeably with the TḲ,) regarding it as a dial. var., or perhaps a mistranscription, of EuSoEuSN, which properly signifies the “os coccygis,”] (M, Ḳ,) so that (M) it will not sit [upright] without one's digging a hole for it: (M, Ḳ:) IDrd says that it is a genuine Arabic word: (M:) pl. [of mult.] dinaAnN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb) [and dinanapN and (of pauc.) OadonunN and Oadun-N, as appears from the following saying of IAạr, quoted by Az:] one says dan-N and OadonunN and Oadun-N and dinaAnN and dinanapN. (T.) [See an ex. in a verse of El-Aạshà cited voce AirotisaAmN.]

dananN A bending, or curving, in the back [so that it resembles a dan-: see Oadan-u]: (M, Ḳ:) and a nearness [to the ground] in the neck and breast, (M, Ḳ,) and a stooping, (M,) and lowness, therein, (M, Ḳ,) by original natural constitution: it is in a man, (M,) and in a horse or the like, and any quadruped: (M, Ḳ:) or shortness, and lowness, or depression, of the neck: (R, TA:) or, in a horse, shortness of the fore legs: or, accord. to Aṣ, in any quadruped, nearness of the breast to the ground; which is one of the worst of faults: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to AZ, in a camel, a leaning forward, with shortness of the fore legs: and, accord. to AHeyth, in a horse or similar beast, shortness of the fore legs, and a consequent nearness of the neck to the ground. (T.)
din-apN A certain insect resembling an ant: (Ḳ:) so called because of its shortness. (TA.)

din-iy-apN The [kind of cap called] qalanosuwap, of a Kádee; likened to a dan-; (Ḳ;) a qlnswp worn by Kádees, as though so called in relation to the dan-, because high and round: (Ḥar p. 109:) accord. to Esh-Shereeshee, originally daniynapN; a qlnswp pointed at the extremity, [in my original AlATrAf is erroneously put for AlT-araf,] worn by Kádees and great men: not a genuine Arabic word, but of the dial. of El-'Irák. (TA.)

hom.sense: dinodinN syn. with danodanapN: see R. Q. 1, in two places.

Also Herbage (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and trees, (M, Ḳ,) or dry herbage, (Aṣ, T,) become black, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or wasted and black, (M,) by reason of oldness: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ:) or what is broken in pieces of [the species of barley-grass called] buhomaI, when it has become black and old: or the stems (OuSuwl) of old and wasted trees: (M:) accord. to Lth, the stems (ASwl) of trees: but the right explanation is that given above on the authority of Aṣ. (T.)

entry.sense: danaAdinu The calaAcil [or lower parts, that are next the ground,] of garments. (Ḳ.)

Oadan-u One whose back resembles the dan-; (IAạr, T;) [i. e.] having a bending, or curving, in the back; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) applied to a man; (Ṣ;) hump-backed: (Fr, TA in art. Ejr:) and having the neck and breast near [to the ground], (M, Ḳ,) and stooping, (M,) and low, (M, Ḳ,) by original natural constitution: applied to a man, (M,) and to a horse or the like, and any quadruped: (M, Ḳ:) or, applied to a horse, short in the fore legs: (Ṣ:) or, applied to a camel, leaning forward, with shortness of the fore legs: (AZ, T:) or, applied to a horse or the like, short in the fore legs, and consequently having his neck near to the ground: (AHeyth, T:) Aṣ said that no Oadan- ever outstripped except that of the Benoo-Yarbooa: (M:) fem. dan-aMCu. (M, Ḳ.) [See also dananN.]
Also, applied to a house, or chamber, or tent, (bayot, [for which Golius appears to have read nabot,]) Low, or depressed, [app. in its roof.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. danaOa, aor. _a {yadonaOu}; and danuWa, aor. _u {yadonuOu}; inf. n. danaMCapN, (AZ, Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the former verb, and of the latter also, (AZ, Lḥ, T, M,) and dunuwoCN, of the former, (Fr, T,) or of the latter, (AZ, T,) and [of the latter] dunuwoCapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He (a man) was, or became, low, ignoble, or mean, in his actions; and cared not for what he did, nor for what was said to him: (ISk and T in explanation of the former verb, and Ṣ in explanation of both verbs:) or the former verb, (AZ, T,) or each, (Lḥ, T, M, Ḳ,) he was, or became, bad, corrupt, or foul, in respect of the belly and the genital member [i. e. in respect of appetite for food and for sexual enjoyment]; not caring for what he did, nor for what was said to him: (AZ, Lḥ, T, M, Ḳ:) and the former verb, (Ṣ) or each, (M, Ḳ,) [accord. to some,] he was, or became, such as is termed daniIoCN, i. e. xasiysN [app. as meaning contemptible]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) like danaA, aor. yadonuw, inf. n. danaAwapN; (Mṣb;) and destitute of good: (Ṣ:) but some make a distinction between the verbs with C and the verb without C; saying that the meaning “he was, or became, xsys” is that of dnA, without C; (T, Mṣb;) and the truth is, that the verbs with C have the meanings assigned to them by AZ and Lḥ; (T;) or signify he was, or became, low, ignoble, or mean: (Mṣb:) or these two verbs also signify, (Ḳ,) or signify as some say, (M,) he was one in whom was little or no good; contemned or contemptible, mean, paltry, or of no weight or worth. (M, Ḳ.)
daniYa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadonaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. danaON, (Ṣ, M,) He was, or became, hump-backed. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: 4. AdnO He committed an action such as is termed daniIoCa. (M, Ḳ.*)
5. tdn-Ohu He, or it, incited him to danaMCap [i. e. low, ignoble, or mean, conduct;, &c.: see danaOa and danuWa, of which danaMCap is an inf. n.]. (Ḳ.)

daniIoCN (AZ, Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and daAniYN↓, (Lḥ, T, Ṣ,* M, Ḳ,) applied to a man, Low, ignoble, or mean, in his actions; not caring for what he does, nor for what is said to him: (Ṣ:) or bad, corrupt, or foul, in respect of the belly and the genital member [i. e. in respect of appetite for food and for sexual enjoyment]; not caring for what he does, nor for what is said to him: (AZ, Lḥ, T, M, Ḳ:) and [accord. to some,] i. q. xasiysN [app. as meaning contemptible]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) like daniI-N, without C; (Mṣb;) and destitute of good: (Ṣ:) but some make a distinction between daniIoCN and daniI-N; saying that the latter means xsys; (T, Mṣb;) and the former, as explained by AZ and Lḥ; and this is the truth; (T;) or that daniIoCN means laYiymN [i. e. low, ignoble, or mean, as contr. of kariymN]: (Mṣb:) daniIoCN is also applied to an action: (M, Ḳ:* [see 4:]) and signifies likewise, (Ḳ,) or as some say, and so daAniYN↓, (M,) one in whom is little or no good; contemned or contemptible, mean, paltry, or of no weight or worth: (M, Ḳ:)
the pl. of daniIoCN is OadoniyaMCu, (AZ, T, M,) or OadoniYaMCu, (Lḥ, T, TA,) or OadonaMCN, (Ḳ, TA,) like OaXoraAfN pl. of XariyfN, (TA,) and dunaMCN, (Ḳ,) which is anomalous, (TA,) or dunaOLCu. (M.)
daniyoYapN A low, or base, quality, property, natural disposition, habit, practice, or action; syn. naqiySapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or such as is blamed; also pronounced daniy-apN. (TA in art. dnw, q. v.)
daAniYN: see daniIoCN, in two places.

hom.sense: OadonaOu [More, and most, low, ignoble, or mean, in his actions;, &c.]. You say, huwa OadonaOu minohu [He is more low,, &c., than he]. (Zj, T.) Fr says that OadonaI in the Ḳur ii. 58 is [for OadonaOu,] derived from danaMCapN: accord. to one reading, it is OadonaOu. (TA.)
Applied to a man, (M,) Hump-backed: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:*) fem. danoOaI. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: 2. dan-ara, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoniyrN; (Ḳ;) and tdn-r↓; (A;) ‡ It (a man's face) glistened (T, M, A, Ḳ) like a diynaAr. (TA.)
dun-ira He (a man, TA) had many danaAniyr [pl. of diynaAr]. (Ḳ.)
See also the pass. part. n., below.
5: see 2.
dunayoniyrN: see the next paragraph.

diynaArN, an arabicized word, (M, Ḳ,) from the Persian [diynaAro], (M,) or from diyno Mro, meaning “the law brought it” [into being or circulation]: (Er-Rághib:) some say, (TA,) its original is din-aArN; one of its n being changed into I (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) to render it more easy to be pronounced, (Mṣb,) or that it may not be confounded with inf. ns., such as kic-aAbN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and hence its pl. is danaAniyru, (M, Mṣb,) and its dim. dunayoniyrN↓: (M:) this is the opinion generally obtaining: others say that it is of the measure fiyEaAlN; but this opinion is contradicted by the absence of the I in [the second syllable of] the pl.; for were it so, its pl. would be like dayaAmiysu, pl. of diymaAsN: (Mṣb:) [it is the name of A certain gold coin;] its weight is seventy-one barley-corns and a half, nearly, reckoning the daAniq as eight grains of wheat and two fifths; but if it be said that the dAnq is eight grains of wheat, then the dynAr is sixty-eight grains of wheat and four sevenths: it is the same as the mavoqaAl. (Mṣb.)
XaraAbN diynaAriI-N A kind of wine or beverage, so called in relation to Ibn-Deenár el-Hakeem, or because like the dynAr in its redness. (TA.)
mudan-arN, applied to a diynaAr, (M, Ḳ,) and to gold, (TA,) Coined. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
Also A man having many danaAniyr [pl. of diynaAr]. (M, Ḳ.)

Also ‡ A horse having specks, or small spots, exceeding what are termed baraXN: (AO, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or having black and white spots like danaAniyr: (Mgh:) or having a spotting (tadoniyr↓) of black intermixed with whiteness predominating over blackness: (TA:) and of a white colour predominating over blackness, with a round blackness intermixed with the former colour upon his back and rump: (M:) or of a white hue intermixed with red, (OaSohabu,) marked with round black spots. (A.)
Also ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, with marks, or figures, like danaAniyr. (A.)

1. danisa, aor. _a {yadonasu}, inf. n. danasN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and danaAsapN, (Ḳ,) It (a garment, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) was, or became, dirty, filthy, foul, sullied, defiled, or polluted; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also tdn-s↓: (Ṣ, M, A:) and in like manner ‡ said of a man's honour, (Ḳ, TA,) and ‡ of his disposition. (TA.)

2. dn-shu, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoniysN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He, or it, made it (namely a garment, Ṣ, A, Ḳ) dirty, filthy, or foul; sullied, defiled, or polluted, it. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.) And in like manner, dn-s EiroDahu ‡ [He sullied his honour;] he did to him that which disgraced him. (A, Ḳ.) And dn-shu suwoCu xuluqihi ‡ [The evilness of his disposition sullied his honour]. (A, TA.)
5: see 1.

danasN Dirt; filth; soil, or pollution: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) pl. OadonaAsN. (M.) [Hence,] huwa yataSaw-anu mina AlOadonaAsu ‡ [He preserves his honour from pollutions], and mina AlmadaAnisi↓ ‡ [from causes of pollution, madaAnisu being pl. of madonasapN↓, a noun of the same kind as maboxalapN and majobanapN]. (A, TA.)

danisN Dirty, filthy, foul, sullied, defiled, or polluted: (M, Ḳ:) [pl. OadonaAsN, agreeably with analogy, and dunasaMCu, contr. to analogy; but the latter is perhaps post-classical.] You say, qawomN OadonaAsN and madaAniysN↓ [A people dirty, filthy,, &c.; both in a proper and in a tropical sense]. (Ḳ.) And huwa danisu AlmuruwoCapi and Alv-iyaAbi and Aljayobi and AlOarodaAni ‡ [He is foul in character, conduct, or the like]. (A.)
madaAniysN: see danisN.

1. danifa, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadonafu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. danafN; (M, Mṣb;) and Adnf↓; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or, accord. to Sb, one does not say danifa, though they sometimes said danifN, for he regarded this as a possessive epithet; (M;) said of a sick man, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) He had a constant, or chronic, disease: (Mṣb: [see danafN, below:]) or he was, or became, heavy, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) by reason of disease, (Mgh, TA,) and near to death, (Mgh,) or at the point of death: (TA:) or he became emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death. (M.)
And [hence,] danifati AlX-amosu, and Adnft↓, ‡ The sun was near to setting, and became yellow. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And danifa AlOamoru ‡ The thing, or event, was, or became, near (Ḳ, TA) to passing. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Adnf: see 1, in two places.

Adnfhu, said of a disease, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It rendered him constantly, or chronically, ill; or clave to him constantly: (Mṣb:) or it rendered him heavy [so that he was near to death, or at the point of death: see 1]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or, said of God, He caused him to become emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death. (M.) Thus the verb is trans. as well as intrans. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
And Oadonafotu AlOamora ‡ I caused the thing, or event, to be near, or brought it near, (Ḳ, TA,) to passing. (TA.)
danafN A constant, or chronic, disease; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) such as infects, or pervades, the person or the inside: or, as some say, any disease, whatever it be. (M.)

Also, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and danifN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter held by Sb to be a possessive epithet, as he disallowed the verb danifa, (M,) A man having a constant, or chronic, disease; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) such as infects, or pervades, his person or his inside: or, accord. to some, having any disease: or emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death: and mudonafN↓ and mudonifN↓ signify the same: (M:) or these two signify rendered heavy by disease [so as to be near to death, or at the point of death: see 1]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) [and Freytag adds daAnifN↓, explained as meaning “interitui obnoxius,” as from the Ḥam; in which I only find (p. 624) authority for danifN, signifying being at the point of death or destruction:] danafN is used alike as masc. (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and fem. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and sing. (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and dual (Ṣ, M) and pl., (Fr, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) as though it were an inf. n. used as an epithet: (M:) but if you say danifN↓, you vary it for the fem. and dual and pl., (T,* Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) saying AimoraOapN danifapN, (Ṣ, M,), &c., (Ṣ,) i. e., saying also rajulaAni danifaAni, (TA,) and qawomN OadonaAfN, (M,) or rijaAlN OadonaAfN: (TA:) and sometimes danafN has a dual form and a pl.; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] one may say OaxawaAka danafaAni and Uixowatuka OadonaAfu. (Fr, T.)

Applied to the sun, it means ‡ Near to setting, (M, TA,) and (TA) becoming yellow. (T, TA.) So in the saying (of El-ʼAjjáj, T, TA),
waAlX-amosu qado kaAdato takuwnu danafaA
‡ [And the sun had almost become near to setting, and to turning yellow]. (T, M, TA.) [See Q. 2 in art. zHlf.]

entry.sense: danifN: see danafN, in two places.
daAnifN: see danafN.
mudonafN: see danafN.
mudonifN: see danafN.

1. danaqa, aor. _u {yadonuqu} and _i {yadoniqu}, inf. n. dunuwqN, He pursued small, little, or minute, things. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, Ḳ. [See also 2.]) [Two other significations assigned to danaqa in the CK and in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag belong to dan-aqa.]

2. dn-q, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) inf. n. tadoniyqN, (Mgh, Ḳ,) He went to the utmost point [in his dealings, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) he was minute, observant of small things, nice, or scrupulous: (Mgh:) he examined minutely into his dealings and expenses. (So accord. to an explanation of the act. part. n. in the TA.) Hence the saying, laA tudan-aquwA fayudan-aqa Ealayokumo [Go not ye to the utmost point against others, for in that case the utmost point may be gone to against you]. (Ṣ, TA.) And the saying of El-Ḥasan, (Mgh, TA,) laEana Qll-ehu Ald-aAnaqa wamano dan-aqa, (TA,) or wamano dan-aqa bihi, (Mgh,) [May God curse the dAnq and him who has been minute,, &c., in his dealings, or and him who has been minute,, &c., therewith;] as though he meant to forbid the considering and examining a paltry or contemptible thing: (TA:) or, as some relate it, waOaw-ala mano OaHodava Ald-aAnaqa [and the first who innovated the dAnaq], meaning El-Hajjáj. (Mgh.)
[Hence,] tadoniyqN, metonymically, signifies ‡ The being niggardly, stingy, or avaricious. (Az, TA.)

Also The continuing to look at a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also taroniyqN: [or rather each has this signification elliptically; for] you say, dn-q Uilayohi Aln-aZara and rn-q [meaning He continued looking at it]. (Ṣ.) [See ran-aqa.] And in like manner, The looking weakly. (Ṣ, TA.) And dn-q baSarahu He looked hard, and sharply, or intently. (JK.)
Also ‡ The approaching of the sun to setting. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say, dn-qt AlX-amosu ‡ The sun became near to setting. (JK, TA. [See also rn-qt.])
And dn-q ‡ He (a man) died: (JK, TA:) or ‡ he was near to dying; inf. n. as above. (TA.)

And dn-qt Eayonuhu, (JK, Ḳ, TA, [accord. to the CK danaqato, which is wrong,]) inf. n. tadoniyqN, (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ His eye sank, or became depressed, in his head: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to Az, the more correct explanation is, the ball, or globe, of his eye became prominent, and apparent. (TA.)
And dn-q wajohuhu, (Lth, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, danaqa,]) inf. n. tadoniyqN, (Lth, TA,) His face exhibited emaciation, arising from fatigue or disease. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.)
dunuwqN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Persons niggardly, or parsimonious, in expenditure, towards their households (IAạr, Ḳ, TA) and themselves. (IAạr, TA.)

daniyqN One who alights by himself, (TA,) and eats by himself in the daytime, and in the moonlight by night, last the guest should see him: (Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by IAạr, on the authority of Abu-I-Mekárim: and so kiySN and SuwSN. (TA.)
daAnaqN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: daAniqN Foolish; stupid; having little, or no, intellect, or understanding: (Ḳ:) and so daAYiqN. (TA.)
‡ A thief. (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA.)

Emaciated and falling down, or emaciated and tottering; expl. by mahozuwlN saAqiTN: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or falling down, or tottering, (saAqiTN,) by reason of emaciation: (JK:) applied to a man (AA, Ḳ) and to a she-camel. (Ḳ.)
Having a constant, or chronic, disease, and oppressed thereby so as to be at the point of death. (AA, TA.)

Also, and daAnaqa↓, (JK, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former, accord. to some, the more chaste, arabicized [from the Pers. daAnok or daAnak], (Mṣb,) and daAnaAqN↓, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) like as they said dirohamN and dirohaAmN, (Ṣ,) [but daAnaAqN seems to have been disallowed by Sb, either as unused or as post-classical,] The sixth part of a dirhem (or drachm); (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [i. e.] two carats; (Mgh;) [i. e.] two grains of the xuronuwb [or carob], with the ancient Greeks, for the dirhem with them was twelve grains of the xrnwb; but the dAnq of the Muslims is two grains of the xrnwb and two thirds of a grain of the xrnwb, for the dirhem of the Muslims is sixteen grains of the xrnwb: (Mṣb:) and the sixth part of the deenár: (TA: [but this I find nowhere else: see diynaArN: and see also riTolN:]) the pl. of dAnq is dawaAniqu and dawaAniyqu; (Mgh, TA;) the former is said by Az to be pl. of daAniqN; and the latter, of daAnaqN; and it is said that every pl. of the measure fawaAEilu or mafaAEilu may be lengthened with I so that one may say fawaAEiylu and mafaAEiylu: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to Sb, dawaAniyqu is pl. of daAnaAqN↓, though this be not in their speech. (TA.) [Also A small silver coin, the sixth part of the coin called diroham.] The dim. is duwayoniyqN↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: daAnaAqN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

dawaAniqiI-N [rel. n. from dawaAniqu pl. of daAniqN], (El-Mekeen, “Hist. Sarac.” p. 104,) or dawaAniyqiI-N [rel. n. from dawaAniyqu pl. of daAnaAqN], (TA,) [Of, or belonging or relating to, dániks: and hence,] a surname of the 'Abbásee Khaleefeh Aboo-Jaáfar El-Manṣoor; (El-Mekeen, TA;) because of his extreme niggardliness. (El-Mekeen.)
duwayniyoqN: see daAniqN, last sentence.
mudan-iqN One who examines minutely into his dealings and expenses: used in this sense by the people of El-'Irák. (TA.)

EayonN mudan-iqapN An eye of which the ball, or globe, is prominent, and apparent: so accord. to AZ; and Az holds this to be the correct explanation, rather than an eye sunk, or depressed, in the head. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. danaA, (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) first pers. danawotu, (T, Ṣ,) aor. yadonuw, (T, Mṣb,) inf. n. dunuw-N (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and danaAwapN, (M, Ḳ,) He, or it, was, or became, near; drew near, or approached; (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AdnI↓; (IAạr, T, Ḳ;) and dn-I↓, inf. n. tadoniyapN; (IAạr, T;) and dAnI↓, inf. n. mudaAnaApN; (KL, but only the inf. n. is there mentioned;) and Aid-anaI↓, inf. n. Aid-inaMCN: (TA:) it is either in person, or substance, or in respect of predicament, and in place, and in time: (El-Harállee, TA:) you say, danaA minohu, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) and danawotu minohu, (T, Ṣ,) and Uilayohi, (M, Mṣb,) and lahu, (TA,) and Ealayohi occurs in a verse of Sá'ideh as meaning minohu, (M,) He, or it, and I, was, or became, near,, &c., to him, or it: (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb:) [and in like manner you use the other verbs mentioned above, except dAnI↓, which is immediately trans.: or danaA minohu with danaAwapN for its inf. n. means, or means also, He was near to him in respect of kindred; was related to him: for] danaAwapN is syn. with qaraAbapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and qurobaI: (M, Ḳ:) you say, bayonahumaA danaAwapN meaning qaraAbapN [i. e. Between them two is relationship]; (Ṣ;) and maA tazodaAdu min-aA Uil-aA qurobFA wadanaAwapK [Thou increasest not save in nearness and relationship to us]. (ISk, T, Ṣ.) A rájiz says,
maA liI OaraAhu daAlifFA qadodunoIa lahu
meaning duniIa lahu [i. e. What hath happened to me that I see him walking gently or with short steps, or rendered lowly by age, having been approached by death?]: it is from danawotu, but the w is changed into I because of the kesreh before it, and then the n is made quiescent: and there are similar instances of contraction of verbs: but [ISd says,] I know not dunoIa except in this instance; and Aṣ used to say of the poem in which this occurs, This rejez is not ancient: it is app. of Khalaf El-Ahmar or some other of the Muwelleds. (M.) One says also, danati AlX-amosu lilomaguruwbi and Oadonat↓ [The sun was, or became, near to setting]. (M.)

daniIa, (T, M, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, mA kAna danoyaA wlqd danA is erroneously put for maA kaAna daniyFA walaqado daniIa,]) like raDiIa, (TA,) aor. yadonaI, (T,) inf. n. danFA (T, M, Ḳ) and danaAyapN, (T, Ḳ, TA,) or dinaAyapN; (M, accord. to the TT; and so in the CK; [app. a mistranscription occasioned by a misunderstanding of what here follows;]) the I [in daniIa] being substituted for w because of the nearness of the kesreh; all on the authority of Lḥ; (M;) and danuwa, aor. yadonuw, without C, inf. n. danaMCapN, with C, (ISk, T,) and dunuw-N; (T;) or danaA, aor. yadonuw, inf. n. danaAwapN; i. q. danaOa and danuWa; (Mṣb;) [i. e.] He (a man, T, M) was, or became, such as is termed daniI-N↓; (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and daniIoCN; (Mṣb;) meaning weak; contemptible (xasiysN); not profitable to any one; who falls short in everything upon which he enters: (T: [like mudan-K:]) or low, ignoble, or mean; (saAqiTN;) weak; (M, Ḳ;) such as, when night affords him covert, will not quit his place, by reason of weakness: (M:) or low, ignoble, or mean, (laYiymN,) in his actions, or conduct; bad, evil, or foul; accord. to the explanation of danaA by Es-Sarakustee: but some distinguish between daniIoCN and daniI-N; making the former to signify “low, ignoble, or mean;” (laYiymN;) and the latter, xasiysN [app. as meaning contemptible]. (Mṣb, and so the latter is explained in the Mgh.)
2: see 1:
and 4.

It is said in a trad., sam-uwA wasam-ituwAwa dan-uwA, i.e. [Pronounce ye the name of God, (i. e. say, In the name of God,) and invoke a blessing upon him at whose abode or table ye eat, (see art. smt,) and] make your words to be near together in praising God. (M.) And in another trad., UicaA Oakalotumo fasam-uwA Qll-eha wadan-uwA, i. e. [When ye eat, pronounce the name of God, and] eat of that which is near you: (M:) or UicaA Oakalotumo fadan-uwA, i. e. [When ye eat,] eat of that which is next you. (Ṣ.)

dan-aI, (T, M,) inf. n. tadoniyapN, (T,) also signifies He (a man) sought after mean, paltry, or contemptible, things. (Lḥ, T, M.) And dn-I fiI AlOumuwri, (inf. n. as above, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He pursued small matters, and mean, paltry, or contemptible: (T, Ṣ, TA:) in the Ḳ, erroneously, and great. (TA.)
Also He was, or became, weak; syn. DaEufa. (Ṣ and TA in art. dwn.)

entry.sense: 3. dAnI, inf. n. mudaAnaApN: see 1, in two places. You say also, daAnayotu AlOamora I was, or became, near to [doing, or experiencing,] the affair, or event. (M.)

daAnayotu Alqayoda lilobaEiyri I made the shackles, or hobbles, strait, or contracted, to the camel. (M, Ḳ.) And daAnaI Alqayodu qayonaIi AlbaEiyri (M, TA) The shackles, or hobbles, straitened, or contracted, [the two parts of the camel that were the places thereof.] (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
daAnaI lahu Alqayodu fiI dayomuwmapK qacafK
qayonayohi waQnoHasarato Eanohu AlOanaAEiymu
[The shackles, or hobbles, straitened to him, in a far-extending, wide desert, the two parts of him that were the places thereof, and enjoyments became removed from him]. (M.) And you say also, daAnayotu bayona AlOamorayoni I made the two affairs, or events, to be nearly uninterrupted; syn. qaArabotu: (T, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or I made the two affairs, or events, to be connected; syn. jamaEotu. (M.)

hom.sense: 4. AdnAhu He made him, or it, to be, or become, near; to draw near, or to approach; he drew near, or brought near, him, or it; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also dn-Ahu↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoniyapN. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] Oadonato vawobahaA EalayohaA She (a woman) let down her garment upon her, and covered, or veiled, herself with it. (Mgh.) And Oadonayotu Als-itora I let down the veil, or curtain, [for the purpose of concealment.] (Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 59], yudoniyna Ealayohin- mino jalaAbiybihin-a [They shall let down upon them a portion of their outer wrapping-garments]; (Mgh;) meaning they shall let down a portion of their outer wrapping-garments over their faces, when they go forth for their needful purposes, except one eye. (Jel.)
AdnI is also intrans.: see 1, in two places.

[Hence,] Oadonato, said of a she-camel, (Ṣ, TA,) and of a woman, (TA,) She was, or became, near to bringing forth. (Ṣ, TA.) And Oadonato EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [a phrase similar to OaDoraEato EalaI raOosi Alwaladi, q. v.]. (Occurring in a verse cited in the TA in art. fkh.)
And AdnI He lived a strait life, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) after easiness and plenty. (IAạr, T.)

entry.sense: 5. tdn-I He (a man, Ṣ) drew near, or approached, by little and little. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
6. tadaAnawoA They drew near, or approached, one to another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] tdAnI It (a thing) drew together, or contracted; or became drawn together or contracted. (M* and L in art. qlS.)
And tadaAnato Uibilu Alr-ajula The camels of the man became few and weak. (M.)
8. Aid-anaI, inf. n. Aid-inaMCN: see 1.

10. AstdnAhu He sought, desired, or demanded, of him, nearness, or approach; (M, Ḳ, TA;) he sought, or desired, to make him draw near, or approach: and he drew him near, or caused him to approach. (MA. [See also 4.])

hom.sense: danFA inf. n. of daniIa, q. v. (T, M, Ḳ.)
OadonaI danFA: see AdnI.

entry.sense: huwa Qbonu Eam- dinoIK and dinoyFA and dinoyaA and dunoyaA↓ mean [He is a son of a paternal uncle] closely related; syn. laH-FA [q. v.]: when you pronounce the d with damm, you do not make the word perfectly decl.: when you pronounce it with kesr, you make it either perfectly or imperfectly decl.: but when you prefix Eam- to a determinate noun, dinoI may not be in the gen. case: for instance, you say, huwa Qbonu Eam-ihi dinoyFA, i. e. [He is the son of his paternal uncle] closely related; as also dinoyapN↓; because dinoI, being indeterminate, cannot be an epithet applied to that which is determinate: (Ṣ:) and [in like manner] you say, huwa Qbonu Eam-iI, or Abn xaAliI, or Abn Eam-atiI, or Abn xaAlatiI, or Abn OaxiI, or Abn OuxotiI, (M, Ḳ,) all mentioned by Lḥ, the last two as on the authority of Aboo-Safwán, but all except the first and second as unknown to Ks and to Aṣ, (M,) followed by dinoyapN↓ and dinoyFA and dinoyaA and dunoyaA↓, (M, Ḳ, TA,) the last two without tenween, (TA; [and so written in the M; but in the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, in the place of these two is put dunoyFA, which is disallowed by J;]) meaning [He is the son of my paternal uncle, and the son of my maternal uncle,, &c.,] closely related: (M, Ḳ:) and huwa Eam-uhu dunNyaA↓ and dinoyapF↓ and dinoyFA and dinoyaA [He is his paternal uncle closely related]: (Ks, T:) Lḥ says that the w is changed into I in dinoyapF↓ and dinNyFA because of the nearness of the kesreh and the weakness of the intervening letter, as is the case in fitoyapN and EiloyapN: but it seems that these words are originally dunoyaA↓, i. e., by a relationship, or uterine relationship, nearer to me than others; and that the change of the letter is made only to show that the I is that of the fem. of OadonaI. (M.) You say also, humo rahoTuhu dinoyapF↓ They are his people, and his tribe, closely related. (Ṣ and TA in art. rhT.)
dinoyapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.
dunoyaA fem. of OadonaI [q. v.].
dunoyiI-N: see what next follows.
dunoyawiI-N: see what next follows.
dunoyaAwiI-N [Of, or relating to, the present world, or state of existence; worldly:] a rel. n. from Ald-unoyaA; (T, Ṣ;) as also dunNyawiI-N↓ and dunoyiI-N↓. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: daniI-N i. q. qariybN [as meaning Near, in person, or substance, or in respect of predicament, and in place, and in time: (see 1, first sentence: and see also daAnK:) and a relation]: (T, Ṣ:) and a friend; or a sincere, or secret, or particular, friend; syn. xuloSaAnN. (T.) It has these significations (of qryb and xlSAn) in the prov. kul-u daniI-K duwanhu daniI-N [app. meaning There is a relation, or a friend, nearer than every other relation, or friend; like another prov., namely, duwna kul-i qurayobaI qurobaI, for the meaning and application of which see art. qrb: Freytag renders it, “Quod attinet ad quemlibet propinquum (amicum), præter eum est propinquus:” (Arab. Prov. ii. 357:) and he adds, “Proverbii sensus esse videtur: Quilibet propinquus seu amicus unicus non est; sed præter eum est alius”]: (T, Meyd:) so says AZ. (Meyd.)
See also OadonaI.

As an epithet applied to a man, signifying Weak; contemptible;, &c.: see 1, near the end of the paragraph: [but J says that] as meaning duwnN, it is [daniIoCN,] with C: (Ṣ:) the pl. is OadoniyaMCu. (T, M.) [In the CK, by a mistranscription mentioned above (voce daniIa), danoIN is made to signify the same.]

entry.sense: daniy-ahN A low, or base, quality, property, natural disposition, habit, practice, or action; syn. naqiySapN; (Mgh;) or such as is blamed; originally daniyoYapN: (TA:) pl. danaAyaA. (Ḥar p. 327.) Hence the saying of Ibn-Háritheh, Almaniy-apa laA Ald-aniy-apa, meaning I choose death rather than, or not, disgrace. (Ḥar ubi suprà.)
daAnK [Being, or becoming, near; drawing near, or approaching: and hence, near; like daniI-N:] act. part. n. of danaA minohu. (Mṣb.)

OadonaI Nearer, and nearest; opposed to OaqoSaI: (TA:) fem. dunoyaA; (M, TA;) in which the [radical] w is changed into I, as in EuloyaA and quSoyaA: (ISd, TA voce buqowaI:) [the pl. of the masc. is OadaAnK and Oadonawona; the latter in the accus. and gen. Oadonayoni: and] the pl. of the fem., dunFI, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) like kubarN pl. of kuboraI, and SugarN pl. of SugoraI; (Ṣ, TA;) said by some to be extr. and strange [in respect of usage]; and El-Mutanebbee has been blamed for using it; (MF, TA;) but in the case referred to he has used Ald-unaI for Ald-unoyaA, [not as a pl.,] suppressing the I by poetic license. (TA.) [Hence,] gulibati Alr-uwmu fiI OadonaI AlOaroDi, in the Ḳur xxx. 1 and 2, The Greeks have been overcome in the nearer, or nearest, part of the land. (Bḍ, Jel.) And Aljamorapu Ald-unoyaA [The nearest heap of pebbles;] the heap of pebbles nearest to Minè. (TA. [See art. jmr.])
And Als-amaMCu Ald-unoyaA [The nearest heaven; i. e. the lowest;] the heaven that is the nearest to us: (T, TA:) also called samaMCu Ald-unoyaA [which means the heaven of the present world; as will be seen from what follows]. (TA.) See also exs. of the fem. in the paragraph commencing with the words huwa Qbonu Eam-K dinoIK, in four places.

Also Former, and first; and fore, and foremost; opposed to MxirN. (TA.) [Hence,] laqiytuhu OadonaI daniI-K↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and OadonaI danFA↓, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AdnI dan-Ie and AdnI daniI-K,]) i. e. I met him the first thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And OadonaI Alfami The fore, or foremost, part of the mouth.] And Ald-unoyaA [for Ald-aAru Ald-unoyaA, and AlHayaApu Ald-unoyaA, The former dwelling, or abode, and life; i. e. the present world, and life, or state of existence]; contr. of AlMxirapu: (M, Ḳ:) [or] it is so called because of its nearness: (T, Ṣ:) [and may be rendered the sublunary abode,, &c.: and the inferior abode,, &c. It also signifies The enjoyments, blessings, or good, of the present world, or life; worldly blessings or prosperity,, &c.] And sometimes it is with tenween, (Ḳ, TA,) when used indeterminately: (TA:) [thus,] IAar mentions the saying maA lahu dunoyFA walaA MxirapN [as meaning He has none of the enjoyments, or blessings, of the present world, nor in prospect any enjoyments, or blessings, of the world to come]; with tenween. (M, TA.) And you say, baAEa dunoyaAhu biMxiratihi [He purchased his enjoyments of the present world at the expense of his enjoyments of the world to come]. (Z, TA in art. byE.) And Aabonu Ald-unoyaA means The rich man. (Mṣb in art. bnI.)

Also More, and most, apt, fit, or proper: thus in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 59], in the phrase celika OadonaI Oano yuEarafona [That will be more, or most, apt, fit, or proper, that they may be known]; (Ksh, Mgh;) i. e., that they may be known to be free women, as distinguished from female slaves, who did not cover their faces. (Jel.)

Also Less [in number or quantity, &c.], and least [therein]; opposed to Oakovaru. (TA.) walaA OadonaI mino celika walaAOakovara, in the Ḳur [lviii. 8], means Nor less in number than that, nor more in number. (Bḍ.) And walanuciyqan-ahumo mina QloEacaAbi QloOadonaI duwna QloEacaAbi QloOakobari, in the Ḳur [xxxii. 21, lit. And we will assuredly make them to taste of the smaller punishment besides the greater punishment], means, accord. to Zj, whatever punishment is inflicted in the present world and the punishment of the world to come. (M.)

Also Worse, [or inferior in quality,] and worst; or more, and most, low, ignoble, base, vile, mean, or weak; opposed to xayorN. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 58], Oatasotabodiluwna Ql-aciI huwa OadonaI biQl-aciI huwa xayorN [Will ye take in exchange that which is worse, or inferior, for that which is better? or], accord. to Zj, meaning that which is less in value [for that which is better]? AdnI being thus, without C: Fr says that it is here from Ald-anaMCapN: and Zuheyr El-Kurkubee [or (accord. to some) El-Furkubee] read OadonaOu. (T.)
mudonK and mudoniyapN, applied to a she-camel, (M, Ḳ,) and to a woman, (M,) Near to bringing forth. (M, Ḳ.)

mudan-K, applied to a man, Weak; (Ṣ, TA;) contemptible (xasiysN); not profitable to any one; who falls short in everything upon which he enters; [like daniI-N;] (TA;) or falling short of accomplishing that which it behooves him to do: (AHeyth, T:) also, for the sake of rhyme, [by poetic license,] written mudano. (T.)

R. Q. 1. dahodaha, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. dahodahapN, (JK,) He rolled a stone down; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA;) as also dahodaI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. dahodaApN and dihodaMCN: (Ṣ:) or he cast stones, or a thing, from a higher to a lower place. (JK.)
And He turned over a thing, one part upon another; (Ḳ;) as also dahodaI. (TA.)
And He collected together camels to drive them. (JK.)
R. Q. 2. tadahodaha, said of a stone, (Ṣ, Ḳ,), &c., (Ṣ,) It rolled down; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA;) as also tadahodaI. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And hence, He, or it, was quick. (Ḥar p. 108.)

Uil-aA daho falaA daho, (JK, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or Uil-aA dahK falaA dahK, (Aṣ, IAạr, Ṣ, TA, and so in copies of the Ḳ,) a saying of the Arabs, meaning If this thing be not now, it will not be after the present time: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) Aṣ says, I know not its origin, but I think it to be Pers., and to mean, if thou strike not him, or it, now, thou wilt not strike him, or it, ever: (Ṣ:) accord. to IAạr, it is said to a man when he is at the point of accomplishing his want in respect of a creditor of his, or in respect of his blood-revenge, or in respect of paying honour to a friend of his; (TA;) and means if thou seize not the opportunity now, thou wilt never meet with it: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to Lth, (TA,) it means, if thou avenge not his blood, or if thou slay him not in blood-revenge, now, thou wilt never do so. (JK, TA.) Accord. to Aṣ, one says also, laA dahK falaA dahK, meaning I will not accept either of the two actions proposed. (TA.) Az says that this saying shows dh to be Pers., and to mean The act of striking: you say to a man, diho↓, meaning Strike thou: and he says, I have seen it written with kesr in the book of AZ. (TA.) diho↓ in Pers. means Give thou: and metonymically, the act of striking. (TA.)

hom.sense: duho duho A cry by which camels are chidden; (IAạr, TA;) a cry by which camels are called to their young ones. (Ḳ in art. dwh.)
duho dur-ayoni, or duho dur-ayono: see art. dhdr.

entry.sense: diho: see daho, last two sentences.
dahodahapN A hundred camels, and more; (JK, Ḳ;) as also dahodahaAnN↓ and duhayodihaAnN↓: (Ḳ:) or ↓the second of these three words signifies many camels. (JK, Ṣ.)
dahodahaAnN: see what next precedes, in two places: and what next follows.

dahodaACN Small, or young, camels: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. dahaAdihu. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.) A rájiz says,
qado rawiyato Uil-aA duhayodihiynaA↓
qulay-iSaAtK waOubayokiriynaA
[They had satisfied their thirst, except some small, or young, camels; little young she-camels and little young he-camels]: as though he formed from dahodaAhN the pl. dahaAdihu; and from this, the dim. duhayodihN; and from this, the pl. duhayodihiyna [in the nom. case duhayodihwuna]: (Ṣ, TA:*) and in like manner, Oubayokiriyna as pl. of OubayokirN, dim. of OabokurN, pl. of bakorN. (Ṣ.) [Accord. to a passage imperfectly written in the TA, it seems to signify also Many small, or young, camels; and so, as there written, dhdAn, app. for dahodahaAnN↓.]
One says also, maA OadoriI OaI-N Ald-ahodaAhi huwa, (TA,) or Ald-ahodaOi and Ald-ahodaMCi, the last on the authority of Ks, meaning I know not what one of men he is. (Ṣ, TA.)

duhoduwhN, (Ḳ, [accord. to the TA duhoduwahN, but this is a mistake,]) or duhoduwhapN, (IB,) The thing which the juEal [or species of black beetle called cantharus] rolls, (IB, Ḳ, TA,) consisting of dung which it collects, (IB, TA,) in a round form; (TA;) and so duhoduw-apN and duhodiy-apN, [the last of these, for alleviation of the utterance,] also without teshdeed. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
duhayodihaAnN: see dahodahapN.
duhayodihiyna: see dahodaAhN.

duhodur-N a noun signifying What is false, or vain; a lie; syn. baATilN and kacibN: as also duhodur-ayoni, (Ḳ,) its dual, (TA,) or duho dur-ayoni, or duho dur-ayono: (as in different copies of the Ṣ:) whence duhodur-ayoni and duhodur-iy-apN↓ are epithets applied to a liar; or a great or habitual liar: and accord. to AZ, the Arabs used to say, duhodur-aAni laA yugoniyAani Eanoka XayoYFA [Lies will not avail thee aught]: and duhodun-N signifies the same as duhodur-N. (TA.)

duhodur-ayoni is also a noun, (Ḳ,) i. e. a verbal noun, (TA,) signifying He was, or has become, unoccupied, or without work; syn. baTala; (Ḳ;) like saroEaAna for saruEa, and hayohaAti for baEuda. (TA.) Hence the prov., (TA,) duhodur-ayoni saEodu Alqayoni, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) without the conjunction wa [after the first word], and dhdr-yn being written as one word, (TA,) meaning Saạd the blacksmith became, or has become, unoccupied, or without work; not being employed because of the people's being diverted from other things by drought (Aṣ, Ḳ) and distress. (TA.) Some say saAEdu Alqayoni: and Aboo-ʼObeydeh Maạmar Ibn-El-Muthennà relates it thus: dhdr-yn saEoda Alqayon, with sEd in the accus. case, and says that dhdr-yn is governed in the accus. case by a verb understood; apparently meaning that it is a noun signifying AlbaATilu, dual of duhodur-N, not a verbal noun, as though the prov. meant Cast ye away what is false, or vain, and Saạd the blacksmith: but what he says is not correct. (TA.)
Or a certain blacksmith asserted his name to be Saad for some time, and then his lying became manifest; so this was said to him; meaning, Thou hast added falsehood to falsehood, O Saạd the blacksmith. (Ḳ.) It is also related separately; (Ḳ;) and so J and others relate it; saying dh dr-yn: (TA:) [in one copy of the Ṣ, I find it written duho dur-ayono: in another, duho dur-ayoni:] duho being an imperative from Ald-ahaMCu; its final radical letter being transposed to the place of the medial, so that it becomes duwoho, and the w being then rejected because of the two quiescent letters, (Ḳ,) so that it becomes duho, like as is done in the case of qulo: (TA:) and dur-ayoni being from dar-a, “it was consecutive;” (Ḳ;) by the dual form being meant repetition, as in the case of lab-ayoka, &c.: (TA:) so that the meaning is Be thou very lying (Ḳ) and cunning, (TA,) O Saạd (Ḳ) the blacksmith: (TA:) and this explanation, says IB, is good, except inasmuch as that the d in dr-yn thus derived should be with fet-ḥ; or, he adds, it may be with damm to assimilate it to the d in duho [like as Alqayoni is terminated with kesr to assimilate it to dur-ayoni]. (TA.) Or the origin of the saying was this: Saạd the blacksmith was a Persian, who went about the districts of El-Yemen, working for the people; and when he became without work in a district, he used to say, in Persian, diho badoruwdo: [so in a copy of the Ṣ; and this, or diho bidoruwdo, is the correct reading: in another copy of the Ṣ, daho baduwrudo: and in the copies of the Ḳ, diho badoruwdo:] (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) meaning, [O town, or village,] farewell: to acquaint them that he was going forth on the morrow: (Ḳ:) or meaning I am going forth to-morrow: (Ṣ:) in order that he might be employed: and they arabicized the expression, and made him the subject of a prov. with respect to lying; and said, When ye hear of the blacksmith's departure at night, he is assuredly coming in the morning. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Some say that the prov. is elliptical, for baTala qawolu saEodK Alx [False is the saying of Saạd, &c.]. (TA.) [This is mentioned in the Ṣ in art. dr.]
duhodur-ay-apN: see above, first sentence.
Q. 1. dahodaI, inf. n. dahodaApN: see R. Q. 1 in art. dh.
Q. 2. tadahodaI: see R. Q. 2 in art. dh.
dahodaMCN: see dahodaAhN, in art. dh.

[duhoduw-apN app. originally duhoduwoyapN, like as quw-apN is held by some to be originally quwoyapN,] and duhodiy-apN [likewise originally duhoduwoyapN], and the latter also without teshdeed [for alleviation of the utterance]: see duhoduwhN, in art. dh.

1. daharahumo OamorN, (JK, A, Ḳ,) and dahara bihimo OamorN, (Ṣ, TA,) aor. _a {yadoharu}, (Ḳ,) An event befell them (Ṣ, A) from fate, or fortune: (A:) or an evil event befell them. (JK, Ḳ.) In a trad. respecting the death of Aboo-Tálib occur these words [as said by him]: lawo laA Oan-F qurayoXFA taquwlu daharahu AljazaEu lafaEalotu [Were it not that the tribe of Kureysh would say, Impatience hath befallen him, (or, perhaps, constrained him, from dahorN signifying “fate,” or overcome him, see what follows,) I would do it]. (TA.)

daharahu, (Bḍ in xlv. 23,) inf. n. dahorN, (Ḳ,) He overcame, conquered, subdued, overpowered, or mastered, him; gained the mastery, prevailed, or predominated, over him; or surpassed him. (Bḍ ubi suprà, B,* Ḳ.)

3. EaAmalahu mudaAharapN and dihaArFA is like muXaAharapF [i. e. it means He made an engagement, or a contract, or bargain, with him to work, or the like, for a long period, or for a constancy; like as muXaAharapF means “for a month”]. (Ḳ.) And in like manner one says, AisotaOojarahu mudaAharapF and dihaArFA [He hired him for a long period, or for a constancy]. (Lḥ, TA.)
Q. Q. 1. dahowarahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. dahowarapN, (TA,) He collected it together, and threw it into a deep place. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He pushed it, namely, a wall, so that it fell. (Ḳ.)
dhwrAll-uqama He made the mouthfuls large, (Ṣ, A,) or round, (Az,) and gulped them down. (Az, A.)
Q. Q. 2. tadahowara It (sand) poured down, and for the most part fell. (Mṣb.)
And hence, He, or it, fell down, from a higher to a lower place. (Mṣb.)
And It (the night) for the most part went: (Mṣb:) or departed, or retreated. (Ḳ, TA.)

dahorN (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) and daharN↓, (M, Ḳ,) the latter either a dial. var., agreeably with the opinion of the Basrees in cases of this kind, and therefore such cases are limited by the authority of hearsay, or it is so written and pronounced because of the guttural letter, and so is accordant to a universal rule, agreeably with the opinion of the Koofees, (ISd,) Time, from the beginning of the world to its end; (Esh-Sháfiʼee, Az, Mṣb, Er-Rághib;) as also HiynN: (Esh-Sháfiʼee, Az:) this is the primary signification: (Er-Rághib:) and any long period of time; (Z, Mgh, Ḳ, Er-Rághib;) thus differing from zamaAnN, which will be explained below: (Er-Rághib:) and a portion of the longest period of time: (Az:) or dahorN signifies, (Ṣ, A,) or signifies also, (Az, Mṣb,) time; or a time; or a space, or period, of time; syn. zamaAnN, (Sh, Az, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) whether long or short: (Mṣb:) or this is the proper signification of zamaAnN, but not of dahorN: (Er-Rághib:) and ‡ a division of the year: and ‡ a less period: (Az, Mṣb:) Az says, I have heard more than one of the Arabs say, OaqamonaA EalaI maMCi kacaA dahorFA [We stayed at such a water a long time, or a time]; and hecaA AlmaroEaI yakofiynaA dahorFA [This pasture-land will suffice us a long time, or a time]; but one does not say that Ald-ahoru is four times, or four seasons, because its application to ‡ a short period of time is tropical, and an extension of its proper signification: (Mṣb:) or it signifies i. q. OabadN [meaning a long unlimited time; or an extended indivisible space of time; or duration without end; time without end]; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) it differs from zamaAnN in having no end: (Khálid Ibn-Yezeed:) or a prolonged, or lengthened, term; syn. OabadN mamoduwdN: (Ḳ, in some copies of which, in the place of Abd, we find Oamad:) and ‡ the period, or duration, of life; an age: (Kull p. 183:) the present state of existence: (Mṣb:) and † a thousand years: (Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OadohurN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] duhuwrN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) both said to be pls. of dahorN, and no other pls. are known as those of daharN; the form OadohaArN not having been heard. (TA.)
You say maDaI Ealayohi dahorN and duhuwrN [A long time and long times, or an age and ages,, &c., passed over him, or it]. (A.)
And kaAna celika dahora Aln-ajomi That was in the time of God's creation of the stars; meaning, in the beginning of time; in ancient time. (A.)
[And fiI Oaw-ali Ald-ahori In the beginning of time. (A.)]
[And yaboqaI Ald-ahora It remains for ever.]
[And laA Mtiyhi Ald-ahora I will not come to him, ever. See also daAhirN.]
And SaAma Ald-ahora [He fasted ever, or always]. (TA in art. Awl, &c. [See a trad. cited voce Mla, in that art.])

[Hence, because, in one sense, time brings to pass events, good and evil,] Ald-ahoru was applied by the Arabs to Fortune; or fate: and they used to blame and revile it: and as the doing so was virtually blaming and reviling God, since events are really brought to pass by Him, Moḥammad forbade their doing thus. (Az, Mgh, TA, &c.) It is said in a trad., laA tasub-uwA Qld-ahora faUin-a Qld-ahora huwa Qll-ehu, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA, &c.,) or, accord. to one reading, faUin-a Qll-ehu huwa Qld-ahoru, (Az, Mgh, TA, &c.,) in which some explain Aldhr in the first proposition as having a different meaning from that which it has in the second, whereas others assign to it the same meaning in both cases: (TA:) the meaning of the trad. is, Revile ye not [fortune, or] the Efficient of fortune; for the Efficient of fortune is God: (Az, Ṣ, TA, &c.:) or, accord. to the second reading, for God is the Efficient of fortune. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) some reckon Ald-ahoru as one of the names of God: (Ḳ, &c.:) but some disallow this: and some say that it is allowable if meant to signify, as rendered above, the Efficient of fortune. (TA, &c.)
zawoju dahorK A husband prepared for the accidents or calamities of fortune. (Ṣ in art. bhr. [See bahorN.])
dahorN also signifies An evil event or accident; a misfortune; a calamity. (Ḳ.) See also dahaAriyru. [And see 1.]

Also A purpose; an intention: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a desire: (TA:) the scope, or end that one has in view. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, maA dahoriI bikacaA, (Ṣ, TA,) and maA dahoriI kacaA, (TA,) My purpose, or intention, (Ṣ, TA,) and my desire, and my scope, or the end that I have in view, (TA,) is not such a thing. (Ṣ, TA.)

Also ‡ A custom, or habit, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that is constant, or permanent, (Kull p. 183,) or that lasts throughout life. (TA.) You say, maA caAka bidahoriI ‡ That is not my custom, or habit, (Ṣ,) that lasts throughout my life: (TA:) and maA dahoriI bikacaA ‡ My habit throughout life is not so. (TA.)
daharN: see dahorN.

dahoriI-N (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and duhoriI-N↓ (Ḳ) One who deviates from the truth, and introduces into it that which does not belong to it, syn. muloHidN; (Ṣ, A;) who asserts that the duration of the present world is from eternity, (A, Mṣb,) or that it is everlasting, (Ḳ,) and does not believe in the resurrection, (Mṣb,) or in the world to come. (TA.)

And the latter, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the former, (IAmb,) An old, or aged, man. (IAmb, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Th says that both are rel. ns. from Ald-ahoru, though the latter is contr. to rule, [as is also remarked in the Mṣb,] like suholiI-N from AlOaroDu Als-aholapu. (Ṣ.)
Some say also that the latter signifies An acute, or ingenious, or expert, man. (TA.)
duhoriI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
dihoraArN: see dahaAriyru.
duhruwrN: see dahaAriyru.
dihoriyrN: see dahaAriyru.
dahyirN: see daAhirN.

dahaAriyru, a pl. without a sing.; (Ḳ, TA;) or its sing. is dahorN↓, like as the sing. of macaAkiyru is cakarN, and that of maXaAbihu, XabahN; or its sing. is duhoruwrN↓, or dihoraArN↓, [in the TA written by mistake dhrAt,] or dihoriyrN↓; (TA;) Misfortunes; calamities: as in the phrase waqaEa fiI Ald-ahaAriyri He fell into misfortunes, or calamities. (A, TA.)

Also Severe, or calamitous. (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad. of Sateeh,
faUin-a caA Ald-ahora OaTowaArFA dahaAriyru
[For verily this age is at times calamitous]. (TA.) dahorN dahaAriyru, A severe, or calamitous, age, is a phrase like layolapu layolaMCu, and nahaArN Oanoharu, &c.: (Ṣ:) [see also daAhirN:] and it also signifies a time of two states, adverse and prosperous: (TA:) and duhuwrN dahaAriyrN, various, or varying, times: (Ḳ:) or long times. (A.) [See daAhirN.]

Also dahaAriyru [or rather, as IbrD says, dahoru Ald-ahaAriyri, for this has the signification immediately following,] The beginning of time past: and [absolutely] preceding, or past, time. (Ḳ, TA.) You say kaAna celika fiI dahori Ald-ahaAriyri [That was in the beginning of past time: or in the time of by-gone ages]. (TA.)

dahorN daAhirN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and dahorN dahiyrN↓ (Ḳ) are phrases in which the epithet has an intensive effect, [meaning A long, or an endless, period, or course, of time,] (Ḳ,) like OabadN OabiydN (Ṣ, TA) and OabadN MbidN: (TA:) or a severe, or calamitous, age. (TA.) [See also dahaAriyru.]
laA Mtiyka dahora Ald-ahiriyna I will not come to thee, ever: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) similar to the phrase Oabada AlMbidiyna. (TA.)
humo madohuwrN bihimN, and madohuwruwna, They are afflicted with an evil event. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. dahiXa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yadohaXu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. dahaXN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and duhiXa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) which is said to be formed by transposition from Xudiha, but Az denies this, and says that duhiXa is the superior form; (TA;) He became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he became bereft of his reason or intellect (Mṣb, Ḳ) in consequence of shame, or of fear, (Mṣb,) or of heedlessness, or diversion by some occupation, or of fear, or grief, or intense grief, (Ḳ,) or of fright, and the like: (TA:) and dh-X↓, inf. n. tadohiyXN, signifies the same: (Ḳ, TA:) or this last is trans., like AdhX. (TḲ.)
dahaXahu: see 4.
2: see 1:
and 4.

entry.sense: 4. AdhXhu He, (God, Ṣ, TA, or a man, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or it, (shame, A, TA, and an affair, TA,) confounded, or perplexed, him, so that he was unable to see his right course: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or bereft him of his reason or intellect; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also dahaXahu↓, aor. _a {yadohaXu}, inf. n. dahoXN; but some disallow this; (Mṣb;) and dh-Xhu↓. (TḲ.)

dahiXN (A, Ḳ) and madohuwXN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dahoXaAn↓ [whether with or without tenween is not indicated] (TA) Confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or bereft of his reason or intellect (Mṣb, Ḳ) in consequence of shame, or of fear, (Mṣb,) or of heedlessness, or diversion by some occupation, or of fear, or grief, or intense grief, (Ḳ,) or of fright, and the like. (TA.)
OaSaAbatohu dahoXapN [A fit of confusion, or perplexity, so that he was unable to see his right course, or a fit of alienation of mind in consequence of shame or fear,, &c., befell him]. (A, TA.)
dahoXaAn: see dahiXN.
madohuwXN: see dahiXN.

hom.sense: Q. 1. dahoqana: see the next paragraph.

dahoqanuwhu, (inf. n. dahoqanapN, TḲ,) They made him a dihoqaAn. (Ḳ.) El-ʼAjjáj says,
duhoqina biAlt-aAji wabiAlt-asowiyri
[He was made a dhqAn by receiving the tAj (meaning either crown or turban) and by being decked with bracelets]. (TA.)

dahoqana AlT-aEaAma, (AʼObeyd, TA,) inf. n. dahoqanapN, with which dahomaqapN is syn., (Aṣ, TA,) He made the food soft, or delicate: (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, TA:) because softness, or delicacy, of food is from Ald-ahoqanapu [as meaning Alt-adahoqun]. (Aṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: Also He affected, or feigned, or made a show of, sharpness or quickness of intellect, cleverness, ingeniousness, skilfulness, knowledge, or intelligence; syn. takay-asa. (TA.)

dahoqanapN [inf. n. of Q. 1: and signifying The state, or condition, of a dihoqaAn;] a subst from dihoqaAnN; (JK, Ḳ;) derived from the latter word. (Mgh.) You say, lahu dahoqanapN bimawoDiEi kacaA [He has a state, or condition, which is that of a dihoqaAn in such a place.] (Ṣ.)

dihoqaAnN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) also written duhoqaAnN, (JK, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in [some of] the copies of the Ṣ written [dihoqaAnN and dahoqaAnN,] with kesr and fet-ḥ, [thus written in one of my copies of the Ṣ,] and said by AO [as there cited] to be like qrTAs, which is written with each of the three vowels, (TA,) an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from the Pers. [diho “a town or village” and xaAno “a prince or lord”]; (TA;) if derived from tadahoqana, (Kh, Sb, Ṣ,) i. e. if the n be regarded as radical, perfectly decl. [and written as above]; (Kh, Sb, Ṣ;) but if derived from Ald-ahoqu, imperfectly decl. [and written dihoqaAnu, &c.], because of the measure fElAnu; (Ṣ;) [but this statement relates especially to the measure faEolaAn, with fet-ḥ to the f; except in the case of a proper name; and an epithet of this measure, moreover, that forms its fem. by the addition of p, as dhqAn does, is perfectly decl.; and it should be observed also, that,] accord. to IJ, dhqAn is of the measure fElAl, from tadahoqana, and there is no instance, in the language, of the measure tafaEolana; (Ḥar p. 102;) it signifies The headman, or chief, of a village or town: (Es-Sem'ánee, Mṣb, TA: [agreeably with the Pers. original:]) or the proprietor thereof, in Khurásán and El-'Irák: (Es-Sem'ánee, TA:) or, as used by the Arabs, a great man of the unbelievers of the 'Ajam [or Persians]: but they disdained this appellation: (Mgh:) Lth says that it is a nickname, or name of reproach: (TA:) it became predominantly applied to such of them as was of the people of the districts of cultivated land and of villages or towns: and then to anyone possessing much land or other immoveable property: (Mgh:) [it signifies generally a dweller, or one having a fixed abode, in a district of cultivated land, or in a village or town of such a district; a rustic; a husbandman:] or it signifies a chief, headman, or person in authority, over the husbandmen, or peasants, of the 'Ajam [or Persians]: and the headman of a province: (Ḳ:) and a possessor of land or other immoveable property: (Mṣb:) and a merchant: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and one who manages affairs firmly, or strongly, with sharpness: (Ḳ:) the fem. is with p {dihoqaAnapN}: (JK, Mgh, Ḳ:) and the pl. is dahaAqiynu (Mṣb, Ḳ) and dahaAqinapN. (Ḳ.) [See a verse cited voce jacaA in art. jcw. The same verse, but with qaroyatiI (my village or town) in the place of qaroyapK, is also cited in the TA in the present art.]

diholiyzN [An entrance-passage of a house; an entrance-hall; a vestibule;] what is between the [outer] door or gate and the house; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the place of entrance to a house: (Mṣb:) a Persian word, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) originally dAlyj, and dAlyz, and dAlAn, and, as some say, daliyjN, (Lth,) arabicized: (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb:)
[also, in modern Arabic, an antechamber: and the anterior apartment of a large tent or pavilion: accord. to the MA, a large tent: accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, i. q. jayoYapN: accord. to some, xaniy-apN, which reading is preferred by the author of the TḲ, who explains dhlyz, from the “Burhán,” as meaning “absurd words:” accord. to some, Haniy-apN, which I think the right reading, meaning a bowed, or curved, structure: Golius seems to have found another reading in the Ḳ, namely, Hay-apN:] pl. dahaAliyzu. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] OabonaMCu Ald-ahaAliyzi † Foundlings, (Ḳ,* TA,) whose fathers are unknown. (TA.) [They are so called because they are generally abandoned at the entrances of mosques or private houses, whence they are usually taken by persons who adopt them.]

1. dahimahumo (Ṣ, Mṣb) and dahamahumo, (Mṣb,) aor. _a {yadohamu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. dahomN, (TA,) It (an event, Ṣ, Mṣb) came upon them, or happened to them, suddenly, unexpectedly, without their being aware of it, or without any previous cause; surprised them; took them by surprise, or unawares: (Mṣb:) or dahamaka and dahamaka, aor. _a {yadohamu}, it (anything) came upon thee so as to overwhelm thee, or cover thee, or as a thing that overwhelmed thee, or covered thee. (Th, Ḳ.) And dahimatohumu Alxayolu [The horsemen came upon them suddenly,, &c.]: and AO says that dahamatohum is a dial. var. thereof. (Ṣ.) See also dahomN, below.
2. dah-amati Aln-aAru Alqidora, inf. n. tadohiymN, The fire blackened the cooking-pot. (ISh, Ḳ.)
4. Adhmhu It (an action done to him, Th, TA) displeased, grieved, or vexed, him, (Th, Ḳ,) and angered him. (Th, TA.)

5. [tdh-m is said by Golius, as on the authority of the Ḳ, to be syn. with tdAm (meaning tdO-m); but app. on no other ground than that of his finding it there said that Almutadah-amu is syn. with AlmutadaO-amu.]

9. Adhm-, inf. n. AidohimaAmN, He (a horse) became Oadoham, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. black. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) And AdhAm-↓, inf. n. AidohimaAmN, It (a thing) was, or became, black. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Hence,] AdhAm-↓ Alz-aroEu The seedproduce [became of a dark green colour, or] was overspread with blackness, by reason of abundance of moisture, or irrigation. (JK, TA.) And in like manner, AdhAm-t↓ Alr-awoDapu and Adhm-t [The meadow became of a dark green colour,, &c.]. (JK.) And AdhAm-t↓ AlxuDorapu The greenness became intense [so as to appear blackish, or so as to appear black when viewed from a distance]. (TA.)
11. AdhAm-: see the next preceding paragraph {9}, in four places.

hom.sense: dahomN A malicious, or mischievous, or grievous, act, by which one takes others unawares, or by surprise. (TA from a trad.)

Also, (Ṣ, TA,) or duhomN↓, (JK, and so in one place in the TA,) A numerous company: (Lth, JK, TA:) or a multitude: pl.duhuwmN. (Ṣ.) A rájiz says,
jiYonaA bidahomK yadohamu Ald-uhuwmaA↓
majorK kaOan-a fawoqahu Aln-ujuwmaA
