[We came with a numerous company that would overwhelm the other numerous companies; a great army, as though the stars were above it]. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also dahomaMCu, voce Oadohamu.] And one says, maA OadoriI OaI-u Ald-uhomi↓ huwa, and OaI-u duhomi↓ Qll-ehi huwa, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) or AI- Ald-ahomi hw, and AI- dahomi Qll-eh hw, (so in the CK and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) i. e. I know not what one of the creation, or of mankind, he is, and what one of the creatures of God he is. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: duhomN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
Also pl. of Oadohamu [q. v.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: duhomapN Blackness: (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and a deep ash-colour [without any tinge of white: see Oadohamu]. (ISd, TA.)

Also A brown ewe (naEojapN HamoraMCu): [see also dahomaMCu, voce Oadohamu:] and sing. of duhamN signifying a certain sort [or breed] of sheep or goats. (JK. [But I do not find either of these two significations in any other lexicon.])

entry.sense: Ald-ahomaAnu The night: opposed to AlwaD-aAHu meaning “the day.” (L in art. wDH.) [Hence,] vinoIu dahomaAna The prayer of nightfall: opposed to bikoru AlwaD-aAHi meaning “the prayer of morning.” (L and Ḳ in that art.: but in the CK and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, instead of dahomaAna we find duhomAna.)
duhaAmN: see Oadohamu:
and see duhaAmiy-apN.

hom.sense: Ald-uhayomi Calamity, or misfortune; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Oum-u Ald-uhayomi; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Ald-uhayomaMCu↓, (JK, Ṣ,) dim. of Ald-ahomaMCu [fem. of AlOadohamu], so called because of its darkness: (Ṣ, TA:) or Ald-ahayomaMCu signifies black, dark, trial or conflict and faction or sedition or the like; and the dim. form is used to denote enhancement: (Sh, TA:) and Ald-ahomaMCu↓ signifies black, dark, calamity or misfortunes: (TA:) calamity, or misfortune, is termed Ald-uhayomu because of its darkness: (TA:) or, originally, (Ṣ,) this was the name of the she-camel of ʼAmr Ibn-Ez-Zebbán Edh-Dhuhlee, who was slain, with his brothers, and their heads were put upon her, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in sacks hung upon her neck, and she returned to Ez-Zebbán: (TA:) whence the saying, Oavoqalu mino Himoli Ald-uhayomi [Heavier than the burden of Ed-Duheym]: (Ṣ:) and OaXoOamu mina Ald-uhayomi [More unlucky than Ed-Duheym]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, seven brothers were slain in a warring and plundering expedition, and were put upon Ed-Duheym; and hence the name became proverbial as applied to any calamity or misfortune. (TA.)
duhayomN also signifies Foolish, or stupid. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: UibilN duhaAmiy-apN Certain camels: so called in relation to Ald-uhaAmu↓, the name of a certain stallion-camel. (TA.)
Ald-uhayomaMCu: see Ald-uhayomu.

hom.sense: Oadohamu Black; (JK, Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also duhaAmN↓: (Ḳ:) the former is applied in this sense to a horse, (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb,* TA,) and to a camel, &c.: (TA:) or, applied to a camel, of a deep ashcolour without any tinge of white; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) when of a deeper hue, so as to be very black, he is termed jawonN: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, applied to a camel, like OaSofaru, [in this case meaning black with some intermixture of yellow,] but less black: (TA:) fem. dahomaMCu; which, when applied to a sheep (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) or goat, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) means of a pure or an unmixed brown colour (xaAliSapu AlHumorapi): (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. duhomN. (TA.) The Arabs say, muluwku Alxayoli duhomuhaA [The kings of horses are the black thereof]. (TA.) And farasN Oadohamu bahiymN A black horse in which is no intermixture of colours. (TA.) And laA Mtiyka maA Han-ati Ald-ahomaMCu [I will not come to thee as long as she (among the camels) that is of a deep ash-colour without any tinge of white reiterates her yearning cry after her young one; meaning, ever]. (Lḥ, TA.) And ramaAdN Oadohamu Black ashes. (TA.)

HadiyqapN dahomaMCu and mudohaAm-apN↓ ‡ [A walled garden] green inclining to black. (Ḳ.) Hence, (Ḳ,) mudohaAm-ataAni↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the Ḳur [lv. 64], (Ṣ, TA,) [Two gardens (jan-ataAni)] of which the greenness inclines to blackness; for every green plant, when its abundance and its moisture, or irrigation, are complete, inclines to blackness: (Zj, TA:) or black by reason of intense greenness arising from abundant moisture, or irrigation; and everything that is green (OaxoDar) the Arabs term Oasowadu. (Ṣ, TA.)

raboEN Oadohamu [A place of alighting or abode] recently occupied by the tribe; [because blackened by their fires, &c.:] pl. OarobuEN duhomN. (TA.) And OavarN Oadohamu A new, or recent, mark, trace, or vestige: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) and Oagoyaru means one that is “old, becoming effaced:” (Aṣ, TA:) and the former means also old, becoming effaced; (Ḳ;) as some explain it; (TA;) thus having two contr. significations. (Ḳ.) And waToOapN dahomaMCu A new, or recent, footstep, or footprint: and gaboraMCu means “becoming effaced:” or the former means one that is becoming effaced, because it has become obscure to him who seeks it; (JK;) or an old footstep, or footprint: and HamoraMCu means one that is “new, or recent.” (Ṣ.) [See also Oagobaru.]

Ald-ahomaMCu also signifies ‡ The cooking-pot: (JK, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or the black cooking-pot: (ISh, TA:) and the old cooking-pot. (Ḳ. [But it is implied in the TA that this last meaning is a mistake, occasioned by an omission; and that, instead of Alqidoru waAlqadiymapu, (in the CK Alqidoru Alqadiymapu,) we should read, Alqidoru waAlwaToOapu Ald-ahomaMCu Alqadiymapu, explained above. Accord. to Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL, Oabuw AlOadohami signifies The great cooking-pot in which a whole sheep is cooked at once.])

And The twenty-ninth night of the [lunar] month: (JK, Ḳ:) because of its blackness. (TA.)
And [the pl.] Ald-uhomu Three nights of the [lunar] month [during which is the change of the moon]: (Ḳ:) because they are black. (TA.)
See also Ald-uhayomu.

[Used as a subst.,] Oadohamu signifies also A shackle or fetter, or a pair of shackles or fetters; syn. qayodN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because of the blackness thereof: accord. to AA, of wood: (TA:) or a heavy shackle or fetter or a pair of shackles or fetters: syn. OadaAhimu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because of the blackform of pl., which is proper to substs., because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it. (TA.)

And [the fem.] dahomaMCu signifies † A multitude, or large number: (Ḳ:) and † a company of men; (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ;*) and multitude thereof: (Ks, TA:) or ‡ the generality, the common mass, or the main part [thereof]: (Z, TA:) or † the commonalty, or common people. (Mbr, Ḥar p. 671.) [See also dahomN.]
Also, dahomaMCu, The aspect, appearance, mien, guise, or garb, of a man. (JK, Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
And Ald-ahomaMCu A certain herb, or tree, green, and broad in the leaves; (JK;) or a certain broad herb, (Ḳ,) having leaves and twigs, resembling the qaronuwap; (TA;) with which one tans. (JK, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mudohaAm-apN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
mutadah-amN A catamite; i. q. maOobuwnN and mivofarN and mivofaArN (AA, TA in the present art. and in art. dvr,) and mutadaO-amN. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. dahanahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yadohunu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. dahonN (MA, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL) and dahonapN, (Ḳ,) He anointed it (MA, Mgh, Mṣb,* KL) with duhon, (Mgh, Mṣb,) i. e., (Mṣb,) with oil (MA, Mṣb, KL) &c.; (Mṣb;) [oiled it; or greased it;] namely, his head, (MA, Mgh,) or his mustache, (Mgh,) or his hair, &c.: (Mṣb:) or he moistened it; namely, his head, &c.: (Ḳ:) and dh-nhu↓, inf. n. tadohiynN signifies the same [but app. in an intensive sense, or as applying to many objects]: (TA:) and UidohaAnN [inf. n. of Oadohana↓] is like tadohiynN. (AHeyth, TA.)
[Hence,] dahana AlOaroDa, said of rain, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ It moistened the ground slightly, or a little: (Ṣ, TA:) or it moistened the surface of the ground. (Ḳ.)

And [hence also,] dahanotuhu biAlEaSaA (Ṣ, Ḳ *) ‡ I struck him (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) gently (TA) with the staff, or stick; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) like as one says, masaHahu biAlEaSaA and biAls-ayofi. (TA.) And dahanotuhu biAlEaSaA dahanaAtK ‡ I struck him [gently] with the staff or stick [some gentle strokes: dahanaAtN being pl. of dahonapN↓, which is the inf. n. of un.]. (So in a copy of the Ṣ.)

[Hence, likewise,] dahana signifies also He (a man, TA) played the hypocrite. (Ḳ, TA.) And you say, dahana fulaAnFA, aor. _u {yadohunu}, inf. n. dahonN, meaning He acted with such a one hypocritically. (TḲ. [See also 3.])

dahunato, (Ḳ, and so in more than three copies of the Ṣ,) and dahanato, aor. _u {yadohunu}; (Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ in lieu of dahunato;) and dahinato, aor. _a {yadohanu}; (AZ, Ḳ;) inf. n. [of the first] dahaAnapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and [of the second or third or of both] dihaAnN; (Ḳ;) ‡ She (a camel) had little milk. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [See dahiynN.]

And dahina, inf. n. dahonN, [or, as appears to be probable from what follows and from general analogy, dahanN,] said of a man, † He was, or became, weak: and also, foolish, or stupid: and [app. soft, flaccid, or flabby; for] dahanN signifies the being soft, flaccid, or flabby; or softness, flaccidity, or flabbiness. (JK.) [See dahiynN.]

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

3. mudaAhanahN and UidohaAnN↓ signify the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e. ‡ The endeavouring to conciliate; syn. muSaAnaEapN: (Ṣ, TA:) or the making peace with another; or becoming reconciled with another: (Mṣb:) or the pretending the contrary of, or what is different from, that which one conceals in his mind: (Ḳ:) and the former signifies also the acting with dishonesty, or dissimulation: or ↓the latter has this signification; and the former signifies the striving to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent; syn. muwaArabapN: (TA:) or daAhanotu signifies I hid, concealed, or covered; syn. waArayotu [accord. to four copies of the Ṣ; but probably this is a mistranscription for waArabotu, meaning I strove to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent, as is indicated in the TA]; and Oadohanotu↓ signifies I acted with dishonesty, or dissimulation: (Ṣ:) or UidohaAnN↓ is [originally] like tadohiynN [as has been stated above]: but is used as denoting the act of treating with gentleness or blandishment, soothing, coaxing, wheedling, beguiling, or deluding; and abstaining from restraint or prohibition: (AHeyth, TA:) or it originally signified the anointing such a thing as a hide with some oil or the like: and as such a thing is rendered soft to the sense [of feeling], it was used tropically, or metaphorically, to denote ideal softness, absolutely: hence, the treating with gentleness or blandishment, soothing, coaxing, wheedling, beguiling, or deluding, was termed mudaAhanapN: then this tropical signification became commonly known, and conventionally regarded as proper: and then the word [mdAhnp or AdhAn↓, or rather each of these words,] was tropically used as signifying the holding a thing in light, or little, or mean, estimation, or in contempt: so in the 'Ináyeh. (MF, TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [lxviii. 9], wad-uwAlawo tudohinu fayudohinuwna↓ ‡ They wish that thou wouldst endeavour to conciliate [them], and in that case they will endeavour to conciliate [thee]: (Ṣ, TA:*) or that thou wouldst be soft, pliant, or gentle, in thy religion, and in that case they will be soft, pliant, or gentle: (TA:) or that thou wouldst be soft, pliant, or gentle, to them, and in that case they will be so to thee: (Jel:) or, accord. to Fr, that thou wouldst be an unbeliever, and they will be unbelievers. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Adhn, inf. n. UidohaAnN: see 1, first sentence: and see 1, in six places. [See also its act. part. n., below.]

AlUidohaAnu is also syn. with AlUiboqaMCu, which, accord. to IAmb, is the primary signification: in the copies of the Ḳ erroneously written AlUinoqaMCu. (TA.) One says, laA tudohino Ealayohi, meaning laA tuboqi Ealayohi [Show not thou mercy to him; or pity not him; or pardon not him]. (IAmb, TA.) And maA Oadohanota Uil-aA EalaI nafosika, i. e. maA Oaboqayota [Thou didst not show, or hast not shown, mercy, save to thyself]. (Lḥ, TA.)
One says also, Oadohanotu fiI Oamorihi, meaning I fell short in his affair, or case. (JK.)
And Oudohina He (a camel) was affected with the vertigo termed duhon. (JK.)

entry.sense: 5: see what next follows {8}.
8. Aid-ahana, of the measure AifotaEala, He anointed himself with duhon, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) i. e. oil, &c.; (Mṣb;) [oiled, or greased, himself;] as also tdh-n↓. (Ṣ.)
Q. Q. 2. tayadohana He (a man) took a mudohun [q. v.]. (Ṣ.)
dahonN: see duhonN.
EayoXN dahonN Bad and scanty [means of subsistence]. (JK.)

hom.sense: duhonN Oil, (MA, Mṣb, KL,) &c., (Mṣb,) [i. e. grease of any kind,] or duhon [i. e. oil] of sesame, &c., (Mgh,) with which one anoints, (Mgh, Mṣb,) [or greases,] or moistens, (Ḳ,) the head or mustache, (Mgh,) or the hair, &c., (Mṣb,) or the head, &c.: (Ḳ:) it is well known: (Ṣ:) and duhonapN↓ signifies a portion thereof: (Ḳ:) [or this latter, being the n. un., signifies a particular oil or kind of oil; like as the former does when it is prefixed to another noun:] you say duhonu AlbaAni (Ṣ and Mgh and Mṣb in art. bwn) and duhonapu baAnK (TA in the present art. from a poet) [both meaning oil of ben]: the pl. (of duhonN, Ṣ, Mṣb, and Bḍ in lv. 37) is dihaAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Bḍ ubi suprà) and OadohaAnN; (Ḳ;) [the latter a pl. of pauc.; both pls. signifying kinds of oil, &c.;] or Ald-ihaAnu↓ signifies that with which one anoints; (Bḍ ubi suprà) or it has this signification also: (TA:) you say, dahanotuhu biAld-ihaAni [meaning I anointed him with oils or with ointment]: (Ṣ, in which this is mentioned as an ex. of the pl. of duhonN:) and hence the prov. kaAld-ihaAni EalaI Alwabari Like [ointment or] that with which one anoints [upon fur, or soft hair]. (TA.) [See also dihaAnN below.]
Also ‡ Weak rain: (AZ, Ṣ:) or rain such as moistens the surface of the ground; (JK, Ḳ;) and so dahonN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. dihaAnN. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And A vertigo (duwaAr) that affects the camel. (JK.)

entry.sense: dihonN A kind of tree with which beasts of prey are killed, (JK, Ḳ,) and by means of which they are taken: (JK:) it is a noxious tree, like the difolaI [q. v.]: (TA:) n. un. with p {dihonapN}. (Ḳ.)
And Such as is large, of trees. (JK.)
dahinN Oily, or greasy. (KL.) You say also rajulN mudohaAn-N↓ meaning dahinu AlX-aEari [A man having oily, or greasy, hair]. (TA.) [See also dahiynN.]
duhonapN: see duhonN.
Also Odour: so in the saying huwa Tay-ibu Ald-uhonapi [He, or it, is sweet in respect of odour]. (Ḳ. [Erroneously written and explained by Golius in his Lexicon.])

hom.sense:
dahonaMCu A [desert such as is termed] falaAp: (Ḳ:)
or a place of sands: (JK:) or a place all sand: (TA:) [or a desert of reddish sand. Hence,] with the article Al, A certain place [or desert tract] belonging to Temeem, in Nejd, (Ṣ Ḳ, TA,) extending to the distance of three days' journey, in which is no water; (TA;) as also Ald-ahonaI; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) this latter occurring in poetry. (TA.) [The same appellation is also applied to The great desert of which the central part lies towards the Ṣ. E. of Nejd.]
Also A certain red herb, (Ḳ,) having broad leaves, used for tanning. (TA.)

entry.sense: [duhoniy-apN An oily quality.]

dihaAnN A red hide. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See also dahiynN.]) Hence, in the Ḳur [lv. 37], fakaAnato warodapF kaAld-ihaAni, i. e. And shall become red, (Ṣ,) or of a rosecolour, (Zj, L in art. wrd,) or of a red colour inclining to yellow, (L in that art.,) like the red hide: (Ṣ, Bḍ, Jel:) or like the hide that is of a pure red colour: (TA:) or like that [oil] with which one anoints; see duhonN: or it is pl. of duhonN: (Bḍ:) [thus] it means, accord. to Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ [Zj], and shall become [red,, &c., and] of various colours, by reason of the very great terror, like divers oils: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, like the dregs of oil, or of olive-oil; for this is another signification of AldhAn. (TA.)
Also A slippery place. (JK, Ḳ.) And A smooth road: or long and smooth. (TA.)

hom.sense: dahiynN [Anointed with oil, &c.; i. q. madohuwnN↓ and madohuwnapN]. You say liHoyapN dahiynN (Ḳ) and dahiynapN (TA) and daAhinN↓, (Ḳ,) [the last, properly, a possessive epithet,] meaning madohuwnapN [i. e. A beard anointed with oil, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And A hide intensely red. (JK. [See also dihaAnN.])

Also, applied to a she-camel, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ Having little milk: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or having very little milk; (JK;) not yielding a drop of milk (JK, TA) when her dug is squeezed: (JK:) accord. to Er-Rághib, having the meaning of an act. part. n., i. e. that yields as much as that with which one may anoint himself: or, as some say, having the meaning of a pass. part. n., because she is anointed [or as though she were anointed] with the milk, by reason of its scantiness; and this is the more probable, because it has not the affix p: pl. duhunN. (TA.)
And, applied to a stallion, † That does not impregnate at all: as though because of the paucity of his seminal fluid. (TA.)

And Weak; applied to a man, and to a thing: one says, Oatayota biOamorK dahiynK [Thou didst, or saidst, or thou hast done, or said, a weak thing]: and Ibn-Hiráweh says,
liyanotaziEuwA turaAva baniI tamiymK
laqadN Zan-uwA binaA Zan-FA dahiynaA
[In order that they might wrest the inheritance of the sons of Temeem, verily they have opined of us a weak opining]. (TA.)

entry.sense: dah-aAnN A seller of oil: (MA, TA:) and a maker of oil. (MA.) [In the present day, it is applied to A painter of houses, &c.]
daAhinN: see dahiynN.
mudohanN A camel affected with the vertigo termed duhon. (JK.)

mudohunN, with damm, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) only, (Ṣ,) to the m and h, (Mṣb, TA,) extr [in form], (Fr, TA,) for by rule it should be midohanN, (Mṣb,) or it was midohanN originally, (Lth, TA,) The utensil (Mlap) for duhon [or oil, &c.]; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. (TA) the thing [or pot or vase] in which duhon is put; (T, Mṣb, TA;) a flask, or phial, (qaAruwrap,) for duhon: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and mudohunapN↓, occurring in this art. and in art. wqb in the TA, signifies the same:] pl. madaAhinu. (Ṣ.)

And ‡ A place, (M, Ḳ, TA,) or a small hollow or cavity, in a mountain, (Ṣ, TA,) in which water remains and collects, or collects and stagnates: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA:) or any place excavated by a torrent: (Ḳ:) or water exuding in stone. (TA.)
mudohinN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.].

OafabihecaA AlHadiyvi Oanotumo mudohinuwna, in the Ḳur [lvi. 80], means Do ye then reject this announcement? or disbelieve, &c.? (TA:) or hold in light, or little, or mean, estimation, (Bḍ, Jel,) and reject,, &c.? (Jel.)
madohanapN A place where oil is made; an oil-mill. (MA.)
mudohunapN: see mudohunN.
qawomN mudah-anuwna ‡ A people, or company of men, upon whom are [visible] the traces of ease and plenty, welfare, or well-being. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
madohuwnN: see dahiynN.
[Hence,] OaroDN madohuwanapN ‡ Land moistened slightly, or a little, by rain. (Ṣ, TA:) or having its surface moistened by rain. (TA.)
mudohaAn-N: see dahinN.

hom.sense: 1. dahiIa, aor. yadohaI, (JK, Ḳ,) inf. n. dahoIN and dahaMCN and dahaMCapN; (Ḳ;) and dahaI, aor. as above, inf. n. dahoIN; (JK;) and dahaA, (JK, TA,) aor. ydohuw, (JK,) or yadohaA [or yadohaI], (TA,) inf. n. dahaMCN (JK, TA) and dahaMCapN; (JK;) and dahuwa, aor. yadohuw, (JK,) [inf. n. app. dahaMCapN;] He possessed cunning; i.e. intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast; and excellence of judgment; (Ḳ, TA;) he was, or became, such as is termed daAhK and dahiI-N and dahK. (JK.) [See dahaMCN, below.]

dahawotuhu, (JK, TA,) inf. n. dahowN; (TA;) and dahayotuhu, (JK,) third pers. dahaAhu, inf. n. dahoIN; (TA;) I treated him with cunning,, &c. (JK,* and TA in explanation of the former.) [Both signify also I outwitted, deceived, deluded, beguiled, or circumvented, him.] And duhiytu means I was turned, or kept, from a thing, or an affair, by deceit, or guile. (JK, TA.)

Also dahaAhu, inf. n. dahoIN, He attributed, or imputed, to him cunning,, &c.; expl. by nasabahu UilaI Ald-ahaMCi [an inverted phrase]: or he attributed, or imputed, to him a vice, or fault, or the like; blamed him, censured him, found fault with him, or detracted from his reputation: or he smote him with a daAhiyap, i. e. great, formidable, grievous, or distressing, thing or event or accident or action: and dh-Ahu↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) thus in the Ḳ, with teshdeed: but in the M and Tekmileh it is said that dahayotuhu and dahawotuhu signify I attributed, or imputed, to him cunning (Ald-ahaMC); without mention of tadohiyapN [inf. n. of dah-aI]. (TA.)
You say also dahaAhu AlOamoru, aor. yadohaI, The thing, or event, befell him: (Mṣb:) and dahatohu daAhiyapN [a calamity befell him]. (Ṣ.) And maA dahaAka What befell, or hath befallen, thee? (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2: see above {1}.

3. dAhAhu (inf. n. mudaAhaApN, M in art. Arb, and Ḳ in art. wrb, &c.,) He strove, or endeavoured, to outwit, deceive, delude, beguile, or circumvent, him; syn. Mrabahu, (Ṣ in art. Arb,) and waArabahu, (Ḳ in art. wrb,) and naAkarahu. (TA in art. nkr.)
And dAhI bidaAhiyapK, inf. n. as above, He smote people with a calamity. (TA.)
4. AdhAhu He found him to be such as is termed daAhK [i. e. cunning,, &c.], (IDrd, TA,) or daAhiyap [which signifies the same in an intensive sense]. (JK.)

[AdhI preceded by maA is also used as a verb of wonder.] A poet says,
OabaA xaAlidK maA kaAna OadohaI muSiybapF
OaSaAbato maEad-FA yawoma OaSobaHota vaAwiyaA
Aboo-Khálid, how great was the calamity that befell Ma' add on the day when thou diedst [or wast slain]! (Ḥam p. 440.)
5. tdh-I [He acted cunningly;] he did as do the duhaAp [or cunning,, &c., pl. of daAhK]. (ISd, Ḳ.)
6. tdAhI [He affected, or pretended, to possess dahaMC; i. e., to be cunning,, &c.]. (IAạr, Ḳ in art. xzr: see 1 and 2 in that art.)

hom.sense: dahK: see daAhK, in two places.
Uil-aA dahK falaA dahK: see art. dh.

entry.sense: dahowN: see dahaMCN.

hom.sense: dahoIN: see dahaMCN.
Also A large [bucket such as is called] garob. (AA, TA.)

entry.sense: dahowaMCu: see the next paragraph.
dahoyaMCu: see daAhiyapN.

It is also used as a corroborative: (ISk, Ṣ:) you say daAhiyapN dahoyaMCu (ISk, JK, Ṣ, Mṣb) and dahowaMCu↓ (ISk, JK, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and duhowiy-apN↓, (JK, Ḳ,) meaning A severe, grievous, or distressing, calamity or misfortune: (JK:) or a very severe or grievous or distressing [calamity]. (Ḳ.)
duhowiy-apN: see what next precedes.

dahaMCN (in which the C is converted from I not from w Ṣ) and dahoIN↓(JK, Ṣ, Ḳ) and dahowN↓ (JK, TA) [are all inf. ns., and] are syn., (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) signifying Cunning; i. e. intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast; (TA in art. AHd;) i. q. UirobN, (Ḳ,) and nukorN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and excellence of judgment. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [It is said in the Ṣ, app. with reference to dahaMCN, that the dual is dahoyaAwaAni: but this is the regular dual of dahoyaMCu; like HamoraAwani, dual of HamoraMCu]
dahiI-N: see what next follows, in three places.

daAhK and dahK↓ (JK, Ḳ) and dahiI-N↓, part. ns. of dahaI and dahiIa and dahuwa [respectively]: (JK,) and daAhiyapN↓, applied to a man, Cunning; i. e. possessing intelligence, or sagacity; or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast: and excellent in judgment: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. q. munokarN [as syn. with nakirN]: (TA, and JK in explanation of daAhiyapN:) knowing, or skilful, in affairs: (TA:) or dahiI-N↓ signifies [simply] intelligent: (AA, Ḳ:) and daAhiyapN↓ is [an intensive epithet, signifying very cunning; i. e. possessing much intelligence,, &c.;] from dahaMCN explained above: or [it means one who is as though he were calamity, or misfortune, personified;] from Ald-aAhiyapu in the sense commonly known [which see below]: (TA in art. AHid:) the pl. (of daAhK, JK, TA) is duhaApN, and (of dahK↓, JK, TA) dahuwna, (JK, Ḳ, TA,) and of dahiI-N↓, OadohiyaMCu (JK, M, TA) and duhawaMCu, in the Ḳ, erroneously, OadohiyapN and dahowaMCu. (TA.)
[Hence,] Ald-aAhiI The lion. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: daAhiyapN A calamity, a misfortune, an evil accident; (JK, Mṣb;) a great, formidable, grievous, or distressing, thing or event or accident or action; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and dahoyaMCu↓ signifies the same: (JK, TA:*) [the dim. of the former, duwayohiyapN↓, generally means a great calamity, &c.; being an instance of what is termed taSogiyru taEoZiymK:] the pl. of daAhiyapN is dawaAhK: (Mṣb, TA:) and dawaAhiI Ald-ahori means the great, formidable, grievous, or distressing, events of fortune that befall men. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also daAhK, in two places.

entry.sense: duwayohiyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OadohaI [More, and most, cunning,, &c. Hence,] OadohaI mino qayosi boni zuhayorK [More intelligent, or sagacious, than Keys the son of Zuheyr]: a prov. (Meyd.)
madohuw-N and madohiI-N pass. part. ns.; (JK, TA;) Treated with cunning,, &c. (TA in explanation of the former.)

hom.sense: 2. dw-I He took his way in the daw- [q. v.]. (M, Ḳ.) And dw-I fiI AlOaroDi He went away into the country, or in the land. (T.) Ru-beh uses the phrase dw-I bihaA as signifying He passed by them; meaning, by them, a male [wild] ass and his she-asses. (T.) And it is said of the daw-iy-ap that it is thus called liOan-ahaA tudaw-iI SaAra fiyhaA, i. e. Because it makes away with those who are in it. (T.)
See also art. dwI.

entry.sense: daw-N and daw-iy-apN↓ (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, the latter [erroneously] written in the CK dawiy-ap) A desert, or waterless desert; syn.mafaAzapN, (Ṣ, M,) or falaApN; (Ḳ;) as also daw-iI-N↓ (Ṣ) and daAwiy-ipN↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in which the first w which is quiescent, [in daw-iy-ipN, for dawowiy-apN,] is changed into A because of the fet-ḥah before it, though this instance is not to be copied as a model, (Ṣ,) and daAwiyapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or daw-N signifies a wide falaAp: (M:) or a level land; likened by Dhu-r-Rummeh to the hand of the purchaser, meaning when he strikes his hand upon that of another in token of the ratification of a bargain: and daw-iy-apN↓, a land of which the extremities are far apart, level, and spacious; said to be so called because of the sound termed dawiI- that is heard in it; [and if so, these two words (the latter of which is also mentioned in art. dwI) belong to one and the same art.;] or because it makes away with those who are in it; [see 2, above;] and daAwiy-apN↓ and daAwiyapN↓ signify the same: (T:) it is also said that daw-N is [in origin] a Pers. word; as though he who traversed the daw- said to his companion dawodawo, meaning “Hasten:” (TA:) or, as some say, a certain region, four nights' journey in extent, like a shield, vacant, traversed by means of the stars, in which one feared losing his way, on the way from El-Basrah to Mekkeh, was named Ald-aw-u for this reason, from the Persians' hastening one another while crossing it by saying dawodawo. (T.)
[Hence,] banaAtu Ald-aw-i † The wild asses. (T in art. bnI.)

daw-iI-N [a rel. n. from daw-N;] One inhabiting a daw-. (Ṣ.) [Hence the saying,] maA bihaA daw-iI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, dawiI-N,]) and duw-iI-N↓ (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, duwiI-N,]) and duwowiI-N↓, as in the M, or dawawiI-N↓, as in the Ḳ, (TA,) i. e. [There is not in it (meaning biAld-aAri in the house)] any one (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of those who inhabit the daw-: like as one says maA bihaA TuwriI-N, and duwriI-N. (Ṣ.)
See daw-N, with which it is also syn. (Ṣ.)
duw-iI-N and duwowiI-N or dawawiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
daw-iy-apN: see daw-N, in two places.
daAwiyapN and daAwiy-apN: see daw-N, in four places.
dawodaApN: see art. dwd.

1. daMCa, (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, [mentioned in the T in art. dwI,]) second pers. diYota, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yadaMCu, inf. n. daMCN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and dawoCN; (Lth, T, Ḳ;) and OadaMCa↓ (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and OadowaOa, (M, Ḳ,) this last from IAạr, (M,) or from AZ, (TA,) He, (a man, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and it, (a limb, or member, Mṣb,) was, or became, diseased, disordered, or distempered; he was, or became, sick, or ill; (AZ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he was, or became, attacked by a disease, or disorder,, &c., in his inside: (T, TA:) and dawiIa, aor. yadowaI, inf. n. dawFI, signifies the same: (Mṣb:) and OadaMCa↓ jawofuhu [his belly, or chest, was, or became, diseased,, &c.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. OadaMCa and OadowaOa: see above, in two places.

You say also to a man when you suspect him, OadaOota, inf. n. UidaMCapN; and OadowaOota, inf. n. UidowaMCN; [i. e. † Thou hast done a thing that has made thee an object of suspicion; or thou hast become an object of suspicion.] (T,* Ṣ, M,* Ḳ.)
OadaMCahu He [or it] affected him with a disease, or disorder,, &c.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [or caused him to be diseased,, &c.:] thus the verb is trans. as well as intrans. (Ṣ.)
And AdwOhu † He suspected him; thought evil of him; as also OadowaAhu [without C]. (AZ, TA in art. dwI.)

daMCN A disease, disorder, distemper, sickness, illness, or malady; syn. maraDN, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or Eil-apN; (Mgh;) external or internal: (Lth, T:) [it is both physical and moral:] signifying also a vice, defect, fault, or blemish; external or internal: so that one says, daMCuAlX-uH-a OaXad-u AlOadowaMCi [The vice of avarice is the most grievous of vices]: (Lth, T, TA:) for the pl. is OadowaMCN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the only instance of a sing. memdood having a pl. memdood: (IKh, TA:) hence also, OaI-N daMCK OadowaOu mina Albuxoli↓ (Mgh,) or OadowaI, but IAth says that the correct word is OadowaOu, (TA,) i. e. [What vice is] more grievous, (Mgh,) or worse, (TA,) [than niggardliness?] occurring in a trad.: and the saying of a woman, kul-u daMCK lahu daMCN, meaning Every vice that is in men is in him: (Lth, T, TA:) and may-itu Ald-aMCi One whose evilness is dead, (Ḳ and TA in art. blh,) so that he is not cognizant of it; (TA in that art.;) said of a person when he does not bear malice towards him who does evil to him. (Lth, T, and TA in the present art.) daMCu Alfiyli: see art. fyl. daMCu Alv-aEolabi: see art. vElb. daMCu Alc-iYobi [The disease of the wolf] means † hunger. (Th, M, Ḳ. [See also art. cOb.]) daMCN AlOasadi [The disease of the lion] means AlHmI [app. AlHum-aI, i. e. † fever]. (AM, TA.) daMCu AlZ-aboIi, (Ṣ, TA,) or daMCu ZaboIK, (M, TA,) [The disease of the gazelle, or of a gazelle,] accord. to AA, (M, TA,) means † health, or soundness, and briskness, or sprightliness; (TA;) or no disease; like as [it is said that] there is no disease in the gazelle: (Ṣ, M:) or, accord. to El-Umawee, binaA daMCu ZaboIK means that when he desires to leap, he pauses a little and then leaps: but AʼObeyd prefers the former explanation. (M.) daMCu Almuluwki [The disease of kings] means † the enjoyment of plenty and pleasure and softness or delicacy. (TA.) daMCu AlkiraAmi [The disease of the generous], † debt and poverty. (TA.) daMCu AlD-araAYiri [The disease of fellow-wives], † constant evil. (TA.) daMCu AlbaToni. [The disease of the belly], † trial, or dissension, or the like, (Alfitonapu,) in which one cannot find the right way to act. (TA.)

daMCN as an epithet, (Lth, Sh, T, M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or daMCK↓ (Ṣ, and so in other copies of the Ḳ,) applied to a man, Diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill; or having a disease, disorder,, &c.: (Lth, Sh, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:)
the former is [originally an inf. n., and therefore is] also applied to a woman; (A, TA;) or it is [originally dawiYN,] of the measure faEilN, and the fem. is daMCapN, (Lth, T, M, TA,) which is also mentioned in the A as applied to a woman, as well as daMCN; (TA;) and the dual is daAMni; and the pl. OadowaMCN: (Lth, Sb, Sh, T, TA:) and mdiIoCN↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) fem. with h: and so dyiY↓; [as though originally dawiIoCN or dayowiYN, of the measure faEiylN or fayoEilN, like jay-idN and say-idN;] fem. with p {daMCapN}: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to the O, daYiI-N, of the measure faEiylN, applied to a man; and daYiy-apN, of the measure faEiylapN, applied to a woman: or, accord. to the T, dayoOFI, of the measure fayoEalN, applied to a man; and dayoOayapN, of the measure fayoEalapN, applied to a woman. (TA.) The saying, in a trad., waUil-aA fayamiynuhu Oan-ahu maA baAEaka daMCK means [And otherwise, his oath shall be, that he did not sell to thee] a girl having a disease, or vice, or the like: and similar to this is the saying, rud-a Ald-aMCu bidaAYihi That which had a vice, or the like, was returned because of the vice,, &c., thereof. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: daMCK: see the next preceding paragraph.
day-iYN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OadowaOu: see the next preceding paragraph.
mudiIoCN: see the next preceding paragraph.
1. daAja, (IAạr, Ḳ,) aor. yaduwju, (IAạr,) inf. n. dawojN, He (a man, IAạr) served, or did service. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: daAjapN [as pl. of daAYijN, agreeably with analogy,] The followers of an army. (Ḳ.)

Also A small want: (Ḳ:) or a want [absolutely]; i. q. HaAjapN, as some say: (TA:) or it is an imitative sequent to HaAjapN. (Ḳ, and Ṣ in art. dj. [See daAj-N in that art.]) It is said in a trad., maA tarakotu mino HaAjapK walaA daAjapK [I left not a want nor a small want: or a want of any kind: or] this means I left not any act of disobedience to which I was enticed. (TA voce HaAjapN.)

entry.sense: 1. daAHati AlX-ajarapu, (Ḳ,) aor. taduwHu; (TA;) and AdAHt↓; (A, TA;) The tree became great. (A, Ḳ.)

dAH baTonuhu, (Ḳ,) and AndAH↓, (A, Ḳ,) and dw-H↓, (TA,) or tdw-H↓, (so in a copy of the A,) His belly became swollen, or inflated, (A,) or big, (Ḳ,) and hung down, (A, Ḳ,) by reason of fatness or disease: (A, TA:) and so daHaA and AndHI. (TA.) And dAHt suraruhumo [Their navels became swollen, and hung down]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. dw-H, inf. n. tadowiyHN, He dispersed, or scattered his property; (L, Ḳ;) as also db-H. (L.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
5: see 1.
7: see 1.

daAHN Variegated, decorated, or embellished, work, [or gewgaws,] which one waves about to children, and with which one sooths, pacifies, or quiets, them: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p, meaning a piece of such work, or a gewgaw:] whence, (Ḳ,) one says, Ald-unoyaA daAHapN↓ [The world is a gewgaw, or gaudy toy]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And hence,] daAHapu↓ [as a proper name] means † The world, or present state of existence: so said Aboo-Hamzeh the Soofee, in explanation of the saying,
lawo laA Hub-atiI daAHahu↓
lakaAna Almawotu liI raAHaho
[Were it not for my loving the world, death would be to me ease]: and AA confirmed this. (T, TA.)

And A kind of variegated, or figured, cloth or garment. (A, Ḳ.) [In this sense also it is a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p {daAHapN}.] You say, fulaAnN yalobasu Ald-aAHa Such a one wears variegated, or figured, garments. (A, TA.) And jaMCa waEalayohi daAHapN↓ [He came having upon him a variegated, or figured, garment]. (A, TA.)
A bracelet consisting of several distinct portions like the strands of a rope, twisted together. (Ḳ.)
Lines, or streaks, upon a bull, &c. (Ḳ.)
The species of perfume called xaluwq. (Ḳ.)
dawoHN: see dawoHapN.
Also A very large tent of [goats'] hair. (IAạr, TA. [See also dawoHapN.])
daAHapN: see daAHN, in four places.

dawoHapN A great tree, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with spreading branches, (TA,) of whatever kind it be: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. dawoHN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [or rather this is the coll. gen. n. of the n. un. dawoHapN,] like as tamorN is of tamorapN; (Mṣb;) and OadowaAHN is pl. of dawoHN: (TA:) and XajarapN daAYiHapN↓ signifies the same; (A,* Ḳ;) and the pl. is dawaAYiHu; (A, Ḳ;) or dawaAYiHu signifies great trees, one of which is called dawoHapN, and its sing., though it be not used, seems to be daAYiHapN. (AḤn, TA.) One says, fulaAnN mino dawoHapi Alkarami ‡ [Such a one is of a great generous stock]. (A, TA.)
Also A great [tent of the kind called] miZal-ap. (TA. [See also dawoHN.])
daw-aAHo Very tall: so in a trad. in which it is said, kamo mino EacoqK daw-aAHK fiI Alj-anapi [How many a very tall palm-tree is there in Paradise!]. (TA.)
XajarapN daAYiHapN: see dawoHapN.
baTonN munodaAHN A prominent, round belly: or a wide belly, low by reason of fatness. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. daAxa, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) aor. yaduwxu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. dawoxN, (L,) He (a man, Ṣ, A) was, or became, submissive, or abject, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and lowly, or humble. (A, L.)
[Also † It (a man's head) was, or became, giddy, or vertiginous: used in this sense in the present day, and probably in ancient times: see 2.]
As a trans. verb: see 2.

entry.sense: 2. dw-x, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadowiyxN, (TA,) He subdued a country, and obtained dominion over its inhabitants; as also dAx↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (TA;) and dy-x, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoyiyxN: (TA:) and he subdued, or subjugated, a people. (L.) And, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) as also dy-x, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) and AdAx↓, (L,) He rendered (a man, Ṣ, L, or people, A) submissive, or abject, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and lowly, or humble: (A:) and in like manner a camel. (L.)
‡ He trod a land much: (A:) or he traversed a country until he knew it and became acquainted with its roads. (L.)
‡ It (heat) weakened a man. (A, TA.)
† It (pain) made a man's head giddy, or vertiginous. (L.)
4: see 2.
layolN daAYixN A dark night. (Ḳ.)

1. daAda, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like xaAfa, (Mṣb,) [sec. pers. didota,] aor. yadaAdu; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and daAda, like qaAla, [sec. pers. dudota,] aor. yaduwdu; (Mṣb;) inf. n. dawodN; (M, L, Ḳ; [in my copy of the Mṣb daAdN, which, I doubt not, is a mistranscription;]) and AdAd↓, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UidaAdapN; (Mṣb;) and dw-d↓, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadowiydN; (Mṣb;) and diyda; (M, L, and so in some copies of the Ḳ; [see its part. n. maduwdN, voce daAYidN, below;] in other copies of the Ḳ day-ada [which is app. a mistranscription];) It (corn, or food, TaEaAm,) had in it duwd (M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) or suws (Ṣ, L) [i. e. worms, grubs, or maggots]; and became eaten thereby. (L.) OaEozimu Ealayoka Oay-uhaA AljuroHu Oano laA taziyda walaA tudiyda↓ [I conjure thee, O wound, that thou increase not nor breed worms,] is a form of conjuration used by the Arabs. (A.)

hom.sense: 2. dw-d: see above {1}.
Also He played with the dawodaAp, i. e. OurojuwaHp [or seesaw]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AdAd: see 1, in two places.

duwdN a word of well-known signification, [Worms, grubs, maggots, and the like; including molluscs; as a coll. gen. n.: and, as a simple gen. n., the worm, grub, maggot,, &c.:] pl. of duwdapN [or rather, as already said, and as is implied in several of the lexicons, duwdN is a coll. gen. n.; therefore duwdapN is the n. un. thereof]: and the pl. of duwdN is diydaAnN. (T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb. [In the Ḳ, diydaAnN is said to be pl. of duwdapN: and in the L, as from the T, duwdaAnN is said to be another pl. of duwdN: this, however, I regard as a mistake; for I do not find it in the T; but I there find added, after diydaAnN, “and duwdaAnN is a tribe of Benoo-Asad.”]) J says that the dim. is duwayodN↓, and that by rule it should be duwayodapN: but this is a mistake [unless it be meant that duwayodapN is the regular dim. of duwdapN]: it is regularly duwayodN, like as tumayorN and quyayoHN are regular dims. of tamorN and qamoHN, which are pls. [or rather coll. gen. ns.] of tamorapN and qamoHapN. (IB.)
duwdapN [n. un. of duwdN, q. v.]
[Also] The fœtus in the belly of a mare from the fortieth day, when its make becomes apparent, until the end of the third month. (Kr, TA voce duEomuwSN, q. v.)

dawodaApN A seesaw; syn. OurojuwHapN: (Ḳ in this art., and T and Ṣ in art. dw:) and the mark made by children upon the dust, or earth, like a path, or track, when they play [upon the seesaw], doing thus with their feet, moving forwards and backwards: (Ṣ in art. dw:) or the mark of the ArjwHp: (M and Ḳ in that art.:) or the sound of the ArjwHp: (TA in the present art.:) and cries, shouts, noises, or clamour; or a confusion, or mixture, of cries, shouts,, &c.: (Ḳ in this art.:) dawodaApN is [said by ISd to belong to art. dw, and to be] originally dawodawapN: (M in art. dw:) the pl. is dawaAdK, (T and Ṣ * and M in that art.,) explained by Aṣ as signifying the marks of the OaraAjiyH [or seesaws] of children; (TA in the present art.;) and dawaAdiIa occurs in a verse, in the gen. case, (Ṣ and M in art. dw,) by poetic license. (M in that art.)
HayawaAnN duwdiI-N [app. A worm-like animal]. (TA in art. crH.)
duwayodN: see duwdN.

daAYidN and mudiydN↓ and mudaw-idN↓ (Mṣb) and maduwdN↓ (L) [the last from diyda, confirming my opinion that day-ada in some copies of the Ḳ is a mistranscription,] Corn, or food, (TaEaAmN,) having in it duwd [or worms,, &c.]; (L, Mṣb;) and becoming eaten thereby. (L.)
maduwdN: see what next precedes.
mudiydN: see what next precedes.
mudaw-idN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. daAra, aor. yaduwru, inf. n. daworN and dawaraAnN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and duWuwrN (M) and madaArN; (Lth, T;) and AstdAr↓; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AdAr↓; (M;) He, or it, went, moved, or turned, round; circled; revolved; returned to the place from which he, or it, began to move. (TA.)

You say, daAruwA Hawolahu and AstdArwA↓ They went round it: (A:) and dAr Hawola Albayoti and AstdAr↓ He went round the house [or Kaabeh]. (Mṣb.) Z and others dislike the phrase dArbiAlbayoti, [which seems to have been used in the same sense as dAr Hawolahu,] preferring the phrase TaAfa biAlbayoti, because of the phrase dAr baAld-uwaAri, signifying He went round about in the circuit called Ald-uwaAr, round the idol called by the same name. (TA.) [AstdAr↓ bihi mostly signifies It encircled, or surrounded, or encompassed, it.]

[You say also, dAr bayonahumo It (a thing, as, for instance, a wine-cup) went round, or circulated, among them. And] dAr Alfalaku fiI madaArihi [The firmament, or celestial orb or sphere, revolved upon its axis]: (A:) dawaraAnu Alfalaki signifies the consecutive incessant motions of the several parts of the firmament. (Mṣb.)

Hence the saying daArati AlmasoOalapu, [inf. n. daworN,] The question formed a circle; one of its propositions depending for proof upon another following it, and perhaps this upon another, and so on, and the latter or last depending upon the admission of the first. (Mṣb.) [And in like manner, dAr, inf. n. daworN, signifies He reasoned in a circle.]

It is said in a trad., Uin-a Alz-amaAna qadi QsotadaAra↓ kahayoYatihi yawoma xaloqi Qll-ehi Als-amewaAti waAlOaroDa [Verily time hath come round to the like of the state in which it was on the day of God's creating the heavens and the earth: this was said by Moḥammad after he had forbidden the practice of intercalating a lunar month, by which the Arabs had long imperfectly adjusted their lunar year to the solar.] (TA.) And one says, daArati AlOay-aAmu [The days came round in their turns]. (Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ in art. dwl.) And yawomN laA yaduwru fiI Xahorihi [A day of the week that does not come round again in its month: as the last Wednesday, &c.]. (Mujáhid, TA voce dubaArN [q. v.].) [And dAr is said of an event, as meaning It came about. See an ex. in a verse cited in art. Ac.]
dArbihi It went round with him; as the ground and the sea do [apparently] with a person sick by reason of vertigo, or giddiness in the head. (L in art. myd. [See also 4.])
One says also, AstdAr↓ bimaA fiI qalobiI ‡ He comprehended [as though he encircled] what was in my heart. (A.)

And fulaAnN yaduwru EalaI OarobaEi nisowapK ‡ Such a one has within the circuit of his rule and care four wives, or women. (A.) And fulaAnN yaduwru Hawola fulaAnapa wayujam-iXuhaA ‡ [Such a man has within his power and care such a female, and toys, dallies, wantons, or holds amorous converse, with her]. (A and TA in art. HwD.) And OanaA Oaduw Hawola celika AlOamori ‡ [I have within my compass, or power, and care, that thing or affair]. (Ṣ and A in art HwD.)
See also 4, in four places.

entry.sense: 2. dw-rhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tadowiyrN, (Ṣ,) He made it mudaw-ar [i. e. round, meaning both circular and spherical]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AdArhu↓. (TA.)
See also 4, in two places.

[One says also, dw-r AlMraMCa fiI OamorK and AdArhA↓ † He turned about, or revolved, thoughts, or ideas, or opinions, in his mind, respecting an affair: like as one says, qal-aba Alfikara faI OamorK.]
3. dAwrhu, inf. n. mudaAwarapN and diwaArN, He went round about with him; syn. daAra maEahu. (M, Ḳ.)

[And hence, † He circumvented him.] Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
Hat-aI OutiyHa lahu yawomFA bimaroqabapK
cuw mir-apK bidiwaAri AlS-ayodu waj-aAsu
[Until there was prepared for him, one day, in a watching-place, an intelligent person, acquainted with the circumvention of game]: wj-As is here made trans. by means of b because it means the same as EaAlimN in the phrase EaAlimN bihi. (M.) [Or the meaning of the latter hemistich is, a person possessing skill in circumventing game, attentive to their motions and sounds.]

dAwrhu also signifies † He endeavoured to induce him to turn, or incline, or decline; or he endeavoured to turn him by deceit, or guile; Eani AlOamori from the thing; and Ealayohi to it; syn. laAwaSahu. (M, Ḳ.) It is said in the trad. respecting the night-journey [of Moḥammad to Jerusalem, and his ascension thence into Heaven], that Moses said to Moḥammad, laqado daAwarotu baniI UisoraAYiyla EalaI OadonaI mino hecaA faDaEufuwA [† Verily I endeavoured to induce the children of Israel to incline to less than this, and they were unable]: or, accord. to one relation, he said raAwadotu. (TA.) See also 4.

daAwara AlOumuwra ‡ He sought to find the modes, or manners, of doing, or performing, affairs, or the affairs: (A:) AlmudaAwarapN is like AlmuEaAlajapN [signifying the labouring, taking pains, applying one's self vigorously, exerting one's self, striving, or struggling, to do, execute, or perform, or to effect, or accomplish, or to manage, or treat, a thing;, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Suheym Ibn-Wetheel says,
Oaxuw xamosiyna mujotamiEN OaXud-iI
wanaj-adaniI mudaAwarapu AlX-uWuwni
[Fifty years of age, my manly vigour full, and vigorous application to the management of affairs has tried and strengthened me]. (Ṣ.)

4. AdArhu, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and dw-rhu↓, (M, A, Ḳ,) and daAra↓ bihi, (M, TA,) and dw-r↓ bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AadaAra bihi, and AstdAr↓ bihi, (M, Ḳ,) He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to go, move, or turn, round; to circle; to revolve; to return to the place from which he, or it, began to move. (TA.) You say, OadaAra AlEimaAmapa EalaI raOosihi [He wound the turban round upon his head]. (A.) And AdAr Alz-aEofaraAna fiI AlmaMCi [He stirred round the saffron in the water, in dissolving it]. (A and TA in art. dwm.) And
daArato↓ bihi dawaAYiru Alz-amaAni
[The revolutions of fortune, or time, made him to turn round from one state, or condition, to another]. (A.) And diyra↓ bihi, and Oudiyra bihi, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and diyra↓ Ealayohi (Ḳ,) [the first and second lit. signifying He was made to turn round; by which, as by the third also, is meant] he became affected by a vertigo, or giddiness in the head. (Ṣ,* A,* Ḳ. [See also 1.])

AdArhu EalaI AlOamori He endeavoured [to turn him to the thing, i. e.] to induce him to do the thing: and AdArhu Eanohu he endeavoured [to turn him from it, i. e.] to induce him to leave, or relinquish, it; (T, A;) or i. q. laAwaSahu; as also daAwarahu↓, q. v. (M, Ḳ.)

UidaArapN [the inf. n.] also signifies The giving and taking, from hand to hand, without delay: and agreeably with this explanation is rendered the phrase in the Ḳur [ii. 282], lijaArapN HaADirapN tudiyruwnahaA bayonakumo [Ready merchandise, which ye give and take among yourselves, from hand to hand, without delay; i. e., not on credit]. (TA.)
See also 1:
and 2, in two places.
5. tdy-r AlmakaAna He took the place as a house, or an abode. (A.) [The I in this verb takes the place of w, as in dayorN and AayobapN, &c.]

10. AstdAr [It had, or assumed, a round, or circular, form; it coiled itself, or became coiled; it wound, or wound round;] it was, or became, round. (KL.) You say, AstdAr Alqamaru [The moon became round, or full: see also the act. part. n., below]. (A.) And laf-ato vawobFA kaQloEiSaAbapi EalaI QsotidaArapi raOosihaA [She wound a piece of cloth like the fillet upon the round of her head, leaving the crown uncovered]. (Mgh and L and Mṣb voce miEojarN.)
See also 1, in six places.
And see 4.

hom.sense: daArN, [originally dawarN, as will be seen below, A house; a mansion; and especially a house of a large size, comprising a court; or a house comprising several sets of apartments and a court; (see bayotN;)] a place of abode which comprises a building, or buildings, and a court, or space in which is no building: (T, M, Ḳ:) as also daArapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or the latter is a more special term; (Ṣ;) meaning any particular house; the former being a generic term: (MF:) accord. to IJ, it is from daAra, aor. yaduwru; because of the many movements of the people in it: (M:) it is of the fem. gender: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and sometimes masc.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as in the Ḳur xvi. 32, as meaning mavowaI, or mawoDiE, (Ṣ,) or as being a gen. n.: (MF:) pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) OadoWurN and OadowurN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and MdurN, (Abu-l- Ḥasan, AAF, Mṣb, Ḳ,) formed by transposition, (Mṣb,) [for OawodurN,] and OadowaArN (T, Ḳ) and OadoyaArN (T) and OadowirapN, (T, Ḳ,) and (of mult., Ṣ) diyaArN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as jibaAlN is pl. of jabalN, (Ṣ,) and diwaArN (T) and diyaArapN (M, Ḳ) and duwrN, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) like as OusodN is pl. of OasadN, (Ṣ,) and diyraAnN (T, M, Ḳ) and duwraAnN (T, Ḳ) and diyarN and diyarapN, (T,) and [quasi-pl. n.] daArapN↓, and [pl. pl.] diyaAraAtN [pl. of diyaArN] and duwraAtN [pl. of duwrN], (M, Ḳ,) and [pl. of daArapN] daAraAtN. (T.) The dim. is duwayorapN↓. (Ḥar p. 161.) [Hence, daAru AlDarobi The mint:, &c.]

Also Any place in which a people have alighted and taken up their abode; an abode; a dwelling. (T, Mgh.) Hence the present world is called daAru AlfanaMCi [The abode of perishableness; or the perishable abode]: and the world to come, daAru AlbaqaMCi [The abode of everlastingness; or the everlasting abode]; and daAru AlqaraAri [The abode of stability; or the stable abode]; and daAru Als-alaAmi [The abode of peace, or of freedom evil]. (T.) [And hence, daAru AlHarobi: see HarobN.] [Hence, also,] daArN is applied to A burial-ground. (Nh from a trad.)
[And hence,] AisotaOocino EalaI rab-iI fiI daArihi [Ask thou permission for me to go in to my Lord] in his Paradise. (TA from a trad. respecting intercession.)

And saOuriykumo daAra AlfaAsiqiyna, in the Ḳur [vii. 142, I will show you the abode of the transgressors], meaning Egypt: or, accord. to Mujáhid, the abode to which the transgressors shall go in the world to come. (TA.)
[Hence, also,] daArN signifies i. q. baladN [A country, or district: or a city, town, or village]. (Mgh, Ḳ.)
And, with the art. Al, [El-Medeeneh;] the City of the Prophet. (Ḳ.)

And hence, (TA,) daArN also signifies ‡ A tribe; syn. qabiylapN: (A, Ḳ:) for Oaholu daArK: (TA:) as also daArapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former, duwrN. (A, Mṣb.) You say, mar-ato binaA daAru baniI fulaAnK ‡ The tribe of the sons of such a one passed by us. (A.) And in the same sense dAr is used in a trad. in which it is said that there remained no dAr among which (fiyhaA) a mosque had not been built. (TA.)

Mtr states that it is said to signify also A year; syn. HawolN; and if this be correct, which he does no hold to be the case, it is from Ald-awaraAnu, like as HawolN is from AlHawalaAnu: or, as some say, i. q. dahorN [as meaning a long time, or the like]. (Ḥar p. 350.)
And Ald-aAru is the name of A certain idol. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[dAr and dyr explained by Freytag as meaning “Medulla liquida in ossibus” are mistakes for raArN and rayorN.]

entry.sense: daworN an inf. n. of daAra. (Ṣ, M, &c.)
[Hence, The circumference of a circle: see takosiyrN.]
And A turn, or twist, of a turban, (T, A,) and of a rope, or any other thing: (T:) pl. OadowaArN. (A.)

dayorN, originally with w; (T, Ṣ;) or originally thus, with I, (M, [and so accord. to the place in which it is mentioned in the A and Mṣb and Ḳ,]) as appears from the occurrence of the I in its pl. and in the derivative day-aArN, for if the I were in this case interchangeable with w it would occur in other derivatives; (M;) [or this is not a valid reason, for day-aArN is held by J to be originally dayowaArN, i. e. of the measure fayoEaAlN; and ISd himself seems in one place to express the same opinion; in like manner as day-uwrN is held by the latter to be originally dayowuwrN; and taday-ara is evidently altered from tadaw-ara;] A convent, or monastery, (xAn,) of Christians: (M, Ḳ:) and also the SawomaEap [i. e. cloister, or cell,] of a monk: (A:) the pl. is OadoyaArN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and duyuwrapN. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] rOosu Ald-ayori [lit. The head of the convent or monastery] is an appellation given to ‡ Any one who has become the head, or chief, of his companions. (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: daArapN: see daAYirapN, in two places. [Hence,] daArapN Alqamari The halo (haAalp) of the moon; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also daw-aArap↓: (Ḳ * and TA in art. Hlq:) pl. daAraAtN. (Mṣb.) Dim. duwayorapN↓. (Ḥar p. 609.) One says, fulaAnN wajohuhu mivolu daArapi Alqamari [Such a one's face is like the halo of the moon]. (TA.) And laA taxorujo Eano daAYirapi↓ AlUisolaAmi Hat-aI yaxoruja Alqamaru mino daAratihi [Go not thou forth from the circle of El-Islám until the moon go forth from its halo]. (A.)

Also A round space of sand; (Ḳ;) as also day-rapN↓, incorrectly written in the Ḳ diyrap↓ (TA) [and in some copies dayorap]; and tadowirapN↓: pl. of the first daAraAtN and duwrN: (Ḳ:) and pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the second day-irN↓: (TA:) or daArapN signifies, accord. to Aṣ, a round tract of sand with a vacancy in the middle; as also duwrapN↓, or, as others say, daworapN↓, and daw-aArapN↓ and day-irapN↓; and sometimes people sit and drink there. (T.)

And Any wide space of land among mountains: (Ḳ:) it is reckoned among productive low lands: (AḤn:) or a plain, or soft, tract of land encompassed by mountains: (A:) or a wide and plain space of land so encompassed: (Aṣ:) or i. q. buhorapN, except that this is always plain, or soft, whereas a dArp may be rugged and plain, or soft: (Aboo-Fak'as, Kr:) or any clear and open space among sands. (TA.)
And Any place that is surrounded and confined by a thing. (T, A.)
See also daArN, in three places.
daArapu, determinate, (M, Ḳ,) and imperfectly decl., (M,) Calamity, or misfortune. (Kr, M, Ḳ.)
daworapN: see daArapN:
and see also daAYirapN.

entry.sense: duwrapN: see daArapN.
diyrapN: see daArapN.

hom.sense: daAriI-N A man (A) who keeps to his house; (M, Ḳ;) who does not quit it, (M, A,) nor seek sustenance; (M;) as also daAriy-apN↓. (Ḳ.)
And hence, (Ṣ,) † A possessor of the blessings, comforts, or conveniences, of life: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. daAriy-uwna. (Ṣ.)

Also A camel, or sheep or goat, that remains at the house, not going to pasture: fem. with p {daAriy-apN}: (A:) or a camel that remains behind in the place where the others lie down; (M, Ḳ;) and so a sheep or goat. (M.)
See also day-aArN.
A sailor that has the charge of the sail. (M, Ḳ.)

A seller of perfumes: so called in relation to Dáreen, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) a port of El-Bahreyn, in which was a market whereto musk used to be brought from India. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., mavalu Aljaliysi AlS-aAliHi mavalu Ald-aAriI-i Uino lamo yuHocika mino EiTorihi Ealiqaka mino riyHihi [The similitude of the righteous companion who sits and converses with one is that of the seller of perfumes: if he give not to thee of his perfume, somewhat of his sweet odour clings to thee]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: duwriI-N: see day-aArN.
daAriy-apN: see daAriI-N.
dayoraAniI-N (anomalous [as a rel. n. from dayorN], M) and day-aArN↓ The master, (SaAHib, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or an inhabitant, (T, A,) of a dayor [i. e. convent, or monastery]. (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)
dawaArN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

hom.sense: duwaArN A vertigo, or giddiness in the head; (Ṣ,* A,* Ḳ;) as also dawaArN↓. (M, Ḳ.)

Also, and dawaArN↓, (Ṣ,) or Ald-uwaAru and Ald-awaAru↓, (T, M, Ḳ,) and (but less commonly, TA) Ald-uw-aAru↓ and Ald-aw-aAru↓, (M, Ḳ,) A certain idol, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which the Arabs set up, and around it they made a space, (T,) round which they turned, or circled: (T, M:) and the same name they applied to the space above mentioned: (T, M:) it is said that they thus compassed it certain weeks, like as people compass the Kaabeh: (MF:) or certain stones around which they circled, in imitation of people compassing the Kaabeh. (IAmb.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says,
EacaAraI duwaArK fiI mulaMCK mucay-ali
[Virgins making the circuit of Duwár, in long-skirted garments of the kind called mulaMC]: (Ṣ:)
likening a herd of [wild] cows to damsels thus occupied and attired, alluding to the length of their tails. (TA.) Ald-uw-aAru↓ and Ald-aw-aAru↓ also signify The Kaabeh. (Kr, M, Ḳ.) And duw-aArN↓ (Th, M, [not duw-aArapN, as is implied in the Ḳ,]) A circling tract (musotadaAr↓) of sand, around which go the wild animals: (Th, M, Ḳ:) a poet says,
bid-uwaAri nihoI ciI EaraArK waHul-abi
[In the sandy tract around a pool of water left by a torrent, containing plants of the kinds called 'arár and hullab]. (Th, M.)

entry.sense: duwayorapN: see daArN and daArapN, of each of which it is the dim.
day-irN: see daAarpN.

hom.sense: day-irapN: see daAarpN, in two places:
and see also daAYirapN.
daw-aArN ' [Turning round, circling, or revolving,] applied to the firmament, or celestial orb. (A.)

Applied likewise to time, or fortune; (M, Ḳ;) as also daw-aAriI-N↓, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) which is said to be a rel. n., but is not so accord. to AAF, though having the form thereof, like kurosiI-N, (M,) the I being a corroborative: (Mṣb voce waHoXiI-N:) thus in the saying,
waAld-ahoru biQloUinosaAni daw-aAriI-u↓ , (Ṣ, M,* A,* Ḳ,*) occurring in a poem of El-ʼAjjáj, (Ṣ,) and daw-aArN, (M, Ḳ,) i. e. And time, or fortune, turns man about from one state, or condition, to another: (Ṣ, M,* A, Ḳ:*) or turns him about much. (Mṣb in art. wHX.)
See also duwaArN, in two places.

entry.sense: duw-aArN: see duwaArN, in three places.

maA biAld-aAri day-aArN, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) originally dayowaArN, of the measure fayoEaAlN, (Ṣ,) and duwriI-N↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and day-iwrN↓, (M, Ḳ,) in which a w is changed into I, (M,) [dy-wr being originally dayowuwrN,] and daAriI-N↓, There is not in the house any one: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) the broken pl. of day-aArN and day-uwrN is dawaAwiyru; the w being unchanged because of its distance from the end of the word. (M.) ISd says, in the EawiyS, that Yaạḳoob has erred in asserting dy-Ar to be used only in negative phrases; for Dhu-r-Rummeh uses it in an affirmative phrase. (MF.)
See also dayoraAniI-N.
day-uwrN: see the next preceding paragraph.
daw-aArapN: see daArapN, in two places:
and see also duw-aArapN, in two places:
and daAYirapN.
Also [or perhaps duw-aArapN↓] The pieces of wood which the water turns so as to make the mill turn with their turning. (Mgh.)
And A pair of compasses. (T, Ḳ,* TA.)
duw-aArapN and daw-aArapN↓, of the head, A round part or portion. (M, Ḳ.)

And of the belly, What winds, or what has, or assumes, a coiled, or circular, form, (maA taHaw-aI, [so in the M and L, in the Ḳ mAyaHowiI, which is evidently a mistake,]) of the guts, or intestines, of a sheep or goat. (M, L, Ḳ.*)
Accord. to IAạr, (T,) daw-aArapN↓ and faw-aArapN are applied to Anything [round] that does not move nor turn round: and duw-aArapN and fuw-aArapN to a thing that moves and turns round. (T, Ḳ, TA.)
See also daw-aArapN.
daw-aAriI-N: see daw-aArN, in two places.

hom.sense: daAYirapN, in which the p is added for the purpose of transferring the word from the category of epithets to that of substs, and as a sign of the fem. gender, ('Ináyeh,) The circuit, compass, ambit, or circumference, of a thing; (T, Ḳ, TA;) as in the phrases daAYirapu AlHaAfiri the circuit of, or what surrounds, the solid hoof, (TA,) or the circuit of hair around the solid hoof, (T,) and daAYirapu Alwajohi the circuit of the face, or the parts around the face; (TA;) and daArapN↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former dawaAYiru; and of the latter daAraAtN. (TA.) [Hence one says, hecaA OawosaEu daAYirapF mino caAka, meaning † This is wider in compass, or more comprehensive, than that. See also 10, third sentence.]
A ring: (M, Ḳ:) or the like thereof; a circle: and a round thing: as also daArapN↓; pl. as above. (T.) See an ex. voce daArapN.

The circular, or spiral, curl of hair upon the crown of a man's head: (T, M, Ḳ:) or the place of the duWaAbap. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.) Hence the prov., maA QqoXaEar-ato lahu daAYiratiI [The circular, or spiral, curl of hair upon the crown of my head did not stand erect on account of him]: said of him who threatens thee with a thing but does not harm thee. (M.)

[What is called, in a horse, A feather; or portion of the hair naturally curled or frizzled, in a spiral manner or otherwise]: pl. dawaAYiru. (T, Ṣ, Mṣb.) In a horse are eighteen dwAYr, (AO, T, Ṣ,) which are distinguished by different names, as AlqahoEapu and AlqaAliEu and Aln-aAxisu and All-aTaApu [&c.]. (AO, T.)

The round thing [or depression] (T) that is beneath the nose, (T, Ḳ,) which is likewise called nuwnapN; (T;) as also daw-aArapN↓ (T, Ḳ) and day-irapN↓. (T.) [But the daAYirap in the middle of the upper lip is The small protuberance termed HivorimapN, q. v.]

A turn of fortune: (AO:) and especially an evil accident; a misfortune; a calamity; (A,* TA;) as also daworapN↓: (TA:) defeat; rout: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) slaughter: death: (TA:) pl. as above. (A, Mṣb, &c.) You say, daArato Ealayohimu Ald-awaAYiru Calamities befell them. (M.) And hence, daAYirapu Als-uwoCi [and Als-awoCi, in the Ḳur ix. 99 and xlviii. 6,] (Ṣ, Mṣb) Calamity which befalls and destroys. (Mṣb. [See also art. swO.])
Also A piece of wood which is stuck in the ground in the middle of a heap of wheat in the place where it is trodden, around which the bulls or cows turn. (TA.)

entry.sense: tadowirapN: see daArapN.
Also i. q. majolisN [A sittingplace,, &c.]. (Seer, M.)

hom.sense: madaArN an inf. n. of daAra. (Lth, T.)
And also, as a proper subst., (T,) The axis of the firmament, or celestial orb, [&c.] (T, A.)
[And hence, † The point upon which a question, or the like, turns. Pl. madaAraAtN.]

entry.sense: mudaArN: see mudaw-arN:
and see what next follows.
huwa maduwru bihi and mudaArN↓ bh [He is affected by a vertigo, or giddiness in the head: see 4]. (A.)

mudaArapN A skin made round, and sewed, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the form of a bucket, (Ṣ,) with which one draws water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) A rájiz says,
laAyasotaqiI fiI Aln-azaHi AlmaDofuwfi
Uil-aA mudaAraAtu Alguruwbi Aljuwfi
[Nothing will draw water in a well of which most of the water has been exhausted, to which many press to draw, except the kind of buckets made of a round piece of skin, of ample capacity]: i. e. one cannot draw water from a small quantity but with wide and shallow buckets: but some say that mdArAt should be mdArAp, from AlmudaAraApu fiI AlOumuwri; holding it to be for bimudaAraApi Ald-ilaMCi; and reading laA yusotaqaI. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also A garment of the kind called UzaAr figured (Ḳ, TA) with sundry circles: pl. mudaAraAtN. (TA.)
mudowarapN, thus preserving its original form, (Ḳ,) not having the w changed into A, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, mudaw-arap,] She-camels which the pastor goes round about and milks. (Ḳ.)

mudaw-arN and mudaArN↓ [Made round, meaning both circular and spherical; rounded; and simply round: the former word is the more common: of the latter, see an ex. in a verse cited voce yalabN: and see also musotadiyrN].
musotadaAru [a noun of place and of time from AisotadaAra, agreeably with a general rule]: see duwaArN.

musotadiyrN [Having, or assuming, a round, or circular, form; round, or circular: see also mudaw-arN]. You say qamarN musotadiyrN musotaniyrN [A round, or full, shining moon]. (A. [Accord. to the TA, the latter epithet is added as an explicative of the former; but this I think an evident mistake.])

1. daAsa, aor. yduwsu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. dawosN (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ) and diyaAsN (M, A, Ḳ) and diyaAsapN, (A, Ḳ,) He trod, trod upon, or trampled upon, (M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,) or the ground, (Mṣb,) vehemently, (Mgh, Mṣb,) with the foot. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, daAsuwhu biOaqodaAmihimo [They trod, or trampled, upon him, or it, with their feet]. (A.) And Alxayolu taduwsu AlqatolaI biAlHawaAfiri [The horses trample upon the slain with the hoofs]. (A.)

daAsa AlT-aEaAma, (Ṣ, A,) or AlHinoTapa, (Mṣb,) or AlHab-a, (M,) aor. yaduwsu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. dyaAsapN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,) or dawosN and diyaAsN, but some say that diyaAsN is not of the language of the Arabs, and some say that it is tropical, as though from daAsa in the sense explained above, (Mṣb,)
or the professors of practical religion use it in the place of diyaAsapN by a kind of license, relying upon the understanding of the hearer or reader, or do so erroneously, (Mgh,) He trod, or thrashed, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) the wheat, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or grain, (M,) either by the feet of beasts, or by repeatedly drawing over it the midowas [q. v. infrà] until it became tibon [or cut straw]; (Mgh;) as also OadaAsahu↓. (M.) You say, daAsuwhu dawosa AlHaSiydi [They trod, or trampled, upon him, or it, with the treading of reaped corn]. (A.)
daAsahu, (IAạr, TA,) inf. n. dawosN, (IAạr, A, Ḳ,) He abased him. (IAạr, A, Ḳ.)

nazala AlEaduw-u bibaniI fulaAnK fajaAsahumo waHaAsahumo wadaAsahumo The enemy [came upon and] slew the sons of such a one, and went through the midst of their dwellings, and made havoc among them. (TA.)

daAsahaA, (A, TA,) inf. n. dawosN, (A, Ḳ,) ‡ Inivit eam; scil., feminam: (A:) vehementer inivit eam: (A, Ḳ: [in the former, this signification is given as proper, though that immediately preceding is said to be tropical: in the TA, the latter is said to be tropical:]) conscendit et vehementer inivit eam. (TA.)
daAsahu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. dawosN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or diyaAsN, (Aṣ, A, Mgh,) ‡ He polished it; namely, a sword, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the like, (Ḳ,) or some other thing. (Mṣb.)

Hence, dawosN also signifies ‡ The framing, and dressing up, of deceit, guile, or circumvention: (Aṣ, A, TA:) [agreeably with which explanation the verb, daAsa, is probably used, though not mentioned in the A nor in the TA:] or simply, the act of deceiving, beguiling, circumventing, and practising artifice. (TA.) You say, OaxaconaA fiI Ald-awosi ‡ We set about the framing, and dressing up, of deceit, guile, or circumvention: (A:) or we set about deceiving,, &c. (TA.)
4: see daAsa AlT-aEaAma, in the paragraph above.
7. AndAs It (wheat [or grain]) was, or became, trodden, or thrashed. (Ṣ,* TA.) [See 1.]
diysN: see the next paragraph.
daw-aAsN The lion (Ḳ, TA) that tramples upon his prey. (TA.)

A courageous man; (Ḳ;) and any one that tramples upon his opponents, or adversaries: (TA:) and [in like manner] diysN↓, originally diwosN, a courageous and strong man, that tramples upon every one who alights with him to fight: pl. of the latter, diyasapN. (AZ, TA.)
‡ Every one skilful (Ḳ, TA) in his art; because he abases (yaduwsu) every one who contends with him. (TA.)

hom.sense: daAYisu [act. part. n. of daAsa; Treading,, &c.].
daAYisapN [the fem.] (A) and [its pl.] dawaAYisu (M, A, TA) The bulls, or cows, that tread, or thrash, wheat, or grain. (M, A, TA.)
Oatatohumo Alxayolu dawaAYisa The horses, or horses with their riders, came to them following one another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Also i. q. OanodarN [A place in which wheat or grain is trodden out; like madaAsapN: or reaped wheat collected together; or wheat collected together in the place where it is trodden out]; (Ḳ;) so accord. to Hishám: or, as some say, he that treads, or thrashes, wheat, and bruises it, in order that the grain may come forth from it. (TA.)

duwsN [pl. of daAYisN, like as buzolN is pl. of baAzilN,] ‡ Polishers of swords or the like; syn. SaqalapN. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, SaqolapN, which is evidently a mistake.])

entry.sense: madaAsN, (Ḳ,) but by rule it should be midaAsN, (Mṣb,) and so, accord. to En-Näwawee, it is also written, as though meaning “an instrument for treading,” (MF,) originally midowasN, (TA in art. mds,) A certain thing that is worn on the foot (Mṣb, Ḳ) by a man; (Mṣb;) [a shoe, or sandal, or a pair of shoes or sandals, of any kind; accord. to present usage: or, accord. to Golius, a kind of high-heeled shoe or sandal, generally used by peasants, and fastened with thongs or with a button or the like:] pl. OamodasapN [which is a pl. of pauc., and the only pl. mentioned]. (Mṣb.)

midowasN The thing [or machine, a kind of drag,] with which wheat is thrashed, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, L, Ḳ,) by its being drawn over it (Mgh, L) repeatedly; called also jarojarN (Mgh) [and naworajN, q. v.]; and so midowaAsN↓. (Ḳ.)

‡ A polishinginstrument; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) an instrument with which swords, &c. are polished; (Mṣb;) a piece of wood upon which is a misan- [or polishing-stone], with which the sword is polished: (M:) pl. madaAwisu. (Ṣ.)
TariyqN maduwsN [A trodden road: or] a road much trodden; (TA;) as also mudaw-asN↓. (A, TA.)
mudaw-asN: see what next precedes.
madaAsapN A place in which wheat [or grain] is trodden, or thrashed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also daAYisN.]
midowaAsN: see midowasN.

1. daAfahu, (T, M, Mṣb,) first pers. dufotuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaduwfuhu, (T, Mṣb,) inf. n. dawofN; (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AdAfhu↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. UidaAfapN; (TA;) He mixed it; (M, Ḳ;) generally meaning medicine, and perfume: (M:) and (Ḳ) he moistened it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, medicine, &c., (Ṣ,) with water, &c., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or with water and the like: (Ḳ:) or dAfh fiI AlmaMCi [he steeped it in water], namely, perfume, &c.: (T:) and daAfahu, aor. yadiyfuhu, inf. n. dayofN, is a dial. var. thereof: (Mṣb:) and faAdahu, aor. yafuwduhu signifies the same. (Aṣ, TA.) [Also, app., He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it; or powered, or pulverized, it; namely, musk: see maduwfN, below.]
4: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
duwfaAnN Incubus, or nightmare; syn. kaAbuwsN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
daAYifN act. part. n. of 1. (T, TA.)
And, applied to musk, i. q. maduwfN, q. v. (TA.)

maduwfN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and madowuwfN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter of the dial. of Temeem, (M,) and [said to be] the only instance of the kind, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e., of a pass. part. n. of a triliteralradical verb with a medial w (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA,) except maSuwwnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) as a variation of maSuwnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) though Mbr asserts it to be agreeable with a rule obtaining in all similar cases, which none [other] of the leading authorities allows, (Mṣb,) and maduwfN and maSuwnN are the usual forms, (Ṣ, TA,) Mixed: (M, Mṣb:) or moistened: or bruised, brayed, or pounded; or powdered, or pulverized: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied to perfume, (T,) or to musk: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) as also daAYifN↓. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. daAkahu, aor. yaduwku, inf. n. dawokN and madaAkN, He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and did so finely, or pulverized it; (TA;) namely, perfume, (Ṣ, TA,), &c. (TA.) Also, inf. n. dawokN, He bruised it, and ground it, like as does a camel a thing with his breast [when lying upon the ground]. (Z, TA.)

And daAkahaA, (AA, Ḳ,) aor. yaduwku, inf. n. dawokN; (AA,) He compressed her; namely, a woman; (AA, Ḳ;) and so baAkahaA. (AA.) And He leaped her; namely, a stallion, the mare: (TA:) and in like manner said of an ass. (IDrd, TA.)
And dAkhu, (IDrd, Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. dawokN, (IDrd,) He plunged him (a man) in water or dust. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
And i. q. Oasar-ahu [He made him captive;, &c.]. (TA.)

dAk Alqawomu The people, or party, fell into a state of confusion (Ḳ, TA) in respect of their case, or affair, and went round about [in perplexity]. (TA,) baAta Alqawomu yaduwkuwna, (Ṣ,) or Aln-aAsu, occurring in a trad., (TA,) inf. n. dawokN, (Ṣ, TA,) means The people passed the night in confusion, and in going round about [in perplexity]: (Ṣ:) or in a state of confusion, and commotion, or disturbance, and disagreement. (TA.)
And The people, or party, became diseased, or sick. (Abu-r-Rabeea El-Bekráwee, Aboo-Turáb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tdAkwA They straitened one another (Ṣ, Ḳ) in war, or battle, (Ṣ,) or in evil, or mischief, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and in contention, or altercation. (Ḳ.)
dawokN A species of mother-of-pearl-shell, or oyster-shell. (IDrd, TA.)
duwkN: see madaAkN.

dawokapN and duwkapN↓ Evil, or mischief; and contention, or altercation; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and a confused state of affairs: pl. of the former diwakN and diyakN, and of the latter duwakN. (TA.) One says, waqaEuwAfiI dawokapK and duwkapK↓ [They fell into evil, &c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Ru-beh says,
farub-amaA najayotu mino tiloka Ald-uwako↓
[And seldom, or often, I escaped from those evils,, &c.] (TA.)
duwkapN; and its pl. duwakN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
Also Disease, or sickness. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.)

madaAkN i. q. SalaMCapN, (Ḳ,) i. e., (TA,) A stone upon which perfume is bruised, brayed, or pounded; (Ṣ, TA;) as also duwkN↓ (TA) and midowakN↓: (Ḳ:) or this last signifies a stone with which perfume is bruised, brayed, or pounded: (Ṣ, TA:) F's making this word and the first to signify the same requires consideration. (TA.)
midowakN: see the next preceding paragraph.
1. daAla i. q. daAra. (TA.) You say, dAlti AlOay-aAmu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. taduwlu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. dawolN, (KL,) meaning daArat; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [i. e.] The days came round [in their turns]. (KL.)

dawolN also signifies The changing of time, or fortune, from one state, or condition, to another; (Ḳ;) and so dawolapN. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, dAlt lahu Ald-awolapu [The turn of fortune was, or became, in his favour; or] good fortune came to him: and dAlt Ealayohi Ald-awolapu [The turn of fortune was, or became, against him; or] good fortune departed from him. (MA.)

[Golius assigns to dAl, with dawolapN for its inf. n., as on the authority of the Ṣ and KL, two significations app. from two meanings of dawolapN, one of which he seems to have misunderstood, and to neither of which do I find any corresponding verb: they are “Obivit alter alterum in bello:” and “superior evasit.” There are many inf. ns. that have no corresponding verbs.]
dAl, aor. yaduwilu, (T, Ḳ,) inf. n. dawolN and daAlapN, (Ḳ,) or dawolapN, (T,) He became notorious [either in a bad or in a good sense]; expl. by SaAra XuhorapF, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) i. e. maXohuwrFA. (TḲ.)

dAl Alv-awobu, aor. yaduwlu, The garment, or piece of cloth, was, or became, old, and worn out. (AZ, Ṣ.) [Hence,] jaEala wud-uhu yaduwlu ‡ His love, or affection, was beginning to become, or at the point of becoming, worn out. (AZ, Ṣ, TA.)
See also 7.
2. dw-l He wrote a d. (TA.)

3. dAwl, [inf. n. mudaAwalapN,] He made to come round [by turns, or to be by turns]: hence the saying in the Ḳur [iii. 134], w tiloka AloOay-aAmu nudaAwiluhaA bayona Aln-aAsi And those days, we make them to come round [by turns] to men: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) or this means, we dispense them by turns to men; (Bḍ, Jel;) to these one time, and to these another; (Bḍ;) or one day to one party, and one day to another. (Jel.) You say, daAwalotu AlX-aIoCa bayonahumo fatadaAwaluwhu↓ [I dispensed the thing among them by turns, and they had, or received, or took, it by turns]. (Bḍ on the passage of the Ḳur quoted above.) mudaAwalapN also signifies The giving a turn of fortune, or good fortune. (KL. [See what next follows {4}.])

4. AdAlhu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UidaAlapN, (T, TA,) [signifying He gave him a turn of good fortune, or a turn to prevail over another in war,, &c.,] is from Ald-awolapu. (T, M, Ḳ, TA. [See what next precedes {4}.]) Hence, [in the CK from Ald-uwlap,] the saying, OadaAlanaA Qll-ehu mino Eaduw-inaA [God gave us, or may God give us, a turn to prevail over our enemy]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And OadaAlaka Qll-ehu mino Eaduw-ika and EalaI Eaduw-ika, i. e. jaEala laka Ealayohi dawolapF [May God appoint thee, or give thee, a turn to prevail over thine enemy]. (Ḥam p. 547.) And AdAl Qll-ehu zayodFA mino EamorKw [God gave to Zeyd a turn to have the superiority over ʼAmr;] i. e. God took away the turn of good fortune, or the good fortune, (Aldwlp,) from ʼAmr, and gave it to Zeyd. (Ḥar p. 118.) Hence, also, (TA,) El-Hajjáj said, Uin-a AlOaroDa satudaAlu min-aA kamaA OudilonaA minohaA [Verily the earth will be given a turn to prevail over us, like as we have been given a turn to prevail over it]; (Lth, T, TA;) meaning that it will consume us, like as we have consumed [of] it. (T, TA.) And [hence] UidaAlapN signifies galabapN [or Victory]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or [rather], as some say, it signifies nuSorapN [i. e. aid against an enemy]: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) you say, Aall-ehuma OadiloniI EalaI fulaAnN O God, aid me against such a one. (Ṣ, and Ḥar ubi suprà. [In the former, waQnoSuroniIEalayohi, as an explicative adjunct: in the latter, AI nS-irnI Elyh, for QnoSuroniI.])

6. tadaAwaluwhu They took it, or had it, by turns. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ. See 3.) You say, tadaAwalonaA AlOamora We took [or did] the affair by turns. (M.) And tadaAwalonaA AlEamala waAlOamorabayonanaA We did the work, and the thing, or affair, by turns, among us. (T.) And tadaAwaluwA AlbaATila They took it by turns to say, or to do, that which was false, wrong, vain, futile, or the like; syn. tabaT-aluwA bayonahumo. (Az and Ḳ in art. bTl.) And tadaAwalatohu AlOayodiI The hands took it by turns. (Ṣ.) And tadaAwalati Alr-iyaAHu rasoma Ald-aAra The winds blew by turns upon, or over, the remains that marked the site of the house [so as to efface them]; one time from the south, and another time from the north, and another time from the east, and another time from the west. (Az, TA in art. Ewr.) And, of a thing, you say, yutadaAwalu (T) or yutadaAwalu bihi (Ṣ) [meaning It is taken, or done, by turns]. And tuduwowilati AlOaroDu biAlr-aEoIi [The land was pastured on by turns]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wZb.) [tadaAwaluwhu also signifies They made frequent use of it; i. e., used it time after time, or turn after turn; namely, a word or phrase: but perhaps in this sense it is post-classical: see an ex. in De Sacy's “Chrest. Arabe,” sec. ed., p. 141 of the Arabic text.] And tadaAwalati AlOaXoyaMCu The things alternated; or succeeded one another by turns, one taking the place of another: (L in art. nsx:) and [in like manner] AlOazomanapu [the times]. (Mṣb and Ḳ in that art.) [See also 6 in art dfw.]
7. AndAl Alqawomu The people, or party, removed, or shifted, from one place to another. (Ṣ.)
AndAl maA fiIbaTonihi What was in his belly, (M, Ḳ,) of intestines or peritonæum, (M,) came forth, (M, Ḳ,) in consequence of its being pierced. (M.)
And AndAl It (the belly) became wide, and near, or approaching, to the ground. (M, Ḳ.) Also (Ḳ) It (the belly) was, or became, flaccid, flabby, or pendulous; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so daAla↓. (Ḳ.)
And It (a thing) dangled, or moved to and fro; and hung. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: daAlN One of the letters of the alphabet, (d,) the place of utterance of which is near to that of t: masc. and fem.; so that you say daAlN HasanN and HasanapN [a beautiful d]: the pl. is OadowaAlN if masc., and daAlaAtN [if fem.; the latter the more common]. (TA.)
Also A fat woman. (Kh, TA.)
See also daAlapN.
dawolN an inf. n. of daAla in senses explained above. (Ḳ, KL.)
Also i. q. dalowN [A bucket]: (Ḳ:) [an arabicized word from the Pers. duwlo: or] formed from dalowN by transposition. (TA.)

dawalN, as an epithet applied to nabolN [or arrows] i. q. mutadaAwalN↓. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.*) So in the saying,
yuluwcu biAljawodi mina Aln-aboli Ald-awalo [app. relating to a wild animal, and meaning. He seeks, or takes, refuge in the copious rain from the arrows received in turns by one after another of the herd]. (IAạr, M.)
See also dawolapN.

entry.sense: daAlapN i. q. XuhorapN [Notoriousness,, &c.]: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] daAlN↓. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)
[Accord. to the Ḳ, it is also an inf. n.: see 1.]

hom.sense:
dawolapN A turn, mutation, change, or vicissitude, of time, or fortune, (Ḳ, TA,) from an unfortunate and evil, to a good and happy, state or condition; (TA;) [i. e.,] relating to good; as daborapN, on the contrary, relates to evil: (Aṣ, T and M in art. dbr:) [therefore meaning a turn of good fortune; a favourable turn of fortune: or] good fortune [absolutely]: (KL:) a happy state or condition, that betides a man: (MF:) [also] a turn which comes to one or which one takes [in an absolute sense]; syn. nawobapN: (Ḳ in art. nwb:) and [particularly] (Ḳ) a turn (EuqobapN) [to share] in wealth, and [to prevail] in war; as also duwlapN↓: (ʼEesà Ibn-ʼOmar,* T,* Ṣ,* M, Ḳ:*) or each is a subst.
