[in an absolute sense, app. as meaning a turn of taking, or having, a thing,] from tadaAwaluwA AlX-aIoCa signifying “they took, or had, the thing by turns:” (Mṣb:) or duwlapN↓ is in wealth; and dawolapN is in war; (Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) this latter being when one of two armies defeats the other and then is defeated; (Fr, T;) or when one party is given a turn to prevail (tudaAl) over the other: one says, kaAnato lanaA Ealayohimu Ald-awolapu fiI AlHarobi [The turn to prevail over them in war was ours]: (Ṣ:) and qado rajaEati Ald-awolapu EalaI heWulaMCi [The turn to prevail against these returned]; as though meaning Almar-apu: so says Fr: but duwlapN↓, he says, is in religions and institutions that are altered and changed with time: (T:) accord. to Zj, (T,) or AʼObeyd, (so in two copies of the Ṣ,) duwlapN↓ signifies a thing that is taken by turns; and dawolapN, the act [of taking by turns]; (T, Ṣ;) and a transition from one state, or condition, to another: (T: [in this last sense, app. an inf. n.: see 1, third sentence:]) you say, SaAra AlfaIoCu duwlapF↓ bayonahumo, meaning [The fIC (or spoil,, &c.,) became] a thing taken by turns among them: (Ṣ:)
and the saying, in the Ḳur [lix. 7], kaIo laA yakuwna duwlapF↓ bayona AlOagoniyaMCi minokumo means That it may not be a thing taken by turns [among the rich of you]: (T:) or dawolapN relates to the present life or world; and duwlapN↓, to that which is to come: (M, Ḳ:) and it is said that the former of these two words signifies prevalence, predominance, mastery, or victory; and ↓the latter, the transition of wealth, blessing, or good, from one people, or party, to another: (TA:) the pl. (of dawolapN, Ṣ, Mṣb) is dawilN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as qiSaEN is pl. of qaSoEapN, (Mṣb,) and (of duwlapN↓, T, Ṣ, Mṣb), duwalN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and duwlaAtN, (Ṣ, TA,) and dawalN↓ (M, Ḳ) is [a quasi-pl. n.] of both, because, as IJ says, dawolapN is regarded as though it were originally duwlapN. (M.)
[In post-classical works, it signifies also A dynasty: and a state, an empire, or a monarchy.]

Also The HawoSalap [or stomach of a bird; its triple stomach: or only its first stomach; the crop, or craw]: because of its AinodiyaAl [or flaccidity]. (Ibn-'Abbaád, Ḳ.) And The qaAniSap [which may here mean the same as the HwSlp, for this is one of the meanings assigned to it, and this explanation of dwlp is not given by Ibn-ʼAbbád: or it may here mean the intestines, of a bird, into which the food passes from the stomach: or the gizzard]. (Ḳ.)
And The XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag of the he-camel]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
And A thing like a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] with a narrow mouth. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
And The side of the belly. (Ḳ.) [But] accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, maA OaEoZama dawolapa baTonihi means How large is his navel! (TA.)

entry.sense: duwlapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in nine places:
and see also what next follows, in two places.

duwalapN (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and diwalapN↓ (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA) [and duwlapN↓, as appears from what follows]; as also tuwalapN (T, Ṣ) [and tiwalapN and tuwalpN]; A calamity, or misfortune: (T, Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. duwalaAtN (Ṣ) and diwalaAtN and duwalaAtN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.) You say, jaMCa biduwalaAtihi (Ṣ) [and bidiwalaAtihi↓] and biduwlaAtihi↓ (Ibn-'Abbad, TA) and biduwlaAhu↓, as also bituwlaAhu, (Aboo-Málik, Ḳ,) He, or it, came with, or brought, or brought to pass, his, or its, calamities, or misfortunes: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
diwalapN and jaMCa bidiwalaAtihi: see duwalapN.
jaMCa biduwlaAhu: see duwalapN.

dawiylN A plant that is a year old, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and dry: (M, Ḳ:) or two years old, (AZ, Ḳ,) and worthless: (AZ, TA:) or especially what is dry of the [plants called] naSiI- and sabaT: (M, Ḳ,* TA:) or any plant broken and black. (TA.)
dawaAliI-u A sort of grapes of Et-Táïf, (M, Ḳ,) black inclining to redness. (M.) [See also dawaAlK, in art. dlw.]

dawaAlayoka i. q. mudaAwalapF, [in the CK, erroneously, mutadAwalapF,] used in an imperative sense [with its verb and the objective complement thereof understood before it, and thus meaning daAwili AlfiEola mudaAwalapF Make thou the action to come round, or to be, by turns]: (M, Ḳ:) or it may be rendered as meaning that the thing happened in this manner [i. e. the action being made to come round, or to be, by turns]: (Sb, M:) or it means tadaAwulN baEoda tadaAwul [i. e. a taking, or doing, (a thing) by turn after (another's) doing so, and may be rendered virtually in the same manner as above, i. e. let the action be done by turns: or the action being done by turns]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ: [in the PṢ, tadaAwulFA baEoda tadaAwulK, which better explains the two manners in which it is said to be used:]) IAạr says that it is an invariable expression, like HajaAzayoka and hacaAcayoka; and is from the phrase tadaAwaluwA AlOamora bayonahumo, said of persons when this takes a turn and this a turn. (T, TA.) ʼAbd-Beni-l- Has-hás says,
Uica Xuq-a burodN Xuq-a biAlburodi mivoluhu
dawaAlayoka Hat-aI layosa liloburodi laAbisu
[When a burd (a kind of garment) is rent, the like thereof is rent with the burd, the action being done by turns, so that there is no wearer of the burd; it having been rent so as to fall off]: (Ṣ:) the poet is speaking of a man's rending the clothing of a woman to see her person, and her rending his also. (T, TA. [This verse is related with several variations: see another reading of it voce hacaAcayoka, in art. hc; with another explanation of it.])

Ibn-Buzurj says, (T,) sometimes the article Al is prefixed to it, so that one says Ald-awaAlayoka, (T,) meaning One's walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side, (T,) or one's urging, or pressing forward, and striving, (Oano yataHaf-aza, [in the CK, erroneously, An yataHaf-aza,]) in his gait, or pace, (Ḳ,) when he moves about his shoulder-joints, and parts his legs widely, in walking. (T, Ḳ,* TA. In the copies of the Ḳ, jAl [or jACk] is erroneously put for HaAka, the reading in the T, TA. [The author of the TḲ follows the reading jAl; and has fallen into several other evident mistakes in explaining this expression; which is itself, in my opinion, when with the article Al, a mistake for Ald-awaAliyoku, mentioned in art. dlk.]) A poet uses the phrase yamoXiI Ald-awaAlayoka as meaning Walking, or going, in the manner explained above: (Ibn-Buzurj, T and TA in the present art.:) or yamoXiI Ald-awaAliyka. (TA in art. dlk.)

munodaAlN as meaning Dangling, or moving to and fro; and hanging; is said by Seer to be of the measure munofaEilN from Alt-adal-aI, and formed by transposition; and if so, it has no inf. n.; for the word that is formed by transposition has no inf. n. (M. [But for this assertion I see no satisfactory reason.])
mutadawaAlN: see dawalN.
[AlkalaAmu AlmutadaAwalu signifies, in modern Arabic, The language commonly used.]
duwlaAbN, or dawolaAbN: see art. dlb.

1. daAma, aor. yaduwmu and yadaAmu; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the see. pers. of the pret. when the aor. is yaduwmu being dumota; and when the aor. is yadaAm, dimota; (M;) and accord. to Kr, (M,) you say also dimota, aor. taduwmu, which is extr., (M, Ḳ,) and not of valid authority, held by the lexicologists [in general] to be anomalous like mit-a having for its aor. tamuwtu, and faDila of which the aor. is yafoDulu, and HaDira of which the aor. is yaHoDuru, and said by Aboo-Bekr to be a compound of the pret. of which the aor. is tadaAmu with the aor. of which the pret. is dumota; (M;) inf. n. dawomN and dawaAmN [which is the most common form] and dayomuwmapN [originally dayowamuwmapN, like qayoduwdapN originally qayowaduwdapN, &c.]; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. q. vabata [as meaning It (a thing, Ṣ, M, Mṣb) continued, lasted, endured, or remained]: (Mṣb, TḲ:) and it became extended, or prolonged; syn. Aimotad-a: (TḲ:) and [it continued, lasted, endured, or remained, long;] its time was, or became, long: (TA:) and i. q. baqiIa [as syn. with vabata (explained above) and as meaning it continued, lasted, or existed, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; it was, or became, permanent, perpetual, or everlasting]: (Mṣb in art. bqI:) and AstdAm↓ signifies the same as dAm [in all of these senses]: (TA:) [but Mṭr says,] AstdAm Als-afaru [The journey continued, or continued long,] is not of established authority. (Mgh.) [Hence, daAma mulokuhu May his dominion be of long continuance.] And dAm EalaI AlOamori; (MA;) and dAwm↓ Ealayohi, [and dAwmhu↓, as is shown by a usage of the act. part. n. in art. dmn in the Ṣ, &c.,] (Ṣ,* MA,) inf. n. mudaAwamapN; (Ṣ;) He kept continually, or constantly, to the thing, or affair. (Ṣ, MA.) maA daAma means Continuance; because mA is a conjunct noun to dAm; and it is not used otherwise than adverbially, like as inf. ns. are used adverbially: you say, laA Oajolisu maA dumota qaAYimFA, i. e., dawaAma qiyaAmika [I will not sit during the continuance of thy standing]; (Ṣ, TA;) [or as long as thou standest; or while thou standest; for] mA denotes time; and qumo maA daAma zayodN qaAYimFA means mud-apa qiyaAmi zayodK [i. e. Stand thou during the period of Zeyd's standing]. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) [And EalaI Ald-awaAmi means Continually, or constantly; like daAYimFA.]

Said of rain, it means It fell, or descended, consecutively, continuously, or constantly. (Mṣb.) Some say, (M,) daAmati Als-amaMCu, aor. tadiymN, inf. n. dayomN, (M, Ḳ,) which, if correct, should be included in art. dym, (M,) meaning The sky rained continually; as also daw-amat↓ and day-amat, (M, Ḳ,) in which last the w is changed into I as it is in diymapN, (M,) and AdAmt↓: (Ḳ:) or rained such rain as is termed diymap; (M in art. dym;) and so day-amat↓, inf. n. tadoyiymN; (Ṣ in art. dym;) and AdAmt↓. (Z, TA.) [See also dawomN, below.] IAar cites the following verse, (M, TA,) by Jahm Ibn-Shibl, (TA in this art.,) or Ibn-Sebel, (TA in art. sbl, in which, also, the verse is cited,) in praise of a horse, as is said in “the Book of Plants” of Ed-Deenäwaree, and in “the Book of Horses” of Ibn-El-Kelbee,
not, as J asserts it to be, in praise of a munificent man, (TA,)
huwa AljawaAdu bonu AljawaAdi boni sabalo
Uino day-amuwA↓ jaAda waUino jaAduwA wabalo
[He is the fleet, the son of the fleet, the son of Sebel (a famous mare): if they are unremitting in their running, (the masc. pl. being here used, though relating to horses, in like manner as it is used in the Ḳur xli. 20,) he is fleet; and if they are fleet, he is vehement in his running]: or, as some relate it, Uino daw-amuwA. (M, TA. [It should be observed that the three verbs in this verse, and the word sbl, also relate to rain.])

‡ It (a thing, T) was, or became, still, or motionless; said of water (T, Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA) left in a pool by a torrent, and of the boiling of a cooking-pot; (Mṣb;;) and said, in this sense, of the sea: (M:) and it stopped, or stood still. (T, TA.)
† He was, or became, tired, or fatigued: (T, TA:) [app. because he who is so stops to rest.]

† It (a thing) went round, revolved, or circled: (T, TA:) [app. because that which does so keeps near to one place.] dawamaAnN [an inf. n. of daAma like as HawamaAnN is of HaAma,] signifies ‡ The circling of a bird (Ḳ, TA) around water. (TA. [But in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, and in the CK, in the place of Ald-awamaAnu I find Ald-awamaMCu↓. See also 2.]) [Hence,] diyma bihi ‡ He was taken, or affected, with a vertigo, or giddiness in the head; as also Oudiyma↓ bihi, (M, TA,) and Ausotudiyma↓ [app., in like manner, followed by bihi]. (Z, TA.)
daAmati Ald-alowi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dawomN, (TA,) † The bucket became full: (Ḳ:) in this meaning, regard is had to the stagnant water [in the bucket]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. daw-amati Als-amaMCu, and day-amat: and day-amuwA said of horses: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places.

dw-mt AlkilaAbu The dogs went far: (Akh, IAạr, M, Ḳ:) or continued their course. (IAạr, M.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, (de scribing a wild bull, T, TA,)
Hat-aI UicaA daw-amato fiI AlOaroDi raAjaEahu
kiborN walawo XaMCa naj-aI nafosahu Alharabu
[Until, when they went far in the land, pride returned to him: but, had he pleased, flight had saved his blood: J, however, assigns to the verb in this instance another signification, as will be seen below]. (M, TA.)

dw-m said of a bird, (T, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadowiymN, (T, Ṣ,) ‡ It circled (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA) in the sky, (Lth, T, M, Ḳ,) as also tdAwm↓, (KL,) [or tadw-m↓, (see mutadaw-imaAtN,)] to rise high towards the sky; (Ṣ;) as also AstdAm↓: (M, Ḳ:) or circled in the sky, (M,) or flew, (T,* Ḳ,) without moving its wings; (T, M, Ḳ;) like the kite and the aquiline vulture: (T, TA:) or put itself into a state of commotion in its flying. (TA. [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.]) Dhu-r-Rummeh makes Alt-adowiym to be on the earth, or ground, in the verse cited above in this paragraph; [as though the meaning were, † Until, when they went round, &c.;] Aṣ disallows this, and asserts that one says only daw-aI fiI AlOaroDi, and daw-ama fiI Als-amaMCi; but some affirm that Alt-adowiymu fiI AlOaroDi is correct; and say that hence is de rived Ald-uw-aAmapu↓, meaning “the round thing [or top] which the boy throws, and makes to revolve, or spin, upon the ground, by means of a string;” though others say that this is so called from the phrase daw-amotu Alqidora [explained below], because, by reason of the quickness of its revolving, or spinning, it seems as though it were at rest: and tadowaAmN is like tadowiymN: some, however, say that tadowiymu Alkalobi signifies the dog's going far in flight: (Ṣ:) AHeyth says that, accord. to Aṣ, Alt-adowiymu is only the act of a bird in the sky: (T, TA:) AAF says that, accord. to some, Alt-adowiymu is in the sky, and Alt-adowiyapu is on the earth, or ground; but accord. to others, the reverse is the case; and this, he says, is the truth in his opinion. (M, TA. [See also daw-aIa in art. dwI.])

You say also, daw-amati, AlX-amosu, (M, Ḳ,) or dw-mt AlXms fI Als-amaACi, (T,) or fiIkabidi Als-amaMCi, (Ṣ,) i. e. daArato fiI Als-amaMCi [or dArt fI kbd AlsmAC, lit. ‡ The sun spun in the sky, or in the middle of the sky; meaning, was as though it were spinning]; (T, M, Ḳ;) or was as though it were motionless [&c.]: (T, Ṣ:) and hence is [said to be] derived the word duw-aAmapN↓ applied to the boy's revolving, or spinning, thing. (T.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, (describing the [insect called] junodab, [generally said to be a species of locust,] TA in art. rmD)
maEoraworiyFA ramaDa Alr-aDoraADi yarokuDuhu
waAlX-amosu HayoraI lahaA fiI Aljaw-i tadowiymu
(T,* Ṣ, TA) i. e. Venturing upon the [vehement] heat of the pebbles, [meaning the vehemently-hot pebbles,] striking them with its foot, for so the jndb does, (TA,) † when the sun is [apparently] stationary in the summer midday, [as though perplexed in its course,] as though having a spinning [in the region between heaven and earth]: (T, TA:) or as though it were motionless. (Ṣ.)
And one says, daw-amato Eayonuhu † [His eye rolled; i. e.] the black of his eye revolved as though it were in the whirl of a spindle. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.)

[dw-m is also trans.] You say, dw-m Ald-uw-aAmapa, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadowiymN, (TA,) † He made the dw-Amp [or top] to revolve, or spin [so as to seem to be at rest, as has been shown above]: (M, Ḳ:) or he played with the dw-Amp. (TA.)
And dw-mt Alxamoru XaAribahaA ‡ The wine intoxicated its drinker so as to make him turn round about. (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA.)
And daw-amuwA AlEamaAYima † They wound the turbans around their heads. (TA.)
And dw-m Almaraqapa † He put much grease into the broth so that it swam round upon it. (M, Ḳ.)
Alt-adowiymu [or app. tadowiymu All-isaAni] also signifies † The mumbling the tongue, and rolling it about in the mouth, in order that the saliva may not dry up: so says Fr. (Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence, app., as the context seems to indicate,] Dhu-r-Rummeh says, describing a camel braying in his XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag],
daw-ama fiyhaA riz-ahu waOaroEadaA
[as though meaning † He made his braying to roll, or rumble, in it, and threatened]. (Fr, Ṣ, TA.)

And dw-m signifies ‡ He moistened a thing. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) Ibn-Aḥmar says,
waqado yudaw-imu riyqa AlT-aAmiEi AlOamalu ; (Ṣ, M;) i. e. † [And hope sometimes, or often,] moistens the saliva [of the eager]: (Ṣ:) he is praising En-Noamán Ibn-Besheer, and means that his hope moistens his saliva in his mouth by making his eulogy to continue. (IB.)
‡ He mixed, or moistened, or steeped, (daAfa,) saffron, (Lth, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) and stirred it round in doing so: (Lth, T, TA:) he dissolved saffron in water, and stirred it round therein. (A, TA.)

dw-m Alqidora, and AdAmhA↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He stilled the boiling of the cooking-pot by means of some [cold] water: (Ṣ:) or he sprinkled cold water upon [the contents of] the cooking-pot to still its boiling: (M, Ḳ:) or the former, (Ḳ,) or both, (M,) he allayed the boiling of the cooking-pot by means of something, (M, Ḳ,) and stilled it: (M:) and the latter signifies he left the cooking-pot upon the OavaAfiI [or three stones that supported it], after it had been emptied, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) not putting it down nor kindling a fire beneath it. (Lḥ, M.)
3. dAwm EalaI AlOamori, and dAwm AlOamora: see 1.
See also 10.

4. AdAmhu, (inf. n. UidaAmapN, TA,) trans. of daAma; (Ṣ, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) [i. e.] i. q. jaEalahu daAYimFA [He made it to continue, last, endure, or remain: to be extended, or prolonged: to continue, last, endure, or remain, long: and to continue, last, or exist, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; to be permanent, perpetual, or everlasting]: (TḲ:) he did it continually, or perpetually: (MA:) he had it continually, or perpetually. (MA, KL.) [Accord. to Golius, followed in this case by Freytag, tdAwm↓ signifies Perennitate donavit; a signification app. given by Golius as on the authority of the KL; but not in my copy of that work.]
AdAm Alqidora: see 2, last sentence.
AdAm Ald-alowa † He filled the bucket. (Ḳ, TA.)

AlUidaAmapN also signifies tanoqiyru Als-ahomi EalaI AlUibohaAmi [i. e. The trying the sonorific quality of the arrow by turning it round upon the thumb: or, as explained in this art. in the TḲ, the making the arrow to produce a sharp sound upon the thumb: or rather this or the former is the meaning of UidaAmapu Als-ahomi; for, as is said in the TḲ, AdAm Als-ahoma signifies nqrh ElI AlAbhAm (i. e. nq-rhu)]. (T, Ḳ.)
AdAmt Als-amaMCu: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.
Oudiyma bihi: see 1, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: 5: see 2:
and see also 10.
6: see 2:
and see also 4.

hom.sense: 10. AstdAm: see 1.
And see also 2.
And Ausotudiyma: see 1, last sentence but one.

As a trans. v., (T,) i. q. AinotaZara, (Sb, T, TA,) as also tdw-m↓, (Ḳ, [or this may perhaps be used only without an objective complement expressed,]) and raqaba, (T,) or taraq-aba: (Sh, TA:) you say, Aisotadimo kacaA, meaning AinotaZirohu and Auroqubohu † [Look thou for, expect, await, wait for, or watch for, such a thing.] (T.)
[When no objective complement is expressed, it seems to mean † He paused, and acted with deliberation, or in a patient or leisurely manner, or he waited in expectation; app. from the same verb as syn. with daw-ama; and thus, like one who hovers about a thing: see Haw-ama; and see also AinotaZara.] And AstdAmhu ‡ He acted with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely, in it; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) namely, an affair, or a case: (Ṣ:) or he sought, desired, asked, or demanded, its continuance, or long continuance, or endless continuance: and so dAwmhu↓ (M, Ḳ, TA) in both of these senses: (Ḳ, TA:) or he asked him to render a thing continual, &c.: (Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and also † he acted gently and deliberately in it; namely, an affair, or a case: (Mṣb:) and † he acted gently with him; (Fr, T in art. dym, M, Mṣb, Ḳṭ;) i. e., another person, (Mṣb,) or his creditor; as also AisotadomaAhu, (Fr, T, M, Ḳ,) which we judge to be formed from the former by transposition, because we do not find it [in this sense] to have any inf. n. (M.) A poet says, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) namely, Keys Ibn-Zuheyr, (Ṣ,)
falaA taEojalo biOamorika waQsotadimohu
famaA Sal-aI EaSaAka kamusotadiymi↓ , (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) i. e. † [Therefore haste not in thine affair, but act with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely, therein]; for no one has straitenedstraightened thy staff by turning it round over the fire, (T,) meaning, no one has managed thine affair soundly, like one who acts with moderation,, &c. (T, Mṣb.) And another says, (Ṣ,) namely, Mejnoon, (TA,)
waUin-aI EalaI layolaI lazaArK waUin-aniI
EalaIcaAka fiymaA bayonanaA OasotadiymuhaA
meaning † [And verily I am blaming Leylà; and verily, notwithstanding that,] I look for her aiding me by good conduct [in the matter that is between us]. (Ṣ.) You say also, Oasotadiymu Qll-eha niEomataka I seek, or desire, or ask, of God the continuance, or long continuance, or endless continuance, of thy favour, or the like. (Mgh, TA.*) And Oasotadiymu Qll-eha Eiz-aka I ask God to continue, or continue long,, &c., thy might, or power,, &c. (Mṣb.) The phrase AstdAm lubosa Alv-awobi, meaning [He continued long the wearing of the garment, or] he did not hasten to pull off the garment, may be from the saying Aisotadamotu EaAqibapa AlOamori, meaning I looked, or watched, or waited, for the end, or issue, or result, of the affair, or case. (Mṣb.)
Also He (a man) stooped his head, blood dropping from it: formed by transposition from AisotadomaI (Kr, TA.)
dawomN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also daAYimN, in two places.

Also [The cucifera Thebaïca; (Delile, “Floræ Ægypt. Illustr.,” no. 941;) or Theban Palm; so called because abundant in the Thebaïs; a species of fan-palm; by some called gingerbread: accord. to Forskål, (under the heading of “Flora Arabiæ Felicis,” in his “Flora Ægypt. Arab.,” p. cxxvi.,) Borassus flabelliformis; a name applied (after him) by Sonnini to the Theban palm; but now generally used by botanists to designate another species of fan-palm:] the tree of the muqol; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a well-known kind of tree, of which the fruit is [called] the muqol: (TA:) n. un. with p {dawomapN}: AḤn says that the dawomap [is a tree that] becomes thick and tall, and has [leaves of the kind termed] xuwS, like the xwS of the date-palm, and racemes like the racemes of a date-palm. (M, TA.) Accord. to Aboo-Ziyád El-Aạrábee, (AḤn, M,) The nabiq [which properly signifies the fruit of the sidor, but here app. means, as it does in the present day, the tree called sidor, a species of lote-tree, called by Linn. rhamnus spina Christi, and by Forskal rhamnus nabeca,] is also thus called, (AḤn, M, Ḳ,) by some of the Arabs: accord. to 'Omárah, great [trees of the kind termed] sidor: (AḤn, M:) and, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to IAạr, (M,) big trees of any kind. (M, Ḳ.) [See also dawomapN, below.]

entry.sense: dayomN, whence the saying maA zaAlati Als-amaMCu dayomFA dayomFA: see dawomN.
diyomN: see diymapN.
dawomapN n. un. of dawomN. (M, TA.) [Also, app., as in the present day, and as appears from what follows, A single fruit of the tree called dawom.]
And † A testicle; (Ḳ;) as being likened to the fruit of the dawom. (TA.)

[Golius also explains it, as on the authority of the Ḳ, as meaning “Ebriosa mulier;” and Freytag, as meaning “mulier vinum vendens:” both are wrong: it is mentioned in the Ḳ as the name of a woman who sold wine.]

diymapN A lasting, or continuous, and still rain: (Aṣ, M, and TA voce DarobN, q. v.:) or rain in which is neither thunder nor lightning; the least of which is the third of a day or the third of a night; and the most thereof, of any period: (AZ, Ṣ in art. dym:) or rain that continues some days: (Mṣb:) or rain that continues long and is still, without thunder and lightning: (Ḳ,* TA:) or rain that continues five days, or six, (M, Ḳ,) or seven, (Ḳ,) or a day and a night, (T in art. dym, M, Ḳ,) or more; (T, TA;) or the least whereof is a third of a day or of a night; and the most thereof, of any period: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. diyamN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the w being changed [into I] in the pl. because it is changed in the sing., (M,) and duyuwmN, (Abu-l-ʼOmeythil, T, Ḳ,) and [coll. gen. n.] diyomN↓ (Sh, T, TA.) [See also mudaAmN.]

Hence other things are thus termed by way of comparison. (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad. (Ṣ, M) of ʼÁïsheh, (M,) kaAna Eamaluhu diymapF (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) † His work was incessant [but moderate, or not excessive]; (Mṣb;) referring to Moḥammad; (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb;) on her being asked if he preferred some days to others: (T:) she likened it to the rain termed dymp in respect of continuance and moderation. (T, M.) And it is related of Hudheyfeh that he said, mentioning fitan [i. e. trials, or probations, or conflicts and factions, &c.], Uin-ahaA laMtiyatukumo diymFA diymFA, meaning † [Verily they are coming to you] filling the earth, or land, [and] with continuance. (T.)

daAmaMCu (in the CK [erroneously] daOomACu) The sea, or a great river; syn. baHorN; (M, Ḳ;) because of the continuance of its water: (M:) originally dawamaMCu, or dawomaMCu: if the latter, the change of the w into A is anomalous. (TA.)
Ald-awamaMCu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense: dayomuwmN and dayomuwmapN, held by Aboo-ʼAlee to be from Ald-awaAmu, and therefore to belong to the present art.: (TA:) see art. dm.
The latter is also an inf. n. of daAma [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: duwaAmN ‡ A vertigo, or giddiness in the head; i. q. duwaArN (Ṣ,* M,* Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, dawACN is erroneously put for duwaArN.]) You say, Oaxacahu duwaAmN ‡ [A vertigo took him, or attacked him]. (Ṣ.) And bihi duwaAmN ‡ [He has a vertigo]. (Aṣ, TA.)
duw-aAmN: see what next follows.

duw-aAmapN † The falokap [or round thing, i. e. top,] which the boy throws, and makes to revolve, or spin, upon the ground, by means of a string: (Ṣ, M,* Ḳ:*) the derivation of the word has been explained above: see 2, in two places: (T, Ṣ:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] duw-aAmN↓. (M, Ḳ.)
duw-aAmapu AlbaHori † [The whirlpool of the sea; so in the present day;] the middle of the sea, upon which the waves circle (tdwm [i. e. tudaw-im]). (TA.)

daAYimN [Continuing, lasting, enduring, or remaining: being extended or prolonged: (see 1, first sentence:)] continuing, lasting, enduring, or remaining, long: (TA:) [and continuing, lasting, or existing, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; permanent, perpetual, or everlasting: (see, again, 1, first sentence:)] and dawomN↓ signifies the same as daAYimN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) applied to shade; (Ṣ, M;) being an inf. n. used as an epithet: (M:) and day-uwmN↓, also, (M, Ḳ,) [of the measure fayoEuwlN, originally dayowuwimN,] like qay-uwmN, (M,) signifies the same as dAYmN [app. in the last of the senses explained above; being of a form proper to intensive epithets]: (M, Ḳ:) Lakeet Ibn-Zurárah says,
Xat-aAna hecaA waAlEinaAqu waAln-awomN
waAlmaXorabu AlbaAridu waAlZ-il-u Ald-awomo
[Different, or widely different, are this and embracing and sleeping and the cool drinkingplace and the continual shade]. (IB, TA.) And the Jews are related, in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, to have said [to the Muslims], Ealayokumo Als-aAmu Ald-aAmu↓, meaning Almawotu Ald-aAYimu, [i. e. May everlasting death come upon you; saying Als-aAmu in the place of Als-alaAmu, and] suppressing the I [or rather the hemzeh] because of [their desire to assimilate AldAYm to] AlsAm. (TA.) [Hence daAYimFA meaning Continually: and always, or for ever.]
Also ‡ Still, or motionless; said, in this sense, of water; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and so dawomN↓. (M, TA.)

It is also said of that which is in motion, [as signifying † Going round, revolving, or circling, (see 1,)] as well as of that which is still, or motionless; thus having two contr. meanings: so says Aboo-Bekr. (TA.)

[Hence,] maraqapN↓ daAwimapN † [Broth into which is put much grease so that this swims round upon it]: which is extr., because the w in this instance should by rule be changed into a hemzeh. (M. [The meaning is there indicated by the mention of this phrase immediately after daw-ama Almaraqapa, q. v.])
maraqapN daAwimapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
day-uwmN: see daAYimN, first sentence.
Oadowamu [More, and most, continual, lasting,, &c.] You say, huwa Oadowamu mino kacaA [It is more continual, or lasting,, &c., than such a thing]: from Ald-awaAmu. (IJ, M.)
mudaAmN Continual, or lasting, rain. (IJ, M, Ḳ.) [See also diymapN, above.]

And Wine; as also mudaAmapN↓: (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so called because it is made to continue for a time (T, M) in the dan-, (T,) or in its receptacle, (M,) until it becomes still after fermenting: (T:) or because, by reason of its abundance, it does not become exhausted: (Sh, T:) or because of its oldness: (AO, T:) or because it is the only beverage of which the drinking can be long continued: (M, Ḳ:) or because the drinking thereof is continued for days, to the exclusion of other beverages. (A, TA.)
mudaAmapN: see what next precedes.
midowamN and midowaAmN↓ A stick, or piece of wood, (M, Ḳ,) or some other thing, (M,) with which one stills the boiling of the cooking-pot. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ.)

OaroDN madiymapN, (Yz, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, mudiymapN,]) and muday-amapN↓, (M, TA,) Land upon which have fallen rains such as are termed diyimN [pl. of diymapN]. (Yz,* Ṣ,* M, Ḳ,* TA.)
mudiymN i. q. raAEifN (Ṣ, Ḳ) [Having blood flowing from his nose: or, accord. to the PṢ and TḲ as meaning having a continual bleeding of the nose].
OaroDN muday-amapN: see madiymapN.
midowaAmN: see midowamN.

mutadaw-imaAtN, applied to birds, means Going round, or circling, over a thing: and this is meant by mutadaAwimaAt↓, which is used for the former word, in the saying [of a rájiz], describing horses,
kaAlT-ayori taboqiI mutadaAwimaAtihaA
i. e. Like birds when thou lookest at, or watchest, those of them that are going round, or circling, over a thing: (Ṣ, TA:*) or mtdw-mAt signifies waiting, or watching. (TA.)
mutadaAwmaAtN: see what next precedes.
musotadiymN: see 10. Accord. to Sh, (TA,) it signifies † Exceeding the usual bounds in an affair; striving, or labouring, therein; or taking pains, or extraordinary pains, therein. (T, TA.)

1. daAna, aor. yaduwnu, inf. n. dawonN; and Oudiyna↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UidaAnapN; (Ṣ;) He, or it, was, or became, such as is termed duwnN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e.] low, base, vile,, &c.: or weak: (Ḳ:) mentioned by Er-Rághib on the authority of IḲt: (TA:) so say some: but accord. to others, duwnN has no verb. (Ṣ, TA.) lamo yaduno, (as in my copies of the Ṣ,) or lm yudano, (as in the TA,) at the end of a verse of 'Adee, as some relate it, [perhaps the only authority for these two verbs,] is accord. to others lm ydan-o, from dan-aI meaning “he, or it, was, or became, weak.” (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

2. dw-n Ald-aywaAna, (inf. n. tadowiynN, TA,) He wrote, composed, or drew up, the register [&c.]. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.*) And dw-n Ald-awaAwiyna He instituted, appointed, or arranged, the registers for the prefects, or administrators, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and the Kádees, (Mgh,) or others: (Mṣb:) said of ʼOmar; who is related to have been the first that did this, (Mgh, Mṣb,) among the Arabs. (Mṣb.) And dw-n Alkutuba He collected the writings. (Mgh.) [And dw-n XiEora fulaAnK He collected the poetry of such a one.] And tadowiynN signifies also The writing [a person's name, &c.] in a diywaAn [or register]. (KL.) You say, dw-nhu He wrote it [in a register]. (MA.) [And He registered him.]

hom.sense: 4. Oudiyna, inf. n. UidaAnapN: see 1.
maA Oadowanahu [as meaning How low, base, vile,, &c., is he, or it!] is [asserted to be] a phrase not used, (Aṣ, T, Ḳ, TA,) because [it is said that] duwnN has no verb. (Aṣ, T, TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tdw-n He was, or became, in a state of complete richness, wealth, or competence. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.) [See also tcw-n. Perhaps both are correct, as dial. vars.]

duwnF Low, base, vile, mean, paltry, inconsiderable, or contemptible; (Fr, T, Ṣ, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a man, &c.: (T, Mṣb:) and inferior, i. e. lower, baser, viler,, &c., in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [or in any approvable quality]: (Lth, T:) and such as falls short [of a thing]; used in this sense as a prefixed noun: (Ḥam p. 686:) [see below what is said of its usage as a prefixed noun by Lth and by Sb: and used as an epithet, scanty, or deficient; applied to anything:] and of a middling sort; between good and bad; applied to a man and to a commodity: (M:) and also high, or eminent, in rank or condition; noble, or honourable: (T, Ḳ:) thus it bears two contr. significations (Ḳ) [and significations intermediate between those two]. A poet says,
UicaA maA EalaA AlmaroCu raAma AlEalaMC
wayaqotaEu biAld-uwni mano kaAnaA duwnaA
[When the man is high in rank, or nobility, he seeks highness: and he who is low is content with that which is low]. (Ṣ.) Accord. to the most common usage, (Mṣb,) or accord. to what is asserted to be the most common usage, (Lḥ, M,) one says rajulN mino duwnK (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and XaIoCN mino duwnK (M, Mṣb) A man who is [of a kind that is] low, base,, &c., and a thing that is [of a kind that is] low, base,, &c.: (Mṣb:) but sometimes they said rajulN duwnN and XaIoCN duwnN, without mino; (M, Mṣb;) and vawobN duwnN a bad [or an inferior] garment, or piece of cloth: (M:) or one should not say rajulN duwnN; (T, Ḳ;) for the Arabs did not use this phrase. (T.) Accord. to Lth, one says, hecaA duwnu caAka [This is the inferior of that], when meaning to denote by it low estimation, using the nom. case: (T:) [but this is uncommon, if allowable:] Sb says that duwn is not used in the nom. case as a prefixed noun: as to the saying in the Ḳur [lxxii. 11, an instance similar to which occurs also in vii. 167], min-aA AlS-aAliHuwna wamin-aA duwna celika, the meaning is, wamin-aA qawomN duwna celika [i. e. Of us are the righteous, and of us are a party below that party in rank or estimation]; (M, TA;) or, as another says, dwn is here in the accus. case but in the place of a noun in the nom. case because it is generally used as an adv. n. (TA.)

As an adv. n., duwn signifies Below, contr. of fawoq; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as denoting a falling short of the [right or approved] limit; (Ṣ;) or denoting low, or mean, estimation or condition; (Lth, T, M;) or a condition lower, baser, viler,, &c., than that of another, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [or in any approvable quality]; (Lth, T;) [and hence, inferior to, beneath, under, or short of, another in rank, height, size,, &c.;] and less than another, and more deficient than another: (Fr, T:) and also above; i. q. fawoq; (T, Ḳ;) in highness, or eminence, of rank or condition, or in nobility; (T;) [and hence, exceeding another, and more than another:] thus bearing two contr. significations. (Ḳ.) You say, zayodN duwnaka meaning Zeyd is [below thee, or] in a condition lower, baser, viler,, &c., than thine, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour [&c.]: and when one says, “Verily such a one is high, or eminent, in rank or condition,” or “is noble,” another replies, waduwna celika meaning And above that. (T.)

Also Beneath, below in situation, or under; syn. taHot. (T, TA.) Using it in this sense, you say, duwan qadamika xad-u Eaduw-ika [May the cheek of thine enemy be beneath thy foot]: (T, TA:) and jalasa duwnahu [He sat below him]. (TA.)

Also Before in respect of place, or in front: and [the contr., namely,] behind, or beyond. (T, M, Ḳ.) [You may say, using it in the former sense, jalasa duwnahu He sat before him, or in front of him: (see Ḥam p. 86:) and, using it in the latter sense,] you say, hecaA OamiyrN EalaI maA duwna jayoHuwna This [man] is governor, or prince, over what is beyond [the river] Jeyhoon. (TA.)

And i. q. qabol [generally signifying Before in respect of time; but as some say, in respect of place also, which may perhaps be here meant]: (T:) and [the contr., namely,] i. q. baEod [generally meaning after in respect of time; but as some say, in respect of place also, which may perhaps be here meant]. (Fr, T, TA.)

It signifies also Nearer than another thing: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so in the phrase hecaA duwna celika [This is nearer than that]; (Ṣ Mṣb;) or hecaA duwnahu [this is nearer than he, or it]. (Ḳ.) [Hence,] one says also, Audonu duwnaka meaning Draw thou near in the space that is between me and thee: (AHeyth, T:) [or approach thou nearer to me:] or draw thou near [or nearer] to me. (IAạr, T, M, Ḳ.) And yaziydu baguD-u AlT-arofa duwniI, a saying of a poet, means Yezeed lowers the eye towards a spot between me and him. (AHeyth, T.) [xaXaEato duwnahu AlOaboSaAru, also, has a similar meaning: see 1 in art. xXE. So, too, has the phrase, xaAwata Tarofahu duwniI: see 3 in art. xwt. And hence,] one says, duwna Aln-ahori jamaAEapN [In the way of, or to, the river, or on this side of the river, or nearer than the river, is a company of men; or] before thy reaching the river [there is to be found, or encountered, a company of men]. (Ḳ.) And duwna qatoli AlOasadi OahowaAlN [In the way of, or to, the slaying of the lion, or] before thine attaining to the slaying of the lion, terrors [are to be encountered]. (T, TA.) [And duwnahu xaroTu AlqataAdi: see 1 in art. xrT.] And HaAla duwna AlX-aIoCi [It intervened as an obstacle in the way to the thing; or] it prevented from attaining the thing. (W p. 71.) [And layosa duwnahu XaIoCN There is nothing intervening as an obstacle in the way of, or to, him, or it.] And [hence,] qutila duwna maAlihi, and nafosihi, and Oaxiyhi, and jaArihi, He was slain in defence of his property, and of himself, and of his brother, and of his neighbour. (Occurring in a trad. commencing with the words Algariyqu XahiydN, in the “Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer,” and thus explained in the margin of a copy of that work.) [And nabaHa duwnahu is a modern phrase meaning † He defended him as though by barking in the way to him.]
[Hence,] also i. q. EalaI [as meaning Against; denoting defence by means of intervention: see an ex. in a verse cited voce XaxoSN]. (Fr, T, TA.)

And i. q. Einoda [meaning At, near, nigh, by, or near by; with, or present with;, &c.]. (Fr, T, Ibn-Es-Seed.) Accord. to Ez-Zowzanee, it has this meaning in the saying of Imra-el-Ḳeys, [describing a horse,]
faOaloHaqanaA biAlhaAdiyaAti waduwnahu
jawaAHiruhaA fiI Sar-apK lamo tuzay-ali , (TA, but only the former hemistich is there given,) i. e. And he made us to overtake the foremost of the wild animals, while near to him were those that lagged behind, in a herd, not dispersed. (EM p. 48.)

And i. q. gayor [as meaning Other than, beside, or besides, exclusively of, or not as used before a substantive or an adjective]. (Ḳ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxi. 82], wayaEomaluwna EamalFA duwna celika [And who should do work other than, or beside, that]. (Fr, TA.) And in the same [iv. 51 and 116], wayagofiru maA duwna celika But He will forgive what is other than that: or, as some say, what is less than that. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And so, it is said, in the trad., layosa fiymaA duwna xamosi OawaAqK SadaqapN [There is no poor-rate to be exacted in the case of what is other than, or not, or, rather less than, five ounces]. (Ḳ.) So, too, it is said to mean in the trad., OajaAza AlxuloEa duwna EiqaASi raOosihaA [He allowed the divorcing a wife for a gift, or compensation, other than the EiqaAS (q. v.) of her head: in the CK, in which AlxaloEu is erroneously put for AlxuloEa, this is given as an ex. of cuwna in the sense of sawiI, which is syn. with gayor]: or the meaning is, for anything, even for the EqAS of her head. (Ḳ, TA.)

It is also used (M, Ḳ, TA) as a subst. (M, TA) with mino prefixed to it, [very often in this case, in the Ḳur and elsewhere, as meaning gayor and sometimes in other senses explained above,] and likewise with bi (M, Ḳ, TA,) though rarely. (Ḳ.) One says, hecaA duwnaka and hecaA mino duwnika [This is below thee, or above thee:, &c.]. (M, TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur [xxviii. 23], wawajada mino duwnihimu QmoraOatayoni (M, TA) And he found in a place below them two women: (Bḍ:) or beside them, or exclusively of them. (Jel.) One says also, hedaA liIduwna laka or mino duwnika [meaning This belongs to me exclusively of thee]; i. e. thou hast no right nor share [with me] in this. (Kull p. 186.) The phrase fiyhimo mano layosa biduwnihi [app. as meaning Among whom was such as was not below him in respect of knowledge of poetry] is used by Akh in his book on rhymes. (M, TA.)

It also denotes a command, (T, Ḳ,) and an incitement (Fr, T, Ṣ, Ḳ) to do a thing. (Ṣ.) Using it in the former sense, you say, duwnaka Ald-irohama, meaning Take thou the dirhem; (T;) or duwnaka AlX-aIoCa and duwnaka biAlX-aIoCi, meaning Take thou the thing: (M:) and using it in the latter sense, you say, duwnakahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) meaning Keep thou, cleave thou, cling thou, or hold thou fast, to him; and take care of him: (TA:) or dunaka zayodFA Keep thou,, &c., to Zeyd, taking care of him. (T.) Temeem [meaning a party of the tribe so named] said to El-Hajjáj, when he had slain, i. e. crucified, Sálih Ibn-ʼAbd-Er-Raḥmán, “Permit us to bury Sálih:” and he replied, duwnakumuwhu [Take ye him]. (Ṣ, TA.)

And it also denotes a threat. (T, Ḳ.) So in the sayings duwaka SiraAEiI [Beware thou of wrestling with me] and duwnaka fatamar-aso biI [Beware thou, and then set thyself against me to do evil if thou canst]. (T, TA.)
It is said that no verb is derived from it: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) but some assert that daAna and Oudiyna [mentioned in the first paragraph of this art.] are derived from it. (Ṣ.)

The dim. of duwna is duwayona↓: (Ḥam p. 404:) and duwayonapa↓ occurs as a dim. in a verse of a post-classical poet; but, [ISd says,] of what word I know not, unless they said duwnapa↓ [for duwna]. (M.)
duwnapa: see the next preceding sentence.
duwayona: see the next preceding sentence.
duwayonapa: see the next preceding sentence.
dayowaAnN: see the next paragraph.

diywaAnN, an arabicized word, (AO, M, Mṣb, &c.,) from the Pers. [diywaAno]; (AO, M, &c.;) [though some hold it to be of Arabic origin:] J says, (TA,) it is originally diw-aAnN, but I is substituted for one of the w s; as is shown by its pl., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) which is dawaAwiynu; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) for if the I were radical, they would say dayaAwiynu; (Ṣ;) but accord. to IDrd and IJ, (IB, TA,) it has this latter pl. also: (M, IB, Ḳ, TA:) Sb says that the w in diywaAnN, though after I, is not changed into I, as it is in say-idN, because the I in the former word is not inherent; that word being of the measure fiE-aAlN, from daw-anota; (M;) [i. e.] it is from daw-ana Alkutuba meaning “he collected the writings;” as is shown by their saying duwayowiynN↓, (M,) which is the dim.: (Mṣb:) ISk says that dywAn is with kesr only [to the d]; (M;) but one says dayowaAnN↓ also, (Ḳ,) which is mentioned by Ks, as post-classical, and by Sb; like bayoTaArN: (M:) the meaning is A dafotar [or register]: (Shifá el-Ghaleel, TA:) or a collection of written leaves or papers [forming a book, generally for registration]: (ISk, M, Mgh,* Ḳ:) or a register of accounts; an accountbook: (Mṣb:) and a register of soldiers and pensioners [and others]: (IAth, Ḳ:) the first who instituted, or appointed, or arranged, such a book, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) among the Arabs, (Mṣb,) for the prefects, or administrators, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and the Kádees, (Mgh,) is said to have been ʼOmar: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) accord. to El-Máwardee, it is a register of what concerns the rights, or dues, of the state, relating to the acts of the government, and the finances, and the military and other administrators thereof: (TA:) then any book was thus called: and especially the poetry of some particular poet: so that this meaning became [conventionally regarded as] a proper signification thereof; (Shifá el-Ghaleel, TA;) i. e. a collection of poetry [of a particular poet]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN mino Oaholi Ald-iywaAni, meaning Such a one is of those whose names are written in the register. (Mgh.) [Also Such a one is of the keepers of the register; or, is of the registrars. (And sometimes it has another meaning, which see below.) And hence the saying] AlX-iEoru diywaAnu AlEarabi † [Poetry is the register of the Arabs]: because they used to refer to it on their differing in opinion respecting genealogies and wars or fights and the appointing of stipends or allowances from the government-treasury, like as the people of the dywAn [properly so called] refer to their dywAn in a case that is doubtful to them; or because it was the depository of their sciences, and the preserver of their rules of discipline, and the mine of their histories. (Ḥar p. 263.)
Afterwards, also, it was applied to signify An account, or a reckoning. (Mṣb, TA.)
And Writers [of accounts or reckonings]. (TA.)
And A place of account or reckoning, (Mṣb, TA,) and of writers [of accounts or reckonings] (TA.)
[Also A council, court, or tribunal: see dasotN. Hence Oaholu Ald-iywaAni sometimes means The people of the council, court, or tribunal.]

[And also, in the present day, A long seat, formed of a mattress laid against the side of a room, upon the floor or upon a raised structure or frame, with cushions to lean against; or two or more of such mattresses, &c. similarly placed.]
dywaAniI-N Of, or belonging to, a diywaAn. (TA.)
duwayowiynN dim. of diywaAnN, q. v. (M,* Mṣb.)

Oadowanu is used by IJ in the phrase celika Oaqal-N AlOamorayoni waOadowanuhumaA [That is the lesser of the two affairs, or cases, and the lower, baser,, &c., of them]: but [ISd says that] this is strange, because [he held that], like OaHonaka, it has no verb belonging to it. (M.)

1. dawiIa, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yadowaI, (Mṣb,) inf. n. dawFI, He was, or became, diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and he was, or became, affected with consumption, or ulceration of the lungs. (M.)
[Hence,] dawiIa Sadoruhu † His bosom was, or became, affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 2. dw-I, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadowiyapN, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He, or it, made a sound; or what is termed dawiI-; (T, M;) [i. e., a confused and continued sound; such as the rustling, or murmuring, of the wind; and the rustling of a bird; and the humming, or buzzing, of bees; and the rumbling of thunder; or the distant sound of rain and of thunder;] accord. to some, particularly said of thunder [as meaning it made a rumbling sound]; (M;) or it (a cloud) thundered: (KL:) and he (a stallioncamel) brayed so as to make a [rumbling] sound such as is termed dawiI- to be heard. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[Also,] said of a bird, It circled in the air without moving its wings: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to Aṣ, one says of a dog, dw-I fiI AlOaroDi [he went round upon the ground]; like as one says of a bird, daw-ama fiI Als-amaMCi, meaning “it circled in its flight, rising:” he says that Alt-adowiymu is not upon the ground, nor Alt-adowiyapu in the sky; and he finds fault with the first of the verses of Dhu-r-Rummeh cited in the second paragraph of art. dwm: but some say that the two verbs are dial. vars., both meaning he went round about. (Ṣ. [See also daw-ama, in two places.])
See also 2 in art. dw.

Also, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and the like, (Ḳ,) and of broth, (T, Ṣ, M,) It was, or became, overspread with the thin skin termed dawaAyapN. (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) And, said of water, It was, or became, overspread with what was raised and scattered by the wind, (M, Ḳ,) resembling what is termed duwaAyap. (M.)
And [hence,] daw-ati AlOaroDu † The land became overspread with various herbage; as though it were the duwaAyap of milk. (T.)
daw-ayotuhu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) I gave him the duwaAyap of milk, (M, Ḳ,) or of broth, to eat it. (M.)
And dw-I He sold [and app. made also (see mudaw-K)] what is called dawaAp. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. daAwayotuhu, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. mudaAwaApN (T, Ṣ, Mṣb) and diwaMCN, (T, Ṣ,) the latter allowable, (T,) I treated him medically, curatively, or therapeutically; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) I cured him [mino maraDihi of his disease]; (T;) biAld-awaMCi [with the remedy]: (M, Ḳ:) and I tended him carefully, or treated him; syn. EaAnayotuhu; (Ḳ, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, EaAyanotuhu;]) namely, AlmariyDa [the sick person]. (M,* TA.) You say, huwa yudowiIwayudaAwiI: see 4. And, of a person, (T,) or thing, (Ṣ,) duwwiIa, without idghám, to distinguish between the measures fuwEila and fuE-ila; (T, Ṣ;) meaning [He or] it was treated medically,, &c.: (Ṣ:) and duwwiIa biOadowiyapK [referring to hair] It was treated (EuwniIa) with remedies, such as oils and the like. (M.)

And dAwI farasahu, inf. n. diwaMCN, with kesr to the d, He fattened his horse, and fed him with fodder that showed its effect upon him: (T:) or daAwayotu Alfarasa I tended the horse well; or took good care of him. (M.) [See also dawaMCN.]

hom.sense: 4. AdwAhu i. q. OamoraDahu [which signifies He rendered him diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill: and also he found him to be so]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, huwa yudowiI wayudaAwiI↓ [He renders, or finds one to be, diseased,, &c., and treats medically,, &c., or cures]. (Ṣ.)
And † He suspected him; thought evil of him; a dial. var. of OadowaOahu. (AZ, TA.)
And AdwI He became a companion to a sick person. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tdAwI bidawaMCK, (Mṣb,) or biAlX-aIoCi (Ṣ,) He treated himself medically, curatively, or therapeutically, [or he cured himself, with a remedy, or] with the thing. (Ṣ.)
8. Aid-awayotu I ate the thin skin, termed duwaAyap, upon milk [or broth]: (Ṣ:) or Aid-awaI Ald-uwaAyapa He took and ate the dwAyp. (M, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: dawFI Disease, disorder, distemper, sickness, illness, or malady: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and consumption, or ulceration of the lungs: (M:) or internal disease in the chest; whereas daMCN signifies such as is external or internal. (Lth, T.) [Being properly an inf. n., it is app. used alike as sing. and pl. in all its senses: or it may, when signifying as explained above, have for its pl. OadowaMCN, which is pl. of daMCN.]
See also dawK, below, in three places.
Also Foolish; stupid; or unsound, dull, or deficient, in intellect; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) applied to a man. (Ṣ.)
And (so applied, TA) Cleaving to his place; (M, Ḳ;) not quitting it. (M.)
See also dawaApN.

entry.sense: dawK and dawFI↓ (applied to a man, Ṣ) Diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill: (T, M, Ḳ:) or whose jawof [i. e. chest, or belly,] is in a bad, or corrupt, state, by reason of a disease: (Ṣ:) the former word has a dual form and a pl., [which is dawuwna,] and a fem., (M,) which is dawiyapN: (Ṣ:) but dawFI↓ is used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. (Ṣ, M) and dual (M) and pl., (Ṣ, M,) being originally an inf. n. (Ṣ.) A poet uses ↓the latter as meaning disordered, or ill, by reason of intense drowsiness. (M.)

[Hence,] one says, Uin-ahu ladawiI AlS-adori [meaning † Verily he is one whose bosom is affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: see 1, second sentence]: and a poet says,
waEayonuka tubodiI Oan-a Sadoraka liI dawiIo
[† And thine eye shows that thy bosom is affected with rancour towards me]. (Lth, T.)

hom.sense: dawaApN [vulgarly dawaAyap, An ink-bottle; and, more commonly, an inkhorn; i. e. a portable case with receptacles for ink and the instruments of writing, so formed as to be stuck in the girdle; the most usual king is figured in my work on the Modern Egyptians, ch. ix.;] a certain thing, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (M, Ḳ,) from which one [takes the ink and instruments with which he] writes: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. dawFI↓, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and duwiI-N, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is pl. of dawFI, (Ṣ, TA,) as also diwiI-N, (M, Ḳ,) and dawayaAtN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) which is applied to a number from three to ten [inclusive]. (Ṣ.)
Also The rind, or skin, of the colocynth, and of the grape, and of the melon; and so cawaApN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
dawaMCN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and diwaMCN↓ (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, said in the Mṣb to be a subst. from daAwayotuhu,) and duwaMCN↓, (M, Ḳ,) the last on the authority of El-Hejeree, and the first that which is commonly known, (TA,) A medicine; a remedy: (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. OadowiyapN. (T, Ṣ.) The following verse is related as presenting an ex. of the second of these dial. vars.:
yaquwluwna maxomuwrN wahecaA diwaAWuhu
EalaI-a Uicona maX-IN UilaI Albayoti waAjibN
[they say, “He is affected with the remains of intoxication;” and this is his remedy: on me, if the case be so, walking to the House of God is incumbent]: meaning that they said, “Flogging, and chastisement, is his diwMC:” but he says, “On me is incumbent a pilgrimage walking if I have drunk it:” but it is said [by some] that diwaMCN is only an inf. n. of daAwayotuhu , like mudaAwaApN. (Ṣ.)
dawaMCN also signifies Food. (M, TA.)
duwaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.
diwaMCN: see dawaMCN, in two places.

hom.sense:
dawiI-N A sound: (M:) or a confused and continued sound (HafiyfN); as [the rustling, or murmuring,] of the wind; and [the rustling] of a bird; and [the humming, or buzzing,] of bees: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the distant sound of rain and of thunder: (T:) or, as some say, particularly the [rumbling] sound of thunder: (M:)
[and a ringing in the ears; as in the saying] xalaA baToniImina AlT-aEaAmi Hat-aIsamiEotu diway-FA limasaAmiEiI [My belly became empty of food so that I heard a ringing in my ears]. (T.)
[It is also an epithet; whence] OaroDN daw-iyapN: see dawK, last sentence.

entry.sense: duwiI-N [an epithet; whence] OaroDN duwiy-apN: see dawK, last sentence.

duwaAyapN A thin skin, (Ṣ, M,) a substance that resembles the pellicle of the egg, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) that overspreads the surface of milk (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and of broth (Ṣ, M) and of [the kind of pottage called] hariysap (Lḥ, M, Ḳ) and the like (Ḳ) when the wind blows upon it; (Lḥ, M, Ḳ;) as also diwaAyapN↓. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
And in, or upon, the teeth, A greenness. (M, Ḳ.)
diwaAyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

dawaAtiI-N and dawawiI-N↓ (MA) and dAwI (TA [app. daAwiI-N↓]) The bearer of the dawaApN. (MA, TA.) [In recent times, the Pers. word dawiydaAro, or dawaAdaAro, has generally been used instead, as the appellation of a certain office-bearer in several Eastern courts, having different functions in different instances.]

hom.sense: dawawiI-N: see what next precedes:
and see also art. dw.

entry.sense: duwwiI-N: see art. dw.
daw-iI-N: see art. dw.
duw-iI-N: see art. dw.
daw-iy-apN: see art. dw.
daAwK Much, or abundant, food; as also mudaw-K↓. (M, Ḳ. [The latter word erroneously written in the CK mudowK.])

Milk having upon it what is termed duwaAyap, like the pellicle of the egg: (Ḳ, TA:) and water overspread with a slight coat [of particles blown upon it by the wind]; as also mudaw-K↓. (T.) And maraqapN daAwiyapN and mudaw-iyapN↓ A mess of broth having much grease [floating upon its surface]. (M.)
daAyapN, mentioned in this art. in the M and TA: see art. dOI.
daAwiI-N: see dawaAtiI-N.
daAwiyapN and daAwiy-apN: see art. dw.

hom.sense: mudaw-K, applied to clouds (saHaAbN, Ṣ, Ḳ), Thundering: (Ḳ:) or vehemently, or loudly, thundering, and in a state of commotion. (Ṣ.)
See also daAwK in three places.
[Hence,] OaroDN mudaw-iyapN † Land overspread with various herbage; as though it were the duwaAyap of milk: or having abundant herbage of which nothing has been eaten. (T.)
And OamorN mudaw-K † An affair that is [as though it were] covered: (Ḳ:) or an affair of which one knows not what is behind it; as though it were covered and concealed by a duwaAyap. (M.)
Also The maker, or manufacturer, of the dawaAp. (TA: but there written mdwiI.)

entry.sense: dayobuwc A garment, or piece of cloth, having a double woof; expl. by vawobN cuw niyrayoni: pl. dayaAbuwcN↓ [an anomalous form of pl.] and dayaAbiyc: (Kudot;:) or dayaAbuwcN↓ has this signification; expl. by vawobN yunosaju biYrayoni; [in form] as though [an irreg.] pl. or dayobuwcN, of the measure fayoEuwlN: (Ṣ, L:) an arabicized word, from the Persian duw buwc [or duw Puwd]: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:*) sometimes arabicized with an unpointed d [for its final letter]. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) [See niyrN.]
dayaAbuwcN: see above, in two places.
1. daAva, aor. yadiyvu, inf. n. dayovN, It (a thing) was, or became, soft, or supple; and easy: whence the term day-uwvN. (Mṣb.)

[And hence,] dAv, aor. as above, inf. n. diyaAvapN, † He was, or became, [a wittol, or tame cuckold; or] without jealousy, and regardless of shame: so in the Nawádir of Aboo-ʼAlee Zekereeyà Ibn-Hároon Ibn-Zekereeyà El-Hejeree: (TA:) and taday-uvN↓ signifies † the acting the part, or performing the office, [of a day-uwv, or wittol; or] of a pimp to one's own wife. (T, Ḳ.)

2. dy-vhu, [inf. n. tadoyiyvN,] He softened, or suppled, it; and made it easy. (Mṣb.) You say also, day-avatohu AlamaTaAriqu The instruments called mTArq softened, or suppled, it; namely, a thing. (M.)
‡ He made it (a road) even, smooth, or easy to walk or ride upon. (M, TA.)
† He smoothed it; namely, an affair. (M.)
† He broke, or trained, him, namely, a camel, in some measure [so as to subdue his refractoriness]. (M.)
And in like manner, [He prepared it in some measure; namely,] a skin in the tan, or tanning-liquid: and a spear in the viqaAf [or straitening-instrument]. (M.)

† He subdued him; or rendered him submissive, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and gentle; namely, a man. (M.) duy-ava biAlS-agaAri occurs in a trad. as meaning † cul-ila [i. e. He was subdued, or rendered submissive, by abasement, or by tyranny, oppression, or injury]. (TA.)
And † It (time, or fortune,) tried him, or proved him, and rendered him experienced, and submissive. (M.)
5: see 1.

hom.sense: diyaAvapN † The act, or conduct, of the day-uwv [or wittol,, &c.]. (Mṣb.) [See also daAva, of which, in the sense assigned to it in the second sentence in this art., it is said to be the inf. n.]
It is also said to signify A distortion in the tongue: so in the Nh: or, as some say, the word in this sense is divaAvapN. (TA.)

entry.sense: day-uwvN, (written by some dayuwvN, without teshdeed, which is strange, TA,) a word of wellknown meaning, (Ḳ,) † [A wittol, or tame cuckold;] one to whose wife another man comes with his [the husband's] knowledge: (Th, M:) or one to whose wife other men go in so that he sees them; as though he had softened, or suppled, [or tamed,] himself to endure this: (M:) or one who is not jealous of him who goes in to his wife: (Mgh:) or a pimp to his own wife: (T:) or one who is not jealous of his wife: (T, Mṣb:) or i. q. qunocuEN; i. e. one who has no jealousy: (Ṣ:) or a submissive, compliant, man, without jealousy: (A:) said to be an arabicized word from the Syriac: or from mudiy-avN as an epithet applied to a camel, explained below; and if so, tropical: (TA:) or from daAva [q. v.]. (Mṣb.)
muday-avN † A camel broken, or trained, so that his refractoriness is subdued: (T:) or ‡ broken, or trained, but not thoroughly. (A.)
‡ A road beaten, or trodden, (Ṣ, A, TA,) and made even, or easy to walk or ride upon: (Ṣ, TA:) or that has been travelled until it has become plain, or conspicuous. (T, TA.)
2. dy-x, inf. n. tadoyiyxN: see 2 in art. dwx, in two places.
2. dy-d: see 1 in art. dwd.
dayodN: see dadanN.
dayadaAnN: see dadanN.
5. tdy-r: see art. dwr.
dayorN: see art. dwr.
dayoraAniI-N: see art. dwr.
day-irN: see art. dwr.
day-irapN: see art. dwr.
day-aArN: see art. dwr.
day-uwrN: see art. dwr.

1. daASa, aor. yadiySu, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. dayaSaAnN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and dayoSN, (M,) He, or it, declined; turned aside, or from the right course or direction; syn. zaAga, (M, Ḳ, TA,) in the copies of the Ṣ, [and in the CK, and in a copy of the A,] raAga, with raMCa [instead of zAI], (TA,) and HaAda: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) he deviated from the road. (M, TA.)
He (a man, M) fled (M, Ḳ) from war, or battle. (Ḳ.)

It (anything) moved about beneath one's hand. (M, Ḳ.) You say, daASati Als-aloEapu, (Ṣ, A,) or Algud-apu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which is the same, (Ṣ,) inf. ns. as above, (M,) The ganglion wabbled, or moved to and fro, or went and came, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) being put in motion by the hand, (Ṣ,) or beneath the hand of him who put it in motion, (Ḳ,) or beneath the skin: (A:) or slipped about (tazal-aqat) between the skin and the flesh. (M.) And in like manner you say, daASati Als-amakapu fiI AlmaMCi [The fish glided about, to and fro, in the water]. (A.)
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. dayoSN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád,) He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) said of a groom. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)
And He (a man, TA) was, or became, low, or vile, after highness of rank or condition. (Ḳ.)
7. AndAS It (a thing) slipped out (Ainosal-a) from the hand. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
AndAS EalayonaA biXar-F (Ṣ, M, Ḳ *) He came upon us suddenly, or unawares, with evil, or mischief; syn. hajama, (M,) or faAjaOa. (Ḳ.)
dayoSN, (so in the TA,) or daASapN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) The motion of flight. (M, TA.) [See also 1, and see daAYiSN.]

hom.sense: daASapN: see dayoSN.
Also pl. of daAYiSN (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: diyowaSN, [so in the TA, but probably diy-awoSN, like its syn. dil-awoSN,] with kesr, That moves about. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

day-aASN A man over whom one cannot get power: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or strong in the muscles: (M:) or a man whom one cannot seize because of the strength of his muscles: (Aṣ, TA:) or a fat man: (Ḳ:) so it is said; and if it be correct, it is because, when he is seized, he slips away from the hand by reason of his abundance of flesh: (IF:) and with p {day-aASapN}, a fat woman: (TA:) or a woman bulky, (A,) or fleshy, (AA, Ḳ, TA,) and short, (AA, A, Ḳ, TA,) and that quivers, or quakes [by reason of her abundance of flesh]: (AA, A, TA:) or a fleshy woman: and a short woman. (CK.)
daAYiSN A thief: pl. daASapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
One who follows the magistrates, and goes round about a thing. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
The pl., mentioned above, also signifies Men who flee from war, or battle: or who put themselves in motion for flight. (TA.)
And The lowest or basest or meanest sort of mankind, or of people; because of their being much in commotion: (Kr, M:) one of such is termed daAYiSN. (M.)
madaASN A diving-place, or plunging-place, in water: (El-Moḥeeṭ, Ḳ:) a place in which fish go to and fro. (A.)

madiySN [app. A place where a person, or thing, declines; or turns aside, or from the right course or direction: a meaning which seems to be indicated in the Ṣ and TA]. A rájiz says,
Uin-a AljawaAda qado raOaI wabiySahaA
faOayonamaA daASato yadiSo madiySahaA
[Verily the courser has seen its glistening; and wheresoever it turns aside, he turns aside at its place of turning aside]. (Ṣ, TA.)

Uin-ahu lamunodaASN biAlX-ar-i (Ṣ, Ḳ) Verily he is one who comes suddenly, or unawares, [upon others] with evil, or mischief; one who is wont to make [others] fall [so I here render waq-aAEN] thereinto. (Ḳ.)
1. daAfahu, aor. yadiyfuhu, inf. n. dayofN: see 1 in art. dwf.
diko diko a cry used in chiding domestic cocks. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
diykN a word of well-known meaning, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) The domestic cock; i. e. the male of the dajaAj: (Mṣb, TA:) pl. (of mult. TA) diyakapN and duyuwkN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of pauc. TA) OadoyaAkN. (Ḳ.) Sometimes it is employed as meaning dajaAjapN, (Ḳ,) [which is a n. un., applied to the male and to the female,] and is therefore made [grammatically] fem., (TA,) [though still applying to the male, agreeably with a common license in the case of a masc. noun that has a fem. syn., and vice versa,] as in the saying,
dajaAjapN waz-aqati Ald-ayku biSawotK zaq-aA
[And the cock muted with a sound, with vehement muting]; (Ḳ;) because the dyk is also a dajaAjap: so says ISd. (TA.)
diyku Aljin-i [The cock of the jinn, or genii;] a certain little creeping thing, or insect, (duwayob-ap,) found in gardens. (Ḳzw.) And the surname of the poet ʼAbd-Es-Selám. (Ḳ.)

Solicitously affectionate; compassionate: (Ḳ:) or solicitously affectionate; affectionate to off spring; applied to a man, in the dial. of El-Yemen: so accord. to El-Muärrij; who says that hence the dyk [or domestic cock] is thus called. (TA.)
† The [season called] rabiyE [here meaning spring]; as though so called because of the various colours of its plants, or herbage, (Ḳ, TA,) and thus likened to the dyk [or domestic cock]. (TA.)
One, and all, of the three stones on which the cooking-pot is placed: used alike as sign. and pl. (El-Muärrij, Ḳ.)
The protuberant bone behind the ear of the horse: (Ḳ:) IKh explains it as meaning a certain bone behind the ear; not particularizing a horse nor any other animal. (IB.)

entry.sense: [diykapN is said by Golius, as on the authority of the Ḳ, in which it is not found, to be sometimes used as signifying A domestic hen.]
OaroDN madaAkapN and mudaAkapN and madiykapN↓ A land abounding with diyakap [or domestic cocks]. (Ḳ.)
OaroDN madiykapN: see what next precedes.
1. daAmati Als-amaMCu, aor. tadiymu, inf. n. dayomN: see 1 in art. dwm.
2. day-amati Als-amaMCu and day-amuwA said of horses: see 1 in art. dwm, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places.
maA zaAlati Als-amaMCu dayomFA dayomFA: see dawomN, in art. dwm.
diymN: see diymapN.
diymapN: see art. dwm.
dayomuwmN and dayomuwmapN: see arts. dm and dwm.
day-awmN: see daAYimN, in art. dwm.
OaroDN madiymapN and muday-amapN: see art. dwm.

hom.sense: 1. daAna, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. yadiynu, (IAạr, M, Ḳ, TA,) [inf. n. diynN, (which see below,) in this and most of the other senses, or the inf. n. is dayonN, and diynN is a simple subst.,] He was, or became, obedient; he obeyed: (IAạr, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA:) this is the primary signification: or, as some say, the primary signification is the following; namely, he was, or became, abased and submissive: (IAạr,* Ḳ,* TA:) or he was, or became, abased and enslaved and obedient. (Ṣ.) You say, daAna lahu, (Ṣ,) and dinotu lahu and dinotuhu, (M, TA,) He, and I, was, or became, obedient to him [&c.], or obeyed him [&c.]. (Ṣ, M, TA.) And dinotuhu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. Oadiynuhu, (Ḳ,) I served him, did service for him, or ministered to him, and acted well to him. (M, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] He became [a servant of God, or] a Muslim. (TḲ.) You say, daAna biQloUisolaAmi, inf. n. diynN, with kesr, [and diyaAnapN,] He became, or made himself, a servant of God by [following the religion of] El-Islám; [i. e. he followed El-Islám as his religion;] and so tdy-n↓. (Mṣb.) And daAna bikacA, (Ṣ,) and dinotu bihi, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. diyaAnapN [and diynN]; and tdy-n↓ bh, [and tdy-ntu bh; He, and I, followed such a thing as his, and my, religion;] (Ṣ, TA;) from diynN as signifying “obedience.” (Ṣ.) And dAn bidiynihimo He followed them in their religion; agreed with them, or was of one mind or opinion with them, upon, or respecting, their religion; took, or adopted, their religion as his. (TA.) And the trad. of ʼAlee, maHab-apu AlEulamaMCu diynN yudaAnu Qll-ehu bihi [The love of the learned is a kind of religion with which God is served]. (TA.) In the phrase walaA yadiynuwna diyna AlHaq-i [Nor follow the religion of the truth, or the true religion], in the Ḳur ix. 29, El-Islám is meant. (Jel.)

Also He was, or became, disobedient; he disobeyed: and he was, or became, mighty, potent, powerful, or strong; or high, or elevated, in rank, condition, or state; noble, honourable, glorious, or illustrious. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.) Thus it bears significations contr. to those mentioned in the first part of this paragraph. (MF.)

Also, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) first pers. dinotu, (T, M8gh,) aor. as above, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. dayonN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) from AlmudaAyanapu, (Mṣb, [see 3,]) i. q. Oaxaca Ald-ayona, (IḲt, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or [rather] Oaxaca dayonFA, (T,) [He took, or received, a loan, or the like; he borrowed: or he took, or received, or bought, upon credit; which is the meaning generally obtaining:] and Aid-aAna↓ and OadaAna↓ and AstdAn↓ and tdy-n↓ signify [in like manner] Oaxaca dayonFA: (Ḳ:) or the first, i. e. dAn, signifies he sought, or demanded, a loan, or the like; (ISk, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also Ad-An↓ and AstdAn↓: (Ṣ, Mgh:) and he became indebted, in debt, or under the obligation of a debt: (Ṣ:) and Ad-An↓ and OadaAna↓ and AstdAn↓ signify Oaxaca bidayonK [he took, or received, by incurring a debt; i. e. he took, or received, or bought, upon credit; like Oaxaca dayonFA]; (M;) or the first and last of these three signify Oaxaca Ald-ayona, and AiqotaraDa [which means the same]: but OadaAna↓ signifies he gave, or granted, what is termed dayonN [meaning a loan, or the like: or he gave, or granted, or sold, a thing upon credit]: (TA:)
accord. to Esh-Sheybánee, this last verb signifies he became entitled to a debt from others [or from another]: Lth says that it (OadaAna) signifies he was, or became, such as is termed musotadiynN; [i. e. it is syn. with AstdAn, as it is said to be in the M and Ḳ;] but [Az says,] this, which has been mentioned on the authority of some one or more by Sh, is in my opinion a mistake; OadaAna means he sold upon credit; or became entitled to a debt from others [or from another]; (T, TA;) or he sold to persons upon a limited credit, or for payment at an appointed period, so that he became entitled to a debt from them: (Ṣ:) and accord. to Sh, Ad-An↓ signifies he became much in debt. (T, TA.) El-Aḥmar cites the following verse of El-ʼOjeyr Es-Saloolee:
nadiynu wayaqoDiI Qll-ehu Ean-aA waqado naraI
maSaAriEa qawomN laA yadiynuwna Duy-aEi
[We incur debt, and God pays for us; and sometimes, or often, we see the places of overthrow of a people, who incur not debt, in a state of perdition]: in the Ṣ [and the T] Duy-aEaA; but correctly as above; for the whole of the qaSiydap is maxofuwDap. (IB, TA.) And it is said in a trad., Aid-aAna↓ muEoriDFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, as some relate it, daAna, (Ḳ,) He bought upon credit, or borrowed, or sought or demanded a loan, of whomsoever he could, addressing himself to such as came in his way: (Ṣ, TA:) or both mean he bought upon credit avoiding payment: or he contracted a debt with every one who presented himself to him: (Ḳ, TA: [see also other explanations voce muEoriDN:]) Ad-An↓ signifies he bought upon credit: (Ḳ:) or [thus and also] the contr., i. e. he sold upon credit. (T, Ḳ.)

It is also trans.; and so is OadaAna↓. (Mṣb.) You say, dinotuhu, (M, Mgh, Ḳ, [in the CK diynapN is here put for dinotuhu,]) inf. n. dayonN; (TA;) and Oadanotuhu↓ (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. UidaAnapN; (TA;) I gave him, or granted him, to a certain period, what is termed dayonN [meaning the loan, or the like; I lent to him: or I gave him, or granted him, credit; or sold to him, upon credit]: (M, Ḳ, TA:) so that he owed a debt: (TA:) and i. q. OaqoraDotuhu [I gave him, or granted him, a loan, or the like]; (M,* Mgh, Ḳ;) as also day-anotuhu↓: (Mgh:) or dinotuhu has this last meaning: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M:) and Oadanotuhu↓ signifies I sought, or demanded, of him a loan, or the like; syn. AisotaqoraDotu minohu; as also Aisotadanotuhu↓: (M:) or dinotuhu has each of the last two meanings: (AʼObeyd, T, Mṣb:) and signifies also I received from him a loan, or the like. (Ḳ.) And one says, Oadin-iI↓ EaXarapa daraAhima meaning Lend thou to me ten dirhems. (Ṣ, TA.)

dAnhu, (Ṣ,) first pers. dinotuhu, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. diynN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and dayonN, (M, Ḳ,) or the latter is the inf. n. and the former is a simple subst., (M,) also signifies He repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, him, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) bifiEolihi for his deed: and so dAynhu↓, inf. n. mudaAyanapN and diyaAnN. (M.) And din-aAhumo We did to them like as they did to us. (Ḥam p. 10.) One says, kamaA tadiynu tudaAnu, (T, Ṣ, M,) a prov., (M,) meaning Like as thou repayest, or requitest,, &c., thou shalt be repaid, or requited,, &c.; (Ṣ, M;) i. e. according to thy deed thou shalt be repaid, or requited,, &c.: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, like as thou doest, it shall be done to thee: (M:) or like as thou doest thou shalt be given, and repaid,, &c. (T.) And it is said in a trad., Aall-ehum-a dinohumo kamaA yadiynuwnanaA, meaning O God, repay them, or requite them,, &c., with [the like of] that which they do to us. (TA.)
Aall-ehu layadiynu mina Aljam--aMCi liloqaronaMCi, a trad. of Selmán, means God will assuredly retaliate [for her that is hornless upon her that is horned]. (TA.)
And one says, mano daAna nafosahu rabiHa, i. e. He who reckons with himself [gains] (Ḥam p. 10. [Or the verb may here have the meaning next following.])

Also, dAnhu, He abased him, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and enslaved him. (T, Ṣ.) Hence, (T,) it is said in a trad., Alkay-isu mano daAna nafosahu waEamila limaA baEoda Almawoti, (Ṣ, T,) i. e. [The intelligent is] he who abases, and enslaves, himself [and works for that which shall be after death]: or, as some say, who reckons with himself: (T:) or, accord. to some, who overcomes himself. (TA.) And dAnhu, (Ḳ,) first pers. dinotuhu, (T,) signifies He made him to do that which he disliked. (AZ, T, Ḳ.) And diyna He was made to do that which he disliked. (T.)
And dinotuhu, inf. n. diynN, I ruled, governed, or managed, him, or it. (M, TA.) And I possessed it; owned it; or exercised, or had, authority over it. (Sh, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

dAn, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) aor. yadiynN, (Ḳ,) [inf. n., app., diynN, which see below,] signifies also He became accustomed or habituated, or he accustomed or habituated himself, to good or to evil: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) and, accord. to Lth, (T,) diyna signifies he was accustomed or habituated: (T, M:) or, as some say, diynN signifying “custom,” or “habit,” has no verb. (M.)
And He (a man, IAạr, T) was, or became, smitten, or affected, by a disease. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.)

2. dy-nhu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tadoyiynN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He left him to his religion; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) left him and his religion, not opposing him in that which he held allowable in his belief. (Mṣb.)

He believed him: so in the saying, dy-nhu fiI AlqaDaMCi [He believed him in respect of the judgment, or judicial decision], (T, M, Mgh,*) and fiymaA bayonahu wabayona Qll-eha [in respect of what was between him and God]: (T, M:) but this is a conventional signification used by the professors. (Mgh.)

day-anotu AlHaAlifa (T, TA) I confirmed the swearer (qaw-ayotuhu [so in the TA, but in the T bar-ayotuhu, app. for bar-aOotuhu, I held him, or pronounced him, to be clear, or quit, if not a mistranscription for qaw-ayotuhu,]) in that which he swore. (T, TA.)
See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

day-anotuhu Alqawoma I made him ruler, governor, or manager of the affairs, of the people, or company of men. (M.) And dy-nhu AlX-aIoCa, (T,* TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made him to possess the thing: to own it; or to exercise, or have, authority over it. (T,* TA.) El-Hotei-ah says, (T, Ṣ, M,) addressing his mother, (T,)
laqado duy-inoti Oamora baniyki Hat-aI
tarakotihimu Oadaq-a mina AlT-aHiyni , (T, Ṣ, M,) meaning mul-ikoti [i. e. Verily thou hast been made to have the ordering of the affairs of thy sons until thou hast rendered them finer than flour]. (T, Ṣ.) And hence the saying, yuday-anu Alr-ajulu Oamorahu i. e. yumal-aku [The man shall be made to have the ordering of his affair, or affairs, or case]. (Sh, T.)

3. daAyanotuhu, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. mudaAyanapN and diyaAnN, (TA,) I dealt, or bought and sold, with him upon credit; (A, TA;) I dealt, or sold and bought, with him, giving upon credit and taking upon credit: (Ṣ, TA:) or I lent to him; or I gave him, or granted him, a loan, or the like; and he did so to me: (M, Ḳ:) or I dealt with him upon credit, giving or taking. (Ksh * and Bḍ in ii. 282.)
See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
Each of the inf. ns. mentioned above is also syn. with muHaAkamapN [The summoning another to the judge, and litigating with him:, &c.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AdAn, inf. n. UidaAnapN; as an intrans. v.: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in three places.
As a trans. v.: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in four places.

[The following significations, namely, “Subegit,” and “Pensavit,” assigned to this verb by Golius as on the authority of the KL, and “Voluit sibi esse servum,” and “Servum cepit,” followed by an accus., assigned to it by him as on the authority of the Ṣ, I do not find in either of those works.]
5. tdy-n: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in three places.

6. tadaAyanuwA They sold and bought, one with another, upon credit; and in like manner tadaAyanaA is said of two persons: (Ṣ:) or they took, or received, or bought, upon credit [app. one of another]: and so Aid-aAyanuwA [which is a variation of the former]. (M.) UicaA tadayanotumo bidayonK, in the Ḳur ii. 282, means When ye deal, one with another, (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel, Mṣb,) upon credit, giving or taking, (Ksh,* Bḍ,) or by prepayment, (Jel, Mṣb,) or lending or the like, (Jel,), &c. (Mṣb.)
8. Aid-aAna, originally AidotaAna: see 1, in six places.
10. AstdAn, as an intrans. v.: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in three places.
AstdAnhu He sought, or demanded, of him what is termed dayonN [meaning a debt]: and also i. q. AisotaqoraDa minohu. (M.) See 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
dayonN [is an inf. n. of 1:]

[and is also a simple subst., and] properly signifies [A debt; such as] the price of a thing sold [which the purchaser is under an obligation to pay]; and a dowry [which one engages to pay]: and a loan, or the like; syn. qaroD: (Mṣb:) or it is [a debt] such as has an appointed time of falling due: what has not such an appointed time is [properly, but not always,] termed qaroDN: (Ḳ:)
and diynapN↓ signifies the same as dayonN (T, M, Ḳ) in the sense above explained: (Ḳ:) a valid dayno (daynN SaHiyHN) is such as does not become annulled save by payment, or by one's being declared clear, or quit: compensation in the case of a contract which a slave makes with his owner to pay him a certain sum as the price of himself and on the payment thereof to be free is not a valid dayon, because it may become annulled without payment, and without his being declared clear, or quit; that is, by the slave's being unable to pay it: (KT:) in the language of the law, but not in the proper language, dayonN is also applied to † [a debt incurred by] a thing taken unjustly, injuriously, or by violence; as being likened to a dayon properly so called: (Mṣb:) and it signifies also anything that is not present: [app. meaning anything to be paid, or done, at a future time:] (M, Ḳ:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OadoyunN (Lḥ, M, Ḳ) and [of mult.] duyuwnN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) [and in the CK is added and diynapN, with kesr; but this is a mistranscription for dinotuhu, as syn. with Oadanotuhu, which follows it, connected therewith by wa]: the pl. of diynapN↓ is diyanN. (TA.) You say, maA Oakovra dayonahu and diynatahu↓ [How great in amount. is his debt!]; both meaning the same. (AZ, T.) And jiYotu liTalabi Ald-iynapi↓ i. e. Ald-ayoni [I came for the demanding of the debt]. (AZ, T.) And Ealayohi dayonN [On him lies a debt; i. e. he owes a debt]: and lahu dayonN [To him is due a debt; i. e. he has a debt owed to him]. (Ṣ, TA.) And AiXotaraI biAld-ayoni [He bought upon credit]: (Ḳ:) and Oaxaca Ald-ayona (IḲt, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) or [rather] Oaxaca dayonFA [signifies the same; or he took, or received, upon credit: or he took, or received, a loan, or the like; he borrowed]: (T, Ḳ:) and Oaxaca bidayonK [likewise signifies the same; or he took, or received, by incurring a debt]. (M.) And baAEa biAld-ayoni [He sold upon credit]: (Ḳ:) and biEovuhu bidayonK (TA) or bidiynapK↓ (Ṣ) [I sold to him upon credit]: and OaEoTayotuhu Ald-ayona [signifies the same; or I gave him, or granted him, credit: or I gave him, or granted him, the loan, or the like]. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence,] ‡ Death; (Ḳ, TA;) because it is a dayon [or debt] which every one must pay when [the angel who is] the demander of its payment comes. (TA.) And hence the prov., ramaAhu Qll-ehu bidayonihi ‡ [May God smite him with his death]. (TA.)

Thaalebeh Ibn-ʼObeyd says, describing palm-trees,
taDam-anu AlHaAjaAti AlEiyaAli waDayofihimo
wamahomaA taDam-ano mino duyuwnihimo taqoDi
[They comprise the wants of the household and of their guest; and whatever they comprise of their debts, they pay]; by the duyuwn meaning what is obtained of their fruit that is gathered. (M, TA.)
